title: Jonathan Bernstein, Film Editor, Weds Meredith Ellen Goodman
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 30 Miss Meredith Ellen Good man, who is with, the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission in New York, was married here this after noon to Jonathan Bernstein, a film editor.

title: Levitt Calls Lindsay Low on Estimates
description: State Controller Arthur Lev itt said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay was underestimating revenues for the, new city bud get by at least $145million.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOCIALISM. Ely Michael Harrington. 436 pages. Saturday Review Press, $12.50.

title: Vatican Unveils 4thCentury Fragment of the Gospel
description: ROME, April 30The Pontifi cal Bible Institute today pre sented a newly deciphered pa pyrus with a significant pas sage from the Gospel of St. Mark.

title: Personal Finance: CreditCard Bill
description: This is the first of two articles about Senate Bill S652 to strengthen con sumers' rights in the area of personal credit.

title: Light Vote Due Tomorrow In the District of Columbia
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)All indications point to a light turnout Tuesday in the primary of the District of Co lumbia, where local races abound and no major Presiden tial candidate has entered the race.

title: Apollo Men Spend a Full Day on Land
description: HOUSTON, April 30 The Apollo 16 astronauts today spent their first full day on land since their mission. Their hearts and other organs con tinued to readjust to the grav ity of earth after 11 days spent partly in the weightlessness of space and partly on the moon, where the gravity is onesixth that of earth.

title: Percy Criticizes Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, criticized President Nixon's bombing policy and said the Administration could again cite the need to protect United States troops as an excuse for more attacks.

title: Coming Clean
description: Law enforcement is at its best when it makes the punishment fit the crime, preferably by giving the cul prit a chance to erase the evil consequences of his mis deeds. In a literal interpretation of the act of erasure, Family Court Judge Shirley Kram recently sentenced two teenaged boys, who had been caught defacing the walls of a subway station, to some early preschool hours of environmental field work. The youngsters had to remove graffiti, including their own, from the under ground gallery at 157th Street and Broadway.

title: The Talk of Breaux Bridge, La.
description: BREAUX BRIDGE, La., April 30La Poussiere is a dance hall at the edge of town. To understand what is happening in Breaux Bridge this weekend, one must un derstand La Poussiere.

title: Nixon Has Suggestion For Finley: Pay Vida
description: FLORESVILLE, Tex., April 30 (UPI)  President Nixon today suggested that the Oakland Athletics' owner, Charles O. Finley, agree to contract terms demanded by his holdout star, Vida Blue.

title: Excerpts From Rockefeller Testimony in Attica Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from the 83page transcript of Governor Rockefeller's testimony before the McKay Commission. The first four segments are from the Gov ernor's introductory state ment.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Whatever comfort the fash ion business has derived in the last year has been from the popularity of sportswear. Women who couldn't quite bring themselves to buy a dress or a coat were tempted by a skirt or a pair of pants. Anne Klein, Bill Blass and Kasper are among the houses that scored significantly with their sportswear collections. By next fall, of course, there will be more.

title: CASPER, WITH 202, LEADS AT DALLAS
description: DALLAS, April 30  I feel like I can play, Billy Casper said today after retaining his onestroke lead in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic with a thirdround 69 that brought his 54hole total to 202.

title: Miss Ciraulo Bows As Refreshing Butterfly
description: The City Opera introduced new Madame Butterfly at the State Theater Saturday night, as the Puccini favorite was given for the last time this season.

title: Nixon Was Right, Dole Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 30, (Reuters)  Senator Robert J. Dole, chairman of the Republi can National Committee, said today that he believed Presi dent Nixon did the right thing in resuming the bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Cornell Squatters Dwindle; Serving of Papers Delayed
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 30 (AP) Antiwar protesters occupied the Cornell University engineer ing administration building for the fifth day today to dramatize their demands for an end to the Reserve Officers Training Corps and warrelated research at the campus.

title: Fast Return to Lineup Vowed by DeBusschere
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 30Discouraged and yet de fiant, Dave DeBusschere pre dicted today his return to the New York Knicks' lineup for the third game of the Na tional Basketball Association championship playoff in New York on Wednesday.

title: The Radical, Sophisticated Right
description: There must be a radical redefinition of the terms of debate over America's social and economic policy. One reason is that conservatism is now located, in the conventional vocabulary at least, not simply to the left of Adam Smith, but of John Maynard Keynes as well.

title: Stage:
description: Although Jane Trahey is an enormously successful ad woman, her play Ring Round the Bathtub is not, as one might expect from the title, about advertising sloganeering. The play, which opened Saturday at the Mar tin Beck, has nothing to do with advertising or even with bathtubsalthough it has a scrubbed, wholesome shine to it.

title: 3 Journalism Awards Are Won by Reporters
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)  Two Washington re porters and one from Min neapolis were named yester day as the winners of three journalism awards at the 58th annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Asso ciation.

title: Wrecking U.S.I.A.
description: There is a strong probability that Senator William Fulbright and his Democratic colleagues on the Foreign Relations Committee will miss the target in their cam paign to redirect the energies of the United States Infor mation Agency. The committee has voted to reduce the U.S.I.A.'s budget request by nearly 25 per cent, from $200 million to $155 million.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Several top city officials, including two members of Mayor Lindsay's inner sanc tum who often act as his spokesmen, have taken each other to lunch and, saying that they discussed city busi ness, billed the city for their meals. The result: Controller Abraham D. Beame disallowed their vouch ers, sent back the tabs for personal payment and be gan circulating among all cityemployes a pocketsized guidebook on allowable ex penses.

title: ExAntitrust Chief Reported to Have Told Of Plan to See White House on I.T.T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Richard W. McLaren, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Antitrust Divi sion, told a subordinate two days before the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration acquired the Canteen Corporation in 1969 that he was going to the White House to discuss the case, according to a reliable source close to the case.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN SUFFOLK RAPE
description: A Suffolk County patrolman early yesterday, recognizing an auto parked in an isolated sec tion of Wyandanch as one wanted in connection with the kidnaping of an 18yearold Brooklyn girl, captured 29year old Ralph Hogan of North Amityville, LI., who, the police said, was holding an 18year old rapekidnap victim at gun point in the car.

title: Laver Outplays Riessen in Net Final
description: DENVER, April 30 (AP) Rod Laver of Australia, having problems with his first serve but hitting his usual superb placement and passing shots, fought back today to defeat Marty Riessen, 4.6, 6.3, 64, and win the $50,000 United Bank Classic, a part of the World Championship Tennis tour.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox Suit Accuses Litton Of Infringement on Patents
description: The Xerox Corporation of Stamford, Conn., has filed a lawsuit in Manhattan Federal Court accusing Litton Indus tries, Inc., of Elmsford, N. Y., of patent infringement involv ing aspects of office copying machines.

title: 76Acre Americana Museum on Cape Cod Grows
description: SANDWICH, Mass, April 30Heritage Plantation, one of the country's youngest museums, will open its fifth building here tomorrow, ex pinding its collections of Americana at a time when most museum construction is at a standstill and deficits have hindered many services.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A M.A.URGES DELAY ON TESTTUBE BABY
description: The American Medical Asso ciation has called for a mora torium on experiments that would seek to implant a test tube baby into the womb of a woman.

title: ENGINEERS EYING HELP FROM UNIONS
description: ATLANTIC CITY. April 29 Many engineers and other well paid professionals buffeted by massive layoffs in the aero space industry are beginning to look to unions for protection. Many have swallowed their professional pride and are look ing for ways to affiliate with unions such as the United Auto mobile Workers so they can get some of the same protection as production workers.

title: Foe Captures 2 Positions in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 30 (UPI)South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops gave up the village of Bavet and the border stronghold of Kompong Trach today, leaving the pro vincial capital at Svayrieng iso lated along a Communistcon trolled 60mile stretch of high way.

title: Betty Garner Married to a Major
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 30Miss Betty Sue Garner of New York was married here this afternoon to Maj. Robert Cooper Carroll, U.S.A. The Rev. Robert F. McCor mick performed the cere mony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity.

title: ALICHUVALO BOUT WEIGHTY MATTER
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, April 30  At what, should be his lightest weight since his return in 1970 from a 3%year exile, Muhammad Ali will op pose George Chuvalo of Cana da tomorrow night in a 12 round heavyweight bout that will be seen worldwide, includ ing six New York area closedcircuit television loca tions.

title: PRICE RULING FOUGHT BY CONTINENTAL CAN
description: Robert S. Hatfield, chairman of the Continental Can Com pany, said yesterday that the information on which the Price Commission decided last week to suspend a 4.2 per cent in crease in prices previously granted to the company was inaccurate.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TOKYO, April 30 (AP)Ja pan won the doubles against Australia, today to reduce the Aussies' lead to 21 in the East ern Zone A Davis Cup compe tition.

title: Governor Explains Attica Role
description: Governor Rockefeller's de cision not to go to Attica during the prison rebellion there was based on both his philosophic belief that elected officials should not negotiate under the pressure of crimi nal acts and his view that his presence at the prison would not serve in a practical way to break the deadlock between the state and rebel inmates.

title: EILEEN FARRELL IN SONG PROGRAM
description: Since Eileen Farrell's voice was one of the great musical instruments produced in the United States in the years im mediately after World War II, it is an object of national pride, and one always welcomes the opportunity to hear it again.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS MEET SQUIRES, IN COLISEUM TONIGHT
description: The Nets, who trail the Vir ginia Squires, three games to two, in their fourofseven se ries for the championship of the American. Basketball Asso ciation Eastern Division, will attempt to avert elimination tonight at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I.

title: QUEENS MAN SLAIN IN GANGLAND STYLE
description: The body of a man shot six times in the back of the head and neck was found Saturday night in a car in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police reported yesterday.

title: Man, 21, Dies in Raft Trip On the Upper Hudson River
description: NORTH RIVER, N. Y., April 30 (AP)A New York City man died today on a raft trip with a companion through the rapids of the upper Hudson River near this Warren County community, according to the state police.

title: WILLIAM F. GIESEN OF MARITIME UNIT
description: William F. Giesen, a lawyer and general manager of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York from 1949 until his retirement April 1, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while driving near his home, 507 Hunt Lane, Man hasset. L.I. He was 56 years old.

title: Gardner Securities Corp. Is Expelled From N.A.S.D.
description: The expulsion of the Gardner Securities Corporation of New York City from the National Association of Securities Deal ers, Inc., was announced during the weekend by the selfregula tory organization for the over thecounter securities markets.

title: Sports of The Times
description: To paraphrase the finest of turf writers, Joe H. Palmer: Four springs ago two men, not now identified, laid plans which are about to come to fruition. One was planning the mating that produced the horse that will win the 98th Kentucky Derby. The other was lighting a fire under the mash at the BrownForman distillery. Strength to them both.

title: Final Playoffs On in Hockey and Basketball; Rangers and Knicks Lose
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 30 Unable to survive the loss of Dave DeBusschere, who pulled a muscle in his right side late in the second quarter, and out played in some respects as well, the New York Knicks were beaten by the Los Angeles Lakers today, 10692.

title: Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, 83, Civic and Social Leader, Dies
description: Mrs. Harriet Alexander Aldrich, a leader in civic, phil anthropic and social activities here for many years and an aunt of Governor Rockefeller, died yesterday in a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn., aft er a long illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 960 Fifth Avenue.

title: Youths March to Aid Poor
description: Thousands of young people yesterday walked for distances of up to 30 miles in the metro politan area, to raise funds for antipoverty programs in the United States and abroad. The Walk for Development, as it was called, was one of hundreds sponsored by Young World De velopment, an organization af filiated with the American Free dom from Hunger Foundation.

title: TRIAL TOMORROW TO CUT DERBY LIST
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 The decisive victories regis tered by Riva Ridge and Hold Your Peace in their recent out ings have failed to cause wholesale withdrawals from the ranks of probable starters in Saturday's Kentucky Der by. Indeed, far from being whittled, the list of candidates for the 98th running of the race over a mile and one quarter for 3yearolds was expanded by two today.

title: Port Unit Weighs Doubling Tolls On Its Six Bridges and Tunnels
description: The Port of New York Au thority is considering doubling the $1 roundtrip tolls on its six bridges and tunnels in order to raise money for mass transit, according to Andrew C. Axtell, a Commissioner of the bistate agency.

title: Tanzania to Get 12 MIG's From China Late in 1973
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 30Tanzania is to re ceive at least 12 Chinesebuilt MIG jet fighters late next year, the Chief of Defense Forces, Maj. Gen. M. S. H. Sarakikya, said here today.

title: Chinese Leave the U.S. Alter Table Tennis Tour
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (UPI)China's table ten nis team, which spent more time playing tourist than ta ble tennis during a 19day visit, left the United States today with memories of a warm and friendly wel some.

title: ROGERS DEFENDS BOMBING POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the bombing of targets around Hanoi and Haiphong had weak ened the North Vietnamese mil itary effort in South Vietnam.

title: Curb on Profits Dispiriting Many Businessmen
description: Many of the nation's busi nessmen are seriously con cerned about a recent crack down on corporate profits by the Nixon Administration, ac cording to an informal national survey.

title: POLICE ARE URGED TO SHIFT WHITES
description: About 5,000 blacks gathered in a Harlem armory yesterday and demonstrated their support for a Black Muslim demand that all white policemen in Harlem be replaced by re educated black policemen.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Three week after the new Federal campaign spending law went into effect, officials here say that enforcement of the key disclosure provisions of the law is enmeshed in con fusion.

title: Judith E. Kahan, Actress, Is Bride Of J. M. Forster
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., April 30Miss Judith Ellen Kahan, an actress, and John Marshall Forster, a composer and arranger, were married at noon today at the home here of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kahan, by State Supreme Court Justice Paul Widlitz. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam H. Forster of Brussels and Philadelphia.

title: Tho Seems to Ease Hanoi's Terms a Bit
description: PARIS, April 30Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Vietnamese Politburo, returned from Hanoi today and said that he was here to negotiate with the United States for a just and equitable peaceful solution to the Vietnamese problem.

title: Grand Jury System Is Assailed Here
description: Prof. Samuel Popkin of Har vard was there, recounting his experiences before the Boston grand jury that is looking into the case surrounding public disclosure of the contents of the Pentagon papers. It was a humiliation, he said, and a fishing expedition, with the prosecutor twisting each of Mr. Popkin's answers and even his refusals to answer.

title: Central Park Buffs Mark Designer's Birthday
description: They celebrated Frederick Law Olmsted's 150th birth day in Central Park yester day with incense, Frisbees, bagels, balloons, Ices, franks, transistor radios, nearnude sunbathing and a Free Pot! parade.

title: Joyous Rock Style Of Three Dog Night At Nassau Coliseum
description: The choice of Three Dog Night as Saturday night's in augural rock act at Nassau County's bright, shiny new Coliseum in Uniondale was ex cellent. The groupactually three singers backed by a four piece rhythm sectionis a clas sic Top 40 act, a guaranteed hit producer, and a powerful favorite with the mass of young people who fill the thousands of seats at New York's many pop music programs.

title: Merle Park Gives Added Clarity To Royal Ballet's Juliet at Met
description: The kind of superb total per formance one expects from the Royal Ballet was provided Sat urday night by Merle Park as Juliet in Kenneth MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Ethel Waters Is Honored
description: CHESTER, Pa., April 30 (AP) Pennsylvania paid tribute to the singer Ethel Waters today, naming the day in her honor. The 74yearold singer returned to her home town to serve as grand marshal for the city's Law Day Parade.

title: Thieu Links Survival To Outcome of Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (UPI)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said to day in a May Day address to the nation that the out come of the enemy offensive would decide the country's survival and that Govern ment troops must fight on despite the costs.

title: A Quota by Any Other Name
description: When the Democratic party assem bles in Miami Beach in July, it is all too possible that it will plunge into an ordeal worse than the primaries which, to borrow a phrase from Lewis Carroll, are turning out to be an Agony in Twentythree Fits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Is Becoming Drug Traffic Center
description: MIAMI, April 30Enterpris ing Frenchmen, South Ameri cans, Puerto Ricans and Cuban refugees are turning southern Florida into the premier Ameri can entry point for smuggled heroin and cocaine.

title: JAMES J. RATTRAY
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 30 James J. Rattray, president since 1969 of HoffmanTaff, Inc., a local division of Syntex Laboratories, Inc., which makes premixes for animal nutrition and bulk pharmaceuticals, died here yesterday at the age of 50.

title: Kissinger Reported in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 30A White House spokesman, after checking with Mr. Kissinger's staff, said that Mr. Kissinger was in Washington today.

title: Candidate in Utah Hikes 689 Miles in Vote Hunt
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 30 (UPI)  Wayne Owens, who is seeking the Demo cratic nomination in Utah's Second Congressional District, says he has more ground to cover after completing a 689 mile hike across the district.

title: Miss Gengler Victor
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., April 30Marjorie Gengler of Prince ton won the Middle States' women's intercollegiate tennis championship by routing Me linda Williams of West Chester State, 60, 60, in the final to day.

title: U.S. General Says Situation at Quangtri Is Tenuous
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 30As South Vietnamese ma rines battled unsuccessfully to open the road to Quangtri, the northernmost town still in Gov ernment hands, an American general here painted a pessi mistic picture of the deteriorat ing northern front.

title: Four Ailey Specials Set.
description: The City Center will present four special daytime perform ances of the Alvin Ailey Amer ican Dance Theater at its 55th Street theater on Thursday and Friday as part of its Senior Citizen and OnSchoolTime programs. Senior citizens may obtain reserved seats at $1 and $1.50 for a performance at 1:30 P.M. both days. There will be a 10 A.M. performance both days for students at $1 a ticket.

title: PAKISTAN, INDIA AGREE ON AGENDA
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 30A 17man Indian delegation left Pakistan today after four days of negotiations with Paki stani officials to decide on an agenda for talks between Presi dent Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Rounqup: Braves Keep Slump Alive, 61
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates be came the champions of base ball last season by dethron ing the Baltimore Orioles in the World Series, but the Bucs currently, are perform ing like a team with no mem ory of its winning capabil ities.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 30 (AP)Erik Van Dillon of Los Angeles won the final in the $10,000 Royal Crown tourna ment today, defeating Gene Scott of New York, 7.6, 63, for the $4,000 first prize.

title: Mill Reef 10Length Victor In $160,000 Prix Ganay
description: PARIS, April 30  Paul Mel lon's 4yearold champion, Mill Reef, demonstrated his class as a thoroughbred again today in winning the $160,000 Prix Gan ay by 10 lengths from the rest of the field of 12 horses.

title: GODFREY CLOSES CAREER ON RADIO
description: The voice of Arthur Godfrey, a fixture on network radio for 27 years, went off the air yes terday a few seconds before 2 P.M. as the entertainer closed out a broadcasting career that spanned the major part of the history of commercial broad casting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Runaways Can Find a Haven
description: First there is Chris, a small, nervous, bespectacled boy from New Jersey whose drunken father grabbed a rifle one night and threatened to annihilate his entire family.

title: WORKERS IN PERU NOW THE BOSSES
description: CARTAVIO, Peru, April 26 Roger Aguilar, the son and grandson of canecutting plan tation laborers and himself a canecutter foreman, stopped the other day on his way into the mansion from which an American company once ran a small sugar empire here.

title: 2 DANCES PORTRAY LIFE AND BEHAVIOR
description: Two concerts on Saturday had stirrings of ideas and then allowed them to escape with out being realized. Rod Rodg ers offered the premiere of In HiRise Shadows at Clark Center in the afternoon and Barbara Lloyd presented The Natural History of The Ameri can Dancer at the Whitney Museum in the evening.

title: Mrs. Sidney Newborg, 80, A Founder of Women's Club
description: Mrs. Agnes Newborg, a founder of the Women's City Club of New York in 1915, died Friday in New York Hospital of injuries from having been struck by an automobile Thurs day. She was 80 years old and lived at 310 East 70th Street.

title: Economist Urges Caution Past Bullish Short Term
description: Shortterm defensive but longterm bullish. That's the current attitude of many an alysts toward the stock mar ket. But a different view is Laken by Peter L. Bernstein, 53, a highly respected econ omist whose first published article on growth companies appeared in 1956 in The Har vard Business Review. Today, Mr. Bernstein serves as chair man of BernsteinMacaulay, Inc., the investment manage ment subsidiary of CBWL Hayden. Stone, Inc. He is also a senior vice president of the parent concern. Mr. Bernstein outlined his views in an in terview last week with Vat. tanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Some of his comments follow:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ROME, April 30 (UPI)The remaining three seeded players at the 29th Italian tennis championships advanced to the semifinals today.

title: Senator Questions Effects Of Health Insurance Rivalry
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)  Senator Philip A. Hart said today that competition in the health insurance industry seems to be working in a manner to illservice consum ers.

title: 7 Nuns Arrested In Antiwar Protest Inside St. Patrick's
description: After receiving communion at the altar, 12 nunssome wearing white sheets with the legend One more person dead in Indochinalay down in the aisles of St. Patrick's Cathedral during the morning service yesterday.

title: A WINNING CARMEN SUNG BY CITY OPERA
description: The City Opera has finally found a Carmen that measures up to the role. Gwendolyn Kil lebrew, who sang the part for the second time with the com pany at yesterday's matinee, is still developing  a few un focused dramatic and vocal edges need to be sharpened out but she already fulfills vir tually every major requirement.

title: BRANDEIS AWARDS GIVEN IN 4 FIELDS
description: Artists with full lifetimes of accomplishment to their credit and younger artists still in mid career were honored last night with encomiums and $1,000 cash at the 16th annual presen tation of the Brandeis Univer sity Creative Arts Awards.

title: Arts Abroad
description: ROMEThe boxoffice rat ings for Federico Fellini's longawaited Roma are ex cellent throughout Italy, but the reviews are lukewarm at best. And Romans have a hard time recognizing their city and themselves in the twohour footage.

title: Columbia and Protesters Meet and Trade Demands
description: Representatives of Columbia University and scores of dem onstrators barricaded in Hamil ton Hall met for 20 minutes last night, but accomplished no more than a formal exchange of demands.

title: A Social Audit
description: Recent trends in business criticism differ from the. PopulistProgressive New Deal attacks of the past in cer tain significant respects that could have a profound bearing on the future role of business in our society.

title: Soviet Calls for Cuts in Research Staffs
description: MOSCOW, April 30A Soviet economist called today for a drastic reduction of workers in overstaffed research institutes to raise a low rate of produc tivity in scientific investiga tions.

title: Women Forced to Undergo Body Searches at Border
description: SAN DIEGO, April 30 (UPI) Some 1,800 women were forced to undergo strip searches while crossing the United StatesMexico border here last year, a Congregsional committee was told during the weekend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Watchdog Groups a Concern to City
description: Mayor Lindsay's top advisers are concerned about a growing rift between the Lindsay ad ministration and goodgovern ment, civicwatchdog groups that supported his reelection.

title: Lynch Hints That Dublin Will Crack Down on I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, April 30Prime Minister John Lynch hinted to day that tougher action by his Government against the Irish Republican Army was likely to be announced soon.

title: U.S. Businessman Is Invited to Peking
description: HONG KONG, April 30An American who has been at the Canton Fair for the last two weeks has become the first foreign businessman at this spring's session of the fair to be invited to Peking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 Supporters of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota said McGovern of South Dakota said today that they hoped to in crease the total of eight Demo cratic National Convention delegates he won yesterday in county and legislative district conventions.

title: Duke Ellington Celebrates 73d Birthday as a Star and Guest
description: In a dark blue, singlebut ton tuxedo, his long hair hanging below his shirt col lar, Duke Ellington began a public celebration of his 73d birthday as he stepped onto the stage, gingerly picking his way over microphone wires and moving to the pi ano to start a benefit concert in Newark.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 30 Donald Mantooth is a true believer.

title: Caution Dominates the Eurobond Market
description: BRUSSELS, April 30Inter est rates on straightdollar debt in the Eurobond market appear to have topped out for the mo ment at 8.25 per cent, with the secondary market looking a bit stronger and the newissue slate blank for the moment.

title: Strike Subsidy
description: Among the tasks awaiting the Legislature in its adjournment rush is the need to correct a longstanding inequity in the state unemployment insurance law, one that puts employers in the position of subsidizing long strikes against themselves.

title: Henry Fein Weds Stephanie Forray
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 30  Miss Stephanie Lynne Forray and Henry George Fein were married here this afternoon. Rabbi Harold Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Arbor Inn.

title: ROBERT W. UPTON, 88, EXSENATOR, IS DEAD
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 30 Robert W. Upton, a former Senator from New Hampshire and a retired lawyer, died here yesterday at the age of 88.

title: Stage:
description: Gore Vidal, if I may subtly misquote him for an instant, has described his play An Evening With Richard Nixon And  as a highly biased political charade. It opened last night at the Shubert The ater, and it even makes you feel sorry for Checkers, let alone Spiro T. Agnew, or have I got those names in the wrong order?

title: Boston Wins on Late Goal After 51 Lead Is Erased
description: BOSTON, April 30Just when it appeared the New York Rang ers were in the midst of remem brance of past playoff collapses, they rallied from a 51 deficit, clawed their way to a tie, but lost in the final minutes, 6.5, to the Boston Bruins today.

title: YANKS AND TWINS SPLIT 54 GAMES
description: The Yankees gave away 17, 242 caps to their young fans at Yankee Stadium yesterday and tried to give away two games to Minnesota. The Twins, how ever, declined to accept the first game so the Yankees wound up with a split of a pair of 54 decisions.throw was high and wide, and the Twins had a 32 lead.

title: Threat to Abortion Law
description: New York State's Abortion Reform law, which is ex pected to come under heavy pressure in Albany this week for repeal or revision, was cited by a Presidential commission only last March as a model for the nation.

title: Wheelabrator Appointment
description: Robert T. Gray, 44 years old, has joined WheelabratorFrye, Inc., as senior vice president administration and chief admin istrative officer. He formerly was corporate director of in dustrial relations at Litton In dustries, Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: City Aide Sees ReliefWork Plans as Inadequate
description: The city's Human Resources Administrator, Jule M. Sugar man, charged yesterday that the Nixon Administration was backing away from needed creation of jobs for welfare re cipients.

title: United Fund Appeal
description: The United Fund of Greater New York begins its 1972 camapaign to help 425 affiliated hospital, health and so cial service agencies and Red Cross to day with a luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. As part of thecampaign, the United Fund has recruited 45,000 volun teers at corporations, unions and governmental agencies. They will conduct employe campaigns to help support the fund's agenciesthe world's largest network of local com munity services. Last year the United Fund agencies spent 89 per cent of the moneys expended in the city's voluntary health and welfare field and helped four million people.

title: Hebrew Teachers to Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30 Unionized Hebrew teachers have called a strike for tomor row and Tuesday that would close 31 Philadelphiaarea Con servative Jewish schools in which 7,000 pupils are enrolled, it was announced today by the 350member Professional He brew Teachers Organization of Philadelphia. The union seeks recognition from the city's Board of Jewish Education, an affiliate of the United Syna gogue of America.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Good evening.

title: Giacomin, Goalie for the Rangers, Had the Kind of Day in the Nets That No Goalie Ever Really Wants
description: BOSTON, April 30Hell, said Vic Hadfield; it's easy to quit.. It's tougher to come back.

title: March Turnover Rates Off For Rank Check Accounts
description: The velocity of money in the economy, which rose during February, declined in March, the Federal Reserve System re ported over the weekend.

title: To End I.R.A. Terror
description: The Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association has at last warned the Irish Republican Army that it must cease its campaign of assassination and terror if the drift toward civil war is to be halted. This plea for an end to violence, which recognizes that the despicable I.R.A. tactics could provoke largescale civil strife, comes very late in Ulster's tragedy. It is doubtful that it can produce early results in Catholic areas of Londonderry, now tightly controlled by the two I.R.A. factions, or in Belfast, where Protestant youths have unfortunately begun to respond to I.R.A. bombings and shootings.

title: TRADE LOSS STIRS COMPLAINT BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The United States, reportedly backed by several other coun tries, has raised in the World Bank the issue of whether American suppliers are unfair ly losing business in many less developed countries linked with the European Common Market, as a result of special tariff ref erences.

title: Credit Markets
description: Technical rebound or part of a major market turn?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: U.S. Aid Seen in Decentralization

title: Costs Blamed in Ship Delays
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)Representative Les As pin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that cost overruns, lengthy delays and serious tech nical problems were delaying the Navy's plan to build two ships and two minisubs de signed to rescue disabled sub marines.

title: Elevators in 40 Buildings Stalled by Power Failure
description: Elevator service in about 40 buildings in the Washington Square area was interrupted for periods of up to several hours last night by a power failure, inconveniencing hun dreds of tenants.

title: Burundi Says ExKing Is Dead as Coup Fails
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 30The former King of Bu rundi, Ntare V, was killed last night when his support ers attempted to release him from the former royal palace at Gitega, where he had been detained since his arrest last month, according to the Bu rundi radio, monitored here.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 30 (AP)India won the doubles and two singles today to sweep Malaysia, 5.0, in their Eastern Zone B Davis Cup series.

title: Vanguard Bank Surmounts Many Obstacles
description: For Harold Trent, this morning was a long time coming. Mr. Trent, 44 years old and black, has been the primary moving force behind the organization of the Van guard National Bank, a new multiracial but blackcon trolled institution that is to open for business today in Hempstead.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30 (AP)Morocco took a 30 lead over Lebanon today and clinched their European Zone B Davis Cup competition. Morocco will meet the Soviet Union in the next round.

title: The Treaty Powers
description: The tendency of Presidents to circumvent the consti tutional requirement for Senate approval of treaties by concluding executive agreements has reached extraordi nary proportions in recent years. In the 150 years prior to 1939, the United States entered into 799 treaties and 1,182 executive agreements, oneandonehalf times as many. In the last 26 years, according to State Depart ment compilations, 368 treaties have been concluded but fifteen times that many executive agreements have been signeda total of 5,590. In addition, there are over 400 secret agreements, the nature of which the State Depart ment declines to reveal. Moreover, thousands of other executive agreements evidently, have been concluded by other governmental agencies, particularly the Defense Department, which reportedly refuses to disclose the details even to Congressional committees.

title: WILLIAM C. SPENCE
description: William Cushman Spence, vice president of the Arthur Schroeder Paper Company and of the National Horse Show, died Saturday, apparently of a stroke, while golfing at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 52 years old and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30 Nevada Democrats elected their 20 delegates today to the na tional party convention with Senator McGovern making a surprisingly strong showing.

title: Advertising:
description: The man who had much to do with the establishment of the first major advertising industry attempt at self regulation has now suggested the industry speak with one voice on major issues and unify its Washington activities.

title: Yugoslavs, Soviet in Tie
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30 (UPI)Yugoslavia held the favored Soviet Union soccer team to a scoreless tie today in the first round of the Euro pean Nations Cup quarterfi nals.

title: CITY'S DRUG USERS PLACED AT 300,000
description: A confidential report to the Mayor's Narcotics Control Council estimates that more than 300,000 New Yorkers were habitual or compulsive users of such drugs as heroin, Dem erol and methadone between 1964 and 1970.

title: Marijuana Penalties Opposed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (UPI)The Bar Association of San Francisco said yesterday that it would support a state initiative that would end crim inal penalties for adult per sonal use of marijuana.

title: U.S. Ready to Raise Quota For Imports of Foreign Oil
description: WASHINGTON, April 30To alleviate the country's inten sifying shortage of fuels, the Nixon Administration is pre paring to make a substantial increase in the impart quota for foreign crude oil.

title: Base Near Quangtri Vacated
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, May 1 (Reuters) South Vietnamese forces in Quantri city below the demili tarized zone abandoned a big combat base on the northern outskirts early today, military soures said in Danang.

title: Seagren Vaults Back into Picture
description: It was not Jim Ryun's week end, but Bob Seagren climbed back into the international polevault picture again.

title: Juggling Career, Husband and Child
description: LONDONQuestion: what kind of woman handles a fulltime career commitment and successfully manages to fulfill her responsibilities to her husband and children?

title: FOE SAID TO PLAN URBAN TERRORISM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30  Allied intelligence sources said today that the enemy planned a major series of terrorist attacks and popu lar uprisings in May in South Vietnam's largest cities, espe cially Danang on the central coast.

title: ALEKAI ALI VICTOR IN FIELD OF 1,507
description: FELTONVILLE, Pa., April 30 A magnificent white standard poodle, Ch. Alekai All of Stone bridge, owned by Janet R. Abrahams of Meriden, Conn., and shown by Wendell Sam mett was chosen as best in a field of 1,507 dogs tonight in the Penn Treaty Kennel Club show on the grounds of the Sun Oil athletic field.

title: British Debating Black Sambo
description: LONDON, April 30Once upon a time there was a little black boy, and his name was Little Black Sambo.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOUSTON, April 30  Last year's Sharpstown stock scan dals have left the Texas politi cal scene in such a muddle that with only a week left before the May 6 Republican and Democratic primaries, large segments of the state's 4,250, 000 voters have not yet com mitted themselves.

title: 6 Tracts of Federal Land Picked for Oil Shale Lease
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton has an nounced the tentative selection of six tracts of Federal land for proposed leasing for devel opment of oil shale.

title: Major Bills Still Unpassed As Albany Aims to Adjourn
description: ALBANY, April 30  With major legislation still to be acted upon, the 1972 Legisla ture continues its push for ad journment this week after nearly four months of marking time.

title: A Huge Crowd Here Protests Soviet Imprisonment and Treatment of Jews
description: A crowd estimated by the police at 45,000 jammed Dag Hammarskjold Plaza and overflowed onto side streets yesterday to protest Soviet treatment and imprisonment of Russian Jews.

title: Excerpts From Statement at Airport by Le Duc Tho
description: PARIS, April 30Follow ing are excerpts from a state ment read by Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Viet namese Politburo, today on his arrival in Paris. Mr. Tho spoke in Vietnamese and this English version was trans lated from an unofficial French translation.

title: Sharon Friedland Bride of C.P.A.
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., April 30 Miss Sharon Lynn Fried land, a granddaughter of Samuel Friedland, founder of Food Fair Stores, Inc., was married here this evening to Sylvan Schwartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schwartz of Wynnewood.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PROXMIRE DOUBTS VALUE OF CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Senator William Proxmire says that eight months of anti inflation price controls show that the nation might do better by scrapping controls and learning to live with inflation as the lesser of two evils.

title: Lanier OneonOne Victor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 30 Bob Lanier of the Detroit Pistons won the oneonone bas ketball tournament for televi sion today by beating Jo Jo White of the Boston Celtics, 2116. The match was played on the Forum court after the completion of the New York Los Angeles playoff game. Lanier earned $15,000 as the winner's share of a $50,500 prize pool.

title: MILTON SIEGEL
description: Milton Siegel, a lawyer, who was executive vice president of Charles Navasky & Co., a rain wear manufacturer, died Sat urday of a heart attack in Kings County Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 1701 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn.

title: Advertising:
description: The sales momentum of Toyota, slowed by the 10 per cent surcharge and the West Coast dock strike, is starting to come back and its high pressure advertising cam paign of reintroduction will continue into midyear.

title: Army Eyes Division With Antitank Copters As an Answer to Russian Armor in Europe
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  The Army is concentrating its search for an answer to the So viet Union's threetoone ar mored superiority in Europe on a new kind of division whose distinctive element is a tank destroying squadron of helicop ters.

title: School Groups Plan Protest
description: The parents of students in many  Roman Catholic grade schools and high schools in Brooklyn and Queens have been asked by their parochial school parents' associations to go to their local public schools today to obtain certificates of enrollthent for their children. The move is, apparently de signed to dramatize how the load on the public school sys tem would increase if parochial schools, denied public assist ance, were forced to close.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 The two major Democratic candidates in this Tuesday's Presidential primary here raced around Ohio today in a last weekend effort to woo the elec torate.

title: Bluegrass Concert Converts Mixups Into Rollicking Fun
description: The program that was planned by the Bluegrass Club of New York for concerts yesterday afternoon and eve ning at St. Catherine of Siena Auditorium, 420 East 69th Street, was intended to be varied but not quite as varied as the afternoon session turned out to be.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 As of tomorrow morning, the real estate responsibilities of John Richard McGuire will soar spectacularly from one suburban halfacre homesite in Virginia to 187 million acreswith something like a corresponding increase in po tential headaches. Mr. McGuire, a lanky, slow  speaking, lookalike of the actor James Stewart, takes over as 10th chief of the United States Forest Service, the beleaguered cus todian of nearly onetenth of the nation's land.

title: Whitten, a Pianist, Shows Maturity in Debut
description: Benjamin Whitten, a pianist who teaches at West Chester College in Pennsylvania, made his New York debut at Car negie Recital Hall late Satur day afternoon playing Ravel's Valses Nobles et Sentimen tales, Schumann's Symphonic Etudes, Berio's Five Variations and Chopin's Sonata in B minor.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH WINS ALAMO GOLF
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 30 (AP)Kathy Whitworth re covered from a double bogey on the 11th hole today and went on to win the $25,000 Alamo women's open golf tour nament by a threestroke mar gin.

title: U. S. Aides Believe Two Whites Are Active in Enemy's Invasion
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, April 30American intelligence officers and advisers here be lieve that the enemy forces that have occupied northern Binhdinh Province have two Caucasians, possibly Americans, operating with them in either an advisory or a combatant role.

title: East German Chief Takes Lead In Lifting Controls on the Arts
description: BERLIN, April 30 Erich Honecker, viewed in the West as a standardbearer of ortho doxy when he took over leader ship of East Germany's Com munist party a year ago, has turned out to be a trail blazer of liberalization in the arts in the last months.

title: DODGERS' SUTTON DOWNS METS, 70
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30 The Los Angeles Dodgers mauled the New York Mets for the second time in a row today, bounching 11 hits off four pitchers and scoring a 70 vic tory.

title: Japan's Press Attacked for Its Peking Reporting
description: TOKYO, April 30A contro versy has developed here over charges that Japanese corre spondents in China are showing a gratuitous proPeking bias in their dispatches.

title: Thompson Backs McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) Representative Frank Thomp son Jr., Democrat of New Jer sey, endorsed Senator George McGovern of South Dakota yes terday for the Democratic Presi dential nomination. Increas ingly, Americans are looking to Senator McGovern as the best man to do what President Nixon has failed to do, he said.

title: 200 TEXANS HEAR NIXON REAFFIRM VIETNAM PLEDGE
description: FLORESVILLE, Tex., Monday, May 1President Nixon flew here yesterday to dine with his Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally, and after wardto the delight and the applause of about 200 influen tial Texansgave a recitation of his views on Vietnam, the oil depletion allowance, busing and other issues.

title: Muskie's Pullout Jolts Ohio Politicians
description: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN

title: Samuel Dixon, 91, Is Dead; Maker of Dental Equipment
description: NEWARK, April 30Samuel F. Dixon, who retired in 1969 as president of William Dixon, Inc., makers of jewelry and dental equipment, now of Carl stadt, N. J., died here yester day. He was 91 years old and lived at 520 Highland Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUSANDS FLEE KONTUM IN PANIC AS ENEMY NEARS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 1Thousands of people were reported yesterday to be fleeing in panic from Kon tum, a key city in the Central Highlands encircled by North Vietnamese forces.

title: Orchestra da Camera Offers Zesty Mix
description: Bernstein's Candide Over ture, Strauss's Bourgeois Gen tilhomme Suite and Puccini's Messa da Gloriaabout as bizarre a juxtaposition of musi cal styles by three theater com posers as could be imagined made up the program offered by the Orchestra da Camera of Long Island, Herbert Grossman conducting, in Tully Hall Satur day night. Thanks to the gen erally fine performances, the variety proved to be every bit as enjoyable as it was spicy.

title: Soviet Group Tours in China At the Invitation of Peking
description: MOSCOW, April 30The So viet Union reported today that its delegation to border talks in Peking had recently made a trip through central and south China at the invitation of the Peking authorities.

title: The Country Girl Closing
description: The revival of the Clifford Odets drama The Country Girl, starring Jason Robards, Maureen Stapleton and George Grizzard, will close Saturday night at the Billy Rose Theater after its 61st performance. The play, presented by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts, will open with the same cast for a threeweek run, starting May 15, at the Huntington Hartford Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Spanish Facility Blown Up
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, April 30 (Reuters)  radio telephone installation under construction in this northern Basque region was destroyed last bight after raiders held technicians at gunpoint and planted explosives there, the police reported today. Similar bombings of radio and televi sion stations in recent months have been attributed by the authorities to Basque separat ists.

title: WILLIAM H. CLARK
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 30 William H. Clark, who retired as treasurer and a director of RKO Radio Pictures 15 years ago, died last night in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 10 Nos band Avenue.

title: Chess: Reshevsky Uses Reti Opening In Tourney Against Bisguier
description: The first round of the 21st annual United States chess championship, a 14man round robin, matched Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., an eighttime United States champion, against Arthur Bisguier of Hartsdale, N. Y., also a former United States invitation and open champion.

title: Bridge: Finalists in L. I. Regionals Employ Same System of Play
description: A team of giants clashed with a team of giant killers in the final of the Long Island Regional Knockout Championships at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., yes terday and both teams were using the Precision System.

title: Steel Mills Hopeful on Quarter; New Orders Taking Firm Tone
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30  Steelmakers are looking ahead to the second quarter with optimism.

title: Bodega Owners Gain Strength in Coop Here
description: Spanishspeaking owners of small grocery stores viho work an average of 108 hours a week to sell a few thousand dollars worth of goods, have been given stature and po litical clout through a food cooperative formed by an imaginative and energetic Puerto Rican businessman here.

title: Diners' Club Suit Withdrawn
description: A $31million suit against Diners' Club, Inc., and its parent, the Continental Corpo ration, by Diners' France, has been withdrawn, Diners' said yesterday. It said no payment or promise of payment was made.

title: NINE BOMBS ROCK AN ULSTER PLANT
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 1A man was killed today and 15 persons were injured, eight seriously, in a series of explosions at a $31million tex tile complex under construc tion northeast of here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dave Kennerly Feature Photography
description: Asked for and got Vietnam assignment after working as U.P.I. White House photog rapher.Before that served as general assignment pho tographer for the wire serv ice on the West Coast. At 25 years of age has seven years professional experi ence. Quit Portland State College to take pictures for Portland Journal and later.

title: McLaren Memo on I.T.T. Merger Revealed
description: WASHINGTON May 1  Although he thought he had only three days to do so, Rich ard W. McLaren, former Assist ant Attorney General in charge of the Antitrust Division, strongly urged then Attorney General John N. Mitchell to seek a temporary restraining order to halt the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration's acquisition of a major food vending company.

title: John W. Machacek General Local Reporting
description: A 32yearold reporter for The Rochester TimesUnion who specializes in covering city education. Born Feb. 18, 1940, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Graduated in 1958 from Immaculate Conception High School, Cedar Rapids, and in 1962 from Marquette University. Worked as sports editor of his high school paper, then as re porter, city editor and execu tive editor of his collge paper.  Joined The Milwaukee Sentinel, where he began on obituaries, then covered the Federal courts and a subur ban beat. Worked as a general assignment, suburban and education reporter for The Knickerbocker News in Albany. Recalls that in high school he was fasci nated by newspaper report ers.  Spent six months on active duty with the Wis consin National Guard. Lives in Rochester with his wife and daughter.

title: JAMES R. LEWIS
description: James R. Lewis, who retired in 1964 after 38 years as an elevator operator at The New York Times, died Thursday while being taken to a hospital from his home at 113 West 113th Street. He was 74 years old.

title: Excerpts From the President's Colloquy on Vietnam
description: FLORESVILLE, Texas, May 1 (AP)Following are ex cerpts from President Nixon's remarks during a question andanswer session with a group of prominent Texas Democrats and Republicans last night at Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally's ranch:

title: Frank L. Peters Jr. Music Criticism
description: Has a broad newspaper background and a long inter est in cultural affairs, espe cially music. Named mu sic critic of The St. Louis Post Dispatch in 1967. Has no favorite music, be lieves a good critic has to try to understand the intentions of composers of every period and to try to tell when they are successful. Feels major role of today's critic is to encourage people to hear more music. Born in Springfield, Mo., Oct. 19, 1930. Received B.A. in English from Drury College in Springfield in 1951 Did graduate study at State University of Iowa in 1953 54. Won first newspaper job on The Arkansas Gazette, then went to Springfield Newspapers, Inc. Before joining PostDispatch in 1964, served as managing editor of Rome Daily American. Lives with wife, former Alba Manciani, and their two chil dren in Webster Groves, Mo.

title: Jacob Druckman Music
description: A 44yearold member of the faculty of Juilliard School of Music, he was born in Philadelphia and has won nu merous awards and grants.

title: Senate Votes 5715 to Restore $45Million to U.S.I.A. Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Senate, overruling its Foreign Relations Committee, voted to day to restore $45.6million to the fund authorization of the United States Information Agency.

title: RADIC INTERPRETS 2 BEETHOVEN WORKS
description: Beethoven was not alto gether a pleasant person and there is a sound basis for pre senting his musical thought in a corresponding nasty, bad tempered fashion. Stjepan Radic, a Yugoslav pianist in his middle years, adheres to this school of interpretation, as his Carnegie Recital Hall program Sunday night made abundantly clear.

title: Everything's Looking Up in Singapore  Harbors, Factories and Skyscrapers
description: SINGAPORE  In the old days, some time after clipper ships stopped nestling into the harbor for sanctuary from Ma lacca Strait pirates but before the carrier Enterprise began slipping in to unload 2,000 American sailors for a night on the town, it was said that the loudest noises in Singapore were the clicking of chopsticks and clacking of mahjongg tiles.

title: Phillies Down Dodgers, 21. On Selma's 3Hit Pitching
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (AP) Dick Selma pitched a three hitter tonight and Willie Mon tanez drove in the deciding runs with a tworun homer in the eighth inning, as the Philadel phia Phillies posted a 21 tri umph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Bronx Official Backs Gay Complaint
description: An assistant to the Bronx Borough President said yester day he was prepared to testify to police inaction in an inci dent involving members of the Gay Activists Alliance who have filed assault charges against Michael J. Maye, presi dent of the Uniformed Fire fighters Association.

title: Pulitzer Jury Wanted Sheehan To Share Prize Given to Times
description: The jury that voted to award a Pulitzer Prize to The New York Times for publishing the Pentagon papers had wanted the prize to be shared by Neil Sheehan. The Times reporter who obtained the documents.

title: Tensions Over Vietnam
description: News Analysis

title: PODGORNY ASSAILS U.S. ON VIETNAM
description: MOSCOW, May 1President Nikolai V. Podgorny denounced United States policy in Vietnam today and pledged continued support for the Indochinese Communists.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: Assistant managing editor of The Morning Globe in Bos ton, he founded a Spotlight Team in 1970 to do investiga tive reporting on municipal misconduct.... Was cited by the American Political Sci ence Association in 1968 for outstanding reporting in the area of governmental reform for a fourpart series on un finished business of reform in Massachusetts and for a six part series on The Cheated Voter, which dealt with a redistricting crisis in the state.... Born in Boston on Sept. 24, 1937.... Was grad uated from the Noble and Greenough School in Dedham, from Harvard cum laude in 1960 and from the Columbia Graduate School of Journal ism in 1961.... Joined The Globe in 1963 as science edi tor, then State House bureau chief.... Worked for The London Sunday Times during a sabbatical in 19691970.... Married the former Natasha Bourso, who is Russianborn. ... They live in Waban, Mass., with their son, Chris tian.

title: Proposed Power Line Halted by Eagles Nest
description: MIO, Mich., May 1 (UPI) Construction of a 345,000 volt electrical transmission line by the Consumers Power Company was postponed to day for nearly three months because company officials feared it would interfere with an active eagles nest near here.

title: Variety Is Sued by Grease Over BoxOffice Statistics
description: The producers of Grease, the musical at the Eden Thea tre, filed a $700,000 damage suit yesterday against Variety, the entertainment newspaper.

title: DEJESUS DEFEATS MARQUEZ IN 12TH
description: Esteban DeJesus of Caro linas, P. R., one of the cleverest boxers to grace a New York ring in several years, success fully defended his lightweight championship of Puerto Rico last night by battering Josue Marquez of Caguas into sub mission in the 12th and final round.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: A former president of Pennsylvania Society Newspaper Editors, he has won prizes for editorials five times at Penn State, Univer sity annual press confer ences. Member of the editorial board of Nieman Reports and a former Nieman Fellow at Harvard. Began his career in 1941 at age of 16 as a night reporter for Bethlehem Globe Times while attending Moravian College.  Served three years in Navy during World War II. Graduated from Muh lenberg College. Attend ed Columbia University Jour nalism school, where he won a Pulitzer traveling scholar ship for finishing first in class. Investigative re porter on crime and corrup tion for Providence (R.I.) Journal Bulletin. Re turned to Bethlehem Globe Times in 1956 as editor. Now a vice president of the Globe Times. Ardent fisherman.He and wtfe, Nancy, a former reporter, have three children.

title: City Better Business Bureau Is 50
description: How well can busines regu late itself to curb consumer abuses?

title: Landing Zone English Hit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 2Landing Zone, English was struck by more than 400 round's of artillery and other indirect fire yester day, the Saigon command an nounced. It said the shelling had caused moderate casual ties, an admission of higher; than usual casualties.

title: Clerics Challenge WORTV's License For Refusing Show
description: The American Board of Mis sions to the Jews said yester day that it had petitioned the Federal Communications Com mission to deny WORTV a re newal of its broadcasting li cense because of alleged dis crimination against a contro versial 1971 religious program produced by the board.

title: Bridges Urges Wide Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (UPI)Harry Bridges, president of the West Coast longshore men's union, called today for a nationwide general strike against President Nixon's wage controls.

title: Car Kills Chicago Woman
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (UPI)A car swerved out of control to day and slammed into a dis play window of Marshall Field's department store in the Loop killing one person and injuring six. Etta Martin, 53 years old, of Chicago died shortly after arrival at Henrotin Hospital.

title: Bethlehem Steel Planning A Sintering Plant for 1974
description: The Bethlehem Steel Cor poration said yesterday that it planned to build a multi milliondollar sintering plant at its steel facility at Sparrows Point, Md.

title: Market Plade: Public Relations And Profit Data
description: Is it possible to put such a publicrelations handle, on an earnings report that the reader is actually misled?

title: COCOA UNIT OPENS AT NEW QUARTERS
PROVINCE IS LOST
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Tues day, May 2The South Viet namese abandoned Quangtri, their northernmost province capital, yesterday, giving the advancing North Vietnamese their biggest prize so far in their monthold invasion.

title: MRS. ELIOT CABOT
description: Mrs. Agnes Flannery Cabot, widow of Eliot Cabot, an actor and member of the Boston Cabot family who died in 1938, died Sunday at the home of her son, Edward S. Cabot, in Port Washington, L.I. She was 66 years old and lived at 54 East 82d Street.

title: WNBCTV News Cleared Of Discrimination Charge
description: The Human Rights Commis sion has dismissed charges of discrimination against WNBC TV News brought by Sherman L. Jackson, a reporter dis charged last December.

title: U.N. Gets Grim Report
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1  A grim picture of Bangladesh was painted today in a report issued by the United Nations.

title: Love It and Leave It
description: When former Beatle John Lennon was in fifth grade, he was caned by a headmaster who later said: I can't remember what I caned him for. Chances are that if the Immigration and Naturalization authorities, who have ordered Mr. Lennon and his wife to appear for a hear ing, proceed with the order to deport the couple, theywill also be at a loss, years hence, to remember what they punished Mr. Lennon for.

title: Lions to Honor Mrs. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will receive the 1972 Lions Inter national humanitarian award next Saturday at the service club's annual banquet in Wash ing, the White House an nounced today. Mrs. Nixon will be honored for her great in fluence throughout the world in humanitarian endeavors, a statement released with the an nouncement said.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Gloria Steinem's Mother Wasn't All That Liberated
description: WASHINGTONRuth Stein em remembers when she ap plied for a job on a metro politan newspaper and was told, We have too many damn women here now. (They had one.) She also re members later, when she had a satisfying job, how naive she was to think a career could be combined with motherhood.

title: New Play by Van Peebles Opens May 16
description: Melvin Van Peebles, the playwright  composer whose Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death was nomi nated for seven Tonys, has fashioned another play with music, Don't Play Us Cheap!, opening at the Ethel Barrymore Theater May 16.

title: Calley's Lawyers Assert Army Made Errors at His Trial
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s lawyers have accused the Army of relying on command influence and making many legal errors in convicting him of the 1968 Mylai killings.

title: Now Two No Faults
description: The only similarity between the two no fault auto mobile insurance bills coming to the floor of the State Senate for a vote is in their titles. Both are called no fault, but one is a genuine nofault bill while the other is a fraud.

title: Sydney Syndicate Offering $225,000 for World Chess
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 1 (Reuters)A Sydney syndicate has submitted a $225,000 bid to stage the world chess cham pionship herethe second offer to come out of Australia in three days.

title: Greta Keller, McKuen Songs And an Evening of Sentiment
description: Rod McKuen, whose normal performing costume is a sweater, slacks and white sneakers, compromised Sun day night when he appeared at Alice Tully Hall to intro duce Greta Keller. He wore a tuxedo, but with white sneak ers. In return, Miss Keller sang some of his songs.

title: U.S. COURT REFUSES KELLER INJUNCTION
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yester day in New York that the Fed eral District Court here had de clined to grant the S.E.C.'s re quest for a preliminary in junction against Keller Indus tries, Inc.

title: Meat Prices Are Expected to Rise in September
description: CHICAGO, May 1House wives who are encouraged by recent reports of lower food prices should enjoy the situation while they can, for it appears certain that the prices farmers will get for their hogs will go up in September. And the indications are that autumn prices for beef cattle will, at best, be as high as they are now or higher.

title: Halpern to Forgo House Race; Only City G.O.P. Congressman
description: Representative Seymour Hal pern, New York City's only Republican Congressman, has told Republican leaders that he will not seek reelection to an eighth term in the House this year.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: At the age of 25, has experi enced war and brutality for most of his professional life.  Was in Czechoslovakia when the Russians marched in in 1968. Worked in Palestine with the Fedayeen in war with Israel. Moved to jungles of Ceylon to cover the brief civil war last year. Was in Dacca when Pakistani troops moved all newsmen out. Hid on roof of hotel. Came down for exclusive pictures of bloodbath following Indian victory. Later joined Horst Faas to get photos of Bangladesh guerrilla reprisals against collaborators. Is now in Ulster to photograph Irish civil war. When off duty, which is rarely, drives around Paris in Jaguar of ancient vintage.  Usu ally with Parisian girl named Michelle, to whom he is en gaged.

title: L. I. Collegiate Golf Title To Sauerman of Adelphi
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., May 1Wolfgang Sauerman, an 18 yearold freshman from Adel phi, took individual honors in the Long Island Intercollegiate Golf Association tournament today. He scored 36, 3874. Play was over the 6,474yard, par72 Eisenhauer Park red course.

title: BEAVER OF METS HALTS GIANTS,74
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May, 1 Tom Seaver was touched for three home runs but struck out 12 batters inside seven innings today as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 74.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Deltona Corporation, Miami, announced yesterday it had filed a registration state ment with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed offering of 180, 000, shares of the company's common stock through a group of underwriters. It was further announced that John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company will sell warrants for such shares to the underwriters who will, it was stated, then exercise them. According to the announcement proceeds from the exercise of these warrants will accrue to the company and be added to working capi tal. Deltona closed yesterday on the New York Stock Ex change (N.Y.S.E.) at 36, down 3.

title: Cyclops Unit Withdrawing Price Rise for Steel Coils
description: The Cyclops Corporation said yesterday that its Universal Cyclops Specialties Steel divi sion had withdraw new base prices for stainless coldrolled strip steel coils under 24 inches in width.

title: Pentagon Papers Still Controversial
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The publication of the Pentagon's secret history of the Vietnam War last June ignited a legal and journalistic controversy that is still under way 10 months after the first article appeared.

title: Ali Awarded Decision Over Chuvalo
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, May 1  Muhammad Ali looked more like himself tonight, but he couldn't knock down George Chuvalo, box ing's rock of ages.

title: The Bids Told Story Of a Lifetime Knack For Buying Antiques
description: By the time John L. Marion, the chief auctioneer for ParkeBernet, had knocked down the last lot in Mrs. Giles Whiting's large and distinguished col lection of American antiques, those of her friends who had come to bid had left and the public wake was over.

title: TWO INDICTED HERE FOR STOCK DEALINGS
description: Two investment advisers were Indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of devising a sophisti cated scheme that allegedly de frauded mutualfund investors of more than $1million. The defendants are Akiyoshi Yamada, 30 years old, of 941 Park Avenue, and John Peter Galanis, 29, formerly of 985 Fifth Avenue. They were among 44 individuals and companies that the Securities and Ex change Commission named last November in a related com plaint alleging securities viola tions.

title: Our Lady of Late, A Dance by Dunas, Needs Clarification
description: Our Lady of Late is murky dance both in content and lighting. The work, created by William Dunas, had lighting that called for a steady lower ing of intensity as the dance progressed. This made it dif ficult to see, though even noon light might not clarify its shadowy thematic line. The niece was presented at The Trust, 57 Laight Street, on Sun day night.

title: Tumbledown Bridge
description: For the second time both houses of the State Legislature have voted overwhelmingly to rescind the improvident authorization they gave five years ago for construction of a sixmile bridge across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay to Rye. Governor Rockefeller, whose enthusi asm for the project prompted his to veto last year's repeal resolution, would be wise to take the second vote as conclusive evidence that his enthusiasm is not widely shared.

title: RECITAL IS GIVEN BY BIRGIT NILSSON
description: Song recitals by most opera stars fall into a fishnorfowl category that makes discussion of them not only difficult but sometimes pointless. Birgit Nils son's appearance at Carnegie Hall Sunday night, for instance, opened with a booming aria, Dich, theure Halle, from Tannhuser, which reminded one of Miss Nilsson's unrivaled stature among present  day Wagnerian sopranos but hardly set the stage for subsequent intimacies of Wolf and Strauss.

title: Couple Regain Child After Nine Years
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 1  A Brooklyn couple who volun tarily agreed to place their in fant daughter in a foster home almost nine years ago because they had become heroin ad dicts received custody of the, child again today in State Su preme Court here.

title: Harrisburg Judge Rejects Move to Subpoena Hoover.
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 1 (UPI)A Federal judge rejected today a defense request that the F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover, acting Attorney Gen eral Richard G. Kleindienst and a Federal prison official, Nor man Carlson, be subpoenaed to supply information on two con victed members of the Harris burg Seven.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL UP BY 0.8% LAST WEEK
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,715,000 tons, the, American Iron and Steel Institute re ported from Washington yes terday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIHN
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 1 (AP)Gov. Reubin Askew pledged today to double to 400 the number of uniformed state law enforcement offi cers on duty if the Republi can National Convention is moved to Miami Beach.

title: Notes on People
description: Judge Bernard J. Lasker signed a temporary order in Federal Court restraining the Immigration and Naturaliza tion Service from holding a deportation hearing today for John Lennon and his wife, Yoko Ono. Judge Lasker ruled that the Government must first hold a hearing on a motion made by the Len nons before it takes up the matter of deportation.

title: CITY CHARTER BILL GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 1 A bill creating an 11member state commission to revise New York City's charter has been agreed upon by Governor Rockefeller and the Republican and Demo cratic legislative leaders.

title: Bogue Sells Belco Interest
description: The Bogue Electric Manu facturing Company has sold its 75 per cent interest in the Belco Pollution Control Cor poration to the Foster Wheeler Corporation for cash. Bogue plans to use the funds from Belco for further development work in the medical field such as its compact breathing de vice, sleep machine and auto matic page turner for handi capped persons.

title: Jack Ruby's Club Safe Stolen Before Auction
description: ATHENS, Tex., May 1 (UPI)L. J. Ware, a partner in a concern hired to auction off the furnishings of Jack Ruby's nightclub, made an agreement with the Ruby es late not to try to open a backroom safe that was to be included in the sale.

title: Plastic Spikes Are Digging In
description: The spiked shoe, as synony mous with track and field as the discus or javelin, may be giving ground to modern technology for the Olympics at Munich.

title: New Construction Rose $2.6Billion in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (Reuters)  Newconstruc tion spending rose $2.6 billion in March to a season ally adjusted annual rate of $125.8billion after Feb ruary's upward revised $1 billion gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A SOVIET GUARANTEE IS HINTED BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, May 1  President Anwar elSadat declared in a televised May Day address at an Alexandria rally today that he now had a guarantee that within a reasonable period we shall have the power to liberate our land.

title: Save NEPA
description: The decline in proven oil and natural gas reserves and the prospect of their shrinking still further in the years just aheadis being put to questionable use on Capitol Hill. Whatever fuel shortage the decline portends for the future, it has already stimulated a mounting offensive against the National Environmental Policy Act.

title: PRISON TERMS FOR 8 DISCLOSED IN TAIW AN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 1The Government disclosed today that eight persons, including noted writer, were convicted of sedition by a military tribu nal in March.

title: New Customs Chief Vernon Darrell Acree
description: Man in the News

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Forthright craftsman of novels often set in the Ameri can West, an upholder of tra ditional values in life and letters. His books, exalt ing the beauty of the land, anticipated ecology movement by many years,  Born in Lake Mills, Iowa, Feb. 18, 1909, of Norwegian, English and Pennsylvania Dutch fore bears. Had a rambling, Huck Finn youth as his fam ily roamed, from North Da kota to the state of Washing ton, to Saskatchewan to Mon tana to Utahfrom whose university he graduated in 1930. Has spent his adult life as professor of literature and creative writing, teaching at Iowa, Wisconsin, Harvard and, after 1945, Stanford. Retired this year. Angle of Repose sets twentieth century narrator, paralyzed and hedged by decadence, ru minating over his grandpar ents' heroic but flawed ad venture in the West. Lives in Los Altos Hills of Califor nia with his wife, Marry.

title: Indian Bus Plunge Kills 25
description: NEW DELHI, India, May 1 (AP)  Twentyfive policemen were killed and four were se riously injured today when a police bus fell into a ravine at Peda on the JammuSprinagar road in Kashmir, according to reports reaching here.

title: PRICES ON AMEX ARE OFF SHARPLY
description: Prices fell quite sharply yes terday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe counter market. The decline was attributed by some to dis couraging news from Vietnam and concern over price roll backs here.

title: House Widens Bias Scope
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The House voted 264 to 66 today to include sex discrimina tion in the jurisdiction of the United States Civil Rights Com mission. The commission, cre ated in 1957, has been limited to investigation of discrimina tion on the basis of race, color, religion or national origin.

title: ADMINISTRATION EXEMPTS ONEQUARTER OF ECONOMY FROM PAYPRICE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Administration exempted mil lions of small businesses and local governments from wage and price controls today, ef fectively freeing more than a quarter of the nation's total work force and sales from com pliance with its economic sta bilization program.

title: ARABS THREATEN BRITISH COMPANY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 A large British company has been threatened with a total boycott in the Arab world if it proceeds with plans to build three submarines for Israel.

title: Swedes Protest Bombing Disptach of The Times, London
description: STOCKHOLM, May 1About 60,000 people demonstrated to day against the American bombardment in Indochina in the largest demonstration seen in Stockholm since the early years of this century.

title: Women's Group Challenges WABCTV's Renewal
description: The New York chapter of the National Organization for Women has filed a petition with the Federal Communica tions Commission challenging the license renewal application of WABCTV, alleging sexism in the station's program and employment practices.

title: Nixon Samples Good Life at Connally's Ranch
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 President Nixon looked be yond the tight circle of re porters around him and, for a brief moment, seemed lit erally to inhale the symbols of good Texas living that John Connally had spread be fore him: the sleek Santa Gertrudis cattle grazing peacefully on the Treasury Secretary's manicured acres, the executive jets perched proudly on his private air strip beyond, the butane fired barbecue pit where ranchhands roasted the sweet corn.

title: Back to Earth
description: Sports of The Times

title: Theater: Different Times, a Musical
description: The most different thing about Different Times, a musical that opened at the ANTA Theater last night, is the title. Michael Brown wrote the book, the lyrics and the music and then directed it. It is a swell way to avoid splitting royalties, but seems no way to produce a musical.

title: PACERS BEAT STARS, WIN WESTERN TITLE
