description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 1 (UPI)  The Indiana Pacers surged after an early thirdpe riod deadlock tonight and de feated the Utah Stars 117113, winning the American Basket ball Association Western Divi sion crown.

title: Day of Jackal Cited
description: Frederick Forsyth's The Day of the Jackal, has been named the best mystery novel of 1971 by the Mystery Writers of America in annual awards here. In addition, John D. McDonald received the group's Grand Masters Award for his nu merous paperback series.

title: ROGERS ASSAILS CURBS ON TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers assailed protectionism at home and abroad today in a strongly worded defense of free trade as best for America and the world.

title: TREASURY OPPOSES ANY TAX REVISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The Administration today op posed any major revision of the Federal income tax to meet criticism that the present sys tem sometimes is unfair to sin gle persons and married couples.

title: COLUMNIST URGES SECRETDATA CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Jack Anderson, the newspaper columnist, urged Congress to day to pass a law to require the automatic declassification of Government documents that are two years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 1 Terry Sanford's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has officially moved out of his home state, but the former Governor has intensified his efforts here, fully aware that, if he cannot defeat Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama here this week, he probably is not going anywhere.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Each spring brings, in addi tion to blooming crocuses and frogs caroling in the swamps, a plethora of new products designed to woo the outdoors enthusiast.

title: England Hooks Up Hot Line to E.E.C. For Money Trading
description: LONDON, May 1The Bank of England today hooked up a hot line linking its foreignex change trader to the conference call system in operation among the central banks of the Euro pean Common Market countries.

title: A Special Dividend Of 25c Set by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corpo ration, the world's largest in dustrial company, yesterday declared a bonus of more than $70million for its shareholders in the form of a special divi dend of 25 cents a share. It will be paid in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share. Currently, the big auto maker has 286,225,000 shares outstanding.

title: PUBLISHERS TOLD OF CENSOR PERIL
description: TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, May 1A new threat of cen sorship is rapidly spreading as the Government continues to seek prosecution of the pub lishers of the Pentagon Papers and as private groups attempt to suppress books on sexual education, the association of American Publishers was told today.

title: Vickers Rejects Threat
description: LONDON, May 1A Vickers spokesman said tonight that the threatened Arab boycott would not dissuade us from carrying out our contract to build submarines for Israel and that the contract had only just been signed to build three small subs of a coastal type.

title: Two Women Take Three Big A Races
description: The campaign by women jockeys for equal recognition with men at America's thor oughbred tracks took another step forward at Aqueduct yes terday. Onethird of the con tests on the nineevent pro gram were won by women riders, a new high for New York.

title: Last Eastern Antiques Show of the Season Opens
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 1The last of the major antiques shows in the East for the sea son opened here today at the Westchester County Center, still a charmer and a market for collector and modest be ginner.

title: City Is Negotiating With Tenant for Pier In Chelsea District
description: A revival of activity at the Chelsea piers on Manhattan's Lower West Side appears im minent, Edgar C. Fabber, the city's Commissioner of Port and Terminals, said here yesterday.

title: Minor League Club Flashes No Vacancy Sign to Bouton
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 1 (UPI)Jim Bouton's attempted pitching comeback was at least temporarily stalled yesterday when the Pittsfield Rangers of the Eastern League decided there was no room on the ros ter for the former Yankee.

title: Peter R. Kann International Reporting
description: A 29yearold correspond ent for The Wall Street Journal. Born in New York City on Dec. 13, 1942, and grew up in Princeton. Worked summers as a re porter for the Princeton Packet, a weekly. Grad uated from Harvard with a degree in government in 1964  Joined The Journal in fall of 1964 and spent first year in Pittsburgh. Transferred in 1965 to Los Angeles to cover film industry and gam bling industry in Nevada. Sent to Vietnam in July, 1967, and covered the war for 16 months. Since November, 1968, has been The Journal's Asian corres pondent, based in Hong Kong.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS DAVIS DIARY OPENED TO PUBLIC
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 1 I see myself tearing down this steel door fighting my way to you, ripping down your cell door and letting you go free.

title: S.E.C. Staff Asks Action On Banks Over Margins
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has recommended that the Com mission take disciplinary ac tion against a number of major banks  including the Union Bank of Los Angeles and the Franklin National Bank of New York  for possible violation of the Federal Reserve's mar gin rules.

title: BERGMAN STAGES THE WILD DUCK
description: LONDON, May 1  Ingmar Bergman, who revealed the se cret life of Hedda Gabler in a recent Stockholm production, has now staged the death of Hedvig in The Mild Duck.

title: Cambodian Election Indicates Passage of New Constitution
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May, 1 (Agence FrancePresse)The first results in yesterday's ref erendum officially published here today show, overwhelm ing support for the Govern ment's proposal for a new con stitution, with the yes vote reaching 100 per cent in some areas.

title: Students Win Safety Awards
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) A 10yearold fifthgrader from Indianapolis was named today the top money winner in the American Automobile As sociation's 28th national school traffic safety poster contest. Linee Miles, a student at Chap elwood Elementary School, re ceived one of two $500 grand awards plus a $75 bond for having the best poster in her category and a $75 award for reprint rights. The other grand award went to 17yearold Jo seph Czarnota of Buffalo, a senior of the John F. Kennedy High School, who won $500 and $100 for best in his category.

title: Don't Tread on Me
description: Men born to freedom, observed Justice Brandeis, are naturally alert to repel invasion of liberty by evil minded rulers. The greatest danger to liberty lurks in insidious encroach ment by the men of zeal, wellmeaning but without understanding.

title: CHESS CONTENDERS ADJOURN CONTESTS
description: Lubomir Kavalek and Sam my Reshevsky, tied for the lead in the 21st National An nual Chess Championship here, played their fifthround games to adjournment Sunday against two other contenders in the tourney.

title: Rangers Need First Aid Alter Injury to Stewart
Bridge: L.I. Regional Knockout Title Is Taken by Precision Team
description: When one of the world's strongest bridge teams com petes in a regional champion ship the result is not difficult to predict. The Precision team of Steve Altman, Gene Nei ger, Alan Sontag, Joel Stuart, Peter Weichsel, all of New York, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., reigning Spingold and Vanderbilt champions on the national level, had no difficulty in win ning the knockout team championship in the Long Is land Regionals at Roosevelt Raceway during the weekend.

title: Barbara W. Tuchman General Nonfiction
description: Won her first Pulitzer in 1963, for The Guns of August, an account of the early weeks of World War I.  Her other volumes of history include Bible and Sword, published in 1956; The Zimmermann Tele gram, in 1958, and The Proud Tower, in 1966 Born in New York City on Jan. 30, 1912, as Barbara Wertheim. Attended the Walden School and Radcliffe, graduating in 1933. Was a research assistant for the Institute of Pacific Relations in Tokyo, then became a cor respondent for The Nation and covered the Spanish Civil War. After stints as a freelance writer, she was on the Far Eastern desk of the Office of War Information from 1943 to 1945. Be sides writing books, she has written numerous book re views and magazine articles.  Married in 1940 to Dr. Lester R. Tuchman, a physi cian  Is the mother of three daughters Resides in Manhattan

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Williams Alleges S.E.C.Wall St. Dealings
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. charged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Com mission was involved in secret dealings with Wall Street in trying to create a national sys tem of securities markets.

title: Kent State Tightens Security
description: KENT, Ohio, May 1 (UPI) Dr. Glenn Olds, president of Kent State University, today approved a program of campus surveillance recommended by the school's campus security advisory committee. Dr. Olds defined surveillance, to be car ried out on the campus, as the covert or secret watching of an individual or individuals by se curity forces.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: Son of a factory worker, began writing poems in self defense in his youth in his native Martins Ferry, Ohio.  Fled Ohio as a. destruc tive and ugly place and never returned. Served in Army in Japan after World War II. Took B.A. at Ken yon College in Ohio in '52 and master's degree and Ph.D. at University of Wash ington in '54 and '59. Taught English during early nineteensixties at University of Minnesota. Poems empathize strongly with poor, lonely and the outcast Award  winning collection contains nearly all poems from four earlier volumes, plus some 30 translations, in cluding works by Pablo Neruda. Other awards include 1972 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets and Melville Cane Award from the Poetry So ciety of America. Now 44 and professor of English at Hunter College, he lives with second wife, the former Ann Rnuk, in Manhattan.

title: FULD ASSAILS PLAN FOR A COURT AIDE
description: ALBANY, May 1Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals today assailed Gover nor Rockefeller's proposal to place an appointed administra tive officer over the courts as an unthinkable abridgment of the independence of the judi ciary.

title: Lebanon's Top Leftist Wins A Sizable Election Victory
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1  Kemal Jumblatt, Lebanon's leading leftist, won a sizable victory in the third and final phase of the parliamentary elec tions yesterday. He and five followers were returned for fouryear terms.

title: MARKET TUMBLES IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices crumpled yester day as the DowJones indus trial average showed its big gest decline in six months.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Daylight saving time is an act of magic. One instant it is 2 o'clock in the morning andabracadabra!the next it is 3 o'clock in the morning. An entire hour has been made to vanish. Science can not justify it; logic cannot explain it farmers cannot tolerate it. But there is the fact, nevertheless. For one entire hour no one has been born and no one has died, no one has made a fortune, no one lost a love.

title: Fittipaldi Wins, Ickx Second In Spanish Grand Prix
description: MADRID, May 1 (AP)  Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil drove his JPS to victory today in the Spanish Grand Prix and gained a firstplace tie with Denis Hulme of New Zealand in the standings of the world championship for Formula cars.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FAIRBORN, Ohio, May 1 Ohio may be different.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lindsay and Aides Decry Litter

title: ALLENDE ACCUSES U.S. OF BLOCKADE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 1 President Salvador Allende Gossens accused the United States today of imposing an economic blockade on Chile and made a dramatic appeal to labor for more work and sacrifice.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mujib Offers Plan to Aid Impoverished
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 1 Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh, an nounced a broad program today to help impoverished workers and peasants in an economy shattered by war.

title: SEBASTIAN BONACIO
description: Sebastian Bonacio, a former pearlbutton manufacturer in Cold Spring, N.Y., a village in Putnam County, died Thursday in Clearwater Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: JOSEPH A. POLSKY
description: Joseph A. Polsky, a real es tate broker; died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 16 East 77th Street.

title: CORNELL PROTESTERS END STAY IN LIBRARY
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 1Faced with a court order and lack of campus support, some 100 stu dent antiwar demonstrators ended their sixday occupation of Cornell University's Car penter Hall Library today just before 2 P.M. University law yers, unaware that the occupa tion had ended, were arguing successfully for a preliminary injunction against the building, takeover in State Supreme Court as the protesters exited on campus.

title: Peter Churchill, British Hero Of the French Resistance, Dies
description: PARIS, May 1 Peter Mor land Churchill, a British hero of the Resistance in France against German occupation in World War II, died today of cancer at Cannes. He was 63 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SEATTLE, May 1Senatorl George McGovern picked up six national convention dele gates in Washington over the weekend and may have gained 10 others.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended April 25.

title: Choirs From 16 Countries, Stir Audience at Festival Finale
description: Every seat was taken at Philharmonic Hall Sunday night for the gala finale of the Third International University Choral Festival. And after in termission, there was no spare room on the stage either. All 640 of the participating singers were there, many in native costume, representing 16 choirs from as many countries, and with Robert Shaw, music director of the festival, conducting from a doubleheight podium, they sang a varied, often exhilarat ing program of folk airs, na tional songs and concert pieces.

title: COURSE OF COMMUNIST OFFENSIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1  Quangtri stood wrecked and empty today, an easy prey for the North Viet namese troops who had be sieged it and subjected it to heavy shelling and rocket at tacks since Friday.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Now that virtually every dress designer has signed his or her name to a perfume, who else is left? How about shoemakers?

title: A Secondary Issue Is Filed By Downe Communications
description: Downe Communications, Inc., publishers of Ladies' Home Journal, American Home and Family Weekly and also in volved in such diverse activi ties as mutual fund manage ment and the sale of pet products, yesterday announced it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for the sale by various stockholders of 1.7 million shares of its com mon stock.

title: Lieut. R. J. Gould Weds Jane Potts
description: Miss Jane Carolyn Potts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George William Potts of Rich mond, was married here yes terday to Lieut. (jg.) Robert Jay Gould, who is serving with the Judge Advocate Gen eral's Corps of the Navy here. He is a son of Mrs. Harry Ed ward Gould of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Springs, Calif., and the late Mr. Gould. Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco performed the ceremony at Mrs. Gould's apartment at the Pierre.

title: MRS. SHMERLER
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 1 Mrs. Ethel Wolinsky Shmerler, wife of Maxwell Shmerler, head of the New York public accounting firm of that name, died today at her home, 21 Sherbrooke Road. She was 80 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CLEVELAND, May 1The Ohio Presidential primary to morrow will provide the first real test in 1972 of whether a demonstrably effective and wellfinanced media campaign can lift a challenger over a favorite who has placed rela tively little reliance on political radio and television.

title: 2D PACT PROPOSED FOR HARLEM LINE
description: A new proposal that would permit the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority to take over the Harlem and Hudson division of the Penn Central was released by the railroad yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1  As the two leading con tenders in tomorrow's Ohio Democratic Presidential pri mary worked hard today to pry out the last possible vote, their campaign, strategists fretted over what they agreed had become an increasingly tight race.

title: The Times Wins a Pulitzer For the Pentagon Papers
description: The 1972 Pulitzer Prize for meritorious public service in journalism was awarded yester day to The New York Times for publication of the Pentagon Papers  documents showing how the United States became involved in the Vietnam war.

title: DIVERSIFIED TAKES STEPS ON FINANCES
description: CLAYTON, Mo., May 1 (AP) Diversified Industries, Inc., announced significant com pany developments today following a 30day corporate study and a meeting with the company's banks.

title: Bishop Moore, Civil Rights Activist, Succeeds Donegan in Episcopal Post
description: The Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., a 52yearold patrician with a reputation as a civil rights activist and as a vig orous opponent of the war in Vietnam, yesterday be came the 13th Episcopal Bishop of New York.

title: DOUBTFUL STATUS FOR DEBUSSCHERE
description: The absolutely definite, un equivocal and final word yes terday on Dave DeBusschere's injury was that nobody knows whether he will be able to play for the New York Knicks against the Los Angeles Lakers tomor row night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Tough, irreverent, sardonic investigative reporter whose column appears Monday through Friday on Page 3 of The Daily News in Chicago.  Born in Chicago on Sept. 19, 1932, son of a Ukrainian immigrant and sometime tav ernkeeper. Attended Wright Junior College 1951 52, then went into Air Force as publicinformation officer; returned home to Lerner Neighborhood Newspapers, the Chicago City News Bu reau and, in 1959, The Daily News. In 1971 made na tional impact with Boss: Richard J. Daley of Chicago, a caustic portrayal of the Mayor and his political ma chine. His column often inhabited by an alter ego named Slate Grobnik, a quintessential Chicago eth nic. A gregarious report er in the tradition of Front Page, he can often be found in the company of his col leagues at the Billy Goat Tavern. Lives with wife, Carol, and two sons on north west side of Chicago.

title: Lyle Bright Spot in Yanks' Gloom
description: The baseball season has a long way to go, but if the first 12 games offer any basis for speculation, the Yankees are in for a long, long season.

title: U.S. Steel Expects Use To Hit Record This Year
description: DISNEY WORLD, Fla., May 1 The United States Steel Cor poration expects steel con sumption this year to reach record 106 million tons.

title: Kleindienst and 13 Others Accused of Plot in Arrests
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)  In a suit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, Acting Attorney General Rich, and G. Kleindienst and 13 other persons were accused today of conspiracy in the mass arrests of May Day last year in Wash ington.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Just as the mass magazines ran into trouble from tele vision, the specialized publi cations may be facing a fight from cassettes and cable TV, Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House's Office of Telecommunications Pol icy, told magazine publishers yesterday.

title: NEW CHANCELLOR NAMED AT N.Y.U.
description: New York University yester day named Dr. Sidney Borowitz, the provost of its University Heights campus, as chancellor and executive vice president of the school, its second highest administrative position.

title: ENGINEERS SOCIETY SCORED IN U.S. SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit in New York today charging the Ameri can Society of Civil Engineers with eliminating price compe tition in the sale of engineering services.

title: Suspect in a Holdup Is Seized, but Police Say $10,000 Is Lost
description: A case with a difference posed a puzzle for law enforce ment authorities yesterday after $10,000 was found in an at tache case allegedly seized at gunpoint by a teenager from a loan officer who said the case contained $20,000 when stolen.

title: Withdrawal of U.S. Troops Surpasses Target by 2,700
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1 (AP)United States troop withdrawals have exceed ed President Nixon's May 1 target by 2,700 men, the Amer ican command announced to day. United States naval strength off Vietnam continued to grow.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS DATA TO AID CONSUMERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The Federal Trade Commission is exploring ways to promote the disclosure of information needed by consumers to make rational buying decisions.

title: Advertising:
description: What kind of things can be used for premium or in centive offers?

title: Rodriguez Captures Golf Playoff
description: DALLAS, May 1Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, golfing idol of the undersized and his fellow Puerto Ricans, sank a birdie at the first hole of a suddendeath playoff against Billy Casper today and won the $125,000 Byron Nelson Classic.

title: Columbia Police Clear Protesters From Hamilton Hall, but Blacks and Latins Remain in Lewisohn
description: Hamilton Hall, which had been held by student antiwar protesters at Columbia Univer sity since last Tuesday, was cleared of demonstrators early yesterday by campus police men who entered the building through an underground pas sageway.

title: Gas Industry Favors Expansion Of F.P.O. Plan on Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 The oil and naturalgas indus try, backed by several states, has welcomed the Federal Pow er Commission's proposal for higher prices on new supplies of natural gas, but it said it should be broadened to permit price rises for gas now flow ing to the nation's 42 million gas consumers.

title: U.M.W. Election of Boyle Is Upset by Federal Judge
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A United States District Court judge here set aside today the election of W. A. Boyle as pres ident of the 200,000member United Mine Workers of America.

title: Title to Santa Monica
description: COSTA MESA, Calif., May 1 (AP)Sand and Sea, a sixman volleyball team from Santa Monica, Calif., won the Ama teur Athletic Union champion ship last night by beating the Balboa Bay Club of Balboa, Calif.

title: Speakers at L.I. Seminar Describe Deceptive Practices of Some Swimming Pool Sellers
description: GREENVALE, L.I., May 1 Many homeowners in the metropolitan area who buy swimming pools are getting soaked by shady construction companies, a Better Business Bureau seminar was told to day.

title: Relief Family in Renovated Housing
description: A welfare family moved yes terday from a hotel where the citypaid rent was $1,200 a month to a renovated apart ment in a Harlem tenement, marking the start of a program to relieve two of the city's most chronic problems  wel fare and housing.

title: GIA SCALA IS DEAD; FILM ACTRESS, 38
description: HOLLYWOOD, May 1 (AP) Gia Scala, the film actress, was found dead in the bedroom of her Hollywood home yesterday, the police reported today. An autopsy showed that the 38year old brunette died from an acci dental overdose of drugs and al cohol. The police said she had been taking medication for a drinking problem.

title: Jersey Schedules Special Session on Tax Proposals
description: TRENTON, May 1The Re publican legislative majority leaders announced today that they had scheduled a special legislative session in June to consider a proposed $1.8bil lion reform of New Jersey's tax structure.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: An English major who fol lowed up a degree from Bos ton University with law stud ies at the Suffolk University Law School in Boston, A member of the Massachusetts bar. Legal background valuable in investigative re porting. One editor says he knows where the records can be found.  Worked as general assignment reporter for The Boston Globe while getting his law degree. Interested in the counter culture, covered the Wood stock Festival in 1969. Was one of original members of The Globe's Spotlight Team. Born in Boston 28 years ago. Had worked on two investigations dealing with Boston's redevelopment authority and its relationship with a parkinglot operator.  Met team member Ann DeSantis and married her last year. Persuaded her to give up job with newspaper. The two live in Quincy, Mass.

title: Jeffrey K. MacNelly Editorial Cartooning
description: One of the youngest Pulitzer Prize winners. Born 24 years ago in New York City.  Reared in Cedarhurst, L. I. Attended Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass.; University of North Carolina.  Drawing for about 24 years.  Cartooning since college days. Started with sports, did brief service as college paper's sports editor.  Worked on Chapel Hill Weekly during college and for year afterward Won National Newspaper Association award for cartooning. Went to work for Richmond News Leader 18 months ago. Describes himself as a conservative cartoonist.  Lives in near by Manakin, Va., with wife, Marguerite, and 3monthold son, Jeffrey Kenneth Jr. Only hobbies, more cartoon ing, helping wife move fur niture.  Parents still live in Cedarhurst. Father, Clarence L., is a portrait painter.

title: New Form of Protest
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A new form of protest against corporate policies affecting the environment and employe safe ty was published here today by a lawyer associated with Ralph Nader.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AHOY Antiquarians and nautical buffs worth their salt could do worse than hoist anchor and set a course for P. J. McNally's at 144 Chambers Street, just west of West Broadway. Those familiar with the store when it was situated on Water Street will find that all the delightful clutter has been transported intact to the new location. Those unfamiliar with McNally's will find themseves amid treasures and triflesships' wheels, lamps fashioned from brass fittings, figureheads includ mg ananomaious cigar store Indian, scrimshaw, paintings, crockery, chronometers, sex tants, engine room tele graphs, capstan beads, old oil cans, ship models, bells and belaying pins.

title: Quangtri, Once Quiet Spot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1Before the North Vietnamese began sweeping down from the demilitarized zone, Quangtri Province had a population of 306,000, some 35,000 of them in the capital, Quangtri city.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 (UPI)  At least eight of the 20 delegates selected in cau cuses yesterday to represent Nevada at the Democratic con vention intend to support Sen ator George McGovern. Many of the others, while maintain ing, they are uncommitted, are believed to be leaning toward Senator Hubert H. Humphrey Nevada has 11 votes at the convention.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: A 25yearold police re porter for The Rochester TimesUnion. Born Dec. 8, 1946, in Grand Rapids, Mich., graduated in 1965 from Central Christian High School there, in 1967 from Grand Rapids Junior College, and in 1969 from Michigan State University with a B.A. in journalism. Had begun junior college as a biology major, but was strongly influ enced by an English profes sor named Walter Lockwood, who wanted his class to write something every week and rated Mr. Cooper's writing pretty good stuff, the prize winner recalls. Switched to a journalism major, but never served on the college paper because he had to work two jobsone as a shipping clerk in a factory, the other in a supermarketto pay his way through college. Lives with his wife and son in Rochester.

title: Rescue Operation Ends
description: Tuesday, May 2The United States command announced early this morning that rescue operations for the downed crew of a Navy P4 Phantom jet that was believed to have been shot down by a North Vietnamese MIG21 jet fighter last Tuesday had been called off.

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets turned in a narrowly mixed performance in quiet trading yesterday as they awaited the bulk of this week's financing, scheduled to reach the market today.

title: Rill Rates Are Mixed At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Yields on United States Treasury bills moved slightly in opposite directions in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities. In last week's sale, the average rate for 3month bills was 3.513 per cent and the average rate for 9month bills was 4.004 per cent.

title: Press Club Elects Raymond
description: The Overseas Press Club has elected Jack Raymond, former New York Times foreign cor respondent, as club president, Ithe organization announced (yesterday. Mr. Raymond suc ceeds Will Oursler, the author, who has ended a twoyear term. The new president heads the International Institute for Environmental Affairs.

title: ASTROS TOP PIRATES ON 2 RUNS IN 9TH, 98
description: PITTSBURGH, May 1 (UPI) The Houston Astros scored two runs in the ninth inning on sin gles by Jim Wynn, Lee May and Bob Watson and a sacrifice fly by Tommy Helms to hand the Pittsburgh Pirates their sixth straight defeat, 98, tonight.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Burly, sandyhaired former Mormon missionary had lost out for 1967 Pulitzer prize when advisory board rejected jury recommendation for na tional reporting award to Drew Pearson and him for exposs of financial affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut.  Took over the Washington MerryGo Round column after Mr. Pearson, its founder, died in 1969. Now commands seven man staff producing seven columns a week for 700 pa pers..  Joined Pearson staff in 1947 after Army service in China.  Column draws up to 300 letters a day, many containing tips.  Lectures, does syndicated radio and television, spots.  Speaks in evangelical style.  Be gan journalistic career at 12 as Boy Scout for Salt Lake City paper.  Married, fa ther of nine.

title: Canadian to Take High U.N. Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 1George F. Davidson, the president of the Cana dian Broadcasting Corpora tion and a former Canadian diplomat, will join the United Nations as Under Secretary General for Administration and. Management, Secretary General Waldheim announced today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Primary elections bearing on the Presidential nomina tions will take place today in Alabama, Indiana, Ohio and the District of Columbia.

title: Index of HelpWanted Ads Rose by 3 Points in March
description: The index of helpwanted ad vertising rose in March to 90 per cent of the 1967 average, up 3 points from the February level, The Conference Board re ported yesterday. The index now stands at 12 points over the level of March, 1971.

title: CATHOLICS CHECK ON PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Thousands of parents who send their children to Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn and Queens went to their local public schools yesterday to in quire about possible admission next fall.

title: Simplicity to Split Stock
description: Shareholders of the Simplici ty Pattern Company approved a proposed 3for1 split of the common stock yesterday. They also voted to increase the au thorized stock to 20,000,000 shares from 8,000,000 shares. The split is effective May 9.

title: IN THE NATION
description: On March 19, 1968, not long after the great Tet offensive in Vietnam, President Lyndon B. Johnson went be fore the National Foreign Policy Con ference to declare:

title: Ved Mehta's Private, Blind Universe
description: Ved Mehta was talking about his book, saying that he wanted it to please his father. The book, Daddyji, which will be published next week by Farrar, Strauss. & Giroux, is about the father; and it is about Ved Mehta, too.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislature Backs Formation Of Siting Unit for Power Plants
description: ALBANY, May 1The Legis lature approved today the crea tion of a power plant siting board that would have full au thority to overrule local zon ing regulations and settle con troversies involving utility, en vironmental and community factions.

title: SCOTIABANK APPOINTMENT
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia announces the appointment of E. D. Hunter as Assist ant General Manager and Senior Agent of its New York Agency. Before his present position Mr. Hunter held senior positions with the Bank in Canada, the Caribbean and Greece.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Born in New York City in 1909, graduated from City College in 1931 and earned a master's degree from Colum bia in 1932. Met Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and was befriended by her while he was active in Socialist politics in the nineteenthir ties. Helped found Amer icans for Democratic Action and was later active in Dem ocratic reform politics here.  From 1950 to 1961, was The New York Post's United Nations correspondent and until 1966 was assistant edi tor of the Post's editorial page. His Eleanor and Franklin, The Story of Their Relationship Based on Elea nor Roosevelt's Private Papers also won a National Book Award and the Francis Parkman Prize of the Society of American Historians. His wife, Trude, also knew Mrs. Roosevelt well. The Lashes and their son, Jona than, live in Manhattan.

title: 14, Most in a Decade, to Start in Derby Trial
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 The Derby Trial, which had been dwindling in the esteem of owners and trainers in re cent years, will bounce back to a point of considerable im portance in the 3yearold pic ture tomorrow with its 36th running.

title: ANTIFRANCO MARCH BROKEN UP IN MADRID
description: MADRID, May 1 (Reuters) Scores of antiGovernment demonstrators were arrested by riot police in Madrid today. Some 200, mainly students, were beaten by policemen as they attempted to march for May Day in a workingclass district.

title: Books of The Times
description: TWO: A PHALLIC NOVEL. By Alberto Moravia. Translated from the Italian by Angus David son. 353 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux $7.95.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1 No Title

title: Beame, in Albany, Says the City Needs Less Than It Asks
description: ALBANY, May 1New York City's Controller, Abraham D. Beame, told Democratic legis lative leaders today that the city needed only $40million in new state aid, not the $227 million the Lindsay adminis tration has asked for, to meet an anticipated budget gap for the next fiscal year.

title: Yugoslays, Soviet in Tie
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 1 (UPI)Yugoslavia held the favored Soviet Union soccer team to a scoreless tie yester day in the first round of the European Nations Cup quarter finals.

title: DUNCAN R. LINSLEY, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 1 Duncan Robertson Linsley, who retired in 1960 as vice chair man of the First Boston Cor poration, 20 Exchange Place, New York, investment bankers, died Saturday in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at Hill Farm Road.

title: DR. ARTHUR KEMPER, TAUGHT CHEMISTRY
description: Dr. Arthur B. Kemper, pro fessor emeritus of chemistry at Manhattan College, died Satur day in Newton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 22 Metropolitan Oval in the Parkchester section of the Bronx.

title: Last Trip for Famed British Train
description: BRIGHTON, England, May 1They said farewell early this morning to the Brighton Belle, with champagne, bands, roses, memories, sadness and even a touch of bitterness.

title: Offering Called Routine By American International
description: American International Group, Inc., whose stock fell 4 points on the overthecounter market yesterday, disclosed last night that an offering of 1,536,186 shares it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Com mission was strictly routine.

title: RentRise Notices On Controlled Units Due Here June 10
description: Maximum base rent orders for 980,000 or the city's 1,019, 000 rentcontrolled apartments will have been sent to tenants and landlords by June 10, Rob ert C. Rosenberg, assistant ad ministrator of the Housing and Development Administration, said yesterday.

title: Blue Will Sign Contract With A's in Boston Today
description: Vida Blue announced yesterday through his attorney, Robert Gerst, that he would report to the Oakland Ath letics today in Boston and was prepared to sign a contract with the team.

title: STANFORD VETOES SHOCKLEY COURSE
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., May 1 Dr. William Shockley, a Nobel laureate whose views on race have made him controversial, was notified today that he would not be permitted to of fer a special course for Stan ford University graduate stu dents on his theories about in heritance of intelligence.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Okinawa Awaiting Reversion Nervously
description: NAHA, Okinawa, April 20 The sign on Okinawa's faded executive office building pro claims, in Japanese, 25 Days to Reversion, and the number is changed each morning. But as the longsought day ap proaches, an air of apprehen sion hangs like the clouds over this sultry militarized island.

title: For Gains in Binh dinh
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 2North Viet namese troops continued their advances in northern Binhdinh Province on the central coast yesterday, taking Tamquan Dis trict and tightening their seige of the Vietnamese 40th Regi ment's headquarters at Landing Zone English, six miles north of Bongson.

title: Martin Processing And HCA Industries Planning a Merger
description: HCA Industries, Inc., is planning to enter the business of processing synthetic carpet yarn through a proposed merg er with the Martin Processing Company, Inc.; of Martinsville, Va., a privately owned com pany, for stock valued at about $22million.

title: Abusing the Diploma
description: The Assembly by overwhelming vote has approved a measure that can only have the effect of undermining young people's respect for both the Legislature and the schools. The bill, sponsored by Assemblyman John A. Esposito, RepublicanConservative of Queens, would withhold high school diplomas from students who have failed to show performance and growth in the vital areas of character and citizenship development.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bicycle Lock Foils Thieves
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 (UPI)  The Massachusetts In stitute of Technology has an nounced the development by two undergraduates of a thief proof bicycle lock made from a steel alloy similar to ship's armor. The singlejointed, pear shaped loop resisted all at tempts at cutting, filing or smashing made by the M.I.T. campus patrol. It weighs three pounds.

title: Homosexual's Ordination Voted In the United Church of Christ
description: SAN CARLOS, Calif. May 1 (AP)After a fourhour debate, delegates of 19 San Francisco Bay area churches of the United Church of Christ have approved the ordination of an affirmed homesexual.

title: 25 Protesting Women Held At Massachusetts Air Base
description: WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., May 1 (AP)  About 25 women were arrested today at the main gate to West over Air Force Base in Chico pee in the sixth day of antiwar protests at the base.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (UPI)A group of Democrats plans a 19hour telethon on the eve of the party's nation al convention with the hope of eliminating much of its $9.3million debt.

title: Ridge Above ExC.I.A. Base Reported Taken by Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 1 (AP) Laotian troops have regained complete control of vital sky line Ridge, overlooking the former United States Central Intelligence Agency base, of Long Tieng, 80 miles northeast of Vientiane, informed sources said today.

title: Respite in Bonn
description: The time has come for cool heads, said Rainer Barzel, leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Union, after two days of bitter debate and cliffhanger votes in the Bundestag had dramatized West Germany's worst postwar political crisis. Mr. Barzel was echoing an earlier call for national unity and parliamentary coopera tion by Chancellor Willy Brandt, who had survived a noconfidence motion by two votes, only to lose a crucial rollcall on the budget on a 247to247 tie.

title: 5 OLYMPIC RIDERS CHOSEN FOR U.S.
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., May 1  Five riders, headed by Bill Steinkraus, the defending gold medal winner, were named today to the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic Prix des Nations (jump ing) squad.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: After doing some graduate work at Harvard, decided to stay in Boston. Got job with The Boston Globe and became research assistant for the newspaper's Spotlight Team of investigative report ers. Met Stephen A. Kurk jian, another team member, and became Mrs. Kurkjian last year. Born in Schenectady 25 years ago.  Received degree from St. Lawrence University. First newspaper job was as reporter for The Schenectady Gazette. Generally col lated and coordinated the material gathered by the Spotlight Team, but also wrote some stories. Left The Globe after her engage ment and is now publicity director of Cahners Publica tion Company, Inc., of Bos ton.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President returned here in early after noon from visits to Florida and Texas. He met with a group of White House secre taries. Later he had a meet ing with Gerard C. Smith, United States disarmament negotiator, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird and Adm. Thomas Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Gibson Continues His Opposition To Housing Board Appointment
description: NEWARK, May 1  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has charged that the State Community Affairs Commissioner, Lawrence Kramer, was pressured into ap pointing to the City Housing Authority a former state legis lator once linked with mem bers of organized, crime.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: A 51yearold educator and historian. Won prize for Neither Black Nor White: Slavery and Race Relations in Brazil and the United States  The work, pub lished last year by Macmillan, also won a Brancroft Prize this year  Born in Orange, N. J., Feb. 6, 1921  Earned A.B. at Upsala College, 1942, M.A. in 1947 from Columbia and Ph.D. from Columbia in 1952  Taught at Hunter, Adelphi and City Colleges be fore joining Vassar faculty in 1952  Became professor of history there in 1962, chair man of department in 1966  Joined Stanford U. fac ulty in 1968  Is also auth or of Out of Our Past: The Forces That Shaped Modern America (1959)  Also wrote Pivotal Interpreta tions of American History, (1966) Age of Economic Revolution. (1967) Afflu ence and Anxiety (1968)  Director of National Organi zation for Women  Mar ried, two children.

title: Nets Win and Even Series
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May  The New York Nets defeated the Virginia Squires, 146136, at the Nassau Coliseum tonight, tying the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division final at three victories apiece. The deciding game of the series will be played Thursday night at Norfolk, Va.

title: Executive Changes
description: David Dibner has been elected chairman and Richard C. Parley, president of the Burndy Corpora tion. They succeed Dr. Birn Dibner and Julian Rogoff, respectively, who have retired.

title: U.S. Indicts G.M. and Ford For Car Fleet PriceFixing
description: DETROIT, May 1  The nation's two largest  auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, were charged today by a Federal grand jury withviolating antitrust laws by conspiring to refuse to cut car prices to fleet buyers.

title: Taiwan Tracking Station
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 1  Nationalist China opened its first satellite tracking station at Tainan in South Taiwan, to day. The station is located at Chengkung University.

title: Japan's Color TV Output Up
description: TOKYO, May 1 (UPI)Pro duction of color television re ceivers in Japan spurted 57.9 per cent in March from a year earlier to 654,138, the Japan Electronic Industry Association reported today. Shipments were up 12.4 per cent to 631,415, but exports declined 1.2 per cent to 140,778.

title: YONKERS MEETING SHOWS A DEFICIT
description: YONKERS, May 1Compared with the corresponding rac ing dates of 1970, business during the first 52 nights of Yonkers Raceway's current har ness meeting has dropped 14.3 per cent in average attendance and 5.2 per cent in average mutuel handle.

title: HANOI SAYS DMZ IS NOT A BORDER
description: HONG KONG, May 1 (AP) The official North Vietna mese radio declared today that the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam was not an international border and that movement of tanks, artil lery and troops across it did not constitute invasion.

title: $55Million Deal Set
description: The CNA Financial Corpora tion said yesterday, that its CNA Leasing subsidiary had signed agreements with two Middle Western utilities cover ing the purchase and leaseback of $55million in nuclear fuel. The agreements cover a $37 million purchaseandleaseback agreement with the Wisconsin Electric Power Company and an $18million pact with the IowaIllinois Gas and Electric Company.

title: Senators Told of Blockbusting In a Financial Conspiracy Here
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A Senate subcommittee was told here today that the real estate industry, insurance companies and financial institutions were using Federal housing pro grams to achieve blockbusting in New York City.

title: U.S. VOICES HOPE OF EXPANDED PACT ON LIMITING ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The White House said today that private exchanges between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist party leader, had ad vanced the prospect for a sig nificant broadening of the scope of an agreement limit ing strategic arms.

title: Giving Brandt a Chance
description: WASHINGTONIn one of the most fateful and uncertain votes of recent years, an almost evenly divided West German Bundestag will shortly be asked to ratify the treaties Chancellor Brandt has negotiated with Moscow and Warsaw.

title: MSGR. ROBERT DELANEY
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 1 Msgr. Robert E. Delaney, pastor emeritus of SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church here, died today in the Mary Manning Walsh Home in New York. He was 73 years old.

title: Howell Signs Kings Pact
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (AP) Harry Howell, who last week was reported to have agreed to coach the Raiders of New York in the new World Hockey Asso ciation, signed his 197273 con tract as a player for the Los Angeles Kings today, the Na tional Hockey League team re ported.

title: Hartford Will Try to Redraw State Districts Today
description: HARTFORD, May 1The Connecticut General Assembly will meet tomorrowthe day before it is required by the State Constitution to adjourn in a final effort to agree on a reapportionment plan and permit election processes and political life in the state to get back on their normal, hec tic, electionyear course.

title: NATIONAL EXCHANGE STARTS NEW TICKER
description: The National Stock Exchange yesterday began operation here of its new highspeed ticker system at 11:30 A.M. in its headquarters at 6 Harrison Street.

title: U.S. Is Indignant That Hanoi Steps Up Fighting While Pressing the Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The State Department said today that the Government was deeply upset and indignant that while the North Vietnam ese were pressing for a nego tiated settlement of the Vietnam war their invasion of the. South has not only not slackened, but, if anything, has increased in intensity in recent days.

title: Industrial Needs Push Gold Price Over $50
description: LONDON, May 1 (AP) Sustained industrial demand sent the price of gold above $50 an ounce today, a post World War II record.

title: Linda Tuero Takes Title In Italian Open, 6.4, 6.3
description: ROME, May 1 (UPI)Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., who failed to win a tournament last year, defeated Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union, 64, 63, to day and became the third American in four years to cap ture the women's singles title in the Italian open tennis cham pionships.

title: Oil Group Cites Gain
description: The Noordwinning Group an nounced yesterday that its first well on Block K13 on the Netherlands Continental shelf is a significant gas discovery.

title: Gerard M. O'Neill Special Local Reporting
description: Started journalistic career as a copyboy at The Boston Globe and worked his way through the suburban desk, city hall and statehouse bu reaus to his current job of editor of the Spotlight Team.  Received United Press International Civic Service Award in 1970 for articles on Boston school committee man and a city contractor.

title: ALLIED PROGRAM FAILS A KEY TEST
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, May 1In Binhdinh Province, here on the coast of Central Vietnam, three countysize dis tricts with a combined popula tion of 200,000 have fallen to Communist attacks in two weeks with little real resistance.

title: Defense Offers No Witnesses; Holder Verdict Due Tomorrow
description: MINEOLA, L. L, May 1 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Paul Widlitz indicated today that he would announce his verdict on Wednesday in the case of a Brooklyn school principal ac cused of conspiring with one of his teachers to murder his wife.

title: STEIN COUNTERING FEARS ON PROFITS
description: Herbert Stein, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, sought to allay business fears yesterday that the Administration was seeking to put a harsh limit on corporate profits.

title: Teachers' Funds to Back 2 of 7 Dissident Proposals
description: The economically and social ly influential Teachers In surance and Annuity Associa tion and College Retirement Equities Fund announced yes terday their decisions on the voting of proxies an stockhold er proposals to come before the annual meetings in May of the General Motors Corpora tion, the Ford Motor Company and the WarnerLambert Com pany.

title: Horst Faas Photography
description: Has known almost nothing but war all his adult life Born in Berlin, 1933. Be gan career as photography salesman in Dusseldorf Joined A.P. in Berlin in 1956.

title: A.C.L.U. Files Suit
description: KENT, Ohio, May 2 (UPI) Acting just two days before the statute of limitations expired, the Ohio branch of the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union named 29 National Guardsmen today as codefendants in a $1 million damage suit resulting from the 1970 disorders at Kent State in which four persons died.

title: Desert Tracts to Be Recreation Lands
description: BRAWLEY, Calif., May 1  In one of the largest allocations of the public domain in United States history, Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Mor ton dedicated today 19 tracts in the Southern California desert, covering 4,200 square miles, as Recreation Lands.

title: Canadian Government Statement on Foreign Takeovers of Businesses
description: OTTAWA, May 2 (Cana dian Press)Following is the text of a policy statement on foregin takeovers of busi nesses, delivered in the House of Commons today by Reve nue Minister Herb Gray:

title: Theater: That Championship Season Is a Winner
description: Wow! Here at last is the perfect Broadway play of the season, perfectly acted and perfectly staged. There is only one minor thing wrong with it. It happens not to be on Broadway. The play is Jason Miller's That Cham pionship Season, and it opened last night at the handsome Newman Theater in Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater complex. It is gor geous and triumphant.

title: DECLINES SHOWN BY AMEX PRICES
description: Discouraged investors con tinued to sell enough shares yesterday so that the Ameri can Stock Exchange index dropped by 0.13 to close at 27.63. In the overthecounter market, trading was described as moderately heavy and prices sharply lower. The NASDAQ index closed at 137, off 1.04.

title: INCREASE BACKED IN GATEWAY PARK
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 A House Interior subcommittee reached tentative agreement today on a Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor that would include more land than the Senate authorized for the project last year.

title: Sale of Ship to U.S. Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)  The Senate unanimously ap proved legislation today to per mit sale of the liner the United States to the Government as a troop ship and to allow five other Government  subsidized passenger vessels now in moth balls to be sold abroad.

title: ROCK AURA FRAMES SHOW BY PINK FLOYD
description: Pink Floyd, the English rock group, is more concerned, I sus pect, with light and sound than with the driving rhythms of traditional rock. The group's concert at Carnegie Hall Mon day night was a characteristic excursion through a Dantesque Purgatory of shrieks, electronic wails, exploding flames and choking smoke.

title: SALES EDGE AHEAD AT RETAIL STORES
description: Sales of major New York department stores last month reflected the whims of the calendar. They ran only slightly ahead of April a year ago be cause of March Easter sales this year against the April Easter of 1971.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein submitted to the County Legislature in Riverhead, L. I., yesterday a $700million, threeyear capital program and what he said would be an annual environmental report. The report proposed that the county engage in the cleanup of all major oil spills, demanding reimbursement by the polluter or the Federal Government.

title: Basil Lermont, 69, Inyentor Of ConstantTension Spring
description: Basil Lermont, a metallurgical engineer and inventor, died of a heart attack on Monday eve ning at his home, 31 Sutton Place. He was 69 years old and also had a home on Center Is land, Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: Alexander Lenard, 62, Dies; Translated Pooh Into Latin
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 2 (AP)  Alexander Lenard, the Hungarian  born scholar who translated Winnie the Pooh into Latin, died April 14 in southern Bran at the age of 62.

title: SELECTION BEGINS FOR NAPIER JURY
description: The selection of a jury be gan yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens in the murder arson trial of four Black Pan thers charged with the 1971 slaying of another Panther, Samuel Napier, in what had been termed a factional feud over party philosophy.

title: Binhdinh Chief Calls for Help
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, May 2 (UPI)The Binhdinh Province chief, Col. Nguyen Van Chuc, warned today he needed immediate reinforce ments or strategic Phumy Dis trict would fall within a week.

title: DeBusschere Doubtful Tonight
description: What will probably prove to be the pivotal game of the Na tional Basketball Association championship series takes place tonight at Madison Square Garden at 8:40 P.M., with the New York Knicks and Los Angeles Lakers tied, 11, in the fourofseven competi tion. It will be televised on Channel 7.

title: Mao's Wife Takes Part In Canton May Day Fete
description: HONG KONG, May 2 Chiang Ching, wife of Mao Tsetung, appeared in Can ton yesterday to take part in May Day celebrations.

title: Jordanian Official Said to Offer To Quit After Being Assaulted
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2 Informed travelers from Am man say that Foreign Minister Abdullah Salah of Jordan has submitted his resignation to King Hussein after being beaten up in his own office by a high ranking official in the ministry.

title: Red Cross Reports It Helps 350,000 Vietnam Refugees
description: GENEVA, May 2More than 350,000 refugees in the Viet namese war zones are being as sisted by the South Vietnamese Red Cross, the League of Red Cross Societies said today.

title: G.O.P. GOVERNORS BACK NIXON POLICY
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 2 (UPI)Repub lican Governors approved to day a resolution endorsing and urging Congressional support for President Nixon's foreign and domestic program, but made no mention of the Ad ministration's Vietnam bombing policy.

title: SECRETDATA RULE HELD STEP AHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Under Congressional attack today, Pentagon and State De partment officials defended terms used in President Nixon's Executive order on document secrecy.

title: ROYAL SEASON JOINED BY MARGOT FONTEYN
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn made her first appearance of the Royal Ballet's season at the Metropolitan Opera House Mon day night, and the roars that greeted her testified to the spe cial place she will always hold in the collective heart of the New York audience.

title: QUARTET OFFERS DRUCKMAN PIECE
description: Jacob Druckman had al ready received one break earlier in the day when the 1972 Pulitzer Prize in composition was awarded to him. Then, as the 44yearold Juilliard School teacher sat in the New School Auditorium Monday night lis tening to the Concord String Quartet playing his String Quartet No. 2 (1966), another break, less welcome, came his way. Quite far along into the performance, the cellist's D string snapped and the work had to be adjourned while a replacement was found.

title: Lennon Win a Skirmish In Battle to Remain in U.S.
description: John Lennon, the former Beatle, and his wife, Yoko Ono, won a preliminary skirm ish yesterday in their fight to remain in the United States when the Immigration and Naturalization Service ruled yesterday they were outstand ing artists, a possible ground for granting permanent resi dence.

title: Action Is Urged to Protect Diplomats
description: GENEVA, May 2An Ameri can legal expert suggested to day that anyone who murders or kidnaps, or inflicts grievous bodily harm on a foreign dip lomat or visiting government official be punished as an inter national criminal.

title: McGovern Flies Here For Samuels Backing
description: Senator George McGovern made a 900mile round trip from Ohio to New York yes terday to receive the endorsement of Howard Samuels, chairman of the Off Track Betting Corporation, at a LaGuardia Airport news conference.

title: Fanny May's Commitments On Mortgages Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (Reuters)  The Federal Na tional Mortgage Association issued a record $336.4million in fourmonth commitments of Governmentbacked home mortgages at its latest auction yesterday, the agency said.

title: RAND TOLD TO GIVE DATA ON ELLSBERG
description: LOS ANGELES, May 2 (UPI) A Federal district judge or dered the Rand Corporation today to produce documents that Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's de fense counsel hopes will show that the Pentagon papers were never the property of the Government.

title: 2 Charged With Attempt To Impersonate Hijacker
description: SEATTLE, May 2 (AP)The Federal Government charged two Washington men today with a plot to impersonate an airline hijacker known as D. B. Cooper in order to ex tort more than $30,000 from a former contributing editor of Newsweek magazine.

title: Fauntroy Slats Wins in Capital Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Rev. Walter E. Fauntroy, a non voting member of Congress, gained control of the Democrat ic party in the District of Co lumbia as His favorite son candidacy for President swept to an easy victory in primary elections here today.

title: National Gallery Unveils 6 Films By Kenneth Clark on Modern Art
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 Everyone here agrees that the highly successful Civilisation, Kenneth Clark's 13part televi sion series reviewing the cul tural history of Western man, is a hard act to follow. But it has now been followed by none other than Lord Clark himself, with Pioneers of Modern Painting, a new series on the work of key 19thcentury art ists, produced originally for British television and unveiled today at a press preview in the National Gallery of Art.

title: State Senate Votes to Widen Gambling
description: ALBANY, May 2  The Sen ate voted today to amend the Constitution to permit the legal ization of various forms of gambling that are now illicit.

title: Youth Elected to School Board In Face of Lefkowitz's Ruling
description: A 19yearold youth was elected yesterday to a local school board upstate, despite an opinion by Attorney Gen eral Louis J. Lefkowitz on Monday that persons under 21 could not hold elective office under present state law.

title: 5 Dead, 77 Missing In Idaho Mine Fire
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 2  Fire swept through the nation's deepest and richest silver mine today, killing at least five miners and leaving 77 unac counted for in the rugged hills of northern Idaho.

title: Bill to Stop Forest Hills Project Gets Final Passage in Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 2The As sembly gave final passage today to a bill designed to kill the controversial Forest Hills low income housing project.

title: MINERS' OFFICIAL HELD IN SLAYINGS
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 Albert E. Pass, a high official of the United Mine Workers of America, was arrested today in the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daugh ter, the Federal Bureau of In vestigation said.

title: Lieut. Fletcher Hueston
description: The suicide of a Brooklyn police lieutenant and the cor ruption accusations against him and a score of his fellow po licemen sent widening circles of anguish through the borough and the Police Department yes terday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Trial for Hijacking Susect
description: SAN DIEGO, May 2 (UPI) Stanley H. Speck, 31 years old, of San Francisco was declared mentally competent today to stand trial on a charge of hijacking a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner on April 9. After the ruling in Federal Dis trict Court here, a plea of inno cent was entered for Mr. Speck by his attorney and a hearing was set for May 11.

title: Museum Honors Curator, 85, Back From Pacific Tour
description: Under the tail of the great blue whale model that dives from the ceiling, grog and sea chanteys were served last night as 600 employes and volunteers of the American Museum of Natural History held a family party in the Hall of Ocean Life.

title: GREECE ACTS TO CURB STUDENT AGITATION
description: ATHENS, May 2The Gov ernment has taken action to curb mounting agitation by students.

title: Nixon Gets Plea on F.B.I.
description: The Committee for Public Justice of the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation wired President Nixon yester day asking him to appoint a new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation whose commitment to the investiga tive functions of the bureau will be equaled by his devo tion to the Bill of Rights and the protection of individual lib erties.

title: Kent State Ends Surveillance Of Students by School Police
description: KENT, Ohio, May 2  Dr. Glenn Olds, the president of Kent State University, has an nounced the end of surveillance of campus organizations by university police.

title: ABORTION REPEAL GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 2Although Governor Rockefeller has said he would veto it, the Assem bly Codes Committee today let out on the floor a bill to repeal the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: Mrs. Norma Wilk Wed To Bert N. Obrentz
description: Mrs. Norma Bloomberg Wilk, widow of Maurice Wilk, the concert violinist, was married here yesterday evening to Bert N. Obrentz.

title: Parole Panel Member Quits
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) William F. Howland Jr. is re signing from the Federal Parole Board and retiring after 40 years of service, the White House announced today. His successor has not been deter mined.

title: Playing It by Ear
description: The Administration has exempted about five million small businessesthose with sixty or fewer employes from wage and price controls. The Cost of Living Council says that this action will enable it to focus its enforce ment efforts on the larger companies, which have much greater market power, and upon the construction and healthservice industries, which, it says, continue to have a serials inflationary impact.

title: LILLEY FORECASTS PHONE RATE RISE
description: The president of the Ameri can Telephone And Telegraph Company, Robert D. Lilley, warned, yesterday that despite voluminous consumer com plaints about poor phone serv ice we are going to have to charge higher prices.

title: After Almost Half a Century, the Process of Selecting a Director of the F.B.I. Begins
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The word drifted down through the bureaucracy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here this afternoon just about the time an informal meeting was taking place in the office of the Attorney Generaldesig nate, Richard G. Kleindienst.

title: Grodin Work Due in Nyack
description: Alan Arkin and Renee Taylor will costar in The Opening, a new comedy by Charles Gro din, which will be presented for one week at the Tappan Zee Playhouse, Nyack, N.Y., start ing May 15, The cast also in cludes Doris Roberts and Louise Lasser. Mr. Grodin will direct.

title: GANGSTYLE DEATH IS REPORTED HERE
description: In the 10th ganglandstyle slaying here this spring, Alfred Bianco, a contractor, was shot at 6;25 A.M. yesterday as he sipped coffee at a luncheonette in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section, long frequented by Mafiosi.

title: LOSS IS REVERSED IN SOYBEAN PRICES
description: A late rally accompanied by a short covering sharply re versed a 2centsabushel loss in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, and the commodity closed 2 cents to 1 cents a bushel higher.

title: Pepitone Quits Baseball; No Longer Interested
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) Joe Pepitone, colorful and controversial most of his 10 season big league career, sur prised the Chicago Cubs to day by announcing he was quitting baseball.

title: KAHANE IS WARNED ON ADVOCATING GUNS
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of the Jewish Defense League, was warned in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to end his advocacy of use of guns by Jews or face jail on a court order to disassociate himself from the league.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEThe saddest aspect of Italy's current election campaign, which ends with a critical vote on Sunday, is the pattern of violence and organized ter rorism on its fringes of extremism, particularly that of the revolutionary left.

title: MISS DAVIS HEARD ON ISSUE AT TRIAL
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 2 Angela Davis took the stand for the first time in her mur derconspiracy trial today in a defense attempt to bar the testimony of a prosecution witness. She testified in the absence of the jury.

title: Nixon Leads Officials in Paying Tribute to the Director of F.B.I.
description: Following are tributes to J. Edgar Hoover that were ex 4pressed yesterday:

title: Ashe Downs Richey
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 2 (AP) Arthur Ashe defeated Cliff Richey, 76, 46, 64, as the $50,000 Alan King tennis tournament began today. It is a stop on the World Champion ship Tennis tour.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Reserves Rose By $58Million in April
description: LONDON, May 2 (Reuters) Britain's official reserves rose by $58million to $7.13 billion in April after transac tions in connection with the repayment of the whole of the outstanding debt to the International Monetary Fund, the Treasury reported today.

title: OVERCALL PUT OFF; ONLY TWO ENTRIES
I.L.A. CHIEF URGES A FULL WAGE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The president of the International Longshoremen's Association asked the Pay Board today to approve in full the wage set tlements negotiated for dock workers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts to assure three years of industrial peace in the longshore industry.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2Rosyfingered dawn stood tiptoe on the misty clubhouse roof when Edward Sweat, the groom who works for Riva Ridge, led his boss out the barn on the muddy backside of Churchill Downs. Riva Ridge is an unusually pale bay with a coat the color of expensive luggage. Unusually tall for a colt that reached his third birthday only three weeks agohe was foaled in Paris, Ky., April 13, 1969he carries his head proudly high, as befits a champion who earned half a million dollars as a 2yearold, has won two of his three starts this year and is as sure as anything can be in racing to go to the post as favorite in the 98th Kentucky Derby Saturday.

title: Brandt Confers With Opposition To Seek a Compromise on Pacts
description: BONN, May 2Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government held talks behind the scenes with its Opposition today to seek a compromise leading to ratification of Bonn's contra versial treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: Peruvians Indicate Growing Dissatisfaction With the Military Government
description: LIMA, Peru, April 29Tra ditionally, the tone of political jokes in Lima and the populari ty of a political party that has spent all of its 40 years in opposition have been good guides to popular moods in Peru.

title: Feltrinelli's Passport Found With Arms in Milan HideOut
description: MILAN, Italy, May 2 (AP) Policemen investigating the death of milionaire leftwing publisher Giangiacomo Feltrin elli in an explosion said they found his passport and a large cache of weapons today in a guerrilla hideout here.

title: Sparkman Leads in Alabama Democratic Primary
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 Senator John J. Sparkman took a commanding lead to night over six challengers in his race for renomination in the Alabama Democratic pri mary.

title: Cleveland Polling MixUp Angers 2 Top Candidates
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 2 A massive failure of voting ma chines in the Cleveland area to day angered the two major Democratic Presidential candi dates and drastically slowed the counting of ballots in Ohio's primary election.

title: Quarry in London Bout
description: LONDON, May 2 (UPI)Jerry Quarry, California heavyweight, signed today to meet Larry Middleton of Baltimore in a 10round fight at Wembley next Tuesday.

title: Woman Dogcatcher Ordered
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)An attorney for the village of Northbrook, a Chicago suburb, said today that he would appeal a ruling by a hearing examiner of the Fair Employment Prac tices Commission that a 20 yearold brunette must be hired as dogcatcher. Kenneth Moy, the hearing examiner, ruled yesterday that Alice Waterman had been denied the job as Northbrook dogcatcher on the basis of sex.

title: Dr. Harold Barnes Dead at 76; Optometrist Was Boxing Judge
description: Dr. Harold R. Barnes, a re tired optometrist and examiner in that profession for the State Board of Regents and known by prizefighting fans as a judge in professional boxing here  died Monday at his home, 1 Hillcrest Place, Locust Valley, L. I. He was 76 years old.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market, which had advanced for the better part of two weeks, stumbled over sev eral giant financings yesterday and fell head over heels. As a result, longterm interest rates rose on a broad front, though rates in the money market remained largely unchanged. These were the principal developments in an unusually busy underwriting session:

title: Advertising:
description: The former editor in chief of Essence, the service maga zine for black women, is now publisher of Encore, a new magazine for both sexes.

title: Wounded Left Behind In Quangtri Retreat
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 2 (AP) A United States Navy doctor, who was among the last Americans evacuated from Quangtri, said hundreds of South Vietnamese wound ed were left behind because there was no way to get them out.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CURB ON WAR PAPERS IS UPHELD BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (Reu ters)Senate critics of the In dochina war, in a lenghty and unusual secret Senate session, were defeated tonight in an at tempt to place into the public record a recently disclosed Nixon administration study questioning the effectiveness of largescale bombing in Viet nam.

title: Retreat Leaves Small Unit Of Marines Facing Enemy
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 2 Thousands of panicking South Vietnamese soldiers most of whom did not appear to have made much contact with the advancing North Viet namesefled in confusion from Quangtri Province today, streaming south down Route 1 like a rabble out of control.

title: J. Edgar Hoover Made the F.B.I. Formidable With Politics, Publicity and Results
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  When J. Edgar Hoover ambled through the Mayflower Hotel after one of his ritual fruit saladandcoffee lunches late last year, he passed almost un noticed.

title: Jackson Cites Lack of Funds in Quitting
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednes day, May 3Senator Henry M. Jackson withdrew last night from active contention for the Democratic Presidential nom ination after finishing a weak fourth here despite weeks of campaigning.

title: ANGELS SUBDUED BY STOTTLEMYRE AND YANKEES, 50
description: Finally getting his stuff to gether, Mel Stottlemyre, the ace of the New York Yankee staff, won his first game of the sea son last night as he scattered seven hits and shut out the California Angels, 50, at Yan kee Stadium.

title: A Twin Proposed for Unapproved L. I. Atomic Plant
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., May 2 The Long Island Lighting Com pany is planning to build a sec ond nuclear powergenerating facility next to the site of one for which the utility still has not received an Atomic Energy Commission construction per mit.

title: Two Bills for Aborting
description: Bowing to the antiabortion pressure exerted on them at Albany, members of the Assembly Codes Committee yesterday reported a bill that would totally repeal New York State's model abortion reform law.

title: Nixon's Hardest Decision
description: President Nixon is now approaching another critical decision in Vietnam: What to do if the enemy stops the in vasion before or after the battle for the former Vietnamese capital of Hue, and offers to make a deal while Hanoi is in control of a large part of the north of South Vietnam?

title: Sheehan of Time Among 10 Given Sidney Hillman Awards
description: Neil Sheehan, the reporter for The New York Times who ob tained, investigated and sum marized the secret Pentagon Papers on the Vietnam war published by the paper, was among those who received Sidney Hillman Foundation awards yesterday for outstand ing achievement in mass Com munications during 1971.

title: CELTICS NOT SOLD, KENNEDY ASSERTS
description: Commissioner Walter Ken nedy of the National Basket ball Association sought to clarify yesterday three issues in question the last two weeks.

title: Film Academy Weighs Voting Changes
description: HOLLYWOOD, May 2  The Academy of Motion Pic ture Arts and Sciences, of ten accused of being a con servative group run by Hol lywood's geriatric set, is con sidering new ways of inject ing fresh policymaking blood, weeding out of voting mem bers who haven't had a film credit in years and selecting of foreign films.

title: Mayor Names 29YearOld Aide Rent and Housing Commissioner
description: Nathan Leventhal, 29year old special assistant to Mayor Lindsay, was appointed yester day Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance.

title: Police Find 15 Fire Bombs In Bronx and Jail 12 Boys
description: Twelve youths, aged 14 to 16, were arrested in the Mor risania section of the Bronx last night when the police un covered a cache of 15 Molotov cocktails on a roof. A loaded hunting rifle was also confis cated when one of the youths allegedly pointed it at police men on the roof.

title: Undercover Agents Were Used In Gathering Payoff Evidence
description: At least two policemen and possibly some gamblers were used as undercover agents to develop evidence against the 24 policemen indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of accept ing payoffs from policy oper ators and bookmakers, accord ing to law enforcement sources.

title: SOME FINES ARE HELD NEGOTIABLE IN N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The National Football League Players' Association, which has insisted that installation of synthetic turf and player fines are negotiable items, was up held today by a regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Washington Aides, Discouraged, Hint At Wider Bombings
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Administration officials tried publicly today to put a brave face on their reaction to news of the battle in South Vietnam, but throughout the Government there were widespread signs of growing pessimism.

title: CHICANO STUDENTS CALLED OPPRESSED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 The United States Commission on Civil Rights charged today that MexicanAmerican pupils were being oppressed in the schools of five states.

title: PRINCIPALS CALLED FOES OF SCRIBNER
description: The president of the Board of Education charged yesterday that some principals were rais ing the issue of violence in the schools in an effort to discredit the leadership of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and to pres sure the board to buy, up his contract.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Race in Ohio Is Close
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednes day, May 3Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George McGovern of South Dakota were locked in a tight race early today in the Ohio Presidential primary.

title: MISS ELSIE SWEENEY, MUSIC PATRON, DEAD
description: COLUMBUS, Ind., May 2 Elsie Irwin Sweeney, a pianist and music patron who had been honored for war work by the German and British Gov ernments, died today at Cas talia, her country home.

title: J. Edgar Hoover, 77, Dies; Will Lie in State in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, May 2J. Edgar Hoover, who directed the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation for 48 years and built it into a dominant and con troversial force in American law enforcement, died during the night from the effects of high blood pressure.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Marijuana Petition
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UPI)Backers of the Califor nia marijuana initiative filed yesterday 319,000 of the 326, 504 voter signatures needed to get the measure rescinding marijuana penalties on the No vember ballot. The filing was the first of two prescribed by law and will be followed in about seven weeks with an other filing.

title: 24 POLICE INDICTED IN A BRIBERY CASE
description: Three police sergeants, 20 patrolmen and one patrolwom an were arrested and suspend ed from the Police Department yesterday after they were in dicted and accused of taking a quarter of a million dollars annually in payoffs to protect gamblers linked to the Mafia.

title: Victory for the Miners
description: The decision of a Federal judge upsetting the scandal tainted 1969 election in the United Mine Workers will give the nation's coal miners their first chance in a half century to practice genuine trade union democracy. The judge's findings validate rankandfile charges that the union's treasury, staff and publications were converted into a ruthless machine for suppressing effective chal lenge of the dictatorial rule of the U.M.W. president, W. A. Boyle.
