description: MOSCOW, May 5The Sov iet Union today unveiled some details of its 350passenger air bus, being designed by the Ilyushin group. The giant plane is expected to go into service on Soviet domestic routes about 1975.

title: New Offer Made for Kings Lafayette
description: Merger News

title: Derby Bettors Send It In Despite Lines at OTB Shops
description: Using hunches, handicapping and hatpins, New York horse players stepped up their bet ting yesterday on today's 98th Kentucky Derby.

title: PostVietnam Syndrome
description: Steve stiffened, looked around fear fully, and thought, These people all look alike. How do I know who's friend and who's enemy? Then he shook himself, remembering: They are all your friends. This is Times Square, U.S.A. Eighteen months after a nonpsychiatric discharge following four years Marine combat duty in the Nam, Steve still suffers unpre dictable episodes of terror and dis orientation.

title: ARLIN OF PADRES DOWNS METS, 60
description: For Steve Arlin, who earned a degree in dentistry at Ohio State, winning games for the San Diego Padres has been a lot tougher than pulling teeth, but he won another one last night by shutting out the New York Mets, 60, on four hits before 21.262 at Shea Stadium.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS AN ABORTION BILL
description: ALBANY, May 5Governor Rockefeller today sent the Leg islature a bill that would mod ify the state's liberalized abor tion law by permitting elective abortions only until 18 weeks of pregnancy, rather than the 24 weeks now permitted.

title: A BRITISH NEWSMAN EXPELLED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 5Soviet au thorities today expelled David Bonavia, the correspondent of The Times of London, and ac cused him of systematic activ ity incompatible with the status of a foreign journalist.

title: Programs of Zanzibar's New Leader Are Awaited
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 1  The usual parades and speeches were canceled last week on the eighth anniversary of the union of Tanganyika and Zanzibar into the nation of Tan zania  and, indeed, there seemed to be little to celebrate.

title: Greece Requiring An Oath of Loyalty From New Priests
description: ATHENS, May 5  Candi dates for the Greek Orthodox priesthood must pass a politi cal loyalty test before they can be ordained, it was disclosed here today in Athens newspa pers.

title: Reshevsky With 6 Points, Leads Chess National Here
description: After eight rounds of the 21st National Chess Championship, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., an eighttime United, States titleholder, leads the tournament with 6points.

title: Pnompenh Struck By Rockets as Foe Attacks Key Bridge
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, May 6 (UPI)Enemy gunners lobbed at least 25 122mm. rockets into down town Pnompenh early today and followed up with an appar ently unsuccessful attack against a key bridge only a mile from the American Embassy.

title: EXADMIRAL TERMS NAVY STRONG ENOUGH
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 5 (AP)A retired flag officer says the United States Navy is far stronger than the Soviet navy and the Russians are doing lit tle that would change the bal ance in the next few years.

title: Boyer Connects in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, May 5 (AP)Clete Boyer, formerly of the New York Yankees and Atlanta Braves, slammed a pair of two run homers today to spark the Taiyo Whales to an 84 victory over the Hiroshima Carps.

title: Upstate Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that an Army officer, Lieut. Col. John J. Mott, of Westfield, N.Y., had been killed in action in South east Asia.

title: Alfred Dronge, a Director Of Avnet, Guitarist, Dead
description: GROTON, Conn., May 5 Alfred Dronge, a director of Avnet, Inc., diversified manu facturing concern, and presi dent of Avnet's Guild Musical Instruments division, was killed Wednesday when the private plane in which he was flying alone crashed near the airport here. He was 60 years old and lived at 16 Sutton Place in New York and also had homes in Watch Hill, R. I., and Fort Lau derdale, Fla.

title: Riva Ridge Is 85 Favorite to Win Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge was established as an 85 fa vorite for Phase 98 of the Ken tucky Derby in early betting to day at Churchill Downs.

title: U.N. Appoints a British Aide Assistant Secretary General
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5Brian E. Urquhart, a Briton and a longtime member of the United Nations staff, has been promoted to an Assistant Secretary General.

title: N. & W. Makes Proposal to Save the Boston & Maine
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)Some Northern railroads should form an agreement, according to the president of the Norfolk & Western Railway, to save the bankrupt Boston & Maine and fight encroachment by the Penn Central.

title: NORMAN SIEGEL DIES; RABBI IN BROOKLYN
description: Rabbi Norman Siegel of the Jewish Center of Kings High way, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 1839 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: MRS. NEWBURGER JR.
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 Mrs. Dorothy Einstein New burger, the wife of Frank L. Newburger Jr., a senior partner of Newburger & Co., the stock brokers, died yesterday of can cer in the University of Penn sylvania Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Rydal, Pa.

title: Roundup: White Sox Win As Wood Halts Tribe, 21
description: In 1968, Wilbur Wood, Chicago's tireless lefthanded pitcher, hurled his way into the baseball record books with the following accom plishments:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Word for Next Week Is Hush

title: Tanks and Another U.S. Carrier Bolster Armed Strength in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 6Communist sap pers overran a South Vietnam ese paratroop base only six miles north of Pleiku this morn ing, killing about 80 paratroop ers and an American adviser and destroying six howitzers, according to military reports reaching Saigon.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)The Democratic lead ership in the House has pro posed a plan to use Federal money for the purchase of broadcast time for Presiden tial candidates.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOUSTON, May 5A turn out of more than two million voters is expected in Texas tomorrow for Democratic and Republican primary elections for Governor, Senator and numerous other offices.

title: Women Now Hold 40% of Jobs in City
description: More women are at work than ever before in New York City and more wives are work ing to help their families make ends meet.

title: N.Y.U. Names FundRaiser
description: The appointment of Mrs. Susan Goldberg Lamb to the post of director of university development was announced yesterday by William F. Payne, vice president for development of New York University.

title: WEISS TRIUMPHS IN QUANTICO RUN
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 5  For the second time in three years, Greg Weiss of Montclair State College scored an upset victory today in the invitation 880yard run at the Marine Corps Relays.

title: PROFESSORS SCORE MISS DAVIS OUSTER
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 5 (AP) The American Association of University Professors censured the Board of Regents of the University of California today for its handling of the re grettable case of Angela Davis.

title: Hijacked Plane Takes Off 2d Time With $303,000
description: WASHINGTON, May 5An air pirate described by his fellow passengers as cool and calculated collected $303,000 in ransom and six parachutes and departed in an Eastern Airlines plane from nearby Dulles International Airport tonight for the second time in six hours.

title: Another View of Willowbrook
description: In their efforts to stir the conscience of society and to call attention to the need to improve the care of the insti tutionalized retarded and to expand communitybased programs, the media have rendered a great public service.

title: Mets Attempting to Get Willie Mays
description: The New York Mets, who lost 400,000 customers last year, are negotiating with the San Francisco Giants for one of the the most durable boxoffice attractions in baseballWillie Mays, who turns 41 years of age today.

title: PLANE IS HIJACKED ON FLIGHT IN WEST
description: DALLAS, Saturday, May 6 (AP)A Western Airlines jet was hijacked yesterday on its way from Salt Lake City and arrived here at 12:17 this morn ing after a flight from Los Angeles. The crew was operat ing at gunpoint.

title: Industrial Demand Cited
description: LONDON, May 5 (Reuters) Another nother increase in the price of gold on the London market to day took the value of the metal to a new high.

title: Member Firms Employes Penalized in Stock Affair
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it had disciplined five officers and five registered representa tives of member firms in con nection with the stock market escapades of Abraham H. Treff, a 19yearold college student from Philadelphia.

title: But the Pakistanis See Some Grounds for Hope
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 5Pakistani officials have come out of the preliminary peace talks with India believing that their country's humiliating de feat in the December war over Bangladesh will be one of the most important assets President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will carry into his meeting with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON PEACE REPORTS
description: Stock prices rose yesterday in response to reports on se cret Vietcong negotiations and later fell back when the State Department said there was no basis to these peace reports.

title: Art: Intricacy of Persian Miniatures
description: The current exhibition of Persian miniature paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is not for the casual visitor. An art of exceedingly complex style, superabundant detail and intricate narrative, the miniatures do not prompt to immediate response from anyone whose eyes are ac customed to rapid visual com prehension.

title: Market Place: Teaching Child Value of Money
description: If you have a child or grandchild who doesn't un derstand the value of money and how easy it is to let it slip through your fingers you might consider buying him a few shares of stock.

title: Navy Gets New Submarine
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 5 (UPI)The Navy's 100th nu clearpowered submarine, the U.S.S, Silversides, was commis sioned here today. The United States has two types of nuclear submarines. There are 41 sub marines that carry missiles. Construction of this type ended in 1967. There are also attack submarines of which the Silver sides is the 59th. Five such at tack subinarines are scheduled to be built in the United States this year.

title: Candidates' Day
description: DAKOTA CITY. Neb., May 5 Senator George McGovern denounced today as a smear campaign reports that he fa vored legalization of marijuana, liberalized abortion laws and immediate amnesty for draft evaders.

title: U.S. Criticism of Soviet's Role In Vietnam Renewed by Rogers
description: BRUSSELS, May 5Secre tary of State William P. Rogers told the Atlantic alliance today that the United States believes the Soviet Union bears a re sponsibility for North Viet nam's invasion of South Viet nam and that President Nixon will raise this matter with Soviet leaders during his forth coming Moscow visit.

title: Convict Slain and Another Held in Rye
description: One convict was killed and a second was captured as they tried to shoot their way past policemen and Federal agents in a tavern parking lot yester day evening in Rye, N.Y.

title: Jobless Rate Is Still 5.9%; Wholesale Price Index Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The unemployment rate remained unchanged in April at almost 6 per cent, as it has for 18 months, and wholesale prices continued to climb, despite a drop in food prices.

title: Nets Open Final Playoff Against the Pacers Today
description: For the first time in their fiveyear history, the New York Nets will compete in the cham pionship round of the Ameri can Basketball Association playoffs today against the In diana Pacers at Bloomington, Ind.

title: 3 Senators Balk at Signing Report on Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Three of the 11 members of the Senate Judiciary Commit tee who had voted to approye Richard G. Kleindienst's nomi nation as Attorney General de clined today to endorse the majority's report, which con cluded that the Justice Depart ment's settlement of I.T.T. anti trust suits was not the product of political influence.

title: OPTIMISM IS FOUND IN BRITISH SURVEY
description: LONDON, May 5A sharp upswing in optimism over busi ness prospects in Britain was reported by the Confederation of British Industry this week as it released findings of a survey among leaders of 1,425 Manu facturing concerns.

title: Thursday Night Fight
description: LOS ANGELESJorge Rodriguez, 128 pounds, Mexico, and Masahito Takahashi, 127, Honolulu, fought a technical draw; Referee halted the fight after Rodriguez was cut by an accidental butt in the sec ond round.

title: A's Subdue Yanks by 31 On Holtzman's 4Hitter
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 5The Yankees' No. 2 pitcher, Fritz Peterson, started impressively once again but ended up still in need of his first victory and first complete game of the year as the Oakland A's caught and beat the New Yorkers, 31, tonight.

title: WIRETAPS IN U.S. UP 37% IN YEAR; STATE HAS MOST
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  A new report to Congress on courtapproved wiretapping by the police has disclosed that the volume of police eaves dropping rose by 37 per cent last year across the country, with the heaviest activity con centrated in New York and New Jersey.

title: Pro Hockey Presents Annual Orr Awards
description: Rangers and Bruins cast covetous glances at a 35 inch trophy yesterday as the Stanley Cup made its first appearance in New York since 1933.

title: A Kennedy for McGovern
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) The oldest son of the late Sen ator Robert F. Kennedy, Joseph Kennedy Jr., 19 years old, said today he supported Senator George McGovern for the Dem ocratic Presidential nomination.

title: SHOP TALK
description: When Samuel A. Simon found some Swiss lollipops 19 inches across and with sticks about 3 feet long, he thought they'd make an in teresting decoration for the windows of his food store, Simon Pure (mostly pack aged things) at 49 East 57th Street. To his surprise, cus tomers kept wanting to buy them, and Mr. Simon has built up quite a business in $14.95 lollipops.

title: 2 MissileHelicopters Arrive From Germany
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 5 (UPI)At least two United States UH1 helicop ters equipped with wire guided antitank missiles are reported to have arrived in South Vietnam for possible use against the enemy.

title: Bridge:
description: Perhaps the commonest bidding error made by play ers below the expert class is bidding a fivecard suit twice. For the opening bidder to rebid a fivecard suit is sel dom right, and for the re sponder to do so is almost never right.

title: Bonn Opposition Leader Loses Ground on Pacts
description: BONN, May 5Rainer C. Barzel, the leader of West Germany's parliamentary Op position, lost ground today in his attempt to promote a bi partisan compromise permit ting a broadbased ratification next week of the Government's treaties with the Soviet bloc.

title: Despite Deficit, Knicks' Frazier Is HopefulCeltics Did It
description: Situation critical  pa tient about to die.

title: CHOU CROUTE WINS NINTH RACE IN ROW
description: Followers of form in yester day's crowd of 20,877 at Aque duct who subscribe to the horses for courses doctrine had just cause to marvel when Emanuel V. Benjamin 3d's highly regarded Chou Croute scored her ninth straight vic toryby a nose.

title: CARTIER TRIUMPHS IN TWOMILE RACE
description: Vince Cartier, upset last week in the onemile run of the Penn Relays, bounced back yesterday with a recordbreak ing performance in the twomile on the opening day of the sev enth annual New York Relays in Downing Stadium.

title: FISCHER ACCEPTS MATCH IN ICELAND
description: Bobby Fischer, the American challenger for the world chess championship, agreed yester day to play the champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, in Reykjavik, Iceland, or anywhere else in the free world.

title: B52 Attacks in Highlands Slow Enemy and Buy Time
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 5  Despite the collapse of morale in the South Vietnamese forces in the Central Highlands in the last two weeks, the Communist offensive has halted for the moment, almost entirely because of the B52's.

title: German Reserves Up in Week
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, May 5 (Reuters)West Germany's net monetary re serves rose by 300million marks to 63.6billion marks in the week ended April 30, the Bundesbank said today.

title: 2 Schools Where Desks Are Bypassed but the Children Aren't
description: Imagine a classroom where there are no children in symmetrical rows of desks and seats, docilely filling out les son books, no children especially on these spring mornings, wriggling in an agony of boredom and restlessness; no body yawning; nobody vandalizing the furniture; hardly anybody with his mouth shut, or his eyes shut, or his mind shut. And no teacher standing up front trying to impart knowledge as she runs a range of emotions from trembling frustration to rage to despair to limp resignation.

title: Former Mayor Is Acquitted In Extortion Case in Jersey
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 5 (AP)  A former East Pat erson Mayor, Albert Merbeth, has been acquitted of charges in connection with the alleged shakedown of the owner of an auto body repair shop.

title: TRADEMARK TREATY IS SEEN PROGRESSING
description: GENEVA, May 5Very substantial progress was made by experts of 32 coun tries on the draft of a treaty on the international registra tion of trademarks that could mean considerable savings in money and administrative for malities for American compa nies, Robert Gottschalk, United States patents commissioner, said today.

title: Police Say Evidence Backs Informant's Gallo Story
description: Physical evidence gathered at Umberto's Clam House, the Mulberry Street restaurant where Joseph. Gallo was mur dered, tends to support the story of the killing offered by Joseph Luparelli, an alleged Mafia informant, officials close to the case said.

title: MercuryPoison Epidemic Has Ended, Iraqis Report
description: BEIRUT Lebanon, May 5, (UPI)  An Iraqi Embassy spokesman said today a mer curypoisoning epidemic that swept Iraq in March was over and that special Government controls had been lifted.

title: DR. STEPHEN PEPPER, ESTHETICIAN, 81, DIES
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 5 Dr. Stephen C. Pepper, chair man of the department of art at the University of California from 1938 to 1952 and of the department of philosophy from 1953 to 1958, died Monday at the age of 81.

Tomorrow, in the state's first Presidential primary, North Carolina's vot ers will decide if Mr. Sanford's candidacy will be taken se riously anywhere else.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN

description: Eldridge Small of Texas A. and I., their No. 1 draft choice, and Tom Gatewood of Notre Dame, No. 5, signed contracts yesterday with the New York Giants.

Civil rights leaders said they would go back on the streets this weekend to demand an end to the internment with out trial of suspected members of the Irish Republican Army.

description: SOUTH KENT, Conn., May 5  Unlike the boys they grew up with in East Harlem, George Pinkston, Albert La court and Alphonse Fuen zalida go to high school on a 500acre campus with rolling hills, tall trees and 154 students.

In an unusually arranged program, he began with Ben Weber's Fantasy of 1946, doubled back to Bach's Partita No. 5 in G and then settled down to the romantic 19thcentury world of Liszt, Chopin and Scriabin.

description: THE LIONHEADS. By Josiah Bunting. 213 pages. Braziller. $5.95.

description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 5 (AP) Foreign Minister Spyros Kyp rianou of Cyprus resigned to day, saying his decision had been forced by the Greek Gov ernment.

description: Sports of The Times

title: Maazel Conducts Cherubini Symphony
description: Napoleon didn't like Che rubini's music, we are told, but Toscanini, we know, did. Faced with contradictory opinions by two great men, what are we to do? The only fair solution seems to listen to the music. That is not as easy as it might seem, of course; the performance of the Symphony in D by the New York Philharmonic Thursday night offered one of the infrequent opportuni ties nowadays to choose up sides between Napoleon and Toscanini.

description: HOUSTON, May 5 (AP) Hale Irwin scrambled through blustery winds with his second consecutive 67 today and es tablished a threestroke lead in the second round of the $125, 000 Houston open golf tourna ment.

description: Mrs. Elizabeth Conolly Pinto, widow of former Kings County Judge Nicholas H. Pinto, who, died on April 14, died yester day in Caledonia Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 82 years, old and lived at 311 Rugby Road, Brooklyn.

description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., May 5 Miss Ann Pongrace, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto W. Pongrace, formerly of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married here this morning to John F. Ezell. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Phil Porter of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mount Kisco, at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Hanoi Ready to Confer
description: PARIS, May 5  A North Vietnamese official told visi tors from California today that his side was ready to meet with Henry A. Kissinger again, privately or publicly.

title: RIESSEN UPSETS LAVER BY 62, 64
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 5 (AP)  Rod Laver, seeded No. 1, was the most prominent vic tim of a series of upsets today in the $50,000 World Cham pionship Tennis tournament.

title: Eye on Demonstrations
description: The events of May 8, 1970, shattered whatever sense of community was then left in New York City. A group of construction workers attacked peace demonstrators in the Wall Street area. Thera ensued a bloody confrontation while in the office towers surrounding the scene many people openly cheered the contestants. (A few wept.) Some say the police, despite inadequate numbers, tried to halt the battle. Others say the police stood and let heads be smashed.

title: White House Confirms Talks By Kissinger in Paris Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The White House confirmed tonight that Henry A. Kissinger met secretly in Paris Tuesday with Le Due Tho, a member of North Vietnam's Politburo, just two days before the United States suspended the Paris peace talks.

title: Federal Agency Funds Medicine Men's Training of 12 Young Navajos to Cure Mental Ills
description: DALLAS, May 5The Na tional Institute of Mental Health, a Federal agency that funds numerous projects to im prove the delivery of psychiatric services, is paying six Navajo medicine men on a reservation in Arizona to teach 12 young Indians the elaborate chants that often cure the mental ail ments of Navajos.

title: CITYCHARTER BILL PASSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 5The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill creating an 11 member state commission to re vise New York City's Charter.

title: Laken Beat Knicks, 116111, for 31 Lead
description: Striking back like the cham pions they may become after one more game, the Los An geles Lakers took a 116111 overtime decision from the New York Knicks at Madison Square Garden last night and headed back to Los Angeles with a 31 lead in the fourof sevengame series for the Na tional Basketball Association title.

title: Candidates' Day
description: OMAHA, May 5Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Min nesota said today We should not; be sending ground troops back in to Vietnam.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Commerce Department reported today that department store sales for last week were an estimated $778million, up seven per cent from last year's $729 million. Total retail store sales last week were about $8.372 billion, up seven percent from the yearearlier $7.846billion.

title: U.S. Says Marines May Land to Protect G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Defense Department held out a possibility today that United States Marines might be landed in South Vietnam to protect withdrawing American forces.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Republican party formally voted today for Miami Beach and abandoned San Diego as the site for the 1972 Republi can National Convention.

title: EVERETT S. SELLERS
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., May 5 Everett S. Sellers, who retired as a vice president of the American News Company in 1958, died today at his home here. He was 76 years old, and was a former fire commissioner and member of the borough council of Westwood.

title: Izvestia Sees South Setback
description: MOSCOW, May 5The Soviet Government newspaper, Izves tia, noting skirmishes around the central Vietnamese city of Hue, forecast this afternoon that a crushing defeat is near for the South Vietnamese armed forces.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON. May 5 Fifteen of the 41 Representa tives from New York have reported to the House ethics committee that they main tained at least some connec tion with law firms back home last year.

title: Candidates' Day
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 5 After attracting overflow crowds in Michigan yesterday, Gov. George C. Wallace brought his Presidential campaign to North Carolina today and promptly attacked his major opponents in the Democratic primary election tomorrow.

title: Screen: A Social Satire From Brazil:'Macunaima' Arrives at Fifth Avenue Cinema Film Travels Between the City and Jungle
description: Joaquin Pedro de Andrade's "Macunaima," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, is a social satire in the form of a picaresque adventure, full of the elements of a fairy tale and proceeding according to a logic that seems to have been learned in the academy of the shaggy dog story.It is also rather a failure in each department. But its ambitions are such that I keep wanting to admire them, and wishing that the skill, invention and energy of "Macunaima" were in any way up to the potential of its forms.Loosely based on a novel written in 1928 by Mario de Andrade, the Brazilian man of letters who is no relation to the director, the film covers the entire life and times of one Macunaima, born a Negro, at what appears to be 45 years of age, to a savage family in the wilds of Brazil. The times are approximately our own.The life, which moves between modern city and primitive jungle and transforms Macunaima from middle-aged black baby to handsome young white man (and occasionally back again), consists mostly of extravagent ups and downs. Macunaima has terrific luck with women and dreadful luck with almost everything else. But at the end it is a woman who does him ina water spirit named Iara. She eats him.It should be mentioned that "Macunaima" is very much about cannibalismor, rather, about the economic and political problems of Brazil understood in terms of cannibalismand that it means at all times to temper its humor with savagery.It includes among its characters an evil giant (a giant industrialist, as it happens) who literally stews guests in his swimming pool, a preparation for soup stock.But the audacity that is so heavily belabored in "Macunaima" is generally more interesting as idea than as achieved image, and the movie fails by being never as comic or as shocking or as comically shocking as it wants and desperately needs to be.As satire it largely repeats conventional formulas. And though more sensational, it is less anarchic than, say, the American madcap comedy of the 1940's that it partly imitates.I suppose it is ultimately a matter of degrees. The performances aren't good enough, the direction isn't sure enough, the insights don't go deep enough to do more than suggest a kind of awkward dancing at the altar of current revolutionary orthodoxies.

title: Jean MacDonald Bride of W. M. Mathers
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gordon MacDonald of Wash ington and Williamstown, Vt., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jean Ann MacDonald, to William Mar tin Mathers.

title: Air Force Mother Loses Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied today an appeal by Capt. Susan Struck, 27 years old, who is fighting to keep the Air Force from discharging her because she gave birth to an outofwedlock child.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I take exception to the claim that Mohawk Airlines was an undependable trans porter of bodies and baggage in Farewell to Bedeviled Mohawk (Travel section, April 16). At one time our lives revolved around Mo hawk, commuting from Ro chester, N.Y, to Newark, and there was only one instance of the plane departing even a minute past the appointed hour. Oh, yes, there were some experiences I could have skipped, such as the choppy rides prompted by the low altitude of the small plane, but the cheerful com ments of the pilots made it all palatable. We're experi encing a smidgen of that old shake, rattle and roll, said one. Hang onto your seats and whoopie bagsand we'll try to deliver you alive. And he did.

title: NIXON SEEKS MORE FOR PUPIL MEALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 President Nixon announced today that he would ask Con gress next week to provide extra money for the school breakfast and summer lunch programs for needy children.

description: Shakespeare slandered the Little People by giving them pixie names and pretending that they were amus ing. Earlier, mostly oral, traditions in the British Isles tell quite a dif ferent story.

description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 6 Anderson Fowler of Oyster Bay and Mrs. Page Hewitt of Stowe, Vt., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Con stance Durrel Hewitt, to Peter McCord Ruth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Ruth of Park Ridge, Ill. A spring wedding is planned.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK The Eagleton Center for the American Woman and Poli tics here will bring 50 women politicians together this month to see what can be done about ending male dom ination of politics.

description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 6 Trinity Episcopal Church here was the setting this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Nancy Carroll King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. King Jr. of Princeton, to Curtis Randall Carleton, son of Dr. and Mrs. William T. Carleton of Wor cester, Mass. The Rev. James Whittemore performed the ceremony.

title: The World
description: OTTAWASince 1945, the value of United States private investment in Canada has risen from $5billion to nearly $35billion. With more than half of the Canadian manufacturing, mining and smelting, and petroleum and natural gas industries already in American hands, Canadians have grown alarmed lest the Yankee in vasion become a complete takeover of the Canadian economy.

title: New & Novel
description: Imprisoned in a Mexican jail for possession of marijuana, a cutie named Simon Grant writes importunate letters to: the American Embassy, the editor of The New York Times, Abi gail Van Buren, his exwife, the State Department, the ACLU, Yvette Mimieux, the President of the United States, his girl friend's father in Duluth, and an indigenous lawyer. The in direct result of this mailing is the receipt of 19gallon cans of paint in his cell, some of which may contain high explosives and the delayed transmission of 43 answering letters.

title: Tourism Is Looking Up
description: To really appreciate Europe, one has to speak a lot of Body English; many of the splendors the traveler encounters are not at eye level but far, far above the head. The resultant continuous craning may make sightseeing a pain in the neck, but the sights are eminently worth look ing up to.

title: Punch And the Magic Fish
description: Happily, good fairy tales grow more potent with age, and keep on having offspring. Here are two, from perhaps the best old story ever, The Fisherman and His Wife. One is brash and splashy, with strong immediate appeal; the other is deeper and yields last ing pleasures. Welcome to them both.

title: Sharman, Quiet Dictator, Put Laker House in Order
description: Casey, they are not getting back quick enough on defense, said Bill Shar man in a low, raspy voice. Wilt has got to get more offensive.

title: A Song of Sixpence, etc.

You can hardly climb a mountain peak without finding the young already there, en tertaining each other on the guitar.

title: If You Go
description: for a cooking course in dieppe, you'll be taking the only one of its kind in France, for all other similar courses are much more ex pensive. We paid $76 for full room and board and instruction for six days, but that rate varies accord ing to the hotel room you choose. The course, which is not con ducted during the summer, will, reopen in October, or possibly September. All information can be obtained from the Syndicat d'Inia tive, Boulevard do la Liberation, Dieppe.

title: What Price Cynicism?
description: The new Federal law to regulate campaign spending depends heavily for its effectiveness upon the principle of public disclosure. Candidates are required to file periodic reports during a campaign in order that the voters will know the sources of political money before they cast their votes on Election Day.

title: News of Dogs
description: Roger S. Pritchard of Ed mond, Okla., is a man who wears several hats in the dog show world. He's a breeder of poodles and Af ghans, the president of the MidDel Tinker Kennel Club and the Afghan Hound Club of Oklahoma, a member of the board of the Sooner Dachshund Club and the Poodle Club of Okla homa; he teach es conformation handling one night a week and spends at least another lecturing to dog clubs.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONThe more the Vietnamese front disintegrates the more President Nixon's Asian policy is threatened and the more Soviet prestige mounts all the way from Suez to Singapore. Con sequently, the desperate effort to blunt General Giap's brilliant offensive has global implications.

title: COAST GUARD CREW WINS CALLOW RACE
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 6 The Rusty Callow Memorial rowing regatta on Lake Quinsi gamond was won today by the United States Caost Guard Academy varsity crew. Leading the entire distance, the unde feated cadets finished four lengths ahead of the defending regatta chompion, Trinity Col lege.

title: Education
description: For some time it has been clear that Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of New York City's school system, and many principals.did not see eye to eye on how the schools should be run. But last week the president of the Board of Education brought the conflict plainly to the surface by charging that some principals were using the issue of violence in the schools as a way of trying to get rid of Dr. Scribner.

title: When It's a Dog's Life, Humane Society Cares
description: LONG BRANCH  When the Humane Society acts against abuse of animals, it usually is a case of cease and desist and punishment of the abuser. In one case under way here, the Humane Society of New Jersey not only seeks to halt what it says are inhumane practices but also asks monetary dam ages from the defendant.

title: Photography
description: A NEW LINE of Instamatic cameras that are much smaller than all pre vious models has re cently been introduced by the Eastman Kodak Company. Called Pocket Instamatics be cause they actually will fit easily into a coat or jacket pocket, these new cameras come in five models and mea sure only one inch in thick ness by a little over two inches in width; three are 5 inches long (the three lower priced units) and two are 5 inches long (the two higher priced models).

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HARTFORD, May 6Sen ator Abraham A. Ribicoff, the Connecticut Democrat who last week declared his sup port for Senator George McGovern as his party's can didate for the Presidency, was himself challenged this week by the McGovern or ganization in Hartford for his seat at the state nominating convention in June.

title: HOSPITAL KILLING LEADS TO INQUIRY
description: Officials of a hospital run by the National Economic Growth and Rehabilitation Organization (NEGRO) have been asked to appear tomorrow at the office of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell, in connec tion with an investigation of a homicide at the hospital.

title: PIRATES TOP REDS ON 5RUN 3D, 81.
description: CINCINNATI, May 6 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates rattled off six straight hits for five runs in the third inning and went on to an 81 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

title: Female Rabbinical Student Asks Increased Feminity in Judaism
description: Mrs. Sandy Eisenberg Sasso, a 25yearold Rabbinical student told the American Jewish Com mittee yesterday that Judaism should be a little more feminine.

title: School Supervisors' Chief Hails Unit's OrganizedLabor Ties
description: Walter J. Degnan, president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators of the city school system, declared yester day that, because of the bar gaining power the council de veloped last year by joining organized labor, nobody in New York City has lost a job as a school supervisor.

title: Sadat Arrives in Tunis
description: TUNIS, May 6  President Anwar elSadat arrived here today for a 48hour official vis it at the invitation of Tunisia's President, Habib Bourguiba. It is the first visit by an Egyp tian chief of state since Gamal Abdel Nasser came in 1962 to help Tunisia celebrate the French evacuation of the naval base at Bizerte. Later, relations between Presidents Naser and Bourguiba were strained.

title: Better Than Laughter
description: Books that attempt to estab lish their significance before the story has even started make some readers (this one) a little wary of what is to fol low. In this novel, the author first thanks a foundation that no longer exists. (It was one of the less spectacular fatalities of our times.) Then there is a quote from Ecclesiastes to the effect that Anger is better than laughter: because in the state of the countenance the mind of the offender is cor rected. Finally, there is a two page history of Redwood Coun ty beginning, The Redwoodtrees were there, along the northern coast of what is now called California, the day Christ died. By the time the reader actually starts the book he is in a suitably serious, not to say apprehensive, frame of mind.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Some part of the Nixon Admini stration's current system of controls over wages and prices is persuasion  a variant of what was formerly known as jawboning. But the role and the impact of jawboning have undergone a significant change.

title: OIL COMPANY SUED ON CHARGE OF BIAS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30  Monroe Baer Jr., a lawyer, is pushing a civil rights suit against the Standard Oil Com pany of California, for which he worked for 19 years. The suit alleges that Mr. Baer was discriminated against because he is a Jew.

title: Is Bride on L.I.
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 6  Miss Margaret Linden Henning and Jeffrey Baeke land Minnick, who are with the Marine Midland Bank in New York, were married here today in the Garden City Community Church (Congre gational). The Rev. Richard B. Smith performed the cere mony.

title: Rutgers Lacrosse Victor
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 6Bidding for a berth in the National Collegiate tourna ment, the Rutgers lacrosse team today routed Yale, 113, for its eighth victory in 11 games. Ed Haugevik, Bob Carney, Roy Malinak and George Massey scored twice each for the Scarlet.

title: Navy's Lightweight Crew Captures Callow Trophy
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 Navy's lightweight varsity crew won the Rusty Callow Trophy here today, defeating Massachu setts Institute of Technology and Pennsylvania. The Navy second varsity was also a win ner, while Penn won the fresh man event, in which Navy had no entry.

title: ZANZIBAR KILLING LAID TO SOLDIER
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 30Informed sources re port that the assassination of Zanzibar's dictator was carried out by a young army lieuten ant whose father had been a famous political assassin him self.

title: Lockheed Loan
description: When Congressafter an intense controversy that was resolved by a single vote in the Senateauthorized a $250million loan guarantee to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy, it set up an emergency board to oversee the loan. That board has now refused to permit the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to examine the board's records and documents, as it does those of most other Government agencies.

title: $250,000 Church Fund Set Up to Fight Racism
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)The Unitarian Universalist Associa tion says it has set up a $250, 000 fund to promote racial justice and to combat racism.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: HARTFORD REGION GETS GROWTH PLAN
description: HARTFORD, May 6A pio neering forum of civic and business organizations here disclosed two major new com ponents today of the largest, most visionary effort ever undertaken to renew and de velop an entire metropolitan area in America.

title: Two Latin American poets and an antipoet
description: Pablo Neruda is an anomaly. He looks like a happily retired banker, what with those immobile features broken only by heavylidded eyes that penetrate everybody and every thing, settling poetic accounts in a flash. A nobody in the street appar ently. And yet, he is a voice (physi cal and poetic) of hypnotic charisma. The ample creator of some 3,000 pages of verse, theater, prose pieces and translations, he is still thriving in both literature and politics. Nobel Prize winner for 1971, he is now the Ambassador to France from the Chile of Salvador Allende.

title: Underground Paper Folds
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 6 (UPI)The Berkeley Tribe, an underground newspaper, will cease publication after 2 years.

title: Bergen Hunt For Maestro Is Nice Work
description: HACKENSACK  Lee. M. Bronster of Oradell, president of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra, and his fellow trustees are in a quandary these days, but they don't seem to mind at all.

title: Roger Nevard to Wed Miss Inglis Miss Henning
description: FREEPORT, L. I., May 6 Miss Beverly Alice Inglis and Roger T. Nevard will be mar ried here May 27 in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Said Mr. Cooper to His Wife: You Know, I Could Write Something Better Than That
description: MEN sometimes become novel ists by accident. Samuel Richardson, father of the AngloAmerican novel, was by trade a printer, and he specialized in vol umes of model letters for young ladies. Out of this practice came a fictional exchange of letters called Pamela, and the first true English psychological novel was in existence. Out of a desire to parody this sensa tional bestseller, as it turned out to be, Henry Fielding wrote Joseph Andrews and was then on the road which led to Tom Jones.

title: Block Power The Jane Street Story
description: BREEEEP! The tiny gold peephole flips open and an eye peers out. The eye stares at Michelle Sandberg's yellow laminated nameplate. The nameplate reads Jane Street Block Association.

title: Femalechauvinistmousemaker
description: I was drawing some mice the other afternoon to illustrate a children's book I'm working on, and they were giving me trouble. I couldn't decide how to dress Mrs. Mouse and her daughter Edwina. So I went down stairs to see if a cup of coffee would help.

title: About Pro Football
description: Those Giant fans partial to Fran Tarkenton will have plenty of chances to see the scrambler in action this season, even though he has been traded to Minnesota. The Vikings will be seen on national television eight times beginning with their final preseason game in Miami against the Dolphins on Sept. 10. The eight appearances include two Mon day night games, at home against Washington on Sept. 18 and at Chicago on Oct. 23.

title: And This Is the House That Grandma Built
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP  Stretched out on her couch in a rare moment of relaxa tion, the whitehaired, 67 yearold grandmother sur veyed the house she had built singlehandedly.

title: News of the Rialto
description: SING Hallelujah! At last a cham pion has arisen who not only favors lower ticket prices for Broadway shows but who also means to do something about it. Harold Prince, one of the theater's most suc cessful producers  he also directs discloses that for his next musical pro duction he expects to price his orches tra from $6 to $15, instead of the $12 weekdays and $15 Fridays and Satur days that prevails for the orchestra for most musicals. Those with champagne tastes, he contends, will be willing to pay top price for front and center. After the first six rows the prices will decline gradually to the minimum.

title: Lacrosse Title to N. Y. Tech
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. L, May 6Richie Klein scored three goals and closed out the season with a total of 46 as New York Tech walloped C.C.N.Y., 170, today to win the Knickerbockerl lacrosse league championship. The Bears completed their con ference schedule with a 70 wonlost and wound up 102 lover all. Dale Whitley led the victors with four goals.

title: Give that dumb bathrobe to Goodwill
description: It's just as fashionable to stay at home as to go out these nights. And you don't have to slop around in dumb nightgowns and bathrobes either, though they're still around. Now there are caf tans for entertaining in the living room or by the pool, knitted bare midriff pajamas that look like sportswear, halter nightgowns in dark prints that may go out dan cing. When dress designers turn to robes, they give them the feel ing of today's fashionsshirt de tailing, wrappy looks and dolman sleeves for comfort and drama.

title: 1,100 Take Courses at Art Center
description: TENAFLYAlthough 1,100 students are busy with at least 35 courses and a travel ing graphics art show is on display, what is perhaps most meaningful to its pupils and members is that the Art Cen ter of Northern New Jersey here is a New Yorkoriented art institution.

title: Health Department Lists Food Places Cited for Violations
description: Two wellknown restaurants, La Crpe, at 48 West 55th, Street, and Manero's Steak House, at 124 West 13th Street, are among 29 foodhandling, establishments that have been cited by the Health Department for serious Health Code viola tions.

title: H. G. Buning Weds Joanne H. Sawers
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., May 6  Miss Joanne Helen Sawers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Sawers of New York, was married here this afternoon to Hano Geert Buning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johan Roelof Anco Buning of Amersfoort, the Netherlands, and Montelimar, Prance. The Rev. James R. Leo performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: 6 Die in Heidelberg Mishap
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, May 6 (UPI)Six per sons were killed and 11 others injured in a traffic pileup on a fogcovered highway near here early today.

title: MacLeish Mourns Lost Values
description: CONWAY, Mass., May 6 American poetry has lost, or at least temporarily mislaid, its historic preoccupation with America as a people and as land of unfolding democratic vistas, Archibald MacLeish re marked this week as he pre pared to celebrate his 80th birthday, here tomorrow.

title: Altman Clouts Tokyo Homer
description: TOKYO, May 6 (AP)George Altman, a former major league outfielderfirst baseman, who is the leading hitter in the Pacific League of the Japanese base ball league, belted his fourth home run of the season today. But it wasn't enough as the Tokyo Lotte Orions were beaten by the Oaska Hankyu Braves, 31. Altman currently is hit ting 412.

title: Antebellum and wartime South rendered as never before
description: No story in America's history has been so often told, or has so well stood the retelling, as that of the Old South and its destruction. But Robert Manson Myers's splendid The Chil dren of Pride tells it as it has not been told before, in the fullness of its poignance and tragedy.

title: Sourball Is Victor
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 6 Buddy Brown's Sourball scored 11 points to win the junior working hunter championship today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club's junior horse show.

title: Iverson, With 209, Leads By 2 Shots at Shreveport
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 6 (AP)Don Iverson shot his third consecutive twounder par 69 today and took a two stroke lead with 207 after the third round of the Shreveport Classic golf tournament.

title: PADRES SCORE, 62
description: Nate Colbert continued to dominate the New York Met pitching staff and discontinued Torn Seaver's domination over San Diego yesterday by knock ing in four runs on a double and a homer and leading the Padres to a 62 victory at Shea Stadium.

title: Pearce, Edwards Gain NorthSouth Golf Final
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 6 An allcollegiate final was assured for the North and South amateur golf tourna ment when Eddie Pearce, the defending champion, and Danny Edwards scored vic tories today.

title: Grenade Kills 14 in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 6 (Reuters)  Fourteen people were killed and at least 30 seriously injured when a hand grenade exploded during a, re ligious ceremony in northern Thailand near the Burmese border, provincial police sources said today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Conservationists Attack
description: It is unlikely that any de cision on an Arizona corpora tion's proposal to develop 24,300 acres of forest land within. New York State's Adirondack Park will be made before next year, a spokesman for the Adiron dack Park Agency indicated late last week.

title: For 60,000 Little Leaguers, It Is Time to Play Ball
description: TEANECK  The major leagues were held up by la bor trouble this year, but at least one baseball league started on time, the Little League, with more than 60, 000 youngsters throughout the state coming out for the game, signaling the real be ginning of spring and the last stages of the school year.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Rice Farms horse show at Middle Island Arena in Middle Island, L. I. today, will have a distinguished judge. John V. N. Klein, who was elected Suffolk County Supervisor last fall, has been assigned as one of the officials.

title: The Bethlehem Star
description: Although the Sunday school, like the weekday school, has been plagued in recent years by reformers, social engineers and curriculum revisionists, it still rolls merrily along, perform ing its traditional role, as baby sitter and dispenser of reli gious education and spiritual nurture. One reason is that, despite the confusion at the top of the educational establish ment (Sunday or weekday) as to what is to be believed and taught and how, the class room teacher is a patient, re sourceful creature who adapts content and method to existen tialist needsor else soon de parts for other less demanding field.

title: R. G. Hazard Marries Eleanor Anne Lanahan
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Miss Eleanor Anne Lanahan, a granddaughter of F. Scott. Fitzgerald, the novelist, was married here today to Row land Gibson Hazard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ware Blake Hazard of Burlington, Vermont.

title: The Good Word
description: The year 1971 will stand in the history of the People's Republic of China, like 1924 in the history of the Soviet Union, as the year of recognition. Both countries had en joyed diplomatic or commercial re lations with a number of nations be fore these dates, and in both cases there remained afterward diehards who refused to acknowledge reality. Nevertheless, 1971, like 1924, con stitutes a watershed.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Consumer Information Week ended yesterday and, while you may not feel any more informed, American business soon will be.

title: A lawyer's brief as well as an elegy
description: As the environmental backlash gains momentum it becomes fashion able to see the controversies in va ious shades of gray, instead of in sharplydefined black and white. After all, ecological concern must be fitted into the economic frame work, we are told, Conservationists, though admittedly wellintentioned, are also often illadvised or emotional, while the polluter (like the sportsman who gets his kicks from ambushing an elephant or a tiger) deeply cares about that which he destroys.

title: Frank Crouch Brooks Jr. Weds Miss Mary Gillian Reighley
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 6Miss Mary Gillian Reigh ley and Frank Crouch Brooks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Baltimore, were married here this afternoon. The bride's, parents are Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ward Reigh ley of New Canaan and Nan tucket, Mass.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: RENT A BIKE IN PARIS. Thru Amtec at the American Express Bullding, 7 Rue Scribe, Paris, starting June 1. New York: Amtec, Intl. Ltd. 1350 Broadway. 6834090. ADVT.

title: C.W. POST WINS TITLE IN TRACK
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 6 Ed Williams, a 23yearold junior from Bermuda, shattered meet records in the long and triple jumps to lead C. W. Post College to the team title in the 20th annual Collegiate Track Conference championship to day.

title: MAYOR ENDORSES CHARTER REVISION
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday en dorsed a bill passed by the Legislature authorizing crea tion of an 11 member state commission that could revise New York City's Charter.

title: Education
description: A few years ago a publicservice ad on television showed some run ners, one of them wearing boots made of lead, lining up for the start of a race. The race they were about to begin symbolized their lives and the less than subtle message was that someone who drops out of high school, like the runner in the leaden boots, bears a lifelong handicap.

title: The Strong Wills and Sweet Tooths of Lubeck
description: LUBECK, West GermanyWhen West German Chancellor Willy Brandt was a young man, he opposed the Nazis so stubbornly here in his home town that ultimately he was forced to flee. Today, the man who ferried him to safety in Norway is so stubborn in his own right that he has refused to travel to a reunion with the nowfamous man he saved from the Gestapo. If Herbert Frahm [Willy Brandt's name as a youth] wants to see me, he knows where my tobacco shop is, says 75yearold Paul Stooss. Besides, I can't leave the cat alone.

title: Students and the War
description: Efforts by a minuscule minority of students to shut down the universities in protest against President Nixon's Indochina policies have fizzled. Temporary occupation of buildings and coercive picket lines at a number of campuses, including Columbia, Harvard and Cornell, con stituted contempt for the law and for the rights of other members of the academic community. These actions also amounted to selfdefeating sabotage of an effective pro test against the Administration's Vietnam war policies.

title: Miss Vita Gallo Fiancee of Gavin Scotti
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 6Announcement has been made by Mrs. Gaspar Gallo of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Vita May Gallo, to Gavin William Scotti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Scotti, also of Garden City.

title: Hunter's Alumni Pause to Remember
description: Bella Savitzky was elected president of her freshman class; Helen Gallant earned college spending money clerking parttime at Lord & Taylor; Gertrude Tannenbaum spent her junior and senior years taking every Civil Service exami nation she heard about; Jack Newfield's classmates introduced him to the works of C. Wright Mills and .

title: James A. Farley 3d Marries Miss Joan Breiterman
description: Miss Joan Breiterman was married here yesterday after noon to James A. Farley 3d. State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Barshay performed the ceremony at the Sherry Netherland.

title: Boys High Wins 3 Relays; Buffalo Quartet Defeated
description: The Cinderella story of St. Joseph's Collegiate High of Buffalo ended yesterday when Newark's Essex Catholic de feated the upstaters in the dis tance medley relay. But Boys High of Brooklyn performed as expected and won, three cham pionship events in the seventh annual New York Relays at Downing Stadium, Randalls Is land.

title: DUBASSOFF TAKES PIMLICO STAKES
description: BALTIMORE, May 6  Du bassoff an eligible for the Preakness, took the measure of 11 other 3yearolds today in capturing the $32,750 Wood lawn Stakes before a crowd of 14,202 at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Books for Fun and Their Very Own
description: The idea is so simple, really, as simple as fun and games.

title: Original Stanley Cup Has a $25,000 Twin
description: The Stanley Cup that sits behind locked doors at the Americana Hotel, waiting for the RangersBruins' cham pionship series to end, is more than the National Hockey League's top prize. To Canadians, it is a symbol of their coun try's professional supremacy in the sport and, to the players, it is their childhood dream.

title: He Will Always Be a Champion, Says Happy Stablehand
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 Walking more or less on two legs and seeming a bit tired from too much sun or too much something, the homewardbound spectators on one side of the fence bare ly noticed the splendid ani mal on the other side, by the barn.

title: the traveler's world
description: WHEN Fairchild Republic, the Farmingdale, L. I., airplane manufacturer, went after the United States Department of Transportation contract to build en ESV (Experimental Safety Vehicle), the com pany naturally made George Hildebrand manager of the project. Hildebrand, a designer of automobiles from his early youth, had been hired away from the General Motors engineering and design staff years before to bring automobile techniques to Fairchild's airplane man ufacturing techniques. Now his job was to borrow from aviation techniques to help design and build a safety vehicle, one of two for which the D.O.T. was putting up $7.8million.

title: Costly Homes in Bergen Drawing Young Buyers
description: TEANECKAlthough the average selling price for a home in Bergen County Is about $40,000, local real estate brokers say that more young families than ever are buying homes throughout the county.

title: Crime
description: They got the wheel man, and he's been singing his head off, one of the boys in blue said at Police Headquar ters last week.

title: Aaron Clouts but Cards Win
description: ST. LOUIS, May 6 (UPI) Joe Torre drove in three runs with a sacrifice fly and a two run homer to offset Hank Aaron's 645th career homer to night and pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 42 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Photography
description: THE almost simultane ous departure of two major figures from the country's two largest photographic muse ums is a remarkable occur rence, and one which will have significant repercus sions throughout the photo graphic community.

title: CHINA LINKS PAY TO PRODUCTIVITY
description: HONG KONG, May 6  China appears to be edging away from the egalitarianism that influenced peasant in comes during the fervent, ex tremist period of the cultural revolution in 196769.

title: Chess
description: THE annual tournament for the championship of Yugoslavia has long been second in prestige and interest only to that of the Soviet Union among the European national championships. The event has been marred in recant years, however, both by the reluctance of some of the top name players in the country to take part at all, and by tie lack of fighting spirit among those who didquick colorless draws have been as much a part of Yugoslav chess as clocks or scoresheets.

title: WALLACE REBUTS CRITICS ON RACISM
description: CUMBERLAND, Md., May 6 George C. Wallace opened his Maryland campaign here to day with an angry complaint that, wherever his Presidential pursuits took him, he was in variably misunderstood, mis interpreted and misquoted on the subject of race.

title: Mundine to Fight Moyer At Sydney on May 29
description: SYDNEY, May 6 (Reuters) Tony Mundine of Australia, the British Empire middle weight champion, will fight Denny Moyar of Portland, moter Ed Silver has an nounced.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  Where are their of ficers? an American military adviser asked last week as he watched South Vietnamese troops flee from the bat tered city of Quangtri. There's no one to tell them Stop and to pull them together.

title: Music
description: ACCORDING to a recent announce ment from Hunter College, it is revitalizing and expanding its Concert Bureau programing to meet the interest of Its growing campus and community audiences. What this means in part is reducing the number of concerts in favor of events that can be closely integrated with the college's educational function and give empha sis to experimental forms of art and communications. The actual number of concerts to be presented in the 197273 season will not be drastically reduced, although the number of series will, but it seems like an ominous trend for one of the major suppliers of topgrade mu sic performances in this city.

title: Miss Shaw Beats Australian In English Final, 75, 63
description: SUTTON, England, May 6 (UPI)  The British Wightman Cup star, Winnie Shaw, beat the Australian junior cham pion, Pat Coleman, 75, 6.3, to day in the final of the Roth man's claycourt tennis tour nament.

title: WORKSHOP SCHOOL FORCED TO CLOSE
description: The Children's Community Workshop, a tuitionfree com munity school organized by parents on the upper West. Side as an alternative to public school education, is seeking af filiation with the public school system on an autonomous basis in an effort to survive a finan cial crisis that forced it to sus pend operations last Monday.

title: Italy Charges That West Germany Snubs Her and Other Common Market Nations in Importing Workers
description: PARIS, May 6Italy has ac cused West Germany of vio lating a cardinal principle of Common Market policy by im porting more workers from out side the market than from Italy while Italian unemploy ment continues at high levels.

title: Gene Hackman, Snoop
description: WE WERE hav ing a conversation about Conversa tion the other day with Francis Ford Coppola. Conversation is the title of an original thriller, and Cop pola is its author. He is also the coauthor and director of a little number called The Godfather, as well as the adapter of F. Scott Fitzger ald's The Great Gatsby, which Jack Clayton will soon direct for Paramount release. Paramount, by the way, will also distribute Conversa tion and they don't mind in the least conversing about the fact that they are the folks behind The Godfather, either.

title: TWO ON DEATH ROW FINALLY WIN PLEA
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 6 (UPI)More than 11 years on Death Row are coming to an end for two blacks who finally won a retrial in a rape case for a crime that the alleged victim hinted may never have been committed.

title: IN THE NATION
description: George McGovern has been fre quently characterized as a leftwing Goldwater, but Christopher Lydon of The New York Times has concluded in a study of the matter that there are as many differences as similarities in the two menwith a large question mark remaining as to whether they will both wind up in history's dustbin.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: A good scientist never grows old; he dies young. the speaker was Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, 65 years old and the holder of some 160 patents in sight and sound technology that include the development of the first practical color television system, the longplaying rec ord and electronic video re cording for the home (EVR).

title: Hijacker, With $303,000, Jumps in Central America
description: MEXICO CITY, May 6  A hijacker who extorted $303,000 from Eastern Airlines para chuted into Central America before dawn today, apparently leaving little trace. The crew of the aircraft landed safely in Mexico, exhausted after a 21 hour ordeal that began in Penn sylvania.

title: LIGHTWEIGHT RACE TO HARVARD CREW
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6  Harvard's lightweight crew today completed its eighth con secutive perfect season by rac ing to a twolength victory over Princeton and Yale in the annual Goldthwait Cup Race on the Charles River.

title: New Kissinger Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Henry A. Kissinger's confer ence with Japanese leaders is now scheduled for May 1114, according to informed sources. President Nixon's adviser on national security had planned to visit Tokyo last month, but the trip was delayed because of the enemy offensive in South Vietnam and Mr. Kissinger's secret trip to Moscow.

title: Cheating In Stock Car Racing Is a Way to Stay Competitive
description: About Motor Sports

title: Legal Aid Urged for the Middle Class
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has called for the establishment of a Legal Aid Society for assistance to the middle classes to protect the moderate wageearner from ex orbitant fees for services in volving litigation problems.

title: LEAGUE OF VOTERS KEEPS BAN ON MEN
description: ATLANTA, May 6In this Southern city known for its hospitality the League of Women Voters was none too kind to men last week at the conclusion of its 30th annual convention.

title: Women's Lib for Boys and Girls
description: When I was growing up I was very politically aware and ambitious. I knew just what I was going to be.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Thomas Engaged
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., May 6  The engagement of Miss Nancy Ann Thomas to Harry Landsiedel 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Landsiedel of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford C. Thomas of Moun tain Lakes. A wedding in September is planned.

title: CONTROLS ASKED ON BIRTHS BY POOR
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., May 6  A conservative Republican Michigan legislator has pro posed the encouragement of an increase in the birth rate among educated, propertied United States citizens and a curbing of births in America's slums.

title: Don't Worry, Micki Can Cope
description: WHEN Dont Bother Me, I Cant Cope, an allBlack musical with no apostrophes, no big names and no book, opened Off Broadway a couple of weeks ago, a chorus of critics sang out, Yes, yes, yes! So now, all of a sudden, Micki Grant, the show's composerlyricist, has to bother about coping with success.

title: Waste Recycling Effort Found to Lag
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 Recycling of castaway bot tles, cans and papers so far is failing to make much head way around the country de spite the efforts of thousands of ecologyminded people who are hauling the waste prod ucts to collection points for reuse.

title: Rent Curb Held Hurdle To Housing
description: FORT LEENew Jersey's building industry is pictured as ready to break out of its long slump and to begin meeting Governor Cahill's goal of 50,000 new housing units annually. But builders say the boom will come only if the state rejects rent con trol and pushes a uniform building code, and if local communities adopt more bal anced zoning.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Riva Ridge and Turcotte: Right Horse, Right Man
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6I still think we have the right horse, Ron Turcotte said today in the jockeys quarters at Churchill Downs. It was about 1:30 P.M., and hours would pass before he could get up on Riva Ridge and prove that he knew what he was talking about.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Religion
description: The presence among the Harrisburg conspiracytrial defendants of Sister Eliza beth McAlister, a religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, should have erased the stere otype of the Catholic nun as the last of the unliberated species of American wom anhood, a person quietly moving about in unmodern izable garb, speaking only when spoken to, and de tached from the activist life.

title: In the comfortably ruminative Snow manner
description: There is a strong sense, in C. P. Snow's novels, of circles overlapping, of year inextricably linking up with year, of old places trodden over with fresh footprints. The Strangers and Brothers sequence hovers back and forth in setting and time, so that even such a novel as The Masters, which covers events in only one year, casts its backward glances, and itself foreshadows its successors. What Anthony Powell does with a cool and almost disdainful use of co incidence in The Music of Time, Snow achieves more circuitously and, indeed, more crudely.

title: Science
description: There was no inkling of Impending doom. There had been a severe earthquake a day or two earlier and a great scar on a mountainside far up the wild valley showed that a landslide had occurred. But for the 20,000 inhabitants of Khait, a town in the Tad zhik Soviet Socialist Repub lic near the Afghanistan bor der, quakes are so common that little heed was paid.

title: Northeastern Crew Beats Two New England Rivals
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 Northeastern University's un defeated heavyweight crew beat Boston University and the Uni versity of Massachusetts today over the 2,000meter course on the Charles River.

title: U.S. Olympians to Hold Dinner Here on May 17
description: The New York chapter of the United States Olympians will hold its annual dinner on Wednesday, May 17, at the Seventh Regiment Ar mory, Park Avenue and 67th Street. All proceeds from the $10aplate dinner will be turned over to the Olympic Committee.

title: Rumania, Spain Gain in Davis Cup Competition
description: Rumania, which unsuccess fully challenged the United! States for Davis. Cup tennis supremacy last year, clinched a firstround European Zone vic tory over Switzerland yester day when Ilie Nastase and Ion Tirlac combined for a 6.0, 64, 46, 61 doubles triumph over Matthias Werren and Freddy Blatter.

title: Alan Mark to Wed Jean Rosen Aug.19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jochim Rosen of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Rosen, to Alan Mark, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Mark of Bayside, Queens.

title: The World
description: TEL AVIVWhen the Israelis ear lier this year ordered elections of local councils in the occupied West Bank area of Jordan, they figured that in view of Arab guerrilla pressure for an election boycott a 60 per cent turnout would be a political triumph. The turn out in the firstround voting in the northern province of Samaria last March was 84 per cent.

title: Triple Bend Takes Coast Stake On 7Furlong Record of 1:19 4/5
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 6 (UPI)Triple Bend raced to a world record of 1:19 4/5 for seven furlongs today in the $64,600 Los Angeles Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: Crisis of the University Press
description: On April 20 Harvard University President Derek C. Bok announced the interim appointment of Prof. Oscar Handlin, the historian, as Act ing Director of the Harvard Univer sity Press. Following is an account of the crisis leading to this decision.

title: Coney Is. Aquarium Finds Moving Ethel Is a Whale of a Job
description: Romance was astir at the New York Aquarium at Coney Island last week but in one case, at least, it wasn't easy.

title: Janice Walsh a Bride
description: Miss Janice Ann Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Walsh of New York and Mantoloking, N. J., was married here yesterday morn ing to Joseph Patrick Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Kelley of East Green bush, N. Y. Msgr. James F. Rigney performed the cere mony in St. Patrick's Cathe dral, where he concelebrated the mass with the Revs. Donald Logan and David Noonan.

title: FUND ACCUSATION DENIED BY BISHOP
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 6In the latest development in a controversy involving the Afri can Methodist Episcopal Church, Bishop William F. Ball Sr. has denied any mis handling of funds.

title: 5 Die in German Auto Crash
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, May 6 (AP)  At least five persons were killed and 15 injured in a chainreaction col lision on the foggy autobahn near here, the police reported.

title: Executives on Sabbatical Learn To Direct ontheJob Training
description: Eleven business executives from some of New York City's leading enterprises met every day last week in a union hall named for a radical leader where they received intensive training in how to become agents of social change.

title: Overtime Provision Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare has voted to require overtime pay ments for nursing home em ployes after 44 hours, instead of 48 as under present law. It voted to put this provision into a minimum wage bill it is con sidering.

title: The Nation
description: What will he do? they ask, from one end of the country to the other. The President who wanted to be re spected for his calculated fury in the face of adversity has indeed inspired that kind of respectand a good measure of fear as wellat least among his own people. The fear was so intense that even the regular voices of protest were muted.

title: DODGE OPEN TO BEGIN IN JERSEY MAY 16
description: Coach Emile Francis and two of his New York Rangers, Jim Neilson and Rod Gilbert, are expected to play in the ninth Dodge Dealers open golf tour ney at the Rockaway River Country Club, Denville, N. J. starting May 16.

title: Elephants Kill 3 in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 6 (UPI) Wild elephants trampled to death a woman and her two children Thursday at Laldhanga village, about 120 miles north of here in Uttar Pradesh, the Press Trust of India reported. The agency said the victims were sleeping in a but that was crushed by the elephants.

title: Here Are Some Routes For Getting Into Politics
description: RIVER EDGEMany peo ple get into polities after long thought and debate; others stumble into politics almost as an accident, the result of some act totally unconnected with public office.

title: Quiet: Time of Nesting
description: BRIGANTINE Holgate Peninsula, a spit of unspoiled beach and dunes a mile and three quarters long at the southern tip of Long Beach Island, will divide its beauties by Federal fiat be tween man and nesting bird from May 15 to July 30.

title: Mary Poppins as a Zen Monk
description: When I attended the recent cere mony at the New York Public Library, at which P. L. Travers, author of Mary Poppins, made a presenta tion of memorabilia to the newly reopened Central Children's Room, I was not looking for Julie Andrews. Those who know Mary Poppins only in Technicolor have never met the real Mary Poppins. As economical as a Japanese blackandwhite, she is no waster of words, no triller of songs. She is an arbitrary and spon taneous individual who never ex plains anythingbut who compre hends form and fitness, who is self contained, fiercely independent, un predictable, the very essence of the creative spirit. She is, in fact, the embodiment of Zenand one of my students had written a paper to prove it.

title: Jay Baxters Have Son
description: A son was born April 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Jay Baxter of New York at the Univer sity hospital. Mrs. Baxter is the former Miss Roselyn Goldman of Scranton, Pa., whose husband is an optom etrist.

title: $36Million in Back Wages Is Paid to 259,000 Workers
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) A total of 26,256 employers paid more than $36million in back wages that had been ille gally withheld from some 259, 000 workers in the last nine months, the Labor Department says.

title: Soccer Strike Is Called By Referees in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5 (AP)Chile's 93 professional soccer referees and linesmen went on strike today to pro test the temporary sus pension of a referee known as Iron Fist for being rough on rowdy players.

title: Soviet Mediterranean Fleet
description: NAPLES, Italy, May 6 (Reu ters)The strength of the So viet fleet in the Mediterranean is 30 surface ships, including the helicoptercarrying cruiser Leningrad, and 12 to 14 sub marines, an Atlantic alliance spokesman said this week.

title: MISS BURFEINDT 213 LEADS AT LAS VEGAS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 6 (UPI)The field closed in on Betty Burfeindt today in the third round of the Sealy Ladies Professional Golf Association Classic, but the woman from Canaan, N. Y., still took a threestroke lead going into to morrow's finale of the $50,000 event.

title: STATE WILL BEGIN CATSKILL SURVEY
description: ALBANY, May 6A nine man commission, appointed by Governor Rockefeller and state legislative leaders, is about to open a massive study of the Catskill Mountains region.

title: M. K. Dahood Fiance Of Rose Mary Liguori
description: MOUNT LEBANON, Pa., May 6Mr. and. Mrs. Alfonso R. Liguori have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rose Mary Francessca Liguori, to Mi chael Kenneth Dahood, son of Mrs. Michael Dahood of Holmes Beach, Fla., former ly of Hillsdale, N. J., and the late Mr. Dahood.

title: CHURCHES URGED TO BE ACTIVISTS
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., May 6  A conference of theologians, Protestant clergymen and scholars has urged that the nation's churches take an activist role in dealing with threats to man's survival in an ecologically plundered world.

title: Rogers Arrives in Bonn To Start ThreeDay Visit
description: BONN, West Germany, May 6 (Reuters)Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here today for a threeday visit, as West German political leaders sought to work out a joint dec laration of policy on the good will treaties with Moscow and Warsaw.

title: RUTGERS OARSMEN DEFEAT COLUMBIA
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 6The Rutgers heavy weight crew scored what its coach. Bill Leavitt, called a predictable victory over Co lumbia in a 2,000meter rade on the Raritan River today under perfection conditions.

title: Florida Millionaire Yields In Charges of Conspiracy
description: ORLANDO, Fla., May 6 (AP) Glenn Turner, a millionaire, surrendered to Orange County sheriff's deputies today after three warrants had, been issued for his arrest on conspiracy charges stemming from a grand jury investigation.

title: Authors Attend Literary Forum At High School in New Rochelle
description: New Rochelle, N.Y., May 6 Twentysix contemporary Am erican authors met with the students of New Rochelle High School this week and quickly learned that when the students asked questions, they wanted direct answers.

title: Pennsylvania Parole Board Plans to Install a Computer
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 6 (AP)The Slate Board of Par dons and Parole plans to com puterize supervision of all pa roles under its jurisdiction.

title: South Vietnamese Said to Blame U.S. for Reverses
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6South Vietnamese journal ists back from the embattled northern regions of the coun try report that soldiers and ci vilians are speaking with re sentment of the United States, placing the blame for Saigon's military reverses on a failure of American support and sus pecting collusion between Ha noi and Washington.

title: Marie Claudel, M. A. Student, Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Marie Helene Claudel and Edward Gilly, graduate students at Columbia Univer sity, will be married here on May 31.

title: M.I.T. CREW VICTOR IN COCHRANE CUP
