description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 A determined Massachusetts In stitute of Technology varsity heavyweight crew hung on to a halflength lead throughout the race today to edge Wiscon sin in the 12th annual Cochrane Cup regatta on the Charles River's 2,000meter course.

title: A Little Bit About a Lot of Black Folks
description: Sometimes, black people will tell you, a person will get an attitude and then you can't deal with him at all. Books are like that. For instance THEY DARED TO LEAD: America's Black Athletes, edited by Phyllis and Zander Hollander. (NortonGrosset & Dunlap. $4.95).

title: Faith Ford Wed to F. H. Sandstrom
description: IRVINGTON, Va., May 6 Christ Episcopal Church here was the setting at noon for the wedding of Miss Faith Ford and Frederick Harris Sandstrom. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jefferson Ford of Kil marnock, formerly of Sands Point, L.I. The Rev. Robert Sheeran performed the cere mony.

title: The World
description: ROMEItalian voters will find six or seven different hammerandsickle symbols on their ballots when they go to the polls today and tomorrow to elect a new Parliament. But there is little chance of Italy's drifting fur ther to the left as a result of the election. The big and ominous ques tion is over the strength of Italian neoFascism.

title: Back to Miami Beach
description: A national political convention involves complicated logistics in housing, feeding and transporting thousands of delegates and visitors as well as serving the special communication needs of newspapers and television. For these mundane reasons, it is always a help all around for both parties to convene in the, same city and to choose one whichlike Miami Beachhas ample facili ties and experience. The decision of the Republican National Committee to shift this year's G.O.P. conven tion to Miami Beach, where the Democrats are already scheduled to meet, thus makes sense in practical terms.

title: BUFFALO OARSMEN TAKE RACE HERE
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 6  Buffalo State University won the lightweight champion ship eightoared shell event of the ninth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate rowing cham pionship today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon Olympic rowing course.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MADISONSmack in the middle of Prospect Street Street here, there is a great oak tree. Rather than destroy the fine tree, the road was built around it. That judg ment (reflectors surround the oak, so it's not too much of a traffic hazard) was made more than 100 years ago, and somehow it seems to have set the tone for Madison's subsequent growth.

title: Agency Says Auto Recalls In 1971 Reached 8.8 Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Domestic automobile manu facturers recalled almost 8.8 million cars last year in 182 safety defect campaigns, ac cording to the National High way Traffic Safety Administra tion.

title: Indians Trounce White Sox by 120 as Perry Scatters Three Hits
description: CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP) Gaylord Perry scattered three hits while his Cleveland Indian teammates collected 18 and took advantage of four errors to rout the Chicago White Sox, 120, today.

title: Ickx Wins 132Mile Race In Francorchamps WarmUp
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, May 6 (UPI)  Jacky Ickx warmed up today for tomor row's 1,000 kilometers of Fran corchamps auto race by win ning the Coupes de Spa grand tourism event for Group Two sports cars.

title: A U.S.Irish Donnybrook Over Air Service to Dublin
description: SHANNON, IrelandThe greenand white sticker on the rear window of the automobile exhorted: Save ShannonPreserve Irish Landing Rights! Scrawled in chalk on a brick wall near the town of Limerick was still another message: No Pan Am [to] Dublin.

title: Passage of Federal Water Pollution Bill This Session Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Dif ferences in the House and Sen ate water pollution control bills are so fundamental that pas sage of legislation this session is in doubt.

title: Kings Point to Honor Liebertz, Retiring Head of Athletics
description: Capt. James W. Liebertz, athletic director of the United States Merchant Marine Acad emy, will be honored May 15 with a testimonial dinner mark ing his retirement.

title: The American Heritage School Dictionary
description: A publicity release that accom panies this book is nine months pregnant with superlatives (most extensive, first, largest,) au thenticated in a grapeshot burst of big statistics. The mammoth research effort is largely vindicated by its resultthough I suspect that, in some part at least, the A.H.S.D. provided six years' busy work for itinerant semanticists and programmers dur ing a time of high unemployment.

title: Antigua Star Is Winner Of Hunt Meetings Award
description: Coventry Rock Stable's An tigua Star has won the Dixie Circuit award by compiling the most points in brush and hurdle events at the six hunt race meetings in the Carolinas and Georgia this spring.

title: NEW WORKS GIVEN IN FIVE CONCERTS
description: If the Composers Theater Festival had been able to main tain the quality it promised with its first concert at the New School on Monday, the series of five events that ended Friday would surely have seemed a laudable undertaking.

title: SAIGON TO REMOVE 30,000 CIVILIANS STILL IN KONTUM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 7The South Vietnamese Government an nounced last night that it had decided to evacuate all civilians from Kontum city, in the Cen tral Highlands, south to Pleiku by road.

title: Mrs. Barry 10and8 Victor For Women's Golf Tourney
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 6 (UPI)  The defending cham pion Mrs. Beth Barry of Mobile, Ala., defeated Mrs. Wanda Hendrix of Tyler, Tex., 10 and 8, in 36 holes of match play today to capture the Women's Southern golf championship.

title: The Cowboy Trade
description: Do you know what it's like getting caught out on the prairie, when blueblack clouds roll in so dense it gets to be twilight do the afternoon, light ning flashing brilliant white, and you the highest thing for miles around? It's more dan gerous than taking your gun to town, son. That's the sort of thing you'll learn from Glen Rounds' new book. It's one of the best.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 6 As North Carolina voted today, the 1972 Democratic primary cam paign reached the halfway point with Senators George McGov ern and Hubert H. Humphrey all even.

title: CORNELL DEFEATS PRINCETON, YALE
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 6Cor nell's heavyweight crew suc cessfully defended the Carnegie Cup today with a decklength victory over Princeton. The Big Red's winning time on Ith aca's west end floodcontrol channel was 5 minutes 50.6 sec onds. Princeton finished in 5:51.4 and Yale was third in 5:59.

title: $10.60 SHOT WINS ON FOUL IN JERSEY
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 6 (AP)  East Acres' Northern Bay was declared the winner of the $29,225 Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park today after ElceeH Stable's New Alibhai, the firstplace fin isher, was disqualified and placed second.

title: Fire Base 42 the Morning After
description: FIRE BASE 42, South Viet nam May 6This strongly fortified and defended base, only three miles north of Pleiku and part of that city's inner defense system, was a burning, exploding wasteland of debris, wrecked cannon and bunkers and mutilated bodies this morning.

title: The Lilies of May
description: May is a lily month, among other things, particularly the month of the lesser lilies of the fields. In the flower garden the domesticated lilies of the valley come to honeysweet blossom, of course. But in the damp woods there are whole beds of lilies hurrying to bloom before the deep shade of full leafing overhead closes in.

title: SITE STUDY URGED FOR POWER PLANTS
description: The New England River Basins Commission has sug gested Environmental Trust Funds in each of the New Eng land states and New York for the evaluation of sites for fu ture power plants.

title: SEA LAMPREY WAR BOON FOR FISHING
description: HAMMOND BAY, Mich. May 6Prospects for good sports fishing in Lake Ontario are be ginning to appear on the hori zon.

title: School: How to Cope With Life for Schizophrenic Children
description: EAST ORANGEFor the 36 children going to school at the Children's Institute here, learning is a matter not simply of the three R's, but of coping with life itself.

title: Jet Hijacked to Cuba
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 6 (UPI) A youth hijacked a jetliner to Cuba today, threatening death to President Nixon and declar ing that the skies of America will not be safe again until the United States Government ceases its aggression in Indo china.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFrom the outset of Phase Two, wage and price controls have been administered and enforced by a thin, redeyed line of overworked officials, experts and bureaucrats.

title: HOSPITAL HOMICIDE IS STUDIED IN QUEENS
description: The police and the Queens District Attorney's office yes terday were investigating a homicide in the Interfaith Hos pital of Queens, which is owned by NEGRO and is head ed by Dr. Thomas Matthew, leader of the black selfhelp or ganization.

title: Shooting Victim Wins Suit
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 6 (UPI)The, City of Montpelier was ordered yesterday to pay an Ithaca, N.Y., man $100,000 for negligence in failing to protect him during a 1970 shooting in a city park. The victim, Alan Wheeler, was shot by a man in custody of city police.

title: My Brother Paul
description: Jesus, yes; Paul, never! would be the feeling of not a few professed Christians, as well as nonChristians and Jews. Paul suffers from a bad press among selfconscious moderns. It is doubtful that most of the dim views of him could survive a full reading of his Letters, but he is com monly thought to have corrupted the supposed simplicities of Jesus in the Gospels with a Hellenized theology and an abstract doctrine of Christ.

title: Columbia Medical Alumni Honor 3 for Leadership
description: Awards were presented last night to two alumni and a member of the graduating class of 1972 by the Association of the Alumni of Columbia Uni versity's College of Physicians and. Surgeons at its annual din ner at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Jesuits Return Land, With Addition, to Kansas Tribe
description: ST. LOUIS, May 6A 320 acre plot of Kansas prairie land given in 1848 by the Potawa tomi Indians to Jesuit mission aries has been paid back with interest.

title: Now the Main Event: Greased Wrestling
description: EDIRNE, TurkeyIt is early June. All week long an island in the Tunca River here has been filling with encampments of gypsies and village farm folk. They picnic together at long lines of spits, roasting hundreds of plump sheep and goats, and they crowd into a carnival's crude rides and sideshows. Last year one hawker with a deafmute gypsy woman at his side offered visitors a look at a real live mermaid for the bargain of a lifetime: three cents. The main event here, however, is the. 611th annual Turkish greased wrestling tournament, one of the most historic and colorful pageants that a visitor can see in modern Turkey. This year's championships will take place from June 7 through 13.

title: Voyageurs Beat Clippers
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Ca nadian Press, May 6Nova Scotia Voyageur's forward, Chuck Arnason, scored three goals to lead his team to a 61 victory over the Baltimore Clip pers tonight. Baltimore holds a 21 lead in their fourofseven game final playoff for the American Hockey League's Calder Cup.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I am annoyed to see the youth air fares in existence again this summer. That the Government continues to con done Let's Go to Europe instead of See U.S.A. is in comprehensible. Middle  aged Americans, who are com pelled to pay full fare, have already traveled throughout the U.S.; today, however, we are raising a generation of young people who are more familiar with the Colosseum than the Grand Canyon. If young people were encour aged to visit the many sights of America, they could de velop a greater sense of pride in their country. It's time to end the discrimination leveled at the over25's.

title: Promises, promises, from Lincoln to Johnson
description: When a gigantic gob pile col lapsed on Buffalo Creek in Logan County, West Virginia on February 25, 1972, it sent a wall of water 30 feet high roaring through a dozen of those jaded, dilapidated and trashstrewn coal towns that typify the central Appalachians. Rows of flimsy camp houses were reduced to splinters, 117 people perished and the floor of the valley was covered with a foul layer of gray, dead slate, waste coal and mud. Newsmen de scended on the horror and, lo, Ap palachia was discovered again! There was a frantic rush of politi cians to express sympathy, to in vestigate, and to make certain that nothing much would change as a result of the region's latest calamity.

title: Israeli Premier Ends Rumanian Talks
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 6Premier Golda Meir of Is rael completed an intensive round of talks with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today but reportedly found no new openings to break the Middle Eastern diplomatic deadlock.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: PRINCETON MOYES TO PUNISH SITINS
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 The dean of students of Prince ton University, Neil L. Ruden stine, summarized this week the school's reasons for pressing disciplinary charges against 88 of the students who occupied the main administration build ing nearly three weeks ago.

title: Picture Books
description: The picturebook pendulum is on a backward stroke this spring, a swing from sophisti cation to nostalgia with the re issue or retelling of old, old favorites, a few from our not toimmediate past, and endur ing folk tales. One hardy sur vivor is RED RIDING HOOD Retold in Verse for Boys and Girls to Read Themselves, by Beatrice Schenk de Regniers, with drawings by Edward Go rey (Atheneum. $5.25). This is the book based on the Broth ers Grimm version, in which a hunter slices open the sleeping wolf to rescue the already swallowed Grandma and Red, fills the animal's belly with stones, and sews him up with out waking him. The verse is easy, lilting, with unexpected twists; Gorey's solemnsly drawings, printed in two col ors (putty and hoodred), are properly ungory. The gobbling up and slicingopen are done offcamera, so to speak, and more deftly than usual: Gorey arms his hunter with a dagger!

title: DISNEY CUTS BACK ON RESORT PLANS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6The Wait Disney organization has proposed major changes in the size and character of its $30 million Mineral King resort project, which conservationists recently opposed in a United States Supreme Court action.

title: Surge in Group Air Travel Is Expected If New Trans Atlantic Rules Are Voted
description: Government regulators in the United States and Europe are moving toward the adoption of new transAtlantic flight regulations that many travel leaders ex pect will touch off a new explosion in mass air travel at low fares.

title: An American Writer's Son Shot to Death in Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 6 (UPI)Mark Lewis, 26year old son of Ray Lewis, an American writer, was shot to death last Sunday while camp ing on a roadside near Sibi in Baluchistan Province, the police here said today.

title: Undefeated Harvard Oarsmen Capture Adams Cup as Penn's New Shell Sinks
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 Harvard's undefeated crew beat Navy while the Penn boat sank in the Adams Cup race today. The Red and Blue shell went down at the halfway mark of the 2,000meter race after hold ing a slight lead in the early going on the rough, windy Schuylkill River.

title: Laura Schoetz Engaged to Wed Timothy B. Ely
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., May 6  Mr. and Mrs. Maximilian C. Schoetz of Bloomfield Hills and OId Black Point, Corm., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Randolph Schoetz, to Tim othy Bassett Ely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Griswold Ely Jr. of Pelham, N. Y., and Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Son to Succeed Father
description: BOSTON, May 3 (UPI)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has ap pointed John C. Boyden to ful fill his late father's term as trustee of the University of Massachusetts. Dr. Frank L. ?? died last week.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: These are palmy days for the housing and homefinance market. Record housing starts, a massive flow of new deposits to mortgage lenders and the prospect of fat prof its for just about everybody are the theme this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jimmy Stewart, Josh Logan Go Back to Nassau Hall for Triangle Club Fete
description: PRINCETONIn the win ter of 1931, a Princeton un dergraduate named James Stewart won warm praise for playing the lead role in this school's Triangle Club production of Spanish Blades.

title: Devlin Posts 67 for 206 and TwoStroke Lead in Houston Golf Tournament
description: HOUSTON, May 6 (AP)  Bruce Devlin of Australia came from five strokes off the pace with a 167 today and opened up a twoshot lead in the third round of the $125,000 Houston open golf tournament.

title: Frog and Toad Together
description: It's the simple things that are the hardest to say. And that's how it is with easy readers, where a too often limited vo cabulary begets dull characters and tooconcrete situations. Ar nold Lobel is an exception to this dismal truismfirst with Frog and Toad Are Friends, now in this second book of their adventures, both I Can Read books.

title: New York
description: ALBANYThe annual legislative Walpurgisnacht is under way with the state's 207 lawmakers busily engaged in massacring the mother tongue as they act on major legislation they have ignored since convening in January.

title: 22 LABOR LEADERS PLAN PEACE DRIVE
description: A group of 22 labor leaders from 13 unions have agreed to call a broadly based national conference to set up an organ ization, Labor for Peace, aimed at bringing the Vietnam war to; an immediate end.

title: Helen H. Scheidecker Is Affianced
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., May 6  Miss Helen Hardy Scheidecker, who expects to graduate May 21 from the University of Vermont, and Theodore Martin Riehle 3d, a teacher at the Mount Mans field Union High School in Stowe, Vt., will be married Sept, 9 on Crow Nest, an is land in Lake Champlain.

title: The Door Is Still Open to Gertrude Stein's Summer Salon
description: GERTRUDE STEIN and her dedi cated companion, Alice B. Toklas, discovered the departments of Ain, Savoie and HauteSavoie in France one summer to the midnineteen twenties while en route to visit their friend Picasso at Antibes. They found the countryside, regional fare and small hotels and inns so satisfying they de cided to stay that summerand several suceeding summersat the Hotel Per nollet in Belley; then they came across in Bilignin, not far from Belley, the com modious old manor house they were to rent as their summer home for 14 years.

title: CARTHEFT SUSPECT GIVES UP IN SUFFOLK
description: BABYLON, L. I., May 6A 28yearold man wanted on charges of masterminding a stolsencar ring surrendered to the police here this morning.

title: Is It alentine's Day in May?
description: THESE days it costs so much time, patience and money to go to the movies that it's not difficult to understand why a few, usually critically successful films do all the busi ness while most others barely limp along until someone comes by and picks them up for televisionas if they were horses worthy only of a glue factory. Some of these movies are certifiable junk. Some are really pretty goad, and in an earlier, more perfect time (or, at least, in a time when it wasn't so easy to do something other than go to the movies) they might have attracted a rather larger percentage of the audience than they will now.

title: Miss Sherry Pine Bride of Lawyer
description: of counseling services for the New York Diabetes Associa tion, was married here yes terday evening to William Samuel Brown Jr., a corpo rate lawyer with Nabisco, Inc., at its international headquarters here.

title: The Specialness Of Growing Up In Washington, D.C.
description: WASHINGTON. THE world from where I stand is made of marble; white, but I had not remembered that white could have such variety. The crags of the face of Daniel Chester French's Lin coln could be made of cream. I have a sudden expectation that the whole massive figure will begin to burble and slide, a great, gooey avalanche of cream that will roll over us like the Flood in Bible movies.

title: Twins Beat Red Sox, 32
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)Har mon Killebrew drove in three runs, two with a tiebreaking double in the eighth inning, to lead the Minnesota Twins to their fourth straight victory, a 32 triumph, over the Boston Red Sox today.

title: Gardese
description: When the forsythia and magnolias bloom in the city, tis time for the penthouse planters to dust off their trowels and spades and begin. Newcomers to the growing of plants on penthouses and terraces should keep in mind that, in the city, everything is greater than in the country.

title: At a Camp Near Saigon: Youths Tell of Captivity
description: GODAU, South Vietnam, May 6As darkness fell, the North Vietnamese soldiers emerged from their bunkers, confident that American war planes could no longer spot them, Lam Cuoi said, and lec tured him and his companions about Communist politics.

title: REPORT OF INJURY LIFTS DICK HOPES
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6Wiit Chamberlain has a severely sprained right wrist and may not be able to play for the Los Angeles Lakers against the New York Knicks tomorrow night.

title: OKLAHOMA VOTING LED BY M'GOVERN
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 6 Senator George McGovern made a strong statewide show ing in precinct caucuses last night and appeared to have swamped Democratic party regulars, in the fight for con vention delegates from Okla homa City and Tulsa.

title: Minneapolis Editor Rises
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 (UPI) Bower Hawthorne, editor of The Minneapolis Tribune, has been appointed vice president for public affairs of the Minne apolis Star and Tribune Com pany, John Cowles Jr., presi dent of the company, an nounced.

title: Gardens
description: THE GENUS CAPSICUM includes many species of peppers: Sweet fleshed peppers used for stuffing or slicing raw; also the mild pimiento or Spanish paprika. Hot spicy kinds such as chili or cay enne peppers, or the tabasco. Fruits or pods of all peppers are boxy (the botanical name derives from the Latin capsa meaning box) but of various shapes.

title: Leeds Tops Arsenal, 10, in Association Cup Final
description: LONDON, May 6for the 100th time, England engaged to day in her annual sports ritual, the Football Association Chal lenge Cup, and marked the oc casion with just about every thing but lions.

title: Legislative Notes: School Aid For the Handicapped Sought
description: TRENTON  If Governor Cahill gives his approval, the State Senate is prepared to authorize a $25million bond issue to finance day schools for seriously handicapped children.

title: BIG NAVY PROJECT STIRS WISCONSIN
description: MADISON, WIS., May 6 Project Sanguine, a United States Navy effort to build a giant underground communica tion antenna across several thousand square miles of north ern Wisconsin, was very much alive this week after more than three years of controversy.

title: New & Novel
description: This sad little novella pin points a neglected area of so ciology: the overprivileged rem nant in the inner city. Doesn't anyone care about these poor little rich Rids growing up along Park Avenue, with psy chiatrists as surrogate papas? Miss Gilbert does for oneand pours her feelings into a callow but genuine cry from the heart.

title: REV. GEORGE WHITMORE
description: OSSINING, N.Y., May 6 The Rev. George Merle Whit more, minister in charge of the John Hall Memorial Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York from 1930 to 1945, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He, was 86 years old.

title: Canada's Adroit Move
description: WASHINGTON  Looking at Canada's new policy to screen foreign takeovers of Canadian businesses, Canada watchers here credit Ottawa with adroitness.

title: New Museum in Delaware Stresses Ecology of Birds and Sea Life
description: GREENVILLE, Del., May 6 The first major museum of na tural history to be established in this country since 1910 will be, opened to the public here next Saturday.

title: Macao's Population Rises
description: MACAO (AP)Nearly 250, 000 people lived in the six square miles of this Portuguese enclave on the China mainland in 1971, census figures revealed an increase of about 80,000 over a decade ago.

title: Caddie Confrontation
description: Will the present caddie im passe mar or disrupt the 1972 Westchester Golf Classic? This $250,000 tournament has been a fixture in the metropolitan area. Its success is measured by the $1.5million it has raised for charity during the last six years. But for the tour nament the golfers must use local caddies, not those who tour with them.

title: Worms and Weeds and Other Heroes
description: When I was in the first grade, our teacher took us all one spring day to a tiny pond in the woods a few miles from the school, which was in eastern Massachusetts. It was hardly a pond, actually no more than a leaf choked, marshy depression among the hardwoods. But it was secluded, and too modest to attract many visitors. With mason jars and dip nets, we spent the morning captur ing mosquito wrigglers, dragonfly nymphs, tadpoles, hydras and roti ferswhich we later watched per form. I was intrigued. I can still re call the immense variety and com plexity of that little wet world, the savage drama going on with seething ferocity under that apparently tranquil sheet of water.

title: The nubiness of memoir and no plot
description: Summer had been lovely in spite of the airraids and Dun kirk and everything and she seemed to be getting on better with people. No one was as surprised as I was  to hear that Cissie Horrible Comber bitch had overheard our form mistress Miss Dobbs telling Miss Somebody Else in the staffroom that Jessica Vye was getting above herself and need ed a bit of setting down.

title: TORTURE IS LAID TO RIO'S MILITARY
description: ?? DE JANEIRO, May 6 Reports by prisoners released within the last month indicate that, after a lull of several months, torture has again be come a regular method of inter rogation in Brazilian military installations here.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LEXINGTON, Va., May 6 (UPI) Six Democratic Presi dential hopefuls were nomi nated today at the Washington and Lee University mock con vention, traditionally one of the most accurate in the nation in predicting the Presidential nominees.

title: The Nation
description: OMAHAAnd now there are two.

title: Art
description: THE Museum of NonOb jective Painting was always a bit pseudo voluptuous, what with ankledeep walltowall car peting, overstuffed divans, enormous tailormade silver or gold frames on paintings in stalled only inches from the floor, soft piped music (pref erably Bach) plus a faint sug gestion of scented air. The last may be a figment of my imagination which often worked overtime when ex posed to the indulgences of this Manhattan institution. It was the unexpected that made a visit there such a provoca tive experience, for all neat museum theories were blithe ly ignored. On the walls hung outstanding works by the greatest masters of the early 20th century, frequently crowded out by the preten tious canvases of inferior imi tators. Even an untutored eye could spot the difference, or so I like to believe.

title: Cubs Check Astros, 64
description: CHICAGO, May 6 (AP)Car men Fanzone, subbing for the injured Ron Santo, cracked a pair of tapemeasure home runs and Jim Hickman added one to day to give the Chicago Cubs a 64 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Algeria Awaits Castro
description: ALGIERS, May 6 (Reuters) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba will make an official visit to Algeria Monday, the Algiers radio announced today. Mr. Castro, no visiting Guinea, is expected to spend about a week in Algeria before going on to eastern Europe.

title: Friday Night Fight
description: New York (Sunnyside Garden) Roy Edmonds, 159 pounds, New York, knocked out Carlos Robledo, 159, Chaco, Argentina, 2 rounds.

title: Music
description: THAT great thinker and tinkerer Henry Ford found his way into Bartlett's by proclaiming that his tory is bunk, and on some supra Hegelian level he may have something there. But there are certain facts that seem, if not beyond dispute, at least truer than others. Such as, that Igor Stravinsky died a year ago last month, that he lies buried in Venice, and that he would have been 90 next month. We must try to hold on to such facts, no matter how elementary, if only because it has been increasingly evident that too much of what we know of Stravinsky in the last 20 years or so has been com ing to us through a thick gauze named Robert Craft.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6Ron Turcotte wheeled around the bench at the far end of the jockey room after his smashing front run for victory in the Kentucky Derby and came face to face with a grinning Don Brumfield. They shook hands and there was an extra fervor to Brumfield's clasp because he once had been through it all when he rode Kauai King to a similarblanket of roses six years ago. I know just how you must have felt, Don, said the happy Turcotte. Wonderful, ain't it? said Brumfield. It sure is,said Turcotte, still looking slightly dazed by the wonder of it all.

title: Stamps,
description: Two Ming Dynasty (13681655) hand scrolls, one 85.9 feet long, the other 98.2 feet long, each 3.2 feet high and depicting a journey by a 16th century Chinese emperorShihtsung (1522 1566), twelfth Ming emperor form the basis for a two tier issue of Republic of China stamps. One install ment is due in June, the other in July. The journey depicted is from Peking to imperial tombs at Chengtien, Hupeh province, and the return.

title: IndianPakistan Truce Reported After Day of Fighting in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, May 6 (Reuters)  India and Pakistan have or dered an immediate ceasefire in the dayold fighting in the Kaiyan area of Kashmir, an Indian Defense Ministry state ment said tonight.

title: NORTH REPORTS RAID 50 MILES FROM HANOI
description: TOKYO, May 6 (UPI)North Vietnam said that United States warplanes raided Namdinh city, 50 miles south of Hanoi today, killing and wounding many civilians.

title: FIVE EVENTS WON BY ES. PLUMB
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., May 6while Mike Plumb is in Eu rope warming up for the Olym pics with the United States Equestrian Team's threeday squad, his wife, Dorman, is looking ahead to 1976.

title: FULBERT YOULOU, EXCONGO LEADER
description: MADRID, May 6 (AP)Ful bert Youlou, former President of the Republic of the Congo, died here last night. He was 55 years old.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The biggest problem facing us today is not Com munism but garbage disposal. The Government has been too slow to grasp this reality. Governments, maybe because they are so often dominated by military men, are almost always slow to leave the comfortable unreality of the past for the uncertainty, of the present.

title: VARIED FARE SETS BRONX WEEK TONE
description: With merriment and medical examinations, thousands of Bronxites yesterday began a week of events to tell the world  and one another  of the pleasures and problems of life in their borough.

title: ENGLISH TEACHERS IN DEMAND IN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, May 6An acute shortage of teachers with knowledge of the language is a major problem in the new drive in China to teach English in the nation's schools, starting with primary grades.

title: Lieut. Michael McRee Weds Mary Gorman
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 6 Miss Mary Lynn Gorman and Lieut. Michael Jon Mc Ree, U.S.A., were married here at noon today in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Robert L. Brown.

title: Largest Lake Ship Begins Hauling Ore
description: ERIE, Pa., May 6The Stewart J. Cortat 1,000 feet long and 105 feet wide the largest ship ever to sail the Great Lakeswent into service this week hauling iron ore for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The following are excerpts from a paper, Power to the People, by Eugene Guccione, metallurgical editor of The Engineering and Mining Jour nal, presented before the Graduate School of business Administration of Brigham Young University, April 10, 1972:

title: Nigeria and Togo Plan Economic Link
description: PALIME, Togo, May 1With a few rhythmic twists and an engaging smile, the Nigerian chief of state, Maj. Gen. Ya kubu Gowon, has crossed the language barrier to win broad popular acclaim in this former French colony.

title: Travel Notes: Bugs Bunny in Zagreb, ArtCuisine Tours, Index to England
description: MOVIE buffs are in vited to join a group flying to Zagreb, Yugoslavia, next month for the annual World Animated Film Festival. The contingent will be led by James Manilla, the president of the New York Film Coun cil, who also teaches film courses at New York Uni versity. About 100 animated movies from all over the world will be competing for prizes at the festival, which previously had always been held in France. The event will also include an American Re trospective program featur ing Bugs Bunny, Mr. Magoo and the Pink Panther  and their creators, who will be among the many profession al movie people at the festi val.

title: President Supports Repeal Of State Law on Abortion
description: President Nixon, taking an unusual step into a state legis lative fight, enunciated his sup port yesterday for a campaign to repeal New York's liberal ized abortion law.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, May 6The Govern ment today mobilized 60,000 army troops to help guard polling stations during the critical twoday general elec tion that will start at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Helen Meyer Sets Wedding
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 6 Mrs. W. Hayward Powers Jr. of Boca Raton and Blake man Quintard Meyer Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Justine Meyer, to Richard Putnam Murdock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcom Putnam Murdock of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: New Meadows Plan Hinted
description: LYNDHURST The Hac kensack Meadowlands Devel opment, Commission may modify its master plan for the meadows in order to mus ter votes in the state Legis lature for passage of a cru cial amendment to the 1968 law that created the regional agency.

title: Englewoocl's Actors' Home: A Haven for Old Troupers
description: ENGLEWOODSara Floyd, 77 years old and a veteran of 34 Broadway shows, says she will never live in Man hattan again. And this both ers her.

title: Childrens Books
description: There's something suspect in the designations: Young Adults. Litera ture for Young Adults. YA.

title: Nancy K. Cash, John Tremaine Wed in South
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C. May 6Miss Nancy Katha rine Cash and John McGean Tremaine were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Dudley Colhoun Jr. in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Miss Dennehy Is Bride on L.I.
description: SETAUKET, L. L, May 6 The marriage of Miss Deirdre Dennehy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dennehy, to Walter Frank Roettinger 2d took place this afternoon. The bridegroom, who expects to graduate next month from the University of Virginia School of Medicine, is the son of Dr. Roettinger of Lake Ronkonkoma and the late Mrs. Roettinger. The Rev. John Priestly Mitton per formed the ceremony in the Caroline Episcopal Church.

title: Price Panel Warns 400 on Profit Reports
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Price Commission released to day its first list of major com panies that it said had failed to file required quarterly reports of profit margins and warned of penalties if the companies did not promptly comply.

title: Behavioral Principle: Testosterone Rules
description: Numerous animal studies have confirmed that there is a curious link between the male hormone, testosterone, and levels of ongoing ag gression. In the mouse, for example, fighting among males commences with the onset of puberty, when hor mone levels are rising ab ruptly. Female mice fight only rarely, as is the case for males which have been castrated. When male mouse castrates are given testo sterone injections, however, they display normal male adult fighting behavior within matter of hours.

title: Inquiry on Pooling Of Revenue Slated
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 The Federal Maritime Com mission decided yesterday to hold early hearings to inves tigate a proposal by leading North Atlantic container ship lines to pool revenues.

title: DerbrOTB:$2.4MillionBet; Winner Returns $6.80 Here
description: Offtrack betting's second Kentucky Derby Special strug gled to the finish line here yesterday with a disappointing handle of $2.4million but a bigger payoff on Riva Ridge than the one at Churchill Downs.

title: Television
description: IT'S time for a bit of grumbling. Perhaps it al ways is. But for today's text, I would like to grum ble about a few things that have no direct connection with each other. About edi torial writers. About space shots on television.

title: Farny Wurlitzer Dead at 88; Headed Organ Manufacturers
description: BUFFALO, May 6, (AP) Farny R. Wurlitzer, former president and retired board chairman of the Wurlitzer Com pany, died today at his home in suburban Kenmore. He was 88 years old.

title: 3 RADICALS FINISH A YEAR IN OFFICE
description: BERKELEY, May 6A full year in office has done little to dampen the controversy sur rounding Berkeley's three radi cal members of the City Coun cil.

title: Announcements 5000
description: Births

title: Criminals At Large
description: If you like the Helen Mac Innes blend of action, romance, international spy stuff and wellresearched backgrounds, you should try Evelyn Anth ony's THE POELLENBERG IN HERITANCE (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $6.95). Anthony, a British lady, handles the genre just as well as her fa mous American counterpart, and there is much in common in the two approaches. The pace is leisurely, the buildup inexorable. A great deal of at tention is paid to character de velopment. Both writers have a deft touch, though Anthony is not the propagandist that Mac Innes is. The latter almost al ways has a message involving the threat of Communism against the United States. Anth ony merely tells a story.

title: C. W. Post Nine Wins, 92.
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 6 C. W. Post defeated Brooklyn College, 92, today behind the fivehit pitching of Boyd Hal vik. Al Striano and Tom Kowal chickh led Post's 13hit attack. Striano got a double and a home run and Kowalchick had three hits and two runs bat ted in.

title: The World
description: Turkey in recent months has seen a wave of terrorism by the anti American, Marxistoriented People's Liberation Army. The Government has proclaimed martial law in key prov inces and cities and has arrested and tried hundreds of terrorist suspects, Three ringleaders have been con demned to death.

title: Ocean County Just Grows, Grows, Grows, Grows and Grows
description: Ocean County is growing so rapidly that quite literal ly more than 50 new build ing lots are carved out of its sprawling acreage on the average every day.

title: 25,000 PUPILS VISIT TEEN ARTS FESTIVAL
description: TRENTONAbout 25,000 highschool pupils  double last year's turnoutvisited the State Cultural Center during last week for the 1972 edition of the Teen Arts Festival. As many as 2,000 came to exhibit their crea tions in the arts and crafts, play music, perform on stage or help move the scenery.

title: Music
description: I SUPPOSE Bob Dylan is the closest thing to a culture hero this genera ation has. He's no prophet; apart from the fact that he's disclaimed the role, you'd have to be desperate for discipleship to follow Dylan any where. He has never been a profound thinker; he is, if anything, both anti political and antiintellectual. But he a hero, in the John P. Marquand sense of someone who does something super latively well.

title: MiniTown Teaches Traffic Safety
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I. May 6Within minutes after the Nassau County Police De partment opened its minia ture safety town here this week to teach young school children traffic safety, there was a fourcar accident on one of its 10footwide macadam roads.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The political and gastro nomic borders between France and Switzerland were confused in the article on Geneva (Travel section, March 5). The author stated correctly that Switzerland is not for gourmets, but gourmets do not consider, Geneva a part of Switzerland. The Michelin Guide to France has long listed the city, and the 1972 edition of the Kleber Guide, the patron of the cur rent French culinary renais sance, includes it in every gastronomad's pilgrimage across France. Twice during recent months, the food edi tor of Le Monde has called his readers to Geneva to enjoy French cooking. In addition to the restaurants mentioned in your article, readers should know of the Hotel du Rhone, the Chat Botte and the Buffet Coma vin, as well as the Auberge du Lion d'Or in Cologny, just outside Geneva.

title: EXPORTS OF STEEL TO U.S. TO BE CUT FOR THREE YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Major European and Japanese steel producers have agreed to new, threeyear export restraints that are intended to reduce steel imports into the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In the heart of every Amer ican woman beats at least a little bit of women's lib.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE ADMINISTRATION exempted millions of small busi nessesthose with 60 employes or fewerfrom wage and price controls. The Price Commission suspended price increases for 1,500 major corporations that failed to sub mit profitmargin reports on time and released industry wide productivity figures that, it said, should pare the average price increase to 2.80% from 3.2%. The Ad ministration is preparing to increase substantially import quotas, for foreign crude oil to alleviate the U.S. fuel short age. The oil and naturalgas industries, backed by sev eral states, asked that the F.P.C.'s proposal for higher prices on new supplies of natural gas, be expanded to in clude gas now flowing to consumers.

title: Pravda Is 60 Years Old
description: MOSCOW, May 6 (Reuters) Pravda, the official news paper of the Soviet Communist party, celebrated its 60th birth day yesterday. Pravda  the word means truthfirst ap peared on May 5, 1912, in what was then St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, five years before the revolution. Original spon sors included Lenin, Stalin, and Molotov. In the birthday trib utes, only Lenin was mentioned.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 6During this latest crisis in Vietnam, there has been a mood of morbid anxiety in Wash ington, a combination of waiting for the bombs to fall on Haiphong plus a feeling that this is very risky busi ness which will not halt the enemy's offensive.

title: U.S. PLANNING DRIVE ON HOUSING FRAUDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reu ters)The Justice Department is organizing task forces in key cities to combat speculators en gaging in housing frauds on poor people, Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Peterson has told Congress.

title: Auto Union Names Aide
description: DETROIT, May 6 (AP)Her man Rebhan, a longtime offi cial of the United Auto Work ers, has been chosen to head the union's international af fairs department, the U.A.W. president, Leonard Woodcock, announced Thursday. He suc ceeds Victor Reuther, who re tired as of Monday.

title: Letters.
description: I read the article Security Deposits Earning Interest for Tenants [April 16] with in terest, but with a feeling of dismay. It gave the impres sion that landlords are will ing and ready to pay inter est on security deposits as required by law, but tenants are not actively interested in the matter.

title: The Nation
description: Damned if you do, damned if you don't. A Federal grand jury last week indicted the Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation on charges of violating antitrust laws by refusing to cut car prices for fleet buyers. And almost simultaneously, a group of car dealers brought an antitrust action against Chrysler Corporation for cut ting its prices to fleet buyers.

title: Stress, Aggression and Male Hormones
description: Is the human male, like the male rhesus monkey, likely to behave more aggressively if his male hormone levels are high? In a study of a young crim inal population at a South ern prison, Dr. Robert Rose, working with Dr. Leo Kreuz, attempted to correlate de grees of expressed aggres sion (threats, refusals to obey orders, fights, etc.) among a group of young male prisoners with the lev els of testosterone measured in their bloodstreams. He could not find, in this group of human males, the same direct relationship that had appeared in an earlier male rhesus study. The only link between high testosterone and aggressive behavior ap peared to be the odd fact that those men with the highest male hormone values were the ones who had com mitted more violent crimes during adolescence: Indeed, the higher a prisoner's tes tosterone level was in adult hood, the earlier in life he had tended to commit a violent crime.

title: SUIT FILED TO BLOCK NIXONHUGHES BOOK
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (UPI) A suit has been filed to block the distribution of a book that contends that Richard M. Nixon received hundreds of thousands of dollars from Howard R. Hughes in return for political favors when Mr. Nixon was Vice President.

title: Illegal Hormone Residues In Cattle Found Up Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  The rate at which the Agri culture Department is finding illegal residues of a controver sial growthpromoting hormone in cattle and sheep livers has of adoption of a new, more sen sitive testing procedure, offi cials have disclosed.

title: McGill Fears Peril To College Freedom In JobBias Efforts
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 6 The president of Columbia Uni versity, William J. McGill, urged efforts today to channel the Government's enforcement of antidiscrimination guidelines away from directions threaten ing to academic freedom.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Making Of the Candidate
description: SENATOR HUBERT HUMPHREY is due at WGALTV in Lancaster, Pa., at 7:30 P.M. for a live halfhour of tele phoneanswering on TVhis 20th such ap pearance of the campaign. At around 1:45 P.M. his amiable media director, D: J. (for Dennis John) Leary, and Leary's associate. Jerry Gross, formerly of Campaign Planners (who handled Humphrey's 1968 advertising), arrive at the studio. They reject some large blueandgreen swivel chairs in favor of two smaller red ones. (They won't overwhelm him, and it will solve the swivel problem, says Leary.) They test the various telephone lines, including a sevenseconddelay tape machine (to guard against obscenity); they install an extra microphone (sometimes an elderly caller or someone from the old coun try has difficulty hearing); they discover an outoforder flasher and ask the telephone maintenance man, who has instructions to stand by throughout the day, to fix it; they choose a color for the background curtain (anything but that green), supervise the building of a platform on which Leary stumps around; he announces that it makes too much noise, so the local production manager pro duces a carpetcolor to orderwhich they tape down. They reject a table (It's big enough to eat on) in favor of a modern tele phone stand, on which is placed a console phone with a lot of buttons, on top of which is an extra gooseneck mikethe only props. Humphrey won't use the console but will hear the calls over a speaker and reply through an offstage mike; the phone and gooseneck mike are there, says Leary, because people want to see something like that. They vague ly know about speaker phones and seeing that microphone takes the slickness off the set.

title: Rangers Are Short Of Defensive Help In 4th Game Today
description: The Rangers (the harassers) and the Boston Bruins (the in timidators) continue their Stan ley Cup championship series this afternoon at Madison Square Garden, which has been transformed into a war zone.

title: Bridge
description: BRIDGE is to some extent an art, but a player should beware of art for art's sake. If you paint a beautiful picture of your strength and distribution for your partner he will sometimes make use of the infor mation to select the best contract. But just as often your elegant art work will be of value to the oppo sition when the play develops.

title: One Way or Another, the Tourist Army Will Travel on Its Stomach To Start, the Menu
description: VIENNAThe other day an Amer ican couple vacationing here landed in a colorful Beisl (what Americans would call a joint) and ordered Kaiserschberlsuppe A real mouthful of vocabulary as well as vic tuals, it turned out to be a superb beef broth with small pieces of pastry dough in it. When the couple asked why it was named for the Kaiser, a friendly waitress explained that the imperial in fluence remains strong in Austrian cook ing even though the monarchy has been finished for more than half a century. Among other dishes that she cited were Kaiserfleisch, a rather democratic (de spite the name) smoked pork with sauer kraut, and Kaiserschmarrn, a kind of pancake.

title: Controls: An Overview From London
description: Faced with Inflation they have been unable to control, more and more governments In the past few years have resorted to some form of prices policy. The pace has been set by the most con servative administrations, es pecially those who originally said that they would intro duce no such thing.

title: The Good Word
description: Books about suicide make lousy gifts, and many people think it's un lucky to have them around the house as well: so A. Alvarez's excellent The Savage God may wind up being more talked about than bought. A pity, because the book is also about life, just as suicide itself is about life, being in fact the sincerest form of criticism life gets.

title: Repailler First in Trial
description: PAU France May 6 (UPI) Patrick, Depailler of France in a March 722 led from start to finish today to win the first qualifying heat of the Pau For mula Two Grand Prix. Nikki Lauda of Austria, current leader of the European Formula Two championship, brought a shni lar co. in second, some 10 sec onds behind. Gerry Birrell of Britain was third in another race.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: In their April 9 article, Putting the Hex on R and X, Stephen Farber and Estelle Changas asserted that the Motion Picture Association of America's rating board goes beyond merely labeling films as to their suitability for children. They charged that board members participate in reediting films and even in reshaping scripts before they are put before the cam eras. Thus, they contended, the board, which is now headed by Dr. Aaron Stern, functions as unofficial censor of American films. They called for an end to all creative interference on the part of the rating board as well as abolition of the X rating, the threat of which can be used by the board to intimidate and terrify the studios.

title: PENN STATE TAKES LEAD IN EAST GOLF
description: NEW HAVEN, May 6 Dan O'Neill of Penn State got his fiveman team off to a brilliant start today in the 38th annual Eastern Intercollegiate golf championship being contested over Yale's demanding, 6,600 yard layout in suburban West ville.

title: Maine's Maples Sought For Japanese Bowlers
description: PORTLAND, Maine, May 6 (AP)A Japanese passion for bowling is creating prob lems for Maine's hardwood furniture industry.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: CHESTERIf there is such a thing as a jazz center in New Jersey, it must he here. Every Friday and Sat urday night in this cross roads town of little more than 1,000, just east of Schooley's Mountain in Morris County, two jazz groups blast away within a few blocks of each other. That is one more jazz group than most Jersey com munities of any size can boast.

title: Hudson County Reform May Be on the Way
description: WEST NEW YORK Re form in Hudson County?

title: Laura Lieberson Wed
description: TENAFLY, N. J., May 6 Miss Laura Anne Lieberson, daughter of Dr. Leonard Lieberson, a surgeon, and Mrs. Lieberson of North Bergen, was married here this evening to Marc Elliot Grossman, son of Samuel Grossman of Teaneck and the late Mrs. Sylvia Gross man. Rabbi Irwin M. Blank performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Jules Laden heim, uncle of the bride. The bride is director of pub lic relations at Greenwich House, a settlement house in New York. Her husband is a lawyer with the New York law firm of Speiser Shumate Geoghan & Krause.

title: 247 Losing Their Jobs With Picatinny Arsenal
description: DOVERPicatinny Arsenal has given dismissal notice to 247 of its 5,529 civilian em ployes in compliance with Department of Defense orders for personnel reductions and other economies. The dismis sals, involving administrative and technical workers, will become effective in 60 days.

title: Bias Found at U. of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 6 (UPI) There is not a fair share of women professors and deans at the University of Texas, and the school favors male over female athletes, according to a special committee that studied sex discrimination. Well quali fied women appeared not to have been promoted because of sexual prejudice, said the ??.

title: A Man Whose Like Will Not Be Seen Again
description: WASHINGTONThe death of J. Edgar Hoover brought an end to an era. That has been said of many men but in the case of Mr. Hooverwho, at 77, had been director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 48 yearsit was really true. The Hoover Era almost exactly spanned the years since the United States emerged from World War I to find itself a world power; and in the halfcentury that followed, he became one of the few constants in a rapidly changing nation, an endlessly evolving society.

title: Chinese Players Will Visit Australia and New Zealand
description: SYDNEY, May 6 (Reuters) A Chinese tabletennis team will tour Australia and New Zealand in July, according to Keith Bowler, international sec retary of the Australian Table Tennis Association.

title: Rain Halts Graebner Match
description: KANSAS CITY, May 6 (AP) Rain halted the semifinal match between Clark Graebner of New York and Haroon Rahim of Pakistan today in the $11, 000 Glenwood Manor invitation tennis tournament.

title: RADIO PREACHER OUSTED BY FATHER
description: PASADENA, Calif. May 6 Garner Ted Armstrong, nation ally known radio preacher, has been ousted as second in command of his father's monolithic Worldwide Church of God.

title: Wornen's Friend In the Assembly
description: MORRISTOWNThe broad brimmed hats of Representa tive Bella Abzug of New York have earned her the so briquet The Hat, and it seems likely that New Jer sey's freshman Assembly woman, Ann Klein, may be come known as The Pants Suit.

title: JACKSON'S HOMER HELPS A'S WIN, 41
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 6 Weak hitting by the New York Yankees and strong pitching by the Oakland Athletics  two distinctive earlyseason trends in the American League  re sulted in a 41 victory for the A's at the Coliseum today.

title: Learning at the Oven of a French Master
description: DIEPPE, France There are two ways to get a reputation as a good French cook. One is to prop Larousse Gastronomique against the mixer and Paris Bistro booking behind the cutting board and follow them with slavish care; the other is to go to France and learn. The first needs luck, the second time. Having had some success with the first method, in cluding a coq au yin famous within a good 10 miles of my kitchen and a Bor delaise sauce notable for its alcoholic content, I sought to polish my skills with a crash course in France.

title: From the Log Of the Dover Rose: Cruising the Shannon
description: AN elderly man leading his donkey and cart came down to the quay as our cruiser lay docked at Carnadoe Waters, one of the many lakes along Ireland's River Shannon. He went about filling a barrel of drinking water to take home. Yes, people do drink the Shannon's water. Pollution is not a problem and there seems little chance of its becoming one in the foreseeable future, for at no place along the river's 220mile length is any industrial waste tipped over its banks.

title: The WAC: Born in Time of Crisis and Still Flourishing
description: Today, when they are not taken for granted, they tend to be forgotten. But when the first women signed up they were a sensation. And what they had to endure their first year or two is now almost impossible to believe.

title: When Escoffier fried chicken
description: No one thinks of fried chick en as a French dish, but this way of serving it is enshrined in the most august of classic French sourcesEscoffier and Pellaprat, to name two. Other Maryland dishes have also worked their way into the French repertoire. But at this stage in, time, it is hard to de termine whether the French were drawn to something like this elaborately garnished and sauced dish because it was for mal and pretty, or whether they took something simple and complicated it themselves. At any rate, chicken a la Mary land is a truly international idea by now. It will suit any festive gathering, does honor to the Eastern Shore and uses lots of post and pans.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: While wages and prices have occupied most of the spotlight during Phase Two of the Nixon Economic Pro gram, another littlepublicized part of the program scru tiny of corporate dividends  has quietly been going forward.

title: Stripped to essentials
description: Building developments and centercity slabs are cramming people into smaller and smaller spaces. Thus, the aim of architects and de signers today is to preserve the feeling of spacedispensing with chairs, tables and lamps and all of the conventional paraphernalia of living. For a bachelor executive in his 40's, architect Douglas Kahn stripped this highrise coop of its vestibules and closets, and grouped the displaced storage areas behind a cabinet wall of stainless steel. Some ceilings were lowered to hide lights, stereo speakers and haphazardly placed structural beams. The white, gray and metallicsilver color scheme runs through all the rooms. The total effect is of graphically streamlined efficiency.

title: New L.I. School Trustee, 18, Is Eager
description: MINEOLA, L.I May, 6  The new trusteeelect on the Mineola Board of Education, who receives $5 a week as an allowance, from his par ents  mostly for lunches  is not unduly disturbed that he will have to help determine educational policy here and spend $10million in the next year.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Bahamas Cruises Set in June, October
description: The yachtsman's piloted cruise to the Bahamas has been revived, and two cruises will be conducted this yearone in June, the other in October.

title: Robert Morris: Maxi of the Minimals
description: ROBERT MORRIS, for anyone who wasn't paying attention to American avantgarde art during its boom in the mid1960's, was a progenitor and perhaps the chief theo rist of Minimal Art, plus the doyen, in quick succession, of such subsequent mini movements as AntiForm, Earthworks and Conceptual Art. Like Robert Rauschen berg and Andy Warhol be fore him (though in the low er key appropriate to his cerebral bent), Morris was, for a moment, a nearly tran scendent art world presence, an artist who, it seemed, could do no wrong.

title: Manhattan Beats C.C.N.Y. On Flynn's FourHitter, 60
description: Gerry Flynn, a freshman righthander, limited City Col lege to four hits and struck out nine men as Manhattan College defeated the Beavers, 6.0, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Mike Quigley had three hits and drove in two runs.

title: Shuffleton, Divan Elected
description: Joe Shuffleton and Paul Divan have been elected cocaptains of the 197273 Rensselaer Poly technic Institute swimming team. Shuffleton is a back stroker from Gardner, Mass., Divan a freestyler from Oak dale, L.I.

title: I.T.T. Case Figure Handles Fortune Of Cabinet Aide
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Felix G. Rohatyn, who made controversial contacts with the White House and Justice De partment concerning an anti trust settlement for the Inter national Telephone and Teleg raph Corporation, is the sole trustee for the personal for une of Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson.

title: M'GILL VOWS TO ACT ON LEWISOHN SITINS
description: Dr. William J. McGill, presi dent of Columbia University, vowed yesterday to take what ever additional steps are neces sary to clear Lewisohn Hall of the black and Latin students and outsiders who have held it for 12 days.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: When former Attorney General John N. Mitchell re joined his old law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alex ander a short time ago, his former spot in the firm's of ficial title was left conspicu ously vacant.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mobil to Curb S. I. Oil Seepage

title: What Looks Like an Egg and Is an Egg?
description: There were the mice who, having learned not only to eat the poison put down for them, but to like it, ignoring the cheese in the traps, were caught because people learned to coat the cheese in the traps with poison.  Reported in The London Daily Mail, Feb. 2, 1967.

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 6 Three young revolutionaries were hanged here early today.

title: ROYALS TROUNCE ORIOLES, 9 TO I
description: BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) The Kansas City Royals reached Baltimore pitching for seven runs in the first two innings tonight, scored a 91 victory and knocked the Orioles out of first place in the American League Eastern Division.

title: Headliners
description: Bucharest's historic Choral Synagogue three decades ago was where stormtroopers began the pogrom that brought death to half of Rumania's 800,000 Jews. It was therefore natural that there was a note of solemnity when the syna gogue last Friday evening was visited by a distinguished leader from IsraelPremier Golda Meir, making her first official trip to a Communist country. The Sabbatheve serv ice marked the emotional highlight of Mrs. Meir's journey, just as her six hours of meetings earlier with President Nicolae Ceausescuthree of them in complete privacy with no aides presentwere the political high points. The talks were believed to have dealt with peace overtures in the Middle East and possibly with Mr. Ceausescu's serving as a mediator in negotiations between Mrs. Meir and Egyp tian President Anwar elSadat.

title: Jersey BikeRiders Rely on Central Park
description: CLOSTER Last Sunday, morning, as they do most Sundays, Dr. Norman Bartner, his wife Edith, and their 9 yearold daughter, Lauren, arose from bed, breakfasted and went off for what has become for them a customary bicycleriding excursion  to Central Park.

title: BLACK CONVICTED IN POLICE SLAYING
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 6 Last Aug. 18 a black visitor from Milwaukee was sleeping an the headquarters of the Re public of New Africa headquar ters here when it was sur rounded by policeman and F.B.I. agents.

title: Ellis's Case Is Postponed On Disorderly Complaint
description: CINCINNATI, May 5 (UPI) Dock Ellis, the Pittsburgh Pirates' pitcher, had his case continued to July 10 in muni cipal court today on a dis orderly conduct complaint filed by a private policeman follow ing an altercation at Riverfront Stadium last night.

title: Newcombe Gains Final
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 6 (AP)John Newcombe and Cliff Drysdale moved into the final of the $50,000 Las Vegas tennis tournament today.

title: Cajun Country in Louisiana Waging Underdog Fight to Keep French Alive
description: LAFAYETTE, La.,  Do you speak French? The old woman being asked the question was black, but since Negroes in the Cajun country historically have spoken French (many ex clusively until recently) and since her English was heavily accented with Cajun, the question seemed natural.

title: Mixologist Blends Indy 500 Fuels
description: Jack Stamper believes he operates the world's most unusual service station. His station isn't on any street corner, however, because for 10 months a year it is on the move along the United States Auto Club race trail.

title: U.A.W. to Train 2,220
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Labor Department has announced a $2million con tract with the United Auto Workers to, train 2,200 persons in 15 states for Jobs in auto, aerospace, agricultural imple ment and related industries. Secretary of Labor 3. D. Hodg son said Wednesday that the contract specified that at least 40 per cent of the trainees would be Vietnam era veterans. Another 600 will be selected from among severely disad vantaged persons.

title: Turnout Small at Loyalty bay Parade
description: In a cool breeze and warm sunshine, several hundred par ticipants marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday to the music or drum and bugle corps in the 25th Annual Loyalty Day Parade.

title: Pulitzer Nominations Oen
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia Univer sity, yesterday announced the opening of nominations for next year's Pulitzer Prizes. They will be awarded May 7, 1973. Juries in letters, drama and music have already been appointed, Mr. McGill said. He urged books to be sent in early as the jurors like to do their reading in the summer months. The book deadline is Nov. 1.

title: M'GOVERN CALLED NEBRASKA CHOICE
description: OMAHA, May 6A legion of at least 3,000 young campaign ers for Senator George Mc Govern has covered this state like a heavy spring rain, pene trating every corner and pre paring for the statewide effort in Tuesday's Presidential pref erence primary.

title: BILINGUAL STUDIES TERMED LAGGING
description: A major expansion of bilin gual education  using both English and Spanish in teaching is being urged in a Board of Eduction study to change the present conditions, which are contributing to the failure of Puerto Rican children in the classroom.

title: Patient British Chief Faces Ulster Coolness
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6Six weeks after his appointment as Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Wil liam Whitelaw has left Protes tants cool and Roman Catholics uncertain.

title: Golf Entry, Sent By Plane and Car, Here at Deadline
description: Mike Dunn, a 29yearold professional, used the services of a plane and a limousine to get his entry for the 1972 United States Open golf championship in on time.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dance
description: AN English dance critic in New York on a visit remarked to me the other day that the Al vin Ailey Dance Company was one of the lifegiving experiences in contemporary dance and theater. I think he was right. I go to the City Center to watch, say, Blues Suite or Revelations, works I have seen dozens and dozens of times, and yet I always get the same lift.

title: No One Had to Walk More Than Two Days To Reach a Polling Place
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea. THE Australian official who is sues the required permit to enter Papua New Guinea in structs the prospective visitor to begin taking a onceaweek anti malaria pill before starting the journey and to continue the prophy lactic dosage for a month after leav ing this hot, humid, mosquitoridden territory. It is the first warning of the culture clash that confronts a stranger almost daily in a wild, tropical coun try of legendary beauty where, amid tangled rain forests, forbidding mountain ranges, mud, swamp and endless green jungle, most of the 2.5million indigenous Melanesians live in conditions approximating the Stone Age.

title: Theater in London
description: ONE of the fictions dearest to the radical temperament is that re pressive, rightwing governments discourage the production of firstclass art. If theaters in Russia, East Berlin and Czechoslovakia hadn't al ready demolished that myth, the preset World Theater Season at the Aldwych certainly would, for among the compa nies garnered by Peter Daubeny as the finest in the world are representatives from South Africa, Spain, Greece and Polandwhich tends to suggest that whatever the political complexion of a society, it is no bar to artistic output even if, as is the case in some of these countries, the artist has to risk his life he heard.

title: Violence Breaks Out at Wallace Rally
description: HAGERSTOWN, Md., May Violence broke out here to day before and after an ap pearance by Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, a candi date in Maryland's Democratic Presidential prithary on May 16.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Prof. William Whyburn Dead; Mathematician at Chapel Hill
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 6 Prof. William Marvin Why burn, a mathematician who was president of Texas Tech nological College from 1944 to 1948 and a vice president of the University of North Caro lina from 1956 to 1960, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Wajima and Tiberia Predict Knockout Victories Tonight
description: FUKUOKA, Japan, May 6 (AP)The world junior middle weight champion, Koichi Wa jima of Japan, and Domenico Tiberia of Italy both expressed confidence today of victory in their 15round title fight to morrow night.

title: WALL STREET
description: Now that a group of Wall Street's major brokerage firms are publicly owned and must issue regular financial reports, it is possible for the first time to discern how the securities industry is per forming.

title: Anne Waldron, W. D. Neumann Plan Marriage
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 6 Miss Anne Goddard Wal dron, a descendant of Gov. John Winthrop of the Massa chusetts Bay Colony, and Dr. Walter David Neumann of Canberra, Australia, a visit ing member at the Institute for Advanced Study here, plan to be married in August. Announcement of their en gagement has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon T. Waldron of Princeton. Mr. Waldron, now retired, was a coowner of the Waldrons, a New York gift and home furnishings concern.

title: Television
description: IT'S almost impossible for today's televisiondisor iented youngsters to ima gine the impact radio had in the thirties and forties, the golden age of the spoken word. There we'd sit, the whole family, huddled around the faceless squawk box in the living room, the glow of the amber dial shining on names like StrombergCarlson, Atwater Kent and Superhet erodyne. And those radios! Some of them, in retrospect, loom large enough to have housed a family of five.

title: Cubans Arrive in Hanoi To Assist War Effort
description: HONG KONG, May 7 (Reuters)A brigade of Cu ban volunteers has arrived in Hanoi to assist the North Vietnamese war effort, the North Vietnam press agency reported today.

title: New & Novel
description: Bonham J. (Bonney) Mc Camey, the proprietor of a Texas tavern, is a poolhall hustler with a heart of at least tencarat gold. In one of his many weaker moments, he ab sconded with $15,000 belong ing to a resident of an old peo ple's home. When the old man's son, traveling incognito, finally locates his father's swindler, he runs into a life style so con voluted with good and bad that his vengeful intentions blend into the crazy gestalt of the place. Folksy wisdom and plen ty of local color would have made this novel a sure thing for Collier's or The Saturday Evening Post.

title: PROSECUTOR ROLE IS HELD TOO GREAT
description: Four wellknown lawyers, in cluding two prosecutors, agreed last week that the great power of the American prosecutor pre sents a grave potential for abuse. However, they failed to agree on what steps, if any, should be taken to reduce this potential.

title: CLEVELAND TOLD TO ALTER HOUSING
description: CLEVELAND, May 6  In efforts to halt racial imbalance in housing and schools here, a Federal judge has ordered the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Hous ing Authority not to build any more public housing units on the city's predominantly black East Side.

title: Giants Subdue Phiflies, 31, as McDowell Gains His 4th Victory With 4Hitter
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) Chris Speier's tworun homer and fourhit pitching by Sam McDowell carried the San Fran cisco Giants to a 31 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

title: PaulEnvoy Extraordinary
description: This is an unusual book about one of history's unusual men. Nothing new can possibly be said, except nonsense of course, about Paul the Apostle, and Messrs. Muggeridge and Vidler do not try. What they attempt is a novel way of presenting a com plex personal figure who is not an easy hero to the modern taste.

title: City's 2d Black Bank Will Open In Financial District in MidJuly
description: Universal National Bank, the city's second blackcontrolled bank, will open in midJuly in the financial district, the bank's organizers have announced.

title: Manhattanville College, Scrapping Traditional Credit System, Will Allow Students to. Keep Records
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., May 6 Manhattanville. College, which has undergone sweeping changes in the last two years, next fall will replace the tradi tional transcript and credit re quirements for graduation with what it calls a portfolio sys tem.

title: Television
description: FOR those of us who watch the soap op eras, once the citadel of escapism, it is clear that we are living in an age in which even such places as Oakdale, Pine Val ley, Henderson, Bay City and Somersetall soap opera locales  can no longer re main completely aloof from the forces at work in our society. We have come a long way from the days when words like abortion, rape and suicide couldn't be mentioned on a soap; when a married couple couldn't be seen in a double bed; and when blacks, just as on the old plantation, were not allowed in the main part of the houseex cept in the roles of domes tics and delivery boys. But the question is: Just how far have we come?

title: 50 TO START TODAY IN TALLADEGA 500
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., May 6 Qualifying was completed this afternoon for tomorrow's run ning of the Winston 500, the 11th race of the season on the Grand National stockcar cir cuit.

title: FRED STAUFFER, 72, OF HERALD TRIBUNE
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 6 Fred B. Stauffer, a former mem ber of the financial news staff of The New York Herald Tribune, died today in St. Vin cent's Hospital, Montclair. He was 72 years old and lived in this community.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FIRE KILLS ONE MAN, HURTS ANOTHER HERE
description: One man died and another was injured in a fire in an apartment on the upper West Side early yesterday.

title: Davis Runs as If There's a Tomorrow
description: Johnny on the Pony in the streets of BedfordStuy vesant; an uncle who once ran track as the college clown at Westminster, Pa.; an involvement in small group rap sessions at Boys High Schoolall are in gredients in the making of the secondlegger catchup man who opened the lead that seized the Penn Relays mile victory for Boys High last weekend.

title: Coins
description: HENRY GRUNTHAL, Curator of European Modern Coins of The American Numismatic Society, will be guest speaker at the monthly meeting of the Ancient Coin Society of New York Wednesday eve ning, The session, starting at 8 o'clock, Will be held at the West Side Y.M.C.A., Eighth Avenue and 51st Street. The meeting is open to the public and there will be no admis sion charge.

title: Medicine
description: A year ago, a 60yearold man call him James Sawyersat in a wheel chair at New York University's Insti tute for Rehabilitative Medicine and stared at the wall with a gaze of seemingly complete vacuity. A stroke had paralyzed the right half of his body. Though nurses often could sea his facial muscles straining, the for mation and comprehension of intelli gible sounds was beyond his ability. The left side of his brain (which con trols the right side of the body and where the ability to speak is largely centered) was crippled beyond repair.

title: S. I. Cricketers Win
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated the Primrose C.C. by 6 wickets yesterday at Walker Park on Staten Island. The Staten Islanders had 137 runs for 4, Primrose had 136.

title: King Takes Tennis Title
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 6 Tom Kiing of Upsala College defeated Bryon Marsden of Franklin and Marshall, 75, 64, to win the Middle Atlantic Conference tennis champion ship today at Moravian Col lege.

title: FOLLMER TAKES TRANSAM RACE
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 6 George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif., who is playing cross country commuter this week end, led from start to finish today and won the 200mile Schaefer TransAm in a Javelin.

title: Beame's Admirers Are Legion, but His Expense Nitpicking Annoys Many at City Hall
description: When a commissioner tries to get the city to pay for his liquor, or the Board of Edu cation makes an arithmetic er ror that doubles its bill for hot dogs, the matter lands on the glasstopped desk of Abraham D. Beame, who exercises some of the most formidale power of anyone in city government.

title: The Word in Chile Is Tomar*
description: TO understand about gossip in Chile, you must stand as the Chileans do on a hot, dry summer afternoon in February on the corner of Calle Bandera and the Avenida Bernardo O'Hig gins, licking a strawberry ice cream cone and reading the red and blue headlines of the tabloid newspapers which are fastened with clothespins to the little kiosks. A stranger is at first shocked by head lines like, State of Alert, and As sassination, and Constitutional Crisis, and Monopolists Murder. Then, you read on and find out that a small labor union in the north has put its workers on strike alert and that the assassination was one drunk merchant sailor knifing an other in a waterfront bar in Val paraiso and that the constitutional crisis has been going on since you were in town five years ago and that the monopolists killed 20,000 chickens on a farm because the open market price for stewing hens went higher than the price for eggs.

title: A Veto by Rome Bans Bird Hunting in Spring
description: ROME, May 6The Gov ernment has vetoed the last of a series of regional meas ures that would have de clared open season on mil lions of migratory birds now ed from shooting at birds in the spring, by a 1970 na tional law that expired with the institution of the re gional councils.

title: Daughter to Lehmans
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Orin Lehman on Tuesday at the New York Hospital. Mrs. Lehman, the former Miss Wendy Vander bilt, is the daughter of Al fred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the sportsman, and Mrs. Edward B. McLean. She is a descend ant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. Mr. Lehman, theatrical producer and broadcasting executive, is a son of the late Mrs. Evelyn Schiffer Lehman and the late Allan S. Lehman, a partner in Lehman Brothers.
