title: Lucille McLoughlin Is Married To Robert K Hornby, Lawyer
description: Miss Lucille McLoughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice E. McLoughlin of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Rob ert K. Hornby, son of Mrs. Cecil R. Hornby of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the late Mr. Hornby.

title: U.S. Airmen Seem To Be Reopening Base in Thailand
description: TAKHLT AIR BASE, Thai land, May 6 (UPI)American airmen worked late tonight, ap parently to reopen this base for an estimated 80 more Phan tom fighterbombers to be used in the Indochina war.

title: The Nation
description: It had been President Nixon's fond hope that the Republican National Convention, which would renominate him for a second term as President, would be held in San Diego, in his native California. The good burghers of San Diego made a bid, which Re publican convention managers prompt ly accepted, and Republican dele gates were instructed to make plans for a westward trip from Aug. 21 to 23.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: HOUSTON, May 6Texans braved heavy rains and the threat of flash floods today to vote in primary elections in which Lyndon B. Johnson's choice for a future President fought for his political life.

title: The Guest Word
description: At the risk of wounding the noble sensi bilities of all Argentines (whatever their particular or political persuasion), the fact must be faced that at this late date a tourist Mecca of the modern New World like Buenos Aires boasts but a single tenebrariumlocated, at that, in a back water of the city some several blocks from the nearest subway station. All things considered, however, the establish ment stands for an effort worthy of the highest praise, for a real breakthrough in the Chinese wall of our general unfash ionableness. More than one acute and far ranging observer has dropped us the hint ad nauseum that the aforementioned tenebrarium is still far from holding its own with counterparts in Amsterdam or Basel or Paris or Denver, Colo., or Bruges lar Morte.

title: Princeton Seeks New Path For Educational Training
description: PRINCETONA program of Instruction at Princeton University seeks to bypass the traditional school of edu cation in training teachers for careers in New Jersey's pub lic schools.

title: Art
description: IN disagreeable times, the art of the primitive, or Sunday, painter has a particular appeal. He sees the world with an openness and freshness few of us can muster. In his pictures, the world seems newly minted: the forms tend to be crisp and unequivocal; the skies are remarkably sunny. Nos talgia for that improbable world, no doubt, accounts for much of the charm in two current exhibitions of naf painters  that of Camille Bombois, the late French primitive, on view at the Perls Galleries, 1016 Madison Ave nue, until May 13, and of Marc Chagall, the Russian born modern master, showing at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, until May 20.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A forthcoming study con tends that the Presidential election can be swung by either Republicans or Dem ocrats with strategies directed at black, Spanishspeaking, Jewish, Italian and Slavic voters. These groups make up 30 to 33 per cent of the elec torate, concentrated in major states.

title: Appeals Judge to Resign
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)Chief Judge Bailey Aldrich of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit has retired and will step down as soon as his successor is appointed. Judge Aldrich, 65 years old, will take on senior status and be available for assignment. His retirement was confirmed by the White House Tuesday.

title: COSMOS IN OPENER AT NEW L.I. HOME
description: The New York Cosmos will open their 1972 North Ameri can Soccer League season at Hofstra stadium in Hempstead, L. I., against the St. Louis Stars at 3 o'clock this after noon. Ralph G. Caso, Nassau County Executive, will wel come the Cosmos to their new home and kick out the first ball.

title: NKRUMAH'S BURIAL IN GHANA UNSURE
description: AFLAO, Ghana, May 3  People in this eastern border town find it hard to believe that Kwame Nkrumah, the man who symbolized African indepen dence, is dead.

title: SONSKY TRIUMPHS IN JAVELIN THROW
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 6 On his last attempt, while his wife beamed proudly, Milt Son sky recorded the finest javelin throw of his career today. He hit 267 feet 2 inches, one of the best performances in the United States this year, at the Marine Corps Relays.

title: A Dieter Can Surviveand Thrivein 3Star France
description: ARISThe hotel had been re modeled with flair and fidelity to the Belle Epoque, and the door locks were of the period. Ours did not work. The chambermaid in serted the heavy iron key, gave it a quarter turn right, pushed deeper into the mechanism, then took a half turn to the left. It worked.

title: 200 in First Legal March
description: BELFAST, May 6 (UPI)  About 200 antiBritish demon strators turned out today for the first legal march in North ern Ireland in nine months. There was no violence, though Protestants booed the marchers and Catholics cheered them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria and Christine Fields Of Garden City Plan Marriages
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6  Miss Victoria Elizabeth Fields and Craig Joseph Ott, graduates of St. Bonaventure University, plan to be married in September. Miss Christine Eugenie Fields, her sister, plans to be married to Pat rick James Sciortino. They are, graduates of Marquette University.

title: Elizabeth I Is Alive and Well and Living in Agoura, Calif.
description: AGOIJRA, Calif.  So you don't know what a rouncerobblehob the is. Well, in Old English, a rouncerobblehobble is a thun derstorm. But in New Californian, it is the name of a character who appears every May at the Renaissance Pleasure Faire and Springtime. Market here.

title: AROUND THE
description: Last call to fertilize lawns; where crabgrass is a problem use combination preemergent and fertil izer; if the lawn has been seeded, use siduron for crabgrass control. Spray tents of tent cater pillars at dusk, when they are inside; use malathion.  Fertilize peonies and other perennials Mulch the strawberries.

title: Philadelphia Lawyer Fined
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) A twojudge panel has fined a Philadelphia lawyer $1,000 for failing to consult with a client who has languished in jail the past 15 months. The sanction was imposed Wednes day on Nino R. Tinari by Com mon Pleas Court Judges J. Victor DiNublio and James R. Cavanaugh. The judges also re moved Mr. Tinari as defense counsel for Ronald Boelter, 26 years old, of Philadelphia, who was to stand trial for murder, robbery, burglary, conspiracy and.

title: It's Women Riders Only, And 501 Shot Triumphs
description: LONDON, May 6Twenty one girl jockeys invaded a traditional male preserve to day by riding in the first offi cially recognized women's flat race to be run on a Brit ish racecourse.

title: A Former Polish Official Loses Veterans' Union Post
description: WARSAW, May 6 (UPI) Misczyslaw Moczar, who as In terior Minister challenged the former Communist leadership, lost his job as leader of the War Veterans Union, the offi cial press agency said.

title: Orthodox. Jews. Elated. With Teaneck Synagogue
description: TEANECK  When Joseph and Marilyn Bak took their 9nionthold daughter to a park near their apartment in Upper Manhattan two years ago, the child began to cry.

title: Deathwatch
description: Robb White is allpro at the game of adventure. Like a veteran quarter back, he has mastered all the tricks and makes his moves seem like child's play. That is why this novel is a pleasure to read, either as a sizzling adventure or as an ironic allegory of our times.

title: Crimson Victory, at $7.60, Wins by 3 Lengths in Sprint
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., May 6 (AP)Crimson Victory, a 4 yearold invader from Suffolk Downs, won the $7,500 May Flowers Handicap at Narragan sett Park today, pulling away by three lengths.

title: Lead Paint Curb Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) A bill intended to combat lead paint poisoning, which each year affects 400,000 chil dren who eat chips peeling from apartment walls, was approved this week by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee. The measure would authorize an annual Federal expenditure of $100million  $5million for research, $45million for treatment of victims of the dis ease and $50million for use by cities, states and civic groups in trying to eliminate lead painted walls.

title: Ft. Monmouth Signal Unit May Move
description: FORT MONMOUTH Legislators, civilian employes and local businessmen are still waiting for the official word on whether the Army plans to move its signal school from here to Georgia. Last month, plans to shift seven career officer courses to the Southeastern Signal School at Fort Gordon were announced and Senator Clif ford P. Case asked for a full report on Forth Monmouth's present and future.

title: DROLL ROLE WINS GREY LAG HERE
description: John M. Schiff's Droll Role, the outsider in an eighthorse field, outlasted Rokeby's Fare well Party in a tense duel down the stretch at Aqueduct yester day to capture the $83,475 Grey, Lag Handicap by a nose.

title: NixonReminding Us Doesn't Amuse Us
description: INASMUCH as the networks have never been willing to give Gore Vidal equal time with President Nixon, Mr. Vidal has been forced to turn to the theater, where equal time is always available if you can find a producer. Mr. Vidal has found a gen erous producer in Hillard Elkins, Mr. Elkins has found a lively director in Edwin Sherin, and Mr. Sherin has found more than a dozen amiable actors who are perfectly capable of simulatingwith or without masks the scowls, pouts, huffs, puffs, grins, groans and perspiring pieties of Mr. Nixon himself, golfer Dwight D. Eisenhower, the George Washington of legend, a laconic but unnamed William Buckley, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, Harry Truman and other such. Clues to the ultimate and surprising weakness of the occasion, which is called An Evening with Richard Nixon And , may be found in two of the play's more candid lines, neither of which be true.

title: Cyclamate Bill, a Sleeper, Would Cost Taxpayers
description: WASHINGTON  There's been a tremendous amount of lobbying, replied Represen tative Emanuel Celler, the Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House Judi ciary Committee, when asked about H.R. 13367, known for short on Capitol Hill as the cyclamate bill.

title: The O'Dowds of New York Brush Up on Their Irish History
description: THE American tourists sitting at the tables in Knappogue Castle are middleaged for the most part and just slightly foundering to ward the end of a sixcourse medieval banquet as they fix their eyes on the Seneschal of Knappogue, the castle's majordomo who introduces the nightly Pageant of Irish History. How many pageants have these Yankee visitors suf fered through at home? There's Mrs. Francis O'Dowd, a fine, solidlooking woman from Jackson Heights, Queens, tactfully attired in green Irish tweed from Macy's, who has seen heaven knows how many little O'Dowds steered through pageants by the Sisters as sawedoff Pilgrim Fathers and pygmy Pocahontases. And O'Dowdthat's Him self there, nodding beside hermust have slept through 10 kiddie reenact ments of American history. Did I come to Ireland for this? he asks Himself, somewhat prematurely. Nor are the O'Dowds the only pageantscarred veter ans in the audience. At this point, a lot of them look as if they could use a drink.

title: Bank in Flushing Is Robbed
description: A masked man held up a Dry Dock Savings Bank in Flush ing, Queens, yesterday morn ing and escaped with $6,000 in cash, the police reported. The holdup man entered the bank, at 43.73 Kissena Boule ard, and told the teller, Give me the money or I'll blow your head, off, the police said.

title: MRS. KING VICTOR IN FINAL, 63, 63
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King scored a 63, 63 victory over Mrs. Nancy Gunter in the final of a women's professional tennis tournament today. It was the second straight tournament Mrs. King had won on the tour.

title: Idaho's Hard Rock Miners: They Work Hard, Play Hard and Don't Save a Dime, but They Enjoy Life
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 6 The Osburn Club is a miner's bar, a place for drinking beer and listening to country music and swapping stories. The other night, a young miner named Paul Wingfield was talking about his life.

title: Hijacking Vow Reported
description: MIAMI, May 6 (AP)The hijacker of the Western Air lines plane told passengers that he would return to the United States and hijack more planes to protest the Indochina war.

title: Trillings Have Son
description: DURHAM, N. C., May 6 A son was born to Prof. and Mrs. Richard J. Trilling on April 24 at the Watts Hos pital here.

title: ENGLISH LEARNED IN A COFFEEHOUSE
description: The Rev. Jacob Biernacki is a 31yearold Polish priest who can barely speak English. Wil liam Hannafin is a middleaged security analyst for Blyth & Co. who knows no Polish.

title: If You Go
description: castle crawling in the Ould Sod, don't expect to be hobnob bing with the natives when you sit down.to dinner. It is more like ly that you will be surrounded by Americans, even though some of them may be named Kelley and O'Keefe. Knappogue, Bunratty and Dungaire Castles hold their ban quet and entertainment programs twice nightly (6 and 9 P.M.). Knap pogue's season began on April and continues through Oct. 31; Bunratty operates all year, and Dungaire runs from May I to Sept. 30. Dinner and entertainment at each one costs $8.70. At Castle Matrix, which is open the year round, the charge is $8.40. Fur ther details from the Irish Tourist Board, 590 Fifth Avenue, New York 10036. There are about 40 castles, stately homes and gardens open to the public in Ireland; for information on these write to the Secretary, Historic Irish Homes and Gardens Association, Rook wood, Ballyboden, Dublin 14, Ire land.

title: Columbia Gains Net Title Tie
description: The Columbia tennis team clinched a tie for its first East ern League title when it de feated Penn, 63, yesterday at the winner's courts. The Lions, who now possess a 70 wonlost record in conference play and are 161 over all, were paced by Rick Pagel, a fresh man who downed the Quakers' highly touted John Adams, 162, 63.

title: New & Novel
description: My name is John Foley, says the narrator. I am 11 years old. I live in Wexford on a farm.. I do not like it. My father and brother like it. I don't. They don't like me be cause I don't. Which about sums up the interpersonal re lationships in this lowkeyed novel of an Irish adolescence.

title: He and She: The Sex Hormones And Behavior
description: FREUD always maintained that human psychology had, as one of its components, some un known biological bedrock. He thought that we all, male and female alike, were captives of our physi ology: that inborn propensities and tendencies exerted a profound effect upon behaviorand that these inner propensities were different in the two sexes. (Hence his nowinfamous remark: Anatomy is Destiny.) This belief is, however, not popular in the present, more environmentalist intellectual climate. The common assumption nowadays appears to be that where male behavior and female behavior are different they are so because of acculturation: that the display of either masculinity or femininity is by and large the result of social training.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Wallace Takes Lead in North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 6 Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama took an early lead over Terry Sanford today in North Carolina's first Presidential pri mary.

title: Robert Manson Myers
description: How did a University of Maryland professor of Eng lish, whose field is the 18th century and whose Co lumbia Ph.D. dissertation was written on the composer Han del, come to devote 20 years of his life to the transcription, arranging and interweaving (plus copious introductory and biographical amplification) of the thousands of documents from a 19thcentury Southern family that make up The Chil dren of Pride?

title: 17,400 See U.C.L.A. Beat U.S.C. in Track
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP)The world recordhold er, John Smith, showing no ill effects from a recent bout with hepatitis, won in the 440yard dash and anchored the University of California, Los Angeles, mile relay team that brought the Bruins a 7669 victory today over Southern California in a dual track meet before 17,400 at the Coliseum.

title: Irish Tourism Is Innocent Victim of the Ulster Violence
description: CASTLE gates have been opening all over the British Isles in recent years, and one of the latest to display the DoComeIn sign is owned, by Northern Ireland's Lord Raymond O'Neill. He is different from some of his touristminded counterparts in that he is hardly poor and he has arranged for visitors to view his estate in private train.

title: In Little Ferry, Sokol Means Fitness in All Things
description: LITTLE FERRY  Sokol is a familiar word in this small north Jersey borough, but its meaning falls victim to the generation gap.

title: SPECIAL PASSPORT STIRS NEW DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The United States diplomatic pass port, long prized for its pres tigeand especially for its magic influence on customs in spectorsseem to be losing its chic.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Like the author of the ar ticle about sketching while on vacation (Travel section, April 23), I know the satis faction that comes when, weeks or months after a journey, I look over a sketch ed travelogue. While travel ing in Colorado, I started a sketch in oil. Before I had a chance to apply some finish ing touches, a cloud of grass hoppers appeared and hopped all over the wet palette and the painting, reducing it in no time from a traditional picture to an extreme ab straction.

title: Martiros Saryan Is Dead; American Painter Was 92
description: MOSCOW, May 6 Martiros Saryan, an Armenian painter who was widely honored in the Sovet Union, died yesterday at the age of 92.

title: WALDEN TRIUMPHS IN STAR CLASS SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 6 Howard T. Walden Jr. of the home club sailed Old Sol to A 20second, fourlength victory today in the third race of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet's annual Eye Opener series.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 6West Virginia is the state that lives in the hearts and minds of Democrats as one of the great national battle grounds of the politics of the sixties.

title: New & Novel
description: One of the oldest military axioms states that there are three ways of doing things: the right way, the wrong wayand the Army way. Mr. Pelfrey's excellent novel is devoted to spelling out the third way, as it applies to a tour in Vietnam.

title: 300,000 Refugees From North Jam Into Danang as Mayor Appeals to Saigon for Help
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 6  The Mayor of Danang said today that his city had become critically overcrowded with refugees and appealed to officials in Saigon to move some of them farther south.

title: Koreans and U.S. to Build GrainStorage Bins at Port
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 6 The Commodity Credit Cor poration of the United States Department of Agriculture and the Korea Silo Company, a pri vate concern, signed here yes terday an agreement to jointly build and operate a $6.6mil lion grainstorage facility in the port of Inchon, west of Seoul.

title: The World
description: BONNRainer C. Barzel started last week with the aureole of an opposi tion leader who had organized the first Parliamentary defeat of Chancellor Willy Brandt since the Government took office 30 months ago. He ended the week without the aureoleas an opposition leader fighting for survival against opposition in his own conserva tive party ranks.

title: Building of Condominium Hinges on Court Ruling
description: RIVER VALEAfter a twoyear zoning battle, con struction on this rural town ship's first condominium project is scheduled to begin this springmaybe.

description: Engagements

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Quintuplets Born in England
description: NORTHAMPTON, England, May 6 (AP) Quintuplets  three boys and two girlswere born here early today by emer gency Ceasarean section to a 24yearold woman who had been taking fertility drugs. The smallest baby, a girl, died with in 10 hours, and the four others were reported to be suffering breathing difficulties. A spokes man for Northampton General Hospital said the babies were born after 33 weeks of preg nancy.

title: Parties at Galleries Had Clear Message The Back Is Back
description: Charityminded New Yorkers got a copious helping of art this week, with parties held at galleries on three con secutive days. And despite rain  a sprinkle on Monday, a downpour on Wednesdaythey got into their finery and made merry on donated champagne. Although an art party can be counted on to bring out at least one woman who made her dress out of the parlor dra peries, it's also a vantage point from which to view what current fashion trends have succeeded and what new ones may be coming up.

title: If You Go
description: to Edirne for the greased wrestling tournament, it might be wise, even if rigorous, to use Is tanbul as a base for a oneday excursion, leaving early yin the morning in a rented car or shared taxi for the 130mile, threehour drive. Edirne has only one good hotel, the Kervan, and it is small. Also, bring a picnic lunch to get into the spirit of things and, if you have one, your own mermaid; it isn't likely that that hawker can really deliver. General admission tickets for the wrestling can be purchased each day; buy them as soon as you arrive. Reserved seats must be purchased in advance.

title: IRISH WOLFHOUND IS SELECTED BEST
description: ERWINNA, Pa., May 6Ch, Broughshane of Eagle, an Irish wolfhound and the biggest dog among six in the final, scored the biggest victory of his career tonight when he was named best in show at the Bucks County fixture at Tinicum Park.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, May 6Ottawa immigration officials say they have discovered an underground route that was to be followed by possibly thousands of Cuban exiles hoping to enter the United States.

title: Economic Flexibility in Poland
description: CZESTOCHOWA, Poland In the openhearth foundry of the Beirut Steel Works Poland's second largest steel milllarge blackboards list the daily output of pig iron and the amount of money earned by each crew. The greater the output, the high er the wages.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE gutter system around the roof of most homes is designed to carry rain water safely away as it flows off the roof to avoid dirt streaks and stains on siding, stucco or shingles; to keep cascading water from seeping in through cracks or open joints in the exterior walls; and to minimize the possibility of saturating the ground next to the founda tion and thus causing flood ing of the basement or wash outs of flower beds and shrubbery located near the walls of the house.

title: The World
description: LONDON  The Chinese undoubt edly suffer from Russophobia, but they have a lot be phobic about. London's International Institute for Strategic Studies lent new substance to Chinese fears last week by pro viding a new analysis of a massive Soviet buildup along the Chinese bor der over the past four years.

title: Uganda to Reopen Border
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 6 (Agenee PrancePresse)Presi dent Idi Ainin will conduct ceremonies next Thursday to reopen the UgandaSudan bor der, closed nearly five years ago, it was announced here. The ceremonies will be held at three border points about 200 miles north of here, at Nimule, Mayo and Oraba.

title: The other Borges than the central one
description: Until quite recently the only image of Borges in the mind of the American reader was Borges the builder of verbal labyrinths, the monstrorum artifex of many fictions, the teller (or reteller) of myths linking contem porary men to Babel, Babylon, Tlon, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius. In short: a writer to place beside Kafka and Nabokov, Pynchon and Barthelme, a representative of a kind of fiction that resists the temptations of real ism, of political or social commit ment, of brave humanistic causes. His was a world of irony and pure aliena tion, of escape into the structural complexities of narrative, of a text whose only ambition was to be read as a text and not as a blueprint for the universe. The Borges of Fic ciones, Labyrinths, Dreamtigers, Other Inquisitions, The Book of Imaginary Beings, The Aleph and Other Stories, was basically a many faced magician, a thoroughly fas cinating literary intelligenceto bor row a few words from review.

title: Pell Challenged for Senate
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. May 1 (UPI)  John Quattrochi, 58 years old, a lawyer, of Provi dence announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic Senate seat currently held by Claiborne Pell. Mr. Quattrochi has run for the Senate twice be fore, once from each, party.

title: Tour of Historic Homes Highlights Montgomery Township Bicentennial
description: MONTGOMERY TOWN SHIP  The Washington Well Farm, where George Washington and his ex hausted troops are reported to have drunk the well dry on the way from Valley Forgo to Monmouth Court House, will be the first stop next Saturday on a tour of historic homes highlighting the yearlong bicentennial celebration here.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Lear Levins Have Son
description: A son was born April 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Lear Levin of New York at the Univer sity Hospital. Mrs. Levin is the former Miss Raquel Rieur of Lawrence, L.I.

title: There's a Good Excuse for Festivity When It's Derby Time in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 All over Kentucky this after noon, the parties stopped for a couple of minutes, to watch the horse race that provided the excuse for all those Kentucky Derby par ties in the first place.

title: Summer Camp Openings Still Available
description: After their income ebbed in 1970 and improved only slightly in 1971, summer camps in New Jersey and across the country are hop ing for greater income this year from larger enroll ments.

title: 72 Is Sutton's Turn to Win 20 In Dodger Staff's Annual Feat
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 Ever since Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale retired, the Los Angeles Dodgers have been looking for that Big Man on the moundthe con sistent winner who can be relied upon as a certain stopper to halt team losing streaks.

title: RED SUTHERLAND, 53, A PUBLICITY WRITER
description: Robert Henderson (Red) Suth erland, a public relations writer who most recently was a con sultant to Pan American Air ways and a contributor to Yachting Magazine, died yester day of a coronary ailment in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Movies
description: AL PACINO is the hot movie star around whom Paramount hopes to build a sequel to The God father; he could be ordering a set of monogrammed motorcycles and sipping Napoleon brandy while a mani curist fiddles with his nails. Instead of that, he's gone off to play for the Theatre Company of Boston in The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel.

title: Elizabeth Rudulph Wed
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church here yesterday Miss Elizabeth Rudulph, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Allan Rudulph of New York and Long Valley, N. J., was married to James M. Lustenader, an account executive with de Garmo, Inc., a New York advertising agency. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony. The bride is assis tant to the editor of the Time Life Educational Division.

title: WORKERS RESIST WITHHOLDING CUT
description: DETROIT, May 6The Gov ernment is withholding too much money from the paycheck of Norbert Gazarek, an auto worker, but he doesn't care.

title: WORKING MOTHERS STUDIED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 6  A so ciological survey of Soviet working women made public here shows that those with pro fessional skills appear to make the best mothers and the most efficient housewives.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Half an hour before the game began, they crept down the slopes of Madison Square Garden, like mangy mountain lions going below the treeline in a search for prey. Quietly, they surrounded the rink from a perch above the boards. When the Boston Bruins, in their black and gold uniforms, glided on to the milkwhite ice for their warmup, the mountain lions pounced. But only with words and gestures. None was polite or humorous. Some were obscene. Skat ing easily, the Bruins never looked up, not even at the loudest of their tormentors, a pack of about a dozen males, perhaps 18 to 21 in age, shouting from above the brown wooden canopy installed to protect the visiting team.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Essex College Sets Up Links With Soviet
description: NEWARKEssex County College, one of the newest community colleges in the state, has established an educational exchange agree ment with a Soviet educa tional institution.

title: Tuesdays Dark at Delaware
description: All Tuesdays during Delaware Park's May 27Aug. 13 tho roughbred race meeting will be dark except for the July 4 holi day program.

title: The World
description: Horrifying was one opponent's description of the plan. Colossal over development said another. But pro moters of a scheme to refurbish Lon don's Piccadilly Circus, unveiled last week, said their project would rejuve nate what had become a downat heel, neonlit slum.

title: NO LE HACE NEXT
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 Riva Ridge flaunted the silks of the Meadow Stable with proud and positive justification today, as he won the $182,800 Kentucky Derby.

title: Lambert Castle Is a Peak Into Paterson's Past
description: PATERSON  When com pleted in 1893, it was called the castle by outsiders, Belle Vista by its owner. Today it is called Lambert Castle by everyone.

title: Tarangioli Net Victor
description: Neil Tarangioli of Fordham Prep won the Athletic Associa tion of Private Schools tennis title yesterday by defeating Don Goebel of Kew Forest, 67, 62, 75, in the final at the West Side Tennis Club in Queens. Fordham Prep won the team title.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: In the realm of pollution control, one of the prime targetsperhaps the No. 1 targetis the paper indus try.

title: Standing Up for the People
description: One was the right man who came along at the wrong time; the other, the wrong man at any time. It is, perhaps, a sufficient commentary onthe dreary American scene of the 1950's that the right man wore him self out battling the forces of en trenched economic power and greed, while the wrong man whipped up a storm of hate, suspicion and intolerance, catapulting his name into headlines across the world.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sex of One and Half a Dozen of Another
description: Sex education has progressed since the year The New York er ran its cartoon of the elab orate church wedding, the bridal pair standing before the minister, the hushed throng watching attentively, and the caption: But mummy, when is he going to put the pollen on her? All the same, while chil dren's books on human repro duction make a great point oftalking directly and informally to young readers, they are still written with as much regard for the feelings of uneasy adults as for the natural curi osity of childhood. This is a fact usually so obvious that only the most unobservant child could miss it and it should help to insure the sur vival of the generation gap for at least another couple of dec ades.

title: Cheering Section of Mothers and Aunt Pull N.Y. U. Players Out of Slump
description: New York University has not won many baseball games this spring, but the Violets can boast of perhaps the most dependable three woman cheering section in the East.

title: MESSERSMITH STARS AS ANGELS WIN, 20
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 6 (AP) Andy Messersmith allowed two hits tonight in pitching the California Angels to a 20 vic tory over the Milwaukee Brew ers.

title: Area Mat Stars to Begin Quest For Olympic Berths on Friday
description: More than 100 amateur wrestlers from this area, hop ing to earn berths on the summer Olympic team, be gin their quest next weekend in the Metropolitan Olympic Trial Meet outdoors at Can tiague Park in Hicksville, L.I.

title: Recordings
description: THE delight in encount ering the Edith Sitwell William Walton Fa ade for the first time is nit something easily for gotten. For this writer, it happened before World War II, when he was played the original recordings by Miss Sitwell and Constant Lambert. The work was recognizable, without any special sensitivi ty, as being perfect of its kind, perhaps unique. Where else have recited poetry and music been mated so perfect ly?

title: Negotiations on ShanghaiVancouver Air Link Open This Week
description: PEKING, May 6A direct air link between Vancouver and Shanghai will move a step closer to reality next week when a delegation ar rives here from Ottawa to open negotiations with Chi nese officials.

title: New British Industrial Court Stirs LaborUnion Dissension
description: LONDON, May 6An indus trial relations court to protect the public interest in labor dis putes is taking strong hold in Britain and is causing dissen sion and confusion in the labor movement.

title: DETERGENT STUDY BARS USE OF NTA
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 The Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare released to day a monthlong scientific study of the controversial detergent chemical NTA con cluding that serious questions still remain concerning its toxicity to humans.

title: If You Go
description: to the Renaissance Pleasure Faire at the Old Paramount Ranch in Agoura, just northwest of Los Angeles off U.S. 101, you'll have to go on one of the remain ing weekends in May. About 12, 000 people a day make that trip, so be prepared for a bit of con gestion. A fall version of the Faire runs throughout September in Marin County, which is across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco.

title: Tennis Title to Redmen
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 6 (AP)The University of Massa chusetts won its 12th Yankee Conference tennis title in 22 years today. Chuck Davis of Vermont won the individual title. Massachusetts compiled 18 points, Rhode Island was second with 14 points, followed by Vermont, 12; Connecticut, 9; Holy Cross, 4; New Hampshire 2.

title: The Grand Illusion
description: Now it's suddenly dawning on higher authority here that the South Vietnamese system is inadequate and has been all along. This assessment by an American adviser in the wake of the recent North Vietnamese victories gets close to, but not quite to the heart of, the truth that this country's political and military leaders have refused to face. What is inadequate is less the South Vietnamese system than the past history and present credibility of the current regime.

title: World News Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6A 48hour strike by 8,000 workers at the Chuquicamata copper mine, Chile's largest, ended to day after the Government made concessions on bonuses, work regulations and promotions.

title: INDIA IS ALARMED BY ACREAGE LIMIT
description: NEW DELHI, May 6A con troversy over limiting land holdings is rocking India and, in some states, threatening a split in the ruling Congress party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Ballet: MacMillan Anastasia at Met
description: The basic difficulty of Ken neth MacMillan's new ballet Anastasia, which was giv en its American premiere by the Royal Ballet at the Met ropolitan Opera House. Fri day night, is simply the story. The idea of basing a ballet on the woman who claimed to be the Grand Duchess Anastasia, a sole survivor from the Russian Czar's family when it was murdered at Ekaterinburg in 1918, was illjudged.

title: N.B.C. Takes the Lion's Share Of Emmys in News Categories
description: The National Broadcasting Company took the lion's share of a group of Emmy Awards presented by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences at twin ceremo nies last night and yesterday afternoon here and in Los Angeles.

title: Kerr on The Crucible and The Heal Inslector found
description: THOUGH I am not an admirer of Arthur Miller's The Cruci ble, which seems to me a wellintentioned tract filled with paperthin people, I have never before been ex asperated by it. Exasperation came in waves, though, on the opening night of the cur rent revival at the Vivian Beaumont, and I wasn't hard put to say why. Most direc tors know that plays contain flaws and work hard to con ceal them. John Berry has mounted The Crucible as though it were his business to advertise them.

title: The Nation
description: HUEFirst came the civilian wave, running south from the doomed city of Quangtri, choking Highway 1 with tens of thousands of people, animals, furniture and food. They had to travel through a gantlet of fire, for North Vietnamese troops were dug in on both sides of the road, shooting ma chine guns and artillery. The road be came a slaughter house.

title: Anne Milbank's Bridal
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., May 6Miss Anne Scrymser Mil bank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Milbank, was married here this afternoon to Ens. John Knisely Mell, Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mell, also of Summit. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. George W. R. MacCray.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Crime
description: They met at least once a month. Sometimes the chairman prepared an agenda. They discussed business mat ters such as insurance, severance pay, the organization's price structure and the possibility of enlarging the staff.

title: Birds Flock to His Yard And View Is Just Grand
description: OCEANVILLE  Hundreds of thousands of nature lovers travel from far and near each year to view the water fowl and shore birds in the 19,233acre Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge here. But all Jack Lacy has to do to view these beauties of nature is to step to the picture window of his home.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CATHY LEE TAKES TROT AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, May 6  The 24,027 fans at Yonkers Race way wagered an aggregate of $243,540 on tonight's featured Jersey City Trot, and the ma jority backed Cathy Lee, the 6yearold Diller HanoverIso la's Giers mare, into 3.5 favor itism.

title: Head of Legislative Index: She Keeps Tabs on Bills
description: TRENTON On Monday and Thursday mornings, when the New, Jersey Legis lature is in session, a brunette takes her place at a long desk marked Legislative In dex, facing the General Assembly.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To TIIE EDITOR:

title: SCHOOL AGREEMENT APPROVED BY COURT
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) A threejudge Federal court gave final approval yesterday to an agreement giving every child in Pennsylvania a free public school education.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: All the panaceas have been subjected to the subversion of her thought
description: In a recent essay not reprinted in this collection, Hannah Arendt has written that thinking is inherently an antisocial and subversive activity, a quiet enemy to all established versions of right and order. The truly independent thinker is never finally at ease with the customs and institutions of his (or her) times, but rather is continually and relent lessly probing for the soft spots in a society's selfimage; attacking the difference between appearance and reality, what is and what ought to be. Thinking scorns all isms, con venient fictions masking the truth about the imperfections of a social orderor of its revolutionary op posite; the thinker is not an ideologue but a philosopher.

title: Art
description: THE relation in which artistic ideas stand to the pressures of revolu tionary politics is too often assumed  almost always for political rather than artistic reasons  to be a simple one. Despite a mountain of evidence to the contrary, the belief persists that art, if it is sufficiently advanced esthetically, will naturally ally itself with the ideology of revolu tion. What this usually means in prac tice is that art is expected to subordi nate its interests  assuming that art has genuine interests of its own, which the ideologues of revolution are not in the habit of admitting to immediate political goals. It all comes down to the notion that art will somehow pro vide a service, a store of esthetic hy giene, helping to cure the social and cultural diseases that linger in the after math of every revolutionary situation.

title: JazzMoving Out of the Doldrums?
description: THIS time the signs that suggest that jazz may be moving out of the doldrums in which it has been sunk for the past 10 years may not be as illu sory as they have been so many times before. They are now appearing in so many different forms that each one tends to support the others.

title: Miss Caroline Savage Ray Betrothed
description: The engagement of Miss Caroline Savage Ray to Clyde Calvin Gunsaulus 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Ray 3d of New York and Virginia Beach, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gunsaulus Jr. of Chicago.

title: G.O.P. Conservatives Back Ashbrook Bid in California
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 7 (UPI)Representative John M. Ashbrook, of Ohio, campaign ing in President Nixon's home state, won the overwhelming endorsement today of the con servative United Republicans of California for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: OffDuty Patrolman Dies In Staten Island Collision
description: Gerald Paul, an offduty policeman attached to the Emergency Service division, was killed early today in a twocar collision at Guyan Avenue and Hyland Boulevard in the New Dorp section of Staten Island, the police said.

title: Kostanecki's Boat Wins On Perfect Score, 5 for 5
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 7In fresh breezes off Annapolis, Andy Kostanecki of Noroton, Conn., became an Olympic prospect today wtih a perfect score of five firsts and a fifth place finish, which was his throwaway, in the Tempest class.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Case for Court Reform
description: In the waning days of a state legislative session when there is little time or inclination to consider wholly new bills, Governor Rockefeller has suggested sweeping changes in the state's judicial system. The proposed changes are generally excellent ones, affecting the admin istration and funding of the courts as well as procedures for expediting trials. They are sure to stir debate, as they already have in the State Senate, but they repre sent overdue reforms.

title: Groucho Stars in a Night at the Carnegie
description: Facing a soldout house at Carnegie Hall Saturday night Groucho Marx described his entrance into show business. He had answered an adver tisement, Boy wanted to sing, in The Morning Herald, which doesn't exist any more, said Groucho, add ing, and hardly do I.

title: SAMARAH BELLARDO BLENDS PIANO WORKS
description: Samarah Bellardo, a pianist who studied at the Juilliard School and now teaches at Virginia Interniont College, gave a recital at Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon. He played Scriabin's Sonata No. 5, Liszt's Sonata in B minor and Shosta kovitch's Sonata No. 1.

title: SEALY GOLF TAKEN BY MISS BURFEINDT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 7 (AP)Betty Burfeindt, who led from the start, shot a closing fourunderpar 69 today and won the $50,000 Sealy golf tournament with a 72hole total of 282.

title: NEW ZEALAND DRIVER VICTOR IN U.S. DEBUT
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 7 (AP)New Zealand's Graham McRae won both heats of to day's L&M Grand Prix at La guna Seca Raceway, scoring a victory in his first United States race.

title: Chares Wins Bicycle Race
description: Pierre Chares of Flushing, Queens, won the 50mile Cen tury Road Club Association amateur bicycle road race in Central Park yesterday. His time was 1 hour 53 minutes. 49 seconds.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Subcommittee on the peaceful uses of outer space, scientific and tech nical subcommittee  10 A.M.; working group on re mote sensing of the earth by satellite3 P.M.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market's rally since midApril fell apart last week when investors decided that Wall Street's traders had pushed prices up too far and thereby depressed rates to un attractive levels. By Friday, a $175 million Bell sys tem offering, which had reached the market Tues day to yield 7.40 per cent, was only onethird placed and re ports circulated that the spon sors were about to give up trying to entice money man agers to buy the issue.

title: STOKOWSKI LEADS RUSSIAN PROGRAM
description: Leopold Stokowski wound up the American Symphony Or chestra's season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with a trio of Russian staples: the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto (Itzhak Perlman as soloist), the Act IV Entr'acte to Khovant ?? by Mussorgsky and ?? Fifth Symphony.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 7American bomb ing and shelling since 1965 have pro duced 21 million craters in South Vietnam.

title: The Crime of Genocide
description: Determined that such horrors as Hitler's deliberate and systematic attempt to destroy an entire people will never be repeated with impunity, the United Nations General Assembly on Dec. 11,1946, unanimously affirmed that genocide is a crime under international law. Two years later the Assembly unanimously approved the text of a Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide.

title: Sonsky, With Help of N.Y.A.C., Eyes Berth on Olympic Team
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 During the Penn Relays two weeks ago in Philadelphia, a meet official spotted Milt Sonsky standing outside Franklin Field.

title: Damodaram Sanjivayya Dead; Head of India's Congress Party
description: NEW DELHI, May 7 (Reuters) Damodaram Sanjivayya, pres ident of India's ruling Congress party, died here tonight of a heart attack. He was 50 years old.

title: RALPH BLANCHARD OF UNITED FUNDS
description: Ralph H. Blanchard, execu tive director of the United Community Funds and Councils of America from 1943 to 1960 and president of the National Health and Welfare Retirement Association from 1951 to 1965, died Saturday at his home, 10 Alden Place, Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Rugby Cup to Washington
description: CHARLOTSEVILLE, Va., May 7A 3point 40yard penalty kick by Gary Rasmussen in the final five miuntes gave the Washington Rugby Club a 16 14 victory today over the Man hattan Club for the Common wealth Cup. Philadelphia beat the University of Virginia, 18 6, for third place and Ohio State finished fifth by defeat ing Birmingham Park, Ala., 106.

title: Mrs. Wachsman Wed To Stanley R. Jacobs
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Wachsman of Mexico City, widow of George Wachsman, was mar ried here yesterday to Stan ley R. Jacobs, a former mem ber of the New York Stock Exchange. The ceremony was performed at the bride groom's apartment by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman.

title: JOURNAL DROPS NIEBUHR'S NAME
description: Bowing to a request from the widow of Reinhold Niebuhr, the editors of Christianity and Crisis will remove the name of the theologian from the mast head of the journal he founded 30 years ago.

title: 5TH AVE. PARADE HONORS DR. KING
description: For more than two sun soaked hours yesterday after noon, hundreds of paraders sang, danced and marched up 40 blocks on Fifth Avenue in a tribute to the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Man, 40, Slain on L. I.
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., May 7 Suffolk County Detectives are investigating the slaying of a 40yearold man whose body was found here early today in the parking lot of the Captain's Table restaurant on Jericho Turnpike. He had been em ployed there as a chef until three weeks ago. The police said that the dead man, Alex ander P. Aksamit, who lived with his wife and two children at 41 Bayard Street, in nearby Lake Grove, had been shot in the chest.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WILBER, Neb., May 7Sena tor George McGovern is cam paigning through conservative, closemouthed Nebraska on the coattails of Calvin Coolidge.

title: 5 U.S. Soldiers Tell of Jungle Survival
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 7Five United States Army men who had been given up as dead ended a 13day ordeal in an enemyheld jungle area last night and described their experiences today at a hos pital.

title: News Analysis
description: ABOARD AIR FORCE 86971, over the Atlantic, May 7The mood aboard Secretary of State William P. Rogers's plane was surprisingly relaxed today de spite the sense of drama caused by President Nixon's decision this morning to summon him home from Bonn. Mr. Rogers sipped lemonade, joked withthe crew, told the four newsmen aboard about his college boxing days, joined his wife, Adele, atbridge, and remarked how glad he was to hear that Bobby Fischer had agreed to play against. Boris Spassky in Ice land for the chess champion ship.

title: Castro Visits Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, May 7 (Reuters)Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived here to day from Guinea, to pay a short visit to Sierra Leone president, Siaka P. Stevens.

title: Bank Robbers' Foe Loses
description: DALLAS, May 7 (Reuters) A member of the posse that shot and killed Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow, the bank robbers, in 1934 has lost his bid to return to law enforce ment as sheriff of Dallas Coun ty. Ted Hinton, 97 years old, was beaten by the incumbent sheriff, Clarence Jones, in yes terday's Democratic primary vote to choose a candidate for November's elections.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Final to Olmedo
description: KANSAS CITY, May 7 (AP) Alex Olmedo, the 36yearold Californian, defeated Haroon Rahim of Pakistan, 62, 57, 76, in the final of the Glenwood invitation tennis tournament today. The winner earned $3, 500.

title: Ulster Boy, 7, Said to Burn Soldier With an Acid Bomb
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 7, (Reuters)A 7yearold boy threw acid in a soldier's face during an incident in Bel fast tonight, the army reported.

title: For Village In France: Adieu Quiet
description: FOSSURMER, France For 700 years the little church of Fos sat perched on the tip of a knob overlook ing the Mediterranean and lorded it over the village nestled on the hillside below.

title: The Theory of Evolution: One Woman's View
description: A 51yearold writer, house wife and mother from Moun tain Ash, Wales (Pop. 2,000) has come up with a theory of evolution that she hopes will shoot holes in the tra ditional maleoriented theo ries of how the human race evolved.

title: Taiwan Without Tears
description: TAIPEIPresident Nixon's turn to ward Peking has left this contested is land, in the view of a Hong Kong newspaper, hanging like a tear in the South China Sea. A whole vale of tears is what a visitor arriving from Tokyo expects to find here after listen ing to Japanese agonies about Wash ington's betrayal of Taiwan. But de spite the expulsion of the Nationalist Chinese Government from the United Nations and the shift or withdrawal of recognition by more than a dozen nonAsian countries, the shockwaves that have swept over Taiwan seem to have left surprisingly little damage.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PAU, France, May 7 (UPI) Peter Gethin of Britain driving a Chevron B20 flashed across the line today just ninetenths of a second ahead of Patrick Depailler of France and won the Pau Formula Two Grand Prix. Gethin and Depailler, in a March 722, battled evenly throughout the 70lap race on a circuit that twists through the center of Pau. They lapped the entire field twice. Gethin was clocked in 1 hour 33 minutes 40.8 seconds for the 70 laps of the 1.7 mile circuit. His average was 77 m.p.h.

title: MRS. THOMAS R. COX
description: Mrs. Marian Buckley Cox, wife of Thomas R. Cox, retired chairman of the Broadway Sav ings Bank, died yesterday at her home, 45 East 85th Street. She was 79 years old.

title: CeaseFire Said to Hold
description: NEW DELHI, May 7 (Reuters) The ceasefire between Indian and Pakistani troops in the Kaiyan area of Kashmir was still in effect tonight, a De fense Ministry spokesman said.

title: Quarantining of Drug Addicts Urged to Halt Epidemic
description: A leading expert on the epidemic nature of drug ad diction believes that heroin use in America has become so widespread that compul sory drugfree villages must be established outside urban centers to take youthful, con tagious addicts out of circu lation for rehabilitation.

title: Truman Will Be 88 Today
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 7 (AP)Former President Harry S. Truman planned to spend a quiet day tomorrow observing his 88th birthday, a family spokesman said. Scores of let ters and messages from old friends and associates were re ceived at the Truman home during the weekend, the spokes man said. The former President was reported in excellent health and enjoying the birthday greet ings.

title: New U S.Japan Trade Dispute Looming
description: TOKYO, May 7  Despite agreements last year intended to resolve their differences, the United States and Japan appear headed for further political con frontation over trade and eco nomic affairs.

title: MRS. LLOYD WEILL
description: Mrs. Ruth Gardner Weill, wife of Lloyd Weill, executive director of the House of Jam ison, dress manufacturers, died Saturday in New York Hospi tal. She was 65 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.

title: JACOB BLAUFARB, 78, FURRIER EXECUTIVE
description: Jacob Blaufarb, who retired as vice president and treasurer of the Ladner Fur Corporation a year ago, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 11 Fifth Avenue.

title: South Korean Boxer Wins
description: PUSAN, Korea, May 7 (AP) Yuh JaeDo of South Korea, Orient middleweight champion, scored a unanimous decision over the Orient junior middle weight champion, Hideo Kana zawa of Japan, in a 12round nontitle fight today.

title: DACCA CRITICIZED ON REFUGEE CARE
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 7 Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross here have severely criti cized the handling of tens of thousands of nonBengali refu gees by Bangladesh authorities.

title: New Soviet Curb on Dissidents Reported as Nixon Trip Nears
description: MOSCOW, May 7Soviet authorities have stepped up measures recently against Jew ish activists and other dis sidents here, evidently to ward off potential incidents during President Nixon's scheduled visit later this month, dissident sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: Carlton Wins 5th
description: Steve Carlton, traded to the Philadelphia Phillies by the St. Louis Cardinals when they refused to meet his re ported $65,000 salary demand after he had won 20 and lost 7 games last season, won his fifth game yesterday by de feating the San Francisco Giants, 83, in Philadelphia. He has lost once.

title: Councilman Robert G. Lindsay Of Staten Island Is Dead at 76
description: Robert G. Lindsay, Demo cratic City Councilmanat Large from Staten Island since 1964 and Democratic leader of Richmond County from 1961 to 1971, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Medical Center, West Brighton, S. I. He was 76 years old and lived at 1346 Victory Boulevard, Sunnyside, S.I.

title: Americans Benefit As France Changes Exchange Controls
description: PARIS, May 7France's Fi nance Minister Valry Giscard d'Estaing has given what amounts to a present to Ameri cans in France by ordering a change in the Government's ex change controls that gives the dollar a higher rate when con verted into French francs.

title: City Ballet Radiates Charm as It Dances Balanchine Waltz
description: There are few pleasanter groups to pass an afternoon with than the four couples who dance George Balanchine's Liebeslieder Waltzer. At yes terday's matinee of the New York City Ballet, the work radi ated, the charm of a drawing room bursting with good music, good dancing and genteel emo tions at the State Theater.

title: 15,000 Mark Hair's 4th Birthday
description: A crowd of about 15,000 persons jammed the band shell are a in Central Park yesterday for a slightly tardy celebration of the fourth an niversary of the Broadway opening of Hair. They were treated to a free rockfolk souljazzLatinblues concert by membeers of domestic and overseas Hair companies.

title: OffDuty Transit Policeman Killed at Party in Bronx
description: An offduty transit policeman was shot to death with his own gun yesterday morning during a struggle with another man following an allnight par ty in the Bronx, the police re ported.

title: Young Sets Mark in Walk
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., May 7 (AP) Larry Young of Kansas City set an American record in the 20kilometer walk of 1 hour 30 minutes 9.9 seconds in Mis souri Cup competition today. Young qualified for the Olym pic trials in the 20 and 50kilo meter walks.

title: Woman Dies In Fire
description: A woman identified as Grace Shankman, 49 years old, was found dead by firemen last night after a fire in her apart ment at 410 East 73d Street. near First Avenue. The Fire Department said that the wom an had apparently died of burns and smoke inhalation.

title: The Theater: Anna K.
description: Apparently the thinking and recipe for Anna K., a staged Variations on Tol stoy's Anna Karenina, went something like this:Do a playwithinaplay, holding to the key characters and original dialogue. Encase it, break it, spur the story as a rehearsal by a group of sharp, with it young people in the studio of a tiny old martinet, a peppery Russian actress who love: Tolstoy. Use a bare stage, except for several chairs and ladders. Even show the bare lights overhead, with one man at a back switchboard, another for taped music. For cos tumesa sash here, a head swatch of bright gauze now and then, a tunic over denims and simple, long swirls of skirt to denote Old Russia.

title: MRS. LENNA YOST, 94, SUFFRAGETTE, DEAD
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 7 (AP)Lenna Lowe Yost, wom an's suffrage and Prohibition leader and a prominent Repub lican, died Friday in Jefferson Memorial Hospital. She was 94 years old.

title: U.S. Five Wins Tour Final
description: MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters) The United States basketball team won the final match on its tour of the Soviet Union today, defeating a Georgia five, 9082, in Tbilisi. The Ameri cans came back strongly after trailing, 3144, at halftime.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALDA, Neb., May 7Senator Hubert H. Humphrey leaned back in his seat as his clanking turboprop made its way through rainy skies back to Omaha.

title: Take 31 Lead as Orr Gets Two Goals, Assist
description: In years to come, when the New York Rangers think about yesterday's game and they willthey'll remember ruefully the wrong bounces, the sticks that were a split second too slow, the shots that sailed past the Boston Bruins' cage by inches.

title: City Hall Notes
description: The Lindsay administration has intensified its struggle with the Board of Estimate over the board's practice of reviewing most city con tracts.

title: Advertising:
description: The telecast of the Ken tucky Derby Saturday had a lot more to it than most of you horse fanciers fancied. It marked Cadillac's moving into another area of tele vision sponsorship. Wow!

title: PLAN IS PROPOSED ON OIL DEPLETION
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Nixon Administration's tax ex perts have worked out a plan that is aimed at countering the demands of tax reformers for a further reduction in the oil de pletio nallowance.

title: City Is Moving to Pay for More Items by Borrowing
description: The city is moving to pare its expense budget by $20mil lion with a proposalbacked by the City Council and need ing state legislative approval to shift school and park re pairs, police car purchases and City University Construction Fund contributions to the capi tal budget.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LEXINGTON, Va., May 7 (UPI)The Washington and Lee University mock political. convention drafted Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy of Massachu setts las night on the seventh ballot as the Democratic Presi dential nominee. The students chase Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas as his running mate.

title: Cosmetics. Millionaire Free On Bail in Conspiracy Case
description: ORLANDO, Fla., May 7 (UPI) Glenn W. Turner, millionaire founder of the Dare to Be Great program and Koscot In terplanetary, Inc., surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged with conspiracy to commit fraud and conspiracy to violate the state lottery law and the securities act. He was booked, fingerprinted and re leased on $2,500 bond.

title: U.S. Pledge for Thai Units In Laos Put at $100Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The United States has committed itself to provide up to $100 million a year to support a Thai irregular army of 10,000 men in Laos, a staff report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today.

title: Illegal Still in Bronx Has a Southern Flavor
description: An illegal still said to be producing large quantities of alcohol was discovered yes terday by detectives in the South yesterdaythe South Bronx.

title: TWO SENATE LEADERS RETURN FROM CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) The Senate's two leaders, Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Mike Mans field, Democrat of Montana, returned tonight from their threeweek trip to China.

title: 500 Who Were at Dachau Mark Liberation at Camp
description: DACHAU, West Germany, May 7 (AP)Five hundred for mer inmates of the Nazi con centration camp at Dachau marked the 27th anniversary of their liberation by the United States Army today with reli gious services and a silent pro cession honoring those who died here.

title: Tanker and Fruit Ship Afire After Colliding Off Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 7 (Agence France  Presse)  A 200,000ton supertanker carry ing fuel oil to United States bases in Thailand and a cargo ship were ablaze in the Gulf of Siam today after colliding headon during the night, a spokesman for Esso, the tanker owners, announced here.

title: Bank Merger Completed
description: The Security National Bank, Hempstead, L. I., announced over the weekend that the merger of the Royal National Bank of New York into Secur ity National was consummated Friday. The merged bank, which includes 12 branches in Man hattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, will use the name of Security National.

title: Steel Mills Reassured
description: PITTSBURGH, May 7Do mestic steel producers had re assuring news on imports last week.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: HOUSTON, May 7Texas voters pushed two women to the forefront of the state's poli tics in primary elections yester day that saw Gov. Preston Smith and Lieut. Gov. Ben Barnes go down to defeat.

title: Danger of Flash Fire Ruled Out Before 35 Died in Silver Mine
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 7 Officials of the Sunshine Silver Mine never expected the kind of fire that ravaged the mine last Tuesday, killing at least 35 miners and leaving 47 more trapped underground.

title: U.S. Rushes to Build AntiMIG Missile
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Pen tagon officials say that the Air Force is rushing to develop an airtoair missile capable of knocking down the highflying Soviet MIG23 jet.

title: Dogfight Fought Near Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 8United States Navy F4 Phantom jets shot down three enemy MIG fight ers during two dogfights 50 to 75 miles southwest of Hanoi the United States command an nounced yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: PRIVATE PRESCHOOLS: BOOMING BUSINESS, Read about it. Turn to Page 14. Alphabetland PreSchool Centers, Advt.

title: Families of War Prisoners Denounce Nixon's Policies
description: WASHINGTON, May 7A national convention of wives and relatives of American prisoners of war adopted a strongly worded resolution to day expressing the members extreme distress at the failure of the Nixon Administration to obtain the release of the prisoners.

title: HUMPHREY LEADING IN MINNESOTA VOTES
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 7Sen ator Hubert H. Humphrey was assured today of a slight major ity of his home state's votes for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: BURUNDI REFUGEES REPORT MASSACRE
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 7 Several thousand men, women and children are reported to have been massacred within the last week by antiGovernment forces in the tiny East African state of Burundi, where a coup d'tat was attempted against President Michel Micombero at the end of April.

title: Books of The Times
description: DADDYJI. By Ved Mehata 195 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $6.95.

title: Village Reported Hit in Error
description: SAIGON, May 7 (AP)  De layed reports from the field said today that a United States F4 Phantom fighterbomber had attacked a South Vietna mese village by mistake on Friday, killing nine South Viet namese marines and wounding 21. The reports said that the incident took place at Mychanh on the northern defense line 20 miles north of Hue.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARISIs it because the Odeonor Thtre de France, as the old neoclassical tem ple on the Left Bank was then calledwas one of the chief stages of the event of May, 1968? At any rate, the rejection of authority is no where more evident than in the realm of drama. The authorities them selves have just given in to this trend by moving the Thtra Na tional Populaire(T.N.P.), founded by the late Jean Vilar, from Paris to an industrial suburb of Lyons, where it will be run by two of the most talented directors of their respective genera tions, Roger Planchon and Patrick Chreau, and by en trusting the immense theater of the Palais de Chaillot, the T.N.P.'s erstwhile home, to Jack Lang, former law pro fessor and creator of the Nancy Festival, which in less than 10 years he has devel oped into the mecca of avant garde theater. This preferen tial treatment granted to the provinces repudiates one of the principles that have shaped France for centuries: the absolute dominance of central authority.

title: Orr Steals Show Despite Bad Injury
description: In the matter of talent and aggression, all things might be considered equal between the Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers, except for one manBobby Orr.

title: Notes on War
description: A South Vietnamese sol dier who ran away on March 31, the second day of the enemy invasion, hitches a ride in our car. Asked if he is returning to fight with his unit, he says no, he is only returning to try to col lect his pay. What if he gets arrested for desertion, he is asked. I would rather go to jail than to the battlefield, he replies.

title: METHADONE PLAN IN SOUTH HAILED
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 7 This city, in sharp contrast to other cities with substantial ad diction problem and big metha done programs, has in the last year nearly eliminated the black market for methadone.

title: 3 FIREMEN KILLED IN NEWARK BLAZE
description: NEWARK, Monday, May 8 Three firemen, two of them captains, were killed late last night when they were trapped while fighting a threealarm blaze in a vacant building in the Lincoln Park section south of the downtown business area here. Three other firemen were injured.

title: F. A. A. to Move to Close 727's Exit to Hijackers
description: In a move to halt extortion andbailout plots, the Govern ment will order the nation's air lines to rewire their more than 600 Boeing 727's so that the rear exit from which hijackers have been parachuting cannot be opened in flight.

title: Lobbying on Abortion Increases at Capitol
description: With rallies, impassioned speeches, angry political threats and a flood of telegrams, let ters and telephone calls, the forces for and against abortion have laid siege to the Legis lature in recent days, hoping to influence the climactic vote on repeal, retention or modifica tion of the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: Sharing the Job of Child Care
description: Myron and Eva Barchas, a young couple without chil dren of their own, like to visit playgrounds and after several such visits they talked over the fact that each mother seemed to sit off by herself while her child played.

title: Experts Meet on the Whens and Whys of the Cold War
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. invited academic friends and a few of his scholarly foes to the Graduate Center of the City University over the weekend for a daylong con ference on Origins of the Cold War. Thirtyfive his torians and former officials attended.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 7 The Arizona Women's Political Caucus got a hearing yesterday on a move to unseat 13 of the state's 25 delegates to the Dem ocratic National Convention on the ground that women are underrepresented.

title: Publisher Denies Violation
description: MILWAUKEE, May 7 (UPI) The Journal Company, a news paper publishing concern, said that the Federal Price Commis sion was in error yesterday in citing the concern as one of 276 major companies failing to file required profit reports. The company publishes The Senti nel mornings and The Journal evenings.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Victims of Onslaught Live in Fear, Bewilderment and Despair
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May. 5The young American heli copter pilot, rescued by an other helicopter after having been shot down by North Vietnamese ground fire, was badly cut and bruised and in a state of shock.

title: Italy Begins Voting for New Parliament
description: ROME, May 7Italy began her decisive two day parliamen tary elections today in a mood of uncertainty over the future of her democratic system.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 7 Terry Sanford left his plans as a Presidential candidate un clear today following his defeat in the North Carolina Demo cratic primary yesterday by Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama.

title: Peace Group Sets Protests With G.I.'s at Army Bases
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) The National Peace Action Coalition called today for a G.I. civilian solidarity day on May 20, with orderly joint antiwar demonstrations at Army bases throughout the country.

title: Rain Delays Final Round At Houston Until Today
description: HOUSTON, May 7 (AP)The final round of the $125,000 Houston open golf tournament, scheduled today, was post poned until tomorrow because of heavy rains that swept the Westwood Country Club course overnight.

title: Racing Triple Crown Has Double Meaning to Laurin
description: LOUISVILLE, Ny., May 7  Riva Ridge, the winner of the most successful Kentucky Der by in its 98year history, lay asleep in his stall this morn ing, indifferent to the many vis itors who clustered around his trainer, Lucien Laurin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: METS WIN IN 10TH ON AGEE'S HOMER
description: If Tommie Agee learns to love the curveball, blame the San Diego Padres. Agee helped the New York Mets de feat them, 86, yesterday by belting his third home run of the season over the centerfield wall with two out in the 10th inning.

title: GIAP SEES VICTORY IN WAR OF NIXON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7 (UPI)Defense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap of North Vietnam, marking the 18th anniversary of the victory over the French at Dienbienphu, said today that the Vietnamese people had defeated three American ad ministrations and were in the process of finishing off the war of Nixon.

title: SENSE OF URGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Nixon today called a meeting tomorrow morning of the National Security Council, the Government's principal for eign policy body, and sum moned Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers home from a European tour to attend it.

title: FEDERAL OUTLAYS INFLATION FACTOR
description: The massive growth in the Federal Government's outlays for public welfare and income maintenance in recent years has been a major source of in flationary pressure, a leading student of the Federal spending process charged over the week end.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, Which was not officially in the annual Andy Awards, managed to walk off with the great est number of them anyway.

title: Personal Finance
description: The mailorder business is receiving increasing scrutiny from the Federal Trade Com mission, In the last few weeks the F.T.C. has issued two unusually strong orders covering sins of omission and commission by two mail order companies in the New York area.

title: Mrs. Frances Herskovits, Anthropologist and Author
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 7 Mrs. Frances Shapiro Hersko vits, an anthropologist who worked with her late husband, Dr. Melville J. Herskovits, on African cultural anthropology, died Thursday at the age of 74.

title: Knicks Defeated, 114100, As Chamberlain Scores 24
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 7The National Basketball Association title, sought so long by the Los Angeles Lakers and especially Jerry West, finally came their way tonight as they defeated the New York Knicks, 114100, and won the final round of the playoffs, four games to one.

title: Hammer and Bruchi Triumph
description: BELLMORE, L. I., May 7 Howard Hammer and John Bruchi won the American Pad dle Ball Association onewall doubles champlogship for the third straight year today by de feating Paul Fromer and Henry Bader, 212, 2022, 2122, at Newbridge Park.

title: Screen: Fiction of a Sort:Resnais's 'Je T'Aime' Opens at New Yorker
description: "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, was shown at the eighth New York Film Festival. The following is from Roger Greenspun's review, which appeared Sept. 15, 1970, in The New York Times.Like most of the previous films of Alain Resnais, "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime" is science fiction of a sort. And like virtually all of Resnais's previous films, its concern is for the past recaptured. To support this concern it proposes a story, the most fragmented of all Resnais' stories, dealing with, perhaps intense but nevertheless transitory love affair.Claude (Claude Rich), having recovered from an unsuccessful suicide attempt, is picked for an experiment by a secret research center that studies time. Claude, along with a laboratory mouse, is placed inside a large soft brain-shaped structure, from which he is to be transported back to relive one minute at 4 in the afternoon exectly one year ago. He does relive that minute (he is snorkeling on vacation in southern France, and "underwater" becomes a recurring image and idea for the film), but he begins reliving it several times overand then in bits and pieces he begins to relive other moments scattered through the seven years he lived with Catrine (Olga Georges-Picot), whom he thinks he killed and for whose death he had tried to kill himself.Assuming that they have lost him forever, and sadly admitting that their experiment has been a most incomplete success, the research scientists wander out of the laboratoryonly to discover Claude, a bullet in his gut (he has most recently relived his botched suicide) lying on the grass. But in their despondency and concern they forget the little mouse, who did come back, and now sniffs forlornly inside his container within the giant brain.I am disturbed by that mouse, not only for the bathos of the image but also because his situation so ludicrously (and, I think, so intentionally) recalls that of the wife, Simone, looking for her husband, already light years away, inside another woman's deserted apartment at the end of Resnais's one masterpiece, "Muriel." For "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime" resembles "Muriel" in so many close ways that the success of the older film (1963) stands in almost total reproach to the general banality of the newer one.Although obsessed with time, memory, the past, the physical material of "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime" is its love story and the daily lives of the couple involved in it. But in that story and in those lives it finds so little of interest or urgency that with all its perceptual complexity it comes to seem an enormous and ingenious structure with almost nothing inside it.

title: ATTACK ON THE U.S.O. IS LINKED TO GOSSIP
description: The president of the United Service Organizations said yes terday that charges made against U.S.O. personnel in Vietnam by a Wisconsin Con gressman were based on gos sip and rumor.

title: Corporal Punishment Ban in Schools Sought
description: Spearheaded by lawsuits, quiet but determined cam paigns are starting to build up in various parts of the country to ban corporal punishment in the schools, a practice that only two states have declared il legal.

title: Diana Coles Married To Charles A. Bitran
description: QUOGUE, L. I., May 7 Miss Diana Lee Coles, daugh ter of Mrs. Franziska Temple Meier Coles of New York and Quogue, and Col. Clarence James Coles, U. S. A., retired, of New York, was married here this noon to Charles Arthur Bitran, son of Joseph Bitran of New York and the late Mrs. Bitran. Southamp ton Town Justice Paul H. Smith Jr. performed the cere mony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. ABRAHAM MANCHER
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., May 7 Mrs. Sarah Gailband Mancher, widow of Abraham Mancher, a fur importer, died here yester day. She was 77 years old and lived at 3017 Moreland Avenue.

title: Civic Group Finds WorkRelief Increases City Unemployment
description: Using relief recipients in parttime city jobs so they can work off their grants increases and perpetuates unemploy ment, the Community Council of Greater New York asserted yesterday. It said some relief recipients were filling jobs left vacant by attrition in the city's budget squeeze.

title: IVERSON'S 276 WINS SHREVEPORT CLASSIC
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 7 (AP)Don Iverson of LaCross, Mich., carded his fourth con secutive twounderpar 69 to day to win the Shreveport Classic golf tournament.

title: Salan Say U.S. Aid Lags
description: BONN, May 7 (UPI)  The former commander in chief of the French Army in Indochina said today that America's material aid to South Vietnam was not enough to meet the military aid given the North Vietnamese by the Soviet Union.

title: Rural Action Helps to Give Poor Southern Blacks Jobs and Pride
description: ATLANTA, May 7Dr. Ran dolph T. Blackwell, director of Southern Rural Action, Inc., unrelentingly walked the back roads of the South attempting to create jobs for rural blacks where none existed and instill ing community pride where it seldom existed.

title: Cosmos Tied in Opener, 33, by Stars
description: The St. Louis Stars rallied to score three goals late in the second half and tie the New York Cosmos, 33, in the Cos mos' North American Soccer League opener at Hofstra Sta dium in Hempstead, L. I., yes terday before 7,324 fans.

title: Pearson Captures Winston 500 in Rain
