title: Spain Attracts ArmsSellers and Military Analysts
description: MADRID, May 11Spain has embarked on an extensive and expensive program of military modernization that has attracted arms salesmen from all over Europe and the United States.

title: Port Notes
description: The possibility of unsettled labor, conditions in the American merchant marine after June 15, when current union agreements expire, is causing apprehension among shippers. James R. Barker, president of MooreMcCormack Lines yesterday told the annual meeting of Moore & McCormack Co., Inc., the line's parent company, that unless contract settlements were reached promptly, continuing uncertainty might be a negative factor for the line's cargohandling operations in the second quarter of this year. It may produce diversions to foreignflag ships, he added.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Oil. President Nixon issued a proclamation increasing foreign oil imports by approximately 15 per cent, or 230,000 barrels a day.

title: 9 EMISSINGER AIDES DENOUNCIU.S. MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, May II, (UPI)Nine former members of Henry A'Kissinger's staff denounced the mining of North Vietnamese harbors today as a fruitless and illconoeiyed effort to preserve the President's concept of American Presidential prestige.

title: U.S. PlywoodChampion
description: HOUSTON, May 11 (AP)Shareholders of U. S. PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., voted today to change the company's name to Champion International.

title: Seedman Revamps Alexander's Security
description: The biggest problem with merchandise thefts is that though they are crimes, they are not violent crimes. The police don't pay as much attention to crimes against property as to crimes against people. So a business has to be largely responsible for its own security.

title: ALBANY LEADERS AGREE ON CITY AID
description: ALBANY, May 11Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leadership agreed at a breakfast meeting this morning on an offer to help New York City by authorizing $100million in additional borrowing power, far short of what Mayor Lindsay has said is needed.

title: Vacations for the Aging
description: One of the glorious sights of summer: watching a busload of men and women in their seventies and eighties leave the steaming city streets for a vacation in the country. As these seniors trundle off with perky sun hats and light hearts, they remind onlookers that anticipation and the need for a change of scene are both lifegiving and ageless.

title: MAHLER'S THIRD IS OFFERED HERE
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night with just one work to perform, but it did not lick for notes to fill out the evening, The work was Mahler's Symphony No. 3, and its six movements stretch out long enough to satisfy almost anyone's need for music to listen to at oneysitting.

title: Allegheny Power Ending All Marketing Activities
description: The Allegheny Power System, Inc., announced yesterday that its operating companies were discontinuing all promotional, advertising and other marketing activities. Charles B. Finch, president, said at the annual meeting here yesterday: This decision is not only a matter of reducing operating expenses but also stems from our conclusion that we will have all the load growth we would want or could handle without these efforts.

title: Art From Alumni Bedecks Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 The Princeton University Art Museum has mounted the most ambitious and the best exhibition in its history. A show of paintings and sculptures from the collection of Princeton alumni, the exhibition is, moreover, one of the outstanding art events in the Metropolitan area this year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OMAHA, May 11 (AP)Senator George McGovern, who defeated Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in the Presidential popularity phase of Nebraska's primary election Tuesday, moved ahead today in the competition for committed Democratic National Convention delegates.

title: U.S. Soccer Team One Victory Short Of Olympic Berth
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (UPI)  Mike Seerey's scoring and the goaltending of Shep Messing are moving the United States closer to its first Olympic berth in soccer.

title: Rail Freight Off for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Association of American Railroads reported that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended May 6 totaled an estimated 15.3 billion ton miles, 1.2 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 516,140 cars, down 3.4 per cent from last year.

title: Gray Plans Wide Change In P. B. I. Policy and Style
description: WASHINGTON, May 11L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today series of steps that may radically change both the appearance and substance of an agency held rigidly to a single pattern by J. Edgar Hoover for nearly 50 years.

title: Battle Erupts in Small Town
description: PORTADOWN, Northern Ireland, May 11 (Reuters)Twelve policemen were injured during a threehour battle here between rockthrowing Protestant and Catholic gangs early today.

title: 2 Times Men, Newsweek Editor Winners of 1972 Loeb Awards
description: Two members of the financial and business news department of The New York Times and an editor of Newsweek magazine have won the 1972 G. M. Loeb Awards for excellence in business and financial journalism. A special award in the competition, adMinistered by the University of Connecticut, was won by the editor of Forbes Magazine.

title: Crampton, Marti Lead in Golf by Shot
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 11 (AP)Bruce, Crampton of Australia and Fred Marti of Baytown, Tex., had 4underpar 66's today to tie for the lead after the first round of the $125,000 Colonial National Invitation golf tournament.

title: British Trade Still Lags
description: LONDON, May 11 (Reuters) Britain's overseas trade transactions in April ended with a deficit of $137.8million, the Government announced today.

title: INDUSTRY OPPOSES RULE ON SECURITIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)  The Banking and Securities Industry Committee today opposed regulation of securities depositories by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Like Coming Back to Paradise, Says Mays And Fans Agree
description: Even before Willie Mays said he was glad to be back, yesterday's big baseball trade had begun engulfing New Yorkers in a wave of emotionalism.

title: Wall St. Woman Market Place With a Specialty
description: You may think that it is enough to be born with silver spoon in your mouth to make it in Well Street. Sue Robbins didn't find it so.

title: BIG BOARD PLANNING ON BIG TRADING DAYS
description: A computer system capable of handling 50 million share trading days and more is being installed at the New York Stock Exchange, officials said yesterday.

title: THREAT CHARGED
description: MOSCOW, May 11The Soviet Union demanded today that the United States immediately end the blockade and bombing of North Vietnam, but gave no indication that it planned to cancel President Nixon's scheduled visit here on May 22.

title: Mentally Ill Burglary Suspect Dies in the Suffolk County Jail
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 11A 30yearold prisoner who had been diagnosed as mentally ill and in periodic catatonic states died yesterday in his cell in the Suffolk County Jail here, apparently of malnutrition or complications of undernourishment after losing 35 pounds in less than two weeks.

title: House Panel Finds Inefficiency and Corruption in Crime Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The House Government Operations Committee voted 22 to 14 along party lines today to approve a report that says the Nixon Administration's efforts to curb crime are plagued by waste, inefficiency and corruption.

title: Two Balanchine Ballets of 20's Given
description: Apollo and Prodigal Son, both presented for the first time this season at the State Theater on Wednesday night, are the only Balanchine ballets in the New York City Ballet repertory that date from the choreographer's days with the Diaghilev company in the nineteentwenties.

title: U.S. ASSERTS NIXON EASED PEACE TERMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The State Department asserted today that President Nixon's latest proposal for a peace settlement in Vietnam, outlined in a speech Monday, had relaxed rather than stiffened the United States terms for a negotiated agreement.

title: Mother's Day Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) President Nixon signed today a proclamation directing Government officials to display the flag Sunday in observance of Mothers Day.

title: Texts of Chinese Statement and Letter
description: On May 8, 1972 U.S. President Nixon brazenly ordered the mining of the ports of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, the cutting off of the land and water communications of North Vietnam and the intensification of air and naval strikes. This is a new grave step taken by the United States in escalating its war of aggression against Vietnam.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BI USSELS, May 11 (AP)Emanuel Orantes of Spain defeated Ove Bengston of Sweden, 62 62, today in the top match in the Belgian open tennis championships. Tom Gorman of Seattle was ousted by Patrick Hombergen of Belgium, 60, 63.

title: CHUTE FOUND IN AREA OF HIJACKER BAILOUT
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 11 (AP)Searchers have found a parachute harness and jump suit they believe were discarded by the hijacker of an Eastern Airlines plane after he bailed out over Honduras with $303,000 in ransom, the government said tonight.

title: CHARLES BELKNAP 2D
description: GUILFORD, Conn., May 11Charles Belknap 2d, a designer of silver and jewelry, died Tuesday of cancer in the West Haven Veterans Hospital. His age Was 59. He graduated from Yale in 1936.

title: Strict Regulations Imposed by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 12South Vietnam was placed on stringent emergency status last night.

title: Dacca Raising the Status of Women While Aiding Rape Victims
description: DACCA,. Bangladesh, May 11Officially sponsored efforts to assist the thousands of victims of rape by Pakistani soldiers in Bangladesh are being expanded into a national program to advance the status of women generally. In this conservative Moslem country, women in orthodox families are traditionally secluded.

title: Agnew Draws Protest At Hilton in Honolulu
description: HONOLULU, May 11 (UPI) Fifty antiwar demonstrators scuffled with the police at the Kahala Hilton today and cursed Vice President Agnew when he appeared on the hotel balcony.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market registered a cautious advance yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: Candidates Day
description: FREDERICK, Md., May 11More than 100 Maryland state troopers and local policemen formed a cordon around Gov. George C. Wallace here tonight, separating him and his wife from a raucous group of black youngsters who waited for him to emerge from the hall where he spoke.

title: Last of the Mine Victims Found, Bringing Toll in Idaho Fire to 91
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 11The last of the victims of a fire on May 2 were found dead tonight in the Sunshine silver mine near have.

title: Pilots in Italy Call 16 Airfields Unsafe And Curb Landings
description: ROME, May 11Italian airline pilots said today that 16 airports in their country were safety risks, and announced that they would land on them only in perfect weather.

title: Protesters Roam Capitol; Suit Seeks to Halt Mining
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Thronging the steps and roaming the halls of the Capitol, antiwar demonstrators protested and lobbied today for an end to the war.

title: Candidates Day
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, who has gone nowhere in Democratic primaries so far, said today that he was still a candidate for President and expected to be the party's compromise candidate after others lost out.

title: Costs on Pollution Put at $22Billion
description: United States business will have to spend a total of $22.8billion to bring its existing facilities up to present pollutioncontrol standards, according to a new study by the economics department of the McGrawHill Publications Company.

title: Police and Protesters: A Kind of Truce
description: For the time being at least, peace demonstrators and the Police Department seem to have reached, if not a rapport, then perhaps an understanding.

title: A Love Film With a Boy of 13 Is Cheered at Cannes Festival
description: CANNES, France, May 11The first allstops, out, triumphal ovation of the 26th Film Festival here has gone to I Love Rosa, an Israeli love story involving a 13yearold youth and a 21yearold widow, set over a century ago in Jerusalem.

title: DOCTORS INITIATE HARLEM REPAIRS
description: Emergencyroom doctors at Harlem Hospital, frustrated by long delays in correcting the facility's inefficient physical layout, took matters Into their own hands yesterday.

title: BritishChinese Talks Due
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)The British Government has instructed its Ambassador in Peking to hold immediate talks with Chinese officials on the Vietnam crisis.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The first Soviet response to the mining of North Vietnam's waters is being read here as delaying action, probably to buy time for secret diplomacy.

title: FOOD CONCERN SETS DUTCH ACQUISITION
description: The Consolidated Food Corporation is planning to enter the toiletriespersonal care field through the proposed acquisi tion of Erdal Concern, a Netherlandsbased company, for about $26million in cash, it was announced yesterday. Under terms of the agreement that has been reached in principle, Consolidated would acquire at least 51 per cent of the common shares, and all of the priority shares (preferred) from the Wolbers family.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Sunday, April 30, a train with 682 city kids and their bicycles arrived at our fair little community of Southanipton, L. I., and I was shocked by their behavior.

title: An Appraisal
description: The poster In the North European travel agency read, Visit Italy Now, Before the Italians Destroy It. It was not a sick joke., It was an indication of a process of degradation of art and land scape approaching a kind of national masochism. The results of that process, now chillingly documented, are being shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in an exhibition en titled Art and Landscape of ItalyToo Late to Be Saved? A small, important show with a very large question mark indeed, its thesis is of no less than cosmic interest to Western. Civilization.

title: Hanoi Says 8 Captured Pilots Signed Statement Against War
description: PARIS, May 11North Vietnam tonight released an antiwar statement it said was signed by eight pilots who are being held captive in Hanoi. It was the first time in 18 months that the Hanoi Government has given any public indication of the location of a prisoner facility.

title: Contempt Convictions Are Upset In Chicago 7 Conspiracy Trial
description: CHICAGO, May 11  Contemptofcourt convictions resulting from the Chicago trial on conspiracy to incite riots at the Democratic National Convention in 1968 were overturned today and remanded to the United States District Court for a new trial before a new judge.

title: Injured Yastrzeinski To Be Out for Month
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 (AP)Carl Yastrzemski will not have to undergo surgery on his injured right knee, but the Red Sox star probably will be lost to the team for at least a month.

title: 5 HAIPHONG SHIPS SAILED, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Defense Department reported today that five vessels, four of them Russian, left the principal North. Vietnamese port of Haiphong before Americanlaid mines blocking the harbor channel became active at 6 A.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CLEVELAND, May 11The Cuyahoga County Board of Elections will be requested tomorrow to order a recount of all 300,000 votes cast in the May 2 Democratic Presidential primary here because of errors turned up in the preliminary count.

title: BROKERDEALERS GET FIRMER RULES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 New regulations designed to make it harder for inexperienced and thinly capitalized persons to enter the brokerage business were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The amended rules will take effect on June 15.

title: Unlikely, Sure, But They Are Belly Dancing a
description: Where are you, Little Egypt? Or Vilma Banky, undulating on the desert sands of the silent screen and driving Valentino mad in The Son of the Sheik?

title: CREWS IS LEAVING 2 BROOKLYN POSTS
description: After 38 years as the Brooklyn Republican leader and 50 years as, a district leader, John R. Crews announced yesterday that he was giving up both posts.

title: WRVRFM Presenting Daylong Antiwar Editorial
description: Radio station WRVRFM will present today a 15hour editorial campaign against United States involvement in Vietnam.John Wicklein, the station's general manager.

title: Damage to Big Belfast Store In Bombing Put at $25Million
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 11  The damage to Belfast's biggest department store, which burned to the ground yesterday after a terrorist bomb exploded inside, was estimated today at $25million.

title: Dr. Anitra L. Thorhaug Is Married
description: MIAMI, May 11Dr. Anitra Louise Thorhaug was married here this evening to Dr. Richard George Bader, associate dean of the University of Miami's Rosensteil School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences, where the bride received her doctorate.

title: Siderowf Captures Medal On 73 in Richardson Golf
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 11Dick Siderowf, the Canadian amateur golf champion from Westport, Conn., holed out from a bunker for a birdie 3 at the last green today to win the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament medal with a 73.

title: In Emergency, Carnesecca of Nets Can Always Call on Baum
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 11 Lou Carnesecca had a scrimmage scheduled today at the Nassau Coliseum, but it never came off. The Net coach didn't have enough bodies available.

title: Serena Welles Is Bride Of Ambler H. Moss Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The marriage of Miss Serena Welles to Ambler H. Moss Jr., a lawyer with Coudert Brothers here, took place in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, on Saturday afternoon. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Bodies in Coal Mine Fire
description: FARMINGTON, W. Va., May 11 (AP)Five more bodies were brought from the No. 9 coal mine here yesterday, nearly forty months after fires and explosions trapped 78 men while they were working underground. Crews have been at work for almost three years in recovering bodies and rehabilitating the mine.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England; May 11 (AP)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., moved into the semifinals of the British hardcourt tennis championships today with a hardfought 64, 98 victory over Jurgen Fassbender of West Germany.

title: MISS PIGNI BETTERS MARK IN LONG RUN
description: FORMIA, Italy, May 11 (AP) Paola Pigni bettered the women's 3,000meter world record by 14 seconds today in the Formia international track and field meet.

title: RIESSEN IS VICTOR OVER DRYSDALE
description: DALLAS, May 11 (AP)Marty Riessen lost the first two sets hut rallied to defeat Cliff Drysdale, 57, 4.6, 6.2, 75, 63, to advance to the semifinals tonight in the World Championship tennis tournament.

title: Mrs. W. Redmond Cross, Led Horticultural Society
description: Mrs. Julia Appleton Newbold Cross, president of the Horticultural Society of New York in the 1950's, who won many prizes at flower shows, particularly for her ranunculus and chrysanthemums, died here Wednesday at the age of 80. She lived in Bernardsville, N.J., and New York.

title: Teacher, Farmer and Businessman Become Refugees
description: DANANG; South Vietnam, May 11  Hong Huu Vinh was a teacher, Bui Van Nam was a farmer and Tran Khanh was a prosperous business man Now they are all refugees three of the some 400,000 Who hive crowded into the banang area in recent days Since the fall of Queried Province to the invading North Vietnainese.

title: Americans Begin Pulling Out of Pleiku
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 11 The United States today began moving out many of the 2,800 American advisers and support troops stationed here as the North Vietnamese offensive came closer to this Central Highlands city.

title: Swedes March for Greenery
description: STOCKHOLM, May 11About 6,000 chanting demonstrators paraded through central Stockholm today demanding that urban planners preserve more greenery in the city. It was the first of a series of demonstrations scheduled here before and during the United Nations Environment Conference here next month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I wish to express our disagreement with your recent editorial entitled Divisive Census, which discussed the racial and ethnic census of New York municipal employes.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Soviets are playing a very clever waiting game with President Nixon. They are spanking him publicly for his latest air offensive against North Vietnam, but corresponding with him privately, allowing their officials to get their pictures taken with him at the White House, and acting in general like disappointed friends dealing with a misguided and reckless child.

title: Judge Sets Hearing Here on Suit to Bar Vietnam Bombing
description: President Nixon and Defense Department officials were directed by a Federal district judge here yesterday to demonstrate why they should not halt the bombing of North Vietnam and the mining of its coastal waters.

title: Two Shows to End Runs
description: Two shows, one on Broadway and the other off Broadway, announced yesterday their intention to end their runs this weekend. Gore Vidal's An Evening With Richard Nixon And will close tit the Shubert Theater tomorrow night after 13 performances. Paul Zindel's The Effect of Gamma Rays on ManintheMoon Marigolds ends its run at the New Theater on Sunday after 819 performances.

title: Mansfield Says StepUp of War Eclipses Chances for Better U.S.China Ties
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, who returned vast weekend from a 16day tour of China, said today that the stepup of the Vietnam war had thrown into at least temporary eclipse the possibility, of improved relations between Washington and Peking.

title: VIOLENT ACTIONS REPORTED RISING
description: Protests against President Nixon's escalation of the Vietnarn, war continued across the country yesterday, amid signs mounting frustration and violence on both sides.

title: Red Smith
description: When Willie Mays was the biggest thing to hit New York since the Great Snow of 47, Charlie Einstein ghosted a book for him, one of those slightly autobiographical quickies that publishers are forever throwing on to the Market in the hope of capturing the first fine careless rapture of discovery. A day br so after the job was finished, Einstein telephoned hid collaborator.

title: Notre Dame Pilot Here to Aid Multiple Sclerosis Fund Drive
description: Ara Parseghian, Notre Dame's football coach, was in New York yesterday seeking financial support for the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: STEIN DOUBTS RISE ON ARMS OR TAXES
description: MONTREAL, May 11  The reescalation of the Vietnam war will probably not require a significant increase in United States military spending or an increase in taxes next year, Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said here today.

title: Most of Day's Air Raids Skirt Hanoi and Haiphong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 12Hundreds of United States planes struck at highways, railroads and supply storage facilities over a wide area of North Vietnam yesterday.

title: Bombs Rock a U.S. Army Base At Frankfurt, Killing a Colonel
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 11A chain of bomb blasts at a United States Army headquarters complex here killed an American lieutenant colonel and wounded 13 people today.

title: Advertising:
description: The sniper fire directed at televisionland from magazine circles has been returned by the boys behind the tube.

title: Bruins Trounce Rangers, 30, And Capture Cup in 6 Games
description: It was over suddenly for the Rangers last night, quick and clean, as the Boston Bruins captured the Stanley Cup with a 30 victory before a Madison Square Garden crowd that gave the New Yorkers a final 50second standing ovation for the try that failed.

title: Robbers Kill Bronx Grocer And Get Away With $400
description: A 28yearold Bronx grocer was shot and killed yesterday by two robbers who took $400 and escaped, the police of the Simpson Street station reported.

title: THOMAS HUGHES, 78, BUILT FOR DIOCESE
description: Thomas J. Hughes, a former constructor of buildings for the Roman Catholic Church in New York, died Wednesday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 13530 Grand Central Parkway, Kew Gardens, ueens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 21 editorial on the Alaska oil pipeline omits one crucial factorwhat about natural gas? We estimate gas reserves on the North Slope of Alaska  those which are proved plus those which are thought to exist but not yet proved could supply the whole of the United States for some fifteen years at present rates of consumption.

title: SUM GAIN MADE BY NORTHERN GAS
description: The Northern Natural Gas Company reported yesterday that its net income from operations in the quarter ended March 31 rose to $21.6million from $20.7million in the corresponding period last year.

title: PENALTIES FACED ON CANADA TIRES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) In the first case of its kind, the Treasury Department served notice today that it was considering imposing extra customs duties on French auto tires imported from Canada because the Canadian Government had helped the concern to build two plants there.

title: Bridge: Precision Team Finds Going Is Harder Here Than on Road
description: A part is not usually greater than the whole, but a case could be made for the proposition that the bridge experts in New York are stronger than the bridge players in the United States.

title: Mays Misses One Mark
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (AP)The trade that sent Willie Mays to the New York Mets left him short of one of the few Giants club batting records he didn't hold. Mays drove in 1,859 runs in 21 seasons with the team in New York and San Francisco. Mel Ott had 1,860 runs batted in for 22 seasons with the New York Giants.

title: Thousands Join Quebec Strike Against Jailing of Union Aides
description: MONTREAL, May 11Thousands of workers in several areas of Quebec stayed away from their jobs today in a militant, and occasionally violent, display of union solidarity.

title: Is Mayor Daley Slipping?
description: CHICAGOMyths die hard. Among the most perdurable of these: He makes the city work. The allusion is, of course, to Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago. A constituent, during occasional visits to New York, is frequently congratulated by despairing hosts; his good fortune in being governed by a man who makes the city work and their bad luck in suffering the nongovernment of John Lindsay. New Yorkers are not alone in this fantasy play.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MAKE A RECOVERY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved up yesterday for the second day in a row, recovering from their slump earlier in the week on news of the Government's new policy in Vietnam. Yesterday the index closed at 27.32, up 0.12 following a Wednesday rise of 0.13.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's a melancholy but common thing to find a novelist who has written one or More good books turning out a bad one. The critic will dutifully mention the good ones and deplore or explainin any of a dozen waysthe falling off in this particular case. What is much more uncommon and not easy to explain is the case of a man who has written several bad or mediocre books and who then suddenly produces one that is dramatically better. By this I mean a book that is not only quantitatively but also qualitatively superior, one in which the author has not simply worked up more of the sort of effects that are his forte, but has used quite different materials and written another sort of book entirely.

title: A Day in the Life of a Welfare Mother
description: At 8:30 in the morning, Bessie Johannes's day is just an hour old. Two babies lie in their cribsone playing, one sleeping, Two older children are stepping from a bathtub. Each gets propped on a chair, dried and dusted with powder.

title: Suddenly Wealthy Johnson Foundation Maps Plans
description: Dr. David E. Rogers, the new president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, was asleep when the clamor of the telephone broke the midnight silence of his apartment overlooking Carnegie Lake in Princeton, N. J.

title: The Steak Is GoodAnd That's Not All
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: China Bars U.N. Role
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11China today rejected any role for the United Nations in attempting to end the war in Vietnam.

title: Banks Reserves Up
description: The nation's monetary gold stock increased, $822million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Irish, by 4 to 1, Approve Joining Market
description: DUBLIN, May 11Ireland has given resounding approval to economic union with Europe, approving an accession treaty with the Common Market countries by a vote of better than 4 to 1.

title: HOUSE REAFFIRMS ANTIBUSING STAND
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The House of Representatives voted once again today to insist that its conferees on the higher education bill stand inflexibly behind the antibusing provisions attached to the House version of the bill.

title: Every Student Needs a Miss Wiggins
description: COLUMBUS, OhioIt was something of a surprise, pleasantly, when on the first day of my high school English classback in the thirtiesMiss Wiggins handed me a comic page from The Raleigh (N.C.) News and Observer. She asked me to read aloud the adventures of the, comic strip Wash Tubbs. I had the assignment for a week, about the length of time would take Captain Easy to subdue Bull Dawson who was armed with cottonbale hook used to move cargo from dock to shipboard. The grappling iron was intended to move Easy from the ranks of the living. Pintsized Wash played a major role for the good guys that week when he shoved a barrel under Bull's legs from behind. I read all the proper inflections and grunts into the balloon dialogue.

title: Canadian Index Is Steady
description: OTTAWA, May 11 (Canadian Press)The index of industrial production was unchanged in March from the February level of 184.3 and only slightly above the January level of 184.27 Statistics Canada reported today. The index measures Canada's industrial output and in adjusted to remove increases caused by Inflation or normal seasonal variations.

title: Store Sales Reported Lip
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Department of Commerce reported today that weekly retail store sales for the week ended May 6 was an estimated $8,398,000,000, up 3 per cent from the yearearlier $8,176,000,000. Department, store sales in the same week were about $833,000,000, up 1 per cent from $821,000,000 (M).

title: Juilliard Unit Presents Behan's Timely Hostage
description: One thing about Irish plays dealing with the troubles, they are always timely. Brendan Behan's The Hostage was first staged in 1958, but it could have been written in 1916, or yesterday. Ireland Unfree Will Never Be at Peace read the posters on the street. Ireland Unfreeand there will always be poets and playwrights to talk about it.

title: Peking Denounces U.S.Vietnam Move
description: PEKING, Friday, May 12The Chinese Government early today condemned the new United States air and naval operations against North Vietnam.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market continued yesterday to shake off the effects of President Nixon's Monday night address on Vietnam and managed another small advance.

title: Woman in the News
description: WASHINGTQN, May 11Barbara Lynn Herwig recalls attending a recruiting session held by the Federal Bureau of Investigation when she was in law school. After I was told they didn't accept women agents, well, I didn't expect to wind up here, she says. But today, the young lawyer was informed by L. Patrick Gray 3d that she would continue to be his special assist ant as he moves into his new job as acting director of the bureau. The move means that, at the age of 27 years, she will become the first woman to play a major role in an agency that has been maledominated since its birth half a century ago.

title: Only Wilt and His Doctor Knew Sprained Wrist Was Broken
description: Wilt Chamberlain disclosed yesterday that his right wrist was fractured, not sprained as had been announced, during the recent National Basketball Association championship playoff. The disclosure also rekindled Chamberlain's feud with Bill Russell.

title: MSGR.P.J.TEMPLE,83; PASTOR. IN SUBURBS
description: Msgr. Patrick J. Temple, pastor emeritus of St. Gabriel Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N. Y., died Wednesday at the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 83.

title: Deaths
description: ALTENHEIN Clarie, on May 9, 1972. Wife of the late Ernest F. Altenhein. Devoted mother of Dr. Margarete R. Altenheln. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street, Thursday, 9 A.M.10 P.M. Service Friday 1:15 P.M. Interment private.

title: Sensible Minimum
description: The House of Representatives exercised good judgment yesterday in voting a twostep increase in the Federal minimum wage from $1.60 an hour to $2 and in killing a proposed extension that would have opened up an almost boundless new area of protectionism in foreign trade.

title: Candidates Day
description: BALTIMORE, May 11Senator Hubert H. Humphrey presented himself to the mostly black Ministerial Alliance here today as your David against the Goliaths of poverty, bigotry, disease and neighborhood decay. About 50 ministers, recognizing a preacher like themselves, chorused, Amen!

title: HERBERT MOSES, JOURNALIST IN RIO
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 11Herbert Moses, who as founder and longtime president of the Brazilian Press Association, led the fight for press freedom here in some of its most difficult periods, died today in the home of a daughter. He was 87 years old.

title: 4 Arrested in Alleged Race Fix,
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 11 Four men, were arrested by New York State Police late tonight for allegedly attempting to fix the Superfecta in the ninth race at Monticello Raceway.

title: First Hearing Held On Landing Project In the East River
description: The first public hearing on the proposed Manhattan Landing, a vast multiuse project that would rise on platforms above the East River, was completed yesterday in 85 minutes, to the amazement and pleasure of city officials.

title: Colonels Get Rights to Price
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels of the American Basketball Association today obtained negotiating rights to Jim Price, the University of Louisville basketball star. Mike Storen, the Colonels president, said the rights were acquired from the Memphis Pros in exchange for an undisclosed amount of cash and a future draft choice.

title: 2 Policemen Are Convicted of Extortion Charge
description: A New York police sergeant and a detective were convicted yesterday of conspiracy to commit extortion and bribery in connection with a Bronx auto theft ring that reportedly had stolen and dismantled at least 1,000 latemodel cars.

title: METS LOSE, 6 TO 4, AFTER 21 VICTORY
description: While the great Willie Mays mystery was being unraveled behind the scenes, the New York Mets divided a daynight doubleheader with the Les Angeles Dodgers yesterday in Shea Stadium.

title: Last Week's Battle Toll At 7Month High for 17.5.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 11 (UPI)The United States command said that 19 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, 17 more than the week before and the highest United States death toll in seven months.

title: SATO VOICES DOUBTS ON U.S. WAR MOVES
description: TOKYO, May 11  Premier Eisaku Sato said today that he doubted the wisdom of President Nixon's order to stop the flow of supplies to North Vietnam and expressed the hope that the move would not turn the Vietnam conflict into an endless war.

title: EXECUTION BILL GAINS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, May 11After several weeks of emotional debate, a measure that would restore capital punishment in New Jersey received initial legislative approval today in the State Senate.

title: Fishing Pact
description: An agreement signed with Brazil this week reflects welcome new flexibility in the United States Government position regarding the right of nations to regulate foreign fishing in waters beyond the twelvemile fishing limit which this country limits itself, and which it has sought to persuade others to accept.

title: Screen: Ann Arbor Films at Whitney
description: The selection of short movies from the 10th Ann Arbor. Film Festival that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum is pretty evenly divided between narrative (not necessarily fictional) vignettes and more or less strict abstractions. And by the grace of whatever gods balance the quality of movie programs, the two best films, Ira Wohl's "Co-Co Puffs" and Standish Lawder's "Raindance," come one each from narrative cinema and the cinema of abstract forms."Co-Co Puffs" is a cinemaverit account of a drum lesson, in which a young woman spends some time with an unusually dedicated teacher ("Everything you do has something to do with drums") and learns how to make a new soundthe "Co-Co Puffs" of the title.It doesn't seem like much, and in treating it the film is quite without pretensions as to scope. But even in the weird context of a drum lesson there is space for doubts and confidence, for false starts and a few seconds of real victory.Ira Wohl is aware of both the dignity and the embarrassment of his situation, and for a study of somebody attempting something new, such awareness leads to sharp and rather lovely insights.Mr. Lawder developed "Raindance" out of some old animated footage, a pattern of driving rain, upon which he works perhaps a quarter of an hour of rich and highly disciplined variations proceeding through multiple wipes, changes in color and changes in duration and intensity of light, "Raindance" becomes a kind of tour-de-force demonstration in ways of achieving maximum effect from minimal means.Rosalind Schneider's "Abstraction," a study of forms reflected and greatly distorted in (I think) crinkled aluminum foil, is probably the most serious film in the program. It is handsome and greatly suggestive of meaning, but I am not sure that it supports its somewhat ponderous rhetoric with an equal proportion of real discovery.Miss Schneider has interesting ideas about a kind of moviemaking, and I believe she will become very good. But for the present it is more fun to follow the modest demands of Mr. Lawder's two-minute "Color Film," Andrew Lugg's five-minute "Gemini Fire Extension," or the double, triple, quadruple exposure of Pat O'Neill's delightful "Last of the Persimmons."A kind of modesty attends Morley Markson's "Our Trip to Bubieeta in Miami Beach"false modesty, I believe. A diary film, narrated, acted out, and largely sung by two precocious little girls (Markson's daughters) who visit their grandmother in Florida, it has approximately the freshness, simplicity, and innocence of an F.A.O. Schwartz toy catalogue.But it at least earns its style more honestly than Allan Holleb's "Heavenly Star," a pseudo-affectionate takeoff put-down of the early 1950's in the form of a movie-musical production number exploiting almost every dramatic dance clich in the bookGene Kelly's book, or Stanley Donen's. Although Holleb knows how to parody his originals' vulgarity, I don't think he knows how to value it, and so he falls into a vulgarity of his ownunfeeling, superficially observant, divided between open condescension and disguised contempt.

title: SENATE VOTES AID TO SPACE SHUTTLE
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The Senate approved today $3.4billion in space authorization funds and all but committed the United States to a new era in space activities.

title: AL CARMINES BLENDS INTERLUDES SERIES
description: Al Carmines, the prolific resident composer at Judson Memorial Church, offered a choice collection of the songs he has written for a variety of shows over the last eight years at Town Hall Wednesday as part of the 5:45 Interludes series.

title: Estimate of 72 Wheat Crop Pared 11% by U.S. Board
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1972 winter wheat crop at 1,149,064,000 bushels, down 11 per cent from a Dec. 1 forecast and 1 per cent smaller than last year's crop.

title: Excerpts From Tho's News Conference in Paris
description: PARIS, May 12Following, in unofficial translation from the Vietnamese, are excerpts from a news conference held today by Le Duc Tho, chief negotiator for the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace conference:

title: CONFEREES DELAY WORLD BANK SUMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 House  Senate conferees have decided to reject an appropriation of $320milliod for money due from the United States to the World Bank but have pledged that this and two other installments of the same size will be approved later.

title: Sports of The Times
description: His locker has been prepared, if not pampered. It had belonged to Don Hahn, an outfielder on his way to the minor leagues, but now it belongs to the New York Mets' new outfielder. On the blue wood was an orange 24 next to Mays on a stenciled nameplate. Inside hung two uniform shirts, two pairs of pants, two bluearmed sweatshirts, two rubber sweatshirts and a blue woolen warmup jacket. On a ledge were two pairs of blue stockings, two pairs of white hose and a pair of white rubber shower sandals. On the floor were six pairs of spikes, black with three orange stripes on each side, that he had worn with the San Francisco Giants until the trade. His blue Mets cap hung on a hook. On the Shea Stadium clubhouse radio a voice was sing ing a rock lyric, I'm on my way, I don't know where I'm going.

title: Arkady A. Plastov, 78, Soviet Farm Life Painter
description: MOSCOW, May 12  Arkady A. Plastov, a Soviet painter of collective farm life, died yesterday in his native Volga Valley village of Prislonikha where he had spent most of his life. He was 78 years old.

title: E. OTTO SICHEL DIES; WINE EXPERT WAS 65
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12E. Otto Sichel, vice president of Fromm & Sichel, Inc., the distributors of the Christian Brothers wines and brandy, died Wednesday at the age of 65.

title: 12 Hurt Slightly by Explosion
description: Two pedestrians were injured slightly by flying glass about 3 P.M. yesterday when a Consolidated Edison transformer exploded under a 12story apartment house at 179th Street and Broadway. According to the police, the explosion sent flames into the M&M children's shop, which occupies the first floor of the apartment house at 4117 Broadway.

title: The Stakes Are High
description: The four men charged with trying to fix Thursday night's superfecta at Monticello Raceway apparently followed a script that seems to be an inevitable byproduct of exotic wagering.

title: Students Here Display Inventiveness
description: Whirring and clicking as it went, a small motorized platform loaded with electronic equipment rolled along the floor, following a twisting and turning black line like a mechanical bloodhound.

title: Reshaping the City
description: There are shortrange, longrange, practical and philosophical reasons supporting the State Legislature's decision to create a charter revision commission to look at the structure of New York City's government. One of the more important reasons is that formation of the commission will avoid the chaos threatened by the city's borough presidents. These officials planned to ram their own particular form of decentralization plan onto November's ballot.

title: Banking on Minorities
description: WASHINGTON (AP) 7 The American Baptist Home Mission Societies decided to deposit $600,000 in banks run by blacks rand other minorities.

title: 11 Dead in Flood in Texas; Thousands Leave Homes
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 12  A wave of water, created by daylong heavy rain, flooded through the hill country of central Texas today, leaving at least 11. persons dead and an undetermined number missing. Braunfels. In Seguin four bodies were recovered and one other victim was sighted in the turbulent waters.

title: Shanker Cites Rise In School Violence; Urges Board to Act
description: Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, called yesterday for the Board of Education to work toward establishing a special department in the District Attorney's office to represent victims of school violence, and for the board to provide rehabilitative facilities for students with criminal records.

title: NIKOLAID.YAKOVLEV, HEADED ARTILLERY
description: MOSCOW, May 12Marshal Nikolai D. Yakovlev, commander of the Red Army's artillery in World War II, died here Tuesday at the age of 73.

title: Philip Ever good's Show Includes His Best Work
description: The exhibition of 43 paintings and drawings by the 70yearold American painter, Philip Evergood, which opened this week at the Kennedy Galleries, 20 nist 56th Street, is not, rightly speaking, a retrospective. Nor is it a oneman exhibition of his most recent works.

title: Notes on People
description: The Mother of the Year, chosen just in time for Mother's Day tomorrow, is Mrs. Esther Hunt Moore, of Hickory, N. C., an educator of the mentally retarded. She is the second Negro to be chosen for the honor in the 37 years the American Mothers Committee has made the award.

title: HIGH BREEZE WINS OPEN JUMP CLASS
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 12  High Breeze, owned by Mike Niles of Purchase, N. Y., and handled by Barbara Myers, won the first open jumper class today at the opening session of the Children's Services horse show.

title: Pentagon Says Several Ships on Way to North Have Apparently Changed Course
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Defense Department said today that several merchant ships on the way to North Vietnam had apparently changed course to avoid running Into the Americanlaid mines. In that country's harbors.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDONOne striking aspect of President Nixon's decision to mine the harbors of North Vietnam, and the manner of its taking, was his contempt for the concept of law. He did not even attempt to justify in international legal terms what stood, unless justified in some way, as an act of outlawry. Domestically he showed not the slightest deference, in committing this formal act of war, to the Constitution's requirement that Congress declare war.

title: MRS. HYMAN TANTLEFF
description: Mrs. Sophie Tantleff, the widow of Hyman Tantleff, the founder of the Tantleff Beef Company who died in 1956, died Thursday at her home in San Carlos Hotel, 150 East 55th Street. She was 90 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: L. Patrick Gray 3d, the new acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, spent an hour yesterday at the F.B.I.'s New York offices, 201 East 69th Street. He addressed the agents and clerical help for about 10 minutes and then conferred with John W. Malone, the assistant director who heads the office here, and other administrators.

title: I.R.A. Man Freed
description: Goulding, chief of staff of the Official wing of the I.R.A., was cleared by a jury today of charges of incitement to violence in recommending the language of the bomb and the bullet in a funeral oration for an I.R.A. member.

title: Dow Plans Texas Facility
description: MIDLAND, Mich., May 12 (UPI)The Dow Chemical Company said today that it would build a multimilliondollar toluene diisocyanate plant with a capacity of 100 million pounds a year in Freeport, Tex. The plant will begin producing the chemical raw material for urethane foam in late 1974.

title: No. 24
description: At age 41, Methuselah time by baseball's clock, Willie Mays is making a double comebackto New York and to what his fans hope will be a bangup season. For the Mets Willie is expected to spell Tommie Agee in centerfield and play first base against lefthanded pitching, with a coaching job in the future. Typically, he commented, I'm looking forward to playing and helping, but not embarrassing myself. No chance. The most graceful centerfielder in ages can't do wrong even if the muscles aren't as rubbery on the throw home. No. 24 is back, and New York rejoices for long afternoons under a brighter sun.

title: Injury Puts Numbered Account Out of Today's Acorn
description: Susan's Girl will be the strong favorite in today's Acorn, against six other 3yearold fillies. The reason for the heavy support that will be accorded Fred Hooper's representative is a plausible one  Numbered Account won't be be in the onemile race at Aqueduct.

title: Berrigan Flies to Paris To Meet Hanoi Aides
description: The Rev. Daniel Berrigan, on parole after serving a prison term for burning draft records, flew to Paris last night to meet, he said, with representatives from the North Vietnamese Government.

title: Target for Dissent
description: While students and other antiwar protesters are taking to the streets to express their opposition to President Nixon's Indochina policy, Presidential aides boast of heavy support for the mining of Haiphong in telegrams and other messages to the White House. While it is questionable whether the claimed 5to1 favorable response truly represents the national mood, the men responsible for national policy in the White House and Congress will never know differently so long as dissent exhausts itself in random street demonstrations that too often result selfdefeating violence.

title: CAREER SCHOOLING BACKED AT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Career education, a concept linking schooling and the working world, was endorsed here today by a succession of speakers who saw in it the potential to aid a host of causes.

title: HANOI'S RESIDENTS REPORTED LEAVING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12  A Canadian official said today that much of Hanoi had been evacuated.

title: Court Upholds Law for Sports Complex in Jersey
description: TRENTON, May 12  The New Jersey Sports Authority Act was upheld today by the State Supreme Court, and authority officials said a new Hackensack Meadowlands football stadium for the New York Giants would definitely be ready by 1975.

title: Brown Named Bucks Aide
description: MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 12 (UPI)Hubie Brown, first assistant coach at Duke University, today was named assistant coach of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Dance: Variationson Sleeping Beauty
description: To Britain's Royal Ballet The Sleeping Beauty is a lady of infinite variations. Perhaps the keystone to the Royal Ballet style is to be found, as it is with the great Russian companies, more in its interpretation of roles than in its production of ballets. The Sleeping Beauty has always been a specially significant work in the Royal Ballet repertory.

title: RAIDS SAID TO CUT ME LINE LINKING HANOI WITH CHINA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 13United States fighterbombers have reportedly cut North Vietnam's northeastern rail link with China by knocking out a bridge.

title: SIDEROWF OUSTS BISCONTI, 4 AND 2
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 12Dick Siderowf, the 34yearold Westport, Conn., stockbroker whose golfing achievements have gained him the Metropolitan and Canadian amateur championships and a place on the United States Walker Cup team, eliminated the defender today to gain the semifinal of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament.

title: Quebec's Cabinet'Confers As Labor Crisis Intensifies
description: MONTREAL, May 12Quebec's Premier, Robert Bourassa, met with members of his Cabinet in emergency session today as the province's labor troubles continued to intensify.

title: Planes Fly Over Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 12 (Agence FrancePresse) The streets of Hanoi were deserted this morning as highflying American planes passed overhead. The crowing of a cock could be head. The antiaircraft batteries were silent.

title: Blasts Rip West German Police Offices
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 12 (AP)Bombs exploded at German police buildings in Munich and Augsburg today as the authorities investigated the blasts at a United States Army headquarters compound in Frankfurt that killed an American colonel and injured 13 persons on Thursday.

title: SCRIBNER SCORED ON EXAMINER JOBS
description: In an unusual public display of private differences, the vice president of the Board of Education took issue yesterday with Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's choices for appointment to the school system's Board of Examiners.

title: Wheelock H. Bingham, 64, Dies;. Retired President of R. H. Macy
description: Wheelock Hayward Bingham, retired president of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., and before that president of its Macy New York division, died last night in his sleep, apparently of heart attack,. at his home in Southbttry, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: Decorating on Budget, but Not With Budget Furniture
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y. Tenants moving into a new housing project here are greeted by an unusual sight a model apartment full of things they can find in Westchester and, in the words of its designer, afford without going into hock.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SUGARRECOVER
description: All eight contract months of the world No. 11 sugar contracts on.the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were 2 to 11 points higher yesterday, reversing the decline of the past few days.

title: Memorial for Dr. James
description: A memorial service for Dr. George James, the former president and dean of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, who died. March 18, will be held at Hosack Hall of the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, on. Tuesday at 5 P.M.

title: A.M.E. Zion Election: It's Like a Family Reunion'
description: MOBILE, Ala., May 12The lobby of the municipal auditorium was plastered with campaign posters. Inside, the organ struck up a boisterous tune, and delegates rose from their seats and marched through the aisles singing and carrying placards for the favorite candidate.

title: Iran Eliminates Egypt.
description: TEHRAN, May 12 (AP) Taghi Akbarl won a fourhour match from All Davoudi of Egypt today and sent Iran into the quarterfinal bracket of the European Zone A, Davis Cup competition. Iran gained a 31 lead on. Akbari's 68, 64, 86, 68, 63 triumph.

title: Tho Spurns Nixon's Plan, But Would Resume Talks
description: PARIS, May 12Le Due Tho, a leading member of the North Vietnamese politburo, today rejected President Nixon's latest proposal for a settlement in Vietnam, but said that he would stay on in Paris and was ready for serious negotiations.

title: Babies Names  Jennifer and Jason Are the Vogue
description: Fashions in first names may not change as rapidly and as inevitably as other fashions. But the do change. If all the babies with Jennifer on their birth certificates were lined up in their prams right this minute, the number of them might surprise you.

title: Nixon Names Labor Aide WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) President Nixon announced today the appointment of a former union official, Donald Rogers, a 45yearold New Yorker, to be his fulltime consultant on labor matters. Mr. Rogers will take a leave of absence from his position as executive director of the New York Building and Construction Industry Board of Urban Affairs. He previously served as recording secretary and business agent for the Operating Engineers International Union.

title: Thuy Leaves Moscow
description: MOSCOW, May 12 (AP)Xuan Thuy, head of North Vietnam's delegation to the Paris peace talks, left today for Hanoi after a twoday stopover.

title: Antiques. Styles in Dolls
description: Dolls in the newly reinstalled toy exhibition at the NewYork Historical Society represent a good cross section of the early examples that collectors covet.

title: Planes to Check Phosphates
description: BOSTON, May 12 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would use planes to check New England waters for excessive phosphates that are choking out fish life. A concentration of phosphates in water causes rapid growth of algae. Decay of the dead algae uses up oxygen needed by, fish. The Federal program seeks to help state and local governments reduce phosphates by better municipal waste treatment.

title: Hemisphere Bank Takes New Path
description: QUITO, Ecuador, May 12The Inter  American Development Bank closed its 13th annual meeting here today by adopting farreaching measures aimed at eliminating some of the bitterness shown by many LatinAmerican countries to ward the industrialized nations in their speeches the last five days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On your April 21 OpEd page you published an article by Andreas G. Papandreou Under the Colonels. In it Mr. Papandreou blames the U.S.A. for the dictatorship in Greece, and to prove his contention he says,  we live in a world dominated by superpowers and Greece became an American protectorate with the announcement of the Truman Doctrine.

title: Man in the News
description: CLEVELAND, May 12Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, elected today as president of the American Jewish Congress, is a scholar, an author and, according to his associates, one of the nation's most outspoken preachers. Spiritual leader of Temple EmanuEI in Englewood, N. J., since 1956, the rabbi angered many of his suburban congregants in 1963 by warning, in a Yom Kippur sermon, against United States involvement in Vietnam. Those whose feathers were ruffled were not only hawks but also those who saw the synagogue as a place for worship, not controversy, particularly during the high holy days.

title: All You Have to Do Is Dream
description: LONDONMy nightlife as a child was full of excitement, drama and terror, but I could never get my parents or teachers to take my nocturnal ad, ventures seriously. Just dreams, they said. But I knew better, and decided to become a psychologist in order to explore the mysteries of the other world which manifests during sleep.

title: Roundup: Robinson Clout Helps Dodgers Beat Phils
description: Wee Willie Keeler, who played 19 years in the major leagues and batted .341, gained that fantastic career batting mark by punching the ball past infielders. He explained his system as, Hit em where they ain't.

title: Fresh Yankee to Seek 6th Straight
description: YONKERS, May 12Fresh Yankee, who lost her first three starts of the season, but won her next five, will be seeking to extend her streak in a $25,000 freeforall handicap onemile trot at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

title: Four Cambodian Posts Fall
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 12 (UPI)The Cambodian military command today announced the fall of four Government positions in Takeo Province, raising to 11 the number of such posts the Communists have captured in the south since overrunning the border town of Kompong Trach on April 30.

title: Exodus Began Last Month
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (UPI)The evacuation of Hanoi, carried out by Government vehicles, began with the American air strikes of April 16, a diplomatic source said here today.

title: 3 I. R. A. Youths Jailed 4 Years In an Attack on Belfast Woman
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 12Three admitted members of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army were each jailed for four years by a court today for their part in painting and feathering a pregnant woman.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON BROAD FRONT
description: An easing of tension over the Vietnam situation enabled the stock market yesterday to score an upturn, with advances outnumbering declines by more than a 2to1 ratio.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Trade. President Nixon proclaimed the week beginning ay 21 as World Trade Week. The President said the United States economy may reap maximum benefits with increased participation in international trading activities. Production and employment in the American economy will be stimulated and our balance of payments placed better equilibrium, he proclaimed.

title: Books of The Times
description: O JERUSALEM. By Larry Collins and Dominiqua Lapierre, 637 pages. Maps and Illustrations. Simon & Schuster. $10.

title: Senegalese Aided by Big Peanut Harvest
description: DAKAR, SenegalThe Senegalese recently proclaimed a national Day of the Peanut, and well they might, because when the peanut prospers everything seems all right.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CLEVELAND, May 12Official results of the Cuyahoga County voting in the May 2 Democratic Presidential primary will be released tomorrow and representatives of the two major contenders will inspect them before deciding whether to ask for a recount.

title: Recovery Continues in Amex Prices
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued the recovery progress since Tuesday's slump, gaining 0.16 to close at 27.48 as measured by the index.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 12 In 1960, Joe Sinay, opened his first furniture store. Today he is the board chairman of RB industries, which operates 37 stores throughout California; he also has investments in several motels, office buildings; and other real estate ventures.

title: Canada, Mexico Tied
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 12 (Canadian Press)Raul Ramirez brought Mexico back to a 11 tie at the end of firstday play in the Davis Cup North American challenge round as he overwhelmed Tony Bardsley of Canada, 64, 8.6, 62 today the first match, Canada's Mike Belkin beat Joaquin Loyo Mayo of Mexico, 62, 60, 3.6, 68, 75.

title: Stockton, Heard Lead by Shot at 135
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 12 (AP)Dave Stockton carded a twounderpar 68 late today and tied Jerry Heard for the lead after two rounds of the $125,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament. Heard had posted a 66 earlier for a 135 total.

title: Yale Service for Nkrumah
description: A memorial service for Kwame Nkrumah, the deposed President of Ghana, who died April 24 at the age of 62, will be held in the Yale Law School auditorium in New Haven tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. The speakers will include Prof. Nana Nktsia, Professor of African History at Boston University.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 20 editorial that began appropriately with the phrase As usual in Albany, electoral reform remains disgracefully neglected contained, surprisingly, praise for the Assembly on its passage of a runoff primary bill. Since then, the Senate has also passed the bill.

title: Agnew in Japan for Okinawa Transfer
description: TOKYO, May 12Vice President Agnew arrived here today for a fourday state visit, the chief purpose of which will be to act as United States representative, in ceremonies Monday marking the transfer of the Ryukyu Islands from United States to Japanese rule.

title: Artist's Yellow Sound of 09 Is Staged
description: In conjunction with its exhibition of Kandinsky paintings, the Guggenheim Museum is presenting in its auditorium the world premiere engagement of a play by Kandinsky, The Yellow Sound (Der Gelbe Kiang). The work, one of a number of stage pieces created by Kandinsky, was written in 1909.

title: Welfare Is Not an Evil Word
description: Many of the poor who came here struggled out of ghettos to a more favorable position in life for their children. But there are still more recent arrivals who have not yet been able to escape their sordid surroundings. What a breach of trust it isas well as a betrayal of a commitment to our own idealswhenever any of these people, because of their race, or color, or creed, find hostility here instead of hospitality, or are awarded not light and warmth from the lamp beside the golden door but a badge of inferiority for conditions they are powerless to change.

title: WORLD TRADE WEEK TO BEGIN ON MAY 21
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) President Nixon today proclaimed the week beginning May 21 as World Trade, Week and said the; United States economy may reap maximum benefits with the nation's increased participation in international trading activities.

title: Auto Output Declines
description: DETROIT, May 12 (AP) With Chrysler production off about 3,000 units this week, domestic auto production registered a mild decline, according to the trade publication, Automotive News.

title: Bridge: The Hazards of Rescuing Player Caught in Double
description: Rescuing a partner who has been doubled at a high level is usually a case of going from the frying pan into the fire. And if the original bidder rescues again, hoping for a lit in some unexplored suit, he is likely to be cooked to a cinder.

title: EXJERSEY AIDE ADMITS BRIBERY
description: NEWARK, May 12Robert J. Bttrkhardt, the former Democratic state chairman of New Jersey and a powerful political figure in the Democratic Hughes administration in the nineteensixties, pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today to charges of bribery and extortion.

title: Exchange Punishes 2 Member Firms On Rule Violations
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several disciplinary actions involving rules covering advertising and investment, literature distributed by member firms.

title: Burns of Reserve Outlines A 10Point Monetary Plan
description: MONTREAL, May 12  Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, set out in an address here today 10point program for a longrange overhaul of the international monetary system.

title: 15 Are Arrested At Hunter College In Hiring Protest
description: Fifteen persons protesting hiring practices in a Puerto Rican studies program at Hunter College were arrested yesterday on criminal trespass charges.

title: Gunman Is Killed
description: BELFAST, May 12 (UP1)Gunfire killed one man and wounded five others tonight in Belfast's Roman Catholic Andersonstown area, the British Army said. A spokesman said a British patrol had reported an ambush by seven gunmen. In an exchange of fire, all but one gunman was hit, he said.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges issued this Week their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies: The reports include the following:

title: BRITAIN LIFTS A BAN ON ARMS TO SPAIN
description: LONOON, May 12Britain has lifted her ban on arms sales to Spain, imposed by the Labor Government in 1965 when Gibraltar was a contentious issue between the two countries.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, May 12The North Vietnamese and the Vietcong insist that they do not want to impose a Communist or socialist government in Saigon. President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger, his chief adviser for national security, say they do.

title: Shearing's Quintet Heard in a Medley Of Familiar Songs
description: George Shearings Quintet is now in its 23d year, as the Britishborn jazz pianist points out to his audiences in the Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel, where the group is now playing. Its sound and style have remained so consistently the same over those years that Mr. Shearing even ventures a feeble joke about still having the original personnel (which he does not).

title: Most Units Gain
description: Record sales and earnings were achieved by Dresser Industries, Inc., in the second fiscal qdarter and half year ended April 30, the Dallasbased producer of equipment and services for the petroleum, and general industrial fields reported yesterday.

title: CITY FALLS SHORT OF STATEAID GOAL
description: ALBANY, May 12New York City's attempt to obtain extensive additional state aid fell short of Mayor Lindsay's goal today as the Legislature enacted a $100million program of extra borrowing authority for the city.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 12Senator George McGovern has apparently won 16 of the 22 elected Nebraska delegate's to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Brydges Is Lauded for an Hour in Albany Goodby
description: ALBANY, May 12The Senate paused in the midst of its drive for adjournment today to bid an emotional, bipartisan farewell to Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges, who is retiring from politids after serving 24 consecutive years as a Senator. matte leader. At center, applauding, is the Assembly. Speaker, Perry B. Duryea of Montauk, L. I., and flanking him are Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, left, Assembly Democratic leader, and Joseph Ruggiero, who is counsel to the Democratic minority in the Assembly.

title: M.T.A. Wins Its Fight for Two Penn Central Lines
description: A Federal District Court judge in Philadelphia yesterday approved the transfer of the Hudson and Harlem commuter lines of the Penn Central to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: U.S. AGENCY BARS DELAY ON CUTTING AUTO POLLUTANTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, denied today the automobile industry's request for a year's postponement of the sharp reduction in exhaust pollutants required for 1975 models under the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: 2 Bronx Teachers Charged With Marijuana Possession
description: Two high school teachers have been arrested by a police anticrime patrol team and charged with the felonious possession of two pounds of marijuana, Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said yesterday.

title: Ready to Accept Women's Applications
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)Moving, quickly to give the Federal Bureau of Investigation anew look, the acting director, L. Patrick Gray 3d, overturned today J. Edgar Hoover's longstanding refusal to hire women as special agents.

title: Barthes Tops Smith, Gains Net Final With Hewitt
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 12 (AP)Pierre Barthes of France, upset Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6.4, 64, today in the semifinal round of the British hardcourts tennis championships.

title: Town in Idaho Remains Stunned By Deaths of 91 in Silver Mine
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 12Residents of this northern Idaho community, 13 tuntied by the death of 91 miners in a fire at the Sunshine silver mine, began trying to return to normal existence today as funeral plans were being made for the victims and efforts were begun to provide financial aid for their families.

title: Detente in the Balance
description: A significant advance in normalizing EastWest relations in Europe now hangs on the ratification by West Germany of the nonaggression treaties with Russia and Poland: namely, the first state treaty ever concluded between East and West Germanya detailed agreement covering all forms of traffic across the 800mile border separating the two parts of Germany. It will be signed and ratified only after Bonn has completed its legal validation of the treaties with Moscow and Warsaw.

title: La Salle Trackmen Lead By 2 Points in Title Event
description: TRENTON, May 12 (AP)La Salle held a 2point lead over West Chester (Pa.) State today after the first day of the twoday Middle Atlantic Conference track and field championships at Rider College.

title: Merger News
description: The Allegheny Corporation, in a prelude that may eventually lead to a major move into the shoe business, has been quietly buying stock of the USM Corporation, formerly known as the United Shoe Machinery Company. Allegheny, which controls Investors Diversified Serv ices, the mutualfund complex based in Minneapolis, announced just before the close of trading here yesterday that it had acquired 207,000 shares of USM as of May 2, or slightly more than 5 per cent of the outstanding common shares of the company.

title: Government Will Increase School Breakfast Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  The Agriculture Department announced today that schools in severe need can soon collect from the Government up to 30 cents for each free breakfast served to poor children.

title: Summer Job Outlook for Youths Is Poor
description: WASHINGTON, May 12High school and college students looking for summer jobs face another difficult season this year, but the prospects for some of them have been brightened by an 11thhour appropriation of additional Federal money by HouseSenate conferees.

title: Catholic Officials Deny Priests Were Crucified
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 12 (Reuters)Roman Catholic officials yesterday denied as unfounded a report by a senior United States official that two French missionaries had been crucified by North Vietnamese troops.

title: Coast Guard Crews Win All 4 Heats in Regatta
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22Well  schooled oarsmen from the United States Coast Guard Academy of New London, Conn., created a stir at the Dad Vail Regatta today by winning heats in all four eightoared events.

title: To Whom Should I Write a Letter?
description: AMHERST, MassI know you attend to what I say because I am president of the college. I thank you for that, but I want to speak to you in two voices. First, as president of Amherst College; second, in my own voice. I am tense and uneasy with the act of dividing myself in two: My hope, as president, has been not to lose myself in the role, the office, to retain a sense of my own self while still president. My personal unease is made worse because as I said at the start, I know you listen to me because I am the president. It is not Bill Ward you want to hear: You want to hear the president of Amherst College. So, let me begin first with the voice you want to hear, that of the president, and then speak as Bill Ward.

title: New President Is Named At Federal's Store Chain
description: Leonard Blackman, a former president of the E. J. Korvette discountstore chain and more recently a retailing executive at the Stratton Group here, has been named president of Federal's Inc., a departmentstore chain in Detroit.

title: Justice Agency Seeking National Gypsum Order
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to charge the National Gypsum Company, one of the nation's leading gypsum producers, with contempt for obstructing proceedings of a Federal grand jury investigating operations in the industry.

title: SMALL COUNTRIES RESISTING U.S.MD
description: GENEVA, May 12  Small countries are resisting an effort of the United States to make a select group of major nations within the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development the key decisionmaking forum of the monetary and trading system.

title: Madison Mood: Cairn and Fear Mixed
description: MADISON, Wis., May 12 Let's hear that Johnny Cash bumchaka beat, the tall blond young man with the fiddle said to his shorter sidekick, who began to strum on his battered guitar.

title: Art Review
description: In his first New York exhibition at O.K. Harris, 465 West Broadway, Sig Rennels reveals in his art that he is a bright and facetious gagman. Although his bag of jokes is not all that big or varied, his work still show enough plucky wit and charming spoof to turn this e xhibition into a, delightfully entertaining slapstick comedy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  Democratic National Chairman Lawrence F. O'Brien has asked state party chairmen to consider appointing women and minoritygroup members to atlarge delegate seats for the party's national convention.

title: POLICE EASE RULE ON TESTING DRUGS
description: In a departure from Police Department policy, Commisstoner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that parents who think their children have brought narcotics into their homes can secretly take the suspected drugs to the police for testing without risk of prosecution of themselves or of their children.

title: RALPH STANTLEY, 58, STAGE, FILM ACTOR
description: Ralph Stantley, stage, screen and television actor who specialized in toughguy roles, died Wednesday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 2130 Broadway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Bruno Stein's letter of April 1, apparently based upon a misreading of several reports carried in The Times, misstates my positions on the welfare system.

title: Pontiff Gives a Role to Laymen In Choosing Bishop Candidates
description: ROME, May 12Pope Paul VI today gave national and regional hierarchies a stronger voice in the selection of new bishops.

title: Major Smallpox Epidemic Reported in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May. 12  A virulent smallpox epidemic of major proportions has broken out in Bangladesh, according to the health authorities in this transportation hub, a center of the rapidly spreading infection.

title: Harold Raynolds, Executive Of Reliance Paint, 77, Dies
description: Harold Raynolds, who retired in 1970 as a vice president of Reliance Paint. Company, died yesterday of cancer In Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 77.

title: Mother's Day: Rich Tradition in Hispanic Culture
description: Mrs. Maria Collazo won't have to cook dinner tomorrow, and a good thing, too.

title: TV: Mining the Crisis in Vietnam
description: Monday evening President Nixon made a speech. On the 11 P.M. edition of WABC TV's Eyewitness News, coanchorman Roger Grimsby announced that the nation's stomach shrunk to the size of a walnut tonight. If indeed so, there was also a noticeable swelling in the ambitions of broadcast Journalism.

title: U.S. AIDE IS HOPEFUL OF RED TRADE PACT
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12 Peter G. Peterson, the Secretary of Commerce, reported today that trade talks in Washington this week with the Soviet Union had moved the two Governments closer to a resolution of the issues.

title: Art. Kandipsky's Steadfast Aims
description: Unlike Mondrian, whose urge to abstraction finally brought him to the ultimate simplification, a painting reducedlike some idea in the mind of Godto a system of elementary grids and primarycolored planes, the great Russian. abstractioriiiir Vastly Kandinsky seemed bent upon introducing into the format of each canvas every imaginable abstract form  points, lines, ovals, squaresuntil the painting existed as a kind of marvelous improvisation, packed full of pictorial incident.

title: LAVER'S COMEBACK DEFEATS RIESSEN
description: DALLAS, May 12 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia overcame a twoset deficit to throttle Marty Riessen of the United States, 4.6, 46, 61, 62, 60, tonight to advance to the World Championship of Tennis finals.
