description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 13 (AP)Dale C. Hollern, a former official of tuberculosis associations in. Connecticut and Pennsylvania, has been named executive director of the Ohio Tuberculosis and Respiratory Disease Association. Dr. Hollis will assume the post July 1, succeeding John A. Louis, who has held the position since 1946.

title: Baptist Convention Decides Against Stand on Vietnam
description: DENVER, May 13 (AP)The American Baptist Convention, the first religious denomination to hold a national meeting since President Nixon's quarantine of North Vietnam harbors, decided today against taking any stand on the conflict in Southeast Asia.

title: HEAD OF SCHEME MISSING ON COAST
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 13More than 100 Akron area residents have invested with a Californiabased venture similar to the nowbankrupt investment scheme of Don Lowers, an Akron lawyer.

title: Black Leaders in Chicago Threaten Demonstra tions if Police Superintendent and Aides Aren't Removed
description: CHICAGO, May 13A group of Chicago's black leaders has threatened to organize massive street demonstrations this summer if Police Superintendent James Conlisk Jr. and his top assistants are not removed from office.

title: GOVERNOR OF OHIO GETS TV EXPOSURE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 13A few weeks ago, Hugh DeMoss, who is news director for WLWC here, slipped out of bed at 9 A.M., picked up his home telephone and, while still clad in his pajamas, taped al brief, unrehearsed television interview with Gov. John J. Gilligan.

title: Girl Scout Cleanup
description: Suffolk County Girl scouts will clean up litter on more than 60 miles of beaches next weekend to mark the 60th anniversary of Girl Scouting.

title: A Politician Apologizes
description: ATLANTA, May 13 (UPI)Gerry C. Dokka, 37 years old, has apologized to the public for being late in announcingl his candidacy for the United States Senate. He said he had been serving a twoyear probation term on a marijuana charge and had to wait until his civil rights were restored.

title: Dance: Royal Ballet's New Giselle
description: Of all the Royal Ballet's productions of the 19thcentury classics, its new staging of Giselle, given its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, is probably the best. Directed by the company's associate director, Peter Wright, it is much the same as the production Mr. Wright gave to the Stuttgart Ballet, which was seen in New York two years ago.

title: Art
description: RAPPING with angelsthe theological, not the theatrical, kindwas never a healthy practice. In the past, men or women foolish enough to admit conversing with such otherworldly visitors were usually denounced to the Inquisition and promptly dispatched to join their heavenly throngs. Joan of Arc, a notable example, was burned at the stake for discussing the future of France with the Archangels Michael and Gabriel. The Church, understandably, takes a cautious attitude toward those who carry their religious vocations too far.

title: Three Novels: Comic, Cute, Cool
description: The author of the following reviews has written a novel, Wolf, and three collections of poems of which the most recent is Outlyer.

title: The Nation
description: At 3 P.M. last Thursday, the Interior Department workers filling the lobby In Washington were informed that Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton would not be there in person to kick off the annual campaign to buy savings bonds. He had another meeting upstairs.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: DR. ARTHUR F. BURNS, Fed chairman, set out a 10point program for international monetary reform. Although other central bankers hailed it, Paul A. Volcker Immediately said, He is not speaking for the U. S. Government. He addressed American bankers in Montreal. A secret I.M.F. document on the same subject was reported to be circulating among embassies and finance ministries. The plan would not allow the U. S. to let dollars pile up abroad and would require the U. S. to devalue as needed.  PierrePaul Schweitzer of the I.M.F. said S.D.R.'s should play a greater role in the future system and gold and reserve currencies a lesser role. The gold price climbed to a postwar peak of $54 an ounce and the dollar weakened.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.Cast along the shore rather than out to sea, because the stripers will probably be on the edge of the dropoff, almost at our feet, I told my son Steve as we prepared to fish off Wasque Point.

title: Woman Enters Race Against Rooney
description: Mrs. Lydia Rivera, who has long been active in Puerto Rican and Democratic affairs in Brooklyn, has entered the primary contest for the 14th Congressional District seat held by John J. Rooney.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The wellreasoned May 1 article of your editorial writer Robert Bendiner, A Quota by Any Other Name , deserves to be read for the implications far and beyond the immediate subject matter. Although it deals primarily with the requirement that the respective state delegations to the Democratic National Convention reflect their state populations in terms of minority groups, women and young people, it points out clearly the kind of society we'are becoming.

title: The Taste Of Success
description: GEORGE McGOVERN was feeling good. He was slumped down on a sofa in his Senate office, his coat off, his tie pulled loose, his long legs stretched out, talking politics, fiddling with a long, thin, unlit Antonio y Cleopatra cigar. Now and then he put the cigar to his lips and tasted it, but what he was really tasting that afternoon was success. The glow of his Wisconsin victory was still on him, his Massachusetts victory was just ahead, encouraging reports were coming in from Pennsylvania and Ohio, the polls and the headlines were starting to look good, his bandwagon was finally rolling. I asked him if he thought he'd be the next President of the United States.

title: ARMY DEFEATS NAVY IN LACROSSE, 9 TO 8
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 13 Mike Griswold, a midfielder, fired a hard, bouncing shot into the net midway through the second overtime period today to give Army a 98 lacrosse victory over Navy.

title: Subversive Control Board Seeking a Budget Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The wad of the Subversive Activities Control Board says he needs $706,000 to expose revolutionaries in the coming year, a $256,000 budget increase:

title: LETTERS
description: I am a 50yearold woman going to work every day who would be happy to buy a simple, shortsleeved, nicely tailored dress, that would be comfortable and presentable in the office. I don't ask for blacks and dark blues. I like bright, pleasant colors and the new materials, especially those that are washable. I like prints, but not sailboats, stars, giraffes and elephants adorning my apparel.

title: Refugees in Saigon Living in Trucks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 11  Phan Dinh Nao and his wife, their four chilthen and their daughter's child live in a truck parked on Phan Thanh Gian Street, one of Saigon's busiest.

title: Northeastern Crew Wins Eastern Sprint in Upset
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 13  Northeastern's unheralded crew made up a onelength deficit on favored Harvard to win the Eastern sprint championships today on placid Lake Quinsigamond. The Huskies finished the 2,000meter course with a tremendous sprint to win a rowing title for the first time in a major upset.

title: MOLAR HAILED IN GUINEA RITES
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, May 13 National funeral ceremonies for former President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana opened here today in an atmosphere made festive by street dancing and artistic displays. Delegations from 40 coutries were present.

title: Many Children Under 5 Subject to Poisoning
description: PRINCETON  The New Jersey Hospital Association estimates that almost 100 children in the state under the age 5 are poisoned every day by consuming products containing harmful chemicals.

title: ROWE'S ANN SCORES IN Y.R.A. SPRING RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 13 Stuart B. Rowe Jr.'s Ann among the Internationals; Dr. George K. Brazil Jr.'s and Joseph F. O'Hora's Shields sloop, DoubleDare; and G. Tyner Corning with Gentlemen's Agreement in the 5.5mile Rhodes19 race were winners again today in the spring series for Yacht Racing Association OneDesign classes on Long Island Sound.

title: For Many Concerns: An Inadvertent 4Day Week
description: One of the best kept secrets in industry today, according to a manpower expert, Is the cost of absenteeism, low productivity, boredom on the job and frequent turnovers among employes.

title: A Very Local Tobago Bus 385 Stops an Afternoon
description: SCARBOROUGH, TobagoYou can keep your frozen daiquiris and rum punches. On this remote little Caribbean island, the refreshment at hot high noon is a SnoCone bought from a street vender and slurped on the spot. The man loads paper cone with shaved ice and drenches it with flavored syrup. Delicious. For a trifle extra, he frosts it with sweet evaporated milk. Elegant. You can get a SnoCone right outside the bus terminal here and carry it abroad for the big eventa bus ride on Tobago.

title: the traveler's world
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  The confluence in time and geography of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the interstate highway system Is bringing this corner of the Appalachian Mountain chain to the forefront as a holiday destination for travelers to the southeastern part of the United States. And the opening last October of Disney World at Orlando, Fla., 600 miles to the south, is already attracting a new crop of tourist families to the Chattanooga area, the almost geographical center of the sevenstate, 36lake power and recreational empire of T.V.A.

title: Pennsylvania Drops Residency Vote Bar
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 13 (AP)  Pennsylvania's top election officer has declared a ban on all voter residency requirements.

title: Home Improvement
description: ELIMINATING the need for bulky and expensive oxygen and acetylene tanks, and the accompanying high priced gauges and heavy hoses that must be used with conventional gas welding outfits, a new type of inexpensive and easily portable gas welding and brazing kit now on the market uses readily obtainable, disposable propane tanks for fuel (the same kind hardware stores sell for use with propane torches and camping equipment). Oxygen, needed to generate the temperatures required for welding and brazing, is supplied in solid form by means of special slowburning pellets in a tubular oxidizing chamber.

title: Princeton Gets $1Million From Mellon Foundation
description: PRINCETONThe Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has given $1million to Princeton University.

title: Art Mailbag
description: IDEMAND that this reply be printed on the same page as Mr. Canaday's personal attack on my character in The New York Times, April 23.

title: Onandaga, 331, Wins $59,000 Dixie, Key to Mint cores in Preakness Prep
description: BALTIMORE, May 13Onandaga, a 331 shot, won the $59,000 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico race course today, but Key to the Mint had most of the 14,088 fans talking of his chances against the Kentucky Derby winner, Riva Ridge, in next Saturday's $150,000added Preakness.

title: Text of AbortionBill Veto
description: ALBANY, May 13Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's message to the Legislature vetoing repeal of the state's liberalized abortion law:

title: WILLIAM DUVALL, 62, UTILITY LABOR AIDE
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md., May 13William G. Duvall, retired general labor relations director of the Western Electric Company, died yesterday at the age of 62.

title: Photography
description: THE Camera Club of New York, 37 East 60th Street is offering 10 different summer courses in photography, ranging from basic courses for beginners to advanced workshops for experienced photographers. Included are courses on color slides, portraiture, studio work, darkroom technique and photographic essays, and each will meet once a week for eight weeks (evenings, except for a field trip course that will meet Saturdays). All will cost $50 and starting dates vary from May 30 to June 5. Registration is going on now by writing to the club for course bulletin and application blank, or by visiting the club's office between 2 and 6 P.M. weekdays. The phone number is (212) 8389710.

title: A London Store Where Lefty Libbers Say Right On!
description: LONDONThere's something sinister about the growing number of individuals seen approaching the store. They walk down the left side of Regent Street (from Oxford Circus and toward Piccadilly) and turn sharply to the left up Beak Street in Soho. They stick to the left side of this narrow street, ignoring trendy Carnaby Street to the left and passing the Gallery Rendezvous (London's finest Chinese restaurant), before turning left into the tiny shopAnything LeftHanded, Ltd., an original and the only place in Europe where the customer is seldom right. Its clients, sharing an attribute with Leonardo da Vinci and Jack the Ripper, are lefties.

title: >TV Mailbag
description: I FOUND Maya Angelou's article (For Years, We Hated Ourselves, April 16) which refers to my Westinghouse Broadcasting series, Black African Heritage, both complimentary and disturbing. Since Miss Angelou is an outstanding and extremely articulate black American, her thoughts are particularly important.

title: Penn State Winds It Up
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 13 (AP)The firststring quarterback, John Hufnagel, ran for two touchdowns today to lead the White squad to a 3615 victory over the Blues in Penn State's final spring football scrimmage.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISSeventeen years ago, that hardy political perennial, Harold Stassen, headed President Eisenhower's Foreign Operations Administration and was worrying about Vietnam. He told me (Jan. 13, 1955):

title: WaitingSuittbakedfor the Pope
description: Handy hanky.

title: They're Full of Money Making SchemesAll for Art's Sake
description: LOS ANGELES  An employment agent was instructing Mexican domestics seeking work here and he told them, only half jokingly, that the most important telephone response they had to learn was: Madame is working at the art museum.

title: Linda MacBeth Is Wed
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., May 13 Miss Linda Jane MacBeth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. MacBeth of South Dartmouth, was married here this afternoon to Peter Sandison Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Crawford of Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Dr. George Hooten performed the ceremony in the Old North Congregational Church. The bride's father is president of Ashley Ford Sales in New Bedford. Mr. Crawford's father is president of the Southeastern Connecticut Broadcasting Company.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: The photograph above of a fresco in the Sanctuary of the Madonnone in Arezzo, Italy, was made in 1920. The fresco is shown below as it was in 1955. These and the other photographs on this page are taken from ART AND LANDSCAPE OF ITALY: TOO LATE TO BE SAVED? by Roberto Brambilla, with an introduction by Giorgio Bassani (illustrated, 144 pp. New York: Italian Art and Landscape Foundation Inc., 660 Madison Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10021. $6). The book powerfully demonstrates the results of years of abuse and neglect of Italy's artistic and natural treasures. The author contends that Italy's situation, in terms of problems, causes, responsibilities and the alternatives to preservation, could serve as a model to all countries that face accelerated growth and change. The book is an elaboration on the theme of the exhibition of the same title, currently on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through July 4. It will thereafter be presented in major museums throughout the United States and Canada.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, May 13  Lieut. Gov. Roger W. Jepsen withdrew today as a candidate for Governor.

title: Hard to Get There From Here Via Bus
description: HACKENSACK  A young woman from a midwestern city, who recently moved to Fair Lawn to teach art Bergen County Community College one mill away in Paramus did not have a car, and had to usepublic buses.

title: Problems Continue For Vega
description: DETROIT, May 13Whenever the engine of his car idles too fast, Michael A. Rajt knows what to do. He gets a hammer and delivers a few whacks at the accelerator linkage.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, May 13 (UPI)Representative Shirley Chisholm began the last weekend of campaigning for Tuesday's Presidential primary today with a series of short appearances in the Detroit area. At Kennedy Square in downtown Detroit, the Brooklyn Democrat told a crowd of about 500 that the Vietnam war was a war we can't win.

title: Clifton's Styertowne: A Place for Getting Things Done
description: CLIFTON  Four hundred seventy manufacturing companies provide 30,000 jobs In this Passaic County city. More than 85,000 people live here, and there are 1,000 stores. But Clifton has new er been a mecca for shoppers.

title: Squires Sign Twardzik
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 13 (AP)  Dave Twardzik, who established career scoring and assist records at Old Dominion University, signed a contract today with the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association. Officials of the club said that the 6footlinch guard signed a multiyear contract.

title: Judge, 89, to Retire
description: BOSTON, May 13 (AP)United States District Court Judge Francis J. W. Ford, at 89 one of the oldest active Federal judges in the nation, announced Wednesday he will retire July 1.

title: ARGENTINA FACES ECONOMIC CRISIS
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 13 The worst inflation Argentina has ever experienced is pushing the military Government of President Alejandro A. Lanusse to a difficult choice between shortrun popularity said financial responsibility.

title: Mr. Mag Rallies to Win By a Nose at Natragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. L; May 13 (AP)Mr. Mag rallied the last loneeighth of a mile today to win the $7,500 Mother's Day handicap at Narragansett Park lby a nose over Duke of Winloc.

title: Science
description: A miss is as good as a kilometer? Or would you believe: A gram of prevention is worth a kilogram of cure? So may speak the next generation of Americans.

title: A Few Words From O.J.
description: DETROIT, May 13 (AP)0. J. Simpson of the Buffalo Bills is to be principal speaker May 22 at the induction dinner of the Michigan Sports Hall of Fame.

title: TECHNOLOGICAL GAIN FOR ECOLOGY SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A newly published study by New York Marine equipment concern offers evidence that technological development need not conflict with a clean environment, according to the company's vice president for research, Henry M. Berler.

title: Japanese Assure Agnew Of Support on Vietnam
description: TOKYO, May 13Vice President Agnew was assured in talks here today with Premier Eisaku Sato and Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda that Japan would continue to support the United States position in Vietnam.

title: Mrs. Harold L. Ickes, Widow Of Roosevelt Aide, Dies at 59
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Mrs. Jane Dahlman Ickes, the widow of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior in the Roosevelt Administration, died in her sleep of heart failure Thursday evening. She was 59 years old.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: As an Exeter classmate and friend of Joyce Maynard read her article with particular interest. Her conclusion (As some people prepare for their old age, so I prepare for my 20's. A little house, a comfortable chair, peace and quiet  retirement sounds tempting) distresses me.

title: Late Yale Rally Defeats Harvard in Lacrosse, 75
description: NEW HAVEN, May 13Yale's lacrosse team rallied in the final period to defeat Harvard, 75, today.

title: Hearing Set on Challenge Over Chicago Delegates
description: CHICAGO, May 13 (UPI)The Democratic Party's Credentials Committee has agreed to hold hearings on challenges to the Chicago delegation that Mayor Richard J. Daley plans to lead at the party's national convention.

title: Village Elevation Urged
description: OMAHA, May 13 (UPI)The Army Corps of Engineers recommended today that the village of Niobrara, Neb., population 800, be moved to higher ground. Ground water floods basements in the community and damages buildings., The project would relocate 188 homes and 55 business establishments.

title: Chinese PingPong Players Vs. the Press: Love All
description: WHEN the Chinese PingPong players were welcomed last month to the United States at Detroit's Metropolitan Airport, the head of their delegation responded with a statement that was to become familiar to those who spent the next two weeks with them. We are going to learn from the American people and the, American players, said Chuang Tsetung, and there was no question in the minds of those few allowed to greet them at a remote Pan Am hangar at the airfield that this was a most diplomatic statement. Chuang is considered the greatest player of modern times, which in PingPong means of all timethe Chinese team ranks No. 1 in the world, the American team does not quite make the first 25, and the nervous State Department security men seemed intent from the first day on keeping the Chinese as far away from the American people as possible. Newspaper and television reporters already suspected that the first visit of the Communist Chinese to the United States was being turned into a dull event, and Chuang's tactful response seemed indicative of the politeness and formality under which the whole tour might proceed.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: Pleasant memories were brought back by the feature on sugarin off, When the Sap Runs in Vermont by Pat Orvis (Travel section, April 23). You see, I used to collect sap for the Elizabeth Chase maple candies in Lyndon, Vt. She ddin't have much candy volume, but oh the flavor! But shame on the writer for neglecting to mention that eggs boiled in the sap are a brand new experience. And what of the raised doughnuts and sour pickles to go with leather aprons (made by ladling boiling syrup onto snow, which gives you your maple product in crisp, tacky form)? By failing to mention these goodies, she's keeping a good thing from the uninitiated.

title: Mrs. Ruckgaber Is Wed to David M. Merrill
description: BROOKSIDE, N. J., May 13 Mrs. Penelope Schust Ruckgaber of Mendham was married here this morning to David Moore Merrill of Mendham Township by the Rev. Donald MacKenzie, a Congregational minister, at the Brookside Community Church.

title: Battle for Alaska
description: The decision of Secretary of the Interior Morton favor of the proposed oil pipeline across Alaska neither surprising in outcome nor convincing in argument. It was foreshadowed by the ninevolume impact statement produced by his department last montha study purporting to show that, while the project would involve grave environmental risks, the hazards were justified by the nation's economic and security needs.

title: Wing Out Takes Turf Race At Hawthorne, Pays $3.60,
description: CHICAGO, May 13 (AinWing Out, the oddson favorite, won the Sun Beau Handicap by nearly two lengths today before 18,358 patrons at Hawthorne Park.

title: Mayor Assails Albany on Judgeships
description: Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that he would refuse to put up city money to pay for eight new State Supreme Court justices whose positions were created by the State Legislature in its closing hours on Friday. He called on Governor Rockefeller to veto what he called a pork barrel deal by the Republican leadership.

title: OffDuty Policeman Kills Holdup Man in Brooklyn
description: James McGrath, an offduty patrolman, shot and killed one of two unidentified gunmen late Friday afternoon who he said attempted to hold up the Polonia Bar and Grill at 192 Nassau Avenue in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Fittipaldi Gains Pole Position
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 13Emerson Fittipaldi, the newest star in auto racing, won the pole position for the 30th Grand Prix de Monaco when it rained today, but he may not win the race if it rains, as forecast, tomorrow.

title: Estate Taxes Drive Farmers Off Land
description: Thousands of American farmers are being driven off their landsforced to sell their farms to real estate speculators, some of them say, because of the method used by the Internal Revenue Service to assess inheritance taxes.

title: CHINA IMPROVISES TO AID SCHOOLING
description: HONG KONG, May 13 China, which has not yet succeeded in providing primary schooling for all her children, as advocating the use of makeshift facilities to meet the urgent needs of certain rural areas.

title: 4 DEMOCRATS SEEK TO OPPOSE CASE
description: TRENTON, May 13  The Democratic senatorial primary campaign in New Jersey, which most party leaders regard as an exercise in political futility, has evolved in its final weeks into a classic confrontation between retormminded liberals and the oldline party regulars.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 13 (UPI)Vicente Zarazua and Joaquin LoyoMayo defeated Canada's Mike Belkin and Dale Power, 6.4, 60, 36, 63, in doubles today to give Mexico a 21 lead in the North American Zone Davis Cup tennis series. Mexico needs one victory in the two singles tomorrow to clinch the series and meet the United States next month.

title: He Was Direct, BY George
description: CRAFTSMANSHIP, high polish, and preference for sparseness were the hallmarks of George S. Kaufman's directorial technique. If an actor could cross the stage in four steps instead of 14, Kaufman would insist on the smaller number. If a laugh could be landed by the flick of a finger rather than a somersault, Kaufman's direction would demand the flicking finger.

title: Joyce Romano Married Here
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Cahtolic Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Joyce Marie Romano became the bride of Dr. Robert Michael Daly. Msgr. Marion Justin Reinhardt, Presiding Judge of the Diocesan Tribunal of Brooklyn, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Annual Meeting No. 290 for the Nation's Oldest Corporation
description: PERTH AMBOYThe General Board of Proprietors of the Eastern Division of New Jersey, the country's oldest corporation, will hold its 290th annual meeting on Tuesday at the company's headquarters on what was the capital square when Perth Amboy was the center of the government for the province of East New Jersey.

title: 3 Libraries Mail Books To Patrons
description: FAIR LAWNWhen a public library mails books to borrowers it seems like a luxury. But it is treated as a basic service by the three libraries in the state that do it, at Fair Lawn, River Vale and New Milford.

title: CARGO FOR NORTH
description: MOSCOW, May 13The Moscow radio said tonight that eight Soviet freighters were on their way from Black Sea ports, to Haiphong, the principal North Vietnamese harbor mined by the United States.

title: About Pro Football
description: Alex Webster, whose second season as coach of the Giants was a failure following a great success the, first time, has completed plans for the third. If the Giants were to begin the season next week, Randy Johnson would be the quarterback in place of the departed Fran Tarkenton; Ron Johnson and Charlie Evans the running backs with Bob Grim, the former Vik ing, Rich Houston and Bob Tucker the receivers.

title: Rugby Cup to St. Helens
description: LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) St. Helens beat Leeds, 1613, in the English Rugby League Cup Final at Wembley Stadium today. St. Helens led, 126, at halftime.

title: World Monetary Reform
description: Chairman Arthur F. Burns of the Federal Reserve Board believes that building a new and stronger world monetary system has become an urgent necessity. As in his Pepperdine College speech in December 1970, urging a national incomes policy to check inflation, Dr. Burns again appears to be prodding the Administration to move faster on a key economic issue. If efforts to rebuild the monetary system are long postponed, he warned an international bankers conference in Montreal, the world may split into restrictive, inwardlooking blocs.

title: Petain
description: The French Government recently declassified some early letters between Marshal Main and Col. Charles de Gaulle, one of the Marshal's ghostwriters between the wars. The two officers were quarreling about passages in a history of the French Army being prepared in Petain's name. De Gaulle had written that the French Revolution caused officers to suffer in their careers, their lives, their honor. Main changed the word order to careers, honor, lives. De Gaulle was adamant: career, life, honor, it is a progression. Main understood the stylistic point, of course; he simply believed in a different progression. For him, life was really more important than honor.

title: Henninger Foundation Elects Nine to Board
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 13 (AP) The Menninger Foundation Board of Trustees elected the following new members yesterday:

title: Mercer: Something Old, Something New.
description: New Jersey's Mercer County is almost a textbook example of the growing contrast between the old and new Americas.

title: No Big Layoff by City Seen Despite Major Budget Gap
description: There will be no massive layoffs of city employes despite a remaining budget gap of $540million, David A. Grossman, the city's Budget Director, said yesterday.

title: A limited future and a frozen pastsuch is the situation
description: Old age is different from the other woes of the world. Its existence is undeniable and its course irrevocable. Racism, poverty and war might lend themselves to a glorious extinction were it the will of society to turn its energy and thought in that direction. But old age is a sort of natural injustice; its cells are the very matter of life itself. It is a calamity, equitable in its relentless arrival to all who live long enough, but the poverty and pain of it are, of course, not impartially or justly spread about. Good luck, good health, certain prosperities of temperament and situation play a part  with the need for money looming over them all. The presence of money cannot always alleviate; its absence is a certain catastrophe. Everything positive that can be summoned is at best relatively helpful  a diminishment of suffering, a mitigation, a crutch that helps one to bear and to endure. There is no cure, no reversal, no hope.

title: Announcements 5000
description: Announcements 5000

title: Here's a Chance to Watch the Troops
description: TRENTON  The nation's military is holding open house, sort of, at several installations in New Jersey next Saturday to help celebrate Armed Forces Day.

title: BELL AND PRUZANSKY GAIN IN WRESTLING
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., May 13 Jerry Bell and Dave Pruzansky, members of the 1971 United States PanAmerican team, were among 16 wrestlers who qualified for the final Olympic team tryouts tonight at the Metropolitan Wrestling Association District Olympic Trials at Cantiague Park.

title: The Big Deal at Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L. I. Roosevelt Raceway coped with its annual invasion of bridge players on a recent weekend, and the crowds were bigger than ever. The average attendance at each of the six session of the Long Island regional championships ran over the 1,000 mark.

title: U.S. COURT HERE CUTS JURY CALL
description: Federal District Court in Manhattan, which last year paid nearly a million dollars to prospective jurors who never saw a trial, has begun to trim the excesses of what was officially termed the worst case of juror wastage in the Federal court system.

title: 50,000Man Draft Limit Announced for All of 72
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird announced today that no more than 50,000 men would be drafted this year.

title: 2 Crime Experts Differ on Prospect That Violence Will Decrease in U. S.
description: PHILADELPHIAWhat are the chances of violence decreasing in America?

title: Waste Treatment Plan Set For Delaware River Basin
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The Delaware River Basin Commission has agreed to develop a liquid waste treatment facility to clean up the water throughout the basin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning on Wallace Given
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 13 Harold Ostroff, the newly elected president of the Workmen's Circle, a Jewish fraternal organization, warned today that liberal and labor movements will reject even old political friends and allies if any attempt is made to wheel and dealwith George Wallace prior to or during the Miami Beach [Democratic] con vention.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I read Joyce Maynard's article with great enthusiasm. It was so unusual to be able to read an article that expressed my feelings so perfectly.

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 13Suat Hayri Urguplu, Turkey's Premierdesignate, named a coalition Cabinet today in an attempt to steer the country out of its political morass, but the proposed ministers were rejected by President Cevdet Sunay.

title: County Kerry to Play Gaelic AllStars Here
description: The County Kerry Gaelic football team, National League champion of Ireland, will play an allstar team from the New York area today at the annual Cardinal Cushing Charity games at Gaelic Park, 240th Street and Broadway.

title: Shows, Maytinie Tours and Plant Sales
description: HOUSE plants will have a show of their own this weekend at the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., 128 West 58th Street. Starting Friday and continuing through next Sunday, the local amateur plant societies will stage a major exhibit. There will be literature and plants for sale and experts to answer questions. The show will be open Friday from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Saturday and next Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. There is no admission charge. Among the societies to be represented are American Begonia Society, Indoor Light Gardening Society, African Violet Society, Bromeliad Society and the Men's Garden Club.

title: Come on, George, Get Fed Up
description: THOUGH George Suggs, an ebullient young man from the hinterlands, is warned upon his arrival in New York that he will have to develop a deviation if he expects to survive there (It's the lack of sunlight), he remains an apostle of metropolitan cheer to the end. One of the first streetphantoms he meets, in David Wiltse's Suggs at the Lincoln Center Forum, is a homed and helmeted fellow with a pikestaff who seems to have been crossbred by Thor and Lear. Suggs is enchanted. He's just part of the great diversity, he exclaims, going on to point out that in the big city a chap can occupy himself seven days a week with culture, can find creativity In the dreariest of jobs, can spend his nights if he likes with models for the yogurt ads whose legs begin at their necks.

title: New Novel
description: Secrets  secrets  They grow like fungi in Taylor Caldwell's jungle of a novel. Young Rory Armagh must never know that his robber baron father Joseph is secretly sabotaging his marriage. Joseph must never know that his wife drove their daughter Ann Marie out of her wits. I can't tell you, cries dashing Courtney Hennessey's mother. If could I would. But you must believe me.

title: The Center of an Ancient Trade Route, Herat Lives in the Ruins of Its Past
description: HERAT, AfghanistanHerat lies approximately in the center of the great ancient trade route between India and the Mediterranean, When Alexander the Great besieged and conquered the city more than 2,000 years ago, Its bazaars held the goods of Greece, Persia, Asia Minor, India and China. The bazaars still stock Chinese goods, but now they are matches and playing cards instead of silks. What was once an international souk, or marketplace, is now no more than the chief market for the northwestern part of Afghanistan, where villages, consisting of tiny clusters of mud huts, seem less common than the black tents of the nomads.

title: The bitter, bloody struggle for the City of Peace
description: By Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre. Illustrated. 637 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.

title: Wife of Textile Executive Found Slaini
description: The 43yearold wife of a New York textile executive was found dead of multiple stab wounds yesterday in the bed of her home at 205 Carroll Street in the Carroll Gardens district of Brooklyn.

title: WHITE SOX WIN, 93; MELTON HITS HOMER
description: CHICAGO, May 13 (UPI)Bill Melton and Dick Allen drove in three runs each tonight to help Stan Bahnsen to his first career victory over Baltimore as the Chicago White Sox handed the Orioles their sixth straight road loss, 93.

title: Laymen Sue to Save Catholic Orphanage
description: NEWARKA Roman Catholic lay organization has filed a civil suit against the Newark Archdiocese and the Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, the Archbishop of Newark, in an effort to preserve St. Peter's Orphanage.

title: Iowa's High Court Upholds Sum for Wounded Prowler
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, May 13 In a unanimous decision, the Iowa Supreme Court has ruled that Marvin Katko of Eddyville, a prowler who was wounded by a rigged trap gun in 1967, is entitled to damages.

title: NIXON SAID TO BAR TAX REFORM IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  A senior White House official said today that the Nixon Administration would not propose any major reforms in the individual and corporate income tax structure this year. But he added that President Nixon, if reelected, would ask for such reforms in his second term.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  An important idea is bubbling to the surface here. It is worth reporting, although if one's objective is a society with minimal inflation and steady growth of corporate profits, the idea, or conclusion, is altogether pessimistic.

title: The Duel
description: A welltold tale: The narrative is lively, dramatic, on the whole accurate. The Duel, which was long considered a duo, is recounted in detail (during the period from 1968 to 1970) like a cloakanddagger film starring Errol Flynn or Douglas Fairbanks Jr. All is included: scenes of passion and breakingoff, attacks, withdrawals, parries, counters and thrusts. One is often reminded of the relationship between d'Artagnan and the Cardinal de Richelieu in The Three Musketeers, or between Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler in Gone with the Wind. The reader is never bored, and learns in a pleasant manner, if

title: The Devil's Wind
description: NanaSahib, one of the leaders of the Indian Mutiny of 1857, gets a chance to tell his own story in a historical novel. According to the author, Nana should not be held responsible for the massacre of the British colony at Cawnpore: the true leader, he tells us, was a lavatory maid. Nana, reviled in encyclopedias and Anglo  Saxon history books as a monster, is depicted in these pages as a temperate rebel, whose moderation could not prevail in the general hysteria. (God knows my control over the Sepoys was never very firm.)

title: Busing Persists as Issue in Mt. Vernon
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 13Busing here is the issue that will not die.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: The 18yearold girl who wrote the article about looking back on life really did me a favor. This was an Article which I have always planned on writing, but I just never got around to doing it.

title: Life at the Opera With Madame Butterball
description: MY name is Martina Arroyo, said a tiny voice when I answered the phone in my Prague apartment in 1968. I'm a singer, and I'm here in Prague to sing Verdi at the National Theater. My press agent had your number, so I'd like to invite you and your wife to see Masked Ball, but if it's any kind of bother don't hesitate to say so. I know other people have schedules, too.

title: U.S. Aide for UNESCO
description: Dr. Martin, who was the author of 14 books on government, was a former president of the American Society for Public Administration and former member of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Texas Girls Run to Record
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 13 (AP)Comanche High School's 880yard relay team of Janet Brightman, Freeda Davis, Laura Spruill and Rhonda Lubke broke the girls national scholastic record today with a time of 1:42.9 In a track met against West Columbia and Gruver.

title: 8 Bangladesh Sailors Flee A Pakistani Ship in Detroit
description: DETROIT, May 13 (UPI)Eight Bangladesh seamen jumped their Pakistani ship today and were granted temporary asylum until they could be safely returned to their homes.

title: The Nation
description: DETROITMere is a seeming calm about the Democratic Presidential campaign, but forces were gathering last week for a final roundprobably decisive, possibly uglyas the primary course prepared to head west.

title: Carrier Nimitz Launched
description: NEWPORT NEWS, VA., May 13 (UPI)The nuclear carrier Chester W. Nimitz was launched today, with Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, proclaiming the $60.5million vessel the greatest ship in the world. About 4,000 persons watched the 95,000ton Nimitz, the nation's second nuclear carrier, slip into the James River at the Newport News shipbuilding yard.

title: Filion Drives 4 Winners, Including Majestic Jerry
description: FREEHOLD, N. J.; May 13Herve Filion, North America's leading driver, drove four winners at Freehold Raceway today, capped by a victory in the $15,000 R. Bruce Cornell Memorial invitation pace with Majestic Jerry.

title: Suddenly, There's a Champion in the Ring
description: JASON MILLER'S That Championship Season, now at the Newman Theater in the Public complex, is a fine play so superbly detailed in the writing, staging, and performing that you miss a gesture or an inflectionany gesture or inflectionat your own peril.

title: The World
description: ROMEIt took a full 24 hours after last Tuesday's election to get a clear picture of how Italy had voted in one of its most decisive electoral tests since the fall of Fascism. The computerized polling tally had proved far from successful.

title: PUBLIC CABLE TV URGED IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, May 13A committee of private citizens recommmended today after a yearlong study that any cable television system built in Detroit should be publicly owned and controlled.

title: DODGERS VICTORS OVER PHILLIES, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (UPI)Claude Osteen delivered a runscoring single in the fourth inning and, with ninthinning relief help from Jim Brewer, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight to a 31 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Transport of New Jersey announced yesterday that its buses were expected to be running on regular schedules tomorrow morning In North Jersey following a strike more than two months against the company throughout the state by the Amalgamated Transit Union.

title: Rangers in Good Shape
description: It was the final pep talk of the National Hockey League season for the Rangers yesterday. Individually, they walked into Coach Emile Francis's office for some parting words.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMTwo airport trucks carrying 18 men in the white overalls of El Al airline maintenance mechanics drove up to a Rule Sabena Belgian jetliner parked at the edge of the Lydda international airport outside Tel Aviv. For four or five minutes the mechanics milled around the Boeing 707, checking the tires and equipment. Suddenly they tore open the emergency exits above the wings and opened fire inside the crowded cabin Lie down! Lie down! It's okay! they shouted. Most of the dazed passengers and crew obeyed, but two men fired back.

title: SHOWDOWN DUE? OUTLOOK UNCLEAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A number of developments left it unclear today whether the Soviet Union had decided to test the sealing off of North Vietnam's harbors by the United States or whether, in fact, the Russians and Americans had reached an agreement on allowing the passage of supplies to the north.

title: Campers Getting Them to the Dog Show on Time
description: Fanciers are getting a lot fancier in the way they attend dog shows.

title: Gutierrez's Mature Style Puts Virtuosic Touch to Piano Debut
description: This season, Hunter College has been presenting a series of recitals by pianists who have won prizes In international competitions. On Friday night, in the Assembly Hall, it came to an end with a bang, in more ways than one. The performer was 24yearold Horacio Gutierrez. He was born in Havana and grew up in Los Angeles. He placed second in the prestigious Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow in 1970. There had been a good deal of favorable advance talk about him in musical circles.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Peterson Loses 6th as Yanks Bow, 62
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 14It's so hot, Fritz Peterson was saying of the 90degree weather, I'm going to melt like Frosty the Snowman.

title: Aid Utgeet for Studies of Soviet
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 14Two dozen senior, specialists on the Soviet Union cited today, an urgent need for more vigorous and systematic support for modern Russian and Soviet studies in the United States.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14Event No. 25, the program read, dream mile run, which goes to show the force of habit. A year ago the adjective was valid. A year ago it really was the sort of footrace that track and field buffs see flashing over the counterpane at 2 A.M. It was the perfect match, the first confrontation between Jim Ryun and Marty Liguori since the world recordholder began his comeback after an 18month sabbatical to learn how to lose, and on a raw and rainy Sunday it drew 22,000 customers to the International Freedom Games.

title: Incentive Program for Cubans Offers More Goods and Food
description: HAVANA, May 14 (Reuters) Cubans can now buy more food and consumer goods than at any time in the past few years as the Government moves to absorb excess money in circulation and create more incerxtive.

title: Mickey Mouse in ParkeBernet Debut
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14 Mickey Mouse, the 44yearold superstar whose name was the password for DDay in World War II, and his Disney cohort reached new heights of respectability today at Sotheby ParkeBernet auction house in Los Angeles when 170 lots of Disney memorabilia brought almost $15,000 from collectors.

title: 20 Years Later, Pyongyang ls Imposing
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 13The last time an American correspondent saw Pyongyang the city was a shellblasted ruin and the United States Army was heading south in something close to a rout under the. KoreanChinese offensive that had rolled down from the Yalu River in the late autumn of 1950.

title: Connecticut Legislature to Get 3 Bills to Restrict Abortions
description: HARTFORD, May 14The Connecticut General Assembly, summoned to a special session on Tuesday to write a new abortion law, will be asked to pass a tough new measure based on the right of the unborn to life and to equal treatment under the law.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: King Hussein of Jordan has recently come out with a proposal for the Solution of the Palestinian problem. This is one of many proposals put forward by deeply or remotely involved parties, and it remains striking that so far no proposal has been made public by the party most concerned  the Palestinian Arabs.

title: Mirjana Bajalovic Makes Solo Debut on Violin
description: Mirjana Bajalovlc, a Yugoslavian violinist who plays with the New Jersey Symphony and appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall a few months ago as a member of the Galliard Trio, returned there Saturday to make her solo debut. With Mimi Stern Wolfe at the piano, she gave the first New York performance of Fairy Tales by her countryman, Zoran Hristic, along with sonatas by Vivaldi, Mozart, Brahms and Prokofiev.

title: U.S. Aids Bangladesh Sailors Who Fled Pakistan Ship
description: DETROIT, May 14 (UPI)Eight Bangladesh seamen who jumped ship in Detroit rather than remain aboard a Pakistani freighter will be taken to New York tomorrow to be flown to their newly independent nation.

title: TV Impressed an Image
description: Dan Blocker was one of those actors whose career became inextricably wound with that of the character he was known for playing. To the millions who watched him each Sunday at 9 P.M., he was not Dan Blocker but Ole Hoss, the massive, kindhearted middle son in the Cartwright family whose clumsiness and gullibility constantly required the mediation of his father and brothers to get him out of trouble.

title: EUROBOND RALLY APPEARS SHAPING
description: BRUSSELS, May 14 The outlook for a solid rally on the Eurobond market is continuing to improve with new issues in all sectors favorably received and prices on the secondary market firm despite the money and stock market jitters following President Nixon's latest moves in Vietnam.

title: Cambodia Reports Battle
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 14 (UPI)Government troops fought a fierce battle with Communists today at Kirivong in the south of Cambodia, only four miles from the South Vietnamese border, a Government spokesman said.

title: WNET Plans to Simulate Plays In Fischer's Bid for Chess Title
description: Channel 13 is planning to carry a simulated playbyplay telecast of the world chess championship between Bobby Fischer of the United States and the present champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, May 14Michigan's Democratic party made an 11thhour effort this weekend to block a victory for Gov. George C. Wallace in the state's Presidential primary Tuesday.

title: Grechko and Sadat Confer
description: CAIRO, May 14 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat conferred with Marshal Grechko shortly after his arrival today to discuss military cooperation between Egypt and the Soviet Union, political sources said.

title: City Hall Notes
description: In a step toward humanizing the city's prisons, Correction Commissioner Benjamin A. Malcolm is about to permit marriage ceremonies within prison walls.

title: R. E. Brodsky Weds Miss Stone
description: Miss Margaret Ann Stone and Richard Eugene Brodsky were married here yesterday afternoon at the Harmonie Club by Rabbi Balfour Brickner, director of the Commission on Interfaith Activities of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

title: Churchmen Decry War Policy And Bombing of North Vietnam
description: Some of the nation's religious leaders have voiced grave concern over President Nixon's war policy in Southeast Asia and the bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Cleveland Strike Delayed
description: CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP)Strike action against Cleveland's two major daily newspapers will be delayed pending a meeting of teamsters union officials and management representatives Tuesday, a Federal mediator said today. Teamsters Local 473, which represents more than 600 newspaper delivery truck drivers, mechanics and garage helpers, voted 479 to 35 earlier in the day to strike the Plain Dealer and the Press. Their contract expired tonight.

title: Beame Is Drafting Plan to Avoid New Taxes but to Keep City Services at Budgeted Level by Borrowing
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame was working yesterday on a plan that he hopes will avoid new taxes yet keep Mayor Lindsay's budgeted level of services, according to sources in the budget negotiations.

title: Metropolitan to Set Up Wright interior
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced the purchase of Frank Lloyd Wright's Francis W. Little House, built between 1912 and 1915 in Wayzata, Minn., with the intention of installing the 55foot living room complete with original furnishings in the museum's enlarged American Wing. Plans for the expanded wing are in the study stage.

title: WOTTLEWINSMILE WITH RYUN NINTH
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14 The Jim Ryun mystery deepened in a cold drizzle today at Franklin Field, but tears of joy fell across the face of another champion, Mrs. Madeline Manning Jackson, during the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. International Freedom Games.

title: Suharto Ends Visit to Japan
description: TOKYO, May 14 (AP)President Suharto of Indonesia ended a fiveday visit to Japan today after reaching agreement with Premier Eisaku Sato on strengthening economic ties between the two countries.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. May 14 (UPI)Ed Sneed of Columbus, Ohio, shot an evenpar 72 for a fourround total of 282 today to win the $25,000 Maumelle Open satellite golf tournament.

title: Mays Homer Wins
description: Willie May, playing his first game as a Met, broke a tie with his 647th career home run in the fifth inning for a 54 victory over the San Francisco Giants at Shea Stadium before 35,505. Detsils on Page 47.

title: U.S. Test Planned For Frozen Foods Supplied by China
description: HONG KONG, May 14.An American food merchandising company will testmarket frozen products imported from China within the next year if they pass laboratory examination.

title: Rockefeller Vetoes
description: Rejecting an opportunity to ride a rising tide of conservative sentiment that swept along so many members of the State Legislature during its final weeks of deliberations, Governor Rockefeller has now vetoed three of that session's most backward measures. The passage of each by lawmakers in a state legislative election year reflects extraordinary efforts by highly articulate pressure groups. Strong support by members of his own party and an unusual letter from President Nixon in the case of one of the bills suggest the degree of conviction and independence the vetoes required.

title: Chavez Fasting to Protest Arizona Farm Labor Law
description: TOLLESON, Ariz., May 14 (AP)Cesar Chavez went into the third day of a fast today to protest the passage in Arizona of a farm labor law that is termed repressive by hisUnited Farm Workers Organizing Committee.

title: Judicial Caricature
description: The unanimous action by a threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals in overturning contemptofcourt sentences against the Chicago Seven and their lawyers and mandating a new trial before a new judge represents the first step in correcting a serious miscarriage of justice.

title: Jersey Meadows Project Held Basically Flawed
description: The proposed plan for urban development of the Jersey Meadowlands is basically flawed, and major changes are needed, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: Some Accept Sex at Home for Young
description: A changing concept of sexual morality, accepted as a matter of course by a number of teenagers, is presenting an emotional problem in more and more homes.

title: SAIGON LAUNCHES A COUNTERATTACK IN THE HUE AREA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 15South Vietnarnese troops, in their second counterattack of the weekend against Communist forces, pushed out from two points southwest of Hue yesterday in an effort to disrupt enemy preparations for an attack on the city.

title: STRIKES IN ITALY END LABOR TRUCE
description: ROME, May 14Italy is returning to normality of sorts this weekwith workers walking off their jobs.

title: Richard Schueller, Diplomat, Teacher, 101, Dies
description: Dr. Richard Schueller, a former Austrian statesman and educator, died yesterday in Washington at the age of 101. He lived in Washington, having moved there from New York three years ago.

title: Nets Play Game 4 Of Finals Tonight, 109th of Season
description: When Lou Carnesecca coached at St. John's University, the regular 26game schedule, often lengthened by as many as four postseason tournament games, appeared like a long season.

title: Soviet Signs Accord With Syria for More Arms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14The Soviet Union is to provide Syria with additional arms under an agreement signed in Damascus. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said the agreements were signed yesterday by the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, and the Syrian Defense Minister Maj. Gen. Mustafa Tlas.

title: Division on Vietnam Policy
description: DENVER, May 14  The American Baptist Convention ended its annual meeting here today without acting on two opposing statements on Vietnam that had prompted considerable debate.

title: EDWARD A. CANTER
description: Edward A. Canter, president and general manager of the Propper Manufacturing Company, Inc., surgical and scientific equipment, died Saturday night at his home, 10820 65th Road, Forest Hils. His age was 57. He received a B.S. degree from Rutgers in 1936 and an M.A. from New York University.

title: Dance Uptown Adds Zest to Program Ii With Creative Edge
description: Dance Uptown presented Program II of its 10th annual series Saturday night in and around the Minor Latham Playhouse on the Barnard College Campus. As in Program I, shown Friday, the evening combined the works of college connected choreographers and choreographers affiliated with independent companies.

title: Parade on Fifth Avenue Hails Israel's 24th Year
description: Tens of thousands of marchers, singers, dancers and stragglers, most of them children, paraded up Fifth Avenue in the rain yesterday to salute the 24th year of Israel's independence.

title: City Block. 85th St. Cherishes the Park
description: West 85th Street's entrance to Central Park was crowded.

title: Woye's Fludde Coming to Times Sq.
description: Some 1,000 children from New York City schools will participate in a performance of Benjamin Britten's Noye's Fludde (Noah's Flood) to be given in Times Square next Sunday at 2 P.M.

title: MAX R. LEPOFSKY
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 14 Max R. Lepofsky, senior partner in the law firm of Lepofsky & Lepofsky, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He lived on Appletree Lane. His age was 59.

title: Two Win Dance Awards
description: Judith Jamison, a leading dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and Anthony Dowell, a principal with Britain's Royal Ballet, will receive the annual Dance Magazine Awards today at the Regency Hotel.

title: Iraqi Communists Enter the Cabinet; First Since 1963
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14Two leaders of Iraq's Communist party were appointed to the Iraqi Cabinet in a reshuffle announced tonight.

title: Motorboat Race to Seebold
description: MORGAN CITY, La., May 14 (AP)Billy Seebold of St. Louis, averaging 75 miles an hour, won the Marathon of Champions outboard motorboats race today.

title: Johnson Gets Digitalis After 2d Attack to Enable Heart to Pump Enough Blood
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 13  Former President Lyndon B. Johnson has developed permanent congestive heart failure as a complication of recent attack, according to his physician.

title: Saigon Troops Advance to Within Half Mile of EnemyHeld Fire Base Bastogne
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 14 Government troops moved out from two points southwest of Hue today and by nightfall had advanced to within half a mile of Fire Base Bastogne, which fell to the enemy more than two weeks ago.

title: Money Manager Is Cautious About Market
description: I'm a fading bear on the stock market, says Paul F. Fenton Jr. In about a year, I hope to be an incipient bull. This conservative approach to current stock prices sums up the position of Mr. Fenton, Jr., the president of Studley, Shupert & Co., Inc., of Boston. The investment counseling firm manages approximately $500million in assets, including its three publicly held funds and investments for individual, pension and bank clients. Mr. Fenton, who also foresees the defeat of President Nixon in the November election, was interviewed last week in Boston by Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times staff. Portions of the interview follow:

title: Karen Hauck Is Bride Of William C. Frank
description: Miss Karen Marie Hauck was married May 6 to William Charles Frank. The Congregational ceremony took place in Hobart, Tasmania, where the bridegroom fishes commercially for abalone, scallops and giant crayfish. He and his wife are graduates of Washington College in Chestertown, Md., class of 70.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 29 editorial Scratch Judge Fusco was the most scandalous, illsupported argument that has ever appeared in print in your newspaper. Not one of the points you used as contentions against Judge Fusco was either valid or realistic.

title: Personal Finance
description: Women do have a more difficult time than men obtaining credit, if irate letters received by the National Commission on Consumer Finance are any indication.

title: Ford Denies It Suppressed Poor Tests of the Corvair
description: DETROIT, May 14 (AP)Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, today labeled as completely false charges by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that Ford had suppressed poor test results of a General Motors car, the Chevrolet Corvair.

title: False City Reports on Crime Suspected
description: An unusual police investigation has uncovered evidence that a small number of pieducts may have falsified their crime statistics by understating the robberies reported by the public.

title: Stock Industry Leaders Also Want to Retain Some Fixed Fees
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.An overwhelming majority of the leaders of the securities industry is opposed to free access to stock exchanges for institutional investors.

title: CHOPIN FILLS DEBUT OF POLISH PIANIST
description: Teresa Rutkowska, a Polish pianist who teaches at the Warsaw Conservatory, made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon playing a program of music by Chopin. It included the FantasieImpromptu in C sharp minor, Polonaise in F sharp minor and groups of Mazurkas, Waltzes and Preludes in addition to other works.

title: THERESA WOLFSON, TAUGHT ECONOMICS
description: Dr. Theresa Wolfson, who retired as a professor of economics and labor relations at Brooklyn College three years ago after 40 years on the faculty, died yesterday at her home, 810 East 19th Street, Brooklyn. She was 74 years old.

title: Chou Terms Mining of Harkors A Serious StepUp of the War
description: PEKING, May 14 (Agence FrancePresse) Premier Chou Enlai today described the mining of North Vietnam's ports as a serious stepup of the war by the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 13 editorial Miserly Re ward is grossly inaccurate in claiming that the presentday G.I. Bill constitutes a niggardly hand out compared with the full funding of college studies under the World War II. G.I. Bill and that educational benefits have been reduced.

title: Unser's 195 M.P.H. Sets Indy500 Qualifying Mark
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 14Bobby Unser blazed a spectacular qualifying record today for the Indianapolis 500, covering the required 10 miles at an average speed of 195.940 miles an hour. Unser, who won the 500 in 1968, ran 17.244 m.p.h. faster than the previous qualifying record of 178.696, set last year by Peter Revson.

title: Moscow's Summit Stakes
description: The Soviet economy passed a historic milestone in the first quarter of this year. By increasing passenger car output 47 per cent, the Soviet Union for the first time in its history produced more automobiles than trucks. This is welcome news for millions of Moscow's eager wouldbe car owners.

title: SUIT AIMS TO FORCE TROOP WITHDRAWAL
description: ST. LOUIS, May 14 Two wellknown St. Louis residents and an antiwar veterans group have taken legal action aimed to forc'e the United States to set a date for withdrawing all military forces from Indochina.

title: THOUSANDS IN GUINEA VIEW NKRUMAH RITES
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, May 14Tens of thousands of Guineans paid final homage today to former President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.

title: The. Proceedings in the U.N. Today
Advertising:
description: Don Hanrahan, the big man from Oui, breezed in from Chicago last week to scout the town.

title: BELTOISE TAKES RACE IN MONACO
description: MONTE CARLO, May 1JeanPierre Beltoise, who has had more than his share of rain in his life, drove brilliantly in the rain today to win the slowest Grand Prix of Monaco in 20 years.

title: Credit Markets
description: Financial markets seldom lend themselves to confident shortterm prediction, but the current outlook for the credit markets seems even more puzzling than usual. A number of powerful forces are playing on interest rates in a way that has produced relative equilibrium in re cent weeks and nobody can know which will gain the upper hand to push them strongly one way or the other.

title: GATT Negotiators Trim Trade Barriers
description: GENEVA, May 14  In the headquarters of the Secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, there is compilation a foot thick of the world's nontariff barriers.

title: OKINAWA ISLANDS RETURNED BY U.S. TO JAPANESE RULE
description: TOKYO, Monday, May 15The return of Okinawa to Japan after 27 years of American rule was celebrated at colorful ceremonies here this morning and hailed as marking a new phase in the friendly relations between Japan and the United States.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BANGALORE, India, May 14 (UPI)The Eastern Zone Davis Cup final between India and Australia was postponed for the third successive day today be cause of rain. Officials hoped to open the series tomorrow on clay courts.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NARASHINO, Japan, May 14 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa shot a twounderpar 70 today for a 72hole total of 280 and a onestroke victory in the $30,000 Japan Airlines international gold tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was amused by the petulant and churlish Who Needs West Point? (OpEd, April 29). It is innuendo and allegation, and not fact and deduction. Perhaps we don't need West Point. Perhaps General Donaldson is guilty. Perhaps West Pointers are a favored clique. But give, us hard evidence responsibly developed, not bitterness and jeremiads. Passionate allegations do not make a Q.E.D. They can only increase the stature of the institution so foolishly pilloried.

title: U.S. Gilt to Poland Honoring Copernicus Planned
description: WARSAW, May 14American scientists are preparing to give Poland a big gift to mark the celebration next year of the 500th anniversary of the birth of Nicolaus Copernicus. It is a $1,000,000 astronomical research center.

title: MOORE SHOWS FLAIR AND POLISH ON CELLO
description: Kermit Moore is an ardent proponent of contemporary music for his instrument, the cello, and his Tully Hall recital yesterday afternoon once again concentrated exclusively on 20thcentury works. Although not as uncompromisingly avantgarde as in the past, the program was a stimulating one, played with stylistic flair and technical polish.

title: Chinese Civil Jet Flight
description: TOKYO, May 14 (AP)The Kyodo news agency reported today from Peking that the first civil jet flight in China was made yesterday when a Chinese crew piloted a Sovietmade IL62 jetliner, with passengers aboard, on a round trip between Peking and Canton.

title: JACOB ZOCKS
description: Jacob Zocks, a cofounder and president of Plaza Beverage Company, Inc., manufacturer of Mission and Plaza beverages, died Friday at Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. His age was 74. He lived at 95.21 68th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: British Rails Are Shut Pending Union Decision
description: LONDON, May 14 (AP)Britain's railroads remained shut down by their Government today while lawyers argued whether 300,000 workers should be asked to vote on accepting a pay offer. No trains ran in any part of the country. Services were due to resume tomorrow morning, but were certain to be crippled by a goslow action ordered by three railroad unions.

title: Ships at Haiphong Unloading Unmolested, U. S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Administration officials said today that Soviet and other vessels in Haiphong harbor were completing their unloadingapparently without molestation by United States aircraft or warships in the area.

title: 51 NEW STOCK ISSUES SET RECORD ON AMEX
description: Governors of the American Stock Exchange approved record listing of 51 new stock issues in the first quarter of 1972.

title: Wright rouse Sold
description: The Metropolitan Museum of. Art has purchased Frank Lloyd Wright's Francis W. Little House, built between 1912 and 1915 in Wayzata, Minn. The 55foot living room with its original furnishings will be installed in the museum's enlarged American Wing. Details, Page 42.

title: Albany Regresses
description: The specter of a holdtheline state budget hovered over much of the floor debate at Albanythere was no money for new programsand this was essentially a noneconomic session of the State Legislature, probably more so than in, any recent year. The reason for this was that a special session at the end of last year worked out a compromise tax package which fixed levels of state spending.

title: S.I.P.C. Tells Congress of Improving Plans to Protect Investors
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Securities Investor Protection Corporation warned today that it is going to be some time before it can develop the most efficient possible liquidation procedures for failed brokerage firms, before it can recommend detailed new rules for preventing such failures and before it can move to system of variable insurance assessments for different types of brokers.

title: Reshevsky, Kavalek and Byrne Tie in National Chess Tourney
description: Three players tied for first place as the 21st annual national chess tournament ended last night at the Group Health Insurance, Inc., building, 230 West 41st Street. Those in the tie were Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., Lubomir Kavalek of Washington and Robert Byrne of Ossining, N.Y., all with 85.

title: ATHENS DEBATES U. S, NAVY PORTS
description: ATHENS, May 14The general in charge of Greece's military forces welcomed today plans for permanent home ports for American warships near Athens, and dismissed suggestions that the presence of United States Navy families here might raise social problems.

title: Local School Boards Accused By Shanker of Job Patronage
description: The president of the United Federation of Teachers charged yesterday that the city's decentralized school boards had appointed about 2,500 people to jobs for which they were either unqualified or that were created for them.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Large numbers of uncommitted delegates to the Democratic National Convention were selected yesterday in three states, and a territory, reflecting the unwillingness of many party members to state a Presidential preference until the contest has been clarified.

title: Brownlee Group Stages Henze Opera
description: With the first New York performances of Hans Werner Henze's Boulevard Solitude Saturday night and yesterday afternoon, the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music proved beyond all doubt that it is one of the major components of the operatic, life of this city.

title: Screen: Program by New Filmmakers
description: The New Films by New Filmmakers program that opened Friday night at the Film Forum features the work of Curt McDowell, a San Franciscan, whose Wieners & Buns Musical and Pornogra Follies dominate the program. As the titles suggest, Mr. McDowell belongs to the entertainment rather than the explorationofinner, reality wing of independent cinema production. But as the titles may also suggest, he offers entertainment of a somewhat unusual order.

title: New Thieu Power Endorsed by House
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 14The lower house of the National Assembly approved a bill this evening granting President Nguyen Van Thieu the right to rule by decree, subject to approval of each decree by the Assembly.

title: Nixon Leaves Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after a weekend at Camp David, Md.

title: 2 MICHIGAN RIVALS WAVER ON BUSING
description: DETROIT, May 14Senator George McGovern of South Dakota joined Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, his main rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, today in wavering on the question of busing children to achieve a racial balance in the public schools.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDONThe moral basis for the exercise of power in a democracy is a complicated business. Ambition and principle are so often confused. But the premise of allowing a man to hold power is at least that he remain conscious of its sources, its purpose and its limits.

title: N. Y. A. C. OARSMEN TAKE 6 OF 7 RACES
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 14  The New York Athletic Club won six of seven events in the Father Knickerbocker regatta on Orchard Beach Lagoon today, including a fivelength triumph over New York State Maritime in the race for lightweight fours with coxswain at 2,000 meters.

title: Signs of War Everywhere In North Vietnam Capital
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 14At 1:30 this afternoon antiaircraft guns were heard. Seconds later the sirens sounded over Hanoi.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Catholic Forensic Winner
description: PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP)Marquette High School of Milwaukee captured top honors yesterday for the third consecutive year in the National Catholic Forensic League debate tournament. Spellman High School and St. Joseph Hill Academy, both of New York, were runnersup.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: An 'allibd official in Vietnam, after viewing from a helicopter the results of our recent B52 raids is quoted (news story May 6) as follows:

title: Sophie M. Sides Becomes Bride Of D. F. Cowan
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 14Miss Sophie Meredith Sides was married here this afternoon to Douglas Fairman Cowan, an alumnus of Phillips Academy at Andover where the bride's father is director of admissions. The bridegroom expects to graduate next month from Harvard Medical School.

title: CampbePilithan Picks Chairman and President
description: Stan Blunt has been named chairman, and George Gruenweld, president, of CampbellMithun, the country's twentysixth largest ad agency, and Minneapolis biggest.

title: Aid and Comfort for the Democrats
description: WASHINGTONI have long been involved in some of our country's seamier activitiesduring my years in Washington, I have been a journalist, a soldier, a Federal bureaucrat and mercenary for the Democratic party.

title: Miss Kim, Soprano, Sings Varied Fare.
description: For her Town Hall concert Saturday, Suk Soon Kim, a young Korean soprano, chose a delightfully varied program of songs, imaginatively interspersing the familiar with the unusual. While her voice has some rather severe limitations  a weak low register and a slightly reedy tone that tends to thin out dangerously in midrange  she handled all the material with intelligence and musical awareness.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI)  The Democratic Platform Committee starts its work tomorrow, with most of its members not chosen and with a deadline that would give convention delegates a chance to study the party platform thoroughly before adopting it.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 14Steve Ross and Louise Gonnerman, the topseeded players, moved into the quarterfinals of the Westchester tennis tournament today. Ross, seeking his third straight title, defeated Ray Clas, 60, 63, and Miss Gonnerman, also defending her title, ousted Sabina Haskins, 62, 61.

title: Princeton Upsets Radcliffe To Win, Women's Regatta
description: OLD LYME, Conn., May 14 The first women's crew in Princeton's history won the second annual New England intercollegiate women's regatta on Rogers Lake today. The Princeton athletes, six of them freshmen, upset Radcliffe College, to whom they had lost a previous race by four seconds, in winning by a little under a boat length. Their time for the 1,000meter course was 3 minutes 34.9 seconds.

title: 110 in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, India May 14 (AP)This capital had its hottest day in five years today when the mercury rose to more than 110 degrees.

title: 2Year High Is Set
description: The firming trend in the aluminum industry continued last week, according to figures released by the National Association of Aluminum Distributors and the Aluminum Association.

title: Fund Helps Commuters
description: The working commuter benefits from the United Fund of. Greater New York's currentcity are helped by the fund's affiliated agencies. Here are some of the ways the commuter and his family use these services:

title: Red Team Wins, 119 to 113, In Black AllStar Game
description: ALBANY, May 14  Ron Smith of Newburgh High School scared 26 points to lead the Red team to a 119113 victory over the Green team yesterday in the first Black AllStar Basketball Classic in the State University of New York gymnasium.

title: 4 IN HEWS ANGELS HELD IN BEATINGS
description: Two boiler mechanics were severely beaten on the Lower East Side yesterday in an alleged attack by Hell's Angels who wielded bludgeons, blackjacks, wrenches and gun butts and unleashed two German shepherd attack dogs.

title: Turkish ExAide Elected By Party to Succeed Inonu
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 14 Bulent Ecevit, a former journalist and cabinet minister, today was elected leader of Turkey's oldest and second largest political organization, the Republican People's party.

title: Excess C Rations Aid the Elderly
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 12 I've ate em before, back there in the Army, when they wasn't as good as now, and I'm still grateful, to get em, Elza Barnett said.

title: Okinawa's Reversion
description: Few colonial renunciations in history have been wholly voluntary or altruistic, not even the celebrated American grant of independence to the Philippines, which owed much to the sugar lobby's interest in imposing tight quotas on Philippine shipments. Nevertheless, at this moment of bad conscience over Vietnam, Americans are entitled to take some pride in the enlightened selfinterest that has brought about the return of Okinawa to Japan.

title: Tugboats Teamwork Sends Liner on Way
description: It was 3:45 P.M. and the sweep of the wheelhouse windows on the tug Patricia Moran were filled with two thingsthe knifeedged bow of the S.S. France 15 feet away and the crowd of 100 or so people jammed together outside Pier 84, North River at 44th Street.

title: Rosewall Topples Layer In $50,000 Tennis Final
description: DALLAS, May 14 (AP)Ken Rosewall captured a dramatic, fifthset tiebreaker and won a marathon match today to successfully defend his World Championship Tennis crown against Rod Laver, the man he beat in last year's final.

title: Roundup: Chambliss Hit Wins for Indians in 10th
description: Chris Chambliss's short baseball career has been wrapped in success stories to which he added another chapter yesterday.

title: Summary of Actions Taken in 1972 Legislative Session
