description: WARWICK, R. I., May 17An organized group of union officers and high school students at the airport here was the only large crowd that greeted Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today in the first resumption of campaigning since Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was shot.

title: 12 TV Channels to Show Regional Plan Dialogues
description: An ambitious plan to involve millions of people in the metropolitan area in a twoway dialogue on major regional development issues was announced yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

title: LICHARDUS TAKES DODGE OPEN LEAD
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 17 A twotime winner, Babe Lichardus of Shackamaxon, broke out of a threeway tie for the, lead today with a secondround 72 and a 36hole total of 140 in the ninth annual $25,000 Dodge Dealers open.

title: McLain Reporting Today To Farm Club, A's Say
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 17 (UPI)In a 10word statement, the Oakland Athletics announced today that Denny McLain would report to their Birmingham farm club in the Southern Association tomorrow.

title: EXAIDE OF LANSKY IS GUILTY IN SLAYING
description: A 70yearold man, identified by authoritiei as a former bodyguard of Meyer Lansky, the underworld figure, pleaded guilty in State Supretne Court yesterday in Queens to firstdegree mahslaughter in the shooting death Jan. 7 of the president of an association of independent unions.

title: Jury Hears Two Witnesses
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (UPI)A Federal grand jury investigating the Penn Central collapse called its first two witnesses today, one of whom explained the corporate intricacies involved in the 1968 merger of tilt:. Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.

title: 2 Papers Publish Jointly As Ohio Strike Shuts One
description: CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP)  The Cleveland Press published its first edition today with a double nrneplate identifying it as The Cleveland Press and The, Plain Dealer after the latter failed to publish because of a strike by Teamsters Union Local 473.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The undersigned, members of the faculty and other officers of instruction of the School of Law of Columbia University, enthusiastically support the candidacy of Judge Nanette Dembitz of the Family Court of New York for the Democratic nomination to one of the three vacancies on the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: 3 Democrats Endorse a Woman Judge for State Court of Appeals
description: Three leading Democrats endorsed Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz yesterday, in her effort to become the first woman to sit on the State Court of Appeals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A very important case, Rosario v. Rockefeller, is now pending before the Supreme Court of the United States. At issue is the validity of Section 186 of the New York Election Law. This restrictive law prohibits young voters and others not registered on Oct. 2, 1971, from voting in the June 20 New York Presidential primary. In New York City alone, of the approximate 385,000 eligible voters between the ages of 18 and 21, only 127,400 registered to vote before Oct. 2, 1971, leaving 257,600 ineligible to vote in the June primary.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Crippling the U.N.
description: By doing at once what a Presidential commission had suggested be spaced over a period of years, the House Appropriations Committee has dealt a potentially crippling blow to the United Nations and to this country's position in the international community.

title: Connally Cancels His Trip To Paris
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (Retiters)John B. Connally, who resigned yesterday as Secretary of the Treasury, has decided to cancel his trip to Paris for monetary and trade talks next week with leading financial officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Deg velopment, the Treasury said today. It gave no reason for his decition.

title: Welcomed in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, May 17The West German Bundestag's ratification of the 1970 Moscow and Warsaw treaties was welcomed here today.

title: DOWNTOWN PLAN GAINS APPROVAL
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday evening approved the $1.2billion Manhattan Landing development project, which would provide a massive complex of apartments and commercial facilities on platforms above the East River bordering Lower Manhattan.

title: Medical Society Asks Methadone Curbs
description: A committee, of the Medical Society of the County of, New York has adopted a resolution calling on officials of methdonemaintenancd programi in the city to terminate takehome privileges, for addictpatients and administer the drug exclusively in clinics to arrest the spread of the methadone black Market.

title: The Wallace Factor
description: Much more than a floodtide of sympathy over the despicable attempt on his life went into the victories scored by George C. Wallace in this week's two key Democratic primaries.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP) The rechecking of May 2 primary election ballots from scattered Cleveland wards ended yesterday with only minimal changes In the Cuyahoga County Election Board's earlier tabulation.

title: Cenco Plans Name Change
description: Stockholders of the Cenco Instruments Corporation, at their annual meeting in September, will vote on increasing the authorized common stock to 25 million from 15 million shares and on changing the company's name to Cenoo, Inc.

title: Case of Deja Vu Ends With the Arrest of a Fifth Avenue Art Dealer
description: Posing as polished art lovers, detectives arrested a Manhattan art dealer yesterday and seized seven paintings that they said he had falsely labeled as valuable works of the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: PURCHASING GROUP SEES BUSINESS GAIN
description: The present rate of business improvement will continue throughout the year, but there is no boom in sight, the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc., reported yesterday.

title: Mediation for Nathari's
description: Michael Wolpert, of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday that he had arranged a mediation session for today in the strike.at six restaurants of Nathan's Famous, Inc. The employes went on strike April 5 for higher wages and other contract improvements.

title: 4 Women Riders Fail to Win at Belmont
description: The women's jockey colony at New York's metropolitan thoroughbred tracks continues to grow. Four women turned up for riding appointments at Belmont Park yesterday, a record for a single program. The previous mark was three.

title: Soviet Hints U.S. War Moves Foster MoscowPeking Cooperation,
description: MOSCOW, May 17With the visit of President Nixon only five clays off, the Soviet media are conveying the impression that the American mining of Haiphong have fostered new collaboration between the Soviet Union and China.

title: NIXON WILL STRESS BUSINESS ON TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The White House today released a rough outline of President Nixon's trip to Moscow. It indicated that his visit would emphasize official business at the expense of ceremony.

title: Baseball Attendance Is Steady Despite Strike
description: If attendance figures are taken as, a reflection of fan Interest, the players strike had no discernible effect on Public responsiveness to major league baseball, according to statistics for the first four weeks of the season.

title: AILING NICKLAUS OUT OF MEMPHIS EVENT
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 17 (AP)  Jack Nicklaus, the leading moneyearner and only threetime winner on the pea golf tour this season, withdrew from the $175,000 Danny ThomasMemphis open tournament today.

title: Fairchild Camera Prospectus Shows an I.R.S. Claim for Taxes
description: Fairchild Camera & Instrument Corporation in a prospectus filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 750,000 shares of its common stock, disclosed that the Internal Revenue Service maintains the company owes $23million in additional Federal income taxes for the years 19641969.

title: Navy Weighs Sending Battleship to Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 17,(Reuters)The United States is considering recommissioning the 58,000ton battleship New Jersey and sending it to Indochina to take part in the United States action off Vietnam, the Defense Department indicated tonight.

title: PREAKNESS BETS TO BEGIN TODAY
description: Offtrack betting's Preakness Special opens today, and assorted touts repdrtedly are urging Mayor Lindsay to parlay his Kentucky Derby winnings onto Riva Ridge.

title: Deficit First in 2 Years
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., reported yesterday its first quarterly loss in two years.

title: Chief Sttrgeon in the Wallace Case Joseph Francis Schanno
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 It was undoubtedly the most unusual and dramatic postoperative procedure that Dr. Joseph F. Schanno had ever been through.

title: TV: The 40's Examines Hollywood
description: Tonight, at 8:30, Playhouse New York's current series on The 40s continues with Hollywood  You Must Remember This. With Victoria Hochberg as producer and Richard Shickel, the film critic, as writer and associate producer, the 90minute program examines the art and industry of American films during the decade that was dominated by the production of World War II.

title: BODY OF CHINESE UNCLAIMED HERE
description: The body of a 26yearold member of the Chinese mission to the United Nations who died suddenly more than three months ago is still in the city morgue.

title: VALENTI URGES SHIFT ON CATV COPYRIGHT
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, called on Congress today to pass a, new copyright law that will provide an independent, objective tribunal to determine fair payment for use of copyright works, including movies, on cable television.

title: A TheaterArts Program Urged For Columbia Undergraduates
description: A special Columbia University committee on the arts has recommended the setting up of a new theaterarts program for undergraduates, in a report submitted yesterday to Dr. William S. McGill, president of Columbia.

title: 3Month Rise in Sales
description: The Unilever group of companies reported yesterday that their consolidated earnings in the first quarter of 1972 were 18 per cent higher than in the yearearlier period, on a sales gain of 13 per cent.

title: Nationalists Ask Chiang To Name Son Premier
description: TAPIEI, Taiwan, May 17The standing committee of the Central Committee of the ruling Nationalist party today voted to urge President Chiang Kaishek to appoint his elder son, Chiang Chingkuo, to the Premiership.

title: Civil Rights Panel Says Busing Foes Oppose Integration
description: ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) School busing is a legitimate method of desegregating schools, and people who oppose busing oppose school desegregation, said a report issued today by the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Home Medica Guide Distributed by Ginzburg Called Out of Date
description: A home guide, dated 1971 and offered as a bonus to advertisers to Ralph Ginzburg's consumer newsletter Moneysworth, was actually written in Germany, at least 20 years ago, a search of records has revealed.

title: General Walker Continues Prayer Vigil for Wallace
description: DALLAS, May 17 (UPI)Former Maj. Gen. Edwin. A. Walker continued his prayer vigil for Gov. George C. Wallace for the third day today but he has apparently ended his conflict with the city's curfew laws.

title: Foe Attacks Laotian Town
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 17 (UPI)  Communist forces opened an attack before dawn today on Khong Sedone, a provincial capital northwest of the Boloven Plateau in southern Laos, wellinformed Laotians and American sources said.

title: Mayor, in Compromise Move, Names A Lawyer to Study Forest Hills Plan
description: Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday toward a compromise on the controversial lowincome housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, by naming Mario R. Cuomo, a lawyer, to make an independent exploration of possible revisions in the development now under construction.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The loose, unbuttoned cardigan jacket by Saint Laurent out of Chanel is everybody's favorite wrapup theme for fall. Several designers combine it with the monotone look which pulls together the multitudinous parts that make up the newest fashions.

title: 12 Killed in Sao Paulo Crash
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 17 (Reuters)  Twelve persons were killed and fifty injured tonight when a crowded suburban train ploughed into a heavy tractortrailer truck stuck on a rail intersection, the police reported.

title: Peru Sharply Restricts Broadcast Programing and Advertising
description: LIMA, Peru, May 17  The Peruvian military Government decreed nevi standards today to restrict television and radio programing and advertising. The decrees say that all progrants broadcast must reflect human values and be sodaily useful.

title: Wager, L.I. Democrat, Links Kremer to G.O.P.
description: MINEOLA, May 17 Assemblyman Ell Wager charged today that the Republicans were openly supporting his Democratic primary opponent, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, in Nassau County's new 20th Assembly District.

title: Dartmouth Sets Up Panel On Investment Relations
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 17 (AP)The president of Dartmouth College, John Kemeny, said today that a committee had been set up by the school to advise the trustees on relations with corporations that might have possible adverse impact on desirable social goals.

title: Notes on People
description: To head a newly created Government watchdog committee to prevent bureaucrats from overzealously using, secrecy stamps, President Nixon named John S. D. Eisenhower.

title: ExChairman of Pennsy Disputes I.C.C. Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Stuart T. Saunders, the former chairman of the Penn Central Transportation Company, said today that the causes of the railroad's financial failure involved problems not of mismanagement, but problems which were unmanageable.

title: PRATT STUDENTS END 8DAY OCCUPATION
description: An eightday occupation of the Student Center at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn by black and Puerto Rican students ended last night after the school's administration and trustees agreed to either implement or investigate the protesters nine demands.

title: Meeting on City Budget Gap Produces No New Ideas
description: Mayor Lindsay offered no new proposals to bridge the city's $540million budget gap during a 90minute session last night at Gracie Mansion with the Board of Estimate and Council leaders.

title: LEE MICHAELS SINGS AT ELECTRIC ORGAN
description: Lee Michaels is a singerkeyboard player whose special conceit is that he performs accompkilied only by his own electric organ playing and a drummer. At Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, One was less impressed by the selfconscious pretensions of Mr. Michaels's tour de force than by the fact that he was able to get so much sound and so little music out of the extensive resources of the two instruments.

title: A.B.A. UNIT URGES FEWER ARRESTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) An American Bar Association committee recommends in a report released today that police departments make far fewer arrests and hire legal advisers to help shape lawenforcement policy.

title: Pact Reached to Sell Boston Herald Traveler to Hearst Chain for
description: BOSTON, May 17An agreement in principle for the sale of The Boston Herald Traveler, for decades the voice of Boston's Republican establishment, to the Hearst newspaper chain was reached here today.

title: REV. R. J. CHARPENTIER
description: KINGS PARK, May 17The Rev. Robert J. Charpentier, pastor emeritus of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, which he served from 1950 to 1969, died yesterday of a heart attack in Whitehall, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: New York Life Picks New Chief Executive
description: R. Manning Brown Jr., $175,000ayear president of the New York Life Insurance Company, the nation's fourth largest life insurer, was elected yesterday to become chairman and chief executive officer.

title: F. W. Woolworth
description: ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 17 (AP) The sales impetus of F. W. Woolworth for the first four months of 1972 was exceptionally strong and the company is exceeding its projected 10 per cent increase over last year, the company's chairman and chief executive officer said today.

title: Cost of Living Unit Rejects Some Ad Rate Exemptions
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council denied today requests that broadcast advertising rates, musicians wages and building service contractors be exempted from wageprice controls.

title: Roundup: Pirates Trounce Cards, 120
description: The world champion Pirates are beginning to look the part.

title: Wallace's Headquarters Getting Back to Normal
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 17  Buoyed by reports that Gov. George C. Wallace was no longer on the critical list, the Wallace for President campaign headquarters got almost back to normal today.

title: BURNSVOLCKER RIFT DOUBTED BY BANKER
description: Bruce K. MacLaury, president of the Federal. Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, challenged yesterday the notion that there is a deepseated difference between Arthur Burns and Paul Volcker over international monetary reform.

title: U.S. Report Calls Many Units Of Strategic Forces Not Ready
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 A report by the General Accounting Office on the status of the Strategic Army Forces in the United States concludes that many units are not combatready.

title: Gold Prices Spurt to Highs On Europe's Free Markets
description: PARIS, May 17The speculative flurry in gold intensified today as the price in the free market centers of Zurich and London rose another $2 an ounce to $57,75.

title: HICKS EPTON
description: WEWOKA, Okla., May 17 (AP) Hicks Epton, a lawyer here who was president of the American College of frial Awyers, died today in theJohni Hopkins Medical Center in Baltimore. He was 65 years old.

title: Students Facing Draft as Saigon Shuts All Colleges
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17  All of South Vietnam's institutions of higher learning closed today in ac cordance with President Nguy en Van Thieu's emergency mobilization decree, and students of both sexes prepared for military or paramilitary training.

title: NCR President Resigns; His Successor Is Named
description: R. Stanley Laing resigned yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the National Cash Register Company.

title: Politics and Performers
description: Mr. Harry Reasoner recently took to his television newsdesk and delivered a commentary. He said that he knew a man who had a pain in the neck about actors getting into politics. He warned President Nixon and Senator McGovern about actors support. He said, Presidential candidates should leave endorsements to makers of false teeth cement.

title: S.E.C. BIDS COURT BAR SALES SCHEME
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a Federal District Court today to halt the sale of Glenn W. Turner's pyramid franchising scheme on the ground that it is nothing but a device, scheme and artifice to defraud.

title: Hightower Is Named Head of Arts Councils
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 (AP)John B. Hightower, former director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was named yesterday as president of the Associated Councils of the Arts at its national convention.

title: Episcopal Group Elects
description: Henry S. Noble, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange concern of Carlisle DeCoppet & Co., has been elected president of the Episcopal Church Foundation. He succeeds William A. Coolidge, who was elected vice chairman of the board of directors. The foundation is a national organization of Episcopal laymen that initiates and underwrites projects in support of the work of the church.

title: F.D.A. Steps Up Campaign On Food Plant Sanitation
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) Responding to Congressional investigators findings that 40 per cent of United States food plants are unsanitary, the Food and Drtig Administration announced today that it was stepping up inspection and enforcement.

title: Arlan's to Restructure Debt; Kenton Accords Terminated
description: Edward Spector, president of Arian's Department Stores, Inc., said yesterday that the discount store chain has reached an agreement with its bank and institutional lenders to restructure $22.3million of existing short and longterm debt Mr. Spector said that in connection with these agreements, the merger and management agreements between the Kenton Corporation and Arlan's are being terminated. As part of the overall program, Mr. Spector, who joined Arlan's last August as president and chief operating officer, will be elected to Arlan's board and will be named chief executive.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BALTIMORE, May 17Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabana captured 39 per cent of the popular vote in the Maryland primary yesterday, but the real meaning of that victory, in terms of conventiondelegate votes, remained unclear today.

title: HENRY L. PINKENFELD
description: RED BANK, N.J., May 17 Henry L. Pinkenfeld, manager of the jewelry repair department of Saks Fifth Avenue for many years, died yesterday of cancer in Riverview Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 200 River Road.

title: Berlin Wall Is Opened For 2d Visiting Period
description: BERLIN, May 17  Thousands of West Berliners passed through the Berlin wall today for family reunions as the East Germans for the second time this year opened the border for an eightday visiting period.

title: Publishing Company Operated by Blacks Opens New Building
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (UPI)The Johnson Publishing Company has formally opened its new 11story headquarters on Michigan Avenue, the first Chicago Loop building exclusively designed and constructed by a blackowned corporation.

title: Carrier Sails for Vietnam
description: SAN DIEGO, May 17 (AP)The aircraft carrier Ticonderoga sailed, for Vietnam today with a new commanding officer, Capt. Frank T. Hemler. At least three crewmen were missing, having taken sanctuary in Quaker church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is distressing to learn of the announcement (news story April 27) by Treasury Under Secretary Paul A. Volcker to the effect that a Group of 20 may negotiate reform of the world monetary system. If any new monetary system comes into being, will remain a piecemeal effort toward solving the broader international economic disequilibrium. In essence there are three inseparable partsnew exchange rates of national currencies, tariffs and trade among the industrial countries, and trade and aid between the developing and developed countries. Ways should be found to arrive at reasonable settlement on all three simultaneously.

title: Milan Investigator Shot Dead; Led Inquiries Into Terrorism
description: MILAN, Italy, May 17An uhidentified gunman this morning shot and killed a nationally known law enforcement officer, Luigi Calabresi, who was chief of the politicalinvestigations section of Milan's police force.

title: BANK UNDER SIEGE ON A DEAD BANDIT
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 (UPI) More than 100 heavily armed policemen ringed the bank, crouching behind patrol cars, rifles and shotguns ready. Snipers peered from surrounding buildings. A police helicopter hovered overhead.

title: This Barnard Girl Can Cook And Tend Bar Like a Pro
description: While students on campuses all over America were griping about the gray meat and glutinous pudding served to them in college dining rooms, a lucky group of Barnard roommates sat down on, a recent evening in their Plimpton Hall suite to an elaborate meal of original dishes that would do credit to most New York restaurants.

title: Senate Clears Bill to Deal With Threat of Blackouts
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Faced with threats of blackouts and brownouts this summer, the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill that would allow the granting of temporary operating licenses for nuclear power plants to meet emergency energy needs.

title: Hartford Gallery Displays for the Blind
description: HARTFORDAt the Tactile Gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum here, there is no admonition to the children and other visitors not to touch.

title: Merger News
description: The American Home Products Corporation has reached an agreement to acquire the Much Group of companies of Bad Soden, West Germany, for stock worth more than $39million, it was announced yesterday. The Much Group produces nonprescription pharmaceuticals. Its products include a leading analgesic, in Germany plus sedatives and toilet preparations. The agreement, which is subject to certain contract conditions, involves about 393,651 common shares to be issued in the exchange. American Home Products closed at the year's high of 100, up  point on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: CITY U. ALTERS STAND ON CREDIT TRANSFER
description: Jewish students enrolled in the City University of New York who also attend Jewish teachers seminaries and yeshivas will receive transfer credits for work in these institutions on a more uniform basis than in the past in accordance with a new policy announced by Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee.

title: Formula for 'The Honkers':James Coburn Cast in Role of Rodeo Rider
description: Because there are so few certifiable American B movies anymore, it would be nice to say something gracious about "The Honkers," a rodeo film that, like Cliff Robertson's "J. W. Coop," has its antecedents in the Saturday-afternoon formula films of the 1930's and 1940's.Unfortunately, Steve Ihnat, who directed "The Honkers" and wrote its screenplay (with Stephen Lodge), lacks Robertson's ability (and perhaps freedom) to enrich an old formula with discoveries made in real life, as well as the kind of direct, no-nonsense narrative talent that occasionally elevated some B's (Nicholas Ray's "The Lusty Men") to A status. When Ihnat uses authentic rodeo characters, they seem to be just self-conscious actors. He also has terrible fondness for pretty dawn-and-dusk cloud shots of the sort that, 30 years ago, no self-respecting B-picture patron would have tolerated for the time it takes to swallow a mouthful of Crackerjacks."The Honkers" is the sluggish and sentimental record of three bad days in the life of Lew Lathrop (James Coburn), a good-natured rodeo circuit rider whose only fault seems to be that he is a little more self-centered than can be accommodated by a faithful wife.After a couple of years on the road, Lew and his adoring sidekick, a rodeo clown played by Slim Pickens, return to Lew's hometown where he abuses his wife, alienates his son and becomes the indirect cause of the death of a friend. If the movie can be said to take a position on anything, I guess you could say it comes out firmly against self-centeredness.It opened here yesterday at the Astor and other theaters on a double bill with a reissue of Sergeo Leone's "A Fistful of Dollars."

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The discussion in your May 10 editorial Mr. Nixon's Brinkmanship and on the OpEd page the same day of the President's Vietnam policy shift makes interesting and somewhat painful reading.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Not too long ago, Denny McLain was the biggest thing in baseball since the invention of the hot dog. He was a 31game, winner, the most valuable player in his league and only 24 years old. Stretching out ahead of him, seemed, was a fabulous future with undreamedof riches. Just the other day, the Oakland Athletics put him up waivers and no other club in the majors wanted him even bargainbasement prices. So he was optioned Birmingham, a minor league team.

title: U.S. Authorized to Buy Former Luxury Liner
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  President Nixon: signed legislation today authorizing the Department of Commerce to buy the former luxury liner United States. The price Will be about $12million.

title: Boston Cargo Unit Formed
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent announced today the creation of a State Planning Commission for Cargo Security. The commision, to be headed by Secretary of Public Safety Richard E. McLaughlin, will have representation from industry, labor and lawenforcement groups, Governor Sargent said.

title: Militance in High Schools Worries London Officials
description: LONDON, May 17 Pupil pdwer, a budding movement that has stirred teenagers and annoyed teachers, held a noisy, surging demonstration here today in a mood of angry milltance.

title: COURT ORDER BARS SITIN AT COLUMBIA
description: Columbia University obtained a court order yesterday temporarily barring a facultystudent antiwar group and three individual adults from occupying Pupin Hall or otherwise disrupting the activities of the university.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 17 (AP)Bill Carpenter, McLain's lawyer, confirmed the Oakland club's statement today, saying: Denny decided it was maybe best to go to Birmingham.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced today his first speeches since withdrawing from active campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination. His office said he would, speak Friday at the LaSalle Academy in Providence, R. I., and later in the day at the Maine State Democratic Convention in Waterville.

title: Policeman Cleared In Corruption Case
description: Poyce Lieut Jack Kaminsky was acquitted last night of charges that he had lied to Federal grand jury when he swore that he had no personal knowledge of police corruption.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market seemingly paid little attention yesterday to the latest batch of economic data and remained in what has become an unusually long period with no pronounced trend in rates. Investors in corporate bonds did display some enthusiasm, perhaps buoyed by the improvement in the balanceofpayments picture, and activity perked up.

title: Russian Patriarch in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, May 17  The head of the Russian Orthodox, Church, Patriarch Pimen, arrived in Jerusalem today for an eightday pilgrimage. It was the first visit by a Russian churchman since the Soviet Union broke diplomatic relations with Israel during the sixday war of 1967.

title: Liberation on the Green
description: ATLANTA, May 17 (AP) The Ladies Professional Golf Association has officially passed the $1million annual purse level for the first time, E. M. (Bud) Erickson, its executive directof, said today. The L.P.G.A. lifted its 1972 purse over that level last week when it added the $25,000 Portland Classic to the schedule.

title: Mrs. Minnie Tananbaum Married
description: Mrs. Minnie Lee Tanenbaum, vice president of Ferdinando Sarmi, Ltd., designers of women's fashions, was married here last evening to Dr. Alberto Lomeo, a gynecologist and obstetrician in practice in New York. Civil Court Judge Budd G. Goodman performed the ceremony at his home.

title: SCHOOL BOARD FILLS 1. OF 2 EXAMINER JOBS
description: The Board of Education gave final approval last night to the choice of Nathan Quinones to fill one of two vacancies on the Board of Examiners, but decided to postpone a vote on the nomination of Dr. Sylvester King, a former Harlem principal once charged with harassing union teachers, to fill the second vacancy.

title: Ballet: A Busy Nureyev
description: The Royal Ballet's triple bill at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night started dismally but moved forward to magnificence. The bad news first, if only because it opened the program and we can at least get it over with. This was John Cranko's Poeme de l'Extase.

title: Newsman Wins Fellowship
description: The Council on Foreign Relations has awarded its 197273 Edward R. Murrow Fellowship for foreign correspondents to Stewart Keifer man of United Press International's Saigon bureau. Mr. Kellerman will spend the academic year at the council's headquarters here studying and discussing longrange foreign policy problems with the emphasis on relations between the United States, China and the Soviet Union.

title: The Urban Coalition Wavering On Decision to Quit Poverty Unit
description: It was disclosed yesterday that the New York Urban Coalition had submitted an immediate resignation from the city's policymaking Council Against Poverty  an action that would automatically displace its oftencontroversial representative, David J. Billings 3d, the council's chairman.

title: MISS HILTON EXCELS IN 8 BAROQUE DANCES
description: Wendy Hilton, a specialist in 18th  century dance, performed eight of these Baroque dances Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program shared with other artists, entitled One Hour of Chamber Music. The event, directed by Jens Nygaard, was presented at a convenient time for zipping in after work (5:40 P.M.).

title: $2.8Million 20th Precinct Station Opens
description: West Side youngsters found a police station a happy place yesterday as the $2,816,000 20th Precinct Station was formally dedicated. The 20th Precinct Community Council staged a block party to mark the dedication.

title: G.O.P. Senators Affirm School Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  In what they called a Republican declaration of conscience, 10 Republican Senators today reaffirmetd support of a national policy aimed at desegregating the nation's schools.

title: Intellectuals in Bloom At Spring Gathering
description: Intellectuals, artists and other savants gathered here yesterday to warm one another's spirit and to renew old friendships. They did it at the annual ceremonies of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters, and they did it with a flourish.

title: DOUGLAS E. NASH
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 17Douglas E. Nash, a former president of the Nash Engineering Company, which, was founded by his father in 1912, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 82 years old and recently had moved here from Norwalk.

title: Brian Furey, 64, Owned Employment Agency Here
description: Brian Furey, who owned and operated the Brian Furey Commercial Employment Agency here between 1950 and 1969, died Tuesday at Flushing Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 3401 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

title: INDIANS TOP YANKS IN WALKOVER, 21
description: CLEVELAND, May 17Eight strong innings of pitching by Steve Kline and Jim Roland went to waste for the New York Yankees at Municipal Stadium tonight when the Cleveland. Indians rallied against Fred Beene in the ninth to post a 21 triumph and maintain their position atop the American League Eastern Division.

title: Romalie Hanover Heads Yonkers Field
description: YONKERS, May 17Twelve, an unusually large field of 3yearolds for this stakes event, will go postward in the $27,700 Bronx Filly Face at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

title: MRS. RUTH M. KNIGHT, A CIVIC LEADER, 77
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., May 17 Mrs. Ruth Morgenthau Knight, a daughter of the late Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, and sister of the late Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today in a hospital in New Canaan. She was 77 years old and lived at Blue Herons, her estate here.

title: Saigon's Troops Advance Within Two Miles of Anloc
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 18 South Vietnamese troops transported by helicopter moved yester: clay within two miles of the besieged and battered city Anloc, senior American officials here said. The advance, by paratroopers and units of the South Vietnamese 21st Division, was said to have met only sporadic opposition.

title: Miss Hogan Flares Up
description: GUILDFORD, England, May 17 (UPI)Patti Hogan showed her temperament again today at the Rothman's tenpis tournament.

title: CITY HOUSING AIDE QUITS UNDER FIRE
description: Joel J. Silver, a city housing official who was under fire by the City Council for awarding a contract to a political ally, resigned yesterday from his $27,954ayear post.

title: Pacers Lewis Revisits House That Taunts Him
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 Freddie Lewis, the 6foot Indiana Pacer guard, gets more attention from the fans in the Other American Basketball Association franchise cities than he does in Indiana. The hometown fans often boo him and make him a scapegoat in defeat.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Every time some highstanding politician utters that line about our not even wanting anything in return for all the fighting we have done in Vietnam and all the money we have spent out there, somebody ought to stand up in the audience and cry, Why not?

title: Advertisin The F.T.C. Replies
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Dr. Yale Brozen who yesterday again attacked the Federal Trade Commission, was charged today with gross distortion by a high official of, that agenty.

title: Interest in Nixon Visit Mounts in Poland
description: WARSAW, May 17Is your President still coming?

title: View of Rifle Group
description: RENO, Nev., May 17 (AP)The executive vice president of the National Rifle Association said today that additional gun controls would not prevent shootings similar to the one that wounded Governor Wallace.

title: Southern Pacific
description: WILMINGTON, Dela., May 17Shareholders of the Southern Pacific Company were told by Benjamin F. Blaggini, president, that Southern Pacific expects improvements in business in the second quarter and continued growth during 1972. Last year earnings for the second quarter were $1.18 per share. Mr. Biaggini told the shareholders that the company plans to spend $267million in 1972 on capital improvements. This is up from $163million in 1971.

title: Premier Said to Declare Hanoi Offers U.S. an Honorable Exit
description: PARIS, May 17  Premier Pharr Van Dong of North Vietnam said in an interview published today that his side would negotiate an end to the war in 24 hours, if it could.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Vice President Agnew has a clear lead as the first choice of the nation's Republican voters to repeat as President Nixon's running mate in November, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: CITY BALLET ADDS GLOW TO JEWELS
description: George Balanchine's Jewels revels in the concept and execution of classical dancing and quite unselfconsciously teases some of its conventions as well. At the State Theater Tuesday evening, the New York City Ballet presented a bright and warm performance of the work.

title: OIL CONCERNS GET IRAQI ULTIMATUM
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17The Government of Iraq today served a twoweek ultimatum or the Western consortium that exploits and markets Iraqi oil.

title: Port Bill Killed in Bay State
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)A bill requiring the Massachusetts Port Authority to publish its master plan for scrutiny by the public and the legislature was killed by the Massachusetts House today, 33 to 19.

title: 3 Children Killed as Fire Sweeps Akron, Ohio, Home
description: AKROON, Ohio, May 17 (AP) Flames swept through an aged apartment building in southwest Akron early today, killing three children, critically injuring another and seriously burning three adults.

title: 5th Man Seized in Inquiry On Purported Trotting Fix
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., May. 17, A fifth man was arrested today in, the alleged attempt to fix last Thursday night's superfeota race at Monticello Raceway.

title: Mujib Role in GandhiBhutto Talks Seen
description: NEW DELHI, May 17Informed sources said today that the meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan was likely to be enlarged to include Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh.

title: U.S. to Investigate Canadian Imports
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)In the second largest case of its kind, the Treasury Department said today it was investigating whether aluminum ingot imported from Canada was being sold at illegal prices in the United States.

title: Liquori Out of Olympics After Visit With Kerlan
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 (UPI)Marty Liguori, the top miler in the world last year, announced today after a consultation with Dr. Robert Kerlan, orthopedic specialist, that he would run no more this year.

title: Senators Are Told of Failure of a Scheme to Reap Profits in Welfare Housing
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The rise and fall of a scheme to buy twofamily houses in Governmentinsured mortgages, rent them to welfare families and get high returns for private investors was described here today to a Senate subcommittee.

title: Communists Report Mines at Haiphong Swept, Ships Sailing
description: HAIPHONG, North Vietnam, May 17The North Vietnamese say they are clearing American mines from the Haiphong harbor as planes drop them, and moving ships in and out.

title: Mrs. Greitzer Charges Politics In Layoffs at the Metropolitan
description: City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer charged yesterday that at least 13 of 63 staff members recently given layoff notices by the Metropolitan Museum of Art were being released because of political and retaliatory reasons.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 17 (Reuters)Harold Passer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said today the outlook was favor able for strong gains in every major sector of the economy.

title: Park West Village Sale By Alcoa to Helmsley Set
description: Harry B. Helmsley, one of the country's largest realestate operators, has signed contract with the Aluminium Company of America to purchase Park West Village, a middle  income seven  building housing project on the Upper West Side.

title: Mets Rout Expos, 122; Milner and Gentry Star
description: The New York Mets added to the best record in baseball last night with a 122 mauling of the Montreal Expos for their sixth straight victory.

title: Gun Bill Voted in Ohio
description: COLUMNS, Ohio, May 17 (UPI)The Ohio Senate, responding to the shooting of Governor Wallace, adopted today a bill setting a mandatory nonprobational prison sentence of one to three years for carrying a firearm while committing a crime of violence.

title: For Lindsay, It's Reappraisal Time After Bitter Defeat
description: Mayor Lindsay, who set forth on the road to the White House with great ebullience, although an admitted long shot, has returned to City Hall stung by his defeat in the primaries, working, harder than ever while soberly reassessing his role as Mayor and his political future, according to his closest advisers.

title: 10 Get Trial Delays
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17Ten of the 13 students and faculty accused of violating an open expression code during last month's barricading of the main administation building of the University of Pennsylvania were granted trial postponements yesterday until the fall. The three remaining accused, were denied postponements and will be tried separately before the University Court tomorrow.

title: Times Study Finds Wallace Could Cut Votes for Nixon
description: The New York Times's primary election surveys indicate strongly that a thirdparty candidacy by Gov. George C. Wallace would be likely to cut far more sharply into President Nixon's vote than into that of the Democratic nominee.

title: Egyptians Demand U.S. Trim Its Mission Staff From 20 to 10
description: CAIRO, Thursday, May 18 (AP)President Anwar elSadat has told the United States to cut the staff of its diplomatic mission here in half within month; American diplomats said today.

title: Chess:
description: The race for first place in the 21st National Annual Chess Championship recently conducted here broke down to a cluster of four top grandmasters  Lubomir Kavalek of Washington, a onetime champion of Czechoslovakia and now an American citizen; Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a sixtime titleholder who defeated Al Horowitz and I. Kashdan in set matches in the 1940's; Robert Byrne of Ossining, N. Y., and the Rev. William Lombardy of New York.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: The twoday rise in the price of soybean futures came to an abrupt halt yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Selloffs erased the early fractional increases as well as other rises later in the session.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday (Reuters)Vice President Agnew left for home today after a threeday visit to Thailand.

title: BERGER AWARD GOES TO 3 ON DAILY NEWS
description: Three reporters for The New York Daily News have won Columbia University's 1972 Meyer Berger Award for an investigative series on organized crime at Kennedy International Airport.

title: IN THE NATION
description: George McGovern now heads, west as the Democratic leader in the number of delegates pledged to him. He is the favorite in the virtually uncontested Oregon primary, which ought to give him a good lift into the showdown California primary on June 6. Behind him in New York he leaves a good lead over Hubert Humphrey, both as measured hi a poll by WCBS and in the opinion of professionals eying the delegate slates.

title: Frazier, Training for Bout, Says He Will Retire Soon
description: OMAHA, May 17 (UPI)Joe Frazier interrupted his training today to announce he would soon retire.

title: URBAN LEAGUE HEAD FEARS WHITE SHIFT
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 17 (UPI)The executive diredtor of the National Urban League fears that black people are going out of style and white Americans, weary of the racial struggle, will let the movement wither as whites did after the Civil War.

title: Horror Double Bill Pairs a Dr. Jekyll With Mummy's Tomb
description: So bemused is he by his discovery of the elixir of lifedistilled from the hormones of freshly killed young womenthat the shy young scientist, Dr. Jekyll, hardly notices, until too late, that drinking it turns him into a womanbeautiful and immortal maybe, but not nice. Jekyll's position is not wholly unhappy. In love by turns with both the son and daughter of the widow on the first floor, Jekyll is embarrassed only by never knowing which sex he's going to be when, and by a seemingly insatiable need for more female hormonesso as to get the elixir formula right.It is the question of hormone supply, more a problem in logistics than in morality, that finally does Dr. Jekyll inand also pretty much does in his movie, "Dr. Jekyll & Sister Hyde," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. For while a sex-change Dr. Jekyll has the potential for some interest, collecting the hormones (an inevitable progression from purchasing at the morgue to stealing corpses to killing the tender young tarts of London to almost knifing the girl upstairs) has no such potential. And yet it is so indulged, provoking so many midnight murders, that it finally overpowers the film in a tedious repetition of dull suspense and unsuspenseful shock.I should say a word for Martine Beswick as Mrs. Hydevery handsome in the skull-beneath-the-skin tradition of Barbara Steeleand for Roy Ward Baker, whose directorial reticence generally makes things bearable even when they aren't much fun.However, Seth Holt's "Blood From the Mummy's Tomb," which shares the bill with Dr. Jekyll and his sister, is for almost its entire length tremendous fun, skillful and wonderfully energetic. It is not so much a fiction movie as a stringing together of direful devices, but I can think of few more guiltily pleasant excuses for overstaying a lunch hour, avoiding duty, or merely escaping the sunshine on a summer afternoon.Of course "Blood From the Mummy's Tomb" has a story, an uncommonly elaborate variation on the kind of revenge from beyond the grave that, from the nature of their discipline, Egyptologists keep running into. But it has so much more that I am inclined just to list a few attractions: a severed hand, a sacred cat, a jackal's skull, five mad scientists, an otherwise marvelously cracked or half-cracked cast, a fine respect for the horror heritage, a young hero named Tod Browning, and for a heroine a millenium's old free-floating astral spirit named Terawho, as currently embodied in Miss Valerie Leon, is a 500 per cent knockout.

title: GARBAGEEN END HONOLULU STRIKE
description: HONOLULU, May 17  City garbage workers returned to their jobs this morning, ending a fiveday strike.

title: 2 Are Killed and 22 Injured In Ulster Shootings and Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 17 (AP)Guerrilla gunmen fatally wounded a British soldier and shot another in the leg tonight. Other violence in Northern Ireland during the day also left one civilian dead and 21 injured.

title: ANACONDA SEES BRIGHT FUTURE
description: ANACONDA, Mont., May 17 (AP) Saying nobody likes some of the things that have had to be done, John B. M. Place, president of the Anaconda Company, told a stockholders meeting today that brighter days were ahead. About 500 of the 123,000 stockholders of the financially troubled Anaconda were told that profits In April were the highest of any month this year.

title: Contact Lens Production Set by WarnerLambert
description: WarnerLambert Company and Frigitronics, Inc. said yesterday that they had signed a definitive contract licensing WarnerLambert to manufacture and market worldwide the Griffin soft hydrophilic contact lens.

title: Pickets From Texas Plants Set Up Lines at Macy's
description: A group of pickets, including two representing workers at plants of the Farah Manufacturing Company in Texas, set up informational picket lines outside Macy's department store at 34th Street yesterday to protest what they called antiunion by the manufacturer activity at the Farah plant in El Paso, Tex.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The undersigned, members of the faculty and other officers of instruction of the School of Law of Columbia University, enthusiastically support the candidacy of Judge Nanette Dembitz of the Family Court of New York for the Democratic nomination to one of the three vacancies on the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, May 17George C. Wallace trounced his liberal opposition in yesterday's Michigan Presidential primary, but there was immediate maneuvering today over his delegate seats at the Democratic National Convention.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Gov. George C. Wallace scored his breathtaking sweep in Michigan yesterday  Walter. Reuther's and G. Mennen William's and Philip A Hart's Michigan, the most liberal of the Middle Western industrial states, with its proud history of racially open politicsfor one essential reason. That reason was busing.

title: JOSEPH A. RUPERT, WHEAT EXPERT, 56
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 17  Dr. Joseph A. Rupert, an internationallyknown wheat scientist and an associate director for the agricultural sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, died of cancer today. He was 56 years old and made his home here.

title: Executive Changes
description: E. R, Squibb & Sons, Inc., has named Dr. Barry Davis, executive vice president, responsible tor worldwide operations; Dr. Lawrence Marks, vice president of corporate development and Vahan Hogroian, vice president of planning and systems.

title: Surgeon Doubts Wallace Can Regain Use of Legs
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 17Gov. George C. Wallace's neurosurgeon said today that the Governor had less than a 5050 chance of regaining the use of his paralyzed legs.

title: Industry Units Back Taxable Municipals
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The Securities Industry Association and the Municipal Finance Officers Association both endorsed in principle today the idea of giving state and local governments the option of issuing taxable bonds with an automatic interest subsidy from the Federal Government.

title: CAHILL OUTLINES HIS TAX PROGRAM
description: TRENTON, May 17  Gov. William T. Cahill Will urge the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow to approve a tax reform program that includes an income tact and a statewide property talc of $1 for every $100 of true value. It is designed to raise $2billion a year.

title: Colombia Gets W.H.O. Seat
description: GENEVA, May 17Colombia will fill the seat vacated by the United States on the board of the world Health Organization for the next three years, the organization's assembly decided today, The United States was not eligible for reelection to the seat on the United Nation's agency's board.

title: AUSTRALIA GAINS DAVIS CUP VICTORY
description: BANGALORE, India, May 17 (AP)Australia clinched the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final by beating India in doubles today, but lost her No. 1 player, 37yearold Mal Anderson.

title: Whitehall St. Center Shuts Its Doors
description: The American flag came down for the last time yesterday outside the Whitehall Induction Center, and the sooty eightstory brick and granite building officially ended 86 years of processing men and women for peacetime duty and war, first on American prairies and then in. European forests, Pacific islands and Asian jungles.

title: Youths Warned of Drug Laws Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The State Department said today that nearly 1,000 young Americans were in jail abroad for drug offenses  six times more than in 1969.

title: Irish Olympic Boxers Face New Yorkers Here Tonight
description: The Irish Olympic boxing team will face a New York team tonight in the Felt Forum beginning at 8:30 o'clock.

title: News Analysis
description: BONN, May 17  One could imagine tonight that from the Atlantic to the Urals, political13, minded Europeans gave muffled sigh of relief at the news that the Bonn parliament had ratified the treaties that offer the hope of EastWest cooperation.

title: Market Place:
description: If you are an investor in small companies, how can you find out whether your brokera participating underwriterregards a specific new issue as a number to be forgotten or an investment?

title: Columbia University Club Votes To Allow Women Membership
description: The Columbia University Club last night overwhelthingly approved 4 constitutional, amendment perniitting women to join as full mernbers.

title: Books of The Times
description: It seems to me that American life has rushed forward so rapidly that it has created a vacuum behind it, and that it has become the special mission of certain Southern writers to fill that vacuum, to bridge the enormous gap between, say, life in Manhattan and in Mount Salus, Miss., where Eudora Welty has placed The Optimist's. Daughter. Perhaps because it lost the Civil Wardon't we always cling more passionately to what we've lost?the South has always been historyhaunted, traditionobsessed, hungry for continuity and connection. Where else do people speak of kin so insistently? Some Southern novelists claim all the cardinal virtues exclusively for their towns, their life, their people, as if the country had been stood on end and all its vital juices had flowed downward.

title: Marcia Leads Li. Golf by Stroke
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 17Chet Marcin, a former harness racing driver and trainer, was the surprising leader at 72 after the first round of the Long Island open golf championship today.

title: Jack Sornack for Prisoner
description: Jack Somack, familiar to television viewers as the husband in the spicy meatball AlkaSeltzer commercial, will replace Vincent Gardenia in the Neil Simon comedy, The Prisoner of Second Avenue, on Monday.

title: Utility Plans Plant
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP), The Commonwealth Edison Company announced today it Plans to build a $500million kilowatt generating station near Morris in Grundy County.

title: New Welfare Plan Is Blamed for Harsh Treatment
description: Cases have been closed arbitrarily, assistance has been erroneously denied or delayed and the homebound poor have encountered difficulties since the Department of Social Services separated incomemaintenance and service functions nine months ago, the Community Council of Greater New York said yesterday.

title: WEST GERMANY'S TREATIES WITH SOVIET AND POLAND WIN BUNDESTAG APPROVAL
description: BONN, May 17After more than two decades of postwar hostility between West Germany and Eastern Europe, treaties of friendship with the Soviet Union and Poland were approved today in the lower house of the West German Parliament.

title: Soviet Launches Satellite
description: MOSCOW, May 17  The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the unmanned spacecraft Cosmos 490, presumed to be a military observation satellite. Tass, the Soviet press agency said the satellite was circling the earth every 89.5 minutes in a low orbit of 193 by 132 miles, with an inclination of 65.4 degrees to the Equator.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The defendants in the Howard R. Hughes autobiography case filed a Federal suit yesterday demanding the return of more than $91,000 that they said was seized illegally last month by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Failure Confronts an Irish Writer in Morrison's Play
description: NEW HAVEN, May 16Patrick Power, the tragic hero of Bill Morrison's new play, Patrick's Day, the final production of the season at the Long Wharf Theater, is a selfmade failure. Taking his pseudonym from a bottle of whisky, he has transformed himself into a prizewinning novelist with the dimension and pretension of Hemingway.

title: Essex House to Give Back $68,533.24 in Overcharges
description: The Essex House at 160 Central, Park South, has agreed to refund 35,000 customers a total of $68,533.24 it overcharged them between Oct. 28, 1969, and July 1, 1970, and promised not to levy deceptive and illegal charges in the future.

title: BANKERS PROTEST RULE PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The Federal Reserve Board has stirred a storm of protest among the nation's bankers with its proposals to overhaul the rules governing bank reserves and checkcollection procedures.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: William Q. Hull, 53, Dead; Aide of Chemical Society
description: William Q. Hull, the head of the American Chemical Society's Department of Special Publishing Services in Washington until he became ill last year, died Saturday at the Oak Hill Rest Home, San Antonio, Tex. He was 53 years old and had made his home in Alexandria, Va.

title: ENTRY DOMINATES PREAKNESS FIELD
description: BALTIMORE, May 17Riva Ridge, the Meadow Stable colt, and his entrymate, Upper Case, dominate the Preakness picture.

title: 10,000 Antiwar. Protesters Demonstrate in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, May 17 (Reuters)About 10,000 Vietnam war protesters chanting Nixon assassin marched past the United States Embassy today.

title: CONFEREES VOTE 19MONTIT DELAY ON BUSING EDICTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17A tiouseSenate conference committee agreed today on legislation that would delay for up to 19 Months the implementation of court desegregation orders that require busing.

title: 2 Suits for Flood Victim's
description: LOGAN, W. Va., May 17 (AP) Two negligence suits were filed today in the Logan Circuit Court on behalf of flood victims in Buffalo Creek Hollow on Feb. 26. Both suits natne the Buffalo Mining Corm pany, its parent Pittston Company, and the Pardee Land ompany, as defendants, charging negligence on their part resulted in the wrongful deaths of Mrs. Ruth Ann Elkins and Mrs. Janice Bailey.

title: Amtrak's Funds Are Increased By $125Million by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Senate conferees have succeeded in increasing the appropriation for Amtrak.

title: DOW RISES BY 1.88; STOCKS END MIXED
description: A recovery in the last halfhour enabled the stock market to finish mixed yesterday in lackluster trading as many investors continued to remain on the sidelines, mainly because of the unsettled Vietnam situation.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This is a quest for a sportsman and a gentleman, an angler of heart and ingenuity, and undoubtedly a dryfly purist even with the stream at 41 degrees and full of snow water. Please help me find him, writes that grand old gentleman of American fly fishing, Sparse Grey Hackle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One of the hardfought perennial debates in Albany concerns a change in legal procedure to permit the judge, rather than the defense and prosecuting attorneys, to question prospective jurors in state criminal cases. Although its supporters have labeled this a mere technical change, intended to reduce court delay, it has nevertheless been defeated in the past, with the opposition not only of defense lawyers, but of some prosecutors and judges. The issues in this submerged controversy, important in principle, have yet to be brought out in public debate.

title: Slain L.I. Woman Was Wife of Man Accused of Fraud
description: A woman found stabbed to death on Long Island Tuesday night was identified yesterday as the wife of a Nassau County private school operator who has been accused by the state of running a fraudulent educational counseling scheme.

title: A Family Threat
description: Multiple sclerosis, a disabling affliction of the brain and spinal cord, usually strikes between the ages of 20 and 40, the vital career and family building years.

title: Two Top Economists Optimistic for 1972
description: Dr. Marina Whitman, the only woman member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, and Dr. Walter W. Heller, chairman of the council under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, were in substantial agreement yesterday that the economy would improve measurably during 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I just returned from a few days in New York City; shopping, dentist, etc. A most successful trip, in spite of rain, due to the extreme courtesy of the taxi drivers. In fact, for the last three years, they are the only ones say Thank you for a tip.

title: Kanicki to Get Surgery
description: The New York Giants said yesterday that their defensive left tackle, Jim Kanicki, would undergo surgery next week to repair a partial tear in his right Achilles tendon. Kanicki told the club he slipped on the ice about six weeks ago near his home in Ohio, but didn't think the injury was serious. However, he had been feeling pain recently and Dr. Anthony Pisani, the team physician, advised corrective surgery.

title: Met's Loss for 1971'72 Season Put at More Than $5Million
description: The Metropolitan Opera, with two months to go before the close of its fiscal year, is facing its largest cash deficit since its opening at Lincoln Center in 1967. George S. Moore, the company's president, said yesterday afternoon the present reading is that we need to raise $750,000. He added that the total loss before contributions for the 197172 season will be more than $5million.

title: Hartford Lawmakers Cautious On Speaking Out on Abortion
description: HARTFORD, May 18Connecticut lawmakers, apparently unwilling to plunge into politically hazardous public debate on abortion, maintained their distance from the issue today despite gathering public interest in a hearing that is to begin tomorrow.

title: Nixon Urges Bill to Cut Red Tape in Social Programs
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today legislation designed to cut through the red tape that entangles much of the nation's social service effort.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, May 18Eddie Litzenberger, who was a jockey and then a trainer and now is assistant racing secretary at Pimlico, shook a leather bottle briskly and, rolled a numbered pill on to the counter. One; he said, Beverly Zerwitz, a tall blonde in riding breeches wearing a yellow sash that read Miss Preakness, drew a sheet of paper from a file and handed it to Larry Abbundi, the racing secretary, who read out the name of the horse that would have the inside post position in the 97th Preakness Saturday. No. 1 is No Le Hace.

title: Columbia Football Players Get Spring Tests
description: What can a coach do with the single day of spring practice permitted by Ivy League football rules? Frank Navarro of Columbia did a lot with his one day as he tested 95 candidates at Baker Field yesterday in six different ways, scoring and ranking every one.

title: Market Place: Shopping Around On Stock Prices
description: A broker gets an order from a small investor to buy 100 shares of International Nickel. Question: Where will he buy it?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times has taken a strong stand against the marine mammal protection act, House Bill 10420. Let us examine the facts. The bill prohibits the killing or harassment as well as the importation of any marine mammal or part thereof anywhere, in the United States. Exception to this law is by permit only, as issued by the Secretary of the Interior after public review. Also included in this bill is fiveyear moratorium on the taking of any marine mammal.

title: Prosecution of Employers Urged To Halt the Flow of Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Spokesmen for migrant farm workers petitioned the Justice Department today to halt the influx of illegal alien harvesters by prosecuting the growers who hire them.

title: Park and Gilbert Are. Selected To AllN. H. L. Team by Writers
description: MONTREAL, May 18 (UPI) The Boston Bruins, New York Rangers, Chicago Black Hawks and Montreal Canadiens filled all 12 berths on the 197172 National Hockey League's first and second AllStar teams announced today by the league.

title: U.S. IS EXAMINING JAPAN EXPORT BID
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 In a case of potentially major importance to JapaneseUnited States trade and to American consumers, the Treasury announced today it was investigating whether a whole series of Japanese Government tax and other incentives to exports of consumer electronic products, such is television sets, constituted an illegal subsidy.

title: Italy's Civil Servants Strike Over Raises to High Aides
description: ROME, May 18Some 300,000 civil servants started a twoday strike today to protest against pay raises for their superiors.

title: Theater: Bewilderment in a Likable Water Hen
description: The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn is most engagingly crazy. It is virtually dead brokeif anyone has any artistic money going spare this would be a good home for itand it cheerfully admits that: In terms of repertoire, audience relationship and attempts at financing, we behaved as though we were in Sweden, rather than America. Never let the Chelsea Theater Center go to Sweden. It woule mean the loss of a major cultural asset.

title: CITY AIDES OFFER BUDGET GAP PLAN
description: A proposal to close the city's $540million budget gap without imposing substantial new taxes  and possibly avoiding new taxes altogether  was made jointly yesterday by the, Controller, the Council President and the five Borough Presi dents.

title: CHRYSLER PROJECT IS CALLED A HOAX
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Center for Auto Safety, calling Chrysler Corporation's My Man in Detroit program, a hoax on the public, has asked the Federal Trade Commission to lodge charges of unfair and deceptive trade, practices against the company.

title: William Webster
description: William Webster, former chairman and chief executive officer of the New England Electric System, died Wednesday, after a long illness, in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S., Soviet and Britain Ratify Treaty on Seabed
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (Reuters)The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain formally pledged themselves today to an international treaty banning the placing of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction of the seabed.

title: S.E.C. Plans Bill to Allow Fund Advisers to Be Sold
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a major new policy step, disclosed today that it would shortly propose that Congress considel legislation designed to permit investment advisory concerns to sell their businesses at a profit under certain circumstances.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 18 Senator John L. McClellan at the age of 76 is in the toughest reelection fight of his 35year Congressional career.

title: Death Penalty for Assassins Is Sought by Robert Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, called today for the death penalty for persons Who assassinate or attempt to assassinate candidates for President.

title: Senate Panel Votes a U.S. Role In Tracing of Deserting Fathers
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 The Senate Finance Committee Noted today to make the Federal locater service available in tracking down runaway fathers of all income levels who fail to Support their children.

title: DORMANT MARKET SPRINGS TO LIFE
description: The slumbering stock market woke up yesterday and made its first advance In three sessions in steppedup trading.

title: Backgammon Fans Bet Across the Board
description: Amid the ceaseless rattle Of 162 pairs of dice, the world's largest backgammon tournament, at the Pierre Hotel, sped last night toward its finish.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market seemed to be gathering strength yesterday to move up and out of its narrow range of recent weeks.

title: BRUNO BUITONI, 82, LED PASTA COMPANY
description: PERUGIA, Italy, May 18Bruno Buitoni, chairman of the I.B.P. Buitoni Perugina pasta and candy corporation, died here yesterday, apparently of heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Port Notes
description: The immediate construction of a $500million offshore oil unloading terminal neat the entrance to Delaware Bay was urged here yesterday by Robert J. Blackwell. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Maritime Affairs.

title: Xerox Planning to Market Color Copier Next Year
description: CHICAGO, May 18  The Xerox Corporation plans to introduce its longawaited color copier next year.

title: Notes on People
description: Interrupting her official state visit to France, Queen Elizabeth II had tea and her fourth reunion with her uncle the Duke of Windsor, at his home in the Boulogne woods on the western perimeter of Paris.

title: Books of The Times
description: If one had to pick superlatives and adjectives of praise for Open Heart, one would have to say that it is the best of Frederick Buechner's novels to date; that it is funny, touching, tender and compassionate; and that reading it has the curious effect of relaxing tensions one hadn't even been aware one was feeling. And if one were forced to explain the meaning of Open Heart, one would have to call it an attempt to envision the boundlessness of Christian love and the mystery of faith, and to reflect them both in a funhouse mirror. But praise and analysis seem out of order herejust as they do in happy families (as Tolstoy once implied). In happy families, you relax and enjoy. Relax and en joy then, as we meet once again the family that first appeared in Mr. Buechner's Lion Country, to which Open Heart is the sequel. There's Harry Bebb, the one true founder of Holy Love Church, with his trick eyelid that goes involuntarily up and down like a window shade, and his almost certain disreputable past. There's his wife, Lucille, drinking gin and orange juice all day in front of a TV set with the green hue turned up too high. There's Mr. Buechner's narrator, Antonio Parr (in a more analytic frame of mind, we'd have to read that Parr for everyman), who went to Florida originally to write an expos of Bebb's religious diploma mill but who ended up marrying Bebb's daughter Sharon.

title: BUSING FIGHT FORCES DELAY IN LAWSUITS
description: The Nixon Administration's stance against busing as a means of school integration has forced the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., to drop, or at least hold up, its plans for a broad range of lawsuits involving the quality of integrated education.

title: Wright Takes L. I. Open By 3 Strokes With 214
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., May 18  Aided by an eagle 3, Jimmy Wright scored a closing threeunderpar 69 today and won the Long Island open golf championship by three strokes. The 32yearold professional from the Inwood Country Club, with a 54hole aggregate of 214, carried off the district honors for the third time.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Social Committee 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mets Mark Koosman Incident Closed
description: Yogi Berra said yesterday that he considered the Jerry Koosman racetrack incident closed, but that it stood as lesson to the rest of the New York Mets to watch out who you associate with.

title: White House Press Aide Attacks The Times on Haiphong Dispatch
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) The White House denied today a New York Times report that the North Vietnamese were clearing United States mines from Haiphong and that ships were entering and leaving the port.

title: The Screen: A Graceful 'Uncle Vanya'
description: Chekhov's "Uncle Vanya," first produced by the Moscow Art Theater in 1898, is seldom done in this country, perhaps because a poor production can make it seem to be the Chekhovian parody that one of New York's drama critics called it in the 1930's. The landscape is familiar enough: a collapsing country estate inhabited by characters who long to be somewhere else, who bicker at tea, and who talk on through evening and night about art, which they miss, provincialism, which is stifling them, inheritances, which are slipping away, opportunities, which they've already lost, and the weatherit seems always about to rain, or to have just finished.Anton Chekhov was the most thoughtful of great dramatists. He wrote plays that, if done badly enough, turn into auto-critiques, something that was apparent in both the Russian film version of "The Three Sisters," released here in 1969, and Sidney Lumet's English language adaptation of "The Sea Gull" (1968).Because there have been so few screen adaptations of Chekhov's plays seen here, it doesn't mean as much as I wish it did to say that the new Russian film version of "Uncle Vanya," which opened yesterday at the Regency Theater, is probably the best filmed Chekhov I've ever seen. Adapted and directed by Andrei Mikhalkov-Konchalovsky, this "Uncle Vanya" is an exceedingly graceful, beautifully acted production that manages to respect Chekhov as a man of his own time, as well as what I would assume to be the Soviet view of Chekhov as Russia's saddest, gentlest, funniest and most compassionate revolutionary playwright.At the beginning of the film, Astrov (Sergei Bondarchuk), the doctor who plants trees in hopes of making future civilizations more humane, sits on the verandah in the September heat and wonders if the coming generations will remember. "They will forget," he says with resignation. "God won't forget," says the old nanny who looks exactly like Nikita Khrushchev and, from time to time, comments on what's going on with appropriate truisms.Like God, the Soviet director has not forgotten, and only in a couple of instances (in the opening credits, for example) does he bear down rather heavily on Chekhov as the scourger of the old order and the prophet of something new. For the most part, the film proceeds at Chekhov's own pace as the camera, which has the presence of a household intimate, follows the action in close-up, sometimes overhearing scenes from adjoining rooms, sometimes, as if by chance, becoming so involved in the action that it doesn't remember to give us an establishing shot until a scene is almost completed.Mikhalkov - Konchalovsky occasionally plays with stage effects (dropping the lights to end a scene with a character in silhouette) and arbitrary film effects (for some reason that I can't fathom the movie alternates between sepia and lovely, autumnal color). Most of the time, however, everything he does seems to be in the service of the text, and of the actors who perform it.They are all marvelous. Innokenty Smoktunovsky as Uncle Vanya, the estate manager who, at 47, imagines (improperly) that had he not wasted his life in the service of his fraudulent brother-in-law, he would have been a Dostoyevsky or a Schopenhauer; Bondarchuk as Astrov, a man who measures his cynicism more carefully than he admits; Irina Kupchenko as Sonya, a lovely, pathetic girl who is left to turn old on the estate with only hopes of heaven to talk about; and Irina Miroschnichenko as Yelena, the young wife of the estate's owner, the second-rate literary celebrity and the outsider who has systematically wrecked the lives of everyone around him.With the exception of some very Soviet-sounding, things-to-come sort of music behind the opening credits, the sounds of the movie are pure Chekhov, those of bored conversations, sudden explosions of anger and silences framed by the echoes of distant thunder or trains or the barking of dogs."Uncle Vanya" has been remembered by the filmmakers with deep appreciation and taste.

title: A Joint Inspection Panel In Arms Accord Is Seen
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 18 The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle to establish a standing committee, with an equal number of members from each side, to examine any charges of violations of the proposed limitations on strategic arms, a reliable source reported today.

title: George C. Whipple Jr. Is Dead; Advertising Executive Was 42
description: George C. Whipple Jr., an advertising and public relations executive, died of heart failure after a brief illness at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday. He was 42 years old and lived at Pine View Farm, Carmel, N.Y., and 520 East 72d Street.

title: AlternateSide Parking Ban Is Suspended for Shabuoth
description: The Traffic Department announced yesterday that alternate side of the street parking would be suspended on Shabuoth, a Jewish holiday, today and tomorrow.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Jersey Project
description: Environmentalists were undoubtedly pleased last week when New Jersey's Gov. William T. Cahill disclosed his reservations about the proposed Tocks Island Reservoir and Recreation Area on the Delaware River.

title: WAR FOES OUTLINE CAPITAL PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 While this Sunday's antiwar march is expected to be much like those before it here, the civil disobedience planned for Monday at the Pentagon will probably be more like the 1967 march on the Defense Department headquarters than last year's May Day.

title: ALBERT I. DICKERSON, DEAN AT DARTMOUTH
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 18 Albert I. Dickerson, dean of freshmen at Dartmouth College since 1956, died today here at his home in Norwich, Vt. He as 64 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President spent the day at Camp David where he confered with Henry Kissinger, his foreign policy adviser, and Soviet Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin. He picked the teamsters president Frank E. Fitzsimmons, to be a member of the board of directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation, succeeding the A.F.L.C.I.O. president, George Meany, who asked to step down.

title: Law Croup Head Reelected
