description: Letters to the Editor

title: Bengalis Are Building Antiflood Earthworks
description: MOWLABIR CHAR, Bangladesh, May 10Every Monsoon changes the map of southern Bangladesh, where the myriad brown waterways of the Ganges Delta tumble into the Bay of Bengal. Islands disappear and others emerge as the yearly floods, heavy with silt, redistribute the soil and alter the courses of the streams in the nation's rice bowl.

title: Screen: British Horror
description: From those gory ads, not to say the title, you expect the worst of Horror on Snape Island. Then the credits unreel. It's British, with a few familiar names. And there's hope, with original story by George Baxt, that master suspense plotter.

title: Antiques: In Baltimore
description: You have until June 16 to see a superb display of Baltimore painted furniture at the Baltimore Museum of Art.

title: Requiem for a Clown
description: I should have kissed him. I know that now. But he was after all only a clown, his face covered with grease paint and his clothes in tatters.

title: TRANSPORTAID BILL BACKED BY REA HEAD
description: The president of REA Express, Inc., appeared before a Senate subcommittee yesterday in Washington in support of the Hartke bill, S2362, which would provide up to $5billion in Federal funds to strengthen the nation's transportation system.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES LOSE SOME GAINS
description: Early gains in the prices of old crop options in soybean futures were trimmed in late dealings yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices of futures for new crop deliveries, however, held most of their early increases.

title: Airports Score Airlines Over Security
description: Airport operators assailed the nation's airlines yesterday for seeking a vast expansion of Federal security forces assigned to airports to prevent hijackings and sabotage.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A $400,000 crystal and gold menagerie has been assembled at Saks Fifth Avenue and will be on display until June 7.

title: Red Sox Beaten on 3d Shptout by Stottlemyre
description: Mel Stottlemyre Pitched shutout last night as the Yankees whipped Boston, 60. So what else is new?

title: U.N. Agency Rejects East German Bid
description: GENEVA, May 19  The World Health Organization rejected today an application for membership from East Germany despite a threat by the Soviet Union and its allies that such action would lead them to boycott next month's United Nations Conference on the Human Environment.

title: Memorial Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) President Nixon today proclaimed May 29 as Memorial Day and designated it a day of prayer for permanent peace.

title: EDWARD J. KING, 67, KENNEDYS ADVISER
description: LUDLOW, Mass., May 19Edward J. King, a labor leader who became a friend and campaign adviser to the Kennedy family, died at his home here Wednesday after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Irving brought a $1.5million law suit against Mr. Irving's former publishers, McGrawHill, charging a conspiracy to prevent them from publishing an account of how they hoodwinked McGraw  Hill with a bogus autobiography of Howard Hughes.

title: The View From Hanoi
description: HANOI, May 19Writing from North Vietnam is a strange experience. A reporter seldom goes to a country with which his own is actively at war. But it is not only the emotions that are confusing. There is the problem of facts.

title: W. LEO MURPHY
description: LA CROSSE, Wis., May 19W. Leo Murphy, board chairman of the Gateway Transportation Company of this city, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn. Mr. Murphy, who was 68 years old, had undergone openheart surgery on Monday.

title: Times Reporter Wins Prize For Articles on Police Graft
description: David Burnham, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, last night received the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City's 1972 Schaefer Gold typewriter Award for public service.

title: New Work by Miss Beck Is Sustained by Technique
description: Rosemarie Beck is, another New York artist who, although formerly an abstract painter, has pursued a steady course of representational painting during the; most recent wave of abstraction to engulf the New York art scene.

title: North Koreans Use 1953 Truce Site as Museum to Depict U.S. Aggression
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, May 19 The big white building where the Korean armistice agreement was signed 19 years ago is attracting visitors as a North Korean museum charging the United States with more than 100 years of aggression against the Korean people.

title: Bridge:
description: An expert often goes out of his way to guard against something that almost certainly will not arise. He exerts more mental effort than a lesser player would, and resigns himself to the fact that the effort will probably be wasted.

title: Simple Life Upheld
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding the right of Amish parents in Wisconsin not to send their children to school beyond the eight elementary grades fits logically into an evolving pattern of constitutional interpretations designed to protect religious principles against inroads by secular power. The opinion by Chief Justice Burger amounted to a concession that, in view of the sect's rejection of virtually all the trappings of modern life, compulsory high school instruction would constitute an assault on the Amish dogma: Be not conformed to this world.

title: T.W.A. IS SEEKING AIRLINE MEETING
description: Trans World Airlines asked the Ciyil Aeronautics Board yesterday for permission to meet with American Airlines and United Air Lines to discuss extension of a controversial agreement under which the three airlines mutually reduced flights on four competitive routes last fall.

title: The Pentagon Bombing
description: The bomb explosion at the Pentagon represents a return to the mindless display of violence as a means of registering dissent from the violence of war. The ultraradicals who boast of responsibility for this pointless act stand totally discredited by the overwhelming mass of the student generation whom they once hoped to enlist in their anarchist ranks.

title: Meskill Signs No Fault Insurance Bill
description: HARTFORD, May 19Gov, Thomas J. Meskill today signed into law Connecticut's no fault automobile insurance plan, which will take effect Jan. 1.

title: 2 Muslims Indicted In Mosque Incident
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted two Black Muslims yesterday on charges of assaulting two policemen during a, melee and shootout in a Harlem mosque last month that led to three hours of sporadic disorders.

title: Instability in Turkey
description: Turkey is mired in one of its worse crises since the founding of the Republic as it tries to preserve a parliamentary system while satisfying military demands for overdue reforms and more effective action against urban terrorism. After rejecting a sixparty coalition put together by Suat Hayri Urguplu in sixteen days of effort, President Sunay has asked Ferit Melen of the Reliance party to try to form a Government.

title: STEVE IHNAT, ACTOR AND DIRECTOR, DEAD
description: PARIS, May 19 (AP)Steve Ihnat, an actor, film director and screen Writer, died of a heart ailment in Cannes last Friday, the Canadian Embassy said yesterday. He was 37 years old.

title: DR. JOHN MERSELIS
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 19  Dr. John Merselis, an otolarynologist, died today, in Orange Memorial Hospital, Orange. He was 74 years old and lived at 321 Hartford Road.

title: Murakami Is Golf Leader
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 19 (AP)Takashi Murakami of Japan shot a fourunderpar 68 for a onestroke lead Friday after the second round of the $65,000 Pepsi Golf Tournament. Murakami had a twoday total of 138 at the 6,841yard, par72 Yokohama Country Club Course.

title: CITY'S AIR TO GET A REVISED INDEX
description: A revised system of measuring the relative cleanliness of the city's air was announced yesterday by pollutioncontrol officials who coneded that the existing index they had been reporting every day was not accurately reflecting the amount of dirt floating in the atmosphere here.

title: AntiAbortion Bill Voted in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, May 19After a daylong public hearing of the General Assembly's Joint Public Health and Safety Committee, a strict new abortion bill for Connecticut was approved by the committee, 16 to 8.

title: Dr. Clinton F. Oliver, 56, Queens. College Professor
description: Dr. Clinton F. Oliver, associate professor of English at Queens College, died Thursday at Italian Hospital of complications arising from pneumonia. He was 56 years old and lived at 50 Morningside Avenue.

title: ARTISTRY REFLECTED IN HARTMAN'S JAZZ
description: Although Johnny Hartnian has been associated with jazz ever since he came to attention as a singer in the late forties, he has always been primarily a ballad singer with a broadly appealing pop style. Those years of association with jazz may explain why he turned up at the Jazz Adventures session yesterday at noon at the Playboy Club but his singing still remains essentially pop rather than jazz.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Long or short dresses, skirts or pants, fitted waists or no waists, elaborate evening clothes or casual daytime onesthey're all available in abundance in the latest fall collections to make their debut on Seventh Avenue. It's definitely not a onenote season. The one thing everybody is agreed on is the importance of the sweater. After that, practically anything goes.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market made its second consecutive sizable advance yesterday in heavier trading as winners outnumbered losers by more than a twotoone ratio.

title: G.M. Sees Record Sales and Cites Lag for Imports
description: DETROIT, May 19The Gen eral Motors Corporation expects domestic car and truck sales for the industry to reach a record high of about 13 million units this year, an increase of more than 5 per cent over last year's high.

title: EARL TEATER
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 19 (AP)  Earl Teater, general manager of Castleton Farm for harness racing horses and trainer for the Dodge Stable of show horses, died of cancer Wednesday at Lexington hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19 (UPI) Mayor Sam Yorty, labeling a proposed HumphreyMcGovern television debate a massive votebuying effort, demanded today that he be included in any such program.

title: Repression in Greece
description: The State Department's criticism of the arrest and banishment of a prominent Greek with strong American ties serves as reminder that the Athens dictatorship has embarked on another round of repression against its opponents. John Pezmazoglu, former Deputy Governor of the Bank of Greece and the first Eisenhower exchange fellow to come to the United States from Greece, was only one of eight intellectuals seized without charge and sent to remote villages in the crackdown.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19 Senator Humphrey sequestered himself in the Beverly Hills mansion of Eugene L. Wyman, his chief backer in California, for a day of rest and quiet fundraising today.

title: Bomber Could Have Used Weatherman Title in Blast
description: The possibility that those who say they bombed the Pentagon may not have a historical claim to the title Weathermam, was raised yesterday by a number of longtime radicals.

title: Rossides Sees Widening
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) The Treasury Department's decision to investigate Japan's, subsidies to its exportminded, electronics industry may be only the beginning of a close look at similar subsidies worldwide, a high official said today.

title: Rosalie Miller, Soprano And Teacher, Dies at 84
description: Rosalie Miller, a wellknown soprano of half a century ago and a teacher in her later years, died on board the Kungsholm at Southampton, England, on Tuesday. She was 84 years Old and lived at 155 West 68th Street.

title: A Newspaper's Function
description: A newspaper's reason for being is to inform. The effective discharge of that function is always most difficultand also most importantin time of war because both sides use news as a weapon and because censorship severely restricts access to combat information.

title: EXAXELRODPARTNER CENSURED BY AMEX
description: The American Stock Exchange's board of governors said yesterday it had approved the settlement of a disciplinary action involving Clement J. Wohlreich, a regular member of the Amex.

title: Music: 2 Styles of Mass
description: Since Stravinsky's Mass (1948) was inspired by his perusal of a Mozart mass (we don't know precisely which one, somehow), it proved to be a clever notion of Abraham Kaplan to present Mozart's most popular mass, the Coronation (K. 317), and the Stravinsky on the same Collegiate Chorale program Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: SHORT INTEREST OFF AT BIG. BOARD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined by 1,749,000 sharei during the latest month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A recent Times editorial condemned efforts by students to close down universities in protest over the escalation of the war in Indochina as counterproductive and violative of the rights of other members of the academic community.

title: Laurin Predicts OneTwo Finish for His Entry, in F'reakness Today
description: BALTIMORE; May 19With the entry, of Riva Ridge and Upper Case, the solid favorite, the 97th running of.the Preakness will (take place tomorrow. A field of nine, will compete in the 1 3/16mile event, the second part of the Triple Crown for 3year:olds, between.the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes.

title: Continental Can Has Plan Rejected By Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, May 19  The European Common Market commission announced today that it was rejecting settlement proposals put forward by the Continental Can Company of the United States over its alleged infringements of antitrust regulations.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Senator James L. Buckley of New York, who unseated a Republican Senator in the 1970 election, received more than $15,000 last year for making Speeches, six of them at Republican fundraising gatherings across the country. Mr. Buckley, a Conservalive  Republican and member of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, has been in demand on the Republican dinnerspeaking circuit since he defeated Senator Charles E. Goodell a liberal Republican.

title: Term of an I.M.F. Official Extended for Four Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 The term of Frank A. Southard Jr. as deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund was extended today for four years, until Nov. 1, 1976.

title: Soviet and China Act to Speed War Aid
description: PEKING, May 19 (Renters)Chinese and Soviet officials held a series of planning sessions with North Vietnamese and Mongolian representatives here today in efforts to defeat the American blockade of North Vietnam.

title: Weaver's 140 Leads Golfby Shoi
description: MEMPHIS, May 19 (AP) Bert Weaver, seeking to become the first man in 11 years to win a tournament on his home course, fired a 69, three under par, and took the lead after the secondround today in the $175,000 Danny Thomas open golf tournament.

title: Talking to a Child Ginotes Method
description: There are 55 million parents and 3 million teachers in this country, and  well, one way or another, Dr. Haim G. Ginott, the child psychotherapist who cited the statistics, says he is determined to reach them all.

title: Art:
description: Although preColumbian art has commanded great respect in this country, modern art of Latin America has generally not received much attention. Not only have our interests been primarily, directed toward our own art and the European esthetic but there has also been a noticeable feeling that LatinAmerican modern art has been, for the most part, a derivative form of expression.

title: CANADIAN EXCHANGE CITES RULE CHANGES
description: MONTREAL, May 19 (Canadian Press)  The Canadian Stock Exchange announced today changes in the minimum requirements a company must meet to be accepted for listing and to remain listed on the exchange.

title: ARNOLD T. GINSBERG
description: Arnold T. Ginsberg, a lawyer her for 35 years until his retirement three years ago, died yesterday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 173 West 78th Street.

title: WATERBURY FIRE KILLS 5 PERSONS
description: WATERBURY, Conn., May 19 (AP)Five men died and three more were feared dead today in an early morning fire that blazed through a roominghouse and restaurant building in downtown Waterbury.

title: The Talk of Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 19There is an air of grotesque unreality to life in Hanoi. A gardener clips the hedge of the old Tonkin imperial residence. One stands outside admiring the city's magnificent trees and watching the little birds. Then the antiaircraft guns start firing. No one could miss the fact that this city is at war. The shelters everywhere, the uniforms, the guns say all that. But there remains a strange tropical tranquility. A girl bicycles by balancing baskets of spinach at either end of a bamboo pole. Walking down the street at night, one hears records of Swan Lake from a window of what turns out to be the home of Hanoi's mayor.

title: Queen Elizabeth Ends State. Visit to France
description: ROUEN, France, May 15 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth II left for home today at the end of a five  day state visit to France that put the royal seal on Britain's entry into the Common Market.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 19A folding houseboat made of fiber glass can be used also as a camping trailer. Robert D. Hawkins, president of the SeaSpace Corporation, Oyster Bay, L. I., which manufactures the craft, was granted Patent 3,662,412 for the hull design this week. The patent explains that the boat has a flatbottomed hull with hinged sides that can be extended and locked in place at water level, serving as outriggers. When they are folded up against the sides they protect the hull and facilitate transportation. The boat top can also be lowered to make a tight package.

title: AIR CRASH KILLS 9 IN NEW MEXICO
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M.,. Mayl 19 (UPI) A light airplane crashed on takeoff today, killing all nine persons aboard, including a leading biomedical scientist who has been consulted on Apollo moon missions.

title: Out of Wedlock
description: BERKELEY, Calif.We're grandparents again! Our first grandson (as yet unnamed), 9 spounds, 8 ounces, made his grand, entrance on the stage of the last half of the twentieth century at 5:17 P.M., Sunday, July 11. I guess I could say all of the usualand tritethings that are said at a time like this: a beautiful baby, a bundle of joy, the greatest child ever. He is all of thatand more.

title: CANNES PRIZES GO TO MARXIST FILMS
description: CANNES, France, May 19The awards of the 26th annual International Film Festival announced today constitute a nearly complete victory for films of a Marxist stance. The best an American film could muster was third prize.

title: BEST U.S. AID DEAL OFFERED TO DACCA
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 19 Officials of the United States Agency for International Development are negotiating an economic aid agreement with Bangladesh on terms described by an American spokesman as the most generous and flexible ever offered by the United States to any country.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In his wallet Lou Carnesecca, the general manager and coach of the New York Nets, carries a small white card with the slogan, Peacock Today, FeatherDuster Tomorrow. It's a reminder to be humble.

title: Van C. Hutto Is Dead at 44; Led C.B.S. Radio Projects
description: Van C. Hutto, traffic manager and special projects supervisor for the C.B.S. Radio Network, died at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday of an acute inflammation of the arteries. He was 44 years old and lived at 61 West Eighth Street.

title: JOHN O'SHAUGHNESSY
description: NORWICH, England, May 19 (AP)John A. O'Shaughnessy, a Democratic candidate for the State Assembly in Rochester, N. Y., died here yesterday of a heart attack while visiting relatives. He was 58 years old.

title: DR. ERNEST CAULFIELD
description: OLD LYME, Conn. May 19 Dr. Ernest Caulfield, a retired pediatrician, died on Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: United Presbyterian Assembly Withdraws From Unity Talks
description: DENVER, May 19The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church; in the U.S.A. voted late tonight to withdraw front the Constiltati On on Church Uhlon, which was formed more thin a, decade ago to seek the merger of major Protestant denathinations.

title: Miss Shelby J. Barta Married To Richard B. Goldsborough
description: PITTSBURGH, May 19Miss Shelby Jean Barta, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Edward Barta of Stoystown, Pa., was married here this afternoon to Richard Brice Goldsborough, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Brice Goldsborough of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y.

title: Holmes Gains Final.
description: GUILDFORD, England, May 19 (Reuters)Kim Warwick of Australia and Norman Holmes of Melbourne, Fla., reached the men's singles final of the Rothmans Surrey hard court tennis championships today.

title: A Million Cigarette Packs Collected in a Futile Drive
description: Millions of empty cigarette packages have been collected by hundreds of people, from employes in a Massachusetts corporation to sailors on the aircraft carrier Enterprise, to raise money for the 2yearold daughter of a garage mechanic in Crown Point, N.Y., who needs. Openheart surgery.

title: Police Detectives Investigating Death of Chinese Mission Aide
description: Homicide detectives are investigating the Feb. 7 death of a staff member of the Chinese Communist United Nations mission here, the police disclosed yesterday after the mission announced that United States authorities were helping to break the case.

title: Sidney Franklin, Producer, Dies; His Mrs. Miniver Won Oscar
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 19 (AP)Sidney Franklin, one of Hollywood's most celebrated film producers and directors, whose films included Mrs. Miniver and The Barrets of Wimpole Street, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Nixon Aide Labels Antibusing Bill Weak
description: WASHINGTON, May 19President Nixon's chief domestic adviser, John D. Ehrlichman, said today that an antibusing proposal approved by a HouseSenate conference committee Wednesday was too weak and failed to meet the President's essential criteria for busing legislation.

title: Rubbicco Charts Victory Route
description: BALTIMORE, May 19 Phil Rubbicco emerged here today as the jockey with the clearest vision of how tomorrow's 97th Preakness will be run.

title: Grote Hits Two HomersPhils Defeated, 83
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 19 Jerry Grote hit two home runs, driving in four runs, and Rusty Staub hit a home run and single driving in three to give the New York Mets an 83 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. It was their eighth straight triumph.

title: RCA Unit Gets Contracts On Two Warning Systems
description: Contracts amounting to $1022million for operition and maintenance, of the Distant Early Warning system and the Ballistic Missile Early Warning System have been received by the RCA Service Company, according to a company announcement yesterday.

title: RUMANIA REACHES ZONE SEMIFINALS
description: Rumania, with a victory in doubles yesterday by Ilie Nastase and Ion Tiriac, moved into the semifinal round of the European Zone A Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: White House Repeats Criticism Of The Times, Which Responds
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 Kenneth W. Clawson, the White House aide who accused The New York Times last night of serving in a least two specific instances as a conduit of enemy propaganda, reaffirmed his views today and said they reflected the attitude of the White House.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Art:
description: Among many good gallery exhibitions that are winding up the season at an encouraging level, there is a little cluster of three that would be a shame to missStrange Birds, a group of sculptures by Isamu Noguchi at Cordier & Ekstrom, 980 Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and, just up the block, Antonio Segui's Stylistic Exercises in Boating at Lefebre and a group of paintings by Cristobal Toral at Staempfli, both at 47 East 77th Street, and both first oneman shows in this country.

title: Pennsylvania Lags In Population Rate
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. This is a dying community, said a labor leader as he stood at the window of his office and looked out on the begrimed roofs of this steel and iron city.

title: TV Networks Plan Live Coverabe of Nixon Trip
description: President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union will be carried live 90 on tape by the three major television networks, starting Monday at 9 A.M. with his Arrival at Moscow's Vnukovo Airport from Salzburg, Austtkar.

title: BASKETBALL PLAYER CHARGED WITH RAPE
description: ATLANTA, May 19 (UPI)Torn Payne, the 7foot2inch rookie center for the Atlanta Hawks team in the National Basketball Association, was charged today with the rape of a 22yearold woman and assault with intent to rape another woman. A preliminary hearing was set for next Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am responding to your recent editorial Unlawful Character. I share your abhorrence of government regulation of admission to the bar through character tests. However, the editorial fails to see the problem and is factually deficient.

title: U.M.W. Official Held On 3 Counts in Slaying
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., May 19Albert E. Pass, a 51yearold official of the United Mine Workers from Middlesboro, Kv., was held for the grand jury today on three counts of murder growing out of the 1969 shooting deaths of Joseph A. Yablonski, a union insurgent, and his wife and daughter.

title: Waldheim, Said to Resist U.S. Gets Soviet Praise
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19Yakov A. Malik, the chief Soviet delegate, credited Secretary General Waldheim today with heeding the wishes of the Security Council and not pressure from the Westin his political activities.

title: Executive Changes
description: First National Stores has elected Alan L. Haberman as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Hillard J. Coan, who beomes chairman of the executive committee. William T. French was elected chairman and a director while Adrian O'Keefe, former chairman, becomes vice chairman of the board.

title: U.S Judge Praises 5 Peace Activists He Had Sentenced
description: BUFFALO, May 19  Five peace activists convicted of attempting to destroy draft board records in a Federal building here were placed on a year's probation today by the United States District Court Judge John T. Curtin, who called the Vietnam war. a horror and told the defendants that their love of country probably was greater than that of most people.

title: Market Place:
description: Anybody who wants an opinion on the franchise industry's stocks can call a broker and get the latest. But these reportsoften with strong sales biasdon't always ring as true as you'd like.

title: Lufthansa Orders Boeings
description: Lufthansa announced yesterday that it had ordered five Boeing 727230 aircraft and taken an option on one more. Two of the aircraft plus the option are for the carrier's own use. The remaining three have been ordered for Condor, the German airline's charter subsidiary.

title: GAS RATE ACCORD APPROVED BY F.P.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The Federal Power Commission, by a vote of 3 to 2, approved today an unusual settlement in a major naturalgas rate case involving markets in New York, New England and other areas.

title: EDWARD O'HARA, 84, SYRACUSE PUBLISHER
description: SYRACUSE, May 19Edward A. O'Hara, publisher of The Syracuse HeraldJournal from 1936 to 1958, died Wednesday night at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: Cardinal Cooke Calls for a Speedy End to the War in Southeast Asia
description: Cardinal Cooke called yesterday for a speedy end to the war in Vietnam and, while praising American motives, said that all wars are to be deplored.

title: From the Lion's Jaws Back to Life a Pilot's Story
description: ABOARD U.S.S. CONSTELLATION, in the Gulf of Tonkin, May 17Thomas R. Wilkinson's A7 Corsair jet was hit by antiaircraft fire on a bombing mission over North Vietnam today, but the Navy pilot managed to make it out to sea. He parachuted and was later plucked from the Gulf of Tonkin by a rescue helicopter as shells from enemy shore batteries pocked the water around him.

title: House Unit Approves Measure To Create Gateway Park Here
description: WASHINGTON, May 19A souse interior subcommittee today approved the creation of the first national park in a heavily congested metropolitan area with a Gateway National Urban Recreation Area extending from Jamaica Bay in Queens to Sandy Hook in New Jersey.

title: ARTHUR ARENT, 67, PLAYWRIGHT HERE
description: Arthur Arent, managing editor and head writer of the galvanic Living Newspaper of the Federal Theater Project, in the 1930's, died here Thursday at the age of 67, after an illness of several months. He lived at 35 East Ninth Street.

title: Movies
description: IT has been obvious for a long time that American filmmakers are unable to deal with the politics of the left in any recognizable way. There is a wide gulf between I Was a Communist for the FBI and The Strawberry Statement, but the two films share a total inability to portray the substance, or even the style, of radical political activity. American films about radicalism are either paranoid cartoons, like the first, or patronizing gobbledygook, like the second.

title: Glen Oaks Gains Series 1 for 73 Golf
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub series, talking place since the end of April, concluded last week with the playing of challenge rounds. The winners of each series challenged the low team of the series above them for the right to move into a higher series next year.

title: The Nation
description: There would have been 200 candles on the birthday cake, and guests were going to be invited from around the world. But last week it looked as though the partyscheduled for Philadelphia in 1976 to celebrate the nation's bicentennialhad been canceled. By a vote of 23 to 4, the American Revolution Bicentennial Committee established by Congress in 1966 to plan the celebrationrecommended that the party in Philadelphia be called off. President Nixon could overrule the committee's decision, but that is considered unlikely.

title: The World
description: HANOI  When Henry Kissinger briefed the White House press May about the decision to mine North Vietnamese ports, he ended by saying that he still hoped for a negotiated settlement. Even in Vietnam, he said, there must be some realities that transcend the parochial concern of the contestants.

title: 4 Decades of Victory For Montclair Coach
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR At first glance, the figure striding across the baseball field at Montclair State College looks like Leo Durocher. But Clary Anderson's resemblance to the Chicago Cubs manager is much deeper than just his facial features.

title: Bush Says Many at U.N. Call Mining of Ports Reasonable
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 20 (UPI)  George Bush, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that President Nixon's mining of North Vietnamese ports was regarded by many United Nations diplomats as 'a reasonable response to an unreasonable enemy.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: THERE is an old joke, perhaps so old it can be retold as new, in which a Soviet official is proudly showing an impressive Moscow subway station to an American engineer. The visitor is so enchanted that he lingers for quite a time  during which no trains pass through. When he asks, But where are the trains? the Russian indignantly replies, What about the Negroes in the South?

title: Bee Bee Bee Accolade: He Just Wouldn't Stop
description: BALTIMORE, May 20They had come out to see Riva Ridge ignite the second stage of the Triple Crown rocket, but they left soggy Pimlico today hailing an unknown long shot named Bee Bee Bee and a 44yearold jockey named Eldon Nelson.

title: BrooklynTech, at 50, Still Showcase
description: It was 50 years ago that the city opened Brooklyn Technical High School to provide a mathematics oriented, scientifictechnical education to budding engineers among gifted public school students.

title: Tulsa Nine Retains Title
description: MEMPHIS, May 18 (UPI)The Tulsa University, paced by Richard Stonebreaker's tworun homer in the final game against Bradley, captured its fourth consecutive Missouri Valley Conference baseball championship.

title: There Is Help for Consumer Bilked by the Seller
description: NEWARK  A New Yorkbased agency sent Salesmen into ghetto areas in New Jersey to sell selfhelp teaching aids in a doortodoor campaign, with the course priced at between $200 and $300.

title: ARNOLD OLIPHANT
description: Arnold Oliphant, a Wall Street research analyst for 20 years, died yesterday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 245 East 21st Street.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Two years ago, when he was not yet 18, Donald Reeves, a student. at New York's prestigious High School of Music and Art, led a kind of siege of the city's high schools. A black himself, he believed that the educational system is involved in a conspiracy to miseducate masses of Black and Puerto Rican students... to crush and penalize those individuals who even before birth are doomed to failure. The antidotes he urged were a student's bill of rights to prevent the arbitrary use of power by principals and greater community control by blacks and Puerto Ricans. This book is more than a chronicling of academic machinations; it is an autobiography of sorts, a portrait of a talented young man flailing. With the ear and eye of a born novelist Reeves reports on his childhood amidst the tropical sounds, and smells of a Jamaica private school, on his boyhood swimming away from the dope and horror and blood of Brownsville, on his affair with a white girl who used him (as, he confesses, he sought to use her). One gets the impression he became an activist as much from boredom as from frustration, As Reeves prophesied, not too much was accomplished by the movement he led. His too long, too little edited book leaves the reader wondering what will become of its author.

title: Threat to Television Show
description: HARTFORD, May 20 (AP)A bomb threat tonight to an operator taking bids for the fundraising auction for Connecticut Public Television forced the interruption of the program for about 40 minutes while the building was evacuated, station officials reported.

title: Patricia Bedell Wed To Dr. Frank Hopp
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 20In the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University here this afternoon, Miss Patricia Ann Bedell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Bedell of East Orange, was married to Dr. Frank Joseph Hopp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hopp of Clifton. Msgr. James F. Kelley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: PARLEY BACKS STEPS TO AID POORER LANDS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20, (Reuters)  The third United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, still bogged down in political squabbles as it nears its end, today took its first significant step toward bridging the gap between rich and poor nations.

title: The Nation
description: The New Yorker. You'd know him anywherehe treads the pavement warily, eyes cast down. But last week the city's Environmental Protection Administrator Jerome Kretchmer proposed legislation that might enable New Yorkers to walk with their heads held high. He asked the City Council to require owners of petsdogs in particularto clean up after their animals, or face a $25 fine.

title: APPLE TREES OUT IN HUDSON VALLEY
description: HUDSON, N.Y., May 20It's appleblossom time in the Hudson River Valley and thousands of visitors are expected to flock into the area while the floral display is at its peak.

title: This Trip Is Necessary
description: The opening tomorrow of President Nixon's historic visit to the Soviet Union is a measure of how far the world's superpowers have moved toward peaceful if competitive coexistence since the abortive summit of 1960 and the Cuban confrontation of 1962. Each side might have been tempted, for shortrun political adVantage, to call off Mr. Nixon's trip; and undoubtedly voices in both Washington and Moscow urged cancellation.

title: New Novel
description: If you didn't already know from Claude Simon's surrealist Provence that Paris is not France, you can get a powerful inkling from this beautifullyatmospheric regional etude. Normandy is Nicole Bressy's scene, a province notable for its livestock, calvados and crotchets. All three play a part in the return of the narrator to her homestead, where daddy raises prize bulls, the locals are permanently stoned, and Julie, the old housekeeper, feeds on ancient hates.

title: War Foes Anchor Harmless Mines in Newport Harbor
description: Armed Forces Day was the occasion for a series of nationwide antiwar demonstrations yesterday, but the one that got the most attention involved an anonymous letter an explosion at sea, a string of red and black balloons and what the Coast Guard at Newport, R. I., called pure coincidence.

title: Rally of Reformers, a la Hague
description: JERSEY CITY  All the signs said Mayors Coalition but all the faces said John V. Kenny.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Anthony Trollope
description: I was an early convert to the Trollope revival during World War II, and to this day the atolls of the Pacific and even the beaches of Normandy are quaintly associated in my mind with Mrs. Proudie and her henpecked bishop, with Lady Glencora and Planty Pall, with Lizzie Eustace and  my favorite of all  the desperate and unlucky Arabella Trefoil. I even recall a leave in Washington where I found my brother and his boss in the State bepartment using their rare leisure in the same pursuit. It was commonly said that in chaos we Trollopians were seeking consolation in this vision of an ordered and complacent world. If this was indeed the case, it may explain why Trollope has gained even greater popularity in the decades that have followed.

title: MEANY SAYS PAIN OF STRIKES RISES
description: George Meany, president of the A.FL.C.I.O., expressed the view on Friday that strikes so far in the nineteenseventies have had more painful and farreaching effects than they had in the nineteenthirties and that new machinery was needed to reduce the likelihood of strikes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A search for the American essence
description: This magical mystery tour of a first novel is a fairy tale of revolution no less vital for being so fashionable in its concerns. The author probes notions of a harrowing manifest destiny for America in the seventies in a hip argot that risks being dated by the new decade. Yet like Kerouac in another day, Gerald Rosen is at ease with his language, and the style of the book rings true. The content is truth of another order, the unappealable verity of the storyteller's lie.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Stephanie Sewall Betrothed
description: BOOTHBAY, Me., May 20 The engagement of Miss Stephanie Kerr Sewall to Douglas Arms Bacon has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Mark W. Sewall, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Bacon Jr. of Amherst, Mass.

title: Colleges Aid Rejected Students In Filing at 115 Other Schools
description: Many of the minority students who were unsuccessful applicants to some of the country's most prestigious colleges and universities are being helped by those schools to get admitted elsewhere.

title: Chess: Soltis's Book on the Openings Is Deserving of Close Study
description: Andrew Soltis, America's newest international master, owes at least some of his success to his painstaking study of the openings, particularly of littleknown lines. The most obvious fruits of his researches are the many victories he scores using offbeat variations, but ne is also the author of two new monographs in which he analyzes systems usually neglected by standard works on the openings.

title: Bridge So you finesse, but how?
Poets Talk To Classes In the State
description: ORADELL  The belief that poetry is only for intellectuals is being challenged in a program that brings poets into the classroom in New Jersey.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Four things can be said with some certainty about George P. Schultz, who is about to become Secretary of the Treasury:

title: Asian Religious Unit Set for Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.The Institute for Advanced Studies of World Religions has agreed to open, at the State University here, a major research facility for the study and teaching of Asian religions. The institute's collection of 20,000 volumes in more than 20 Asian and European languages will be housed in the university's Frank J. Melville Memorial Library, along with office and research facilities.

title: ELKS CLUBS DENIED TAXEXEMPT STATUS
description: MADISON, Wis., May 20The State Department of Revenue has removed the taxexempt status of seven Elks clubs in Wisconsin because the department says a survey showed that the clubs discriminated in their membership because of race.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Cunard Line Is Planning New Security Measures That Could Mean the End of Bon Voyage Parties
description: The Cunard Line, severely shaken by an extortionist's threat to blow up the Queen Elizabeth 2 at sea, is considering a broad range of measures to tighten security, including the abandonment of the decadesold tradition of bon voyage sailing parties.

title: Education
description: There was a time when nobody paid much attention to the kinds of schedules college teachers kept. As a result, many professors were able to spend a good deal of time on pursuits outside the classroom or on work not necessarily related to their primary job.

title: Josiah Marvel Is Fiance Of Miss Julia C. Biddle
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20Oliver Caldwell Biddle of Philadelphia and Mrs. George S. Mikhalapov of Crum Creek Farm, Devon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Caldwell Biddle, to Josiah Marvel, son of the late Josiah Marvel of Greenville, Del., and Mrs. Frank A. Elliott of Philadelphia.

title: EXPLOSION ROCKS SITE OF PAGEANT
description: DORADO, P. R., Sunday, May 21An explosion damaged part of a seaside hotel here last night where the Miss U.S.A. Beauty Pageant was in progress and being televised. A hotel spokesman reported that there were no injuries.

title: Berlin Roads Clogged By Visitors to East
description: BERLIN, May 20 (AP)Large traffic jams formed along the Berlin Wall and on roads leading out of the city today as West Berliners sought to visit East Berlin and other points in East Germany.

title: SAMURI IS VICTOR IN PRIMROSE SHOW
description: SOMERS, N. Y., May 20It came up mud at the Primrose Farms Horse Show today but Villa Eda Stables Samuri didn't mind at all.

title: Church Members Listed In Record of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)All the members of St. James Roman Catholic Church in Youngstown, Ohio, had their names published in The Congressional Record this week, and it cost the Government $852.50.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: WOODBURY, L.I., May 20Art Carrington of Elizabeth, N.J., seeded second, reached the final of the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championship at the Woodbury Country Club today while firstseeded Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, was forced to withdraw from his match because of illness.

title: Local Qualifying For National Open Begins Tomorrow
description: Local qualifying rounds of the United States Open golf championship will be held this week in Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey.

title: Air Crash Near Kharkov Fatal To All Aboard, Soviet Reports
description: MOSCOW, May 20The Soviet Union announced today that a domestic AN10 airliner crashed Thursday near Kharkov, killing all aboard.

title: Allsopp Wins Kelly Trophy In Stotesbury Cup Regatta
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20Chris Allsopp of Locust Valley (L.I.) High School scored a narrow singles victory of two feet over Frank Pisani of New Rochelle (N.Y.) High School to win the John B. Kelly Cub today in the 46th annual Stotesbury Cup rowing regatta on the Schuylkill River.

title: Jersey National Guard Is Short on Recruits
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Army National Guard, despite an extensive recruiting and retention program, is suffering a serious manpower shortage.

title: Miss Thompson Wed in Jersey
description: TENAFLY, N. J., May 20Miss Norma Theresa Thompson, circulation manager with Publishing Dynamics, Inc., industrial magazines in Stamford, Conn., was married here at noon today to Edward Paul Bashian, a junior executive with Bashian Brothers, Inc., of New York, importers of Oriental rugs.

title: Clancy to Get State Post: A Classic Patronage Tale
description: After years of dispensing political plums and favors to others, John T. Clancy, former Queens surrogate and Borough President, is now slated to receive a rather large plum of his own.

title: The World
description: PYONGYANG, North KoreaA century ago Korea was sometimes known in the West as the Hermit Kingdom. Not much in today's North Korea reminds one of those times, and yet the analogy does come to mind as this fiercely patriotic, intensely proud, Communist nation begins a slow and still hesitant search for new relationships with states from which it has long been cut off.

title: A Palace In the Sky For Parties In Queens
description: During my society reporting days the very thought of which causes me to mumble such words as stephanotis, bouffant, smilax and AlenconI covered the very first party thrown in the almost completed Top of the Fair.

title: Dance
description: THE New York City Ballet is a company of modernist sensibility. Life would be simpler if those who are willing to make an adjustment in their point of view when confrontect with 20th century fiction, poetry, painting or sculpture, would make the corresponding and conscious adjustment in their attitude to the New York City Ballet.

title: The World
description: Lying as it does astride the sea routes by which oil from Arabia has been shipped to Europe since the blocking of the Suez Canal in the 1967 ArabIsraeli war, the island of Madagascar has taken on a new strategic importance. The civil disorders that broke out in the former French colony 10 days ago thus had significance well beyond the island.

title: Okinawa Currency Shift Sets Off Steep Price Spiral
description: NAHA, Okinawa, May 20The reversion of Okinawa to Japanese administration Monday has set off a panicky chain reaction among the people here impulse buying, price markups, frenzied shopping and then further price increases.

title: Talking to an infant and dying in Vietnam; War Year; By Joe W. Haldeman. 122 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart Winston. $4.50.; Crossfire; A Vietnam Novel. By Gail Graham. Illustrated by David Stone Martin. 135 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $4.50. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Military tacticians know that very young men make very good foot soldiers. Nations as different as China and Israel know that their national survival may depend on how well they persuade their chil dren to accept a romantic heroic view of death One wonders how many German children would have marched off to war if so much of German literature had not softened them up for it; or how many Japa nese youths would have volunteered for kamikaze raids if, their child hoods had not been so full of the folklore of heroism.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON  Should President Nixon's welfare reform bill, the Family Assistance Plan, he killed? Some of those most insistent on the need for a more humane and generous welfare system now believe that it should. And since many of those who don't like any kind of welfare program always have been willing to kill F.A.P., it may well become one of the most prominent casualties of Mr. Nixon's Administration.

title: Announcements 5000
description: Engagements 5022

title: 2d Stanford Fire in 2 Days
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., May 20 (UPI)Stanford University had its second major fire in two days when Lathrop House was badly damaged last night by a blaze. The 23 coeds who lived inside the threestory building were evacuated, but there were no injuries. Mecha House, the campus Chicano headquarters was destroyed by fire the night before.

title: MAN HELD IN DEATH OF A CRIPPLED BOY
description: HOUSTON, May 20 (AP)A 36yearold man was charged with murder and assault to murder today after he allegedly pushed two young brothers in wheelchairs off the edge of a boat dock. One of the boys drowned.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The second installment (the first was published by Syracuse in 1963 at $7.95) of a scholarly threevolume biography of the homespun Nebraska Progressive who, to improve the quality of American life, waged a lifelong battle against inertia and special interests, During the two decades covered here, the odds ran heavily against him: The nation was becoming predominantly urban and a world power; during most of the period conservatives of his own Republican party occupied the White House. In the age of Coolidge he fought against Andrew Mellon's tax reforms, which accelerated the concentration of economic power; in Hoover's term he resisted further monopolizing measures and the President's selfdefeating measures to combat the Depression. As a son of the Middle Border, Norris was an isolationist, opposing American entry into World War I and disdaining the Versailles treaty. He did, however, support disarmament, favored recognition of the Soviet Union and espoused China's cause against Japanese imperialism, This is a thoroughly researched biography, balanced in its judginents, the first worthy of a man because of whose dreams as Hiram Johnson put it human beings may be a bit happier.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GOLD PRICES spurted in Europe's free markets, reaching a high of $62 an ounce at midweek and then receding to $57.05 in the London market at the close of the week. Gold prices have risen more than 30 per cent since the first of the year and have pushed up goldmining stocks by 25 per cent. In the meantime, the United States balance of payments showed a marked improvement in the first quarter, the Department of Commerce reported. The payments deficit, on the officialreservetransactions basis of measurement, receded to $3.5billion from $6.3billion in the final quarter of 1971 and $12.2billion in the third quarter.... The Commerce Department also reported that corporate profits before taxes rose by $5.6billion, or 6.5 per cent, in first quarter to a record $91.6billion, up 10.4 per cent from the yearearlier level. Aftertax corporate profits at. $52.3billion rose $2.6billion from previous quarter, and were up $7.5billion from first quarter of 1971.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BOUND BROOK  Walking down Bound Brook's Main Street, one sees an occasional dark line at about shoulder level on the sides of some white painted buildings. The lines are the highwater marks left by the 5foot wave that followed in the wake of Doria's gale force winds when the Raritan River flooded the town last August.

title: SOVIET STRESSING HUMAN RELATIONS
description: MOSCOW, May 20  The SoViet Union, having more or less satisfied the basic material needs of its population, is turning its attention increasingly to the more intangible problem of human relations.

title: 218 Yachts to Start Block Island Race Friday
description: Four of last year's overall class champions, as well as the firstplace finisher on elapsed time, will be part of a huge 218boat fleet entered in the 200mile 27th annual Block Island Race starting Friday.

title: COUGAR II TAKES RICH COAST RACE
description: INGLEWOOD, May 20Cougar II, the Chilean blazer, won the $133,900 Californian at Hollywood Park today to become the top foreignbred money winner in United States thoroughbred racing.

title: 3 CHILDREN BURNED TO DEATH IN HARLEM
description: Three young children were burned to death last evening, when a fire swept an apartmeat in a newly renovated tenement building at 2211 Eighth Avenue, near 119th Street, in Harlem.

title: The Arabs were never more Arabian
description: A Western diplomat once told me that he thought diplomacy in the Arab world was to ordinary diplomacy what three dimensional chess was to ordinary chess. You must pretend to be operating on one set of assumptions, he said, while you are actually operating on another, and what you decide has to make sense in relation to both.

title: Padres. Stop. Reds
description: SAN DIEGO, May 20 (UPI) Leron Lee, hitting safely in his 15th straight game, drove in a pair of runs with a homer and a single tonight as the San Diego Padres defeated Cincinnati, 53; to halt the Reds ninegame winning streak.

title: Music Mailbag
description: THERE are few developments, changes or trends to report about the coming summer music scene. Now that Washington has its Kennedy Center it can expect to be entertained there during what used to be the off season. A twoweek run of Leonard Bernstein's Mass and a series of National Symphony concerts have already been booked, and more presentations are promised. A few of the smaller summer series have been abandoned for reasons of economy, but replacements have sprung up elsewhere. To name one Sarah Lawrence College, in Bronxville, N. Y., will be offering concerts in connection with its new seminars on ensemble playing from early music to jazz.

title: WALLACE MORALE IS REPORTED HIGH
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 20Gov. George C. Wallace's condition remained unchanged in a hospital here today. There was no rurther word from his doctors on when and where bullet lodged in his spinal canal will be removed.

title: King Is Named Director Of All Racing by USAC
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 20Dick King, the supervisor of the United States Auto Club's championship division, has been appointed director of competition for the entire club.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The husbandwife team of Maj Sjowall and Per Wahloo have had a pretty secure lock on Swedish mystery fiction, but they are not alone, and a young man named 011e Hogstrand is going to give them some competition. Hogstrand's first book, translated by Elina Leliy, has just come out. It is ON THE PRIME MINISTER'S ACCOUNT (Pantheon, $4.95), fastmoving, wellconstructed work that combines high politics, kidnapping, blackmail and police procedure in a neat package.

title: MGOVERN LIKELY TO WIN IN OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 20George McGovern looks to be the certain winner of Oregon's Democratic Presidential primary election next Tuesday.

title: Two Are Injured by Blast in a Manhole in Harlem
description: A manhole explosion of unusual force injured at least two persons and blew out windows in more than two dozen tenements in Harlem yesterday morning.

title: MARYLAND GAINS IN LACROSSE, 93
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 20 (AP)John Kaestner led the attack with six assists today as Maryland won its opening contest in the National Collegiate lacrosse tournament 93, from Rutgers.

title: Fight of Roussel's Life?
description: NEW ORLEANSHe wears a diamondstudded model of an oil derrick for a tiepin, a $5,000 wristwatch with diamond numerals, a threecarat diamond ring, a small gold belt buckle and a $6 health bracelet ringed with magnets.

title: Cynthia SaltzmanWed To Warren Motley 2d
description: Miss Cynthia Myrick Saltzman was married here yesterday afternoon to Warren Motley 2d. The Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.

title: 2 AGENCIES URGED ON ELECTRIC NEED
description: A study of the nation's decisionmaking process for electricity needs has concluded with recommendations for the creation of two new, unifying Federal agenciesone to handle all energy research and development and another body to advise Congress on future energy policies.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Rusty Staub slid into second base with a clean steal on that particular night in Atlanta two years ago, he added a few happy extras to the procedure. While still stretched out on the ground, he slapped the bag with an open hand and waved a friendly fist in the direction of Donald Davidson of the Braves in the press box. Then he spoke to Felix Milian, the Atlanta second baseman. This is mine, said Rusty, slapping the bag again. The bewildered Felix didn't know what he was talking about, but high up in the press box aerie, Davidson understood every gesture. Little Donald, the world's smallest traveling secretary, reached for the phone and gave instructions to the groundskeeper. Shortly after the game ended, the groundskeeper approached Rusty in the clubhouse and formally handed him the base he had stolen.

title: W. NORTON WOODS, FARM COOP LEADER
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 20W. Norton Woods, a promoter of agribusiness with hybrid corn and tomato seeds and president for 10 years of a state farmers cooperative, died yesterday in Toledo Hospital. He was 82 years old and had lived in suburban Monclova Township.

title: Miss Kleinerman To Marry Aug. 27
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, May 20Miss Eugenie Kleinerman and Leonard A. Zwelling, students at the Duke University School of Medicine, will be married Aug. 27 in Shaker Heights.

title: With Surprising Ease, Women Create Waves in College Rowing
description: The Northeastern crew that won the Eastern college sprint championships last Saturday is a big, brawny group, averaging 195 pounds in weight, 6 feet 3 inches in height. The Princeton crew that won a similar championship last Sunday went about 140 pounds in weight, 5 feet 6 in height, and was devoid of bulging muscles. The Princetonians were women and they rowed very skillfully, reflecting the three months of 1hour workouts at 6:30 A.M., five days a week.

title: Canadian Commission Would Legalize the Possession of Marijuana
description: MONTREAL, May 20A Canadian Government commission recommended this week that the possession of marijuana be legalized but that selling it remain a crime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Pays City for Oil Spill
description: The Navy has paid New York City SS6,246,41 for costs incurred in cleaning waterfronts at Coney Island in Brooklyn and at South Beach on Staten Island, after 40,000 gallons of oil spilled from a Navy ship last July 16, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday,

title: Judge Dembitz Gains Support Of 6 of City's Representatives
description: Six of the city's Democratic Representatives endorsed Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz yesterday for their party's nomination for the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: New Ithaca College Dean
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 20 (AP) Dr. William B. Koch will become dean of the school of Health, Physical Education and Recreation at Ithaca College July 1. Dr. Koch is now an associate professor of physical education at Western Kentucky University.

title: Scholarship Fund, 15 Years of Success
description: TEANECK  The Community Scholarship Fund of Teaneck, marking its 15th anniversary today, is pausing only briefly for celebration in the midst of its annual efforts toward aiding Teaneck youngsters in pursuit of higher education.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The practical questions on the NixonBrezhnev agendathe control of strategic weapons, the expansion of trade, the Joint exploration of space, etc.have all been settled or almost settled in advance, so there will be plenty of time to discuss the problems of ending the war in Vietnam and avoiding another ArabIsraeli convulsion in the Middle East.

title: Art; L.A. Art? Interesting  But Painful
description: FOR some years it has been fashionable in some circles to opine that Californiaand, In particular, Los Angeleswill eventually equal New York as a fountainhead of American art and culture. Indeed, some people claim it has already happened, though what they have in mind,, rather perversely, is just the sheer torrent of variously gagaand sinister phenomena that makes the West Coast one of the funniest and scariest places in the world. Most of our really viable and influential art and literary (as opposed to life) styles; meanwhile, continue to enjoy their richest and hardiest growth here by the Hudson.

title: Heads of the Thundering Herd
description: The founder of Merrill Lynch was Charles Edward Merrill, who, in the words of the M. L. house organ, had the physique of a Plymouth Rock rooster, the savvy and courage of a horse trader and the soul of a poet. He grew up in Jacksonville, Fla., where his father was a doctor. According to the semiofficial hagiography, Merrill got his first stake of $75 when he sold a very prcifitable newspaper route he had developed in Jacksonville. He would station himself at the edge of the redlight district and sell lots of papers to men who were anxious to cover their faces as they left the area.

title: New Novel
description: Mrs. Emerson is an abstracted Baltimore dowager, rattling around in a Victorian mansion filled with eightday clocks and deserted by her grownup children. Some of these filter back from time to time, stirring up tangential flurries of activity. All are as indeterminate as the mother, secure in her sealed, weightless bubble floating through time, but not as indestructible. Timothy, a medical student, has selfdestructive leanings. Matthew whiles away his days as assistant to an alcoholic country newspaper editor. Peter, a brilliant student, expends his promise teaching chemistry in a secondrate girls school.

title: Japan Plans Program to Adjust HerTrade and Spur the Economy
description: TOKYO, May 20The Gov ernment decided today on a wideranging series of rneastires, described as an emergency program, to deal with Japan's growing payments surplus, huge accumulation of dollar reserves and lagging domestic economy.

title: Trend or Coincidence?; Disposal Rate of Player Representatives Is Up Sharply Since End of Last Season
description: When Jack Aker was sold by the New York Yankees to the Chicago Cubs for the $25,000 waiver price last week, he became the eighth team player representative to be traded, sold, sent to the minors or released outright since the baseball players began taking a strike vote in early March.

title: The River To Pickle Beach
description: Among those Southern women who have contributed so vigorously to postwar American fiction, Doris Betts has never quite got her due. She is a tough, wise and compassionate writer; her last book, The Astronomer and Other Stories, is among the best collections of short fiction of the 1960's, but outside her native North Carolina her audience has been small.

title: School Bus Seat Belts Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) Representative Seymour Halpern. Republican of Queens, proposed today that school buses be required to have seat belts.

title: Lieut, John Cassella Weds Miss Taylor
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., May 20 Miss Claire Eloise Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry William Taylor, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. John Woodson Cassella, U.S.A.F., son of Dr. and Mrs. William Nathan Cassella Jr. of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. The Rev. Charles W. Wilding performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Leaders'
description: No more let us falter! From Malta to Yalta! Let nobody alter!

title: NoFault Car Insurance May Set Off a Long Debate
description: TRENTON  Instead of settling the issue, the nofault auto insurance bill passed last week by the New Jersey Legislature is expected to inspire heated debate for some time to come.

title: PhilsDefeated,31 and 21; Matlack and Koosman Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20The streaking New York Mets, the hottest they've been since they won the world championship in 1969, swept a doubleheader with the Phillies by scores of 31 and 21 tonight. A crowd of 36,697, the largest ever to see the Mets play in Philadelphia, saw the New Yorkers win their ninth and 10th in a row and their 12th and 13th in the last 14 games.

title: First Woman Is Named To M.I.T. Dean's Post
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 (AP)Dr. Carola B. Eisenberg has been appointed dean of student affairs at Massachusetts Insitute of Technology, a position in which she will be in charge of the 3,764 men and 390 women students at the school.

title: National Wildlife Refuges To Charge Daily Visitor Fee
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The Interior Department has announced that daily fees will be charged for public use of a dozen national wildlife refuges.

title: ExSS Leader in Bolivia Denies WarCrime Charge
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 20 (AP) Klaus Altmann, a Germanborn Bolivian citizen, admitted today that he headed a special command of the SS, Hitler's Elite Guard, in France during World War II and used the pseudonym Klaus Barbie.

title: VETERANS APPEAL FOR GAINS IN AID
description: URBANA, Ill., May 20About 200 Vietnam veterans, burdened by rising college costs and frustrated by delays in receiving G.I. Bill benefits, have urged Congress to begin an immediate effort to retrain, reeducate and rehabilitate veterans.

title: Youth Has Civic Role In Teaneck
description: TEANECK  Three hun. dred twenty Teaneck High School seniors left school last Monday to begin five wefes of concentrated service to the cortimunity. Unlike most volunteer programs, which provide a few hours a week of service, Teaneck High's communityservice project keeps its volunteers on the job five days a week, at least five hours a day.

title: Hanoi Reports Raids
description: HONG KONG, May 20 (Reuters)North Vietnam said the Hanoi area had been savagely attacked by American aircraft today.

title: PENN CREW WINS IN BURK CUP RACE
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20Penn's varsity eightoared crew, beaten in its lest two races, turned the tables on Northeastern today on the Schuylkill when it won the Burk Cup for the second straight year by 10 foot margin, Northeastern took the Junior varsity and freshman races by substantial margins.

title: ASTROS BEATEN BY DODGERS, 30
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UPI)  Al Dawning hurled a twohit shutout tonight to dispose of the Houston Astros, 30, in the clubrecord time of 1 hour 30 minutes as the Dodgers regained first place in the National League West.

description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., May 20 (UPI)Johnnie M. Walters, Internal Revenue Commissioner, accused many businessmen today of dabbling in tax avoidance and evasion schemes. He said Federal tax agents would make closer audits of big companies to guard against such deception.

title: Wilton Free Schoolls Making It
description: WILTON Conn. May 20My mother said free schools don't work, said 11yearold Kevin Rccd, a student at the Learning Community, a new progressive education school in this affluent Fairfield County community.

description: SNYDER, N. Y., May 20Dr. and Mrs. John W. Boylan of Snyder and Bar Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Wilson Boylan, to Douglas Castle Townson 2d, son of Mrs. Martin deRham of Marbella, Spain, and Gstaad, Switzerland, and the late William Werner Townson.

title: Home Grown
description: $1.05 said a supermarket's vegetabledepartment manager as he took two plump tomatoes from a scale. Aghast, his customer exclaimed, At that price you can keep them! and stalked out.

title: The Price of Utopia On One Island...
description: MONHEGAN ISLAND, Me.This island of rare beauty and some danger lies 10 miles offshore and a million light years away from the megalopolitan sprawl that inhabitents of the Eastern Seaboard call civilization. Mingling each summer with its 40 or so permanent residents are the members of an artists colonymore than 20 professionals, many of them temporary refugees from Manhattan. Ail are Individualists, some quite celebrated. Yet all are in thrall to the overpowering personality of the island; Monhegan is the only genuine celebrity here.

title: Bangladesh Food Airlift Pressed
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 20Flight preparations for a massive airborne food relief program for Bangladesh are rapidly going forward here on a commitment of $1.5million in Federal funds that have been authorized for its support.

title: The World
description: In the last great battle of World War II in the Pacific, American forces in 1945 seized the Japanese bastion of Okinawa. Since then, the United States has built the island into its own strongpoint in the Western Pacific.

title: Chef Hands Us Our just Desserts
description: MONTAGUE  Bernhard Oesen, the pastry chef at the Holiday Lake clubhouse, wants to see that Americans get their just desserts.

title: Ten Versions Of America
description: The title is misleading. In fact the book contains only one version of America, which runs roughly like this: If there was a good American dream of individual freedom and plenty, then (quoting Tom Wolfe quoting Ken Kesey) WE BLEW IT? In effect, Mr. Nelson offers 10 versions of this thesis through biographical outlines of the chief characters of Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises, Fitzgerald's Tender Is the Night, Vonnegut's God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater, Nathanael West's Miss Lonelyhearts, Djuna Barnes's Nightwood, Flannery O'Connor's Wise Blood, Saul Bellow's Seize the Day, Philip Roth's Goodbye, Columbus, Joseph Heller's Catch22, and Nabokov's Lolita. They prove, Mr. Nelson concludes, that the effect of the American experience on the individual who cannot adjust to the mindless mass ranges from impotence, disappearance and despair to madness, martyrdom and murder, with cynical withdrawal and panic flight as further alternatives. Mr. Nelson's method ignores that fact that the characters exist only in fictional space and assumes that the 10 novels are accurate accounts of the state of America. The special complexity of each book is drastically simplified, with the result that the characters tend to run together in one metamorphizing metaoharacter.

title: First Big Overnight Race of Season Run on Sound

description: Col. Hans Jay, a World War II German army officer, who during the occupation of France served as an aide of Gen. Dietrich von Choltitz, the last German commander of the Greater Paris area, died Thursday in Kilcock, Ireland, at the age of 77.

description: INDIANAPOLIS  One of the more memorable unsolicited testimonials by a sporting figure was uttered by Jules Goux, a Frenchman who in 1913 proclaimed, Sans le bon vin, je n'aurais pas dtd d'Otre vainqueurt (Without the good wine, I could not have been the winner!), a tribute to the four bottles of champagne he consumed while speeding to first place in the third Indianapolis 500Mile Race.

title: Ford to Build Transit System

title: The World
description: LONDONLast Tuesday, a car car rying William Whitelaw, the man in charge in the new regime of direct British rule over Northern Ireland, was punched and kicked by Roman Catholic women in the border town of Newry. One woman shrieked: Now you know what it's like to be hated!

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For several years now have watched with interest the buildings chosen to receive the annual awards of the American Institute of Architects A.I.A. Bestows Awards, [April 30.] I must confess that my reactions to the buildings chosen have all been visceral and I want to cry enough.

Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today. Mr, Reuss has been pressing for amendments to the pending revenuesharing bill that would close tax loopholes.

Thirteen per cent held them inadequate and the rest had no opinion.

title: Why Merrill Lynch Is Bullish About Merrill Lynch
description: WHEN William Wilson Hewitt Jr., a lanky, white haired, 43 year old necromancer, opens his goldwalled shop on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, N. Y., at 8:15 A.M., he doesn't have to dust. His everreplenishing inventory is invisible. And rather like the strange items carried by J. W. Wells & Co., family sorcerers, Hewitt's stock is also sometimes cursed, occasionally blessed, and a very rare few will give customers everfilled purses. If only they were tagged more clearly! On demand Hewitt and his staff can conjure up any one of nearly 15,000 different items. For $5,000 you can acquire a single share of stock in HoffmanLaRoche, the Swiss drug firm; for $8,000 a share of CocaCola International; for $1,000 a minimum purchase of a speculative mutual fund; or $250 will enable you to gamble on the future price of 50,000 pounds of Maine potatoes.

title: Political Gunfare
description: The scenario has become terrifyingly familiar. After the assassin's bulletsthe numbing shock, the fear a wider plot or spreading chaos, then the shame and finally the explanationaccurate but inadequatethat, really, in so large a country there can never be safety from the demented deeds of a minute fringe of the insanely and unpredictably violent. And so it was again when sudden shots felled Governor Wallace last week.

title: Dr. Sam
description: The bizarre, truncated life of Dr. Sam Sheppard, the Cleveland osteopath who after 10 years imprisonment was cleared of the murder of his wife Marilyn. Although vindicated in a second trial run by F. Lee Bailey, Sheppard could not put his life together again. He tried to reestablish a medical practice, divorced a second wife, remarried, engaged in professional wrestling, drank heavily and died of a fiver ailment. It's a sad story, and one feels for Dr. Sam, As for the jacket's promise of new information on the crime, there is precious little of that. What really happened in the early morning hours at the Sheppard's Baby River home remains a mystery.

Anderson, a sixth grade teacher and 1950 A.I.C. graduate.

title: Cahill on a Tightrope With His Tax Plan
description: TRENTONJust in case the Legislature didn't get the message, Governor Cahill handed out a set of figures Thursday that illustrated far better than anything he could tell the joint legislative session how his proposed tax reforms would cut property taxes wholesale throughout the state.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to the Cabot Trail, the route is by ferry from Bar Harbor, Me. (a 100mile trip) or from Portland, Me. (200 miles) to Yarmouth, the southern tip of Nova Scotia. From there it's an allday drive across the province to the Canso Causeway, the link with Cape Breton Island. Some say this allday drive to Cape Breton is tedious, but even they add that once you get to Cape Breton the scenery there makes the journey worthwhile. The trail and the rest of the island is fairly busy with tourists through the end of September. There are motels, cottages and a few guesthouses, and for sybarites there is the Keltic Lodge at Ingonish Beach, which charges up to $40 a day a person, American plan. Details about accommodations may be obtained from the Nova Scotia Information Office, Suite 3115, 630 Fifth Avemie, New York 10020.

title: Alicia Zintl Wed to Edwin Russell
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 20  Miss Alicia Zintl, daughter of Mrs. LeRoy K. McCune of Wilmington and the late Robert Trainor Zintl, was married here this afternoon to Edwin Larson Russell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Fortune Russell of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Miss Burfeindt's 71 For 139 Holds Lead In Bluegrass Golf
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20 (UPI)Betty Burfeindt, relying heavily on her long drives, withstood a rally today by Mrs. Kathy Cornelius to retain her twostroke lead in the second round of the $25,000 Bluegrass Invitation golf tournament.

title: Golf Clubs Urged to Give Youth A Swing as Survival Measure
description: A greater percentage of youthful members, less formality at dances, and introduction of notie parties were among survival measures recommended for metropolitan golf clubs during a recent session of private club presidents.

title: Spain Wins Doubles for 30 Edge, Clinches Davis Cup Series With France

The victory gave Spain a 30 lead in the threeoffivematch series, The Associated Press reported.

title: 44 Hurt in Protest in Manila

title: HAROLD AUST
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UPI) Harold (Ted) Aust, former circulation manager of The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer, a Hearst publication, died yes, terday at his home in Cheviot Hills. He was 79 years old.

title: ROSS, FINN IN FINAL AT WESTCHESTER NET
description: ARMONK, N.Y., May 20Steve Ross, the topseeded player seeking his third straight title, and Andy Finn reached the final of the Westchester tennis tournament today. Rain forced the matches indoors at the Armonk Tennis Club.

title: U.S. May Acquire River
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The Council on Environmental Quality and the Corps of Engineers recommended Thursday that a 30mile stretch of the Oklawaha River in Florida he designated for potential inelusion in the National Wild and Scenic River System. The stretch runs from the St. Johns River to Dead River Swamp.

title: Incidents at Sea
description: The two Governments are also expected to announce in Moscow final details on anagreement aimed at avoiding collisions and other harassment between naval vessels of the two countries on the high seas. During periods of tensionand even in times of calmSoviet and American naval vessels have tended to follow one another so closely that collisions have occurred, as well as many near collisions. American officials believe that the agreement is symbolically important because it is the first one negotiated by each nation's Imilitary establishment since they were allies in World War II

title: M'DERMOTT NAMED TOP N.Y.U. ATHLETE
description: Mike McDermott, the New York University career recordholder in the 35pound weight and hammer throws, has been named as the school's outstanding athlete for the 197172 season.

title: Pop

And yet, listening to a collection of Joplin's performances just released by ColumbiaJoplin In Concert (Columbia C2X31160 2 disks) makes those rapidly receding days come vividly, and sadly, to lila once again.

title: Dance

Britain's Royal Balletthe larger companystarted its current season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, on Oct. 9 of last year. The season continues through Aug. 5 of this year, during which time the company is in the process of giving a sixweek New York season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: A MEDICINE MAN HEARD AT PARLEY
