title: Life With Father Hitler
description: THE Phantom is about to strike again. And you'd better watch out, especially if your name is Heinrichor Hitler. The Phantom, of course, is the fearless hero of the King Features comic strip created by Lee Falk, and Hitler is the 84yearold Adolf Hitler, who has been hanging out in South America for the past couple of decades with his heinous son, Heinrich. At least that's the way the story goes in The Phantom vs. the Fourth Reich, a movie which will star Peter Sellers as the notorious Naziand son.

title: YANKS RAINED OUT; PLAY 2 HERE TODAY
description: Heavy rains early In the day forced the Yankees to postpone their scheduled afternoon baseball game against the Boston Red Sox yesterday at Yankee Stadium. The teams will play regularly scheduled doubleheader starting at 1 P.M. today.

title: Music
description: NO mystery in the history of arts and letters, except for the questions about the ident'tY of Shakespeare himself and his Dark Lady of the SOnnets, has enjoyed a longer or more popular run than the puzzle of Beethoven's Immortal Beloved. In the 146, years since the composer's death, mountains of steamy prose have been heaped on the subject, and more than a dozen candidates for the title have been advanced by musicologists and biographers, none convincingly. Who was this unsterbliche Geliehte, the woman to whoM Beethoven wrote a wildly romantic, almost deranged, love letter on July 6 and 7 1812? If ever a riddle sermed likely to remain unsolved, it was this hoary one.

title: Transpo 72 to Open Saturday Amid a Traffic Jam of Its Own
description: WASHINGTON  Next Saturday afternoon, shortly after 1 o'clock, a barrage of model rockets will roar into the sky above Dulles International Airport to release 100,000 balloons, and 110 parachutists bearing the flags of the United States, the 50 states and 59 foreign countries will bail out of passing aircraft and float slowly to earth. This spectacular aerial collage will signal the opening of Transpo 72, the first international exposition devoted to land, sea and air transportation, which will continue at Dulles from May 27 to June 4.

title: Drug sisters with the same dream
description: Pascale, 21, and Mireille, 18, are drug sisters, children of the same dreamveteran heroin addicts when this book begins, and likely to remain so after it ends, though their attempted cure was part of the project that produced the book. Their story is a somewhat foreign chapter in the journal of this plague, and the reader must do some cultural translating to benefit by its insight into the love and hopelessness that binds junkies to their drug, the stereotyped, monotonous life they lead on hero (lit only by flashes of panic when they run out of it), and the frightened and vindictive societal attitudes that defeat any attempt to help them.

title: A $2Million Kidney Fund Is Sought to Honor Bunche
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20An international drive has been opened here to raise $2million for treatment and research in kidney disease as a living memorial to the late Ralph Bunche, former Under Secretary General. Dr. Bunche, who died last December, had been a victim of kidney disease.

title: Claridge, 13 Years Old, Wins By 4 Lengths at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., May 20Claridge, a 13yearold Australianbred gelding owned by David H. Wallach of Philadelphia, won the $7,500 Pitman Purse by four lengths today at Freehold Raceway.

title: On Bolstering County Government...
description: TRENTON  For the better part of a decade, reform groups in New Jersey have been waging a campaign to modernize county government so it could become an effective force in dealing with problems that cross municipal lines.

title: From Unemployment Insurance to Championship
description: SIX weeks ago, an obscure, 32yearold actor and playwright named Jason Miller was standing on line at an unemployment insurance office in Queens, wondering how much longer he would be able to pursue a career in the theater. He had a wife and three young children to support, and his prospects seemed grim. There were 16,000 actors in New York, he recalled, and how many plays, how many jobs? Miller was convinced that, barring a sudden turn in his fortunes, he would have to find a livelihood elsewhere.

title: Benefit for Animal Shelter
description: A oneman show of canine portraits by Alton Anderson is being held at 20 South Main Street, New City. N.Y., for the benefit of the HiTor Animal Care Center. The show, depicting color photos of more than 20 breeds, will run through May 29.

title: U.S. Rob Team Wins Cup
description: COWDRAY PARK, England, May 20 (AP)James Sharp of Tulsa, Okla., led his Greenhill Farm polo team to a 42 victory today over Pimms, an English club, to win the final of the Jersey Lilies Challenge Cup.

title: FLORIDA PLAYERS REGAIN STABILITY
description: The Jacksonville Symphony Orchestra has had several things to celebrate. It has become stabilized after ardissolution two years ago, with the acquisition of a new conductor, Willis Page, this season. And the Florida city is currently observing the 150th anniversary of its founding.

title: A NEW DIRECTORY LISTS BLACK UNITS
description: More than 200 black organizationsreligious, professional, political, fraternal, educational, civic and businesshave been described and listed in the new DirectoryNational Black Organizations.

title: Miss Lipscomb Lawyer's Bride
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., May 20The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Lipscomb, daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. C. Lloyd Lipscomb Jr. of Rochester, to Edward Truesdell Robinson took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Horace B. B. Robinson, a partner with the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, and Mrs. Robinson of New York and Chilmark. Colonel Robinson, a chemical engineer, is retired from the Army and from the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Strategic Arms Limitation
description: There seems no question but that the 1972 summit meeting will be best remembered for the unveiling of the first SovietAmerican limitation on strategic arms. Barring some last minute hitches, the two sides seem to have just about wrapped up the first phase of the negotiations, which began in November, 1969. Aside from the details of the accord, the agreement is important because it indicates that the United States and the Soviet Union have dropped efforts to secure unilateral advantages in the arms race. The two superpowers now are agreed in principle on what Mr. Brezhnev has called equal security for both sides.

title: Streicher Dancers Cover Wide Range In Satan's Games
description: Robert Streicher, a choreographer whose ideas literally range from the mundane to the visionary, presented three works, Satan's Games and Other Dances Friday night at Washington Square tethodist Church with the Robert Streicher Dance Company.

title: His Thing Is Herbs  200 Kinds
description: PORT MURRAYLife Is variety of spices to Cyrus Hyde, who raises herb plants and dried flowers on the WellSweep Farm in this village, six miles west of Hackettstown in the northwest corner of New Jersey. His credo: to make the land produce our food and livelihood.

title: An Ideal Place to Write
description: QUOGUE, L. I.Budd Schulberg is a study these days in what has made Budd Schulberg settle down after years as a migratory writer in such places as Hollywood, Bucks County, Mexico City and New York. It is not that he is tired of running at the age of 5S so much as it is that he has found what he considers the ideal place to write.

title: Frisco Express, $9, Wins
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., May 20 (AP)Frisco Express, a 7yearold gray gelding, won the $2,100 feature today at Finger Lakes. Deltas Gem was second. The winner's time over six furlongs was 1:13 and he paid $9, $4.40 and $2.60 for $2 across the board.

title: W.N. Farran, 3d And Anne Culp Have Nuptials
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa., May 20Miss Anne Rawlings Roberts Culp was married this afternoon to William Neely Ferran 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Benner Farran of Philadelphia. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Campbell Culp of Yardley.

title: Man Crushed to Death Here By Car After an Argument
description: A 27yearold Brooklyn man was crushed to death between a parked car and a station wagon driven by a man he was arguing with, the police said.

title: Photography
description: RTHUR Tcholakian's The Majesty of the Black Woman (Van Nostrand Reinhold Co., $14.95 hardbound) is so oldfashioned a book that its appearance at this time bemuses me greatly. Certainly there is a legitimate need  perhaps even a demandfor a volume of portraits of black women; but, though such a project is long overdue, the basic failing of this book is that it approaches its task with premises which are not only outdated but actually anachronistic.

title: 50 Serious Young Musicians Will Wind Up a Year's Work Tomorrow
description: MILLBURN  A festive endofseason concert at the Paper Mill Playhouse here at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow winds up the musical year for the 50 serious young musicians of northern New Jersey's Young Artists Chamber Orchestra.

title: Boeing to Get $12.1Million For Development of SST
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The Boeing Company of Seattle, has been awarded a $12.1million contract for work done in the development program of the supersonic transport, according to Secretary of Transportatiton John A. Volpe.

title: Jacobs Is Upset in New York A. C. Handball Semifinal
description: The two topseeded players in the third annual New York Athletic Club fourwall handball tournament were upset yesterday in play at the Athletic Club.

title: The Nation
description: How guard them, then, the candidates? Float them in bulletproof bubbles over upturned faces? Add more Secret Service men? Portable booths like Eichmann's wired for sound? Or quarantine capsules like those the first men from the moon returned to?

title: Nuptials Held for Karen K. Kelley
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., May 20  Miss Karen Kay Kelley and Barry Frank Fahr were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Gene Mulcahy performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Hartford Art School of the University of Hartford.

title: An apolitical Israeli
description: Amos Oz at 33 has clearly established himself as one of Israel's most gifted and original writers. The four volumes of fiction he has produced so far exhibit a growing artistic control over the hallucinatory vision of spiritual and sexual unrest that is his hallmark as a novelist. My Michael, a virtually unprecedented bestseller when it first appeared in Israel in 1968, is his first fulllength work to be published in English, and in Nicholas de Lange's admirable translation it should give English readers a good sense of Oz's special, haunting power.

title: ROBERT E. NUESE
description: CORNWALL, Conn., May 20 Robert E. Nuese, who operated the Hayloft Book and Print Shop, selling old prints and rare books in this community, died yesterday at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: The World
description: SAIGONWhen the North Vietnamese began their big offensive seven weeks ago, the big question was: Is this the beginning of the end for South Vietnam?

title: AL GREEN IS BLAND IN COPA SONG SHOW
description: Al Green came into the Copacabana last week with a reputation as a guaranteed hitmaker. His current album is riding high on the charts, and his song, Let's Stay Together, has been a solid seller in both his version and Isaac Hayes's.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: On May 9 the Federal Communications Commission ruled that bank trust departments may own as much as 5 per cent of the shares of any number of broadcastersa larger percentage than is allowed for individuals or mutual funds or others with multiple holdings. Following are excerpts from the dissenting opinion of Commissioner Nicholas Johnson, in which Commissioner Robert T. Bartley joined:

title: After Bonn's Treaties
description: West Germany's ratification of its friendship treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland will not usher in the millennium but it will put other important EastWest agreements into effect and clear the way for more efforts to build dtente. It will also improve the climate for President Nixon's talks with Soviet leaders, which helps explain the strong expression of satisfaction by Secretary of State Rogers after the Bundesrat in Bonn completed parliamentary approval of the pacts last week.

title: TIGHTER TAX RULES SUPPORTED IN POLL
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) A poll ordered by a Presidential commission reports strong taxpayer support for closing income lax loopholes and taxpayer resentment about local property taxes.

title: Riva Ridge Is Up Early For Bad Day in the Mud
description: BALTIMORE, May 2Riva Ridge had his head over the webbing of his stall and was watching the door of the tack room when Edward Sweat, his groom, emerged at 4 A.M. to give the Preakness favorite his breakfast He sleeps all night lying down, Sweat said. I don't know when he woke up, but it was before I did. He always watches for me to come out of that door.

title: Hanoi, Apparently Addressing Soviet, Warns Against Weakness in Face of U.S.
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 20Nhan Dhan, the leading Hanoi daily, warned in an artitle today against signs of weakness that would encourage American truculence.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: GYPSY MOTH

title: BROWN SCORES 32
description: UNIONDALE, L. L, May 20 The Indiana Pacers are the champions of the American Basketball Association and New York's professional winter sports teams have struck out in the title round.

title: Lauree Leaman Is Married Here
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier here yesterday morning, Miss Lauree Leaman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sherwood Leaman of New York and Canaan, N.Y., was married to Francis James Longobardi Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Longobardi of Queens Village, Queens. The Rev. Joseph O'Rourke performed the ceremony.

title: From Resistance To Revolution
description: Despite all the revolutions that have occurred in history, most Americans have been convinced that there has never been one quite like ours. Right from the beginning the Revolution seemed to be an unusually conservative movement, free of the tumult and violence that accompanied other revolutions. Especially in contrast to the French Revolution, the American Revolution appeared to be hardly revolutionary at all.

title: Civil Liberties
description: Although there is no formal agenda in the Moscow talks, Mr. Nixon has given private assurances to American Jewish groups that he will privately raise the subject of Soviet Jewry in his discussions with Soviet leaders.

title: Kontum : Sign of G.I.'s War Swept Away in New Fight
description: KONTUM, South Vietnam, May 17There was a mess sergeant at the American military compound here back in 1965 who took pride in bypassing such things as regulations on meal hours, and could always come up with a meal for a hungry correspondent. The sergeant also took pride in the condition of the compound, and especially the mess hall, and once, with the help of an elderly French nunan expert scroungerbuilt a magnificent barbecue on the shaded veranda.

title: The Making of No, No, Nanette
description: Behind the scenes at No, No, Nanette. Don Dunn followed the production from the time it was a gleam in coproducer Harry Rigby's eye till the show was a hit and Rigby was fired by Cyma Rubin, the other coproducer who put up the money. In between, we see the rehearsals, the infighting, the heads rolling. (Rubin fired 35 people.) Dunn tells that no one was sure about the show until that matinee in Boston when Ruby Keeler broke into her tap dance for I Want to Be Happy and the assembled matrons swooned with nostalgia. From then on, it was purest ecstasy, except for the show's originator, the aforementioned Rigby, who ran afoul of Mrs. Rubin, known to the cast as the Black Witch. At the end of the book there is a remarkable taperecorded interview with Mrs. Rubin, who has hardly a civil word for anyone connected with the Show. (A person who dislikes Ruby Keeler can't be all good.) This is a delicious cat fight; it makes one wonder how shows ever do get on Broadway.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to Smith Island from New York City, the drive to Crisfield (New Jersey Turnpike and U.S. 13 through Delaware and Maryland) takes about five hours. Board the ferryboat, along with the mail sacks and empty oyster barrels, in time for a 12:30 P.M. departure. The trip takes about an hour, and the boat returns at 8 A.M. next day. On this trip you have to stay overnight. Fare: $2 each way. The daytrip excursions to Smith and Tangier Island on Capt. Homer Windsor's Island Queen will continue daily until Oct. 15. The Queen departs from Crisfield at 11 A.M. and returns about 5:30 P.M., and the $12.50 fare includes a snack lunch on board and dinner back in Crisfield at the skipper's restaurant, Windsor's Seafood. For accommodations on Smith, write to Capt. Windsor, Box 266, Crisfield, Md., or to Mrs. Bernice Guy or Mrs. Frances Kitchen, both of Ewell, Smith Island, Md. Remember, there's no entertainment, unless you catch the Smith Island Ladies Quartet.

title: Chiang Is Sworn In for 6 More Years
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 20President Chiang Kaishek was sworn in today for his fifth sixyear term as head of state.

title: Hannah Senesh
description: Hannah Senesh was the daughter of Bela Senesh, a wellknown Budapest playwright and man of letters who died in 1927, when Hannah was 6. Living in comfort with her mother and older brother, she inwardly grieved the loss of her father (for she was very much Daddy's little princess) but outwardly continued to lead what appeared to be a normal wellordered middle class childhood. She had Jewish and gentile playmates, attended a Protestant school, earned pocket money tutoring, went to parties and concerts, was kind to her mother, summered on Lake Balaton, saw numerous family relations, and was, by all accounts, good natured, precocious and charming. A serious girl, a little priggish perhaps, but she would probably get over that someday, when she met a young man she could trust.

title: About Pro Football
description: Edward R. Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, will address the owners of the 26 N.F.L. teams at their annual spring meeting tomorrow Inasmuch as the owners and the players are in wide disagreement on at least three issues, two of which are in the hands of the National Labor Relations Board, the invitation extended to Garvey can be construed as a change of posture by management. The owners will at least listen to their players representative, who was invited to the meeting for the first time by Wellington Mara of the Giants, chairman of the N.F.L. management council.

title: Miss Brown Wed to D. Scott Ketner
description: NEW HAVEN, May 20Miss Elizabeth Brown and D. Scott Ketner were married here this afternoon in an EpiscopO ceremony in the Yale University Dwight Memorial Chapel by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, chaplain emeritus of Yale.

title: Law
description: Thee scene: The hearing room in the Immigration and Naturalization Service building in lower Manhattan. Yoko Ono, sitting in the witness chair in a denim pants suit, wringing a hand kerchief, whispers in a choked voice: You're asking me to choose between my child and my husband. I don't think you can ask any human being to do that. John Lennon, in the wit chair in a nearly identical suit, wringing a handkerchief, tells the inquiry officer: I don't know if there's any mercy to plead for because this isn't a Federal court, but if there is, I'd like it, please.

title: J.W.A Winner About a Loser
description: BECAUSE anyone who wants to make a film today has to overcome so many obstacles, it must be especially difficult to make a film about underachievement. The very process of making the film would seem to give the lie to the theme. A man who has managed to get the money and the screenplay and the actors together all at the same timehas obviously scored a triumph, a feeling of which must, I think, be reflected in the film itself and make it seem slightly phony. How can a man who has raised $1.5million to do with as he will successfully lower his sights to the failure without somehow acknowledging that the failure is, after all, a poor slob, someone whom God for His own good reasons has flunked?

title: Home was never like this
description: MANY Italian products are already familiar household items. The lampsarching suspensions of steel, stems of plastic or chrome topped by glowing domes, translucent coils of light, periscopic arms ending in light showershave revolutionized lighting concepts. The furnituremodular systems of latex foam, freeform or sausage shapes, steel frames or molded plastic shells, stacking plastic chairs, molded plastic tables (such as those inset below) have taught us that most everyday furniture is susceptible to radical cilange.

title: US. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Homebuilding, a mainstay of an otherwise down economy in 1971, continues strong apparently. Last month's actual starts, as reported last week by the United States Department of Commerce, reached a record monthly high of 212,000 units.

title: Carol Hunter Bride of C. F. Weymuller
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., May 20Miss Carol Mae Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Carroll Hunter of Woodbridge, was married here this afternoon to Charles Frederick Weymuller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Augustus Weymuller of Albuquerque, N. M., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa. The Rev. George McLean Milne performed the ceremony in the First Church of Christ, Congregational.

title: Secretary of the Year Chosen
description: MORRISTOWNThe New Jersey division of the National Secretaries Association has chosen Mrs. Vergalene Hayes of Woodcliff Lakes as its Secretary of the Year. As such, she will officially represent the association until May, 1973.

title: TENNIS FINAL GOES TO MISS GOOLAGONG
description: GUILFORD, England, May 20 (AP)Evonne Goolagong, the Wimbledon queen, defeated Mrs. Joyce Williams, the British Wightman Cup player, 75, 62, in the final Rothman's claycourt tennis tournament today.

title: Virginia Downs Army, 103
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 20 (AP)Tom Duquette scored three goals in the second period today and led Virginia to a 10.3 victory over Army inthe N.C.A.A. lacrosse championship quarterfinals.

title: Legislative Notes: Senate Approves Regulation of Cable TV
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Senate has approved legislation giving the Public Utilities Commission the power to regulate the state's cabletelevision industry.

title: They Tried It
description: AFILM is being made in the old Original Joe's, the paneled restaurant which used to be on Third Avenue. An actor portraying a disgruntled patron sits in a booth, complaining to the camera that he ate something that gave him indigestion. He mimics the waiter, and says, Try it, you'll like it....

title: Books:
description: NOFAULT. WHAT YOU CAN SAVE, GAIN, AND LOSE WITH THE NEW AUTO INSURANCE. By Paul Gillespie and Miriam Klipper. 164 pages. Praeger. $5.95.

title: LIBRARY ASSOCIATION HONORS NINE MOVIES
description: Nine movies were cited Friday night at the closing banquet of the 14th annual American Film Festival, held at the New York Hilton Hotel under the auspices of the Educational Film Library Association.

title: Miss Witham Has Nuptials
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 20  Miss Marsha Lynn Witham was married tonight to Francis Chase Whitman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitman of Norwalk. The bride's parents are Col. Bertram H. Witham, U.S.A.F., retired and Mrs. Witham of Stamford.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Price Commission Weighs Limiting Increases for Many Services to 3% a Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Price Commission is considering limiting price increases in the service industry to a maximum of 3 per cent a year, but small companies would not he affected, a commission spokesman disclosed today.

title: Sales of UsedBuses Soar As a Trend Catches On
description: CLEVELAND, May 20Mr. and Mrs. George T. Darling of Stow, a community between Cleveland and Akron, Ohio, recently went shopping for a recreational vehicle to take them and their four sons on a variety of excursions, hopefully including a trip to Alaska some day.

title: Two Are Arrested In Museum Paintings Missing
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 20 (UPI)A man and a woman were arrested early today in connection with the daylight theft of a Rembrandt, a Picasso and two Gauguins valued at more than $1million but have not disclosed where the art treasures are hidden.

title: PASSPORT CHIEF BARS GADGETRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Frances G. Knight, director of the United States Passport Office, is standing firm against mounting pressures for what she describes as pieinthesky gadgetry.

title: Fill It Up! Compressed Gas or Gasoline?
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  Jack Vick drove away recently from Union Oil's service station on Magnolia Avenue with a bright new sticker on the back of his 1970 Buick LeSabre. It said:

title: Douglas E. Erb Weds Sherrill Harris
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 20In the Second Congregational Church here this afternoon, Miss Sherrill Theodora Harris, daughter of Mrs. Elliott Harris Jr. of Greenwich and Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Harris, was married to Douglas Everett Erb, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. J. Erb of Dearborn, Mich., and Sarasota. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth Nye, assisted by the Rev. Arthur Barton.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Scotty Rigs
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.Muffled by fog, waterfront sounds came to us as we sat aboard Capt. Pete Rubino's 36foot Mainebuilt charter boat, the Wild Duck, talking of fish and fishing and waiting for the weather to clear.

title: EISENHOWER HALL DEDICATED AT POINT
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 20 (UPI)Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower joined Army officials today in a brief ceremony dedicating Eisenhower Hall, the United States Military Academy's stillunfinished cadet activities center named for her husband.

title: A New Breed of Country Musicians Steps Forward
description: COUNTRY music is undergoing changes. We are faced with the prospect, particularly unpleasant to hardnosed traditionalists, of a new country music, reflecting many aspects of musical America. We're already well into the process. And it was as inevitable as Monday following Sunday. No longer is it possible for country to be purely a regional phenomena. Courtesy of the media, music of all styles has become common property.

title: Camera World
description: ABATTERY powered, cordless, motorized splicer for both regular 8mm and Super 8 film is now available from AIC Photo, Inc., 168 Glen Cove Road, Carle Place, N. Y. 11514. Called the Hahnel SD Dual 8 Splicer, the unit has a sapphirecoated scraper and a cutter that trims both ends of the films square without losing a single frame. A wedgeshaped splice that will be unnoticeable is created with no visible marks in the film. After scraping, the two ends are cemented with the aid of a small bulb that makes the work easier to see, and that also speeds drying time (10 to 15 seconds). A folding pressure bar holds film ends in perfect alignment. The splicer is powered by two C batteries and is priced at under $40.

title: Television
description: IT IS referred to officially as the Matter of Establishment of Domestic CommunicationsSatellite Facilities by NonGovernment Entities. There are, of course, U.S. military satellites. There is, with Comsat, an international satellite system. This particular matter has to do with a satellite system that will focus on domestic needs.

title: The World
description: Over the centuries, no people had closer, more longstanding or more striferidden relations than we, said President Georges Pompidou last week, welcoming Britain's Queen Elizabeth to France. The two nations, he said, had been separated by a narrow strip of water, at daggers drawn, and yet passionately attracted to each other. That separation is about to be narrowed as Britain joins France and five other European countries as a new member of the Common Market. Elizabeth's visit set a symbolic seal on the new BritishFrench relationship.

title: Abortive Bombing Linked To Jewish Protest Group
description: JERICHO, L. I., May 20 (AP) A twofootlong pipe bomb was thrown through the firstfloor window of an office building here early today, but the fuse went out before it exploded, the Nassau County police said.

title: The Doctor Isn't Fit to Sprint
description: A freakish injury at the finish of an Indoor race last February may spoil Dr. Delano Meriwether's goldmedal dream for the Olympics this year.

title: Miss Van Dorn Wed To Francis V. Grace
description: HOLMDEL, N.J., May 20 In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church here this morning, Miss Barbara Jean Van Dorn became the bride of Francis Victor Grace. The Rev. Eugene R. Scheg performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Insider's View of E. E. C.
description: BRUSSELS  The European Economic Community exists, and is going to exist. It would be folly to act as though this were an academic question and that somehow if we made up our minds that the Community was a bad thing, it would go away.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTS FOR HEALTH FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Members of the House who are interested in health affairs have been exerting unusual pressure in the last two weeks to raise appropriations for the next fiscal year substantially above the Nixon Administration's budget requests.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On the white walls of Yankee Stadium, where drivers on the nearby Major Deegan Expressway can see them, signs herald the arrival of visiting teams. But when are the Yankees going to appear at Yankee Stadium?

title: HOSPITALS CAUGHT IN UNIONS BATTLE
description: A thorny dispute pitting labor unions against each other and threatening ultimately to cripple city hospital services has grown into two separate court actions in a month.

title: Recordings
description: ONE of the good things about enjoying operatic selections recorded many years ago is that no one thinks it's an unhealthy habit. Indeed, the more one knows about how divas of the past launched into Sempre Mere the more one is judged qualified to enjoy current attempts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE I972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Despite the Democratic party's reform rules and their farreaching effect, uncommitted delegates may hold the key to the party's Presidential nomination this year as they have in years past.

title: Miss Suzanne Marie Sattels Married to Patrick Robinson
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 Miss Suzanne Marie Sattels, a fashion coordinator with the Fibers Division, Allied Chemical Corporation, in New York, was married here this afternoon to Patrick Robinson, a London businessman.

title: Laird Saw No Likelihood Of Wide Enemy Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told members of the House of Representatives five weeks before the North Vietnamese began their offensive in South Vietnam that a nationwide Communist attack was not a serious possibility.

title: 40 Feared Killed in India
description: LUCKNOW, India, May 20 (Reuters)More than 40 persons are feared to have been burned to death when a bus plunged into a pit and caught fire in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, officials said here today.

title: The World
description: MONTREAL  Watching his men take up their tools again late last week after a disruptive eightday strike, the foreman of a construction crew here predicted that things may well never be the same again.

title: Bremer's Way of Life Likened to 3 Assassins
description: As details come to light about the life of Arthur Herman Bremer, the man accused of shooting George C. Wallace, similarities to Lee Harvey Oswald, James Earl Ray and Sirhan Bishara Sirhan frequently appear.

title: Talking to an infant and dying in Vietnam; The Boy Who Spoke Chinese Doll sop ago lOwaiqnoa; By Jessica Krasilovsky Illustrated by the authur. Unpaged. New York: Doubleday & Co.$4.95. (Ages 5 to 9)
description: Let s get things straight from the offset Despite its title this book is not about China, the Chinese or the Chinese language. It is about Nicho las, a child who is differentexactly how different we are left to guess. It is also about his older sister, Amanda, and her desperate need to be accepted by a girl her own age.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PONTSAINTEMAXENCE, FranceThis coming week's Moscow summit differs in American eyes from that which preceded it in Peking. President Nixon's visit to the Chinese capital was regarded as a historic landmark. No such pretension is made about the journey to the U.S.S.R., which is seen as a major political event but not a watershed.

title: Nettles's TwoRun Homer, One of Only Two Indian Hits, Beats Tigers, 21
description: DETROIT, May 20 (AP)Graig Nettles belted his first home run of the season, a tworun that in the first inning, to pace the Cleveland Indians to a 21 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

title: Television
description: FCC Commissioner and author of How to Talk Back to Your Television Set

title: Concerning an intractable and contagious disease
description: There are encouraging signs that the internecine controversy that has ravaged the field of drugabuse treatment for many years is easing, and that tentative accommodations are being struck between the two great enemy camps: psychotherapy and chemotherapy. The enormous expansion of methadonemaintenance programstwo years ago there were 50 programs with 10,000 patients, now there are 434 with 65,000still terrifies the defenders of the drugfree therapeutic approach, which has been hobbled in the deadly struggle for funds by its smaller scale, higher costs, poorer retention rates, unthorough evaluations and miniscule percentage of successful graduates. But with the final theoretical battle still undecidedwe know astonishingly little about the origins of addiction and what metabolic changes, if any, it causesthere is a pragmatic trend toward catholicity in the better treatment programs.

title: Gray Panthers Out to Liberate Aged
description: DENVER, May 18Margaret Kuhn would not be flattered if someone told her she looked younger than her 67 years, and she wouldn't play shuffleboard if you paid her $100.

title: Lucy Blundon Married To Christopher Biddle
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Miss Lucy Downing Blundon, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Montague Blundon Jr., was married here this afternoon to Christopher Stark Biddle, son of Mrs. Sydney Geoffrey Biddle of Cuttingsville, Vt., formerly of Philadelphia, and the late Dr. Biddle. The ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. James R. Adams. A reception followed at the Blundon home in McLean, Va.

title: New Novel
description: Why is it so hard to prove malpractice in medicine? Eleazar Lipsky's brilliant courtroom novel should give you a clue. It presents a victim of what may have been superfluous brain surgery, involved in a suit in which the chief adversaries are both good guys. One is the resident surgeon who performed the operation. The other is the tenacious lawyer for the plaintiff.

title: BOYS HIGH IS VICTOR OF 4 TRACK EVENTS
description: HARTFORD, May 20Boys High School of Brooklyn won four events and Sam Carr of the host school won three today in the rainsoaked Hartford High School invitation track and field meet.

title: Track Meet Here Tuesday
description: The Park Department will sponsor a track meet for open and high school athletes at 4:30 P.M. Tuesday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. Entries include Vince Matthews, Larry James and Tommy Ulan in the 400meter run and Byron Dyce and Marcel Philippe in the 1,500.

title: NEW DORP TAKES EDDY TRACK MEET
IN NORTH KOREA, MARX ON SUNDAY
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 20Sunday afternoon in Pyongyang finds thousands of Korean children absorbed in extracurricular activities in an imposing building complex known as the Children's Palace.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Patricia Stetson Wed to Nathaniel Tripp
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., May 20Miss Patricia Pate Stet son and Nathaniel Wardwell Tripp were married here this noon at the home of Mrs. G. Richardson Stetson of Southport and Woodstock, Vt., mother of the bride. The Rev. Jeffrey Kittredge, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Bus Terminal Set for Holiday Crush
description: The Port Authority Bus Terminal, the world's busiest bus depot, is bracing itself for the first big holiday crush of 1972.

title: Army Acts to Ease the Transition Into Civilian Life
description: FORT DIX  From Vietnam jungles to army post to civilian life is a transition that Fort Dix seeks to ease through a jobcounseling program, to give the veteran a chance in a squeezed job market.

title: Steel Prices: Why No Rise?; Imports Now Seen As Key Factor
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation surprised the business world by announcing on April 13 that it would not raise prices on rolledsteel before next Jan. 1. The other producers followed Bethlehem's lead and C. Grayson Jackson Jr., chairman of the Price Commission, hailed the action as a stabilizing influence on a large section of the economy.

title: Mrs. Anne Wright, Couturier, Directed Town Hall Club
description: Mrs. Anne Wright, executive director of the Town Hall Club during World War II and couturier here in the 1930's, died Thursday in a convalescent home in Meriden, Conn. She was 80 years old.

title: Nicholas Noell Marries Jennifer Franke
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 20Miss Jennifer DeWitt Funke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Funke, was married here this afternoon to Nicholas Alexander Noell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Noell of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Thomas G. Madden performed the ceremony in St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE I972 CAMPAIGN
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20Overshadowed as it is in so many things by the larger states, Rhode, Island has just barely avoided being totally bypassed by the competing candidates in its Presidential primary.

title: U.S. Move For Closer Ties Spurs Hopes
description: Been to Moscow lately? This is a knowing greetmg now among the many American business executives who have been in the Soviet capital preparing for or investigating the anticipated boom in United States trade with Russia.

title: JOBLESS TRAINED AS HEALTH AIDES
description: Labor ana management in the health industry have joined to train disadvantaged people to fill a serious need in nursing homes for aides, orderlies and other workers.

title: Art
description: ONE way of looking at the history of abstract art is to view it as a series of audacious attempts to achieve the maximum esthetic results from the smallest possible artistic means. The Miesian dictum of Less is more represents a powerful Impulse which, in the halfcenturylong chronicle of abstract art, has sometimes been implemented with a terrifying fanaticism and success. Standards have changed, of course, on the question of what the smallest possible means may be, but the chimera of some ultimate reduction has been ardently pursued. In all the arts, but most conspicuously in painting, sculpture and music, the quest for some final essentiality has been adamant and abiding. This is what is meantmost of the time anywaywhen a work of art is spoken of as ad

title: Frank Knight and the Chicago School
description: The economic profession in the United States is divided into a set of oldboy networks revolving around the university departments where the economists did their graduate work.

title: Commander Fayette Wins Handicap at Suffolk Downs
description: BOSTON, May 20 (AP)Commander Fayette, an 1110 favorite, wan his third race in a row as he led all the way to beat Simrok by a neck in the $9,000 Raceland Handicap today before a crowd of 11,260 at Suffolk Downs.

title: Not everyone has signed the social contract
description: On Oct. 9, 1964, a sad old man named Alexander Helmer was stabbed to death in his apartment at 399 East 160th St., Bronx, N.Y. Since no one cared very much about Mr. Helmer when he was alive, no one missed him when he was dead; it was not until they nosed him, as they climbed the stairs, that anyone called the cops to brave the clouds of flies and the troops of maggots and the hideous stench and took him away.

title: Merzario Paces Trials
description: PALERMO, Sicily, May 20 (AP)Arturo Merzario, driving one of the few Ferraris in trials for the Targa Florio road race tomorrow, turned in the fastest time today despite a blowout that caused him to skid off the road. Merzario completed the tricky 44.7mile lap in 33 minutes 59.6 seconds. His average speed was 80 miles an hour.

title: Study Sees Billion Chinese
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (Reuters)A Congressional study predicted today that.,China's population, at present about 500 million, would be between 1.319 billion and 1.330 billion by 1990. The study. was made by the staff of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.

title: Child to the Kleins
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Klein of Englewood and Fort Lee, N. J., on April 24 in the Englewood Hospital.

title: Swaziland Vote Lessens Royalist Rule
description: MBABANE, Swaziland, May 20Swaziland's first general election since independence from Britain in 1968 has put the ruling royalists strongly in control of this small southern African monarchy.

title: Soviet's Appetite for Technology Is Immense
description: MOSCOW  Against a backdrop of two huge Soviet and United States flags, officials of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce formally opened a small exhibit of American scientific equipment at the Institute of Medical Technology here the other day.

title: Manville Breathes Easier: Asbestos Dust Fear Eased
description: MANVILLE  Residents of this Central Jersey industrial town of 13,000 are breathing easier these days: the air along Main Street is more contaminated by car fumes than by asbestos dust.

title: Girl, 8, Found Slain In Bronx Building In Which She Lived
description: An 8yearold Bronx girl missing since Friday night was found dead yesterday in a vacant apartment in the building where she lived, the apparent victim of strangulation and a sexual attack, according to the police.

title: THE I972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 Operationally, the race for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination matches an established organization with traIditional votegetting techniques against a loose confederation of leaders heavily dependent on the personal drawing power of their candidate.

title: Dozen Food Places Listed as Violators Of the Health Code
description: Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase yesterday made public the names of 12 more food processing businesses charged with violations of the city Health Code.

title: A Revolutionary War soldier in Vietnam
description: Blacks suffer so many disadvantages that one wonders when black fiction will begin to imitate black life and turn disadvantages into style. For what American fiction needs more than anything else is style. We are all tired of tedious, welltailored books that look too much alike. Our fiction industry needs what our clothing industry has, but black authors have not improvised enough original material to which the Pierre Cardins of the literary world can look for inspiration.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYERS TO TOUR U.S. BASES
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, in cooperation with the Department of Defense, again will sponsor a goodwill tour of military bases in Vietnam and Korea this summer.

title: ... And Life Without Demands on Another
description: SMITH ISLAND, Md.The only person who seems to move at anything approaching fast on Smith Island is the Methodist minister, who has to travel to each of the island's three churches on Sunday mornings to conduct services and preach a sermon. There is really no need for anyone else to rush about.

title: Dance: Senior Ballerinas
description: Over the last 23 years New York has seen many Royal Ballet ballerinas, from Margot Fonteyn onward, dance OdetteOdile in Swan Lake. Two of this season's OdetteOdiles, Monica Mason and Deanne Bergsma, have long enjoyed a particular popularity with New York balletomanes. I remember, for example, that when Miss Bergsma made her Metropolitan Opera House debut in Swan Lake a few years ago one fan had special lapel buttons made and distributed that read Bravo Deanne Bergsma.

title: Exploring. One of Nature's Last Strongholds, the Cabot Trail
description: D.H. LAWRENCE could have been talking about the Cabot Trail, the 184mile road that circles the nrothwestern part of Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, when he said, Comes over one an absolute necessity to move. And what is more, to move in some particular direction. Most drivers do just that on the trail. They move through some of the most spectacular and compressed scenery in North America, and most of them, bringing their own reasonableness to such disorderly vistas, drive the route clockwise. They enter at Margaree Forks, continue northward to winsome Cheticamp, go up North Mountain and down Smoky Mountain and emerge at Baddeck.

title: New Novel
description: Onward Virgin Soldiers continues the adventures of the postwar British Army, begun in a previous novel. Mr. Thomas's cast of characters here are the N.C.O.'s and enlisted men belonging to the Hong Kong garrison.

title: A Press Mention Here  a Photo There, And Kitty Hawks Became Girl of Year
description: The mother is Lady Keith, better known as Slim to her friends and Big Mama to Truman Capote. The daughter is Kitty Hawks, who has suddenly emerged as the Girl of the Year, the girl who made the 1971 International Best Dressed List after only three months in the social whirl.

title: Cortland Upsets Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 20 (AP) Cortland State registered the first upset of the lacrosse championship playoffs today by beating Navy, 109, in overtime. Bert Severns scored the deciding goal at 1:37 of the extra period.

title: New Novel
description: There's a dandy jacket photograph of Rosie Blake, wearing a man's shirt and heavy galluses. Fabulous, as Rosie's heroine, Stephanie, might say., That's about as far as I can go with compliments.

title: OTB Returns $31.60 On Preakness Race, Less Than at Track
description: Bettors in the metropolitan area who backed the winner of yesterday's Preakness in the separate pool set up by the Offtrack Betting Corporation received a substantially smaller return than the customers at Pimlico.

title: The Guest Word
description: Maurice Samuel, who died on May 4 at the age of 77, was a literary man who spent his life near one or another cultural margin, not quite at home in the American literary milieu nor fully accepted by the Yiddish writers whose work he translated so brilliantly into English. That was his special virtue, his own testy strength: to be illatease in the world, moving with a useful discomfort between two cultures while casting sardonic glances at both.

title: Roosevelt to Offer New Way to Lose
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 20A form of gambling novel to North American harness racing will be introduced Thursday night as Roosevelt Raceway launches the middle segment of its three 1972 home stands. The The reopening in Nassau County will follow by less than 24 hours the conclusion of the first half of Yonkers Raceway's 23d year of operation.

title: Nations Retail Merchants Mobilize Security Systems to Combat FastGrowing Shoplifting Trend
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 After years of relatively quiet resignation in the face of a runaway increase in shoplifting, the nation's retail merchants are now fighting back. Retail sources say the battle is beginning to pay off.

title: U.S.C. TRIUMPHS IN COAST TRACK
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., May 20 (AP)The University of Southern California Trojans won their first Pacific8 track title in four years today, outscoring the defending champion, the University of California, Los Angeles, despite getting only one point from the sprint star, Don Quarrie.

title: John L. Marion Named President of ParkeBernet
description: There's a rumor afoot that the art auction house of ParkeBernet, taken over by the British concern of Sotheby's in 1964, has been recaptured by Americans.

title: Eudora Welty's new novel about death and class
description: Eudora Welty's novel, The Optimist's Daughter, which first appeared in The New Yorker of March 15, 1969, is a miracle of compression, the kind of book, small in scope but profound in its implications, that rewards a lifetime of work. Its style is at the service of a story that follows its nose with the instincts of a good hunting dog never losing the scent of its quarry. And its story has all those qualities peculiar to the finest short novels: a theme that vibrates with overtones, suspense and classical inevitability.

title: Russian Said to Die in Raid
description: TOKYO, May 20 (UPI)North Vietnam's official press agency said today that a Soviet seaman was killed when American planes bombed a Russian ship in a North Vietnamese port May 10.

title: Rinaldi Killed in Crash
description: PRAGUE, May 20 (AP)Luigi Rinaldi, an Italian racer driving an Alfa Romeo, was killed today during a raindrenched training run in Brno. Rinaldi's car was traveling at about 125 miles an hour when it skidded and hit the referee's tower, the station said. The Alfa Romeo was demolished and several spectators were injured.

title: CHILDREN STAGE PYONGYANG SHOW
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 20Sometimes children catch the spirit of a country better than speeches, pronouncements and slogans.

title: Silver: Stability Despite Instability
description: This month includes an anniversary in the long history of silver that some people would like to forget. Five years ago this month, the United States Treasury stopped honoring its longstanding commitment to buy and sell all domestically produced silver at $1.29 an ounce.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A careful and detailed, study of the man and his campaigns. The writing, which approaches in density a legal brief, is hard going, probably the result of Lippman's attempts to be fair. As a county executive, Agnew remained more liberal than his suburban constituency; nontheless, Lippman sees him now as the new suburban man, reflecting the interests of part of the coalition that barely put Nixon over in 1968. Lippman's Agnew is not so bad as he sounded during that campaign, when he traveled the low lawandorder road; still, one senses an odor of political opportunism, somewhat in contradiction to the compassionate side of Agnew's nature (which he seems well able to subdue). As an ethnic, Agnew fits the American tradition of second generation rejecting the father: he refused to go to Greek school and never spoke Greek. An interesting documentary.

title: ME WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE queasiness that infiltrated Wall Street almost two months ago with the intensification of the Vietnam fighting finally subsided late last week as investors once again paid attention to the fundamental strengths in the nation's economy.

title: VETOES 20 MORE BUS
description: HARTFORD, May 20Gov. Thomas J. Meskill has vetoed 120 bills passed in the regular session of the General Assembly including a forgiveness bill that would have allowed private and parochial schools to keep the funds they had received under a 1969 law that has since been declared unconstitutional.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTONSeldom has legislation wanted by so many been caught in so enormous a parliamentary tangle.

title: An Open Meeting on Aging Set
description: PRINCETON  We're all aging.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 20Tension heightened in Northern Ireland today as a wave of shootings and bombings brought nearer the menace of open sectarian warfare between Protestants and Roman Catholics.

title: Fighting Near Angkor Wat
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 20 (AP)Nineteen Cambodian soldiers were killed and 78 wounded in two days of battles within sight of Angkor Wat, one of Asia's art treasures, the Cambodian high command reported tonight.

title: Books:
description: TAKE TODAY: The Executive As Dropout. By Marshall McLuhan and Barrington. Nevitt. 304 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc. $9.95.

title: Generation Allies Serve on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I.Throughout the churches in Roosevelt today, the elderly will be filling out questionnaires in a concentrated effort to find the answers to the following questions:

title: Lee Andersen Bride Of John Delmhorst
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 20 In Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Lee Andersen and John R. Delmhorst, both with the First National City Bank in New York, were married by the Rev. Dana F. Kennedy.

title: Girl's Poem Evokes Brooklyn
description: Last week, the Brooklyn Center Chamber Orchestra performed a new composition, Reflections on the 5th Ray, written by a music professor and inspired by the words of a poem written by an eighthgrade student.

title: The SansCulottes
description: When I first began my study of 18thcentury France, it was dominated by the personalities of great men Voltaire, Diderot, Rousseau, Danton, Marat, Robespierre and, of course, Napoleon. They loomed larger than life over the flow of history, directing its course through. the hazardous paths of revolution; they either caused it by their inflammatory doctrines; or created the Terror through their revolutionary intransigence; orlike Napoleonfound the solution and led Revolution back to social stability, nationalism and war.

title: European Elevens Move to Semifinals In Soccer June 14
description: Belgium will meet West Germany, Hungary and the Soviet Union Wednesday, June 14, in semifinal matches for the European Nations Cup, a competition held every four years for soccer supremacy among European countries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Those initials, obscenities and nicknames on subway walls may be artwork to some people, but not to City Council President Sanford D. Garelik. He proposed yesterday that New Yorkers band together under the auspicies of the Environmental Protection Administration to wage a massive war on graffiti, including a onceamonth AntiGraffiti Day.

title: Glen Cove's Downtown Area Getting a Massive Renewal
description: GLEN COVE, L. I.After nearly 15 years of planning, a $20million urban renewal program has begun here that is expected, in about five years, to generate additional real estate taxes and induce local residents to shop more in downtown stores.

title: Horse Show News
description: Gary Kunsman, a 24yearold professional who has studied horsemanship from Virginia to England, has been appointed chief instructor at Four Seasons Farm in Readington, N. J.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Scanning Fingerprints For Clues to Pentagon Blast
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation began today a search of its fingerprint files to try to learn who bombed the rest room at the Pentagon.

title: Son to the Topilows
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Topilow of Riverdale, the Bronx, on May 4 in the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. Mrs. Topilow is the former Judith H. Fiedler of New York. She is director of Pediatric Emergency Room Care at Metropolitan Hospital under the name of Dr. Judith F. Topilow. The child, whose father is a diplomate of the American Board of Internal Medicine, and a hematology fellow at New York Medical College, is named Justin Lee.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The God Committee
description: The baby is a mongoloid born with duodenal atresia, an intestinal obstruction. The parents, professional people in Maryland, refuse permission for the surgery that will enable the infant to survive, deciding that it would be unfair to their two normal children to bring a mongoloid into the home. Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore seek help from the courts, which in Maryland have the power to appoint a guardian who will authorize necessary medical care for a child when the parents won't. A senior member of the judiciary advises them that the courts would not force the parentsor society7to bear the burden of rearing such a child.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Man's love affair with the automobile endures. Greater love hath no man than this, that he should lay down $25 or $17.95 to buy a book about automobiles or, at these prices, motor cars. Some treatments require the expensive coffeetable format: quality color photographs, for example, would be wasted in conventional book sizes. So, every year we have a formidable array of car books, many of them beautiful. Some are simply collections of magnificent machines to admire for their own sake. Others are histories that dramatize the hard years of pioneering that produced the necessity we now take for granted. And some of these books make good reading.

title: Travel Notes: R. I. to Observe Nation's First Bicentennial Event
description: GETTING a jump on the nation's bicentennial celebration by four years, the village of Pawtuxet, R.I., is about to observe the 200th anniversary of the burning of the revenue schooner Gaspee, which the British had sent to the Colonies to enforce the Stamp Act by harassing smugglers.

title: Professionals and Executives Showing Up on Welfare Rolls
description: HACKENSACIC  The re cent appearance of Junior executives and professional men among the unemployed and on the suburban welfare rolls has highlighted an aswt of welfare with which Bergen County's caseworkers have long been familiar.

title: Penrod and Sam in the Faulkner manner
description: The Stones of Summer cannot possibly be called a promising first novel for the simple reason that it is such a marvelous achievement that it puts forth much more than mere promise. Fulfillment is perhaps the best word, fulfillment at the first stroke, which is so often the sign of superior talent and which is also a frightening thing, for the author may remain forever awed by the force and witness of his first production. I don't think, however, that this will happen in the present instance. Dow Mossrnan's novel is a whole river of words fed by a torrential imagination, and such a source is not likely to stop flowing.

title: Economic Issues
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are the world's greatest economic powers, but their commercial contacts are minimal, with trade averaging only about $200million yearly. In recent months, however, intensive discussions have taken place with an eye to raising that trade to about $1billion or $2billion yearly. Premier Kosygin will undoubtedly stress to Mr. Nixon his country's. strong desire to see a closer economic relationship with the United States.

title: Birthday Troubles
description: President Nixon will do the country a service if he rejects the recommendation of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission to cancel Philadelphia's plans for an international exposition in 1976. To uphold the commission's view would have the effect of precluding such an exposition in honor of the nation's 200th birthday, since it is probably too late now for any other city to resume bidding for the honor.

title: McGovern to Help Wallace Be Heard
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20Senator George McGovern is prepared to help Gov. George C. Wallace send them a message when the Democratic National Convention drafts a party platform for the 1972, campaign.

title: Joseph Bloch is crazy and becomes crazier
description: Peter Handke is a young Austrian writer, best known for his plays, which have been variously described as audacious, clever, brilliant, pretentious, fraudulent, exciting and maddening. If only from the passionate excess into which both his champions and critics are drawn, it seems safe to conclude (without having seen the plays on stage) that the man has a flair for the theatrical and the unexpected. He takes people by surprise in order to pull them deeper into his work than they might otherwise be disposed to go. A disoriented audience is lured to involvement by the suggestion that penetration of the play itself will somehow restore that equilibrium, not to say smugness, with which they entered the theater.

title: CHAVEZ CONTINUES A FAST IN ARIZONA
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 20Cesar Chavez, who is protesting a new Arizona farm labor law, continued what he calls his fast of sacrifice today with the support of Senator George McGovern.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: If You Go...
description: ... to Monhegan Island, bear in mind that like most utopias, it wraps itself in an aura of unattainability. It is easier to get to Europe than to Monhegan, one resident says. The island is still very inaccessible, particularly since the Boston & Maine Railroad was discontinued. The bus trip from New York City takes nine hours, and if you arrive late you have to stay overnight on the mainland and take the 10:30 ferry next morning out of Port Clyde. (The bus stops in Thomaston; from there it is necessary to take a taxi to Port Clyde.)

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S
description: When the Oratorio Society of Flushing at Flushing High School presented its first concert on May 12, 1927, Esther Treadwell was among its 100 singers.

title: Major Assassination Attempts Since 1835
description: One out of every five Presidents in roughly the last century has been assassinated.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In the curtain and drapery end of the textile industry the battle of the fibers is particularly acute and promises to become more intense with the advent of a national standard for flame retardancy.

title: The Actors Are Willing, But the Authors Aren't
description: THE theater today is dull, pretentious, and sloppy, Eugenie Leontovich announces in Anna K., tossing her tiny white head so that the swathes of red netting she wears for a crown rise and tremble like a battered ship at sea. The lady is hound to seem right, given our current disaffections: and she is certainly to be admired, standing birdlike and erect after all these long years of service with challenge in her husky voice and defiance in her eyes.

title: Modern Medical Price: Bankruptcy for a Family
description: DETROIT, May 20Harold E. Wagner died almost unnoticed in a hospital here in an operation in which a dozen specialists fought to save him. His fatal heart illness has all but bankrupted his family and, in a national sense, underscored the often fantastic costs of modern medicine.

title: A Year of Difficulty for Ramapo College Blacks
description: MAHWAH  Five mornings a week, Mrs. Lucy Walker leaves her home in a black neighborhood of Hackensack, straps her 2yearold daughter Lucretia into the front seat of her tiny gray car, and drives north for 35 minutes to attend classes at New Jersey's newest fouryear college.

title: For Summer Theaters, a Season of Challenge
description: Harry Pomeran of the Gateway Theater in Bellport, L.I., likes to remember the good old daysthe fifties, when there were at least a dozen of us spread all over the map, from Mineola to Northport to Montauk, in barns and tents as well as theaters.

title: Why are they so obsessed?; Wasted; The Story of My Son's Drug Addiction. By William Chapin. 216 pp. New York: McGrawHill Book Co. $6.95.
description: Those of us who lived in places like the East Village, HaightAshbury or Dupont Circle saw a flood of unkempt, longhaired white children invade our neighborhoods during the middle years of the last decade. More often than not we resented the way they made nuisances of themselves begging for nickels and pennies with their $800 cameras slung around their necks. Much of what they did seemed silly. Why would anyone want to go dirty or hungry or sleep on hard, cold concrete when there were warm beds not too many miles away?

title: Keeping Seniors Involved In Those Closing Weeks
description: ORADELLOnce seniorleis, or senior slump, is diagnosed in a high school, it can be ignoredor it can be treated.

title: OCEAN CIRCULATION UNDER SHIP'S STUDY
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., May 20  The 245foot research vessel Knorr sailed from here this week on a threeweek cruise to implant various instruments on specially placed buoys as part of a study of the physics of general ocean circulation.

title: Middle East
description: Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev. have direct interest in a settlement of the Middle East crisis, and the two sides are expected to discuss the ArabIsrael dispute at some length. Mr. Nixon would like some commitment from the Russians to limit the arms flow in the area, but he is unlikely to get any Soviet support for the idea since Moscow seems to believe its main leverage on the Egyptians is its continued pipeline of war materiel.

title: TURN FOR BETTER IS SEEN IN DACCA
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 20 A resilient population combined with a great infusion of foreign aid has enabled Bangladesh to emerge from the ashes of the war that made this former Pakistani province an independent republic, according to a report by the United Nations relief mission here.

title: WALL STREET
description: The 1972 annual meeting season is about over and one feature that has been conspicuous by its absence is a major proxy fight, that muchcelebrated corporate struggle in which rival slates of directors contest for the hearts, minds and votes of their fellow shareholders.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Two new magazines for blacks have appeared on the scene just as the business is witnessing a flap over the efficiency of advertising in black publications.

title: Johns Hopkins Triumphs
description: BALTIMORE, May 30 (AP)Johns Hopkins outscored Washington and Lee, 81, in the second and third periods today and triumphed, 115, in the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. lacrosse playoffs.

title: Stamps
description: FIVE postal cards with the theme Tourism Year of The Americas will be released by the Postal Service at Boston on June 29. Three cards will be of 6cent denomination, one will be a 9c domestic airmail postal card, and the fifth will be a 15c card for overseas mail. The reverse of each card will picture four tourist sites in the United States.

title: State Moving to End Transportation Pinch
description: TRENTON  Fifty years ago, New Jersey enjoyed a national reputation for having one of the best highway systems and some of the best commuter railroads in the country.

title: Nixon Approves Extension Of Aid to Lung Victims
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) President Nixon has signed a bill providing an 18month extension for Federal benefits to victims of black lung disease and their dependents, including a new provision to cover orphans.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to Transpo, wear comfortable shoes, since you will have to walk around a site a mile and a half long and threefourths of a mile wide. Exposition hours are from 9 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. May 27, 28, and 29 and June 3 and 4, and from noon to 7:30 P.M. from May 30 to June 2. Remember, Transpo is open in the morning from May 30 to June 2 for business people only; on those days there will be afternoon (2 P.M.) and evening (6:15 P.M.) air shows.

title: Washington Captures Coast Rowing Title for 9th Time in Last 13 Years

title: Unforgettable Bluets

But they colonize, and vast patches of their white or pale lilac blossoms are like frost on the grass in upland meadows. They please the countryman, who may also call them quaker ladies innocence, though the individual flower is only half an inch across its four small petals, at the center of which Is a golden eye.

I.If you stand on the little balcony behind Great Neck's shiny new public library you can see a pleasant little pond, called Udalls Mill Pond, ringed with grass and budding trees. It is a serene, parklike refuge amid the countless houses and busy streets of a comfortable suburban community.

Indeed, one has to go to London to duplicate the scale of 19thcentury survival or the variety of architectural styles that are represened here. often in a state of nearperfect preservation.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: At the age of 51, Tex Maule, a writer for Sports Illustrated, had his first heart attack, followed by a second one a few days later that almost did him in. Fortunately he had access to good care quickly. But this is more than the story of a heart attack; it tells how Maule took up jogging, in fact became a jogging freak. He couldn't, give up cigarettes or booze, but he could and did run daily. He lost weight, and after a year or so a kind of second wind overtook him and he began eying the Boston Marathon as his own personal World Series of jogging. How. he entered the race (against his doctor's advice) is the conclusion to a book that should interest heart patients and joggers everywhere.

title: The Nation
description: In American politics seen as a game, John Connally is the establishment's boldest broken field runner.

title: Spies in the Promised Land
description: The Israeli Secret Service has established itself as one of the world's most effective, with its significant penetration of a numbeT of inimical Arab countries. Its architect was Iser Harel who arrived in Palestine as a young Russian migr in 1930. During World War II and the 1948 war he became a seasoned op, and in 1952 Prime Minister Ben Gurion appointed him head of the Secret Service, a position he held with complete anonymity until 1963, when his resignation precipitated a Cabinet crisis. His coups include putting down dissident organizations in the early days of Israel, and warning of King Abdullab's intention to attack in 1948. The book also tells of the C.I.A. backing of Nasser and of an Israeli plot to bomb the British and American installations in Egypt in order to put the blame on Nasser.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with interest David Tishman's article City Must Spur Residential Building [April 30] and couldn't agree more that luxury housing has come to be regarded as a frill. However, we can no longer subscribe to the filtering down process as a means of alleviating the crisis in low, moderate and middleincome housing because of the stateimposed vacancy decontrol law.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONI was keyed up and ready for battle as the flight neared Moscow. But I knew that this was not to be a single crisis in the classic sense. While my meeting with Mr. Khrushchev might be a personal crisis for me, I recognized that in perspective it was only one episode in the continuing crisis that Mr. Khrushchev and his Communist coljedgues are determined to perpetuate through our lifetime.Richard M. Nixon, recalling his 1959 Vice Presidential journey to the Soviet Union in his book, Six Crises.

title: Cleveland Papers Publish
description: CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP)The Plain Dealer and The Cleveland Press resumed publication today after settlement of a labor dispute that had left this city without a major daily newspaper. Delivery truck drivers who had struck the Plain Dealer Tuesday returned to work last night. The Press, which had shut down voluntarily Thursday, resumed publication this afternoon.

title: Home Improvement
description: TO MAKE certain that their room air conditions (window mount or throughthe wall) will provide the cooling relief expected when the first hot weather arrives, owners of these units should take time out now to clean and check them, and to make certain that they are in proper operating condition. This type of preventive maintenance and preseason checkup will not only serve to minimize the likelihood of a breakdown later on (usually right in the middle of a heat spell), it will also give the owner plenty of time to have repairs made, if needed. After pulling off the air conditioner's cover on the outside (assuming that one was put on at the end of the previous season) the first thing that should be done is to take out the builtin filter and inspect it to see if it needs cleaning or replacement. The best test is to hold the filter up and look through it at a bright light; if no light shows through it needs to be cleaned (if it is the permanent type that is washable) or replaced (if it is the disposable type).

title: BEE BEE BEE FIRST IN THE PREAKNESS
description: William S. Farish's Bee Bee Bee, ridden by Eldon Nelson, raced to victory in the Preakness at Pimlico over a muddy track. He led through most of the race and triumphed by a length and a quarter over No Le Hace. Key to the Mint was third. The win price at Pimlico was $39.40 and in the separate OTB pool here it was $31.60. Riva Ridge, the Kentucky Derby winner, finished fourth.

title: Queensboro's First Reunion: A Sign of Growing Up

title: The World; Gold Prices:; Who'stoBlame? (Select One)
description: The South Africans are to blame! Nonsense. it's Connally's resignation now. You boys are going too far. It's just a question of industrial supply and demand. Oh yeah? title: James Doty Marries Miss Carol Shirley

title: No Peace Beyond the Line
description: The line of this book's title delimited the area west of the Azores, and south of the Tropic of Cancer, which, in the 17th century, the European powers regarded tacitly as a legitimate zone of strife  despite whatever conditions of war, or of precarious peace, obtained momentarily in the European continent. Consequently, on the mainland of the two Americas, the European rivalries were fierce enough; but in the islands of the Caribbean, and especially in the archipelago of the Lesser Antilles, a grim game of grab ensued between the nascent imperialisms of half a dozen European nations. This made the systematic plantation of colonies, hazardous enough in continental America, a sort of human and financial gamble in which islands were prizes, and human beings miserable pawns.

title: Davis Cup Juniors to Play In Annual Columbia Event

title: Poll in Jersey Gives Nixon Lead Over Four

title: School should enliven kids lives
description: Nowhere in the education worldunder or overgroundcan one be taught to discover fundamental attributes that guide a human being on his own course; nor is any school geared to help an individual discover his personal law and function, fitting with his individual capacity and inclination. Thus the first paragraph of the introduction defines, albeit stiffly, the intention of this outsized offshoot of the Whole Earth Catalog. The goal evokes the state of mind of a prophetic minority in American education today. But though the Big Rock is more than we deserve, it is less than we need.

description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 21Steve Ross of Brooklyn won his fourth Westchester tennis championship today with a 61, 61 rout of Andy Finn of White Plains. Ross is ranked seventh in the East.

title: Two Black Politicians Cancel TV Appearance
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)Two black politicians canceled their appearance on the American Broadcasting Company's radiotelevision program Issues and Answers, which was shown today, because the network had refused to put a black newsman on the questioning panel, a network producer said.

title: Film: German I Love You, I Kill You
Albert G. McCracken Dies; Lions International Officer
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 21 Albert G. McCracken, New Jersey State Secretary of Lions International, died Friday in Boca Raton Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 63 Linden Drive, Fair Haven, N. J.

title: Price Favoritism Charged
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Joint Economic Committee accused the Price Commission today of showing favoritism toward the New York Telephone Company and the General Foods Corporation.

title: Belgian Driver Killed
description: CHIMAY, Belgium, May 21, (AP)Yvo Grauls, a 32yearold Belgian racing driver, was killed today in a Group 2 race.

title: Conservative Scottish Trusts Keep Eye on Dividends
description: The Scottish Trusts, in, vestment vehicles roughly comparable to our oldline, closedend investment companies, tend to stress income as much as price appreciation. They rarely grant interviews, but Robert Metz of The New York Times on a recent trip to Europe interviewed Michael D. Pentland, manager of the British Investment Trust, and his associate, J. E. Hubbard, the trust's deputy manager. Mr. Pentland, in his downtown Edinburgh office, sketched a picture of conservatism that might well appeal to the investor who seeps to preserve capital by limiting his risks to stocks that might be expected to advance moderately.

title: Miss Gordon, R. R. Parks Jr. Marry on L. I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., May 21St. John's Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Gwendoline Erica Gordon and Robert Ralph Parks Jr. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee, the rector, perfamed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Plandome Country Club.

title: Blasts Near Pageant Investigated
description: DORADO P.R., May 21Police bomb experts searched for clues today in the rubble of two explosions that occurred near the scene of the Miss U.S.A. Beauty Pageant at the Cerromar Hotel last night. There were no injuries, and the pageant proceeded without interruption.

title: Experts Here Doubt Pieta Can Be Perfectly Restored
description: Michelangelo's Pieta can definitely be repaired, according to art restorers and experts here, but some doubted that the evidence of yesteday's attack could be completely erased. The attack shattered an, arm of the figure of the Virgin Mary and damaged parts of the head.

title: MOTHER MARY BERTRAND
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 21Mother Mary Bertrand Miller, Mother General of the Sisters of Mercy of New Jersey from 1956 to 1962, died yesterday in McAuley Hall here at the age of 91.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One political adviser was made commissioner while dozens of City Hall aides who resigned last December to work on Mayor Lindsay's Presidential campaign are returning to the city payroll; and now Sid Davidoff, who also resigned to work for the Mayor's bid for the Presidency, is rejoining the City Hall staff.

title: Mass Starts at 4:30 A.M. At the Hanoi Cathedral
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 21The Roman Catholic cathedral in. Hanoi was crowded with hundreds of worshipers for the first mass at 4:30 this morning and again for the second at 6 o'clock. The services are held at such early hours, North Vietnamese say, to avoid American bombing.

title: DR. C. H. KANENGISER, A SURGEON IN JERSEY
description: JERSEY CITY, May 21Dr. Clifford H. Kanengiser, a surgeon here for the last 30 years, died yesterday at Christ Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 26 Gifford Avenue, where he maintained an office.

title: 4 PREAKNESS HORSES VANNED TO BELMONT
