title: Hiss, Promising Rookie Driver, Gets First Chance in Indy 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 23When Andy Granatelli signed a contract on the trunk lid of the Indianapolis 500 pace car last Saturday, he acquired a halfinterest in year old Eagle Offenhauser and the driving services of Mike Hiss, who is considered one of the most promis

title: Car Crash, Undiscovered 2 Days, Fatal to Couple
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 23 A United States State Department official and his wife, both mortally injured, lay unnoticed for two days after an auto accident sent their car plunging down a 35foot ravine alongside the heavily traveled Connecticut Turnpike here.

title: Advertising:
description: Benton & Bowles, a major consumergoods agency for Procter & Gamble, has just been named to handle the advertising to the health professions for four of P. & G.'s products.

title: COURT FREES BECK IN CONSPIRACY CASE
description: Louis Beck, 70yearold for mer confidential secretary to Surrogate Samuel Difalco, was freed yesterday after pleading guilty to taking part in a con spiracy seeking to influence a Supreme Court justice in im posing sentence on a convicted extortionist.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Comparing the Journeys
description: MOSCOW, May 24Peking was an adventure; Moscow is a meeting of merchants. In China, the President was Marco Polo, marveling at the novelty of it all on a journey of discovery. Here he is the traveling salesman, hopeful but cagey about opening some new accounts in a familiar territory.

title: A New Era for Historic Home for Women
description: Many of the antique pins and necklaces sold yesterday at an improvised boutique to raise funds for the Asso ciation Residence for Women were owned by residents of the home who had worn the ornaments as girls and young women.

title: 6 ARE DEAD IN BLAST AT MUNITIONS PLANT
description: KILN, Miss., May 24 (UPI) Explosions and fire swept a military munitions plant near this small south Mississippi community today, sending in cendiary flares hurtling into smokefilled sky and killing six persons.

title: US PLANES STRIKE AT POWER PLANTS IN THE HANOI AREA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 25American Air Force and Navy jet aircraft heavily attacked North Viet namese power plants and oil storage tanks in the Hanoi Haiphong area Tuesday and yesterday, the United States command reported.

title: Executive Changes
description: W. Glenn Gordon has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Turbo dyne Corporation, effective June 30. He replaces Arthur P. Burris, who is retiring but will continue as vice chairman of the board of directors.

title: U.S. CHARGES HANOI SEEKS DOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) The State Department said that North Vietnam was seeking political domination of South Vietnam and dis missed assertions by Le Duc Tho, Hanoi's chief negotiator in Paris, that the other side sought a coalition Government in Saigon.

title: Retreat on Rights
description: The Supreme Court decisions permitting criminal con victions by less than unanimous juries and narrowing witnesses immunity against selfincrimination are dis quieting in their practical effects but, even more, portents of things to come.

title: HAROLD DEAN DIES; EXCON ED AIDE, 84
description: MAITLAND, Fla., May 24 (UPI)Harold C. Dean, a former vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died today. He was 84 years old and had lived here since his retirement in April, 1953.

title: British Experts Support Research on Aborted Fetuses
description: LONDON, May 24 (AP) British medical and legal ex perts have called on the Gov ernment to allow scientists to use human fetuses obtained in abortions for such projects as the search for a cancer cure.

title: RISE AT 3YEAR LOW FOR BUILDING LABOR
description: The smallest increase in three years in the cost of construction labor and materials across the nation was announced yester day by the Dodge building services of the McGrawHill Company.

title: Amex Indicator Lists O.05 Gain; Counter Index Moves Up by 1.26
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange recovered their slight loss on Tuesday and snapped back yesterday to 27.88, up 0.05, as measured by the index.

title: Brezhnev: Tough, Flexible Negotiator
description: MOSCOW, May 24  I'd rather negotiate with Brezhnev than Kosygin, a senior West ern Ambassador confided. Kosygin is the toughest negoti ator of the whole damn bunch. When he has instructions from the Politburo, he doesn't budge an inch. Don't misunderstand Brezhnev is plenty tough, too. But he seems to have more give, and more authority to give. He's the one to decide when to use the fallback position.

title: RESERVE ASSETS UP; GOLD STOCKS STEADY
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (Reuters)Total reserve assets of the United States increased by $15million in April to $12, 285,000,000 while the gold stock remained unchanged, the Treasury reported today.

title: America in the Kitchen: As 3 Cookbook Authors See It
description: Like any large and com plex subject, American cook ing can be interpreted from many points of view, all dif ferent, each true to its way, This is the case with three American cookbooks that have just been published.

title: MODEST ADVANCE MADE BY STOCKS
description: Glamour issues and some bluechip stocks set tile pace yesterday as the stock market registered a modest advance in steppedup trading.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your rather murky May 16 editorial on the city budget suggests, if we un derstand it, that (1) there is something questionable about the process of re ducing the budget gap as new reve nues are supplied by the competent legislative authorities and (2) the ex ecutive management of city govern ment has suffered from an insufficient mayoral mandate for productivity improvement.

title: Cardenal Belts 2 for Chicago Hooton Wins
description: CHICAGO, May 24  Willie Mays finally saw the New York Mets lose a game today.

title: $2.5Million Pilot Boat Makes Debut Here After Trip From Wisconsin
description: The $2.5million pilot boat New York, the first newly constructed vessel of her type to make a debut here in 75 years, arrived yesterday after a 2,500mile maiden voyage from Wisconsin.

title: Methadone Program Is Praised And Attacked by Drug Experts
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Conflicting pleas for more lib eral methadone treatment for heroin addicts and warnings that methadone will compound existing addiction problems were aired today before the Senate Subcommittee on Alco holism and Narcotics.

title: Businessmen, Come to Lecture the Police, Listen
description: Two members of the Asso ciation for a Better New York, went to a training session yes terday for policemen intending to talk about the problems of the business community and what the police should do about them.

title: MORE 852S ON WAY TO SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Pentagon reported today that additional B52 bombers were being sent to Southeast Asia for use in the Vietnam war.

title: Credit Markets: Bond Prices Show Another Gain
description: Bond prices continued to forge ahead yesterday, though not with quite as much enthu siasm as earlier in the week.

title: CORDELIA BIDDLE, 56, MAGAZINE AIDE, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24  Mrs. Cordelia Frances Fenton Biddle, wife of Livingston L. Biddle Jr., the novelist and for mer deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, died of cancer here on Monday. She was 56 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: Texas Instruments Elects
description: Texas Instruments, Inc., has elected J. Fred Bucy, A. Ray McCord and E. O. Vetlet as ex ecutive vice presidents. New group vice presidents are Stew art Carrell, C. M. Chang, Grant A. Dove, Edward S. Hill and Sam K. Smith.

title: The Political Torture of a Woman Shakes Argentina
description: GOYA, Argentina, May 15 Nothing has brought home the problem of political torture to Argentines more forcibly than the experiences of Norma Morello.

title: PRESIDENT URGES FREE, FAIR TRADE
description: PARIS, May 24  President Nixon called today for a free and fair system of trade the United States and France tried to patch up differences that could hold up reform the world monetary and trading order.

title: Some Big City Banks Cut StockbrokerLoan Rates
description: A number of major New York City banks, led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany, have reduced the mini mum rates they charge on loans to stockbrokers to 4 per cent from 5 per cent.

title: Tie Games to Count In N.F.L. Standing
description: In an effort to stress win ning of the games rather than merely qualifying for the playoffs, the National Foot ball League's owners yester day agreed to a change in figuring the standing of the teams. Henceforth games that end in ties will be counted as one halfgame won and one halfgame lost. Percentages will determine the order of the standing as heretofore.

title: City Stores Loss Widened In Quarter
description: The City Stores Company, whose retail chain in cludes Franklin Simon, W.83. Sloane and Hearn's in the New York metropolitan area, had slightly increased sales but a wider loss in the 13 weeks ended April 29, shareholders were told at the annual meet ing yesterday.

title: Southern Company
description: Earnings of the Southern Company are expected to aver age between $1.85 and $1.90 a share this year, Alvin W. Vogtle Jr., president, reported at yes terclay's annual meeting in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. Last year the utility holding company earned $1.71 a share. The an ticipated 1972 earnings do not take into account any rate in creases that may be granted during the year, he said, adding that several operating subsidi aries have several rate in creases pending.

title: Franklin Elects a New President
description: The Franklin New York Corporation announced yes terday the election of Paul Luftig, 42 years old, as presi dent and chief administrative officer of both the company and its principal subsidiary, the Franklin National Bank.

title: Navy Loses Oil Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 24 (UPI)A Federal judge today dismissed a suit filed by the Navy, accusing the Standard Oil Company of California of illegally pumping oil from the Navy's Elk Hills oil reserve.

title: Morrisania Section of Bronx Gets New Maternity Center
description: A new maternity and family planning center built from pre fabricated materials was opened yesterday in the Morri sania section of the Bronx.

title: Kennedy Group Reports A Big Civilian War Toll
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the staff of his Senate sub committee on refugees esti mated today that the renewed fighting in South Vietnam had resulted in 40,000 to 50,000 civ ilian war casualties, including about 15,000 dead, by the first week in May.

title: Customs Official Appointed
description: The appointment of Roland Raymond as assistant regional commissioner of customs for the New YorkNew Jersey area was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Customs.

title: U. S.Soviet Accord Hailed by NASA Chief
description: WASHINGTON. May 24 (AP)James T. Fletcher, ad ministrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Ad ministration, today hailed the new United StatesSoviet ac cord on space cooperation.

title: Ohio Republicans Vow Unity In Effort to Elect Nixon
Federal Action Is Urged to Aid Industry in Foreign Markets
description: Two steel industry leaders called for governmental action here yesterday to help their in dustry compete in foreign markets.

title: More Loophole Than Law
description: Three months ago President Nixon signed a bill theo retically forbidding the hunting of animals from airplanes. The law, greeted by wildlife enthusiasts with more pleasure than was warranted, now turns out to be full of holes. As a result, so are hundreds of Alaskan wolves, blasted by shotguns from the windows of lowflying planes.

title: Roundup: Expos Morton Beats Phils on OneHitter
description: Carl Morton of the Expos, who gave up more runs than any other pitcher in the Na tional League last season and hadn't been doing much better this season, tossed a onehitter last night and de feated the Philadelphia Phil lies, 41, in Montreal. It was the ninth straight loss for the Phillies, the last three to Montreal. The Expos went into the Phillies series with a sevengame losing streak.

title: BREMER IS LINKED TO A TRIP BY NIXON
description: TORONTO, May 24  Arthur Herman Bremer, the man ac cused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in Laurel, Md., nine days, was in Ottawa during President Nixon's visit to Canada last month, The Toronto Star reported tonight.

title: FIRE AIDES STRESS NEW CALL SYSTEM
Facts on Title Fight
description: Principals Joe Frazier, Phila delphia, and Ron Stander, Council Bluffs, Iowa.

title: Teacher Is Upheld On His War Dissent
description: A teacher's right to express political views that do not dis rupt school work was vigorous ly supported here yesterday by the United States Court of Ap peals for the Second Circuit.

title: Advertising:
description: American Motors, which named the New York office of Cunningham & Walsh to handle its national advertis ing account on March 24, announced yesterday that the San Francisco office would handle its dealer ad vertising.

title: G.O.P. in Kentucky Begins Uphill Senate Battle
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24  Kentucky Republicans be gan their usual uphill battle for a United States Senate seat today after giving their nomi nation for the post to former Gov. Louie B. Nunn in the primary yesterday.

title: LINDSAY LAYS GOALS FOR LAW PROFESSION
description: Mayor Lindsay told those attending a celebration of the centennial of the Brooklyn Bar Association last night that law yers ought to help restore faith in government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Dr. Richard Burack's May 13 letter concerning generic versus brandname drugs is fraught with halftruths and unwarranted slurs both on the medical profession and the pharmaceutical in dustry. In addition, It is tragic that Dr. Burack misinforms the public on so vital a matter as prescription drugs.

title: An Epitaph for the Great Society
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Don't just do something, reads the poster in the poverty worker's office. Stand there. It is a wry symbol of the harsh disillusionment with Federal social programs that has in creasingly infused Washington. The glory days of the Great Society, the don'tjuststand

title: Dance: The Royal Ballet Steps Out in Modern Style
description: Britain's Royal Ballet is never exactly full of sur prises, but its repertory pro gram at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday and Tuesday had its own modi cum of shock. The company, led by Rudolf Nureyev. no less, performed an American modern dance work to elec tronic music by Karlheinz Stockhausen. The choreogra phy was by Europe's leading choreographerwho happens to be an AmericanGlen Tetley.

title: STOCKBROKER GROUP ASKS STATUS CHANGE
description: A spokesman for a stock broker group said yesterday it had voted to change its consti tution and become a collective bargaining organization.

title: Two Killed in Copter Crash Are Identified as Germans
description: The police of the Missing Persons Bureau identified the bodies yesterday of the couple killed in a crash of a sight seeing helicopter April 17 in the East River near the Wall Street Heliport.

title: First 2 Air Aces of Vietnam War Are Here for Treat
description: The first two American fliers to shoot down five North Vietnamese MIG's are being treated here to two days on the town for what Navy spokesmen describe variously as a little exposure and a little reward, an infor mation tour and a move to get them home before their luck out.

title: 82% of Restaurants in Jersey Are Unsanitary, Report Says
description: A secret 1970 report by the New Jersey Health Department contends that up to 82 per cent of New Jersey's restau rants are unsanitary.

title: Samples of Those HomeCooked Dishes
description: A chartreuse is a fancy dish dis guised as a plain dish. The name is at tributed to the monks of Chartreuse who are supposed to have invented it to dodge fast days.

title: AntiSoviet Bomb Plot Is Laid to 4 on L.I.
description: LIDO BEACH, L. I., May 24 A conspiracy to blow up the residence of the Soviet mission to the United Nations at Glen Cove was reported broken up here last night with the arrest of four reputed members of the Jewish Defense League.

title: Burt Lancaster Acquitted
description: LOS ANGELES, May 2 (Reu ters)Burt Lancaster, the ac tor, was aquitted by a Munici pal Court jury yesterday on charges of drunken driving.

title: Strife in Madagascar
description: In other circumstances a threat of civil war in Madagascar would get little attention from the rest of the world. The island republic has racial, tribal and regional problems similar to those of many young nations of Africa and Asia. But in this period of deep Soviet military penetration and of expanding Chinese initiatives in East Africa, what happens in Madagascarsituated in the Indian Ocean along the oiltanker routes from the Middle Easttakes on much greater significance.

title: European Team Gives Up Attempt to Scale Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 24 (AP)A European team seek ing to climb Mount Everest has turned back short of its goal for the second consecutive year, leaving unconquered the treacherous southwest face of the world's highest mountain.

title: Virginia Menzies Is Married To Claus Labes in London
description: Miss Virginia Victoria Graham Menzies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Menzies of New York, Upper Brookville, L. I., London and Johannesburg, South Africa, was married in London yes terday afternoon to Claus G. Labes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Labes of Cologne, West Germany.

title: Humphrey Says He Saves Jobs And Ties His Rival to Welfare
description: PALMDALE, Calif., May 24 The choice for Californians, as, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, explains it, is between a jobs man like himself and a Demo cratic opponent who he said would put thousands of aero space workers on unemploy ment and saddle the rest with a $72billion welfare program.

title: Konstantin D.Bushuyev
description: MOSCOW, May 24With the signing today of the So vietUnited States agreement on a joint space mission in 1975, yet another space scien tist of the Soviet Union was publicly identified for the first time.

title: 'Malcolm X'
description: We suspect that even the slain subject of the documentary "Malcolm X," depicted as an uncommonly shrewd man, would concur with our one reservation about this film. Over and over, relentlessly and interminably, it pelts the viewer with random footage of armed whites battering blacks. Granted, this turbulence suits the fiery, autobiographical quotes (from James Earl Jones) of the subject's formative years. But it becomes simply monotonous punctuation in the thoughtful last chapter of a generally rounded, often fascinating movie.It is the documentary core of this film, in the black militant's speeches and interviews and the movie's surprisingly balanced format, quoting dissenters in policy, that makes its real worth. The picture was adapted by Arnold Perl from "The Autobiography of Malcolm X." His widow, Betty Shabazz, a cosponsor of the movie and a woman with a beautiful speaking voice, appears briefly and effectively, one of many meaningful cameos.The personal drama is so credible and ironic, as the dynamic leader breaks with his Islam colleagues and strives, more reflectively, for Afro-American unity, that the footage of the gunned-down Malcolm (a chaotic aftermath) comes as a jolt. The conclusion, with the funeral and various testimonies, is numbing and touching. The sight we will remember is the black face inside the coffin, eyes closed forever, head swathed in white.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If you have to start from scratch on a fall wardrobe, buy a sweater. It's the safest road to fashion. Add a pair of pants with cuffs, a high waistband and pleats and you're on your way. Your coat can be a flaring topper or a jacket with a belt that wraps like a bathrobe, either one about fingertip length. Alternatives are waistlength battlejackets or kneelength wrap coats that can go over dresses if you're not disposed to pants. For evening any thing goes, from sweaters to chemises to strapless dresses.

title: Kennedy Assails Nixon on Absence of Gun Curbs
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, told Illinois Democrats tonight that the cruelest single irony of the Nixon Administration was the President's failure to get gun controls.

title: Post Offices Across Nation Picketed by Union Workers
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) Union postal workers picket ed post offices across the na tion today, demanding settle ment of local bargaining dis putes and the right to strike.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS VOTING LAW SHIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)The House Administra tion Committee reached tenta tive agreement today on revi sions in disclosure provisions of the new Federal campaign spending law.

title: Metromedia Chooses President for Playbill
description: Metromedia has finally filled the president's slot at Playbill. And filled it with Stanley R. Greenfield, a 47 yearold exLook man who more recently has been a senior vice president and a vice president and a board member at ZiffDavis Pub lishing.

title: LOW INFLATION RATE IS CALLED DOUBTFUL
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A former member of the Pay Board said today that it ap peared highly doubtful that President Nixon's goal of re ducing inflation to an annual rate of 2 to 3 per cent by the end of the year could be met.

title: Atlanta Considers A Green Belt Plan Similar to London's
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (UPI) The Atlanta metropolitan area may some day be patterned after Londonthe central city surrounded by a greesi belt with a ring of satellite cities or new towns.

title: Saigon Tries to Raise Army Morale by Gifts of Cash Donated by Businessmen
Fire Curbs in U.S. Forests
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 24 (UPI)Tinderdry conditions have forced the United States Forest Service to place all na tional forests in New Mexico under fire and smoking restric tions, the service said today. The restrictions are effective at 8 A.M. Friday for the Santa Fe and Carson National Forests, the only two that have not had such restrictions until now.

title: Private Pension System Termed Fraud by Nader
description: Ralph Nader contended yesterday that the private pen sion system represented one of the most comprehensive consumer frauds that many Americans ever encounter. At the same time, the consumer advocate outlined details of a plan for restructuring the system so as to provide vest ing for an individual from the first day and also give every employe greater control over his share of pension funds.

title: Watney Mann Parries in TakeOver Battle
description: LONDON, May 24In the biggest and most bitterly fought takeover battle ever seen here, Watney Mann, Ltd., the huge beer, whisky and pub group, today offered its stockholders a free share for every four they own if they would turn down a billiondollar merger bid from Grand Metropolitan Hotels, Ltd.

title: N.B.A. Warns of Penalties if Stars Play Tonight
Special Citation Voted By Critics to Rabe Play
description: The New York Drama Critics Circle will give special citation to David Rabe's Sticks and Bones, which erroneously had been adjudged the best drama of the 197172 season because of a mistake in the tabulation of the critics votes.

title: Soviet Minister of Culture Says Solzhenitsyn Opposes Our Entire Society
description: MOSCOW, May 24  Ye katerina A. Furtseva, the Min ister of Culture. used a news conference for visiting journal ists today to deliver an attack on the author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  A sharp northeast wind was shredding the tops of the combers. Despite the bright sunlight, the morning was raw, but we had the west running tide we wanted, the tide that had been producing striped bass the previous several days off Wasque Point on Martha's Vineyard's south shore.

title: MOB'S INFLUENCE ON JOCKEYS TOLD
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Half the horses racing in New England are owned by front men for the mob, Joe (The Baron) Barboza testified today before a Congressional commit tee investigating underworld influence in sports.

title: Japanese Trading Mission Seeks More U.S. Exports
description: An increasingly affluent Ja pan offers a market for all kinds of American products from golf clubs to lipsticks, members of a Japanese trade mission said here yesterday. The mission seeks to encourage exports from the United States.

title: STUDY FINDS U.S. MAY FACE A NEED FOR BIG TAX RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A major study by the Brookings Institution concludes that the Federal Government has ready overcommitted for the next two years all the revenues it can expect from a growing economy and cannot spend more on solving social or other problems without a big tax in crease.

title: Five Groups Make N.H.L. Franchise Bids
description: At $200,000 a minute, five potential National Hockey League franchise holders made their pitch to the league yes terday to field one of two clubs that will be added in 1974.

title: Bombs Rip Legion Post And U. S. Office in Paris
description: PARIS, Thursday, May 25 (UPI)Two bomb blasts early today destroyed washrooms in the United States con sulate and an American Le gion post, the police said. There were no injuries.

title: Notes on People
description: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences governing council has denied a recom mended award to Ezra Pound, the poet, on the alleged grounds it found his political and racial views obnoxious. A fourman literary commit tee recommended Mr. Pound, who lives in Italy, for, the $2,000 Emerson Thoreau Medal, but the council voted down the award, 13 to 9.

title: Gulf Will Purchase Algerian Crude Oil
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation confirmed yesterday that it would buy very important quantities of Algerian crude oil starting in 1972 and until 19801

title: 42 Victory for Hinton in First Mound Start
description: A mere seven weeks after having left Florida, Manager Ralph Houk finally found the opportunity last night to use that New York Yankee depth he had talked about so much during spring training, and it produced a 42 victory over the Cleveland Indians at the Sta dium.

title: VIETNAM A TOPIC
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, May 25 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and President Nixon signed an agreement on space cooperation yesterday, proclaiming a com mitment to carry out a joint flight with linked Soviet and American spacecraft in 1975.

title: Board of Estimate Slashes $35Million From Budget
description: A city budget slashed by $35million through the elimi nation of a proposed rise in water rates was approved last night by the Board of Estimate at 11:43 P.M., just 17 minutes before a midnight deadline under the City Charter and over vehement objections from Mayor Lindsay.

title: Life Sentence in Slaying
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) A jury convicted James Earl lak, 36 years old, of firstdegree murder yesterday and sentenced him to life imprisonment. He was found guilty of slashing the throat of Philip Harman, 17 months ago and dumping the body on the grounds of the Philadelphia State Hospital.

title: Texts of the U. S.Soviet Agreements on Cooperation in Space Exploration and in Science and Technology
description: The United States of Amer ica and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: Bremer, in a Heavily Guarded Courtroom, Pleads Not Guilty to U.S. Charges in Shooting of Wallace
description: BALTIMORE, May 24  With a nervous smile flickering across his face, Arthur Herman Brem er stood before a Federal judge here today and pleaded not guilty to charges arising from the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: BACHE'S REVENUES AND EARNINGS FALL
description: Bache & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that net income and revenues in the fiscal first quarter, ended April 30, fell from yearearlier levels.

title: Leftists Seized, Turks Say
description: ISTANBUL, May, 24 (UPI) In a major crackdown today on the leftist Turkish People's Liberation Army, security forces raided what were said to be hideouts of urban guerrillas, arresting 24 men and a woman and seizing what they described as large quantities of arms.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINEADVT.

title: 3 VISLOCKY DANCES GIVEN ON TERRACE
description: Dorothy Vislocky made re freshing use, literally and figu ratively, of a pleasant environ ment in her three dance pieces Tuesday night at the Delacorte SitOut, an outdoor garden terrace accessible through the seventh floor of the Hunter College building.

title: Frazier Heavy Choice Tonight
description: OMAHA, May 24In what amounts to another physical exam for him, Joe Frazier will defend his world heavyweight boxing title tomorrow night against Ron Stander, an obscure challenger whose local popu larity is his dominant attribute.

title: Ford Hopes to Meet Goal On 73 Emission Standards
description: DETROIT, May 24 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company hopes to complete retesting of its automobile engines to meet 1973 emission standards and still meet scheduled Sept. 22 introductions of its new models, a top company execu tive said today.

title: PROBLEMS SEEN IN GENETIC TESTS
description: A research group, including leading American biologists, lawyers and theologians, has raised questions about the psy chological and social impact of mass screening for such genet ic characteristics as sickle cell and TaySachs disease.

title: ALBERT S. DAVIS JR., PATENT LAWYER, 61
description: Albert Samuel Davis Jr., a patent lawyer who had been counsel since 1942 to the Re search Corporation, a nonprofit body that supports research in educational and scientific insti tutions, died Tuesday in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N. J. He was 61 years old and lived at 731 Garretson Road; Somerville, N. J.

title: Bridge: Semifinal Draw Completed  For Von Zedtwitz Team Play
description: The Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship reached its semifinal stage as a result of three matches played this week. The semi final draw matches a team headed by Sam Stayman against one led by Jeff Ru bens, and a John Solodar captained team against one led by George Lewis. All four teams have lost one match.

title: Law Officers Ask Gun Curb
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 24 (UPI)Private citizens should not be allowed to buy or own pistolsand perhaps even rifles the Los Angeles police chief and county sheriff said yester Aay. I know such statements will bring down the wrath of certain interested groups, but we can no longer live with the constant threat of death, said Sheriff Peter Pitchess, whose comments were endorsed by Police Chief Edward M. Davis.

title: Jean Antrim Plays Tankas, Saito Work
description: For some years now, the music of many of the world's oldest cultures has been flowing toward a confluence with our own Western vari eties, and the results have been unquestionably vitaliz ing, if sometimes confusing. Things have reached the point, in fact, where one could listen to the first New York performance of a work called Tankas at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night and not really he sure whether Eva Saito, the com poser, is a Japanese with Western leanings or the other way around.

title: 10% Vote in Rhode Island Sets a Low for This Year
ROBBER IS GIVEN HELP BY A JUDGE
description: MIAMI, May 24 (AP) When Joseph Armstrong pleaded guil ty to armed robbery last month. Criminal Court Judge Al Sepe cailed it an environmentally motivated crime. The same judge found him a job and freed him from jail when he discovered Armstrong's family living in a ratinfested house.

title: NEW ALIBHAI WINS BELMONT FEATURE
description: A gathering of 3yearolds pointing for the Belmont Stakes and the Withers and older horses competing in the $28,225 Edgemere Handicap combined to keep stakesmind ed followers of form interested at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: ArmTwisting Marks Budget Negotiations
description: They're at a real im passe, Councilman Bertram L. Gelfand, Bronx Democrat, said early yesterday after noon. I will predict that there will be sonic Criminal Court judges made between now and midnight.

title: CHARLES HILTON OF CLOTHIER HERE
description: Charles M. Hilton, president and chairman of the Browning Fifth Avenue men's clothing stores, died Tuesday in River view Hospital, Red Bank, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived at 51 Bellevue Avenue in Rum son, N. J.

title: Trevino Threatens to Skip Westchester Over Caddie Issue
The Real Populism Fights Unequal Wealth
description: WASHINGTONIn 1912 Senator Robert LaFollette wrote, I have be come more and more impressed with the deep underlying singleness of the issue. It is not the tariff or conserva tion or the currency. It is not the trusts. The supreme issue, involving all the others, is the encroachment of the powerful few upon the rights of the many.

title: BIG BOARD APPROVES SPECIALIST RULING
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday it had approved a rule allowing spe cialist firms to become publicly owned. Two years ago, bro kerage firms gained permission from the Big Board to go pub lic.

title: Decade of Change in U. S. Spending
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Following is a table from the Brookings Institution study, Setting National Pri orities: The 1973 Budget, showing the changing com position of Federal expenditures in the 10 years starting with the fiscal year 1963:

title: Wallace Backers Split In Indiana on 3d Party
Panel Told of Need for Good Jobs for ExConvicts
description: Witnesses testifying before the City Commission on Human Rights agreed yesterday that society must provide Former convicts with meaningful, well paying jobs as soon as they leave prison. But there was no agreement on how this goal should be achieved.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Maremont Corporation, Chicago auto parts company with $241.07million in sales last year, plans to sell 688,191 shares of common stock through an underwriting, net work managed by Kuhn, Loeb & Co. The shares to be offered give effect to a 3for2 stock split scheduled May 31. Of the total, 300,000 will be sold for Maremont itself and 388,191 by the underwriters after they con vert some preferred stock and exercise warrants they are buy ing from some insurance com panies.

title: U.S.TOUSETANKER AS A BENGALI SILO
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Tim United States Government has chartered the largest Amer ican merchant ship, the tanker Manhattan, to serve as a float ing grain silo off the coast of Bangladesh to bypass damaged and congested port facilities and to speed up distribution of food to the country's interior.

title: 300 FROM HUNGARY ADDRESSED BY POPE
description: ROME, May 24Pope Paul VI, in an address today to the first group of pilgrims from Hungary to Rome since the end of World War II, expressed his good wishes for the church in their country, 'and also for the state.

title: Dakotan Falls Short of Goal in Missouri
Dr. Felix MartiIbanez is Dead; Psychiatrist and Publisher, 60
description: Dr. Felix MartiIbanez, a psy chiatrist, publisher and author, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was CO years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Surgeons Refuse Duty At Lincoln Over Security
description: Lincoln Hospital resumed all medical services yesterday after a night in which its emer gency room was forced to divert ambulances to another hospital.

title: Fete for Basketball Stars
description: The Harlem Professionals, Inc., who run the Rucker bas ketball tournament each sum mer, will stage an awards din ner tomorrow night at Big Wilt's Smalls Paradise, 135th Street and Seventh Avenue. Among the players to be hon ored are Earl Monroe, Dean Meminger, Julius Erving, Charlie Scott, Connie Hawkins and Nate Archibald.

title: Chess:
description: It is a chess maxim that no one ever won a game by resigning. This means, obvi ously, that if one plays on in a lost position there is al ways the chance, however remote, that one's opponent may make a mistake and throw away his advantage.

title: Nassau Doctors Elect Radiologist
description: Dr. Perry Mandel, a Gar den City radiologist who has been active in cancer prevention and detection programs, was elected pres ident of the Nassau County Medical Society last night.

title: 2 Manufacturers Plan 100,000Tire Recall
description: WASHINGTON. May 24 (UPI)  The Transportation Department announced today that two major tire manu facturers would recall 100.000 tires that failed to meet Gov ernment safety standards. It said continued use of the tires could be dangerous under certain circumstances.

title: Blaze Damages an Exhibit In Natural History Museum
description: A fire in a display at the Museum of Natural History started shortly after noon yes terday and burned for more than half an hour. Firemen moved about 100 people out of the area, but no one was injured.

title: Iselin Adds Programing Duties To Executive Posts at WNET
description: John Jay Iselin, vice presi dent and general manager of WNET/13 here, was named yesterday to the additional post of station managing direc tor. This will place him in charge of all broadcasting acti vities, including the planning and production of programs for national distribution by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Theater: Icon and Image
description: The Bread and Puppet Theater offers innocence, spirituality and extraordinary theatrical ingenuity  three qualities that are greatly in evidence in the troupe's The Stations of the Cross, its Easter play having an un seasonal but welcome New York premiere engagement at St. Clement's Church. The Peter Schumann production opened Tuesday and runs through Sunday.

title: Vietnam Veteran, Sought For Arson. Surrenders
description: A 22yearold wounded Viet nam veteran who the police said had been AWOL from Fort Dix, N. J., for the last year, sur rendered to the City Fire Mar shal's office yesterday morning on an arson charge.

title: Much Less of a BigWar Risk Seen by Bundy in Next Decade
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  McGeorge Bundy, adviser on na tional security to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, predicted today that the risk of largescale war would be much less in the com ing decade than at any time since World War II.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the wake of the attack on Gov ernor Wallace, the country asks itself: What can be done to stop these as saults on our leaders?

title: Glynn Stephen Lunney
description: A Soviet space official spoke recently of a forthcom ing meeting with American space engineers. Asked who would be on the American team, he replied without hes itation: I hope Glynn Lun ney.

title: TV: Diverse Ventures in News and Public Affairs
description: Some notes on television ventures in news and public affairs:

title: Study's Tax Reform Plan Would Curb Preferences
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 The Brookings Institution out lined today a way to increase Federal tax collections by $13.5billion with a taxreform program that would concen trate on reducing present tax preferences, rather than elim inating them.

title: MRS. HENRY F. GRADY
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., May 24 (AP)Mrs. Lucretia del Valle Grady, widow of Henry F. Grady, who had been Ambas sador to Greece,. India and Iran, died yesterday of a heart attack. She was 79 years old.

title: MILTON BARON
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 24 (AP)Milton Baron, a retired theatrical producer, died Monday at the Martha's Vineyard Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Unity in Space
description: More than space research or scientific progress involved in the agreement on space cooperation signed by President Nixon and Premier Kosygin in Moscow yesterday. The decision to have American and Soviet astronauts work together intimately so that space ships from the two nations can rendezvous and clock in the summer of 1975 has, above all, immense political signi ficance.

title: PRICE CUT RULED FOR DAMN CHAIN
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  The Price Commission ordered Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc., to day to roll back its prices, as serting that the big New York retail grocery chain had illegal ly raised prices and exceeded its permissible profit margin.

title: LONE STAR GAS SETS A CASH ACQUISITION
description: The Lone Star Gas Company has agreed in principle to ac quire the Industrial Gas Supply Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Stone & Webster, Inc., for $13.75million in cash, it was announced yesterday.

title: Start Indefinite for Race TV
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 A track spokesman for Roose velt Raceway said today that the television of Roosevelt races in connection with an agreement with the New York City Offtrack Betting Corpo ration would not start until some time after the State Har ness Racing Commission had deliberatcd the agreement. Tne commission will take up the matter next Wednesday.

title: Second Oil Spill in Groton
description: GROTON, Conn., May 24 The second oil spill in as many days in the Hess Oil Company terminal on the Thames River fouled Groton city beaches to day at the entrance to Long Island Sound. A total of about 200 gallons was spilled in two days while workers were trans ferring the oil to barges.

title: HOSPITAL TALKS ASSAILED BY UNION
description: Repeating the threat of a hospital strike, Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Un ion, charged yesterday that the League of Voluntary Hospitals had refused to bargain on a new contract and had broken off negotiations.

title: Bill Giving Rights to Fetuses Advances in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, May 24 (UPI)  A bill granting the rights of chil dren to fetuses from the mo ment of conception has won initial approval by the Massa chusetts House on an over whelming vote.

title: DoItYourself Parents Patrol Streets on the East Side
description: Can a mother and father wearing blue and white arm bands make the East Side safe for private school chil dren?

title: MEL SEEKS CUT IN PORT UNIT'S AID
description: Theodore W. Kheel called on the Federal Government yester day to end all capital grants to the Port of New York Au thority for masstransportation projects.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The kids, the kids! Remember the kids? Of course. Who could forget? They were the hit of the sixties, the agony and the glory. Already we begin to miss them. The music is tired. Everybody is getting older, duller. The country feels kneedeep in lint. Massacre's fre quency has made it a bore. Nixon is a rerun. The lovein is forgotten, and the country pins its hope on jail. Where have they gone, those great exciting, infuriating kids?

title: 10 Unions Here Endorse Lowenstein for Congress
description: The local branches of 10 trade unions gave their support yesterday to former Represent ative Allard K. Lowenstein in his primary contest with Rep resentative John J. Rooney for the Democratic nomination in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: Diplomatic Corps in Hanoi: In Quiet of a Storm Center
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 24The. mood in Hanoi's small diplomatic community this week is strange: it is a little like being in the quiet of a storm, center.

title: PROMINENT FOES OF WAR ARRESTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  About 100 antiwar protesters, many of them prominent in the arts and sciences, were arrested today when they refused to leave the Capitol.

title: Market Place: Generalist Seen  Out of Spotlight
description: In recent years, Wall Street has had a love affair with the hot shot research analyst who searched the land for that concept stockthe com pany with a story that would take it to the moon.

title: MidMay New Auto Sales Surged 14% to Peak Level
description: DETROIT, May 24Newcar sales in midMay surged to 277,993, up 14 per cent from 243,075 a year ago and midMay record for the American industry. All four com panies reported gains in the sale of domestictype cars. Here are the May 1120 figures:

title: Seagren Says 19 Feet Is Within Reach

description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Legislation to set up a nation al nofault automobile insur ance system was approved to day by, the Senate Commerce Committee, 13 to 4.

title: Antitrust Charge Filed by Consumers Union in a Rare Tactic
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A novel lawsuit by Consumers Union charged today that the recent agreement negotiated by the State Department and for eign steel producers to limit steel imports into the United States for the next three years violates the antitrust laws.

title: 7 Youths Arrested After a Rampage On BMT Subway
description: A band of high school boys, many of them armed with knives, went on a subway ram page in midtown around noon yesterday, robbing, beating people up and generally terror izing those aboard a BMT train bound for Astoria, Queens.

title: Accord Is Big Step in Handling Space Emergencies
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 In their agreement today on a docking of spacecraft in 1975, the United States and the Soviet Union took an im portant step toward a means of handling an emergency res cue in space, something both nations have always lacked.

title: Man Awaiting Trial Killed in Explosion In Bay State Prison
description: WALPOLE, Mass., May 24 (UPI)Stanley R. Bond, who was awaiting trial for allegedly materminding a bank robbery in which a policeman was killed died today in Walpole State Prison in an explosion.

title: Illegal Hunting Attacked
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The Interior Department an nounced today a crackdown on illegal biggame hunting in Montana, Alaska, Washington, California and Wyoming. Sec retary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said Interior's garne management agencies and state conservation officers were executing warrants and serving subpoenas in the five states against organized illegal hunt ing.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MOSCOW, May 24 (AP) Van Cliburn is expected to perform Friday night at a banquet being given by Pres ident and Mrs. Nixon for their Russian hosts.

title: Grand Union Company
description: Capital expenditures of the Grand Union Company this year will total $33.7million, up 29 per cent over 1971, Charles G. Rodman, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Saddle Brook, N. J.

title: Chicago Teachers Accord Avoids a Strike Due Today
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI) The Chicago teachers union House of Representatives ac cepted tonight a school board proposal to head off a strike scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Russians Lose in Cup Soccer To Scotland, Then Protest
description: BARCELONA, Spain, May 24 (UPI)Moscow Dynamo lost the European Cup Winners soc cer cup final to the Glasgow Rangers, 32, tonight and im mediately lodged a request that the result be annulled and the game replayed.

title: Cliburn and Miss Peters Are Hailed in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, May 24 (Reuters)  The American pianist Van Cliburn and the Metropolitan opera soprano Roberta Peters received en thusiastic reviews today from the Soviet press after firstnight performances yes terday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:In the April 30 column of his weekly advertisement in the Times Week in Review, Albert Shenker gave a dis torted impression of the contents of my article on full state funding of schools in the March 31 Wall Street Journal, attacked what he called My dangerous views and held them up to ridicule ("shoddy reasoning"). He im puted to me the statement or opinion that pupil achievements in reading and math in many New York City schools are low because of high expenditures and small class sizes in those schools.

title: Monmouth K.C. Prefers to Stay on the Small Side
description: The Monmouth County Ken nel Club, organized in 1908, never has tried to have large membership.

title: Suspect Is Seized in Theft Of $1.68Million on Wall St.
description: A 32yearold Long Island man, formerly a partner in a Wall Street firm, has been ar rested on a 12count indict ment involving the theft of $1.68million, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

title: Blasts at U.S. Base in Germany Kill 3
description: HEIDELBERG, Germany, May 24 (AP)Bombs went off tonight in two cars parked in side the United States Army's European command headquar ters compound, killing three American servicemen and in juring five other persons.

title: Tito at 80: An Uncomplicated Marxist
description: Marshal Tito is 80 today. Between May 1944 and May 1972, I saw him 28 times, including 12 times in the war. The last time I saw him was on May 12, in the presence of his wife, Jovanka, in Belgrade, for an hour's conversation. Except for his weight, he made the same impression on me as he did on May 9, 1944, when, as an American pool correspondent, I dined with him in a cabin beside a lake inside an electrically lit cave behind a waterfall in wartom Bosnia. He is still athletic with his head high, steps and gestures brisk, thoughts clear and words simple, filling the room with energy and decision, and he is still the least complicated Marxist of them all. Tito seems to belong to that extraor dinary modern generation of longliving leaders in so many fields, such as Churchill, De Valera, Picasso, Casals.

title: Aquarium at Coney Island Closed by Contract Dispute
description: The New York Aquarium at, Coney Island was closed by a strike yesterday and plans were made by management and labor to meet at 1 P.M. today with the State Mediation Board at 270 Broadway. Supervisors are caring for the fishes and mam mals.

title: Davis Defense Rests With Testimony by Soledad Brother
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 24 The defense in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy trial of Angela Davis rested today without calling the defendant.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill for Panel to Site Power Plants
description: ALBANY, May 24  Gov ernor Rockefeller signed into law today a bill creating state board to oversee the sit ing of electric power generat ing plants to assure that they will be compatible with their environment.

title: Transit Agency Funds Bin Approved by the House
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a $2.9 billion appropriation bill for the Department of Transport ation and related agencies for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: On to California
description: From an unpromising beginning, Senator George McGovern continues to move forward in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination. His victories in Oregon and Rhode Island bring his delegate total to above 500. His capture of most of New York's delegates now seems a runaway certainty. If he adds California's 271 delegates in that state's winnertakeall primary June 6, he will have amassed approximately 1,000 votes and will be far ahead of his rivals. California thus becomes a critical battleground.

title: Belfast Man, 22, Shot Dead
description: BELFAST, May 24 (UPI) A lone gunman shot and killed Andrew Brennan, 22 years old, in the front drive of his home near the Roman Catholic An derstown area in Belfast short ly after 1 A.M. today as his Wife opened the door. Mr. Bren nan was the 339th fatality since violence flared up in Northern Ireland in August, 1969.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner ordered an audit yesterday of some of the administrative and employment practices of Community School Board 23, in the Oceanhill Brownsville section of Brooklyn, to determine the truth charges of political favoritism brought against the board by a parents group.

title: Venezuela ExRuler Returns
description: MAIQUETIA, Venezuela, May 24 (Reuters)Venezuela's for mer ruler, Marcos Perez Ji menez, returned here today after fourandahalf years of exile to a flagwaving welcome by an estimated 10,000 sup porters and in defiance of al charge of indirect responsibility for murder. Perez Jimenez, who ruled Venezuela with an iron hand from 1948 to 1959, has announced his intention of running for president in next year's elections.

title: $4Million in Heroin Seized; 2 Syrians Held in Seattle
description: SEEATTLE, May 24, (A) Heroin valued at more than $4 million has been seized in Seat tle and a retired Syrian police officer and his son have been arrested, the Customs Bureau announced today.

title: Disagreements Mark Decline Of County Leaders in the City
description: In 1968, the city's Demo cratic county leaders op posed Eugene J. McCarthy and Paul O'Dwyer in the New York Presidential and senatorial primary. Neverthe less, Mr. McCarthy and Mr. O'Dwyer scored decisive victories.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The most recent assassination at tempt against a public figure should come as no surprise. When the entire social and legal structure accepts, con dones and even encourages violence to solve problems (e.g. war, electric chairs), can we really expect that in dividuals will not consider similar methods as viable means to settle dif ferences?

title: A CATHOLIC SHIFT IN ULSTER HINTED
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 24  Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority, anxious about growing Protes tant militancy and uncertain about the terror tactics of the Irish Republican army, has made tentative steps to ward supporting William Whitelaw, the British admin istrator in Ulster.

Kenny, the Hudson County po litical leader who has spent 14 months in a Jersey City hospital contending he was too ill to stand trial on three Fed eral indictments. was commit ted today to a Federal medical center to determine whether he was well enough to go to prison.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the wake of the George Wallace shooting there will be a spate of lofty public breastbeating about the real guilt resting morally and ethically with the public and lack of respect for democratic processes and conduct.

title: An Israeli Madame Bovary
description: Ever since My Michael appeared in Hebrew in 1968, Amos Oz has been con sidered one of Israel's best young novel ists. Now 33, he has published two novels, two novellas, short stories and various political, social and literary essays. But advance rumors hardly prepare one for this first translation of his major work. My Michael is anything but a provincial achievement; it has nothing to do with noble kibbutzim, Sten guns and sabras, nor with the Talmudic dryness of Israel's Nobel Prizewinner, the late S. Y. Agnon. It's quite the last kind of book one expects from a young writer living in the midst of a melodramatic political situation, for My Michael is an extremely selfconscious and serious psychological novel, slow, thoughtful, selfassured and highly sophis ticated, full of the most skillful modula tions of tone and texture. On the surface it is very much what used to be called a woman's novel"the story of a disinte grating marriage told from the unhappy wife's point of view. In a way it's a modern Israeli Madame Bovary, a finely wrought portrait of a woman that is also a critique of a superficial masculine society. But unlike Emma Bovary, the heroine doesn't flee to romantic infidelity but to schizo

description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 24 (UPI)Cheered by his show ing in the Oregon primary, Gov. George C. Wallace visited to day with a group of reporters for the first time since he was wounded and told them, They say I'm doing fine.

It is one of the rare supergroups that continue to make bookings, wherever possible, to appear before relatively small audi ences, rather than the huge crowds of stadiumtype con certs. title: Church and State
description: There is growing support for the view that the wall of separation between church and state has outlived its usefulness. In the absence of any threat to establish a state religion and in recognition of both the greater liberalization of churches and the new ecumenical spirit between the faiths, the old Jeffersonian warning sounds quaint and obsolete to some political pragmatists.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It has recently become fashionable to argue that Senator George McGovern's economic proposals are radical, as if resort to such vague sloganeering were sufficient to demonstrate their undesirability. While The Times has commended Senator McGovern for shifting debate on... crucial tax, welfare and defense issues from vague rhetoric to specific proposals, and has expressed the hope that he could thereby stimulate intelligent discussion by all candidates (editorial, May 6), it is ironic that The Times itself was largely content to use vague rhetoric in discussing Senator McGovern's economic proposals, merely labeling them drastic, radical changes, drastically large estate and gift tax increases, etc.

title: Screen: 'Pied Piper' Anachronism:Title Role Taken by Donovan, Folk Singer 'Z.P.G.,' on Population Growth, Shares Bill
description: You wouldn't know by reading the ads but "The Pied Piper," which opened at a number of theaters here yesterday with a totally befuddled science-fiction film called "Z.P.G.," is a new work by Jacques Demy, the very talented, idiosyncratic French director who came out of the Nouvelle Vague with "Lola" and then went on to develop what amounted to a new kind of contemporary fairy tale with "The Umbrella of Cherbourg" and "The Young Girls of Rochefort."Paramount Pictures apparently couldn't squeeze Demy's name into the ads, which is too bad since the director is a much better reason for seeing the film than Donovan, the young English folk singer-composer who plays the title role with so little style and charm that it seems to be witting self-effacement.No matter how it's toldin the prose of the Brothers Grimm or in the poetry of Robert Browningthe legend of the Pied Piper of Hamelin, which dates from the 14th century, is a decidedly somber tale. This is something that Demy, with the help of the writers who worked with him on the screenplay, repeatedly emphasizes in the story extensions, which are almost always cruel, and in the color images, which are soft and lovely, but in the way of dark corners, tangled underbrush and piles of rotting leaves, things that can hide unspeakable terrors for the very young.The film, which Demy shot mostly in Germany with an English cast, features among other things, the burning at the stake of Melius the Jew, an old chemist who persists in seeking some kind of protection against the coming plague, instead of manufacturing fool's gold for the baron.There are also the marriage against her will, of the brgermeister's 11-year-old daughter, a pale, wispy girl who looks hardly 9, to the baron's evil son; bad-dream scenes of rats coming out of cakes, crawling out of beds, of people dying of plague, and, of course, the ending in which all the children of Hamelin follow the vengeful piper out of Hamelin, dancing into the countryside, never to be seen again.It's a very odd film, too scary for some children, I suspect, and too childlike for most adults, with the result that everything in the film becomes its own kind of anachronism, whether it's Donovan's several songs, the casting of a puffed-up Diana Dors as the brgermeister's lusty, ill-tempered wife, or the appearance of a weary English pilgrim who is inclined to say things like, "There's no craftsmanship left these days, no standards. Just greed.""Z.P.G.," initials that stand for zero population growth, is a sometimes funny (unintentionally), untimely meditation on the earth's over-population problems, set in some future smog-bound England where the World Deliberation Council has decreed that for 30 years there shall be no babies born.Women mad for motherhood who refuse to be content with mechanical dolls programmed to say "Mummy, I love you Mummy," take to giving birth in cellars and stealing each other's offspring.Geraldine Chaplin, who has become astonishingly beautiful since "Dr. Zhivago," Oliver Reed and Diane Cilento play the foolish roles without a single snicker.

title: Trial Date Is Set
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., May 25 (Reuters)Arthur A. Marshall Jr., the state's attorney for Prince Georges County, announced today a tentative trial date of July 12 for Arthur H. Bremer. Mr. Bremer was indicted on Tuesday by the county grand jury on 24 counts.

title: Pennsy Acquires New Cars
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday it was arranging to acquire by lease 1,500 new freight cars. A total of 2,350 cars have been acquired in the, company's freight equipment program this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is not at all clear that the Ullman bill, which ostensibly permits conservation and environmental organizations to do limited lobbying, will not hamper them even more than they are at present.

title: CITY COUNCIL FAILS TO ACT ON BUDGET; IT'S UP TO MAYOR
description: The City Council, caught in a flurry of accusations of double cross and facttwisting hurled at each other by Mayor Lindsay and Controller Abraham D. Beame, met briefly last night and despaired of all efforts to break an impasse over the expense budget.

title: The Politics of City BudgetPassing
description: Tampering with time and with one another's basic sensibilities, the elected politicians of city government have marked the period of budgetpassing as one long, jagged and memorable stretch of multibilliondollar politicking.

title: U.S. to Send Soviet Viruses for Studies
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The United States is preparing to send to the Soviet Union samples of about 100 cancer viruses discovered and studied in this country during the last 60 years.

title: ESPOSITO READY TO BACK M'GOVERN
description: In a major breakthrough for Senator George McGovern, Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, will endorse the South Dakota Senator's Presidential candidacy within the next week, sources close to Mr. McGovern and Mr. Esposito reported yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Night fell, a whippoorwill cried from the white oaks on the far shore, the wind fell to a whisper and in the moonwashed shallows of the salt pond, mating horseshoe crabs slid by in tandem.

title: Tight Security on French Line Fails to Mar Bon Voyage Gaiety
description: Additional security measures had little effect yesterday afternoon on the gaiety of the liner France's departure.

title: Honeywell Target in Geneva
description: GENEVA. May 25Windows of the building occupied by a Swiss sales subsidiary of Honeywell, Inc., the United States computer manufacturer, were smashed and antiAmerican Vietnam war slogans were daubed on the wall in red paint here early today.

title: Ill Widow of Frankfurter Near Charity on Pension
description: WASHINGTON, May 25In a nursing home here, Mrs. Felix Frankfurter is quietly approaching insolvency on the $5,000a year pension granted widows of Supreme Court Justices.

title: Mafia Spreading Through Italy, Rome's New Parliament Is Told
description: ROME, May 25A parliamentary commission that has been investigating the Mafia for more than eight years today depicted the Sicilian criminal organization as a cancer spreading throughout Italy.

title: Management Win Indicated In Voting at Liberty Leasing
description: The Liberty Leasing Company said yesterday that a preliminary count of proxies submitted at the annual meeting on Tuesday had indicated shareholder support for the management slate of directors.

title: Steel Industry Urged to Increase Its Political Activity
description: The head of the nation's second largest steel company urged the industry yesterday to become more active in Washington.

title: U.S.Command Reports Drop In Death Toll to 8 in Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25 (AP)Eight Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, seven were missing and 22 were wounded, the United States command announced today. This represented a decline from the week before, when 13 men were reported killed in action, 5 missing and 26 wounded.

title: Productivity Increases, bat Labor Costs Also Show Advances
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Government's composite index of leading economic indicators rose at nearboom proportions in March and April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: To Outflank the I.R.A.
description: In one of the most hopeful Ulster developments in many months, Northern Ireland's Roman Catholics in ever greater numbers are turning decisively against the Irish Republican Army and seeking a basis for cooperating with British Minister William Whitelaw. The isolation and disarmament of the I.R.A. in Catholic areas of Belfast and Londonderry remains one of the imperatives for restoring peace and launching reforms to aid Ulster's Catholic minority.

title: MITCHELL CALLS N0.2 POST OPEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 John N. Mitchell, manager of President Nixon's reelection campaign, said today that he regarded the selection of a Republican Vice Presidential nominee as an open question.

title: 2 ARE FOUND GUILTY OF DOUBLE MURDER
description: SOMERVILLE, N. J., May 25 (AP)Two 22yearold men accused of slashing to death a teeenaged boy and girl were found guilty tonight of murder, kidnapping and attempted murder.

title: Rail Traffic Up, Trucking Off
description: WASHINGTON, May 25Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended May 20 totaled an estimated 15.6 billion tonmiles, 15.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year, when there was a twoday nationwide strike. Carloadings in the same week totaled 523,234, up 12.3 per cent from last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported the week's tonnage fell 0.6 per cent.

title: Missiles and Pigs Coexist in North Vietnamese Countryside
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 25  There are more than 1,800 miles of dikes in North Vietnam. They are maintained and reinforced as they have been for centuries  by hand labor.

title: DOGS UPSETTING BROOKLYN HEIGHTS
description: The serenity and harmony of Brooklyn Heights are threatened by a clash between citizens over a highly emotional, issue: dogs that foul the streets.

title: First NASA Aircraft is Flown by Computer
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 25 (AP)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration flew its first aircraft entirely dependent on a computer system in a test today.

title: Nuisance in Technicolor
description: The wanton use of spray paint to deface subways, buses and public buildings has reached epidemic proportions. There is something to be said for graffiti when they take the form of modestly written, sometimes revealing inscriptionsbut not for the pointless names and blobs that now disfigure the city in technicolor.

title: Judgment Filed to Settle AutoBody Repair Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment today that would settle civil antitrust charges brought against two associations representing autobody repair concerns in Clarke County, Ga.

title: Soviet Official Confirms Rioting in Lithuanian City
description: MOSCOW, May 25 (AP)A Soviet official confirmed today that there had been rioting in the Lithuanian city of Kaunas after the death of a young Roman Catholic who drenched himself in gasoline and burned himself.

title: Parents W ho Refused Treatment For Girl, 8, Overruled by a Judge
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 25  An 8yearold girl suffering from a rare disease of the connective tissues was rushed to the intensive care unit of Long Island Jewish Hospital here this morning. Three floors away, a State Supreme Court justice was deciding whether to overrule her parents, members of an obscure religious sect, and order the medication and transfusions she needed to live.

title: BroadwayHale Stores Cites a Gain
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 25BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., the largest retailer on the West Coast, had 15.7 per cent higher net income in the first fiscal quarter ended April 29 to $4,133,000 from $3,573,000 In the like 1971 period, Edward W. Carter chairman, told the annual meeting here today. Earnings were equal to 29 cents a share up from 26 cents a share a year ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your news story of May 16 reports on the cut voted by the Appropriations Committee of the House in the U.S. contribution to the United Nations and its agencies and cites the percentage figures of our proposed participation in them. In the interest of accuracy, I would like to correct the impressiOn given that in making its voluntary contribution to the Children's Fund, the United States share of payments runs as high as 60 per cent to 70 per cent.

title: Unusual Hudson River Museum Cited
description: The Hudson River Museum of Yonkers, cited yesterday with an award by the New York State Council on the Arts, is considered one of the nation's most unusual cultural facilities.

title: Leonard B. Sadow Dead; Longines Counsel Was 58
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 25 Leonard B. Sadow, corporate counsel and executive vice president of the LonginesWittnauer Watch Company, Inc., died of a stroke today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Putnam Green.

title: Grand Jury Exonerates N.F.L., Rozelle Says
description: A Federal grand jury that spent the last 18 months investigating pro football on alleged charges of monopoly and the boycotting of players has exonerated the National Football League, according to Pete Rozelle, its commissioner.

title: CITY PATROLMAN CLEARED IN KILLING
description: A patrolman who inadvertently killed a detective in Queens last month while the detective, with gun drawn, was trying to capture a suspect, was absolved yesterday of possible criminal charges by a Queens grand jury on the ground of self defense.

title: SONG PROGRAM GIVEN BY PAMELA POLLAND
description: Every now and then performers arrive who somehow seem a little out of joint with time, their message appropriate for another day and place, but not in synchronization with this one.

title: SHELEST IS REMOVED AS UKRAINE'S LEADER
description: MOSCOW, May 25Pyotr Y. Shelest, a reputedly conservative member of the Soviet Union's ruling Politburo, was dismissed today from the Communist party leadership of the Ukraine, which he had headed since 1963.

title: Lawyer Slain, 2 Wounded In Court by Man in Lawsuit
description: OROVILLE, Calif., May 25 (AP)A spray of gunfire in courtroom today killed a lawyer and wounded a judge and witness.

title: Chamber Works by 6 Composers Fill Carnegie Recital Program
description: A chambermusic concert with works by Garry Sherman, Charles Haubiel, Tui St. George Tucker, Stephen Mayer, Bert Lande and Eugene Seaman was given at Carnegie Recital Hall late Wednesday afternoon.

title: It's People Dance at Outdoor Festival
description: The concentrated outdoor dance assault that began two weeks ago on the Avenue of the Americas between 50th and 54th Streets has infiltrated the five boroughs and will conclude with performances this weekend in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan. This second Spring Dance Festival, presented by the City Center of Music and Drama, includes the Elizabeth Keen Company; Theater Workshop, Boston; James Cunningham and the Acme Dance Company, and the Rudy Perez Dance Theater.

title: Bove Stops Its Operations Before S.E.C. Starts Suit
description: Kenneth Bove & Co., Inc., voluntarily, shut down operations yesterday before a Federal court action initiated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Africans and Black Americans Open Conference in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A conference of black Americans and Africans seeking to develop methods of influencing official, policies toward black Africa opened here today.

title: China Said to Bar Soviet Ships With Arms for North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Chinese Government has turned down a Soviet proposal to let 12 freighters carrying military equipment for North Vietnam enter Chinese ports to discharge their cargoes, according to diplomatic reports here.

title: A MOSCOW PARLEY ENDS IN UPROAR,
description: MOSCOW, May 25  The reading of an excerpt on the Soviet Union's Jewish problem from a 40yearold satirical novel stirred an uproar at a news conference here today, causing two American journalists to walk out.

title: Two American Offices Bombed In Paris, Others Are Threatened
description: PARIS, May 25 (Reuters)Bomb blasts shook two American guildings here early today and two United States airline offices were evacuated after bomb threats.

title: One Billion Chinese
description: The specter of a billion Chinese on the mainland, raised by former Secretary of State Dean Rusk five years ago in connection with the Vietnam war, has emerged againbut in a strikingly different context.

title: Barbara Schwartz Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Barbara Ellen Schwartz and Morton Lawrence Annis Jr. were married here yesterday afternoon in the St. RegisSheraton Hotel by Rabbi William Berkowitz of Congregation B'Nai Jershurun.

title: American Elections An African View
description: The Presidential election attracts the attention of the whole world because the White House and Washington are the source of many decisions which can change the course of history. It is an open secret that many political regimes have survived thanks to Washington's support or intervention. Many African countries and governments have realized the influence of the White House in the conduct of international affairs. The American President is not a dictator; his powers and his personality are subject to all sorts of pressures.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Bendix Corporation has named William M. Agee as executive vice president and chief financial officer. He formerly was senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Boise Cascade Corporation.

title: UNITED AND EASTERN TO BUY MORE PLANES
description: United Air Lines, Inc., a unit of UAL., Inc., announced yesterday that it has elected to exercise options to purchase seven more DC10 trijet aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation at a cost of $130million. The planes will be delivered in 1975 or 1976. The purchase will increase United's DC10 fleet to 32 planes.

title: Miss McGrath, Massimo Triulzi Are Wed Here
description: Miss Lucy John McGrath was married here yesterday afternoon to Massimo Triulzi in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew C. Varga, director of the John LaFarge Institute and the John Courtney Murray Forum.

title: British Aide in Ulster Names 11 Advisers
description: LONDON, May 25William Whitelaw, who has administered Northern Ireland since Britain imposed direct rule two months ago, announced today the appointment of an advisory commission of seven Protestants and four Roman Catholics.

title: Business Incorporations Up
description: New business incorporations jumped to a record 27,399 in March from 24,743 in February, continuing the advance from comparable yearearlier levels for the 12th straight month, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

title: Proxmire Disputes Pentagon Estimate Of Soviet Sea Force
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in I a Senate speech today that the Pentagon has artificially made it appear that the Soviet navy is a massive, modern force that directly threatens the United States while in fact, the United States leads the Soviet Union in almost every major naval category and current building programs will keep us on top.

title: Martin Hails Exchange Progress
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., the former Federal Reserve Board chairman whose 1971 Martin Report proposed a restructuring of securities markets, said yesterday that significant progress is being made.

title: White's Clout Backs Peterson's 7Hitter
description: A strong pitching performance by Fritz Peterson for his first shutout of the season plus one swing of the bat by Roy White for a tworun homer combined to bring the Yankees a 20 victory over the Cleveland Indians yesterday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.

title: N.B.A. AllStars Sink A.B.A., 106104
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 25Amid the usual abundance of spectacular individual plays and with plenty of running in both directions, the National Basketball Association's allstar team defeated the American Basketball Association's stars, 106104, tonight before a crowd of 14,086 and a national television audience.

title: 100 Evacuate Freighter In Florida Coast Fire
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 25 (UPI)A Liberian freighter with 100 persons aboard caught fire and was abandoned today about 45 miles off the Florida coast. All aboard were rescued by a passing ship.

title: Theater: Sweet Feet
description: Sweet Feet sours toot suite. If there were any Hollywood people watching this excruciating little musical satire of the film capital forties last night. they had every right to feel superior. Like a bleating, rusty caboose catching up pellmell with the nostalgia trend, the show chugged into the New Theater offBroadwayand off is right.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm the only man in Yugoslavia who can't lie about his age, said President Tito as he celebrated his 80th birthday. His country welcomed his entry into the ranks of the octogenarians with a mass youth rally in Partizan Stadium in Belgrade. Mr. Tito joined hundreds of children from all over the country in a snack of juice and sweets.

title: Small Quake in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 25 (UPI) small earthquake was felt in eastern Portland early today. No damage was reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The halfpage advertisement The People vs. The New York Times violates the truth. The single quotation from The Times editorial of May 10 is itself malicious by its failure to quote in full, its failure to show that there was an omission, and by omitting the key phrase ... runs counter both to Congressional mandate....

title: Emergency Repair Overcharges Laid to 5 Contractors
description: Examination of the books of six of the largest contractors for the city's Emergency Repair Program disclosed that five were overcharging for labor and materials and three of those five appear to have been paying bribes to city employes, Robert K. Ruskin, Commissioner of Investigation, reported yesterday.

title: Exchange Chief Renamed
description: TORONTO, May 25 (Canadian Press)John Kimber, president of the Toronto Stock Exchange since 1967, has been signed to another fiveyear term as chief executive and administrative officer of the exchange. Mr. Kimber, 54 years old, came to the exchange after serving as chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission.

title: Wallace Gets Incision To Remove Infections
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 25 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace had minor surgery today to remove infections that had accumulated near a place where a bullet was removed earlier.

title: Bridge: Eastern Regionals, Highlighted Goldman Pairs, Open Today
