description: Two bookstalls were installed and opened yesterday along the outer wall of Central Park just above 60th Street, not quite transforming Fifth Avenue at that point into the Quai des Grands Augustins, but improving it vastly in the opinion of invited bibliophiles and casual pedestrians who happened by at dedication time.

title: Budgetary Brouhaha
description: An incredible budget, proposed by a city administration heedless of either economic or political realities, winds up now in the middle of a brouhaha that may eventually require court action to determine final revenue and spending figures.

title: AMEX SHARES UP IN LIGHT TRADING
SOYBEAN FUTURES RETREAT IN PRICE
description: Soybeanfutures prices dropped several times to as much as 10 cents a bushel but closed lower by 2 cents yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: CARDS SCORE, 62, AS METS'
description: ST. LOUIS, May 26Tom Seaver failed to go the distance for the sixth straight time tonight as the lastplace St. Louis Cardinals defeated the firstplace New York Mets, 62.

title: Sam Goody Store in South
description: Sam Goody, Inc., the New Yorkbased record and audio dealer, yesterday told its shareholders at their annual meeting that it would open its first Southern store on Aug. 2. The new unit, to be followed by four more in the South in the next few years, will be in the new Crabtree Valley Mall, Raleigh, N. C.

title: Miss Henderson Bride of H. J. Coolidge
description: WEST MEDFORD, Mass., May 26Miss Martha Thayer Henderson and Harold Jefferson Coolidge of Washington were married here this afternoon. The bride is a consultant in environmental education. Her husband is president of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources in Morgues, Switzerland.

title: 5 of 11 New Stock Issues Advance in Quiet Week
description: Eleven new issues came out on the market this week, and at the close of public trading, yesterday five of the newcomers had registered gains in comparatively quiet trading.

title: S.E.C. WILL LIFT BAN ON APPLIED DEVICES
description: The Secuities and Exchange Commission said yesterday it would lift the trading ban in stock of the Applied Devices Corporation at the close of business on June 1. Trading has been halted since Feb. to obtain additional financial information about the company and its plans for recapitalization.

title: Davis Prosecution Granted Delay Until Next Tuesday
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 26The final sessions in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy trial of Angela Davis have been delayed until next week.

title: Alcoa Magnesium License
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday it had acquired a license from PechineyUgineKuhlmann for the French company's magnatherm process for making magnesium.Alcoa announced in 1970 it would build a $25million magnesium plant near Addy, Wash. Magnesium is an alloy ingredient in aluminum products.

title: MURPHY APPOINTS DETECTIVE CHIEF Cottell, 30 Years on Force, Is Seedman's Successor
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday appointed Deputy Chief Inspector Louis C. Cottell, a policeman for 30 years, as chief of detectives.

title: OneFamily Housing Plan In Poland Is Facing Snags
description: WARSAW May 26Poland's reformminded leaders have created a stir here by endorsing one of the more blatantly bourgeois symbols of Western lifethe private houseas a means of easing a chronic housing shortage.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The president of the Pasco Fence Corporation, one the largest suppliers of fencing materials on Long Island, agreed in court yesterday to put himself and his companies out of the fence business for the rest of his life. In unusual judgment, brought by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and signed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Sol Wachtler, Daniel Roberts agreed never again to engage in the selling or repairing of fences, and removed all liens against homes that Mr. Lefkowitz charged had been fraudulently obtained.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 25Boys and girls in their last year at Hanoi High School began taking their final examinations the other dayin villages miles from here.

title: MISS BRYN SINGS; SGODAVA ON PIANO
description: Oksana Bryn, soprano, and Richard Sgodava, pianist, gave a joint recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night. Miss Bryn, a native of the Ukraine, now lives and teaches in Minneapolis. Mr. Sgodava is a former pianist with the Minnesota Orchestra.

title: ROBERT BEERS DEAD; FOLK SINGER WAS 51
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 26 (AP)Robert Beers, patriarch of the folksinging Beers Family and host of popular Fox Hollow music festival, was killed early today in a threecar collision along the Taconic Trail highway. He was 51 years old.

title: FiveYear Effort for an Arms Curb Began With Secret Johnson Letter to Kosygin
description: WASHINGTON, May 26On Jan. 21, 1967, President Lyndon B. Johnson sent a secret letter to Soviet Premier Alekse N. Kosygin warning him that the recent deployment of an antiballistic missiles defense system around Moscow had put him under pressure to increase greatly our capabilities to penetrate any defensive systems which you might establish.

title: 3 Yankee Errors Help Tigers Win, 82
description: The Detroit Tigers began long Memorial Day weekend visit to New York last night and nowhere could they have found more accommodating hosts than the Yankees.

title: Nationalist China's New Premier Chiang Chingkuo
description: TAIPEI Taiwan May 26When Chiang Chingkuo the elder son of President Chiang Kaishek was named Deputy Premier and chairman of the Government's most important economic committees in 1969 many businessmen and officials in the economic agencies were apprehensive.

title: MRS. GANDHI TO MEET WITH BHUTTO JUNE 23
description: NEW DELHI, May 216A meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan will be held in New Delhi on June 28 official sources confirmed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am writing to protest the May 22 letter '68 G.O.P. Platform Revisited. I admit that everything stated in the letter is true. The omission of one very important fact, however, labels the letter as little more than a misleading piece of propaganda.

title: Antiwar Protests Spawned at a House in Cambridge
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26The pulse of 67 Winthrop Street, at times slow and steady, at times frenzied and spasmodic, emanates from Washington.

title: Harkness Ballet Blends Skill and Unity in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Was it really spring 1972 and not fall 1967? Was it the prestigious Kennedy Center in Washington and not the glittering Broadway Theater in New York? Yes, it was most emphatically  and though it was not the same Harkness Ballet that made its American debut five years ago, there are similarities between that company and the present one. The new company has also toured abroad before appearing in a prestigious American house and in this reincarnation it is still a company of welltrained dancers looking for dances worthy of them.

title: N.B.A. AllStars Ready to Resist Fines
description: In a flurry of ringing pronouncements likely to dissipate into thin air by next fall, the professional basketball season finally ended Thursday night with the National Basketball Association's AllStars beating their American Basketball Association counterparts, 106104. The game at the Nassau Coliseum drew a crowd of 14,086 in a house scaled to $10 for the highestprice tickets.

title: MRS. BERNARD SACHERE
description: Mrs. Anna G. Sachere, librarian of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, died yesterday at her. home, 90 La Salle Street. She was 82 years old and had retired recently.

title: College Aid Tied to Busing Is Assailed
description: ALBANY, May 26Dr. Kenneth B. Clark called today on college officials and students to reject any Federal funds under the higher education bill now before Congress because the benefits would be tainted by the bill's socalled antibusing amendment.

title: Suit Accuses Labor Department of Using Funds to Aid a Lobby
description: WASHINGTON, May 2G A suit filed in Federal District Court today seeks to enjoin the alleged illegal use of Federal funds to support specialinterest lobbying activities.

title: Town Hails Astronaut
description: LANCASTER, S. C., May 26 (UPI)Residents of this textile town turned out today to hail Lieut. Col. Charles M. Duke Jr., Lancaster's native son and member of the Apollo 16 space crew. Colonel Duke and his family rode in a parade that had some 70 entries, including beauty queens, bands from all branches of the military and floats.

title: Montagnards Kept in Kontum Now Permitted to Go
description: SAIGON South Vietnam May 26 Thousands of montagnard tribesmen, who had reportedly been kept in the beseiged city of Kontum by South Vietnamese official who wanted them to fight for the city, are now gradually being permitted to flee the danger zone.

title: $11MiIlion Listed By Cancer Society In Research Grants
description: MEMPHIS, May 26 (AP)The board of the American Cancer Society approved today 251 grants totaling nearly $11,million to support laboratory research and clinical investigations into cancer.

title: RACHEL HARTMAN, 51, A MAGAZINE WRITER
description: Rachel Hartman, an author who had been associated with The Christian Herald Magazine for 16 years, died yesterday in New York University Hospital after a long illness. She was 51 years old.

title: Morton Announces Measures To Make Noncoal Mines Safer
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)  Acting in the shadow, of a tragic mine fire at Kellogg, Idaho, Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton announced today new steps to improve safety in noncoal mines.

title: Bobby Unser Is Favored in Indy 500 Today
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26Bobby Unser stood out today as the heavy favorite to win the 56th running of the In dianapolis 500 tomorrow. Un ser, who won in 1968, will be driving the white Olsonite EagleOffenhauser built and prepared by Dan Gurney's All American Racers.

title: No Bargain
description: The Adirondack communities of Clare and Colton are reported bitterly torn by the plans of the Horizon Corporation, a giant Arizona land developer that has bought up 24,345 wooded acres in the immediate area. The threat to the local environment appalls many St. Lawrence County residents, including the director of its Planning Board. But to others the project offers the shimmering hope of jobs and a flow of cash to a region that is none too flourishing.

title: KLAUS FRITZEN
description: Klaus Fritzen, a shipping executive who had lived here, on the Gulf Coast and in the West, died on Thursday at home in Aurich, Germany, near Emden. He was 42 years old.

title: Wometco Acquiring Firm
description: Wometco Enterprises, Inc., said yesterday its CATV subsidiary, Wometco Communications, Inc., had agreed in principle to acquire Ausable Communications, Inc., which operates community antenna television systems in upstate New York. Ausable's owners will receive an undisclosed amount of Wometco class A common stock.

title: Electric Power Research
description: The Electric Research Council said yesterday that an industrywide program for research and development of underground electric transmission would require an estimated $618million outlay from all segments, including equipment makers. The study was carried out by Arthur D. Little, Inc.

title: GOLF LEAD TAKEN BY MISS PALMER
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., May 26 (UPI)Sandra Palmer matched par of 71 today for a onestroke openinground lead in the Women's Titleholders golf tournament.

title: M.T.A. TAKES OVER 2 COMMUTER LINES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday completed the takeover of the Harlem and Hudson division commuter lines of the Penn Central. But almost immediately, State Controller Arthur Levitt denounced the agreement as contrary to the longrun public interest?

title: SHOP TALK
description: With the urge to camp reaching epidemic proportions, Abercrombie & Fitch has turned up the grandest tent of them all. It's called the Europa Chateau and is a sort of Versailles of the community with two double bedrooms (40 square feet), kitchen (45 square feet), lounge (110 square feet) and two picture windows flanking the front door.

title: Wallace Is Allowed To Sit Up in Chair; Marked Gain Seen
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 26 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace, showing a marked overall improvement, got permission from his doctors today to sit in a chair. It was the first time he had been allowed to sit up in a chair since the May 15 shooting that left his legs paralyzed.

title: Better Pension Forecast For Mrs. Frankfurter
description: More aid will be made available to Mrs. Felix Frankfurter, 82 years old, who is impoverished on a $5,000ayear pension granted to widows of Supreme Court Justices, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Film: From Yale Fete
description: The latest batch of avantgarde shorts at the uptown Film Forum, drawn from the recent Yale University Film Festival, is a rewarding one. The longest, Peter Hutton's July 1971 in San Francisco, was previously appraised here and drew the following comment from Roger Greenspun: A diary film, a currently popular type, and the title tells you what it is all about. The end result seems like a home movie made by Matthew Brady.

title: Nixon's Itinerary: Today, Leningrad
description: Following is President Nixon's itinerary for the rest of his visit to the Soviet Union:

title: Art: Bedford Collects
description: There are several magnificent Greek Revival buildings in Bedford, N. Y., a lush, opulent little town with a long history, 40 miles from the city. Boldly handsome in proportion and majestic in appearance, the structures represent an important part of our cultural legacy. But, like many of this country's buildings of the past, two of them have been slated for demolition to make way for what might turn out to be another insignificant shopping center.

title: 1,000Year Sentence Given
description: HOUSTON, May 26 (UPI)Solomon James Henry was suntwice( to 1,000 yeors in ?? today for the rape of in 18 yearold university

title: First National City And Irving Trust Cut Prime Rates
description: The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company, as expected, reduced their prime lending rates yesterday to 5 per cent, effective next week. Previously, their rates had been 5 per cent and 5 per cent, respectively.

title: THOUSANDS FLEE CITY FOR HOLIDAY
description: The threeday Memorial Day weekend got under way in earnest yesterday as travelers ?? the hundreds of thousands entered and left the city by air, road and rail. A bright sun and clear skies were in evidence during the day, and weather prospects for the weekend were described by the National Weather Service as favorable.

title: California Strike Ends
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 26 (UPI)State water project workers returned to manning the aqueducts and pumping stations of California's distribution system today following settlement of the first strike by state employes. The workers walked off the job Monday. Last night they agreed to 12.5 per cent wage increasa.

title: American Express Agrees To Buy Into British Concern
description: American Express International, Inc., a subsidiary of the American Express Company, announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the $17million purchase of a substantial minority interest in Clarksons Holiday (Holdings), Ltd., major package tour operator ii Britain.

title: McGovern Appears Ahead On Eve of Coast Debates
description: SAN FRANCISO, May 27As they come into the final 10 days of the campaign, Senator George McGovern of South Dakota appears to be leading Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in the Democratic Presidential primary in California.

title: Austin of Rahway Betters New Jersey Hurdles Mark
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 27Nate Austin of Rahway set a New Jersey schoolboy record of 18.6 seconds in the 180yard low hurdles as the state track and field championships opened today with sectional meets at four sites. Austin ran at Williams Field, Elizabeth. He won the high hurdles in 0:14.0.

title: Miss Pritchett Plans Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. R. A. Rees Pritchett of New York and Silver Bay, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Edith Pritchett, to William Aubrey Schmidt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Aubrey Schmidt of Alexandria, Va.

title: Mrs. Zimmerman Wed to Engineer
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., May 27 Mrs. Anne Parke Zimmerman, daughter of John 0. Zimmerman, president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, and Mrs. Zimmerman of Amityville, was married here this morning to John Dennis Rodrigues. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Rodrigues of Georgetown, Guyama.

title: Miss Morris Becomes Bride
description: LAC DU FLAMBEAU, Wis., May 27Miss Patricia Ann Morris, daughter of Thomas Asbury Morris of Kansas City, Mo., was married here this afternoon to Gordon Eames MorrisBrown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Eames Brown of New York and Branford, Conn.

title: Boreham Baranova, Fox Terrier, Named Best at Monmouth County Show
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., May 27 A long shot scored a stunning victory at Wolf Hill Farm, an annex to the Monmouth Park race track tonight, when Harry Lumb chose a smooth fox terrier, Ch. Boreham Barenova, as best at the 2,176dog Monmouth County Kennel Club show.

title: Mich. State Takes Big 10 Track Title By Point Over Illini
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 27 (AP)Michigan State, piling up 38 points in the 100 and 220 dashes, scored a 1point triumph over Illinois in the Big Ten outdoor track and field championships today.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: RIKERS PRISONER IS FOUND HANGED
description: Details of Perez's record could not be learned last night. Sexual abuse is defined under the law as forced sexual contact not resulting in rape, or with a chtild under 11 years of age, or with a mental incompetent. It is punishable by up to seven years in prison.

title: Cathy Rigby Added To Gymnastic Team Despite Foot Injury
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 27 (AP)Cathy Rigby, America's brightest hope for a women's Olympic gold medal in gymnastics, was added to the United States team tonight despite her failure to qualify because of a foot injury.

title: Cosmos Pull Away in Last Half for 42 Soccer League Triumph Over Chiefs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 27Despite firsthalf problems in their defense, the New York Cosmos defeated the Atlanta Chiefs, 4.2, at Hofstra Field tonight before 4,445 fans.

title: Sister Attends Lucile. McKee At Her Bridal
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 27 Miss Lucile Best McKee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McKee, was married here this afternoon to William Clarkson 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson 3d of Corsicana, Tex.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible STOLport Sites Now Up to 3
description: SECAUCUS  A federally financed study on the feasibility of building a metropolitanarea airport in Hudson County for short takeoff and landing airplanes (STOL) is to be completed within two weeks.

title: Soviet Said to Seize Dancer Who Sought to Go to Israel
description: MOSCOW, May 27 (Reuters) A top Soviet ballet dancer who wants to emigrate to Israel was arrested in Leningrad on the eve of President Nixon's visit there today, his friends said.

title: SakiWith a Hatpin and a Rapier
description: ON another occasion, in these columns, I stated that so many efforts of Caedmon Records (the recording company of the spoken word) seem superfluous, since most prose is better read than spokenor, more precisely, more satisfying to read than to listen to. But two of Caedmon's recent releases are striking exceptions to that obiter dictum. Tobermory and Other Stories (Caedmon, TC 1380) and Reginald on HouseParties and Other Stories by Saki (Caedmon, TC 1386) are exquisite distillations of Essence of Drawing Room Comedy that are perfectly understated, and, therefore, seductive, in the superb readings (on both records) Keith Baxter.

title: Connecticut Waterfall Imperiled
description: TERRYVILLE, Conn., May 27 Conservationists opened a campaign during a driving storm a Jew days ago to raise $15,000 to guarantee the preservation of spectacular Buttermilk Falls.

title: F.D.A. Says Some Sterilizers Can Cause Electrical Shock
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers that 20,000 small sterilizers used in homes and doctors offices can cause an electrical shock that might prove fatal in extreme cases.

title: After 50 Years, the Uniform Suits Jim Turner Fine
description: Just as it was in 1923, Paris, Tenn., is still about 100 miles from Antioch, Tenn. But to Jim Turner, the distance between the towns was much greater then.

title: Nassau Democratic Chief Comes Out for McGovern
description: Nassau County's Democratic Chairman, Marvin Christenfeld, said yesterday that he was asking each of the state's Democratic county chairmen to support the candidacy of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota in the state's June Presidential primary.

title: Schoolboy Sets Mark
description: PORTERVILLE, Calif., May 27 (AP)Gerald Hardeman, a junior at Edison High School in Fresno, smashed the national prep school longjump record yesterday with a leap of 25 feet 9 inches. The previous mark was 257.

title: MINER DISSIDENTS OPEN CONVENTION
description: WHEELING, W. Va., May 27 An insurgent reform movement within the United Mine Workers of America that once seemed as dead as its slain leader, Joseph A. Yablonski,, opened a convention here today to choose a candidate to challenge the union president, W, A. Boyle.

title: 10,000 Protest on South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  A crowd estimated by the police at 8,000 to 10,000 marched five miles through the streets here today to protest the treatment of blacks in South Africa and United States relations with that country.

title: Television; The Voice of Westchester? Well, It's One of Them
description: WESTCHESTER County is directly north of New York City. One notable statistic about the county is that, according to Fortune mqvzine, it houses 40 per cent of the presidents or board chairmen of the biggest companies in the United States. The focus here, however, will be on a radio station that is located in the basement, which its president casually calls an upholstered sewer, of the Pershing Building in New RochelleWV0XAMFM.

title: Smokies Hikers Need Pass on Historic Trail
description: ATLANTA, May 27 (UPI)The National Park Service announced today that permits would be required for overnight hikers along the Appalachian Trail in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, effective June 1.

title: 2 Promoters Suspended
description: CLEVELAND, May 27 (UPI) David Ott, chairman of the Cleveland Boxing Commission, temporarily suspended Don Elbaum and Dean Chance, pro rooters, last night pending hearings on alleged Irregularities in bouts. Chance is the former major league pitcher.

title: From Malcolm X To Dan B.
description: RADICAL politics make lousy movies, at least most of the time. Robert Kramer's Ice is an exception, as are JeanLuc Godard's Wind from The East, See You at Mao and Vladimir and Rosa, which are so political and so radical that their practical effect is less often to inflame audiences than to put them immediately to sleep.

title: Art
description: PERHAPS it's a question of the way you look at it. A few paintings in the current exhibition of recent works by David Hockney now on viewto May 31at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, might well pass for very respectable, contemporary hardedge abstractions. Passages in other pictures seem like exercises in the equally current style of painterly abstraction. Yet all of the pictures are hosed on Pop esthetics. Hockney, now 34, was one of the learlifig lights in the British Pop Art movement of the 1960's. Like all Pop artists who have survived into maturity, he has done so by developing a styleand a subjectmatter  that is uniquely his own.

title: David Wall Proves A Personal Dancer In Sleeping Beauty
description: Another major cast change in the Royal Ballet Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House made David Wall the Prince in The Sleeping Beauty for the first time this season.

title: The Moscow Summit
description: Both the American and the Soviet people have good reason to be happy about the developments at the Moscow summit. The gains made go beyond the specific agreements that were concluded, notably the hittoric NixonBrezhnev accords on limiting defensive and offensive missiles. More important for the long run may well be the personal contacts between the leaders of the two nations and the positive images of the two nations transmitted by both Soviet and American media to their audiences. President Nixon underscored this aspect when he told the Soviet leaders at Friday's banquet: We look forward to the tine when we shall be able to welcome you in our country and in some way respond in an effective manner to the way in which you have received us so generously in your country.

title: Johns Hopkins Wins, 96; Reaches Final in Lacrosse
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 27Johns Hopkins, long a power in intercollegiate lacrosse, established itself as the favorite to win the second annual National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse title by beating Maryland, 96, in a semifinal game before 8,100 persons in Byrd Stadium today.

title: Christine T. Paddock Is Bride Of Herbert Hastings Foster 3d
description: LENOX, Mass., May 27Miss Christine Tileston Paddock, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Franklin Kittredge Paddock of Lenox, was married here this afternoon to Herbert Hastings Foster 3d, son of Mr. Foster Jr. of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mrs. Joanne Fargo Foster. The Rev. Robert S. S. Whitman performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. W. Holt Souder.

title: LOREN D. DODSON
description: NAPLES, Fla., May 27Loren R. Dodson, who was secretary and treasurer of the Continental Can Company when he retired in 1959, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 72 years old.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SAN DIEGOWhen a news confer. ence questioner asked George McGovern here last week how he aimed to get off the defensive in the California primary campaign, Mr. McGovern replied, a little testily, that he had not spent a total of five minutes defending himself.

title: VIRGINIA VICTOR INLACROSSE, 147
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., May 27 (AP)A strong Virginia team got off to a slow start today but ended with a 147 victory to eliminate Cortland State from the National Collegiate Lacrosse tournament in the semifinal round.

title: Cancer Research Center To Be Built in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 27A $4.5million cancer research and treatment center will be constructed at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Cross Goes to Burundi
description: GENEVA, May 27 (AP)The Tnternational Committee of the Red Cross has sent two delegates and a physician to the troubled areas of Burundi because of the serious disturbances there, Red Cross sources said today. There have been reports of killings of men, women and children of the Hutu tribe by the ruling Watusi in the nation in east central Africa.

title: Four Bobbies Get a Taste of U.S. Law and Order
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C.Four British constables are winding up a threeweek visit to this Piedmont tobacco center with clearer views of the United States and its problems of law and order.

title: Angels Beat Royals, 42
description: ANAHEIM, May 27 (AP)Jim Spencer and Ken McMullen singled home a run each in a tworun eighth inning, leading the California Angels past the

title: Peters Gets Hockey Honor
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. May 27 (AP)Garry Peters of the Boston Braves was named today the most valuable player in the American Hockey League. Terry Caffery of the Cleveland Barons was chosen rookie of the year.

title: Norah Garrity Is Wed
description: RYE, N.Y., May 27Miss Norah March Garrity, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Devin Adair Garrity, was married here this afternoon in her parents home to Alan Elihu Sapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Sapiro of North Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Bishop officiated. The bride's father is president of the Devin Adair Book Publishing Company, Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Leaves of May
description: May is a time of swift, almost astonishing change, with flowers everywhere you look. Grass grows like the proverbial weed, and orchards which a month ago were stark gray trunks and limbs now have the look of vast bouquets. Apple blossoms and lilacs are everywhere, and the seasonal overlap matches foamwhite bloodroot with redandgold columbine, dainty windflower with bold lady's slipper. Wild strawberries and wild raspberries are in bloom, the pasture roses in fat bud.

title: Misses Stacy and Baugh on Curtis Squad
description: For the second time in two years, the United States Golf AssOciation has nominated an extremely young team to defend the Curtis Cup in the 17th playing of these matches in Western Gailes, Ayrshire, Scotland on June 9 and 10.

title: Pickup Crew Rows to Victory In Regatta at Orchard Beach
description: Crews from the United States Merchant Marine Academy and the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia shared rowing honors yesterday with a pickup crew representing four different clubs in a regatta at the Orchard Beach Lagoon's Olympic course in the Bronx.

title: Travel Notes: U.S. Influx
description: NO New Yorker should be too surprised if one of these mornings when he is dashing madly across Times Square, late for work, a short, dark stranger asks him to pause for just 1/100th of a second (at f16) so that he can take back to his homeland a picture of a typical American hauling his ulcers to work.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Wallace Keeps ThirdParty Option Open
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 27  In one of the thousands of letters mailed to Gov. George C. Wallace since he was shot May 15, a housewife in Toledo, Ohio, wrote this week of her hopes for the continuation of his Presidential campaign.

title: Reduced Labor Influence On Democrats Expected
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Organized labor is expected to have substantially more delegate strength at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach this year than it did four years ago in Chicago. But while labor is expected to play a prominent role in shaping the Democratic platform, it will probably have less influence in nominating the Presidential candidate than it did in 1968.

title: The Living Flock to a Town of the Dead
description: EAST HANOVER TOWNSHIP  In this riverbounded suburban community on the eastern edge of Morris County, the dead outnumber the living about 9 to 1.

title: Elizabeth Saylor Prospective Bride
description: RYE, N. Y., May 27Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Stuart Saylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fyte Saylor, to Thomas Nelson Erb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Erb of Venice, Fla.

title: About Motor Sports
description: When Sam Posey, Denny Long, Peter Gregg, Hurley Haywood and a host of other drivers thunder away from Lime Rock's start line tomorrow in their Corvettes and Porsches, they will be introducing fans to a racing club that is relatively new in this area, the International Motor Sports Association. The occasion will be the Camel 200, an endurance event for GT cars and the feature event of a threerace program.

title: The Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: New Mexico Regents Rule The Faculty Erred on Nixon
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 27The Board of Regents of the University of New Mexico, at its monthly meeting this week, ruled that the university's faculty had acted outside its jurisdiction in calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Fear of Busing Exceeds Its Use
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The fear and angry opposition that has swept the nation in recent months regarding busing for school desegregation stems more from busing orders that are an ticipated than from those that have taken effect.

title: Silent Majority and Hilarious Way Capture Divisions of Commodore Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 27Unbeaten Silent Majority, registering the first 2minutemile of the season here, and Hilarious Way won divisions of the 10th annual Commodore Pace for 3yearolds tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Hilarious, Way beat the glamorous Strike Out by a nose in 2:02 4/5 and paid $5.20, after which Silent Majority registered his fifth straight victory.

title: Shooting of Milwaukee Woman By Police Evokes Black Protests
description: MILWAUKEE, May 27The fatal shooting of a 19yearold black woman by a white detective has aroused anger in Milwaukee's black community and demands that white policemen be replaced by black in the area.

title: Illinois Community to Revitalize StripMined. Soil With Treated Chicago Sewage
description: ST. DAVID, Ill., May 27The residents of this little farming community 200 miles southwest of Chicago do not fully realize it, but they are about to become the focus of a vast sewage disposal project that is expected to relieve Chicago's hardpressed sanitary system, revitalize much of the area's stripmined land and, perhaps, lead the way for many of the nation's other cities whose sewage problems steadily mount.

title: The Nation
description: DETROITThe hand of the world's most famous industrialist was trembling, making his cigarette shake as he put it to his lips. Henry Ford 2d, the gruff, blunt chairman of the Ford Motor Company, was being interrogated about a disclosure by William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (E.P.A.), that Ford had improperly conducted emissions tests of its 1973 automobiles.

title: Marjorie Johnson Is Married To Eric Wallach at Wellesley
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 27In the Houghton Chapel at Wellesley College today, Miss Marjorie Anne Johnson, who expects to graduate from Wellesley next Saturday, was married to Eric Jean Wallach, who expects to receive his degree June 15 from the Harvard Law School.

title: WILLIAM HADLEY, ENGINEER, IS DEAD
description: William A. Hadley, a former associate professor of mechanical engineering at Columbia University who worked on improvements in mechanical typesetting, died of a stroke Friday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Tappan, N.Y.

title: N.Y.U. Track DinnerTuesday
description: New York University track stars who have performed for Coach Joe Healey will be honored Tuesday night at the Spiked Shoe Club's senior track and field awards dinner. Healey has been the N.Y.0 track coach since 1957.

title: Bethpage Park Opens Its Polo Season Today
description: The polo season will open today at Bethpage (L. I.) State Park with a game at 3:30 P.M. between Jericho and Brookville. Games will be played there every Sunday afternoon through midOctober.

title: 4 FROM U.S. TO MEET WITH RUSSIAN GROUP
description: Four leading members of the Citizens Exchange Corps will fly to Moscow next Friday to join a group of Soviet citizens in organizing a congress on international education and exchange of people.

title: Greater Numbers Of Able Students Seen in Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Two college professors report that strong growth in higher education in this country has enabled increasing numbers of students with high ability to attend colleges.

title: HENRY A. PFISTERER, YALE PROFESSOR, 63
description: NEW HAVEN, May 27Henry A. Pfisterer, professor of architecture at Yale University, died yesterday at his home in Hamden. His age was 63.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Queer rumors, a soulless story and a failed optimist; Delpha Green & Company; By Vera and Bill Cleaver. 141 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company. Paper, $1.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: We hear a good deal from actors about the woes of typecasting. Writers, too, often suffer from the problem. It's hard to say how Cleaver fans are going to take this new book, seeing that the Cleavers, long known for lighting single candles in oceanic darks, are now presenting a comedy. It's about the oldest child of an exconturnedpreacher and it must have given them great fun in the making.

title: Sailing Trials Are Set on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif. May 27 (AP)Sailboat skippers will compete in three classes here in trials for the Summer Olympic Games in Germany.

title: Is education too important to be left to educators?; Teachers And Power; The Story of the American Federation of Teachers. By Robert J. Braun. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $7.95.
description: The American Federation of Teachers  led by its strongest affiliate, Local 2, United Federation of Teachers (who have made U.F.T. a household term to most New Yorkers)  is determined to control the public schools of America by waging an allout war against any of its enemies, whether they be parents, students, school boards, politicians or minority communities, all in the name of education. Modeling itself after the American Medical Association and the American Bar Association, the teachers union is after a strong, disciplined national organization that will negotiate contracts escalating teachers demands without genuine responsibility to any one, certainly not the public. This is the warning of Robert J. Braun, education editor of the Newark StarLedger, in his fascinating account of Teachers and Power. Since he first covered a teacher strike in Perth Amboy, N. J., in 1965, Braun has become an intimately involved observer of teacher strikes, including the two prolonged affairs in New York City (1968, the Ocean HillBrownsville crisis) and Newark (1970), which he skillfully recounts and analyzes.

title: Medicine
description: CATO, N. Y.The health care crisis began abruptly in this rolling farm country of Northern Cayuga County, just south of Lake Ontario, in late 1967 when Cato's aging and only physician left for an easier life working in a big city hospital. It ended just as abruptly six weeks ago when two doctors arrived to set up shop in a medical center created out of three classrooms in the CatoMeridian Central School two miles east of here.

title: Laird Orders Army to Halt ABM Project in Montana
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird ordered the Army today to halt construction of the (Safeguard antimissile base in Montana and to drop plans for future work at projected sites not already under construction.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 40 in High Schools Getting College, Too
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I.Forty high school students have learned that their best shortcut to college is coenrollment at the New York Institute of Technology here.

title: Four Teachers Win Princeton Awards
description: PRINCETON  Dr. Robert F. Goheen, the president of Princeton University, has announced that four high school teachers have been cited as the 1972 recipients of the Princeton prizes for distinguished secondary school teaching in New Jersey.

title: YOUTH PROGRAMS HELPED BY POLICE
description: I see an empty city building, I like it, I say let's grab it, said Robert C. de Lellis. The executive director of the New York City Police Athletic League (P.A.L.) was explaining how the organization tries to reduce overhead and channel most of its money directly into youth programs.

title: Cholera Clinic in Dacca Periled by Cutoff in Funds
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 27  The Cholera Research Laboratory in Dacca, which leads the world in the study of the disease and has saved thousands of lives here, has been an unintended financial casualty of the war between India and Pakistan last December.

title: The fees are high and so is the price
description: If America has an equivalent to the playing fields of Eton, where the Battle of Waterloo was said to have been won, it is the world of the Washington lawyer. As its members move back and forth between Government and private practice, they learn rules of conduct and develop oldschool ties which virtually assure their advancement and success. Whatever party is in power, men like Clark Clifford, Dean Acheson, and Abe Fortas exert the kind of influence which once was reserved for the Rockefellers and Morgans of Wall Street.

title: Suzanne Calhoun Wed to C. J. Radano
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 27 Miss Suzanne Calhoun and Charles John Radano were married here this afternoon. The Rev. John Wiest performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Paul Beam of the Scarsdale Community Baptist Church assisted.

title: Rangers Trounce Twins, 162, With Nine Runs in 2d inning and Six in 3d
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 27 (AP)The Texas Rangers, led by threerun homers by Dick Billings and Don Mincher, scored nine runs in the second inning and six in the third and crushed the Minnesota Twins, 162, today.

title: The Duke of Windsor Dies at 77
description: LONDON, Sunday, May 28the Duke of Windsor, who gave up the British throne in 1936 10 rry an American divorcee, died in his home near Paris carly today, a Buckingham Palace spokesman announced here. The Duke was 77 years old.

title: Fire in Jersey Takes Life Of Girl, 4, and a Man, 29
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., May 27A 4yearold girl and a 29yearold man died in a fire that destroyed a twostory frame house here early today.

title: Chief Astronaut Foresees Further Cuts in the Corps
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Donald K. Slayton, the chief astronaut. said today that his corps of space pilots had three times as many people as are needed and forecast further cuts in their number.

title: Dream Bar Victor by Neck
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 27 (AP)Dream Bar held off a challenge by Darien Fats today in winning the $7,500 Block Island Handicap by a neck at Narragansett Park.

title: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT ?? FORBES MAGAZINEADVT.
WILDERNESS AREA DEBATED IN UTAH
description: KANAB, Utah, May 27Field hearings in this southern Utah ranching community by a Congressional subcommittee this weekend arc bringing into focus conflicting views of local land users and the nation's wilderness seekers.

title: ARMS CURB TO END BOOM TOWN'S BOOM
description: HELENA, Mont., May 27 (AP) The agreement signed in Moscow to cool the arms race sent economic shivers through the little boom town of Conrad, Mont.

title: Study Urges More Aid for Orchestras
description: A study of the financial profile of America's 28 major orchestras for the last decade concludes that Federal, state and local government support must increase from $13million to $17million in the next fiscal year and from $22million to $28million by 1976.

title: Child to Mrs. Baker 3d
description: A daughter was born May 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Baker 3d in Tokyo, where Mr. Baker is with IBM World Trade. Mrs. Baker is the former Miss Mary York Reidy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Reidy of Riverdale, the Bronx. The child has been named Marian York.

title: Paddling Your Own Canoe Is a Day's Trip on a River
description: CLINTONIf you want to go paddle your own canoe or tell someone else to do so, there is a put in point about 60 miles from New York just off Route 78 near hers.

title: House Racing Inquiry Seen Paving Way for Federal Control of All Sports
description: After its third lurid week of hearings, the House Select Committee on Crime appears to be leaning toward some kind of Federal regulation for horse racing.

title: 15 Marks Fall, But Ryun Pulls Out of Federation Track Meet
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 27 (AP) Five meet records were broken tonight in the windup of the 10th United States Track and Field Federation meet, but a crowd of 9,600 in Wichita State University's Cessna Stadium was disappointed when Jim Ryun pulled out of the featured halfmile run.

title: Books: One That Figures
description: THE BOOK OF BASEBALL RECORDS, by Seymour Siwoff (320 pp., $4.95). For those who work in baseball, and for hundreds of thousands of fans who take the game seriously record books are essential to a greater degree than in other sports. A new standard one has been produced this year by Siwoff, for many years official statistician for the National League through the Elias Sports Bureau, which he heads.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation; McGovern:; Can George Be Stopped? It Won't Be Easy
description: LOS ANGELESThere is a long tradition of stopsomebody movements in American politicsmost recently the tacit alliance between Nelson Rockefeller and Ronald Reagan, who wanted to stop Richard Nixon in 1968but they fail more often than not.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  In the era of orthodoxy and stability that has descended over the Soviet Union since the fall of Nikita Khrushchev in 19G4, there rarely any untoward event to ruffle the serene surface of Soviet politics. The most important maneuverings at the top remain obscure. Problems in the hinterland are usually hushed up.

title: Homosexual Gets Clearance
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) A Federal judge has ordered the Defense Department to restore the security status it had revoked from an avowed homosexual. United States District Judge John H. Pratt ordered clearance restored to Benning Wentworth, an employe of an electronics company.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Administration's penchant for hyperbole left it without adequate words last week for the historic agreement to curb the nuclear arms race that was reached at the Moscow summit. The SovietAmerican understanding  a treaty limiting deployment of antiballistic, or defensive, missiles (ABM's) and an executive agreement freezing offensive missiles at current levelsare probably the most important accords of the postwar period.

title: GERMAN AMATEURS ALLEGED TO BE PAID
description: A shadowy figure known as Santa Claus has systematically been paying off East German amateur athletes after significant track and field victories, Time magazine charges in its forthcoming issue.

title: Feminine Mayor Maintains a Home Life
description: WALLINGTON  If Doris Mahalick had not had her two children at a comparatively young age, or if she and her husband had not lived in a town with many of its streets unpaved, she never would have run for office. But what really decided her was a sudden change in her husband's working hours to a 4 P.M.tomidnight shift.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: I F THE nation's economic engine had been running on all cylinders, instead of functioning with two major ones in an idling state, the impressive business recovery that has already occurred this year would be even more significant.

title: Grant Finishes Second
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27Mark Donohue won the Indianapolis 500 this afternoon in a theatrical finish, taking the lead just 13 laps from the end after his teammate and another driver ran into trouble.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to the Upper Peninsula, you can, if you work at it, find the quiet, haunting spots that John Voelker loves. But if you do not revere the wilderness, better that you stay away, he says.

title: Solomon Beats Connors and Reaches Round of 16 in $100,000 French Tennis
description: PARIS, May 27 (UPI)Harold Solomon, controlling his topspin drives In the wind, beat Jimmy Connors, a fellow American, in straight sets at the $100,000 French open tennis championships today. Solomon took the fivehour match, which was interrupted three times by rain, 64, 75, 61 and entered the round of 16. He is unseeded while Connors was No. 12.

title: Julia Bell Is Wed To Peter Cowen Of Boston Globe
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 27St. Paul's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Julia Parker Bell of Boston, a freelance writer and photographer, to Pete Donnelly Cowen, who is a reporter for The Boston Globe.

title: Credit Date
description: A machine that takes customer's money, reads his credit card, tells a computer what he bought and checks his credit rating is starting to replace cash registers in stores across the country.

title: Gardens
description: AGARDENER envisioning his first colorful perennial border will be disappointed with results unless he realizes the need for careful planning before the trowel is in hand. When browsing through the catalogues, one is often enamoured by the luscious color photographs of perennial flowers but overlooks the information given as to height, spacing and the flowering period. Many plants have a peak season of bloom that may last but a week or two, while others bloom heavily for several weeks and then only intermittently or not at all during the rest of the summer.

title: PRESIDENT HONORS LENINGRAD DEAD; CALLS FOR PEACE
description: LENINGRAD. May 27President Nixon, the difficult diplomacy of his Moscow summit now behind him, today paid a quick but relaxed call on this historic city and issued a plea for a world without war.

title: St. Louis Generating Electricity By Burning Garbage With Coal
description: ST. LOUIS, May 27  Residential trash is being converted to electricity here in an experiment that uses processed solid waste as supplementary fuel in conventional utility boilers.

title: 2,271 Acres of Federal Land Returned to Local Control
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) The White House has announced that President Nixon has ordered 2,271 acres of Federal land returned to state and local governments for park and recreational use. The land is valued at more than $8.3million.

title: 29 FOOD CONCERNS FOUND INSANITARY
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, has released the names of 29 food processing establishments cited for violations of the Health Code.

title: Miss Newman Wed in South
description: ROANOKE, Va., May 27Miss Virginia Ann Newman and Kenneth Foster Haelsig Jr. were married this morning in the Dupont Chapel Gardens at Hollins College by the Rev. Alvord Beardslee, the chaplain.

title: Donohue Captures Indianapolis 500
description: In 3 hours 3 minutes 31.55 seconds, Mark Donohue won the Indianapolis 500mile auto race yesterday before more than 275,000 fans.

title: Pamela Tripp Is Bride
description: WAPITAGH, L. I., May 27 Miss Pamela Jane Tripp was married here this afternoon to Eric Daniel Kinne Melby by the Rev. John A. Greco in the Episcopal Church of St. Jude. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Tripp are the parents of the bride. Mr. and Mrs. Melby are the parents of the bridegroom.

title: UCONN AND HARVARD VICTORS IN BASEBALL
description: STORRS, Conn., May 27Connecticut and Harvard won opening games in the National Collegiate District I baseball tournament today and will meet here tomorrow at 1 P.M.

title: It's Your Dream
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Of the many devices that affect our society, the computer is among the most worrisome. However, its societal impact, contrary to what the propaganda emanating from the computer community and amplified by the mass media would lead us to believe, is still slight. Airline reservations, banking, and other such social service systems affect, after all, only small and then only the most affluent sectors of society. Yet, sensitive individuals perceive the computer to be a source of social crisis.

title: English Booms in Japan
description: TOKYO  A Japanese woman, who described herself as rich, advertised recently in a Tokyo newspaper offering $300 a month, a private room and three meals a day for a livein foreign English instructressmaid. The notice added that daytimes would mostly be free.

title: Stamps
description: OLD village churches, some with architectural styles more than 1,000 years old, will be the subjects for five British stamps due June 21. Pictured will be St. Andrew's Church, GreenstedJuxtaOngar, Essex, on a Spence; All Saints, Earls Barton, Northamptonshire, on a 4pence; St. Andrew's, Letheringsett, Norfolk, on a Spence; St. Andrew's, Helpringham, Lincolnshire, on a 7pence; and Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Huish, Episcopi, Somerset, on a Spence.

title: Dance
description: As I was saying last week, when the demands of space interrupted me, the direction of Britain's Royal Ballet is to be evaluated not only on its creativity, but also on its management of the company's basic repertory (which by and large is the Ashton repertory) and its custodianship of those old AngloRussian classics that have always been a staple element of the Royal Ballet.

title: SOLING CLASS WON BY SHAYS PROMESAS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 27 Sue Ann Shay's and William Shay Jr.'s Promesas was Soling Class winner on Long Island Sound today when Belle Haven Club ran the second championship regatta of the season for Yacht Racing Association fleets based East of Rye.

title: Cambodian City Attacked
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 127 (AP)  The Cambodian high command reported today I that Communist forces had attacked the provincial capital of Svayrieng in southeastern Cambodia for the third straight day.

title: La Forza del Destino Leads YachtRace
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 27 Sailing under very light air, a Class A yacht, La Forza del Destino, was reported leading the way to Block Island today in the Storm Trysail Club's 27th annual race. The race began yesterday from Larchmont. N.Y.. with the finish scheduled at Stamford.

title: Nancy G. Morris, Tufts Alumna, Wed to A. Paxton Henderson Jr.
description: TITIAN. Pa., May 27Miss Nancy Glenn Morris, daughter of I. Wistar Morris Jr. of Villanova and the late Mrs. Eleanor Pew Morris, was married here this afternoon to A. Faxon Henderson Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Henderson of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The World
description: SAIGONThe enemy bombing is so terrible I will die here. I want to get out of this hole, to fly away from this mountain range, to go to a lonely place so I can be alone.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: GARDENA, Calif., May 27 They are hearing Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's message loud and clearin Gardena 33, but they are not buying it. At least not yet.

title: MRS. K. BETHUNE
description: Mrs. Katharine Blanck Bethune, assistant woman's page editor on the former Brooklyn Eagle and later assistant manager in public relations for Trans World Airlines, died Thursday in Mineola, LI., where she lived. She was 64 years old.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Another bit of Americana the wooden icecream stick is about to give way to plastic.

title: Sedalia, Mo., to Suffer
description: SEDALIA, Mo., May 27 (UPI)  The United StatesSoviet agreement to limit nuclear arms is expected to cost this central Missouri town millions of dollars in anticipated income and construction.

title: Paris Letter: The Unsuccessful Surrealist
description: The Surrealist political revolution never came off, and so from a safe distance of 50 years, and with some pomp, Paris will honor the movement in June. It should provide us with a splendid show of paintings but it sounds terribly removed from Surrealism at its beginningsrather more like the anniversary of the Battle of the Marne.

title: M'ANDREVII VICTOR VVITH A SIXHITTER
description: ST. LOUIS, May 27Jim McAndrew, the highbrow of the New York Mets, pitched his first complete game in two seasons tonight as the Mets defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 41.

title: CATHOLIC PRIESTS WILL GET RATINGS
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has set up what it describes as the first permanent system of accountability for priests in any diocese in this country.

title: The Lampwicks Are Burning Low on Fire Island
description: DAVIS PARK, Fire IslandDo you still carry these? I asked the young salesgirl showing her a loop of coated wire. She shook her head.

title: The World
description: BONN  Four dead, 31 wounded, wrecked cars and offices these are the results of a dozen bomb blasts in six major cities during the last fortnight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lawyers for the Federal Government and Westchester County agreed yesterday on a number of steps that the county will take this summer to reduce pollutants flowing into the Hudson River from Croton Point's 100acre refuse dump. Croton Point, which is owned by the county, also contains a park with facilities for bathing, fishing, picnicking and camping.

title: Everything writers and composers of musicals need to know
description: The author of this book and its present reviewer grew up in the same home town. One night, the magician cameThurston, or was it Blackstone?to the Century Theater, and waiting for the curtain to go up, the Jackson, Miss., audience was fairly wild. Near me, on the frontrow balcony, little boys were swinging like monkeys from the railing. Then I saw, stepping down the aisle of the orchestra, a handsome, stylish little boy about my own age, 7 or 8, who showed nothing but aplomb. Escorting his party of three beautiful little girls to their seats, he took his own on the aisle, where he sat looking entirely selfcontained. I thought: that little boy knows how the magician does it. He may even be in on it. My intuition was working ahead of time.

title: The Pros Are Con
description: The prospect of the Soviet Union team playing a squad of National Hockey League players is virtually Topic No. 1 in Canada as well as among a loud minority of fans in the United States. The trouble is, the players and the league aren't that happy about the whole affair.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The World
description: LONDON  When Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath and his top aides unveiled the terms of their proposed reconciliation with the breakaway colony of Rhodesia last November, they did so with the air of men who had found the solution to a sixyearold crisis that had thwarted the best efforts of the preceding Laborite Government.

title: J. B. Convery Weds Miss Saunders
description: NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., May 27Miss Colleen Estelle Saunders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Saunders of New York and North Caldwell, was married here this morning to James Bernard Convery of Edison, son of Judge Samuel V. Convety of the New Jersey Superior Court and Mrs. Convery of Highland Park.

title: Tomorrow's Music: Something Old, Something New
description: ABOUT this time every four years, when it can hear itself think over the gunfire, the American nation takes time out to ponder its future. So, taking advantage of the speculative fever in the air, may we choose this moment to consider the question of Whither American Music?

title: Youth Is Hoping to Be Served In State's ClayCourt Tourney
description: With a junior having stunned the field in taking one of the opening men's tournaments, the Eastern tennis season may be headed for some strange turns.

title: Legislative Notes: Rights Of Adulthood Down to 18
description: TRENTON  Major bills passed by the New Jersey Legislature prior to its current recess are few in number but they should significantly affect the lives of most citizens.

title: Labor of love
description: Classic sauces and elaborate composed dishes have gone out of style even in France, but this elegant and arduous recipe for lamb chops Villeroi will give those who have the timeit's a twoday projecta chance to see for themselves whether the hard, old way was worth all the trouble. The Villeroi sauce is fabulously smooth and rich. And using it as a dip for lamb chops is prodigal.

title: Queer rumors, a soulless story and a failed optimist; Sticks And Stones; By Lynn Hall. 220 pp. Chicago: Follett Publishing Company. $4.95. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Some will say this is a book about homosexuality. It isn't. What it is about is far more important; injustice through the power of gossip. The story revolves around Tom Naylor, 17, who comes to live in Buck Greek, Iowa, with his recentlydivorced mother.

title: Miss Leonard a Bride
description: ROSEMONT, Pa., May 27 Miss Joyce Kempker Leonard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Leonard Jr., and George Kendall Moss, son of Mrs. Tevis Huhn of New York and David C. Moss of Lloyds Neck, L. I., were married here this morning at the home of the bride's parents by Justice of the Peace James W. McKelvy of Manoa. The bride's father is retired from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. in Wynnewood, where he was district sales manager. Mr. Moss's father is a retired investment banker.

title: Steel Pier's 75th Season
description: ATLANTIC CITYThe Steel Pier, one of the oldest sources of family entertainment in one of America's oldest family resorts, opens its 75th season in June.

title: REV. TIMOTHY DINEEN
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 27The Rev. Timothy J. Dineen, assistant director of the Loyola House of Retreat here, who had taught philosophy and theology Iat Canisius College, Buffalo, for 22 years, died yesterday in All Souls Community Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Farms Fading in Hunterdon
description: In the green hills of New Jersey's Hunterdon Countyon the far fringe of the New York City metropolitan area  anybody with half an ear cannot fail to heed the clatter of onrushing suburbia.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 27The personal delegate of Juan D. PerOn said today that the exiled former dictator would not return to Argentina without governmental guarantees for his personal security.

title: The World
description: The mutilation of Michelangelo's Pieta last Sunday by a mentally disturbed young man shocked the world as an act of mayhem against one of the supreme masterpieces in the history of Western art. Laszlo Toth, 33, a Hungarianborn Australian, had leaped over a guard rail in St. Peter's crying, I'm Jesus Christ! and attacked the statue with a hammer. The left arm of the Virgin was shattered and the nose, left eye and veil were chipped.

title: Janet E. Judd Has Nuptials
description: ORLEANS, Mass., May 27 Miss Janet Elizabeth Judd, assistant registrar at Simmons College in Boston, and Brian Barrett, a copy editor with The Boston Traveler, were married here this afternoon.

title: Friendship a YouthCenter Theme
description: FLANDERS  Two years ago, a culturally oriented youth center was a dream of Stan Barber and Bob Findlay, then English teachers at West Morris High School. Today that dream is a reality, called Pax Amicus peace and the spirit of friendship.

title: Tarport Skipper Scores
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., May 27Tarport Skipper, a 4yearold bay colt owned by Del Miller and Hugh Grant of Meadowlands, Pa., turned in the first sub twominute mile of the Atlantic City Raceway meeting at Freehold this season when he won the $12,500 Wenonah Pace by two lengths today. Tarport Skipper, driven by John Chapman, was timed in 1:59.4 and paid $3.20.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: N.Y.U. Class of 71 Sets Record For Contributions to University
description: New York University's class of 1971, which gave the school some of the most turbulent times in its history, has been contributing money to the university in greater numbers than has any other class.

title: ALBANY REJECTS WELFARE CLAIMS
description: The State Department of Social Services has already disallowed nearly $8million in Federal and state reimbursements to the city's welfare and Medicaid programs for the first three months of this year.

title: Announcements
description: Engagements 5022

title: U.S. Writer Confined in Greece On Drug Charge Is Reported Ill
description: WASHINGTON, May 27A 41yearold American writer, whose big World War II novel won literary acclaim in 1967, is in a mental hospital near Athens clinging to the hope that the Premier of Greece will waive on compassionate grounds the balance of his stiff prison sentence for smuggling narcotics into the country.

title: Oakland to Spend Day In the Handlebar Era
description: OAKLAND, May 27 (UPI) Remember the House of David semipro baseball teams of the 1930's and 40's? Some fans going to the Oakland Coliseum on June 18 might be reminded of those bewhiskered House of David players of another era if they look closely.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The first step toward elimination of lead shot for waterfowling will be taken this fall in the United States when its use will be prohibited on certain Federal lands in the continent's four major waterfowl flyways.

title: MOSCOW DETAILS FIVEYEAR PLAN
description: MOSCOW, May 27The Soviet Union, for the first time in more than 30 years, has published a detailed version of a current fiveyear plan, a major Government document guiding the nation's economic and social development.

title: An Art Sales Boom In Japan Attributed To Inflation Hedge
description: TOKYO, May 27 (Reuters)Japanese art dealers believe investors have turned from jewels to paintings in their search for a way to hedge against inflation.

title: Art Notes
description: CAN the New York Cultural Center, the confused young art gallery on Columbus Circle founded by Huntington Hartford and now run by Fairleigh Dickinson University, find itselt at last as a Mature Museum?

title: Where Are You Off To? College. What's Your Major? Tourism.
description: WHEN tourism first grew up and went off to college, it was taught as the equivalent of a home economics course in collegiate hotel schools. But now it is a multimilliondollar industry, and it has moved into the School of Business Administration and become a big man on campus.

title: DELAWARE DASHWON BY OVER ARRANGED
description: STANTON, Del., May 27 (AP) Elberon Farm's favored Over Arranged, the only 3yearold in a field of seven sprinters, sped to victory in the $28,100 Hannibal Handicap today as Delaware Park opened its 65day meeting.

title: Lynch Reflects on Year as Head Of African Institute at Columbia
description: Hollis R. Lynch, historian and director of Columbia University's Institute of African Studies, sat in a highbacked, upholstered swivel chair in his study, wearing a modestly resplendent dashiki and casually slipping his bare feet in and out of his sandals.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: About Pro Football
description: In spite of all the law suits against it, the National Football League will open its 53d season on July 29 when the College AllStars play the Dallas Cowboys in Chicago. That is the first of the preseason contests and the second comes the next day at Canton, Ohio, where the Giants will meet the Kansas City Chiefs in the annual hall of fame game. Both contests will be televised nationally by the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Two Killed as Pathans Ambush Convoy on Pakistan's Frontier
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 24  It was about noon on April 3 in 1895 that Sir Robert Low's column of the British Indian Army fended off a savage charge of Pathan tribesmen near Malakand and breached the dangerous pass that led to a besieged northern fortress at Chitral.

title: Leningrad: Touch of West
description: MOSCOW, May 27Leningrad, the Soviet Union's second largest city, visited today on a hurried trip by President Nixon, is still an impressive metropolitan center after having lost its past political preeminence under the Soviet regime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleaning Up Union Carbide
description: ALLOY, W. Va.I think Union Carbide got the message. In the last few years, they decided to cope with their pollution problem.

title: MRS. R. O. UETZMANN
description: WILLISTON PARK, L. L., May 27 Mrs. Jane Gourley Uetzmann, who retired recently as senior actuarial statistician of American Cyanamid Company and who was a breeder of poodles, canaries and parakeets, died yesterday at her home here. Her age was 56.

title: Frank Tashlin
description: FRANK TASHLIN directed and wrote 21 comedies in Hollywood, wrote and illustrated three children's books and made at least 40 animated cartoons. Not many people in America took much notice of him, probably because many of his films were, on the surface anyway, brassy vehicles for Jerry Lewis, Bob Hope, Doris Daynot the sort of material you get any credit for among the critical establishment. Though JeanLuc Godard and several other critics and directors were ecstatic in their praise of his work, he was virtually unknown and certainly unappreciated in his own

title: Golden Gate Bridge Is 35
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 (AP)The Golden Gate Bridge is 35 years old today and remains a money maker, its directors say. Over the years the bridge has earned enough tolls to pay off $35million in construction bonds and to finance current bus and ferry transit projects designed to alleviate auto congestion.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Northwestern Accused of Antiwhite Bias
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 27Northwestern University has been accused of discriminating against white students in a suit filed in Federal District Court this week.

title: METHADONE PLAN BEHIND SCHEDULE
description: Last November, Mayor Lindsay announced that the Health Services Administration methadonemaintenance program would be rapidly expanded from 3.000 patients to 11,000 by June next. With June only three days away, there are currently 5,620 methadone patients in the program.

title: New Haven Ousts Montclair From College Tourney, 51
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 27Montclair State was eliminated from the Atlantic Coast regional playoff of the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division baseball tournament today when it lost to New Haven College, 51. New Haven scored four runs in the sixth inning on four singles and a double.

title: Chi Cheng's Progress Is Called Encouraging
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 27 Chi Cheng, Taiwan's worldchampion sprinter, says her doctors believe she is making excellent progress toward recovery after an operation to remove a stiffened section of muscle from her left thigh six weeks ago.

title: A Parley at Glassboro, Recalling the Summit
description: GLASSBOROA billboard on Route 47 bears the greeting Welcome to Glassboro, the Summit City. A small granite marker in front of Holly Bush, a threestory fieldstone house on the state college campus, notes that it was the site of summit conferences between President Lyndon B. Johnson and Aleksei N. Kosygin, the Soviet Premier, on June 23 and 25, 1967.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Redecorating with fabric
description: Brownstone rooms needn't always be totally reorganized to meet the demands of contemporary living. Anthony Tortora and Jay Crawford, the design team behind Quadrille Fabrics, illustrate how to update an older brownstone (built in the eighteensixties) with no architectural changes at all. They relied on smallscale prints and a few spectacular objects to give each room a distinctive feeling. Yet there is no jarring discordance when moving from one room to another. We tried to create a contemporary background within the Victorian spaces. says owner Crawford, who chose objects for their abstract shapes and pleasing textures. Lots of lively but subdued colors, contemporary paintings and the use of natural materials such as hemp rugs, are the key to the tiny house's huge success.

title: LETTERS

title: ... and There the Trend Is to the Backless Look

title: Police Fingerprint Men Continue to Study Gallo Killing
description: Sore eyes, not sore feet, plague the handful of Police Department sleuths who specialize in studying fingerprints found at the scenes of crimes.

title: I Get a Charge From Seeing Myself On Stage
description: Black poet and author of Gemini

title: A great gift for scorn and charm;Grapes From Thorns
description: This nonbook, a posthumous collection of insignificant pieces, is no key to the importance of the man who was one of the most powerful figures in and creators of our half of the 20th century. And Dean Acheson was fully as interesting a personality as he was peculiarly dominating a Secretary of State and creator of foreign policy. He was more intelligent than most of our national leaders (how well he knew it); he had more style than most American writers, educators, artists; and he could be as persuasively charming and beautifully civilized when he wanted something as he could be dismissive and arrogant toward those with whom he disagreed. If ever we had a Foreign Secretary of stature, Acheson was ithe was without Hull's bumbling archaism, Eden's bad nerves, Dulles's gift for irritating even God, Bevin's personal brutality, Molotov's lethal orthodoxy, Rusk's crippling obstinacy, Rogers's amateurism.

title: Hotel in Miami Beach Picked as Nixon's Base
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 27The Doral Beach Hotel was named yesterday, as the headquarters for President Nixon for the Republican National Convention here. The Doral is at 4833 Collins Avenue facing the Atlantic Ocean.

title: WANDA TRIUMPHS IN MOTHER GOOSE
description: Wanda of the Niblick Stable came through with a dramatic and surprising victory in the $84,600 Mother Goose at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenny Chitwood a Bride
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 27Miss Jenny Callen Chitwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Chitwood, was married here this afternoon to Michael Stanley Field, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Field of Hampton Hill, Middlesex, England. The Rev. Charles Knapp performed the ceremony in St. Saviour's Episcopal Church. Mr. Chitwood is an illustrator. The bridegroom whose father works for the Admirality Office in London, is an electrical engineer with National C, S. S., Inc., in Stamford as manager of systems marketing and professional services.

title: A Strong and Independent Man Speaks Out for the companionship of Trout
description: MARQUETTE, Mich.Hey, hey, John Voelker cries, as the trout rises to his fly. Such excitement in this big, old guy is surprising. He has caught thousands of trout in his lifetime, and he knows by the flash of water that this is a small onejust another trout, one would think. But trout fishing is the center of Voelker's life; it is, literally, much of what he lives for. Fishing, he says, is the only time he really feels at home.

title: Preschoolers Learn to Like Classical Music
description: CLOSTERWhile they listened to classical violin music, one child played an imaginary flute, others vibrated their bodies to the beat, a few crawled along the floor and three youngsters firmly held their hands over their cars.

title: Construction of Subway Tunnel Stalling Traffic on 6th Avenue
description: Subway construction is once again tying up traffic on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Friendship House Offering A New Life to the Distressed
description: HACKENSACK  Where do the emotionally distressed go after perhaps a long hospital stay to get on their feet and begin to live again? Perhaps to Friendship House here, a rehabilitation center where such men and women are helped to make maximum use of their abilities.

description: PRINCETON  Eyebrows were raised among the lowerschool faculty members when Mrs. Sheila M. Johnson said that she was going to teach kindergartners to play the violin, a hard musical instrument to master.

description: TWINSBURG, Ohio, May 27 (AP)John and James Sesnowchik, identical twins who are finishing R. B. Chamberlin High School with identically perfect 4.0 academic averages, will graduate Wednesday as covaledictorians of their class.

description: BELFAST, Northern I reland, May 27 (Reuters)Thousands of militant Protestants demonstrated their strength today with a parade through Belfast, their biggest show of force in years.

description: The hyphen In nofault automobile insurance reflects the deep divisions that have arisen on this issue at the Federal, state and local level.

description: LUBECK, West Germany, May 23HansWerner Grosse, the West German pilot who set a new world record in longdistance glider flying last month, said that he flew beneath most of Central Europe's supposedly crowded air lanes from the Baltic Sea to the Spanish border and encountered only five other gliders on the 900mile trip.

title: Photography

Called the International Photo Optical Association, the organization is planning a series of regional photographic shows, with the first one scheduled to be held June 16, 17 and 18 in the Albert Hall of the Americana Hotel (53d Street and Seventh Avenue). Various members of IPOSA will be exhibiting their newest products and answering questions in booths throughout the hall, and there will be seminars on various subjects on each

title: Mary E. Henry Becomes Bride
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 27  Miss Mary Elizabeth Henry, a grandniece of the late Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of New York, was married here this evening to Scott Abercrombie Fitzgerald.

description: George Dugan of The New York Times and H. Elliott Wright of Religious News Service were named winners last week of Faith and Freedom Awards for superior work in covering, interpreting and examining religious news and issues.

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Bengalis Still Cheering But Nova Want Results
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 27 Thundering out of the ubiciluitous electronic bullhorns, the patriotic war cry Joi Bangla!  Long Live Bengal!  resounds in Dacca's sultry air every day, although the war ended nearly six months ago.

description: The Yankees, who escaped unscathed following a threebase wild pitch three weeks ago, perpetrated a twobase wild pitch yesterday and it reiulted in a 21 loss to Detroit.

description: Yes, we do break for tea, but I wish to God someone would tell the American public why we break for tea, said Edmund Peckover, the 76yearold Briton, who is in charge of publicity for the Staten Island Cricket Club.

description: WUPPERTAL, GermanyAt the Vorwerk plant here, one of West Germany's leading manufacturers of electrical appliances, workers consider liquid paints for the coating of refrigerators almost as antiquated as the paint brush.

description: TRENTON, May 27 (AP)A group of 14 prisoners stoned windows during their recreation period at Trenton State Prison today, breaking 30 panes of glass, a prison spokesman said.

description: Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., and Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., both ranked in the top ten nationally by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, head a list of six players named yesterday to the United States Davis Cup squad.
