description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 27The engagement of Miss Juliana Fuerbringer to Daniel Nall, ion of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Nall of Savannah, Ga., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Otto Fuerbringer of Greenwich.

title: A Chinese Man Sues G.M.; Cites Dead Son's Earnings
description: TULSA, Okla., May 27A Sapulpa, Okla., man of Chinese origin has sued the General Motors Company charging that the company through faulty workmanship, caused his son's death and deprived the family estate of earnings the dead man would have contributed in compliance with Chinese tradition.

title: Woody Was as Scared of Me as I Was of Him
description: DIANE KEATON, at 26, has played the female leads in the Broadway production of Hair, the film The Godfather, and the stage and screen versions of Woody Allen's Play It Again, Sam. When the Allen movie opened recently, Vincent canby was captivated by her sweetly lunatic sincerity. Another critic, Gail Rock, wrote, Ms. Keaton nearly steals the show. She does it by. maintaining a lovely sweet calm in the midst of the madness.

title: Then I Stood On My Head
description: I WON'T say I wasn't nervous when. one day last fall, I went before several hundred junior high school students in Fort Wayne, Ind., to talk about music. I was warned of the tension in the school due to overcrowding, busing, racial issues, etc. All I could think was how seemingly useless a subject like classical music is to people faced with such social and economic emergencies. If a man is drowning you don't play him a concerto. So I planned a special approach.

title: Federal Sterilization Program in Doubt
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 26  Harold Sharp is not going to have any more children. The Federal Government made that possible by furnishing him with a male sterilization operationa vasectomyearlier this year.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 27 (AP)  Ethiopia's chance of winning the marathon at the Munich Olympics brightened today with the victory of an unknown Army sergeant at the Ethiopian armed forces sports day.

description: Leonard Bernstein's Mass will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House for four weeks beginning the last week in June. Following previews on June 26 and 27, the work will have its official opening on June 28. The engagement will end on July 22.

title: C.B.S. Cameraman Wounded
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27 (AP)A cameraman for the Columbia Broadcasting System was wounded today in fighting at Mychanh on the northern front, C.B.S. News announced. Vinh ye, a veteran combat photographer, suffered shrapnel wounds on the right forearm when a North Vietnamese rocketgrenade exploded near him. He was treated at a Hue hospital.

title: Priorities in 1972
description: Back in the early nineteensixties, the economists of the Kennedy Administration produced the concept of the fiscal dividendthe additional tax revenues that would be generated for the Federal Treasury by an expanding national economy. Administrations, under this concept, would have the blissful choice of what to do with the fiscal dividend; they could either spend it on new Federal programs or they could cut taxes. Indeed, it was essential that they do one or the other, lest the fiscal dividend turn into fiscal dragand slow the economy to stagnation or recession.

title: Phillipa A. Brisbane Betrothed To Ens. Henry Milton Shaw Jr.
description: ATLANTA, May 27  Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Brisbane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phillips Annette Brisbane, to Ens. Henry Milton Shaw Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw of South Bend, Ind.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Not unnaturally, the youth culture has been attracting writers of crime novels, and Burt Hirschfeld has come up with one of the most bizarre ideas of all. In FATHER PIG (Arbor House, $6.95), a group of dropouts decide to murder their parents. These kids come mostly from upperclass families, but, to them, parents are. pigs. The world would be better off without them, and what better way to start the revolution?

title: A Not So Retiring Dame
description: LESS than two weeks agoon May 18, to be exactDame Margot Fonteyn, hailed as the greatest ballerina in the world, turned 53. At best, 53 is a precarious age for any woman. For a ballerina, no matter how gifted, it is usually a time for looking backa time for recollection, retirement, rest, teaching, or the possible writing of a book of memoirs. For Dame Margot, last May 18 was just another Thursday.

description: PHILADELPHIA  When the Philadelphia Orchestra left this month to tour Japan, one of the sponsors was the Girard Bank.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27 (AP)Dan Lasater's Pleasure Castle caught up with Gallant Agent in the stretch posted a 2length victory today in the 71st Bashford Manor at Churchill Downs.

title: The lire next time this time
description: If we...do not falter in our duty now, we may be able...to end the racial nightmare, James Baldwin said nine years ago in The Fire Next Time, warning that, if we did not, violent and vengeful racial clashes were inevitable. His caveat was clamorously hailed, but insufficiently heeded. Riots, assassinations, the emergence of black power and the intensification of white blacklash have attested to Baldwin's powers of divination. Yet those same events may have rendered him an anachronism. Reading his latest book, No Name in the Street  a twopart, extended essay that is a memoir, chronicle of and commentary on America's abortive civilrights movementthat suspicion is nearly substantiated.

title: Belmont Ball Is Off, but No One Is Saying Why
description: The Belmont Ball, which has been a fixture for the society silks set since 1951, will not be held this yearbut don't ask why.

title: An Antiwar Monument Is Erected in Bay State
description: EAST BRIDGEWATER, Mass., May 27 (AP)The inscription on the monument says, VietnamAn American Tragedy. An apology for What We Did There. Memorial Day, 1972.

title: Boy Rejects Legion Award

Fourteenyearold Alfred Kohn raised the Legion's ire when he rejected its scholarship and service runnerup award at Ida M. Fisher Junior High School this week.

title: The Nation
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut's Governor Thomas J. Meskill smiles easily, but not in a long time has he beamed so, broadly before the cameras as he did last Tuesday night when he signed a tough new abortion bill into law.

title: The Cabinets of Doctor Inke
description: STONY BROOK, L.I. An anatomy professor with an eye for the future has just come out with what may seem like a macabre request: If there's a skeleton in your closet, he wants it.

title: HARYOU INSTALLS BOARD ON GROWTH
description: Fifteen members of the board of directors of HaryouAct, Harlem's antipoverty agency, have been installed as the board of directors for a newly formed local development corporation that will operate as a profitmaking arm of the agency.

title: The Mailbox:
description: It Was All in Fun

title: Bringing Baby Up in a Jet Isn't Easy...
description: IT doesn't take long to develop the symptoms. A few flights and you find yourself behaving like an untouchable as you file past the stewardesses, searching their faces for the slightest sign of compassion, any indication that they might respond to a sister human in distress. And no matter how often you remind yourself, as you line up at the boarding gate, to maintain some shred of selfrespect, you inevitably find your facial muscles contorting into that same sickening halfguilty, halfpleading grin as you confront the cold, brighttoothed smile at the cabin door. You can't even keep yourself from the ridiculous, furtive charade of trying to conceal what you are taking onto the plane. Ridiculous, because how can you possibly hide a 4yearold boy (who is insistently urging everyone to move on or the plane will leave without them) and a wriggling, oversized 11monthold son (who is grabbing at your glasses, pulling your hair and drooling over everyone within a fivefoot radius)?

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 27This is the button.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISBecause of the triangulation of U.S. power relations with Moscow and Peking, now would be as good as any moment for Washington to straighten out what might appear to be a minor diplomatic lapse.

title: 101,000 defendants were convicted of misdemeanors last year. 98,000 of them had pleaded guiltyto get reduced sentences.
description: ON March 9, 1972, Federal and state grand juries in New York indicted Clifford Irving and his wife Edith. The indictments were the opening shots in the long, protracted war between individual and Government we call a criminal case. Four days later, the war ended abruptlyafter a few minutes in the Federal Court, a few across the street in the state criminal court, some ritual incantations (something like You understand the charges against you? Yes, sir. You are pleading guilty of your own free will? Yes, sir), a confession by the defendants, a ruling by the judge that the defendants pleaded guilty voluntarily, and a date set for sentencing.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Bridal Upstate For Alice Dodge And Oil Official
description: CLAYTON, N, Y., May 27 Miss Alice Dodge and Robin A. C. Berkeley were married here today at noon at Wild Goose Island, the summer home of the bride's grandfather, Cleveland E. Dodge of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. A. Grant Noble, retired rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Daughter for the Sibers
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 27A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Victor Siber on May 9 at the White Plains Hospital.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: NOW Says: TV Commercials Insult Women
description: The bride and groom have run directly from their wedding without bothering to change their clothes or go on their honeymoon, to the appliance store. The salesman is telling the groom (not the bride) how terrific the G.E. ToasterOven is. The bride is standing around in a daze, having just achieved the greatest ambition of her lifea husband. The two men decide that the groom should buy the product and then, as a polite afterthought, they turn to the bride and ask her what she thinks. Oblivious to everything she replies, I do.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Toronto's Stadium Installs Foundation For N.F.L. Posts
description: TORONTO, May 26 (Canadian Press)The Canadian National Exhibition Stadium, home of the Toronto Argonauts in the Canadian Football League, has installed foundations for goalpc:As that could be used for a National Football League game.

title: City Agencies Are Trying to Avert Possible War Among Youth Gangs During Summer School Vacation
description: City social work agencies and the police, alarmed by the continued proliferation of youth gangs here, are trying to defuse tensions among the groups that they fear could flare into warfare once summer school vacations begin.

title: Easing of Marijuana Laws Stirs Wide Concern Over Those in Prison
description: The rapid liberalization of the nation's marijuana laws in recent years, and the growing reluctance of judges to impose jail sentences for simple possession, is beginning to stir concern for the plight of those who were jailed under older laws and harsher attitudes.

title: KENTUCKIAN WINS COAST TURF STAKE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 27 (AP)Kentuckian sprinted to a halflength victory today in the $55,000 Argonaut Stakes and Jerry Lambert escaped serious injury in a fall from Bicker shorty after the start of the turf race at Hollywood Park.

title: Stricken Professor Teaches by Phone
description: JERSEY CITYDr. James Clarkin, chairman of the English Department at Jersey City State College, has turned the tables on a common educational procedure to start a new way of teaching.

title: New Cabinet Is Formed By the Lebanese Premier
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 A new Cabinet was formed here under Premier Saeb Salam. Most of the 16 new members are conservatives who head the parliamentary blocs that scored the largest victories in the general elections last month.

title: New &Novel
description: Milbry is Mildred Prewett, a little girl growing up in Tennessee before and after World War I. Father drives a Marathon; Mother is ineffably elegant; and twice a year the family visits Nashville, considered the culture capital of the world.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Opens New Museum Illustrating History of Army
description: LONDON, May 27 (Canadian Press)Britain has placed the history of its army, from the days of 15th century yeoman archers to modern times, on display in the newly opened National Army Museum in Chelsea.

title: Religion
description: The Vatican has always been adept at adjusting its methods of selecting bishops to existing political systems. Absolute rulers like King Francis I of France in the 16th century exercised absolute control over episcopal patronage. General Franco in Spain still possesses the right of presentation, i.e., the power to nominate.

title: Queer rumors, a soulless story and a failed optimist; The Underside Of the Leaf; By M. B. Goffstein. 150 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $4.50. (Ages 11 to 15)
description: M. B. Goffstein is one of the few originals in children's literature. Her tiny, delicate picture books have a Middle European flavor and a gentle reverence for life. In both words and illustrations, she blends gravity with humour, and the effect has always been disarming. Lately, however, Miss Goffstein's work has been growing more complexand now we have a full length novel from her. I regret to say that it is a disappointment

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe issue was Federal taxes, which just might turn out to be the biggest issue of the Presidential campaign. A major study by the Brookings Institution, released last Wednesday, said, in effect, that taxes will have to go upcertainly if more money is to be spent on solving domestic social problems and probably even if only present programs are maintained and those proposed by President Nixon are enacted.

title: Patricia Driggs, John A. Balassi Plan Marriage
description: DEWITT, N.Y., May 27Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Paul Driggs of Dewitt and Point Lookout, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Heffernan Driggs, to John A. Balassi. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine G. Balassi of North Tarrytown.

title: Chess.
description: A course in the elements of chess play is a collection of about 300 masterpieces containing the best of the last decade. The leadoff match is Shmatkov against Eidlin, a Queen's Gambit Declined from Moscow, 1960.

title: David Martin Darst Is Fiance Of Diane Elizabeth Wassman
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 27The engagement of Miss Diane Elizabeth Wassman to David Martin Darst has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Robert Wessman, parents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Bewley Darst of Nashville.

title: Van Zifl of South Africa Runs Fastest Mile of Year in 3:56.0
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 271 (AF)Fanie Van Zit of South Africa recorded the fastest mile time of the year tonight, clocking 3 minutes 56 seconds at the 31st California Relays,

title: A NEW SCHEDULE SET BY CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The six Friday night subscription programs of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will be repeated on Sunday afternoons instead of Saturday nights next season.

title: PENN CREWS SWEEP CORNELL AT ITHACA
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 27 (AP) Pennsylvania crews swept a threerace regatta against Cornell today, winning the varsity Madeira Cup for the seventh consecutive year.

title: Wallace Condition Stable As Recovery Progresses
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 27 (UPI)  An aide described Gov. George C. Wallace's condition as stabilized today to such a degree that four of the seven staff members who have stayed by his side since his shooting on May 15 would go home this weekend.

title: Survival New Word For Tiniest Babies
description: LONG BRANCHIn one crib, a tiny baby slept beneath a tag reading, My name is Shah. Guess who I was named for.

title: From a master of the narrative tease
description: For at least a century most French novelists have been disappointed painters and aspiring detectives. It is a natural condition in the country that produced the School of Paris, extending from Manet and Cezanne through postImpressionism, and where a novelist's mother may, while expecting, have been frightened by Poe or Dostoevsky. In our day this double orientation of the French novel appears to be bearing strange fruit.

title: The Politics Of Prisoners of War
description: PROBLEM for students of international law: Which of the following kinds of captives in Vietnam benefit from the rules of the Geneva Conventions?

title: ORIOLES TRIUMPH OVER INDIANS, 42
description: BALTIMORE, May 27 (AP)Terry Crowley slammed a tworun homer in the eighth, powering the Baltimore Orioles to a 42 victory over the faltering Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWThe two nuclear scorpions of this earth created bonds here last week designed to force them finally to live more decently together.

title: Icebreaking Lakers Planned
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 25 Finnish icebreaker experts believe that the Great Lakes can be opened to navigation year round by the introduction of specially designed oceangoing cargo ships. Navigation on the lakes is now halted by ice for four months yearly beginning in December.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHITE HOUSE declared that the Administration was opposed to any increase in Federal taxes for the foreseeable future, and said it was committed instead to cutting spending. The announcement followed a Brookings Institution study that said the Government was already overcommitted on spending for the next two years and could not spend more on solving social or other problems without a big tax increase.

title: Religious Indoctrination Suit
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 27 (UPI)The American Civil Liberties Union sued yesterday to halt systematic religious indoctrination in the New Philadelphia public school system. The suit in United States District Court in Youngstown, contends that a program of weekday religious education classes offered in the Tuscarawas County schools is in violation of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Cahill Takes His TaxReform Plans to the People
description: TRENTON  Although the special legislative session on New Jersey tax reform is not scheduled to begin until June 15, Governor Cahill undertook what many leaders here regard as the most crucial part of his campaign last week when he started bringing his case for reform to the people.

title: LUTZ WILL COMPETE IN STAMFORD TENNIS
description: Bob Lutz, former United States Open doubles champion and a member of the World Championship Tennis tour, will be one of the four competitors in the Clark Gum tennis tournament at Stamford, Conn.

title: Melvin Van Prolific
description: MOST Broadway hits wind up on the screen sooner or latermostly later, that being the ordinary order of things. However, there doesn't seem to be anything at all ordinary about Melvin Van Peebles, so why should we be surprised to learn that Van Peebles's new and successful musical, Don't Play Us Cheap!, was safely locked away on film before the show reached Broadway?

title: The Lazard Freres Style

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Despite vigorous assertions to the contrary by the White House, there seems to be very little doubt that a Federal tax increase is in the cards for next year oratory that has recently been heard on both sidesfrom the position of John B. Connally Jr. at one extreme, saying there are no such things as tax loopholes, to the position of George McGovern, at the other, acting as though it were practical to raise the taxes of all families with incomes above $12,000.

title: H.H.H.: What this country needs is a nice man as President of the United States
description: THAT Hubert Horatio Humphrey was running again for President was news almost as incredible as the prospect that he might succeed. After his great fall in 1968 it would surely take a miracle to put the Hump together again. It had been sad to see such a messy end to such an honorable and constructive political careerbut end it had seemed. His dream of being the first druggist to hold the greatest office in the land was gone in the morning of his defeat at the hands of one of the bestknown losers in the business. On his politician's grave under the letters R.I.P. it was necessary only to add three moreL.B.J. But old politicians never die and Hubert Humphrey refuses to fade away. Here he is again, alive and running in California, and it requires not too great a leap of fancy to hear him deliveringfor one could write the scripthis speech of acceptance and  is it possible?  his inaugural

This advice is prompted by listening this week to two new releases that juxtapose Italian operas composed approximately two hundred years apart Francesco Cavalli's La Calisto (2 disks, Argo ZNF 1112) and Giuseppe Verdi's I Lombardi alla prima crociata (3 disks, Philips 6703 032).

title: Photography
description: THOMAS EAKINS was not a photographer but a painter who took photographs. He never mastered photographic processing, and many of the pictures in Gordon Hendricks's new book, The Photographs of Thomas Eakins (Grossman, $30), are recreated by modern photographers from faded and damaged originals. With Eakins, therefore, it is more than usually necessary to think of his photographs simply as pictures, and to consider the place they occupy in his Work whole.

title: New &Novel
description: A youth named Nick is into a mamapapa fish market, where he transfers his Oedipal urges to the lady of the store. Meanwhile, in Texas, the heir to the fish store is into making pornographic TV tapes, writing a movie script, working for the C.I.A.  and becoming even more psycho. Mr. Pomerantz is into a Grand Guignol tour de force that goes nowhere at 100 miles an hour  but if his comprehension of human beings ever catches up with his amazing sense of tempo, he will be someone to watch.

title: Art
description: N OT MUCH has been written about the paintings of Alfred a. Jensen, and one can easily see why. They are intimidating. Their intricate, colored grids are based on a dizzyingly abstruse system of mathematical, archeological and philosophical concepts and principles, and their rationale, even when explained, is likely to pass the understanding of even erudite critics (of whom I'm not one). Add to this the paintings perfectly direct, obvious beauty (no challenge to anyone's descriptive powers) and it becomes understandable that Jensen, while one of the most respected of American abstractionists, should also be one of the discussed.

title: Law
description: I refuse to answer any questions on grounds that it might tend to incriminate me. Those magical words, deriving from the Fifth Amendment's stricture that no person... shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, are familiar to all Americans. But for generations, the interpretation and application of this privilege against selfincrimination has been one of the most debated guarantees of the Constitution.

Y., May 27 Elie Wiesel, the author, told graduates of Manhattanville College today that while it was difficult not to despair of the world's horror and violence, I am absolutely convinced that even when faith is impossible, you must make it possible, and each person, when he talks to another, has a certain faith in the other.

title: LESTER ABELMAN
description: Lester Abelman, a drama reviewer, rewriteman and reporter for The Daily News, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 300 East 57th Street.

title: His First Love: Theater
description: FOR a composer who came to his interest in opera late, Carlisle Floyd has done pretty well in that medium. In New York recently for the performance by the Jacksonville Symphony of his latest work, Flower and Hawk, he talked about his career, noting that when he was growing up his biggest love was for the theater and the piano. If he was in New York, he went to see plays, not operas. When he was a graduate student at Syracuse University, he did turn out a oneact opera called Slow Dusk, but his main ambition was to be a concert pianist. "Susannah, his first and biggest success, was written in his late twenties, and it was about that time that he became sufficiently fascinated by the operatic form to begin analyzing some of the major examples. What proved particularly impressive and useful to him were the last three operas of Verdi and Britten's Peter Grimes.

title: A cannibal past and Christian Present
description: SINCE English Baptist missionaries ended the isolation of the Bataks of northern Sumatra in 1824, the Bataks have mended their ways they no longer eat people. Today the grandeur of the Lake Toba landscape in Indonesia, the Batak ancestral homeland, is a fascinating blend of the spirithaunted megalithic past and the Christian present (those who have stayed in the area are mostly Christians), where thatchedroof homes grouped like a flotilla at sea stand side by side with Batakmade stone symbols of imagined and real ancestors. A trip through the villages on the lake provides colorful vignettes of Sumatran life; there are also a great number and variety of churches, some of them in close proximity to the old animist sarcophagi.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 27 (AP)Dave Duncan and Bert Campaneris hit homers, backing the eighthit pitching of Jim (Catfish) Hunter, and led the Oakland A's to a 63 victory over the Chicago White Sox today in a nationally televised game.

title: Mrs. Moore Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ronnie Malcolm Moore of Newark on May 15 in St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N. J. Mrs. Moore is the former Miss Carol Beatty of Newark. The child has been named Ronnie Malcolm 2d. His father is executive director of Scholarship, Education and Defense Fund for Racial Equality.

title: Miss Holt Bride of Paul Schaffner
description: PRINCETON, N J., May 27 Miss Alexandra Foster Holt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philetus Havens Holt 3d, was married here at noon today to Paul Eugene Schaffner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Blaine Schaffner of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: Wagner Denies Intention To Run for Mayor Again
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, whose recent political activities have caused speculation about his future plans, declined yesterday to rule out running again for public office  except for one job: Mayor.

title: French Confounded As N.F.L. Players Make Their Debut
description: PARIS, May 27An American accent at the Stade de Charlety screamed from the grandstand, Hey, how about some football?

title: Chinese Debate U.S. Visitors On Vietnam but Remain Cordial
description: HONG KONG, May 27Chinese friendliness toward American businessmen who attended the Canton trade fair did not diminish by any noticeable degree after President Nixon announced the mining of North Vietnam's ports, according to a Los Angeles lawyer who visited China on behalf of 12 companies.

title: Expenditures Filed By Common Cause Top Lobbyists List
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Common Cause, a selfstyled people's lobby, topped the big spenders among lobbyists whose financial reports have been published in the Congressional Record.

title: BUSINESS BUREAUS BACK ARBITRATION
description: CHICAGO  Arbitration of consumer merchant disputes could be the missing link needed to improve relations between the business community and the buying public, managers of the nation's Better Business Bureaus were told last week.

title: Employes Who Balked at Oath Gain a Delay in Massachusetts
description: WALTHAM, Mass., May 27The mandatory dismissal of group of children's counselors and nurses at the Metropolitan State Hospital who refused to sign a recently revived state loyalty oath has been postponed.

title: Playing the violin and living life
description: At one point in Candide Voltaire runs a playful variation on the classical definition of man by calling him a twolegged, featherless being with a soul. In one of his essays collected under the title Theme and Variations, Yehudi Menuhin almost seems tempted to suggest that this posture was somehow predestined to be put to one very special use. Man's peculiar privilege, he writes, is walking erect on two feet (and not on four): and thereby being forced to stretch his hands upwards. to heaven. This conquering of gravity, space and height, as well as of horizon, is essential to violinplaying. We may be reminded of Pangloss, who taught Candide that the existence of eyeglasses could be explained by the fact that noses were obviously made to support them. Fortunately, however, Yehudi Menuhin never tries to convince us that fiddleplaying is the beall and endall of creation. Indeed, the great virtue of this group of essays and lectures is that it shows us how farranging the musician's interests and concerns really are and how exceptional he is among performing artists in this respect.

title: The World
description: BELFASTAs twilight enveloped Stormont Castle last Wednesday five Roman Catholic women of Londonderry stepped outside after spending 40 minutes with William Whitelaw, Britain's Secretary of Stateor proconsul  for Northern Ireland. The women spoke rapidly, emotionally. We told him we wanted the barricades down and that we wanted peace and an end to violence, said Mrs. Mary Barr. But at the same time we told him that we didn't want the I.R.A. out of our area. We need them.

title: OUSTED REPORTER LOSES HIS APPEAL
description: CLEVELAND, May 27The right of The Plain Dealer to dismiss one of its reporters for publishing an article highly critical of the newspaper was upheld this week by an arbitrator.

title: Coins
description: JEAN ANTOINE HOUDON's portrait of George Washington has been selected by the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission for the face bid:: design of the first official national medal to be issued in honor of the 200th anniversary of this country's birthday. The bronze commemorative will be part of a philatelicnumismatic combination, which is expected to be ready for sale to collectors about July 4.

title: H. S. Lipson Fiance Of Miss Oberman
description: MONSEY, N.Y., May 27Mr. and Mrs. Nathan M. Oberman of Monsey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Oberman, to Henry S. Lipson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Lipson of Long Island City, Queens.

title: Foe's New Missile Disrupts Air Tactics in South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27A recently introduced Sovietbuilt missile that can be easily fired from the shoulder of a single soldier has made American pilots flying in South Vietnam apprehensive and has, hampered what is perhaps the most crucial of their air operations herethe observation missions by slowmoving aircraft that spot enemy targets and call in bombing strikes by attack planes.

title: LEADING GOLFERS TEE OFF TUESDAY
description: Four of the greatest names in golfing will be on the same card Tuesday at Canterbury Golf Club in Cleveland for the 1972 National Golf Day challenge round.

title: the traveler's world
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.This is a riverfront town and Louisville, unlike New York which seems to forget that its great harbor and rivers made it what it is, is proud to a man of its Muddy and beautiful Ohio River. Nonriver people and residents of cities like those in upstate New York along the Mohawk; where the river now is something to be bridged on the way to someplace else, often do not realize how much a river can mean to a city, how much it molds and directs a city's economic, social and recreational life.

title: Robber Kills a G.I. Working Part Time In Gasoline Station
description: EATONTOWN, N.J., May 27 (UPI) A 24yearold gas station attendant was shot and killed and his alleged assailant critically wounded by gunfire today when the police, answering a silent alarm, arrived at the scene of an attempted holdup on Route 36 in Eatontown.

title: LA SALLE VICTOR IN C.H.S.A,A. MEET
description: Mike Brown, a consistently top performer, led La Salle Academy to its third straight team title yesterday in the New York section of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships.

title: ORDER TO POLICE RESCINDED HERE
description: New York precinct captains have been instructed to remove and destroy a police department order requiring them to write periodic reports listing serious problems in their commands and the steps they have taken to correct them.

title: Yesterday Was for Traveling, Strolling, Eating and Relaxing
description: By noon yesterday, the crush of cars carrying New Yorkers to mountains and shores for the Memorial Day weekend was over, and the pace of life in the city had begun to wind down to slow springtime surrealism.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Ridiculing television commercials is one of the great indoor sports of today. These commercials are criticized and scoffed atin clubs, in bars, around bridge tablesas being corny, fatuous, inane, even nauseating. And when these uncharitable words about today's television commercials are bandied about, hardly anyone dissents.

title: MISS KENT DANCES EXOTIC BUGAKU
description: George Balanchine's Bugaku is an exotic, mysterious and sensuously erotic ballet. Friday evening at the State Theater, Allegra Kent returned dazzlingly to the work after too long an absence and gave one of those special performances that brought all of the elements into harmony.

title: Couple Hurt in Plane Crash
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., May 27 (AP)An Ohio couple were injured today when their light airplane overshot a runway at Ramapo General Airport while landing and crashed into a dirt mound, the Clarkstown police reported. Admitted to Ramapo General Hospital and treated for cuts and shock were Myron and Shirley Goldman, each 37 years old, of Kettering.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Susan Mixter Plans to Wed
description: CINCINNATI, May 27Mr. and Mrs. James Murchie Eaton Mixter of Cincinnati and Little Boars Head, N. H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Cutler Milder, to Peter Sherrill Blanchard. He is the son of the Right Rev. Roger W. Blanchard, executive vice president of the executive council of the Episcopal Church, and former Bishop of the Diocese of Southern Ohio, and Mrs. Blanchard of New York and Round Pond, Me.

title: Miss Carlotta Heinsohn Married
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 27 Miss Carlotta Lorraine Heinsohn and Jack Perry Crisp Jr., were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by Canon Stanley Francis Hemsley, assisted by the Rev. Cecil Swackhammer of the First Methodist Church here.

title: Officials Voice Concern at Rash of School Bombings
description: DENVER, May 27On Feb. 1, a small bomb exploded in the basement of Central High School in Jackson, Miss.

title: MRS. DEMAILLE WINS IN FENCING
description: Mrs. Marie Chantal Demaille, the world foils champion from Grenoble, France, staved off a challenge from Ruth White, the former United States champion, last night at the New York Athletic Club to capture top honors in the Martini & Rossi tournament.

title: ORDER IS AMENDED ON ETHNIC CENSUS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday amended his order providing for a census of the city's 400,000 employes to guard against the establishment of quotas on the basis of sex, race or national origin.

title: Silent Beauty,$14.20, Wins in $30,600 Colonial Handicap at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 27 (AP)Leslie Combs 2d's Silent Beauty, ridden by Mike Manganello, defeated 11 rivals today and won the $30,600 Colonial Handicap at Garden State Park.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON Until two years ago, the jury in the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of a criminal trial by an impartial jury was a very special institution, unchanged since was borrowed intact by the first Congress from the English common law.

title: Lutherans No Longer Require Brides to Be Given by Fathers
description: Lutheran fathers are no longer required to give their daughters away in marriage, and Lutheran brides and bridegrooms may now write their own wedding vows.

title: New &Novel
description: Satire is alive and well in Great Britain, where this small gem was first published. The plot thickens in early Aldous Huxley fashion when three Cambridge classmates start a health spa with an 80,000 inheritance bequeathed by an eccentric aunt. A full house of hypochondriacs would seem to guarantee instant success, were it not for a couple of flies in the herbal ointment. One is a disgruntled beneficiary (an osteopath with sinister intentions). The other is a resident naturehealer.

title: Saigon Says It Has Ordered Italian Newsman's Ouster
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27 (Reuters)An Italian freelance journalist, Ennio Iacobucci, has been ordered to leave South Vietnam on charges of illegally hoarding weapons, ammunition and documents, the official press agency said today.

title: Pleasure Castle Is First
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27 (AP)Pleasure Castle caught Gallant Agent in the stretch and went on to post a 2length victory and paid $18 today in the Bashford Manor at Churchill Downs. Game Lad, the second half of the winning entry, came in third.

title: Moscow Notes: Trust and Doubt
description: MOSCOW, May 27There are two vivid images that promise to linger after the Moscow summit meeting, evoking the strange emotions of old suspicions and new confidences that coexisted here this week.

title: Mrs. Gandhi and Bhutto Set Meeting for June 28 in India
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 27 (UPI)President Zulfikar All Bhutto will visit New Delhi June 28 for summit talks with India's Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: Bookstall Salesmen Along Central Park Given Summonses
description: Salesmen at two new bookstalls at the busy southeast corner of Central Park were given summonses by the police yesterday, charging them with unlicensed peddling and pedciting in a restricted area.

title: L.I.R.R. Agrees to Award $15,000 to ExExecutive
description: Arthur T. Van Wart, a former $35,000ayear vice president with the Long Island Rail Road, yesterday reached a settlement with the line in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, where he had sued to recover more than two years pay.

title: W. H. Adams Marries Ellen G. Dale
description: BALTIMORE, May 27Miss Ellen Glendinning Dale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wade Dale Jr., was married here this afternoon to William Healey Adams, son of Thaddeus A. Adams of Charlotte, N. C., and the late Mrs. Adams.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The following article, written by Valdry Giscard d'Estaing, the French Finance Minister, is taken from the preface to Transactions Between East and West by Samuel Pisan The book by Mr. Pisar, an American lawyer based in Paris, has recently been published in France.

title: Wisconsin Urged to End Prisons And Provide Care in Community
description: MADISON. Wis., May 27Wisconsin was urged this week to close its prisons and establish communitybased treatment facilities.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dritish Go to ValueAdded Tax
description: LONDONA revolution in Britain's system of indirect taxation is taking shape in Parliament this spring and it portends profound changes for the country's businssmen.

title: Here the Designers Emphasize High Fashion...
description: The sweater, grandmother's lowly chill chaser, has made it into the loftiest ranks of fashion. Grandmother's knitted cardigan will be tossed over the most fashionable shoulders next fall. Turtlenecks, halters, dolmans, V neck styles and good old classic twin sweater sets will also have their place in the fashion sun. And the labels inside will carry the names of Seventh Avenue's most prestigious designers.

title: Mutual Effort Produces Harlem Housing
description: A combination of mother wits and business acumen was celebrated yesterday in East Harlem as public officials and private investors joined local residents in dedicating a 91unit apartment house that they had worked jointly to construct.

title: Captain Brings a GoldPlater North
description: WRIGHTSVILLE, N. C.This is the season when rich men's yachts, following the migratory birds, move north with the spring.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Mickey Lolich hit the ball to left field, he didn't even bother to watch it in flight. There is a fatalistic strain in all bad hitters, so that they expect fielders to catch any ball they accidentally hit. Although this was the second game of the 1968 World Series, the Detroit lefthander was too busy thinking about St. Louis batsmen than to pay attention to his own humble efforts at the plate. When he swung at a Nelson Briles pitch, he dutifully tucked in his head and lumbered down the line toward first base, an operation so unfamiliar to him that he missed touching the bag.

title: Garner and Lovett Honored
description: Richie Garner (basketball) and John Lovett (track), took the top honors at Manhattan College's 23d annual Block M sports awards dinner.

title: Phil Gets A Beautiful Assignment In Flushing
description: It is the business of editors to know which reporters can turn out hard, investigative, probing, penetrating, incisive news stories. So it was no surprise to me when the editors of this section turned to me with a particularly delicate assignment.

title: News of Dogs
description: There will be an extra 40 winks for New York dog fanciers today and tomorrow. Instead of getting up at the crack of dawn for a long drive to watch their favorite breeds being judged, they can move at a leisurely pace. Today's big show is the Plainfield K. C. event in nearby Metuchen, N. J., and tomorrow's is the Queensboro at Queens Village. Each starts at 9 A.M. The Jersey event, with an entry of 1,895 dogs, is being held on the grounds of St. Joseph's High School on Plainfield Avenue. This is the third year the club has used the site, which is a big improvement over the previous fields at the Raritan Arsenal and the Linden Airport.

title: SAIGON SUFFERS A MAJOR DEFEAT SOUTH OF ANLOC
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 28A South Vietnamese relief force has suffered a major defeat trying to evacuate wounded soldiers from the area just south of the besieged city of Anloc.

title: The Nation
description: It was a kind of danse macabre, carefully choreographed, painstakinglyand painfullyexecuted.

title: BOYS HIGH TRACKMEN WIN BROOKLYN TITLE
description: Boys High posted eight victories, two of them meet records, to capture its 11th straight Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League track title yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randall's Island.

title: JERSEY PRIMARY FACES AN ECLIPSE
description: TRENTON, May 27  It is New Jersey's political misfortune to hold its Presidential primary election on June 6, the same day as California. That is like trying to upstage today's Indianapolis 500 with a midget auto race.

title: Troubled? Phone the Hot Line, Always Open
description: TEANECK  We call it Friends because that's what we're all about. a young volunteer said of the Friends Not Line. Bergen County's oldest telephone counseling service.

title: THOUSANDS ENJOY BENEFIT FESTIVAL
description: Several thousand people filled the plaza at Lincoln Center yesterday for a free benefit festival of dance, drama and music staged to dramatize the financial plight of the New York Public Library.

title: ...But When He's Older Reserve a Padded Hotel Room
description: WE are seated, the four of us (myself, my wife, my 13yearold son John and 10yearold daughter Jenny) before El Greco's Burial of Count Orgaz in a church in Toledo, Spain. Our guide is explaining in considerable detail why the painting is a masterpiece. She points out the triangular composition of the two saints lifting the limp armorclad body of the count, the ethereal quality of the heavenly figures above. She finishes, and as we rise to move on, John comments: Boy, I sure don't see why we had to waste so much time on that.

title: Unlimited Hydroplane Racing to Open Season Friday
description: The fastestand loudestwatercraft afloat start their season next Friday in Miami with the $25,000 Champion Spark Plug unlimited hydroplane regatta.

title: EXBANK PRESIDENT GIVES UP IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, May 27 (Reuters)Daniel D. Moore, former president of the defunct Surety Bank and Trust Company of nearby Wakefield, surrendered to the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today following disclosures of a $7million shortage at the bank.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Page Kelley a Bride
description: HILLSDALE, N. J., May 27 Miss Page Kelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Welbourn Kelley, was married here this afternoon to Robert Edwin Lambregtse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Lambregtse. Both families are of Park Ridge. The Rev. John S. Allen, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Foster, performed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HACKENSACKIf you've never seen clotheslines hung with art, here's your chance. Art teachers in the Bergen County elementary schools have picked more than 2,000 entries for the eighth annual outdoor clothesline exhibit of children's art. The show will be held next Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at. Bloomingdale's Bergen County.

title: The World
description: HANOI  Day after day last week North Vietnamese newspapers and radio ignored the Moscow summit meeting. It was one indication of how peculiar the situation seems in Hanoi.

title: Religion
description: The traditionally conservative Lutherans have liberalized their wedding ceremony. A new service issued for trial use last week by the InterLutheran Commission on Worship makes these changes: The couple can write their own marriage vows; the bride's father no longer will give her away"; the subordination of woman to man is played down"; and the prayer for fertility is eliminated on the ground that we not regard marriage as a matter primarily of child bearing.

title: McDowell Loses 6Run Lead
description: ATLANTA. May 27 (UPI)Ed Goodson's eighthinning homer enabled the San Francisco Giants to post an 119 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight after their pitching ace, Sam McDowell, had lost a sixrun lead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While it may be true, as some commentators have suggested, that the centrist base of the Democratic party has suffered considerable erosion, Senator Hubert Humphrey is still unquestionably the party's strongest and most effective campaigner, and the bestqualified of any of the potential candidates to provide the caliber of national leadership the people of this country need.

title: Canonero II a CoFavorite With Bold Reasoning Here
description: Canonero II and Bold Reasoning, a pair of 4yearold colts staging comebacks after being sidelined with ailments, are cofavorites at 21 in the 79th Metropolitan Handicap today at Belmont Park.

title: Michigan Governor to Speak
description: CLEVELAND, May 28 (UPI) Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan will be. the principal speaker June 11 at the award dinner here of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. The organization will present its national human relations award to Mr. and Mrs. William C. Truehaft of Shaker Heights for their dedication in their public and private lives to the health, welfare and common concerns of all people, regardless of race, nationality or religious belief.

title: Levitt Assails State Transportation Unit
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday sharply criticized some maintenance procedures and equipmentmanagement functions of the State Department of Transportation.

title: Summer Camps Fear SeasonIf It StartsWill Be Slow
description: Are camps in trouble? the director of a coed summer camp in the Berkshires asked rhetorically. We're all in trouble: our schools, our universities, our cities, our institutions. Why should the camps be different?

title: Chance of Trade Accord Still Dim, U.S. Aides Say
description: MOSCOW, May 28United States officials said today that the chances for specific agreements on new trading arrangements between the Soviet Union and the United States remained dim.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Television Address to the Soviet People From the Great Kremlin Palace
description: Dobry vecher [Good evening]. deeply appreciate this opportunity your government has given me to speak directly with the people of the Soviet Union to bring you a message of friendship from all the people of the United States and to share with you some of my thoughts about the relations between our two countries and about the way to peace and progress in the world.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police of the 19th Precinct agreed yesterday suspend, at least until after the holiday weekend, issuing summonses to the operators of two bookstalls on Fifth Avenue at 60th Street. On Saturday several of the booksellers, who began displaying their tomes in specially constructed stands near Central Park last week, received summonses for peddling without a license.

title: ShortWave Frequencies Disrupted by Solar Flare
description: BOULDER, Colo., May 28 (UPI)A solar flare, termed quite severe, disrupted shortwave frequencies over the entire sunlit hemisphere today.

title: The U.N. Is the Only Game in Town
description: The facade is finally off. For 25 years successive Presidents have convinced the American people, supporters and opponents alike, that the United States was steadfast in its support of the United Nations. For their own reasons both supporters and opponents wanted to believe it and, after all, didn't every President and Secretary of State solemnly proclaim that support? The opponents believed it for they were desperate to find some outside agency to blame for American difficulties abroad and many of the supporters believed it because they were deeply committed to the ideal of a universal international organization dedicated to world peace.

title: MILO W. PECK
description: WINDSOR, Conn., May 28 (AP)Milo W. Peck, Mayor of Windsor since 1941, died at his home last night. He was 56 years old.

title: City Ballet Offers Romanticism In Staging Clifford's  Fantasies
description: John Clifford's Fantasies, given at the State Theater Saturday afternoon for the first time this season, is not the kind of ballet you would expect to find at the New York City Ballet.

title: U.S. FUNDS IN BANKS DRAW PATMAN'S FIRE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) More than a third of the Government's tax and loan deposits, on which banks do not pay interest, are concentrated in the 50 largest institutions, Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today.

title: Tanya of Leningrad Died in 1943
description: Tanya Savicheva, a Leningrad schoolgirl, lived in House 13, Second Line, Vasilevsky Island, Leningrad. During and after the winter of 194142, when the city was under siege by the Germans, she recorded the deaths of her relatives in a notebook that is still kept at the Leningrad historical museum.

title: Prospectors Stake Claims In Australia Uranium Rush
description: PERTH, Australia, May 28 (Reuters)A uranium rush is under way In Western Australia as prospectors hurry to stake claims to promising sites.

title: TAXPAYERS GIVEN RIGHT TO APPEAL
description: The taxpayer accompanied the Internal Revenue Service's appellate division conferee into a bare conference room, occupied by a small table and four chairs, on the ninth floor of 90 Church Street.

title: McGovern and Humphrey Clash on War and Relief
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator George McGovern, treating the California primary as if it was the Presidential election itself, repeatedly stung each other in cold anger in their first television confrontation today.

title: Designer Shows His Versatility
description: Small wonder that Bernard Johnson has been called black Cecil Beaton. The designer already has the costume credits for a hit Broadway show, Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death, and in his pocket are a Lincoln Center production and two brand new Melvin Van Peebles projects the play and the movie, Don't Play Us Cheap.

title: Man Termed Legally Dead Is Alive in Hospital on Coast
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 28 (UPI)A man declared legally and clinically dead after a head injury clung to life today.

title: Westinghouse Is Emphasizing Compressors
description: COLUMBUS, OhioThere's a brand new, sparkling clean factory within the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's major appliance factory here.

title: WIDE HEALTH ROLE URGED FOR NURSES
description: CHICAGO, May 28 (AP)A Government committee says that nurses should play a Biggers role in the carp and treatment of patients to provide better health care.

title: Miss Ruggieri Bride of C. A. Gordon 2d
description: Miss Geraldine Patricia Ruggieri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ruggieri of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Alexander Gordon 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Gordon, also of Fresh Meadows.

title: PATROLMAN KNIFED; SHOT SUSPECT HELD
description: A man who allegedly struck a patrolman with a golf club and cut him with a knife outside a Harlem apartment house early yesterday was arrested later at Harlem Hospital, where he had gone for treatment of bullet wounds.

title: Ferrari Scores Again
description: ADENAU, Germany, May 28 (AP)Ronnie Peterson of Sweden and Tim Schenken of Australia, driving a Ferrari, won the 1,000 kilometer race (621 miles) at the Nuerburgring toI day. The victory was the eighth in eight races of the world manufacturer's championship for Ferrari.

title: Brookville Poloists Down Jericho in Opener, 8 to 3
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., May 28Ted Shapiro scored four goals and John Greenleaf added three as Brookville defeated Jericho, 83, today in the opening polo match of the season at Bethpage State Park.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Midway and Haiphong
description: WASHINGTONIn the great turningpoint Battle of Midway that began just thirty years ago this week, the United States Navy fielded but three lonely carriers in its task force facing Japan's main fleet. The fliers who sank Tokyo's Imperial dreams thousand miles from Hawaii, and the American people, knew that the declared aim of the highriding enemy was the conquest of United States territory.

title: Skyscraper Alters Face of Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, May 28  On the canopied, secondfloor veranda of the Hong Kong Club, which overlooks a small plot of grass and a cenotaph commemorating The Glorious Dead of two world wars, elderly members sip pink gins and glare with obvious distaste at the striking new building that has already obstructed their view of the harbor and will soon tower 50 stories above them.

title: NASSAU TO CHECK JOB PERFORMANCE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 28 Nassau County plans to begin a comprehensive system of analyzing the productivity of all its employes, in cooperation with the Civil Service Employes Association, in a project that Federal officials say could be a prototype for government units across the nation.

title: Florida Storm Weakens
description: MIAMI, May 28 (UPI)A subtropical cyclone moved across south Georgia and through the Florida panhandle to the Gulf of Mexico at Apalachicola today, its winds weakened to less than 20 miles an hour. Its highest winds over land were reported as 58 miles an hour at Brunswick, Ga., as the storm swept inland last night. No serious damage was reported from the wind and rain.

title: GRANT LOSES 2D ON INDY PENALTY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 Yesterday's Indianapolis 500 evolved today into the TwentyFour Hours of Indianapolis with a series of three protests, possible appeal and endless secondguessing.

title: Father Kills Son in Accident
description: EUREKA, Utah, May 28 (UPI) You shot me in the finger, Dad, the boy said, and then he died. Sheriff Edgar Mills of Millard County said Eugene Lynch of Sandy had shot a rabbit on a family outing at Topaz Mountain yesterday and was reloading his 22caliber pistol when it fired accidentally. The bullet apparently struck the finger of his 8yearold son, Robert, and then went into his chest.

title: Albatross Ties Track Mark In Pacing at Brandywine
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 28 Albatross continued his winning ways today at Brandywine Raceway, scoring a 7i/2length victory in the $25,000 Adios Butler invitation pace. The 4yearold son of Meadow SkipperVoodoo Hanover, who is owned by the Amicable Stable of Hanover, Pa., paced the mile in 1:563/5, equaling the mark for the fiveeighthmile course posted last year by Steady Star.

title: College Recruits Through Ecology
description: Accompanying the acceptance letter that Pitzer College in Claremont, Calif., sent to each successful applicant this year in a long, red mailing tube was a sprightly decorated poster depicting the cover of a 19thcentury seed catalogue. On the back of the poster, the college told of its concern for the environment.

title: Raben's Sloop Captures Block Island Race
Critics Forcing Changes in Master Plan
description: A deluge of community criticism of the city's proposed Master Plan will bring major, changes in some neighborl.o I projects, according to Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the City Planning Commission.

title: Forest Fire Burns 120 Acres
description: WEST MILAN, N.H. May 28 (AP)A forest fire that burned through most of the night destroyed 120 acres of heavy timber in this northeast New Hampshire town, not far from the White Mountain National Forest.

title: Gentry, Taylor Bear Brunt of 16Hit Spree
description: ST. LOUIS, May 28The St. Louis Cardinals overpowered the New York Mets, 83, today and rattled 16 hits off what may prove to be Manager Yogi Berra's Achilles heelhis pitching staff.

title: Miscues Help Detroit Notch 3d Straight
description: Carrying their twin millstones of poor fielding and tweak hitting, the New York Yankees sank into fifth place in the American League's Eastern Division yesterday by losing to the Detroit Tigers, 54.

title: Archbishop Sheen Honored
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 28 (AP)The 1971 Knights of lumbus's Catholic Man of Action award was presented today to the Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen at the National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa near here. Accepting the award, Archbishop Sheen told 6,000 persons attending the ceremonies that permissiveness and concessions had undermined both church and country.

title: Walsh Rides Gem's Date To Laurels in a Hackoff
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., May 28 James Walsh piloted his 6yearold chestnut gelding, Gem's Date, to the regular working hunter championship with 8 points today at the Helping Hand horse show. He took the title after a hackoff with Old Mill Farm's First N Ten, ridden by Ann Yohai, who also finished with 8.

title: A Wife Whose Job Is The Care and Feeding Of a Touring Athlete
description: LOS ANGELES  Mary Laver is the wife of a tennis millionaire, but she still does his laundryat least when he is on the pro circuit where winning a match sometimes can mean as much as $50,000 and losing can add up to $20,000, which happened a couple of weeks ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The article by the Rev. Battista Mondin in the Vatican's L'Osservatore Della Dominica, stating that the Roman Catholic Church in our country is near collapse [news story May 11], deserves a replyand not much more.

title: Goldwater Has Operation
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater. Republican of Arizona, is recovering in Bethesda Naval Hospital after a gall bladder operation on Friday, his office announced today.

title: Southeast Banking Corp. Seeks a Florida Concern
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation said over the weekend that it is seeking to acquire the outstanding stock of the American National Bank and Trust Company of South Pasadena, Fla., whose resources total $43.4million.

title: An Ecumenical Setback
description: Twelve years ago the Rev. Eugene Carson Blake, then the chief executive of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., preached a historic sermon in the Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco proposing the merger of four major Protestant denominations. His words led to the formation of the Consultation on Church Union, which has since grown to nine churches with a total of 25 million members.

title: Two Slain Patrolmen Honored at Ceremony
description: About 300 persons attended a tree dedication ceremony yesterday honoring two patrolmen who were shot and killed in Harlem year ago.

title: Bremer, in Red, White and Blue, Was Conspicuous at Many Rallies
description: LAUREL, Md., May 28Arthur Herman Bremer, the Milwaukee resident accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, made no effort to be inconspicuous during the 10 weeks in which he frequented political rallies last winter and this spring.

title: Prof. John L. Snell, Author of Histories Of Diplomacy, Dies
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 28 Prof. John L. Snell, author of several studies in the diploImacy of the World War II period and holder since 1968 of a distinguished professorship in history at the University of North Carolina, died yesterday in North Carolina Memorial Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: Denise Field Bride in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio May 28 Miss Denise Audrey Field and William Allen Baker 3d, graduates of the theater department at Ohio State University, were married here this afternoon. Col. Kalman Levitan, Chaplains Corps, U.S.A.F., performed the Jewish ceremony at the Columbus Club.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It's no longer a does she or doesn't she question about cosmetic surgery, but rather How soon will she? Now that wellknown figures in the theater, business or politics are happily telling the world about their new uplifted faces or hair transplants, the secrecy that cloaked surgical rejuvenation has been blown wide open.

title: Theologian Preaches a Thing Exchange at Columbia
description: Nobody noticed when Harvey Cox took off his shoes to exchange socks with a young man in the congregation Saturday night at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

title: For Many Russians, Nixon's TV Address Hit Home
description: MOSCOW, May 28  The initial reaction of a few ordinary Russians to President Nixon's televised address tonight was favorable, but some asked why he had not mentioned Vietnam in view of his emphasis on moves toward peace.

title: Tokyo Asks Tougher Pollution Curbs
description: TOKYO, May 28  The Japanese Government's new environment agency has declared that mere policies aimed at preventing pollution are no longer enough.

title: Aldo Montano Captures Final in Saber Here
description: Mario Aldo Montano, a 25yearold economics major at the University of Pisa captured saber honors at the New York Athletic Club last night as the annual threeday Martini & Rossi international fencing tournament ended.

title: Simon Comedy, Sunshine Boys, Slated for a December Opening
description: Neil Simon's next Broadway work will be The Sunshine Boys, which Saint Subber will open at the Broadhurst Theater Dec. 20.

title: Most Markets Closed
description: Domestic and British markets will be closed today. United States markets are closing for Memorial Day and British markets for a bank holiday. Canadian markets will be open.

title: Inflation Nibbles at Argentines'
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 28Buy your needs before the hippopotamus takes them away. So goes the slogan of Minimax, Argentina's biggest supermarket chain.

title: Suspect in 25 Slayings on Coast Becomes Chicano Rights Cause
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 28 (AP)One year after his arrest, Juan V. Corona, accused of murdering 25 men and burying them in orchards, is becoming a civil rights symbol to MexicanAmericans who say he has been persecuted because of his nationality.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 25How strange comments that filter into this isolated place from the outside world often sound. This week the Voice of America told us that Vice President Agnew had declared the North Vietnamese Army demoralized. Then Maj. Gen. Alexander Haig Jr., Henry Kissinger's deputy, told correspondents that the political structure was under serious strain in Hanoi and prostitution was growing.

title: Books of The Times
description: One begins Arnold Beichman's book hopefully. To characterize as Big Lies the claims from the left that America is Fascist, Genocidal, Guilty, Insane and Materialistic, that our political system is a Fraud, the Bomber Left a Moral Force, and the American worker a honky, and that America needs a violent revolution, probably lending undue dignity to such rhetoric; but such extreme claims ought to be examined critically. And as Tom Wolfe points out in the book review (of JeanFrancois Revel's Without Marx or Jesus) that somehow ended up as a foreword to Belchman's volume: the propounders of these claims do occasionally make a hash of the mother tongue. As Mr. Wolfe notes, there did seem a certain comic lack of quantifiable specifics in Philip Slater's remark, in The Pursuit of Loneliness, that more and more people feel with a larger and larger portion of themselves that the destruction of mankind as a failed species might be a sound idea. And it was downright funny when Paul Jacobs wrote in a Partisan Review symposium on What's Happening in America? that Madness surrounds us on all sides (just try to picture that). It would be tonic to have Mr. Beichman prick such balloons.

title: REV. JOHN M'GINN OF PAULIST ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 The Rev. John T. McGinn; a teacher of mission methods since 1943 at St. Paul's College here, the seminary of the Paulist order of the Roman Catholic Church, died today in Sibley Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Press Awards Are Presented To Stanton and Sulzberger
description: The 1972 Freedom of the Press awards of the New York Press Photographers Association were presented last night to Dr. Frank Stanton, vice chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Raising faros and curtailing service is hardly a sound way for Transport of New Jersey to get its riders back after they had 75 days to discover that T.N.J. service wasn't that wonderful. The only way public transport can survive in New Jersey is through subsidized fares, vastly restructured routes and rates, higherquality and more dependable service and coordinated busrail service and fares.

title: Australian Cricketers Win
description: The Australian Old Collegians defeated the Metropolitan AllStars by four wickets yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. The score was Metropolitan 86, Old Collegians 87 for 6.

title: A Day Like Any Other Day in Junk City
description: The girl in my building is running scared.

title: Londonderry Is Divided
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, May 28 (Reuters)The largely Catholic population of Londonderry braved driving wind and rain today to demonstrate for peacebut in different ways.

title: Italy to Push Stalled Bill To Save Sinking Venice
description: ROME, May 28The Government will ask the newly elected parliament for speedy passage of a longpending bill to permit the start of major work to prevent Venice from sinking further into its lagoon, officials said here today.

title: POPE CALLS FOR END OF BURUNDI VIOLENCE
description: ROME, May 28Pope Paul VI said today that the small East African nation of Burundi was in the throes of pitiless and ferocious madness, and he appealed to communal groups there to halt bloodshed.

title: Matson Seeks to Regain His ShotPut Form of '68
description: There was a time when Randy Matson was a trade name for the shotput, when he had the 25 longest marks of all time, when losing his eventnot winning itmade news.

title: Reform Miners Select Candidate to Run Against Boyle
description: WHEELING, W. Va., May 28 A convention of rankandfile reformers within the United Mine Workers of America nominated today its candidate for president of the union in a courtordered election.

title: Black Panelists Link Arts to Politics
description: CHICAGO, May 28A gathering of black artists and scholars agreed today to explore new ways to offer greater contributions and leadership to the black liberation movement.

title: Day Laborers in City Are Exploited, Study Says
description: New York City's 3,000 to 4,000 lowskilled day laborers are being exploited in the same ways that rural migrant workers are, according to a study released by the City Economic Development Administration.

title: Billy Graham Is Visitor
description: BELFAST, May 28 (UPI)The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the American evangelist, walked in the bomb rubble of Short Strand today and told the Roman Catholic residents their prayers for peace would be heard.

title: 6 Killed by Bomb in Belfast Include 3 I.R.A. Members
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May, 28  Six people were killed early today in a big bomb explosion in Short Strand, a Roman Catholic section of Belfast.

title: G. F. Henschel Jr. Weds Miss Krone
description: CHICAGO, May 28Miss Karyn Sue Krone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Krone of Lincolnwood and North Miami, Fla., was married here this morning to George Frederick Henschel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henschel of Mount Kisco, N. Y, Cantor Dale Lind performed the ceremony at the Ambassador West.

title: 4 Years of Sea Drilling Yields Vast Lore
description: After four years of drilling into the ocean floor, the Glomar Challenger, an ungainly vessel with a giant drilling derrick amidships, has produced a vast treasure of important new information on the history of the earth.

title: Ballet: In Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 28The Royal Danish Ballet Festival, which is held every Maythe official ending of the seasonis traditionally both a retrospective of the company's immediate past and a statement of the company's timeless present.

title: Bunny, Cocker Spaniel, Gains Her 15th Best at Plainfield Show
'72 Sunday Funday Is Banjos and Brahms
description: Stephanie Sills, walkietalkie in hand, stood in the middle of Astoria Boulevard, in Queens, yesterday afternoon and surveyed her fiveblocklong stage: I don't know it you can ever bring of a street event perfectly smoothly, she said. You can't rehearse.

title: Preacher Criticizes Nixon For Visiting Soviet Church
description: COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., May 28 (UPI)The radio preacher Carl McIntire criticized President Nixon today for attending a Baptist church in Moscow.

title: Treasures of the Czars Inspected by Mrs. Nixon
description: MOSCOW, May 28 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon walked through the grand halls of the Kremlin today and inspected the Armory, containing treasures of the Czars, and said, I still like our little White House.

title: NIXON TALKSONTV TO SOVIET PEOPLE AND HAILS ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, May 28  President Nixon told the Soviet people in a televised speech today that the memory of the wartime alliance between the United States and the Soviet Union can serve as inspiration for renewal of cooperation in the nineteenseventies.

title: Beame Reports a $5Million Surprise Yield in City Investments
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie reported yesterday an increase of $5million in revenues available for the city budget and said the money should reduce a projected controversial increase in realestate taxes from $65million to $60million.

title: Foe Shells Cambodian Town
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 28 (UPI)  The Cambodian command said that Communist forces fired 32 shells from captured Americanmade 105mm. howitzers into the beleaguered provincial capital of Svayrieng today, killing woman and three child:en among the town's refugeeswollen population.

title: SAIGON IS STALLED IN DRIVES TO OPEN ROADS TO 2 TOWNS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 29The war continued to produce casualties on both sides yesterday, but there was little change in the overall situation, with many opposing units dug into strong positions on South Vietnam's three most active fronts.

title: ExDean in Africa Calls Apartheid Evil In St. John's Sermon
description: The Very Rev. Gonville Aubie ffrenchBeytagh, former Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, told worshipers at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday that racial separation was evil, blasphemous and devilish.

title: A Tribute by Nixon
description: MOSCOW, May 28 (UPI) President Nixon today called the Duke of Windsor a man of noble spirit and high ideals who was respected by millions of Americans.

title: Personal Finance
description: School is about over now, and much to the emotional and financial relief of many parents, some teenagers and older students will be working at summer jobs.

title: 3 OF 4 ARE SEIZED IN BRONX ROBBERIES
description: Four men, including a Penn Central railroad policeman, allegedly posed as city policemen and robbed at least three persons of more than $700 before exchanging shots with policemen in the South Bronx on Saturday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Rea Irvin, Cartoonist for New Yorker, Dies at 90
description: Rea Irvin, the creator of the first cover for The New Yorker and hundreds of others in the magazine's early years, died yesterday afternoon at Ingeborg Clinic in Fredericksted, the Virgin Islands. He was 90 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: Samuel Jackson Snead went to a birthday party over the weekendhis own. The sweetest swinger golf has known turned 60 on Saturday. On Friday he had shot 63 at Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. That gave him an average score of 64 for his last seven rounds. To be sure, all were played at Greenbrier, whose fairways have felt his spikes for more than 35 years. This was ready his home course in 1937, his rookie year on the tournament beat, when he first met Fred Corcoran, then tournament manager of the Professional Golfers Association, in California. The Oakland open was on and Corcoran, in swivet of promotional zeal, had promised to deliver some pros to a seven o'clock breakfast in the Lake Merritt Club, but when he shaped up in the lobby of the Leamington Hotel at 6:30 the only animal life in sight was a gangling hillbilly who thought everybody had to get the milking done by that time.

title: Car With a GasTurbine Engine Breaks Down 8 Times in Tests
description: A $250,000 experimental automobile with a gasturbine engine has broken down eight times since February while being tested at a municipal facility in Brooklyn for airpollution emissions.

title: RATE CONSENSUS ERODES FURTHER
description: The consensus forecast of interest rates is continuing to erode. As the economy gathers momentum, there is still no sign that the ed on rates Is going to be blown off anytime soon.

title: Piecemeal Into Disaster
description: The authorized sale of New York University's Bronx campus and the subsequent merger of its engineering school with Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute have been met with predictable indignation on the University Heights campus. There is room for legitimate debate on whether it would not have been better to move the Brooklyn engineering school to the Bronx, where the technical facilities are considered superior. Whatever the merits of either solution, however, those protesting the present plan are clearly right in denouncing its origin. The measure, which Governor Rockefeller signed into law yesterday, was the handiwork, not of academic experts but of Brooklyn's more powerful political voice the Legislature.

title: U.S. Auto Makers Begin To Stem the Import Tide
description: DETROIT, May 28  The counterattack from Detroit and Washington against foreignmade cars is starting to succeed.

title: Agnes Igwe Is Bride Of Emmanuel Oko Isu
description: Emmanuel Oko Isu and Agnes Colette Nneka Igwe, both children of Nigerian tribal chiefs, were married yesterday afternoon at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church at 1634 Manhattan Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Smith and Graebner Gain in Paris Tennis
description: PARIS, May 28 (AP)Stan Smith and Clark Graebner powered their way into the round of 16 in the French open tennis tournament today. Smith, of Sea Pines, S. C., who didn't put out any more effort than necessary, in defeating Bernard Mignot of Belgium, 63, 75, 79, 63.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For the first time in its 52year history, the board of directors of the American Friends Service Committee called for a Quaker witness against the Indochina war in front of the White Housethree years ago.

title: Second Line Put on Ship Hit by Blast Off Virginia
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., May 28 (UPI)An oceangoing tugboat placed a second towline aboard the Zim Tokyo today and headed the explosionshattered cargo vessel to port, the Coast Guard said.

title: In Dahomey, Voodoo Practice Is Still a Part of Life
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, May II From the inner room, a drum beats imperiously calling devotees to worship the gods, known as voodoo. And they come, men of different ages and classes, but mostly women and children, for whom the voodoo rite is an integral part of daily life.

title: MEXICO CITY ACTS ON POLICE GRAFT
description: MEXICO CITY, May 28The chief of Mexico City's police force has announced that he intends to end departmental corruption and has started his campaign with the arrest of 12 motorcycle patrolmen and the dismissal of two commanders.

title: Nixons Give a Chess Set and Clocks
description: MOSCOW, May 28 (UPI)President and Mrs. Nixon have given a porcelain chess set to the people of the Soviet Union and specially designed clocks to its leaders.

title: Financing Air Safety
description: The House Appropriations Committee has earmarked funds to buy 800 electronic weapons detectors to help prevent airline hijackings and sabotage. That's good news for the airlines and their passengers, but it threatens to Impose a questionable burden on taxpayers.

title: First Graduation Is Held By Eisenhower College
description: SENECA FALLS, N. Y., May 28 Wearing the new red, white and blue academic robe of Eisenhower College, Mrs. Dwight David Eisenhower sat on the platform beside her son and grandson today at the first commencement of the college officially designated as a living memorial to the 34th President.

title: CAROLINA POLICE ASK AID IN RACIAL UNREST
description: CONCORD, N. C., May 28 (UPI)The police called for help from neighboring towns and the Highway Patrol tonight to put down a second night of racial violence in this textile town.

title: Park Cyclists Make Birders an Endangered Species
