description: I grew up in the forties and fifties in south Georgia where my father was a sharecropper, as were most of my numerous kinfolk scattered around the adjacent counties. Several of these relatives had runins with the law. One rustled cattle when work was scarce, a few made moonshine or hauled it around the county in the trunks of their cars, another was whispered to have kilt a nigger, and one uncle went to the pen for an offense which, if I ever knew, I have now forgotten.

title: Arab Group Claims Credit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, May 31 (UPI)The Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said today that it was responsible for the attack in Tel Aviv.

title: Virginia Assures Delaware On Dumping of Sewage
description: RICHMOND, May 30 (AP)Gov. Linwood Holton of Virginia had interceded to block the dumping of more than 700,000 gallons of partially treated sewage from Virginia off the Delaware coast.

title: Lockwood Wins by 31Yields Single in 6th
description: MILWAUKEE, May 30Before managing his first majorleague game tonight, Del Crandall stood in the Milwaukee Brewer's clubhouse and longingly recalled the days of 1957 and 1958 when another Milwaukee team, the Braves, reigned as National League champions.

title: Letters to the Editor;... and Waging Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: FASHION TALK
description: The prevailing look on Seventh Avenue is casual, sensible, safe, but that hasn't hampered designers. The existence of an accepted framework of fashion for fall has inspired some of the most pleasing clothes in years.

title: CHINA GRANTS SYRIA A $40MILLION LOAN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 China has agreed to make a $40million loan to Syria, Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam announced on his return to Damascus today from a 10day visit to China, reports from Damascus said. Mr. Khaddam said the main part of the loan would be used to building two yarn factories in northern Syria and in expanding a textile plant the Chinese have established in the central town of Horns.

title: Droll Role Defeats EvenMoney Choice In $118,280 Race
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) Droll Role, owned by John M. Schiff of New York, led virtually all the way today to win the $118,280 Hawthorne Gold Cup before a closingday crowd of 11,101 at Hawthorne.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Priest Hired as City Aide Ordered Back to Boston
description: A 30yearold Boston priest who started work at City Hall as an urban fellow in Septemher, 1970, and who was named assistant city administrator May, 5, has been told by his archdiocese he is working without authorization of the church and lie should return to Boston for reassignment.

title: Betting Runs 2d for Belmont's Blue Jean Set
description: They do their handicapping on the graSs behind the Belmont Park stands, too relaxed in their blue jeans and chinos and bellbottoms to worry about drycleaning billow

title: NATO Meeting Hears Rogers Report on Moscow Talks
description: BONN, May 30Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States had informed the Soviet Union that it expected preparatory talks on a conference on security and coopperation in Europe to lead to a full conference in 1973.

title: 3 Are Charged With Passing Bogus Traveler's Checks
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested three West Side residents yesterday on charges they had passed counterfeit American Express traveler's checks, according to John F. Malone, assistant director of the F. B. I. in charge of the New York office.

title: DR. HELGA MAE ERDMAN
description: Dr. Helga Mae Erdman, a surgeon here, died of lung cancer Sunday in Columbus Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 640 West 153d Street with her mother, Mrs. Addison Erdman, widow of an authority on hospital architecture.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MUNICH, May 30 (UPI)Clifford Buck, chairman of the United States Olympic Committee, arrived today for talks with the Olympic Organizing Committee. The Games begin Aug. 26.

title: Bhutto Is Said to Have Vetoed Early Talks With Mrs. Gandhi
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 30  Qualified Government sources here say that President Zulfikar All Bhutto vetoed, tentative plans to meet with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India in New Delhi early in June instead of late in the month as now planned. This was a maneuver designed to show that Pakistan was under no pressure to rush into the talks, they said.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: FLORENCE, Italy, May 30 (UPI)The world's major commercial airlines announced new fare policy today to meet growing competition from charter operators.

title: 25 DIE AT ISRAELI AIRPORT AS 3 GUNMEN FROM PLANE FIRE ON 250 IN A TERMINAL
description: TEL AVIV. Wednesday. May 31Three gunmen armed with automatic rifles and hand grenades attacked a crowd of 250 to 300 people last night at Lod International Airport outside Tel Aviv. Twentyfive persons were killed and 72 were wounded.

title: Kennedy Library Notes Birthday of President
description: BOSTON, May 30 (AP) The John F. Kennedy Library is marking what would have been the 55th birthday of President Kennedy with an exhibit of 46 photographs and 28 mementoes from the collection that it has in storage.

title: STATE HIM VOTE IN PRIMARY IS CUT
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Supreme Court refused today to stay a lower court's decision barring 500.000 or more 18to20yearold New York residents from voting in the state's primary election Jane 20.

title: RAPIDAMERICAN SETS A MERGER
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation, which has had a complicated financial structure with its 75 per centowned Glen Alden Corporation, will simplify their combined operation through a merger. The proposal announced last night by Meshulam Riklis, chairman of RapidAmerican, could involve in excess of $120mi1lion. Under the proposed terms, public common shareholders of Glen Alden would receive for each share 0.35 of share of RapidAmerican common plus a warrant to purchase one share of RapidAmerican common stock.

title: Plans for Spending On Plants Widened By Manufacturers
description: Capital appropriations are surging ahead at a substantial rate in industry plans to improve facilities and modernize equipment, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: RUDOLPH DREIKURS, ADLER'S ASSOCIATE
description: CHICAGO, May 30Dr. Rudolph Dreikurs, emeritus professor of psychiatry at the Chicago MediCal School and director of the Alfred Adler Institute, died Thursday at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Absolute Ruler of North Korea Kim II Sung
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 26  Portraits usually show him as dour and unsmiling, but Premier Kim II Sung is an extroverted, even charismatic, man.

title: MRS. THOMAS CORCORAN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 30Mrs. Kay McCreave Corcoran, wife of Thomas B. Corcoran, a retired New York City detective, died last night at New Rochelle Hospital after a heart attack. She was 60 years old and lived at 157 Liberty Avenue.

title: 23 Are Seized at Lincoln Hospital at Revolutionary Film Show
description: Twentythree supporters of radical third world group at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx were arrested yesterday after authorities called in the police to the hospital chapel to break up the showing of a film on an African liberation movement.

title: COTTON FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Taking note of the continued favorable outlook for the 1972 cotton crop, traders sent cotton futures prices down $1.20 to $4.55 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Astor Theater on Broadway Goes Dark After 49 Years
description: The Astor Theater at Broadway and 45th Street, which has been showing movies since 1913, closed last night after the final performance of Hennie Caulder.

title: Candidate for State Senate Guilty of Resisting Arrest
description: A candidate for the State Senate was convicted today on charges of resisting arrest and harassment. He is Simon Levine, 33 years old, of 13529 Sutter Avenue, South Ozone Park;, Queens, who was found guilty of the misdemeanors after a trial before State Supreme Court Justice Neil Bot tigiieri in the Bronx.

title: Siegel at 59: Director, Rebel, Star
description: HOLLYWOOD  The accent on youth, coupled here with the emergence of the  director as star, has slowed down the careers of most middleaged filmmakers who have gray hair instead of long hair and wear hornrimmed spectacles instead of tinted eyeshades. But the career of Don Siegel, age 59, contradicts just about every rule in the Hollywood book.

title: Oil Exporting Countries Accuse Western Concern
description: VIENNA, May 30 (Reuters)The 11nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries charged today that the Westerncontrolled Iraq Petroleum Company had cut its oil output to punish the Baghdad Government.

title: Italians Begin Prolonged Ritual Of Picking Premier and Cabinet
description: ROME, May 30President Giovanni Leone began ceremonial talks today about designating a new premier as a move; toward forming a new Cabinet.

title: LUCIEN BERNHARD
description: Lucien Bernhard, a graphic artist and former judge of the Ayer Cup competition for newspaper typography, died Monday at his home, 120 East 86th Street. He was 89 years old.

title: Let George Do It?
description: WASHINGTON, May 30It is not easy for a political party to make every mistake in the book during single election, but the Democrats may do it yet. They are in a suicidal mood: broke, divided and now getting a little nasty, with Hubert Humphrey cutting up his old friend George McGovern for putting on the radical mantle Hubert has worn all his political life.

title: Baron Will Do Lenny
description: Sandy Baron, the theater and television actor and comedian, will take over the title role in Lenny on June 12 when Cliff German, its Tony Awardwinner, leaves the show to make film. The show, which is in its second year at the Brooks Atkinson theater, returns to Monday evening performances with Mr. Baron's appearance as the late Lenny Bruce on that date.

title: GUNMAN'S MOTIVE REMAINS MYSTERY
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 31The City of Raleigh, like many Southern cities, is roughly divided into two demographic sectors  the largely black Southside and the whitedominated suburbs of the Northside.

title: MORE RACE FIXES RELATED IN. HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  The chief investigator, for the United States Trotting Association told a House committee today he had found fixed races in four states but had no evidence that organized crime was involved.

title: FINLAY APPOINTED HEAD OF FORDHAM
description: The Rev. James C. Finlay, dean of Fordham University's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, was named the 30th president of the university yes. terday.

title: Bungling Charged Again in Operation Of Indianapolis 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 30What would be the national reactions to racing if, in the start of the Indianapolis 500, an astronaut, the wife of the president of General Motors and one or two others were killed in the pace car? Just such a disaster was narrowly averted last Saturday at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, which still feels the shock of the pacelap accident of 1971. The start and several inci dents during the race illustrate once again the bungling management of the world's greatest auto race. The wonder is how the Indianapolis 500 survives its oldcrony officiating.

title: New French Olympic Unit Not Recognized by I. O. C.
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 30 (AP)The executive board of the International (Olympic Committee refused today to recognize a French national committee set up recently under government auspices as sponsor for the French team at the Summer Games in Munich.

title: The Ultimate Summit
description: While President Nixon was meeting with Soviet leaders in Moscow last week, Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations voiced unusually sharp criticism of the big powers and of the theory that the world's problems can best be settled privately between the nuclear giants. There is... a tendency at present to deride the United Nations as a weak and ineffective political organization which is no match for the guile and superior wealth and wisdom of powerful sovereign states, Mr. Waldheim observed in an Ottawa address.

title: Helping 500,000 People
description: Although the cause, prevention and cure of multiple sclerosis remain unknown, its disabling effect is unhappily familiar. As one of the foremost neurological problems of our time, it is esti mated that M.S. and related diseases afflict 500,000 Americans. The National Multiple Sclerosis Society is the only national voluntary health agency supporting research on this problem nationally and internationally.

title: Schoolboy AllStars To Clash on Court In Foundation Game
description: The third annual allstar basketball game between public high school and Catholicprivate school teams will be played tomorrow night at New York University's uptown gymnasium, University Avenue and 181st Street in the Bronx, beginning at 7:30 o'clock. The game is sponsored by Sports Foundation, Inc.

title: Atoning on Sanctions
description: The Senate will get an opportunity, probably today, tostart pulling the United States back from a violation of international legal obligations and the United Nations Charter. It will vote on Senator Gale McGee's bill to repeal a 1971 provision that had the effect of breaching sanctions twice invoked against Rhodesia's white minority Government by the U.N. Security Council.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Robbed
description: Two men held up the crew of a Long Island Rail Road train, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning as the train was preparing to leave the station in Valley Stream, L. I., on a run to Far, Rockaway, Queens. The robbers boarded the first car of a fourcar train, pulled out guns and took $217 from William Mansfield, the conductor; Henry Misuraca, the brakeman, and John Bauman, the engineer. There were no passengers on the train.

title: Investment Firm Formed
description: Formation of a new firm, Hemboldt & Co., to advise on investment opportunities in African countries was announced yesterday by Niles E. Helmboldt, a former manager at the Bank of Monrovia, a Liberian subsidiary of the First National City Bank of New York. The new firm has been established in Hadlyme, Conn.

title: Jacksons'
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 30The state closed its case against Angela Davis today after a surprise lastminute effort to force testimony from the father of George and Jonathan Jackson.

title: Niekro Limited to Relief
description: CLEVELAND, May 30 (UPI) Joe Niekro, a Detroit pitcher hit on the right knee by a line drive at Yankee Stadium yesterday, said today he would be limited to relief pitching for the Tigers during their series with the Cleveland Indians.

title: STEIN,ROE&FARNHAM IS SUED BY HOLDERS
description: A civil suit filed in Federal Court here yesterday charged Stein, Roe & Farnham, an Investment counseling firm, with maintaining the separate existence of two mutual funds it advises in order to collect higher management fees.

title: F.P.C. Case to Be Heard
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Power Commission must investigate antitrust charges made in connection with a utility company's application to issue bonds.

title: Cadets No Longer Submit to Petty Rules
description: LEXINGTON, Va.  The rats, resplendent In their dress uniforms, sat in rows at the rear of the hall marveling, along with the speaker, how they had endured what seemed an eternity of hell in the ratline of Virginia Military Institute.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS TRANSITAID BILL
description: ALBANY, May 30  Governor Rockefeller signed legislation today establishing a Transit. Construction Fund in New York City with power to issue up to $250million in bonds.The proceeds are to help enable the city to finance its share of building new masstransit facilities without exceeding its debt limit.

title: Fiscal Malaise in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 How did the United States, whose longterm record of Government financial management is really quite good, get itself into the predicament described last week in the nonpartisan major study by the Brookings Institution?

title: F.T.C. Opens Drive to Bar Deceptive Health Food Ads
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission began today a drive against deceptive health food advertising, announcing an agreement barring allegedly false claims for sugar in the raw.

title: Blind Student Admitted
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (UPI)  A 23yearold blind student has been admitted to the Temple University School of Medicine.

title: SOVIET TELESCOPE GETS HUGE MIRROR
description: MOSCOW, May 30The Soviet Union announced today that the world's biggest astronomical observatory, under construction in the Caucasus, had entered its final stage with the installation of its huge telescopic mirror, nearly 20 feet in diameter.

title: Acupuncture Wonderful To a Patient
description: William Rosner, who underwent skingraft surgery here while anesthetized by acupuncture in a procedure announced Monday, said yesterday that the technique was really a wonderful thing and predicted that it's going to be a big thing in this country.

title: New Bid on Paris Talks
description: PARIS, May 30The North Vietnamese and Vietcong demanded today that the Paris peace talks resume on Thursday. It was the third such call since the United States and South Vietnam suspended the talks on May 4.

title: BENEDICT BRUCIA, 60, A HUMAN RIGHTS AIDE
description: Benedict Brucia, chief hearing examiner of the New York State Division of Human Rights, died yesterday in New York Hospital, which he had entered 10 days ago. He was 60 years old and lived at 189 Highland Boulevard, Brooklyn.

title: Knights Join New League
description: HAGERSTOWN, Md., May 30 (AP)The Hartford Knights of the Atlantic Coast Football League have joined the Seaboard Professional Football League, Hugh Wyatt, an official of the eightteam league, announced tonight. The A.C.F.L. will suspend operations for a year.

title: Newspapermen? Bushers.
description: He is the house raconteur and bard in a manly bar about two blocks from his apartment. His friends are newspapermen. Who are all writers, am. I correct? Bushers. And Leo, who could write a poem falling out of an airplane, dazzled these bushers. I mean, they all worked with the same tools, right? Words, words. They thought that any poem that was not Snowbound was an achievement. Some of them even read Yeats. Scribes together, to the end. I once knew a dumbbell, a pleasant enough guy, but a dumbbell, who insisted that was hard to write good news copy. There was no way to convince him otherwise. I understand his point. Personally, think it's hard to play The Blue Danube, since I can not play a kazoo. So these men thought Leo's poems astounding. To captains however, he was no captain, as the old joke has it. He surrendered, dear. I don't want to get into an essay about these newspapermen, but they all came out of a movie. At any moment, you would expect one of them to say, voice harsh and hoarse from years of straight bourbon, I don't know much about anything like that... I'm just a newspaperman. That old soft shoe. Hemingway had given birth to them, Pegler as midwife. Their basic style formed itself around the weird idea that politicians have complicated human motives for their acts. If they once recognized the fact that politicians have complicated political motives instead, they would have been forced to think, which is very difficult for a journalist, or to employ the imagination, which they have spent their professional lives denying. These are the same men who fall down in adulation of Mailer's journalism, because, in their pin heads, they have some idea that Mailer has brought to his journalism the same mind that they bring to theirs. And then, by some magic, writes them all under the table. What they don't recognize is that Mailer is eating apple pie in his journalism. His artist's gifts brought to bear on these facts and figures. Shooting fish in a barrel. But those gifts, marshaled in assault on their true target, the novel, have not yet triumphed. Mailer in his journalism is Koufax, in his day, against the Columbia varsity. The big, classic breaking curve simply overwhelming. Koufax against McCovey or Aaron, however, thought about it.

title: WALLACE FIGHTS WOUND INFECTION
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 30 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wel, lace continued to fight the effects of infection around one of his bullet wounds amid Indications that he would not be moved from Holy Cross Hospital any time soon.

title: James May, Former Mayor Of New London, Dead at 71
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 30 James Austin May, a former Mayor and member of the City Council here, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP)  Trainer Pat Catrone, accused of involvement in a ringer scandal, was denied all privileges at New Jersey tracks yesterday for an indefinite period. Garden State Park stewards said Catrone, unlicensed in New Jersey since 1969, was accused of entering Rule Away at Garden State Park as El Toro Tortuga in May, 1971.

title: Voice From Pyongyang
description: The new fluidity in international relations that has found expression in President Nixon's visits to Moscow and Peking undoubtedly helps explain the decision of Premier Kim II Sung of North Korea to present his new political line to the American people.

title: A Witness for Ecologists Says They Altered Opinion on LILCO
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 30A key witness for an environmental organization that has been fighting the Long Island Lighting Company's plans for a nuclear power plant at Shoreham, L. I., has charged in a confidential letter to the Atomic Energy Commission that his testimony was altered without his permission before it, was submitted to the commission.

title: Ships Said to Go to Chins
description: HONG KONG, May 30 (AP) Shipping sources in Hong Kong reported today that two East German freighters loaded with supplies for North Vietnam had left for the Chinese port of Whampoa. apparently to unload their cargo, including heavy trucks, for possible rail movement to North Vietnam.

title: Substitute Rider Victor At Devon on Lord Sutler
Mayor of Carolina Town Ending All.Night Curfew
description: CONCORD, N. C., May 30 (UPI)Mayor Alfred E. Brown said today that he was lifting the threeday curfew imposed after an outbreak of violence in a black neighborhood in this textile center.

title: High School Disruptions Put at 5,191 Since Fall
description: The city's high schbol principals said yesterday that a partial count had shown that more than 5,000 acts of violence and disruptive behavior had occurred in the high schools since last September.

title: NAUMBURG CONCERT IS LED BY KAPLAN
description: Perfect Memorial Day weather favored the first Naumburg concert of the summer Oil Monday night, presented, as has been customary over the last 67 years, on the Central Park Mall. Abraham Kaplan conducted a pleasantly lightish program, subtle enough to provide musical substance but sufficiently sturdy to withstand the vagaries of amplification and New York's openair disturbances.

title: Georgia Club Picks Player
description: MACON, Ga., May 30 (AP) Gary Player will be the touring golf pro at River North Country Club. Robert J. Adams, the developer of River North, said today that Player, from South Africa, would spend minimum of one week a year here.

title: Choosing Transit Sides
description: Whose side is the State of New York on, that of the metropolitan straphanger who desperately needs better mass transit systems or that of the Port Authority which resists any involvement in providing them? The answer seems to be that the state is on both sides of the issue at the same time.

title: Dentzer Named Chief for C.C.S.
description: The New York Stock Exchange has named William T. Den tzer Jr., former New York State Superintendent of Banks, as chairman and chief executive officer of the Central Certificate Service, Inc., effective tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Daley Turns In His Police Badge, but Keeps Gun
description: Robert Daley, who formally stepped down yesterday after a year as Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's chief spokesman, said the Commissioner felt hated by some policemen and wished that weren't the case.

title: Marriott Unit Accused
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused a subsidiary of the Marriott Corporation of violating registration provisions of the Federal securities law.

title: U.S.SOVIETACCORD DUE TO MAKE JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The White House said today that the space accord between the Soviet Union and the United States, signed during President Nixon's just completed visit to Moscow, would create about 4,400 new jobs in California's aerospace industry and preserve 1,500 jobs in Florida and Alabama.

title: Connor Is Defeated in Bid For Reelection in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 Eugene (Bull) Connor, who was police commissioner in Birmingham during the civil rights demonstrations of the early nineteensixties, was defeated today in his race for reelection as president of the Alabama Public Service Commission.

title: C.A.B. Wins an Injunction Curtailing British Charter Airline's Operations
description: The United States for the firse time won a court injunctionl yesterday to curb flights of a foreign airline. The Government said the action would go far in curbing illegal charter flights to Europe.

title: Vermont Is Upheld On Driver Solvency By a Federal Court
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 30 (AP)A threejudge Federal panel has upheld the constitutionality of a state law that requires a person convicted of certain motor vehicle crimes to post proof of financial responsibility before his right to drive is reinstated.

title: A Memorial to Editor
description: ATLANTA, May 30 (UPI) A perpetual flame was ignited In front of the Atlanta Journal and Constitution building today in memory of its late editor and publisher Ralph E. McGill. The Shining Light Award to Mr. McGill, who died in 1969, was presented by WSB radio and the Atlanta Gas Light Company. It is given in recognition of Georgians whose lives contributed to humanity.

title: Stock Exchange Chooses Envoy To Sweden, a Black, as Director
description: Jerome H. Holland, United States Ambassador to Sweden and former president of the Hampton Institute in Virginia, has been chosen to become the first black director of the New York Stock Exchange in its 180year history.

title: Bernstein Def ends His Mass in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Leonard Bernstein faced the National Press club here today to defend and comment on his controversial Mass.

title: EL PASO CO. BUYING MORE ALGERIAN GAS
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that it has contracted to buY additional quantities of liquefied natural gas (LNG) over a 25year period from Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil and gas company.

title: High Court Rules On a Patent Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) In a 5to4 decision, the Supreme Court ruled today that a New Orleans company may sell abroad machines that it cannot distribute in the United States without violating patent laws.

title: Head in the Sand
description: The posture is always the same. Whether the criticism has come from within the municipal government (as did when former Deputy Mayor Costello reported on Sanitation Department failings), from outside the municipal government (as it has in repeated state audits) from wholly private civic groups and others, the administration at City Hall has seemed intent on keeping its head in the sand. Its reaction to criticism, however nonpartisan, is invariably one of outrage.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: UMC Industries Inc. yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a secondary offering of 2, 449,053 common shares for sale through White Weld & Co. and Salomon MCorp., Overseas International Corp., a unit of Banque de Paris et des PaysBas SA is selling all of its 2.394,953 shares, representing 47 per cent of the 15,291,530 shares of UMC Industries now outstanding. UMC Industries, traded on the New New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at 26, down .

title: At Brooks Brothers Sales Keep Pace With Fashion
description: How has Brooks Brothersthe home of the threebutton suit and the buttondown shirtbeen doing since the fashion revolution hit the men's wear industry?

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President flew from Kiev, U.S.S.R., to Teheran, Iran.

title: PRICE FOR GOLD RISES TO RECORD
description: LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) The London freemarket price of gold rose by $1.80 an ounce today and tonight transactions were being made at a record of $59.75 an ounce.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISMonarchy is the most ancient form of government still in use although, as practiced in the West, it is but an atavistic symbol of human continuity. Yet whether as observed in Europe where sovereigns only reign or in Asia or Africa where they so often rule, the profession of kingship has one cardinal rule: It is lifetime job.

title: LAZARD FRERES SUED BY EDWARD GILBERT
description: Edward M. Gilbert, who was convicted of illegally withdrawing about $2million from the E. L. Bruce Company in 1962, when he headed the concern, says the investmentbanking concern of Lazar Freres & Co, caused him to take such action.

title: AL GERHEAUSER
description: JOPLIN, Mo., May 30 (AP)Al Gerheauser, a former major league pitcher, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at a Springfield hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Fund Shareholder Who Rebought in 15 Days Need Not Pay Fee
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission held today that a mutual fund shareholder who sold his shares and then bought shares from the same fund within 15 days did not need to pay a sales charge on the purchase.

title: OneYear Moratorium On New OTB Units
description: ALBANY, May 30  Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill imposing a oneyear moratorium on the approval of new offtrack betting corporations in the state, his office announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MGOVERN TO ASK 2 RIVALS TO YIELD
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 Senator George McGovern, anticipating victory in next week's California primary, is drafting plans to try to persuade Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and Edmund S. Muskie to withdraw from the Presidential race before the Democratic National Convention meets in July.

title: Simmons Option: A Baseball First
description: Ted Simmons, the St. Louis Cardinal catcher, is making baseball history this season by playing without a new contract for the 1972 season. According to the records of the Commissioner of Baseball who checks on all contracts, this is the first time a player is actually particpating in championship games under the reserve option clause of his previous year's contract. The significance of the case is this: It has been established in basketball and football that a man can play out his option and, at the end of that season, be legally free to sign with another club. But this has not been tested in baseball for more than half a century, except indirectly in a complicated fashion wtih respect to the Mexican League right after World War H.

title: Suit Accuses Firm of Bias
description: United States District Judge John M. Cannella reserved decision here yesterday in a suit by James E. Cofield Jr. against Goldman, Sachs & Co., after lawyers submitted papers. Mr. Cofield seeks to enjoin the investment banking concern from alleged job discrimination against blacks. He is seeking more than $1million in damages.

title: Watson Is Player of Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (AP) Bob Watson, a Houston Astro outfielder, was named today as the National.League's player of the week for the period of May 22 through last Sunday.

title: Sales Here in May Lifted by Buying of Summer Apparel
description: Early consumer buying of summer apparel and accessories, aided by a strong promotional push by stores, spurred retail sales in the four weeks ended last Saturday and gave six of New York's largest department stores their best monthly gains this year over the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Roundup: Reds Turn on Their Power
description: The Cincinnati Reds looked for one night something like the Big Red Machine that won the 1970 National League pennant on power.

title: Landi Named to Oversee Efficient Role for Police
description: Dr. Dale M. Landi, a former assistant director of the city's Budget Bureau, was appointed yesterday to a $32,000ayear Police Department position to encourage the efficient use of manpower.

title: CITY POLICE ADOPT 72 MASTER PLAN
description: The Police Department has adopted a master plan that, if fully carried out. will mean extensive changes in the pumber of policemen assigned ti each precinct, in the ways in which the policemen pr:% eat crime and in who is permitted to become a patrolman.

title: Nylon for Carpets Increased in Price
description: Helped by a strong demand situation, two major producers announced yesterday they were raising prices on a type of nylon used principally by the carpet industry. Prices had declined over the last 18 months.

title: NIGH COURT SAYS RELIEF CAN VARY WITH RECIPIENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Supreme Court ruled today that states did not violate the Constitution or the Federal Social Security Act when they granted lower benefits for child welfare, whose recipients are predominantly black and Spanishspeaking, than to programs with recipients who are mostly white.

title: College Division Nines Open Title Tournament on Friday
description: KANSAS CITY, May 30 (UPI) The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today the schedule for the 1972 College Division baseball championships. The games will be played next Friday through Monday in Springfield, Ill.

title: Rodeo Cowboys Fragile World
description: PUEBLO WEST, Colo. For all the maleness, the sense of physical power, the recklessness of climbing aboard an explosive animal and riding him. the shrugging off of injuries, a rodeo cowboy's world seems a fragile one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Job to Newark Man
description: Joseph Chodes, a Newark lawyer, has been named a judge on the staff of the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission and assigned to the New York City office, Robert D. Moran, commission chairman, has announced in Washington, D. C. Judges of the review commission, an independent agency of the Federal Government, adjudicate contested enforcement actions initiated, by the Department of Labor.

title: 4 Guards Hurt in Passaic Jail Revolt
description: PATERSON, N.J., May 30Six inmates from the maximumsecurity block at the Passaic County Jail today seized seven hostages, including the warden and a nurse, and held control of the cellblock for just under three hours.

title: House Votes to Revive AntiSubversive Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 30, (AP)The House shouted down an attempt to scrap the Subversive Activities Control Board today, and then voted, 226 to 105, to empower the President to revitalize the panel with new work undez a new name.

title: 15 SANITATIONMEN LOSE U.S. APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by 15 former New York City sanitation workers who were discharged for refusing to testify at fraud investigation.

title: Dr. Asher Winkelstein, 78, Gastroenterologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Asher Winkelstein, al gastroenterologist and clinical professor emeritus of medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died yesterday at his home, 40 East 84th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: HAROLD W. BULGER
description: PORTLAND, Me., May 30Harold W. Bulger, retired city circulation sales manager of the Gannett Publishing Company's three Portland newspapers, The Express, PressHerald and Maine Sunday Telegram, died inl his home here yesterday. He, was 71 years old.

title: Bridge: Strong Finish Gives Roth Unit Victory in Swiss Mixed Teams
description: A strong lastround finish on Monday gave a Swiss mixed team victory in the Eastern Regional Championships to Alvin Roth, Gene Neiger, John and Judi Solodar all of New York, and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J. In a field of 102 teams they were placed fourth before the final match, but a 17to3 victory permitted them to finish one victory point ahead of Jay Wendt's team, which was held to a 1010 tie.

title: Candid Catherine Triumphs
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., May 30 Candid Catherine showed off before an openingday crowd at Monmouth Park today, winning the $29,025 Miss Woodford Stakes while her owner and her trainer were absent and her jockey wore borrowed silks.

title: Underground Paper Quits
description: BALTIMORE, May 30 (UPI)The editor of Harry announced today that the weekly underground newspaper was going out of business after two and onehalf years of publication. The enthusiasm for Harry is dead. said the editor, Thomas V, D'Antoni. T think the time, I for this kind of paper is over.

title: 2 PATROLMEN SHOT EXPANTHER SOUGHT
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Wednesday, May 31Two policemen trying to disband a group of loiterers were shot late last night on Stratford Avenue on the east side of this industrial city.

title: Burundi Radio Puts Massacre's Toll at 50,000
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 30 (AP)  The Government radio in Burundi reported today that at least 50,000 people had been killed there since an abortive coup d'etat a month ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Journalists? Innovators.
description: TUCSON, Ariz.When you cease to be a news editor and become a fulltime reader for your own pleasure you start questioning some of the rigidities of your former craft. You wonder why a news story can't tell you what happened with the informality, grace and wit of an articulate friend talking at lunch; why the characters in the news don't come to life for you the way characters do in good novels; why so few reporters let you know by even a word or phrase that they were there when it happened. You wonder why there has to be one writing style for newsoften thirdperson, standoffish, cold and dulland another style for fictionwarm with human juices, readable, rewarding and memorable. Instead of standing close to the people and events we write about we lean away and, perhaps, some of our readers lean away too

title: AIR QUALITY RULE IS SET FOR STATES
description: WASHINGTON, May 30A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Government could not approve a state plan for cleaning up its air that permitted significant deterioration in areas where the air quality is now superior to Federal standards.

title: U.S. SEEKS REFUND IN UNION PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON. May 30The Cost of Living Council announced today the Government's first lawsuit aimed at forcing members of a labor union to make restitution to their employer of wages received since last December in excess of the limits set by the Pay Board.

title: CORPORATE BONDS ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: The corporate bond market, happy over the prospect of light volume of new financing, moved fairly eagerly yesterday toward higher prices and lower longterm interest rates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Blacks Vie for Rodino's Seat in Newark Race
description: NEWARK, May 30  The Democratic primary campaign in the newly reapportioned 10th Congressional District has not been gentlemanly.

title: Lost Innocence Theme at Royal Ballet
description: Adolescence, especially its traumas, is a recurrent theme in Kenneth MacMillan's dramatic ballets.

title: Agency Decides Not to Wait for Congress to Resolve Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Securities and Exchange Commission, in what seems certain to be only the opening move in a long legal battle, formally requested all the nation's stock exchanges today to adopt a rule barring what is known as institutional membership.

title: ISRAELIS AROUSED BY LAWYERS FEES
description: JERUSALEM, May 30 Israelis who have long prided themselves on building an egalitarian society were jolted this last week by disclosures of the high pay scales of lawyers and other professional men in an economy that is supposedly operating close to austerity conditions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: CHILE AUTHORIZES PFIZER TAKEOVER
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 (UPI)  The Government authorized a Health Ministry official today to take control of the Chilean subsidiary of the New Yorkbased Pfizer Company, with the aid of the police if necessary.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS SUFFER SETBACK
description: The kingpin glamour stocks took it on the chin yesterday as profit taking attacked this select sector of the market with force.

title: FAMILY ARGUMENT RESULTS IN ARSON
description: I was so mad I decided to burn the house down that lived in for 20 years and had finally paid for, the police quoted the woman. Mrs. Anna Marie Turner, 38, as saying.

title: 20 Dead in Haitian Floods
description: PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, May 30 (AP)Some 20 persons drowned in floods that swept the Haitian south coast last week, the United States Embassy reported today.

title: 7,200 TO BE CALLED FOR DRAFT THIS JULY
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) The Selective Service will draft men with lottery numbers up to 50 to meet a call for 7,200 draftees during July, it was announced today.

title: Explosion in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 30Belfast leaders of the Provisional I.R.A. made no comment today on the cease fire by the Officials, but two big explosions were set off that damaged a bottling plant and a laundry.

title: Golf Stars Set Marks For Amateurs'
description: CLEVELAND, May 30 (UPI) A foursome of professional golfers today set target scores for amateurs in the 20th annual National Golf Day competition at the Canterbury Golf Club in suburban Beachwood.

title: RESERVE REVISES MARGIN PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The Federal Reserve Board issued a revised and liberalized proposed rule today exempting from margin rules stockbrokers who take positions in stock.

title: Advertising:
description: According to a usually reliable source, merger discussions are going on between the Interpublic Group of Companies and CampbellEwald.

title: COLUMBIA TO CITE 3 FOR AID TO RELIGION
description: Columbia University will hold a convocation today to honor Leslie Lester, Gerard Oestreicher and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger for their contributions to the quality of religiouscultural life at the university.

title: McClellan in Slim Lead; RunOff Appears Likely
Plot to Defraud Air Force Laid to General Dynamics
description: WASHINGTON. May 30The General Dynamic Corporation and four present or former employes were charged today with conspiracy to defrauds the Air Force by passing on $300.000 worth of costs for de fective parts on the F111 fighterbomber.

title: Man With an Artificial Kidney Graduates From Medical School
description: When 28yearold Peter Lundin received his medical degree from Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday, he looked much like the other 297 graduating physicians. But there was a differenceMr. Lundin has an artifical kidney.

title: Cut Said to Be 44 Per Cent
description: VIENNA, May 30 (UPI)Secretary General Pachachi of the O.P.E.C. said the company had cut its production by 44 per cent.

title: Books of The Times
description: Long long ago... back in the mild Miocene, there was a generalized vegetarian prehominid hairy ape. She had not yet developed the highpowered brain which today distinguishes woman from all other species. With these words, Oxfordeducated Elaine Morgan begins her surprising version of how the human species really evolved. And with thousands more, she mounts a witty but determined assault on the traditional view that the story of Man is the story of men, and forget the women and children.

title: Majority for McGovern At Alaska Convention
City Disputes State On Report Charging Waste of Job Time
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton denied yesterday the contention of state auditors that sizable budget savings could be made if city workers ended allegal widespread timewasting on the job.

title: Hilbert Schenck, Director Of Paper Concern, Is Dead
description: HYANNIS PORT, Mass., May 30Hilbert Van N. Schenck, director of the Great Northern I Paper Company, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Inquiry Ordered on Charges Of F.B.I.Conspiracy Links
description: SEATTLE, May 30 (AP)A Federal grand jury was ordered today to investigate a selfstyled informant's charges that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a United States Attorney were involved in illegal conspiracies to obstruct justice.

title: Bulgaria Said to Enter Computer Age
description: SOFIA. Bulgaria, May 24,An Eastern European diplomat, sipping a drink before lunch on the balcony of one of Sofia's modern apartment houses, said somewhat absently:

title: Dr. Stephen Nagy, Headed Material Sciences at M.I.T.
description: BELMONT, Mass., May 30 (AP)Dr. Stephen M. Nagy, a microanalyst credited with many contributions to atomic energy, died yesterday at his summer home at Hampstead, N. H. He was 61 years old.

title: Jazzmen From U. of Utah Spice Kennedy Center's College Fete
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The University of Utah last night dominated the final evening of the twoday American College Jazz Festival at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: MOSCOW PUBLISHES U.S.SOVIET ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, May 30 (APMoscow's major newspapers published the text today of the statement on AmericanSoviet relations signed yesterday by President Nixon and the Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Executive Changes
description: Philip S. Sassower has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Bates Manufacturing Company, Maine's largest textile producer.

title: Notes on People
description: Pope Paul VI seemed to be saying that reports that he would retire at the age of 75 in September were exaggerated. Amid speculation around the Vatican that he would become the first Pontiff in modern history to relinquish the Papacy before death, the Pope said: It Is neither easy nor pleasant to shoulder certain responsibilities and certain burdens.

title: North Korean Leader Bids U. S. Leave the South as Step to Peace
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 26Premier Kim 11 Sung says North Korea still considers itself to be in a state of technical ceasefire, but he expressed the hope that relations with the United States might be eased if it withdrew its forces from South Korea.

title: 7 Honorary Degrees Awarded At City College Commencement
description: City College, which has rarely awarded an honorary degree, gave seven of them at last night's commencement in Lewisohn Stadium, along with 4,149 undergraduate and graduate degrees.

title: Red Smith
description: Thomas David Henrich was lunching with friends Harry M's when somebody asked how old Joe McCarthy would be now. That's Joseph Vincent McCarthy, who managed the Yankees when young Tommy Henrich came New York away back in the days when the Yankees were winning championships. Give me a minute and I'll tell you, Henrich said.

title: Zoo Prohibits Furs on People
description: ST. ALBANS, England (UPI)Women who want to see the tigers, leopards and cheetahs of the St. Albans Zoo will have to check their tiger, leopard and cheetah fur coats, gloves and handbags with the turnstile attendant.

title: Chrysler Is Recalling AU Plymouth Crickets
description: DETROIT, May 30 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling all subcompact Plymouth Crickets sold in the United States since the model was introduced in January, 1971.

title: Soviet TV: Movies, News, Serials and Then Some
description: MOSCOW, May 30On a recent uneventful demonstration ride in a police patrol car through a quiet Moscow neighborhood, a police official sought to explain why there were so few people in the streets.

title: Donohue in Rex Mays Race
description: MILWAUKEE, May 30 (AP)Four Indianapolis 500 champions, including Mark Donohue, the 1972 winner, entered next Sunday's 140mile Rex Mays speedway car race at the Wisconsin State Fairgrounds. Al and Bobby Unser and Mario Andretti are the other former Indy winners entered.

title: Senate Votes Regulation of Hazardous Chemicals, 770
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The Senate unanimously passed today legislation establishing) Federal regulation over the use) of potentially hazardous chemical substances, such as mecury and lead, in consumer products. The vote was 77 to 0.

title: Israeli Leaders Detect a Gain On Mideast in Moscow Talks
description: JERUSALEM, May 30 Israel's leaders expressed satisfaction today at the outcome of President Nixon's talks in Moscow as they affect the. Middle East.

title: Jersey Tax Reform Denounced By State Labor Body as Faulty
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 30 (AP) The 750,000member State, A.F. of L. and C.I.O. rejected Gov. William T. Cahill's tax reform package today.

title: Market Place: Paying Analysts On Performance
description: It has often been suggested that one of the great weaknesses in the Wall Street system is that brokers are rewarded for their sales skill and not their skill in picking winning stocks.

title: Excerpts From Interview With North Korean Premier on Policy Toward the U.S.
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 26Following are excerpts front, an interview conducted with Premier Kim 11 Sung through, an official interpreter by Harrison, E. Salisbury and John M. Lee of The New York Times:

title: MRS.K1NG REACHES FRENCH SEMIFINAL
description: PARIS, May 30Billie Jean King dropped into the semifinals of the $100,000 French open tennis tournament, the only major event she has failed to win, with a 61, 63 victory over Virginia Wade of England in just 56 minutes today.

title: Ellsberg Hearing Delayed
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 (UPI) A final pretrial hearing in the Pentagon papers case involving Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. has been put over until next Monday. The delay was granted to give attorneys more time to prepare the case. The two men arc under an indictment charging them with illegal possession and disposition of Government documents.

title: Elevator With 18 Falls
description: HOUSTON, May 30 (UPI) Eighteen convention delegates fell almost 15 floors in a hotel elevator today and were trapped for almost an hour before they were rescued. No one was seriously hurt. They were members of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes Union.

title: Flag on Pants Not a Crime
description: BOSTON, May 30 (UPI)It is no crime to wear a United States flag sewed to the seat of your pants, a Federal judge ruled today. District Judge Levin Campbell said there was such widespread use of the flag on cars, bumpers, jackets, sweaters, coats and elsewhere that it could not be considered a crime to wear it on pants. He ordered the release of Valerie Goguen, 22 years old, of Leominster. Mass., who was arrested in 1970 for having flag sewn to the seat of his pants.

title: Boycott Over Leadership Cuts P.S. 113 Attendance
description: A parent boycott kept most pupils and teachers out of Public School 113, at 240 West 113th. Street, yesterday.

title: Castro in Budapest
description: BUDAPEST, May 30Premier Fidel Castro arrived from Rumania today for an official visit at the invitation of the Communist party leader, Janos kadar. Mr. Castro is on a 10nation tour of North Africa and Eastern Europe, which ends in Moscow in June.

title: What's Gone Wrong With the Tomato?
description: Where, oh where are the tomatoes of yesteryear, the ones that were flame red on the top and lime green on the bottom, the ones that were misshapen, cracked, diseaseprone, the ones that ripened unevenly, spoiled quickly, didn't pack neatlyand tasted, some people insist, better than anything you c:..a buy today?

title: Acquitted Navy Chaplain Will Study at Princeton
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 30 (AP)  Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain acquitted by a courtmartial of misconduct in adultery charges, has received an assignment to study for the next year at Princeton University's School of Theology.
